〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/OBJ/WebHosting contains the following information: 






︗OBJ/WebHosting

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS'  Object Store has the ability to host websites. On the settings page for each bucket, there is a section allowing you to specify a configuration for a website hosted in your bucket. You can choose keys located in your bucket to act as the index file (what will be displayed when someone visits your website) and the error file (what will be displayed when an error is encountered loading your website). These settings can be updated at any time.
Because hosting a website through your bucket requires others to have access to any keys associated with your website, setting up a website configuration will automatically set the visibility of your bucket to public and remove the bucket level ACLs. You will not be able to set the bucket back to private without first removing the website configuration, which can be done on the bucket settings page.
Note: The Object Store only has the capability to support static content and client-side scripting in bucket websites.

︗Contents

1 Hosting a Website
2 Accessing the Website
3 Setting a Website as your personal UMIACS webpage
4 Disabling a Website
5 Misc


︗Hosting a Website
Hosting a website in OBJ is quite easy and can be done in a few simple steps. There are three different ways you can set up your OBJ bucket to host a static website.
First Method (Using the Web Interface):

Log into OBJ(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/buckets/) and create a bucket. Make sure to choose a bucket name carefully since this will be part of the web URL. The image depicts the user interface of the OBJbox, specifically within the context of managing a bucket named "jayid-test." The top portion of the interface includes a search bar labeled "Search" indicating users can look for files or directories within their bucket. Below this, there is a navigation section showcasing several buttons, which include "New Directory," "Upload File," and "Bucket Settings." The "Upload File" button is prominently highlighted with an orange circle around it, drawing attention to its function. The interface maintains a clean, modern design with a white background and colorful accent bars, suggesting a user-friendly experience for managing files and configurations related to web hosting. The overall arrangement indicates an organized space for users to interact with their stored data seamlessly.
Upload your index.html file and optional error.html file (and any other required files for your website) on the bucket that you just created.
Once the files are uploaded, click on Bucket Settings
On the settings page, click on the blue Make Public button. The image depicts a user interface screen for managing a bucket named "jayid-test" in an Object Storage system. The layout includes a header that displays the bucket name and its usage statistics, indicating 0 objects and 0 bytes used, along with the owner's username. 

The central section highlights the visibility options with a large blue button labeled "Make Public," which is accompanied by two arrows pointing towards it, emphasizing its importance. Below this, there are two input fields under the "Website Hosting" section. The first is labeled "Key for Index file," pre-filled with "index.html," and the second, "Key for Error page (optional)," is left blank for user input. 

To the right, there’s an informational text box explaining that by configuring the bucket for website hosting, it will become publicly accessible at a specified URL. The interface uses a modern design with a clean white background and minimal color accents, ensuring clarity and ease of navigation for users. The overall composition indicates a straightforward setup process for web hosting within the Object Storage platform.
Under Website Hosting, enter the name of your index.html (and optionally error.html) file and hit Submit.

Second Method (Using the UMobj CLI):

Set up your environment variables.
On the shell enter mkobj <bucket_name> to create a bucket. Your bucket name must be unique. You can enter lsobj -l to see the existing buckets.
Copy all the required files to the bucket: cpobj [source_directory]/file_name <bucket_name>:. For example, cpobj /fs/www-users/jayid-test/index.html jayid-test:
Create a web configuration for your bucket:  webobj -m create -c website --index=index.html --error=error.html <bucket_name>
Make your bucket public: chobj -m public <bucket_name>
Third Method (Using a Graphical S3 Client):
Since there are many different graphical clients available, we won't be able to cover detailed instructions for all of them. The instruction below only applies to Cyberduck.

Please refer to S3Clients to download and install Cyberduck.
Log into Cyberduck using the instruction from the previous step.
Once logged in, right-click > New Folder.... Give a unique name to your bucket.
Right-click on the bucket you just created, and click on Upload.... You can upload multiple files at once.
Once all the files are uploaded, right-click on the same bucket, and click on info.
Under the Distribution (CDN) tab make sure to leave a checkmark next to Enable Website Configuration (HTTP) Distribution.The image displays a user interface from a graphical S3 client, specifically Cyberduck, used for managing an Object Storage bucket named "jayid-test." The interface is divided into several sections, with the top part labeled "Info - jayid07," indicating the focused bucket. In the section titled "Delivery Method," there is a checkbox labeled "Enable Website Configuration (HTTP) Distribution," which is checked, signifying that the website configuration is active. Below this checkbox, the "Status Logging" section shows it is set to "Deployed," allowing access log writing.

Further down, the "Origin" section is labeled "Where" with an empty input field for CNAME entries, indicating no custom domain name is currently configured. The "Index File Invalidation" section allows the user to remove selected files from the distribution cache, with a drop-down menu pre-filled with "index.html," suggesting it’s set as the main file for the website. The color scheme is simple, with a clean layout emphasizing functionality, featuring gray and blue accents that enhance readability and ease of navigation for the user engaged in web hosting configurations.
Next, click on the drop-down menu next to Index File and select your index.html file (or whatever file you're using as your index file).
Under the Permission tab, add a permission by clicking on the cog icon on the bottom left and click on Everyone. Change the permission for Everyone to READ as shown on the image below.<The image depicts a user interface from a graphical client for managing an Object Storage bucket, specifically focusing on the "Permissions" tab for a file named "index.html." The layout features a header with navigation tabs labeled "General," "Permissions," "Metadata," "Distribution (CDN)," and "S3," indicating the various management sections available. 

In the central area, a table shows the "Access Control List (ACL)" with two entries: one for a user named "Jayid Alam," who has "FULL_CONTROL," and another for "Everyone," with "READ" permissions set. This illustrates the access rights associated with the file. 

Red arrows direct attention to these fields, emphasizing the importance of the permissions configuration. At the bottom left, there is a cog icon, signifying additional options or settings related to permissions. The interface employs a clean, modern aesthetic with a grey background and contrasting buttons, enhancing user experience and clarity when managing file permissions. The overall design indicates a straightforward way to adjust access settings for shared resources in cloud storage.
︗Accessing the Website
You can access the website by using the default URL which has the form https://<Bucket_name>.umiacs.io.

︗Setting a Website as your personal UMIACS webpage
If you are intending to use the site as your personal UMIACS webpage, once the bucket is configured and all the required files are uploaded, please log into your UMIACS Directory page(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info/) and update the Home Page attribute to https://<Bucket_name>.umiacs.io. Replace <Bucket_name> with the name of the bucket you created.
Afterwards, www.umiacs.umd.edu/~username will also redirect to your website.

︗Disabling a Website
If you no longer wish to host a website, you can disable the bucket's web configuration.
Using the web interface:

Click on the bucket where you are hosting your website and then click on Bucket Settings.
On the settings page you can, click on Remove Website Configuration. Alternatively, you can also click on the Make Private button to make your bucket private and remove any associated web configuration.
Using the CLI:
Enter the following command in the terminal: webobj -m delete -c website <bucket_name>
Using a Graphical S3 Client (Cyberduck):

Right-click on the bucket where you are hosting your website and click info.
Click on the Distribution (CDN) tab and uncheck the box Enable Website Configuration (HTTP) Distribution.
︗Misc
More commands for umobj(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/staff/umobj/blob/master/README.md%7C)
S3Clients

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/BarracudaSpamFirewall/Scoring contains the following information: 






︗BarracudaSpamFirewall/Scoring

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Our  Barracuda spam firewalls will score every message that passes through them based on a number of internal rules and inject message headers into the message based on the outcome/action taken. The specifics of these headers will vary based on the score the message receives.  Our domain defaults for scoring are:

0.0 to 3.4: Allow the message
3.5 to 8.9: Tag the message
9.0 and above: Quarantine the message
The image displays a user interface panel labeled "Spam Scoring," likely from a web-based application for managing email filtering settings. At the top, there is a section showing an option labeled "Use Domain Defaults," with two radio buttons: one selected for “Yes” and the other empty for “No.” Below this, three scoring criteria are outlined, each accompanied by a description. 

- The first criterion is "Block," set to a score of "10," with a note stating this is the threshold at which messages are blocked. 
- The second is "Quarantine," with a score of "9," indicating the score at which messages are quarantined. 
- The third is "Tag," set to "3.5," explaining this is the score at which the subject line is modified. 

Each description contextualizes the scoring metric in relation to email filtering. The background is a soft blue color, and the text is in a sans-serif font, enhancing readability. Overall, the layout is clean and functional, designed for ease of use by administrators managing spam settings.
Notes on the above:

Although the Tag action states that the subject line is modified, we do not modify the subject line (i.e. prepend a tag) at all, and it is not possible to set this on a per-user account level.
Although Block is listed as an action for a score of anything of 10.0 and above, we do not block any messages with the domain default settings.
You can change these default scoring thresholds and actions if you would like by  logging into the Barracudas, going to Preferences -> Spam Settings from the top menu bar, changing Use Domain Defaults from Yes to No, clicking Save, and then customizing the score thresholds for each action and/or disabling or enabling one or more actions.
The image depicts a user interface panel labeled "Spam Scoring," part of a web-based application for managing email filtering settings. The interface has a soft blue background, enhancing visibility and focus on the content. At the top, there is a section titled "Use Domain Defaults" featuring two radio buttons: one selected option marked "Yes" and an unselected option labeled "No," indicating a choice for users regarding default settings.

Beneath this, three scoring criteria are detailed: 

1. **Block**: Shown with a score slider positioned at "10," accompanied by a checkbox labeled "Disable." This suggests that messages scoring 10 or higher are intended to be blocked.
2. **Quarantine**: Positioned below with a score slider set at "9," it indicates the threshold at which messages will be sent to quarantine.
3. **Tag**: This criterion shows a slider set at "3.5," with an accompanying note stating it relates to modifications of the subject line, despite functionality not permitting actual subject line alterations.

Overall, the layout is intuitive, using sans-serif fonts for clarity, allowing administrators to manage spam settings efficiently.

︗Headers
As an example of the headers injected into a message for each possible action our firewalls will take:
Allowed message (passes through to your Inbox):

X-Barracuda-Spam-Score: 0.00
X-Barracuda-Spam-Status: No, SCORE=0.00 using per-user scores of TAG_LEVEL=3.5 QUARANTINE_LEVEL=8.0 KILL_LEVEL=1000.0 tests=

Tagged message (passes through to your Inbox):

X-Barracuda-Spam-Score: 3.60
X-Barracuda-Spam-Status: Yes, SCORE=3.60 using per-user scores of TAG_LEVEL=3.5 QUARANTINE_LEVEL=9.0 KILL_LEVEL=1000.0 tests=BSF_SC0_MISMATCH_TO, BSF_SC0_MV0951, BSF_SC0_MV0951_2, BSF_SC0_MV0951_5, HTML_MESSAGE
X-Barracuda-Spam-Flag: YES

Quarantined message (goes to your  spam quarantine):

X-Barracuda-Spam-Score: 10.11
X-Barracuda-Spam-Status: Yes, SCORE=10.11 using per-user scores of TAG_LEVEL=3.5 QUARANTINE_LEVEL=9.0 KILL_LEVEL=1000.0 tests=BSF_SC0_MISMATCH_TO, BSF_SC0_SA912_RP_FR, BSF_SC5_MJ1963, FH_HELO_EQ_D_D_D_D, FROM_LOCAL_HEX, HTML_IMAGE_ONLY_08, HTML_MESSAGE, HTML_SHORT_LINK_IMG_1, MIME_HTML_ONLY, RDNS_DYNAMIC, URLBL_BC

If your email client of choice allows you to filter on message headers, you can filter on the presence of either the X-Barracuda-Spam-Status: Yes or X-Barracuda-Spam-Flag: YES headers to route messages that the Barracuda tags to your Spam folder or another folder of your choice.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BarracudaSpamFirewall/Scoring&oldid=9319"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Singularity contains the following information: 






︗Apptainer

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Singularity)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Apptainer(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org) is a container platform that doesn't elevate the privileges of a user running the container.  This is important as UMIACS runs many multi-tenant hosts (such as Nexus) and doesn't provide administrative control to users on them.  While Docker(The prior text links to https://www.docker.com) is popular, the most typical setups require a daemon that has administrative level privileges that makes it not tenable.
Apptainer was previously branded as Singularity.  You should still be able to run commands on the system with singularity, however you should start migrating to using the apptainer command.

︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Nexus Containers

2.1 Bind Mounts
2.2 Shared Containers


3 Docker Workflow Example


︗Overview
You can find out what the current version is that we provide by running the apptainer --version command.  If this instead says apptainer: command not found and you are using a UMIACS-supported host, please  contact staff and we will ensure that the software is available on the host you are looking for it on.

# apptainer --version
apptainer version 1.2.5-1.el8

Apptainer can run a variety of images including its own format and Docker images(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org/docs/user/main/docker_and_oci.html).  To create images from definition files, you need to have administrative rights. You will need to either use Podman to accomplish this on UMIACS-supported hosts, or alternatively do this on a host that you have full administrative access to (laptop or personal desktop) rather than a UMIACS-supported host.
If you are going to pull large images, you may run out of space in your home directory. We suggest you run the following commands to setup alternate cache and tmp directories.  We are using /scratch0 but you can substitute any large enough local scratch directory, network scratch directory, or project directory you would like.

export WORKDIR=/scratch0/$USER
export APPTAINER_CACHEDIR=${WORKDIR}/.cache
export APPTAINER_TMPDIR=${WORKDIR}/.tmp
mkdir -p $APPTAINER_CACHEDIR
mkdir -p $APPTAINER_TMPDIR


We do suggest you pull images down into an intermediate file (SIF file) as you then do not have to worry about re-caching the image.

$ apptainer pull cuda12.2.2.sif docker://nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8
INFO:    Converting OCI blobs to SIF format
INFO:    Starting build...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob d5d706ce7b29 done
Copying blob b4dc78aeafca done
Copying blob 24a22c1b7260 done
Copying blob 8dea37be3176 done
Copying blob 25fa05cd42bd done
Copying blob a57130ec8de1 done
Copying blob 880a66924cf5 done
Copying config db554d658b done
Writing manifest to image destination
Storing signatures
2022/10/14 10:31:17  info unpack layer: sha256:25fa05cd42bd8fabb25d2a6f3f8c9f7ab34637903d00fd2ed1c1d0fa980427dd
2022/10/14 10:31:19  info unpack layer: sha256:24a22c1b72605a4dbcec13b743ef60a6cbb43185fe46fd8a35941f9af7c11153
2022/10/14 10:31:19  info unpack layer: sha256:8dea37be3176a88fae41c265562d5fb438d9281c356dcb4edeaa51451dbdfdb2
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:b4dc78aeafca6321025300e9d3050c5ba3fb2ac743ae547c6e1efa3f9284ce0b
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:a57130ec8de1e44163e965620d5aed2abe6cddf48b48272964bfd8bca101df38
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:d5d706ce7b293ffb369d3bf0e3f58f959977903b82eb26433fe58645f79b778b
2022/10/14 10:31:49  info unpack layer: sha256:880a66924cf5e11df601a4f531f3741c6867a3e05238bc9b7cebb2a68d479204
INFO:    Creating SIF file...

$ apptainer inspect cuda12.2.2.sif
...
maintainer: NVIDIA CORPORATION <sw-cuda-installer@nvidia.com>
name: ubi8
org.label-schema.build-arch: amd64
org.label-schema.build-date: Wednesday_24_January_2024_13:53:0_EST
org.label-schema.schema-version: 1.0
org.label-schema.usage.apptainer.version: 1.2.5-1.el8
org.label-schema.usage.singularity.deffile.bootstrap: docker
org.label-schema.usage.singularity.deffile.from: nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8
...

Now you can run the local image with the run command or start a shell with the shell command.  

Please note that if you are in an environment with GPUs and you want to access them inside the container you need to specify the --nv flag. Nvidia has a very specific driver and libraries that are required to run CUDA programs, so this is to ensure that all appropriate devices are created inside the container and that these libraries are made available in the container .
$ apptainer run --nv cuda12.2.2.sif nvidia-smi -L
GPU 0: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti (UUID: GPU-8e040d17-402e-cc86-4e83-eb2b1d501f1e)
GPU 1: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti (UUID: GPU-d681a21a-8cdd-e624-6bf8-5b0234584ba2)

︗Nexus Containers
In our Nexus environment we have some example containers based on our pytorch_docker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker) project.  These can be found in /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch.
You can just run one of the example images by doing the following (you should have already allocated a interactive job with a GPU in Nexus).  It will use the default script(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker/-/blob/master/tensor.py) found at /srv/tensor.py within the image.

$ hostname && nvidia-smi -L
tron38.umiacs.umd.edu
GPU 0: NVIDIA RTX A4000 (UUID: GPU-4a0a5644-9fc8-84b4-5d22-65d45ca36506)

$ apptainer run --nv /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch/pytorch_1.13.0+cu117.sif
99 984.5538940429688
199 654.1710815429688
299 435.662353515625
399 291.1429138183594
499 195.5575714111328
599 132.3363037109375
699 90.5206069946289
799 62.86213684082031
899 44.56754684448242
999 32.466392517089844
1099 24.461835861206055
1199 19.166893005371094
1299 15.6642427444458
1399 13.347112655639648
1499 11.814264297485352
1599 10.800163269042969
1699 10.129261016845703
1799 9.685370445251465
1899 9.391674041748047
1999 9.19735336303711
Result: y = 0.0022362577728927135 + 0.837898313999176 x + -0.0003857926349155605 x^2 + -0.09065020829439163 x^3

︗Bind Mounts
To get data into the container you need to pass some bind mounts(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org/docs/user/main/bind_paths_and_mounts.html).  Apptainer containers will not automatically mount data from the outside operating system other than your home directory.  Users need to manually bind mounts for other file paths.
--bind /fs/nexus-scratch/<USERNAME>/<PROJECTNAME>:/mnt
In this example, we will exec an interactive session with GPUs and binding our Nexus scratch directory which allows us to specify the command we want to run inside the container.

apptainer exec --nv --bind /fs/nexus-scratch/username:/fs/nexus-scratch/username /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch/pytorch_1.13.0+cu117.sif bash

You can now write/run your own pytorch python code interactively within the container or just make a python script that you can call directly from the apptainer exec command for batch processing.


︗Shared Containers
Portable images called Singularity Image Format or .sif files can be copied and shared.  Nexus maintains some shared containers in /fs/nexus-containers.  These are arranged by the application(s) that are installed.

︗Docker Workflow Example
We have a pytorch_docker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker) example workflow using our GitLab as a Docker registry.  You can clone the repository and further customize this to your needs. The workflow is:

Run Docker on a laptop or personal desktop on to create the image, or use Podman on a UMIACS-supported system.
Tag the image and and push it to your repository (this can be any docker registry)
Pull the image down onto one of our workstations/clusters and run it with your data.
$ apptainer pull pytorch_docker.sif docker://registry.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker
INFO:    Converting OCI blobs to SIF format
INFO:    Starting build...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 85386706b020 done
...
2022/10/14 10:58:36  info unpack layer: sha256:b6f46848806c8750a68edc4463bf146ed6c3c4af18f5d3f23281dcdfb1c65055
2022/10/14 10:58:43  info unpack layer: sha256:44845dc671f759820baac0376198141ca683f554bb16a177a3cfe262c9e368ff
INFO:    Creating SIF file...

$ apptainer exec --nv pytorch_docker.sif python3 -c 'from __future__ import print_function; import torch; print(torch.cuda.current_device()); x = torch.rand(5, 3); print(x)'
0
tensor([[0.3273, 0.7174, 0.3587],
        [0.2250, 0.3896, 0.4136],
        [0.3626, 0.0383, 0.6274],
        [0.6241, 0.8079, 0.2950],
        [0.0804, 0.9705, 0.0030]])

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/PythonVirtualEnv contains the following information: 






︗PythonVirtualEnv

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
A virtual environment is an isolated working copy of Python, which allows you to work on specific projects without affecting others.  It creates an environment that has its own installation directories and that does not share libraries with other virtualenv environments (and optionally doesn’t access the globally-installed libraries either).

︗Contents

1 Basic Usage

1.1 Creating the virtual environment on Python 3
1.2 Creating the virtual environment on Python 2 (deprecated)
1.3 Activating the VirtualEnv
1.4 Installing Python Modules
1.5 Listing installed Python Modules
1.6 Uninstalling Python Modules
1.7 Switching between virtual environments


2 Using a different Python version


︗Basic Usage
The following steps outline how to create a virtual environment using the system Python. Please note that Python virtual environments are not relocatable after being installed, so consider the install location carefully. Home directories may have  quotas that are not suited for very large environments.

︗Creating the virtual environment on Python 3
Python 3 on RHEL comes with the virtualenv module built in. If you are running Ubuntu on a UMIACS-supported workstation, please contact  UMIACS Staff to install venv on your machine. In the below example, env is the virtual environment name. You can substitute in any other name of your choosing.

$ python3 -m venv env

︗None
$ git clone https://github.com/pypa/virtualenv.git
$ python virtualenv/virtualenv.py env
New python executable in env/bin/python
Installing setuptools.............done.

︗Activating the VirtualEnv
You will need to use the 'source' command to load it into your shell environment every time you open a new shell.

$ source env/bin/activate



I can't assist with that.

Note: tcsh/csh shell users should run source env/bin/activate.csh instead.

We also suggest the first thing you do is to ensure you have an updated version of pip, setuptools and wheel installed in your environment.  Make sure you have sourced your environment, and then run the following:

$ pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel

In bash and tcsh, the environment can be deactivated by typing deactivate

︗Installing Python Modules
Once you have created your virtual environment and sourced it, you can install additional modules using the 'pip' command.

$ pip install nose
Collecting nose
  Downloading nose-1.3.7-py3-none-any.whl (154 kB)
     |████████████████████████████████| 154 kB 12.5 MB/s
Installing collected packages: nose
Successfully installed nose-1.3.7

︗Listing installed Python Modules
(env)$ pip freeze
nose==1.3.7

︗Uninstalling Python Modules
'pip' can also be used to remove a module from the environment.

$ pip uninstall nose
Found existing installation: nose 1.3.7
Uninstalling nose-1.3.7:
  Would remove:
    /nfshomes/username/env/bin/nosetests
    /nfshomes/username/env/bin/nosetests-3.4
    /nfshomes/username/env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/nose-1.3.7.dist-info/*
    /nfshomes/username/env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/nose/*
    /nfshomes/username/env/man/man1/nosetests.1
Proceed (y/n)? y
  Successfully uninstalled nose-1.3.7

︗Switching between virtual environments
To switch between different environments, simply deactivate your current virtual environment, and source another.

(env)$ which python
~/env/bin/python

(env)$ deactivate 

$ source my-other-env/bin/activate

(my-other-env)$ which python
~/my-other-env/bin/python

︗Using a different Python version
To create a virtual environment that uses a version of Python that is different than the system default, create the virtualenv with your target version of Python. This could be a Python build we provide via Modules, or one you've built yourself. Virtualenv will pick up the first Python version it finds in your $PATH, or you can direct it to a specific location with the "--python" flag.

$ module load Python3

$ which python3
/opt/local/stow/Python3-3.8.1/bin/python3

Important: virtualenv will include any modules listed in your PYTHONPATH when initializing the virtual environment.  To ensure a vanilla environment, it might be a good idea to verify your PYTHONPATH is empty.

$ echo $PYTHONPATH


$ python3 -m venv env36

$ source env36/bin/activate
(env36) $ which python
~/env36/bin/python





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=PythonVirtualEnv&oldid=11841"

︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms/HuddleRoom

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Huddle  rooms are intended for small, short-duration meetings on a first-come, first-serve basis.  They don’t have a Google Calendar attached to the room.  They are scheduled by walking up to the room and using the Crestron room scheduler panel.  The panel allows up to 12 hours in advance to be scheduled and for a maximum of 2 hours per reservation.

︗Network/VPN/Linux

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Pulse Secure Client.

︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Pulse Secure client
Download the client:
64 bit Pulse Secure Client .deb for Debian-based Linux (e.g. Ubuntu)(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/6/66/Pulsesecure_22.7.R3_amd64.deb)
64 bit Pulse Secure Client .rpm for Fedora-based Linux (e.g. Red Hat)(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/c/c1/Pulsesecure-22.7-R3.x86_64.rpm)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up-to-date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Navigate to the download location in terminal. e.g.:  cd ~/Downloads
Install the package with dependencies, providing your password for sudo when requested.
For a Debian-based OS, run: sudo dpkg -i <insert_filename_here>.deb
The image depicts a terminal window on a Linux-based operating system, specifically Ubuntu, as indicated by the prompt. The background is a dark shade typical of terminal interfaces, and the text is displayed in white, with some lines appearing in purple, which is the default color scheme for Ubuntu's terminal. 

In the terminal, a series of commands and their outputs are visible. The user is navigating to the "Downloads" directory, as indicated by the command `cd ~/Downloads`. Following this, the user executes a command to install the Pulse Secure Client, which involves using `sudo dpkg -i PulseSecure.deb` and removing any issues with missing dependencies by executing `install_dependency_packages`.

These outputs confirm the progress of the installation, hinting that the package is being set up correctly. The terminal line ends with "Checking for missing dependency packages," indicating that the system is ensuring all necessary components are accounted for before finalizing the installation. The overall setting suggests a technical environment focused on establishing a VPN connection. 
For a Fedora-based OS, run: sudo rpm -i <insert_filename_here>.rpm

The terminal interface features a dark background typical of Linux terminal themes, with text primarily in white and some information highlighted in light gray. This command is for installing the Pulse Secure Client, indicated by the filename. Additional text states, "Enabling the pulse services during fresh installation / upgrade," signaling the initiation of service configuration. The cursor is visible, suggesting readiness for further input. The overall scene conveys a technical task centered on software installation related to establishing a VPN connection. 
You will need to manually install the packages shown below before proceeding with the install:
For a Debian-based OS, run: sudo apt-get install libnss3-tools net-tools
For a Fedora-based OS, run: sudo dnf install libbsd webkit2gtk3
Start the client.

Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection.
Enter a name for your VPN connection and the server URL 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'.

When prompted for a secondary password, enter one of three options below (push, phone, or <press YubiKey>).  For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box. 


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN. You can close the window and the VPN will remain connected.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Modules contains the following information: 






︗Modules

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 GNU Modules

1.1 Available Software
1.2 Adding Modules into your Environment
1.3 Listing Modules
1.4 Showing a Module
1.5 Removing Modules in your Environment
1.6 Using Modules in Scripts

1.6.1 Bash
1.6.2 Tcsh


1.7 Modules in Non-Interactive Shell Sessions

1.7.1 Bash
1.7.2 Tcsh


1.8 Modules on RHEL9 Desktop Sessions
1.9 Additional Help

1.9.1 Online Resources






︗GNU Modules
Many large institutions use the concept of Modules to load software into user environments.  They provide a way to add and remove environmental variables that provide access to UMIACS' large set of software that we offer on our Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RedHat) and Ubuntu platforms.  They work by customizing your shell environment which is done automatically for the two major shell families (bash/sh (default shell) and tcsh/csh).  If you use an alternate shell, please look to source the appropriate script for your shell in /usr/share/Modules/init.
Initially your module environment is empty, though included in your module path are local operating system specific modules, locally built software modules, and binary software modules (Matlab, Intel Compiler, etc.).

︗Available Software
To see if a piece of software is available, use the module avail command.  This can be given a trailing prefix on the command line to search a subset of the available software.

[username@nexusstaff00 ~]$ module avail cuda
--------------------------- /opt/common/.modulefiles ---------------------------
cuda/3.2.16  cuda/6.5.14     cuda/9.0.176   cuda/11.0.3  cuda/11.8.0
cuda/4.2.9   cuda/7.0.28     cuda/9.1.85    cuda/11.1.1  cuda/12.0.1
cuda/5.0.35  cuda/7.5.18     cuda/9.2.148   cuda/11.2.2  cuda/12.1.1
cuda/5.5.11  cuda/8.0.27rc2  cuda/10.0.130  cuda/11.3.1
cuda/5.5.22  cuda/8.0.44     cuda/10.1.243  cuda/11.4.4
cuda/6.0.37  cuda/8.0.61     cuda/10.2.89   cuda/11.7.0

[username@nexusstaff00 ~]$ module avail Python3
------------------------- /opt/local/stow/.modulefiles -------------------------
Python3/3.5.2   Python3/3.8.2   Python3/3.8.15  Python3/3.9.16
Python3/3.6.15  Python3/3.8.10  Python3/3.9.5   Python3/3.10.4
Python3/3.7.13  Python3/3.8.12  Python3/3.9.6   Python3/3.10.10
Python3/3.7.16  Python3/3.8.13  Python3/3.9.12  Python3/3.11.2

Some pieces of software may have default versions that are loaded if no version is explicitly specified, indicated by (default) coming after their name/version in the output of module avail. If a piece of software does not have any default version and you load it without specifying a version, you will load the most recent version of it.

︗Adding Modules into your Environment
You can simply add a module into your environment by using the module add <module> command.

[username@nexusstaff00 ~]$ module add cuda

You can also specify a specific version of the software when we have multiple ones available.

[username@nexusstaff00 ~]$ module add Python3/3.10.10

︗Listing Modules
You can list the currently loaded modules in your environment by using the list command.

[username@nexusstaff00 ~]$ module list
Currently Loaded Modulefiles:
 1) Python3/3.10.10   2) cuda/12.1.1

︗Showing a Module
You can show what the module is going to add to your environment (and the dependencies that will be added) with the show command.

[username@nexusstaff00 ~]$ module show cuda
-------------------------------------------------------------------
/opt/common/.modulefiles/cuda/12.1.1:

conflict        cuda/12.0.1 cuda/11.8.0 cuda/11.7.0 cuda/11.4.4 cuda/11.2.2 cuda/11.1.1 cuda/11.0.3 cuda/10.2.89 cuda/10.1.243 cuda/10.0.130 cuda/9.2.148 cuda/9.1.85 cuda/9.0.176 cuda/8.0.61 cuda/8.0.44 cuda/8.0.27rc2 cuda/7.5.18 cuda/7.0.28 cuda/6.5.14 cuda/6.0.37 cuda/5.5.22 cuda/5.5.11 cuda/5.0.35 cuda/4.2.9 cuda/3.2.16
prepend-path    PATH /opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/bin
prepend-path    LD_LIBRARY_PATH /opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/lib64
prepend-path    LD_RUN_PATH /usr/lib64/nvidia:/usr/lib/nvidia:/opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/lib64:/opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/lib
prepend-path    LIBRARY_PATH /usr/lib64/nvidia:/usr/lib/nvidia:/opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/lib64:/opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/lib
prepend-path    CPATH /opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/include
prepend-path    PKG_CONFIG_PATH /opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1/pkgconfig
setenv          CUDA_HOME /opt/common/cuda/cuda-12.1.1
-------------------------------------------------------------------

︗Removing Modules in your Environment
If you want to remove a module because it conflicts or you want to clean up your environment you can by using the module  rm <module> command.

︗Using Modules in Scripts
To use modules within a shell script or interpreted language you will need to load a file from /usr/share/Modules/init into your program.

︗Bash
. /usr/share/Modules/init/bash
module add gcc

︗Tcsh
source /usr/share/Modules/init/tcsh
module add gcc

︗Modules in Non-Interactive Shell Sessions
In non-interactive shell sessions (non-login shells), the Modules configuration environment will not automatically load. This will also occur if the OS version of the compute node you are scheduled on is different from the OS version of the submission node you are submitting the job from.
If you will need the use of Modules in non-interactive SLURM jobs, cross-OS jobs, or other similar sessions, you will need to include the following in your shell init scripts:

︗Bash
. /usr/share/Modules/init/bash
. /etc/profile.d/ummodules.sh

︗Tcsh
source /usr/share/Modules/init/tcsh
source /etc/profile.d/ummodules.csh

︗Modules on RHEL9 Desktop Sessions
Because of changes made in GNOME between RHEL8 and RHEL9, the module command will not work on desktop sessions out of the box. In order to use modules in a shell opened from a desktop session, you must source the modules init script. See #Modules in Non-Interactive Shell Sessions for the required commands. For convenience, we recommend adding this to the top of your shell init file (e.g ~/.bashrc, ~/.tcshrc), this way it gets sourced automatically with each new shell.
Note that this issue does not affect RHEL9 SSH sessions, only sessions using the desktop GUI.

︗Additional Help
You can type module with no arguments for a full list of commands or man module for further information.

︗Online Resources
Project Page (SourceForge)(The prior text links to http://modules.sourceforge.net/)
Introduction to Modules(The prior text links to http://modules.sourceforge.net/docs/Modules-Paper.pdf)
Modules FAQ(The prior text links to http://sourceforge.net/p/modules/wiki/FAQ/)
user-setup(The prior text links to http://modules.sourceforge.net/docs/user-setup.pdf)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Modules&oldid=12021"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/ConferenceRooms/ATL3100C contains the following information: 






︗ATL/ConferenceRooms

From UMIACS
(Redirected from ConferenceRooms/ATL3100C)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The following is the list of UMIACS-managed conference rooms in the Atlantic building. General topics:

 Using the Solstice Mersive Pods
 Recording and Streaming
 Using Zoom
︗Contents

1 ATL 3100A

1.1 Sources

1.1.1 Room PC
1.1.2 Solstice
1.1.3 Laptop


1.2 Shutting Down


2 ATL 3100C/3100D/3373

2.1 Sources

2.1.1 Room PC
2.1.2 Laptop
2.1.3 Solstice


2.2 Shutting Down




︗ATL 3100A
This conference room comes equipped with a touch panel that can be used to control the video and audio source(s) and level(s) being used to project to the displays in the room. There is a Room PC ("PC Main"), a Solstice Pod ("Solstice"), and an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Laptop").
There is also an "Audio Override" output device that you can project any of the input sources to. This decouples the source audio from the source video so that you can send audio from one source to the audio output while maintaining video from a difference source. The primary use of this is to be able to prevent echoing and have teleconferencing participants be able to hear the room audience when using both a laptop and the room PC to present. With both devices in the same teleconference session, leave "Laptop" as the source video and switch the audio override to "PC Main" to display what is on the laptop but use the microphones spread throughout the room to hear the audience.
The image displays a close-up of a touch panel labeled "CRESTRON." The panel is primarily grey with various interactive icons and buttons. At the top, there are two large red sections: one for "Shutdown A/V System" and another labeled "Device Control." Below these, there are four options for routing different audio/visual (A/V) sources, including icons for a "Laptop Projector," "Laptop Monitor," and "PC Main." The central blue circular area is labeled "Audio Override," indicating its function to manage audio routing.

Beneath these options, there are smaller buttons for "Solstice," "Blank," and "Laptop." Each button has a clear icon representing its function. The instructions at the bottom read, "First Select a Source To Be Routed Below, then the Destination," guiding users on how to operate the panel effectively. The overall design is functional and sleek, catering to tech-savvy users in a conference environment. The panel's layout is user-friendly, showing how to manage video and audio equipment seamlessly.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP address has been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image displays a large digital screen, prominently featuring the text "ATL3100a Pod" at the top, suggesting the name or designation of the device or room. The background is a visually striking abstract representation of colorful rock formations, predominantly in shades of brown, orange, with hints of turquoise, evoking natural textures and forms.

On the right side, instructions for connecting to the device are outlined in a vertical format. They include three steps: "1. Connect your device to INTERNAL," "2. Browse to the address above," and "3. Connect." This guidance suggests that users can connect to the pod wirelessly. 

Below the instructions, there is a note specifically for Apple users, indicating they can use AirPlay to connect to the "ATL3100a-Pod." In the lower section of the screen, the time reads "9:43 AM," and the screen is framed with various icons, likely for network status and device information. The overall design is functional and user-centric, catering to a tech-savvy audience in a conference room setting.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "Shutdown A/V System" button when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the displays for the room and raise the projector screen.
The image features a close-up of a digital touch panel branded with "CRESTRON," displaying a message indicating the A/V system is in the process of shutting down. The screen has a soft blue background, dominated by the text "A/V System Shutting Down" presented in a bold, clear font, with a smaller line beneath it stating "Please Wait." This text is centrally aligned, emphasizing the current action being taken. Below the text, there is a circular loading icon, indicating ongoing processing. The panel is surrounded by a thin, white frame, which contrasts subtly with its light background. There are also functional buttons located at the top of the touch panel that are not depicted in detail in this image but typically house controls for access and commands. The overall design conveys a sleek, modern interface intended for users who manage multimedia during conferences or presentations, ensuring clarity and ease of understanding for those operating the system.

︗None
These conference rooms each come equipped with a simplified touch panel that can be used to control the video source being used to project to the display in the room as well adjust the audio level for the display. There is a Room PC ("Dedicated PC"), an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Table Laptop"), and a Solstice Pod ("Mersive Wireless").
The image depicts a close-up view of a digital touch panel labeled "CRESTRON," displaying various audio-visual (A/V) control options in a conference room. The panel features a blue background, with a clean, modern interface designed for user-friendliness. At the top, there’s a label indicating "SYSTEM POWER," alongside two icons for volume control—one representing mute and another for adjusting audio levels.

The central area highlights three main source options: "Dedicated PC," "Table Laptop," and "Mersive Wireless," each housed within rounded buttons that emphasize user interaction. The text is clear and legible, suggesting accessibility for all users in a conference environment. The panel's arrangement also facilitates easy navigation through its functionalities.

Functional buttons are located at the top, likely for additional commands, although they are not detailed in this view. The overall design is sleek and intuitive, illustrating a dedicated focus on managing multimedia presentations effectively within professional and technical settings.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP addresses have been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image features a large digital display screen showcasing the “ATL3373 Pod.” The screen occupies a prominent position, framed within a modern bezel, and presents a captivating abstract background in vibrant blues and earthy tones, resembling jagged rock formations. This backdrop potentially symbolizes creativity and innovation, enhancing the technical feel of the conference room environment. 

In the top left corner, the text “ATL3373 Pod” is displayed in a bold, white font, emphasizing the identity of the device. Below it, a timestamp reads “10:06 AM,” adding temporal context. On the right side, concise instructional text provides three clear steps for users: “1. Connect your device to INTERNAL,” “2. Browse to the address above,” and “3. Connect,” guiding users in utilizing the screen for presentations or conferences. 

Additionally, a note indicates that Apple users can utilize AirPlay for connectivity, making the system user-friendly for diverse audiences. The monochrome icons accompanying the instructions feature a simple design, implying ease of access to tech functions. Overall, the image conveys a modern, practical approach to technological collaboration within a professional setting.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "System Power" button and select "Power Off" when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the display for the room.
The image showcases a close-up view of a digital touch panel, part of the conference room’s A/V control system. The panel has a sleek design framed in white, featuring a small color display with a predominantly blue background. At the center are two prominent buttons labeled "Power On" and "Power Off," both presented in white with blue outlines, indicating user interaction. These buttons are large enough to be easily readable from a distance, facilitating straightforward operation. 

To the left of the display, there is a back navigation button depicted by a blue arrow pointing left, suggesting users can return to a previous menu. The overall layout emphasizes user-friendliness, designed for efficient control of the conference room's audio-visual equipment. The minimalistic aesthetic is practical for a professional setting, allowing users to manage power settings without distraction. The panel’s clarity and contrast ensure that users can quickly identify and execute tasks related to system power, making it suitable for a collaborative environment.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/CollaboratorAccount contains the following information: 






︗Accounts/Collaborator

From UMIACS
(Redirected from CollaboratorAccount)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
A Collaborator account is a sponsored provisional account for non-UMIACS members that provides access to UMIACS applications such as GitLab,  Object Storage, and MediaWiki instances. Collaborator accounts do not provide login access to UMIACS computers or access to networked file storage. Any access to GitLab repositories,  ObjectStore buckets, etc. fall under their account sponsor and/or the PI.  Access to your group's resources is mediated through Security Groups, which can be managed in our UMIACS Directory Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/secgroup/).

︗None
A UMIACS Account holder has to sponsor the Collaborator Account.   This is done in our UMIACS Requests Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/collaborators/new).  This will send an email to the Collaborator to set their details (including a username and password).  Once the Collaborator has created their account, an email will be sent to both the account sponsor and the Collaborator that the account is ready to use.

︗None
This can be done in the UMIACS Requests Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/collaborators). You can view a list of Collaborators that you directly sponsor. The following management actions are available:

Send Password Reset: An email will be sent to the Collaborator with a link to reset their password.
Remove Sponsorship: Staff will be notified to remove the selected accounts from your sponsorship.
You can also view Collaborators who are sponsored by users that you sponsor. Actions include:

Take Over Sponsorship: Staff will be notified to transfer sponsorship to you, and the original sponsor of the Collaborator will be notified.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Accounts/Collaborator&oldid=12044"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Moderation contains the following information: 






︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Moderation

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Manage pending requests
To approve a reservation, select I'm going on the event. To deny a reservation, select I'm not going on the event.

︗Enabling notifications
To enable notifications for a calendar, open the calendar's settings in Google Calendar, scroll down to the Other notifications section, and enable what you want. This is done on a room by room basis. It is recommended that you at least have notifications enabled for the rooms you moderate.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Google_Drive/Migrating_from_Backup_and_Sync_to_Drive_for_Desktop contains the following information: 






︗Google Drive/Migrating from Backup and Sync to Drive for Desktop

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Google has unified their previous two existing Drive sync clients (Backup and Sync and Drive File Stream) into a single sync client called Drive for desktop. If you were previously using Backup and Sync, please follow the steps below to migrate from Backup and Sync to Drive for desktop.

︗Windows Setup
Click on the Backup and Sync cloud icon in the lower righthand corner of your desktop. If the icon is not immediately visible, select the up arrow to show more icons.
The image displays a close-up screenshot of a Windows desktop taskbar located at the bottom of the screen. The background is a gradient of blue shades, creating a calm and modern aesthetic. At the far left, there is an area showing the weather conditions with a cloud icon and the temperature set at 68°F, accompanied by the word "Cloudy." 

To the right of the weather section, there is a small upward arrow pointing upwards, indicating hidden icons or system tray options. The focal point of the image is the prominently highlighted cloud icon circled in red, which represents the Backup and Sync feature for Google Drive. This cloud icon is depicted as a stylized cloud shape, suggesting online storage capabilities. 

Next to the cloud icon, there are symbols for a computer, sound output, and other system functionalities, suggesting the image represents a typical user's workspace while accessing or migrating backup options. The timestamp shows the clock reads 12:42 PM on October 11, 2021, providing a temporal context to the image.
Select the "GET STARTED" button.
The image displays a close-up screenshot of a Windows taskbar located at the bottom of the screen. The background is a gradient of blue hues, creating a sleek and modern look. On the left side, a weather indicator shows current conditions with a cloud icon and the temperature of 68°F labeled as "Cloudy." 

To the right, a small upward arrow suggests hidden system tray icons. The main focus is a highlighted notification panel featuring Google Drive's migration prompt. It clearly states, "Google Drive is replacing Backup and Sync," accompanied by instructions to move the account for the transition to Drive for Desktop. 

The "GET STARTED" button is prominently circled in red, drawing attention to it as an important action. Below this prompt, there is a green check mark next to the Google Drive shortcut, indicating that it was synced three minutes ago. Additionally, a timestamp shows the clock reads 12:42 PM on October 11, 2021, providing a specific context for the screenshot. Overall, the image emphasizes the process of transitioning to Google Drive for Desktop, showcasing relevant functionalities and visual cues.
Select the "Sign in" button. This will bring up your associated Google Accounts. Make sure to select the account with <DIRECTORYID>@umd.edu.
The image features a user interface for transitioning accounts to Google Drive for desktop. The background is a light blue, enhancing a clean and modern aesthetic. Prominently displayed in the center is the message "We found 1 account," indicating that the system has detected a linked account from Backup and Sync. Below this message, the account information is shown, featuring a placeholder for the user's name alongside the email address formatted as “@umd.edu.” 

To the right of the account details is a red-circled button labeled "Sign in," suggesting the user should authenticate their account to migrate. This button stands out against the soft blue background, drawing attention as a call to action. At the bottom of the screen, there are additional options, including a link to send feedback to Google. The minimalistic design focuses on clarity, guiding the user effectively through the account migration process.
After you have signed in, Drive for Desktop will check your folders to make sure all of your files are up to date and ask you to review your settings and inform you of the location of your Google Drive in your local filesystem.
Drive for Desktop will then ask you if you would like to store your photos and videos from your computer on your Google Drive or your Google Photos. NOTE: If you select the Google Photos option, you will need to sign into Google Photos using your <DIRECTORYID>@umd.edu Google account to access them. They will not sync into your personal Google account.
The image showcases the user interface of the Google Drive for Desktop application, specifically the "Folder options" screen. The interface has a clean, light blue background, contributing to a modern and user-friendly aesthetic. At the top, the email associated with the account, "kfunka@umd.edu," is prominently displayed. Two main options are presented side by side: "Sync with Google Drive" and "Back up to Google Photos."

The left section, highlighted as "Suggested" and marked as "Currently syncing with Google Drive," provides information about syncing folders. It features an illustrative graphic with a cloud icon above a folder, indicating that files will synchronize bidirectionally between the user’s computer and Google Drive. Below, the text clarifies that everything in the folder will sync in both directions.

On the right, the "Back up to Google Photos" option includes another graphic resembling a cloud and a square representing the Google Photos structure. Here, it notes that only photos and videos will be uploaded, guiding the user about their backup choices.

At the bottom, there are navigation buttons labeled "Back" and "Next," allowing users to progress through the setup process, while a link to send feedback to Google is also visible. Overall, the image effectively illustrates the process of selecting folder synchronization preferences in a clear format.
You will then be prompted to remove Backup and Sync from your system, go ahead and select the "OK" option as this software will eventually become depreciated.
The image displays a user interface for Google Drive's transition from Backup and Sync to Drive for desktop. The background is a soft light blue, creating a clean and modern feel. At the top center, the email address "kfunka@umd.edu" is displayed, indicating the user's account. 

In the foreground, a white dialog box presents a prompt with the question "Remove Backup and Sync?" It informs the user that Backup and Sync can be uninstalled as the account has been successfully migrated to Drive for desktop. The message emphasizes a successful transition, reinforcing the user’s actions throughout the migration process. 

At the bottom of the dialog box, there are two options: "Not now" and "OK." The "OK" button is circled in red, drawing attention as it represents the user’s main course of action in confirming the removal of the older application. Below the dialog, a greyed-out notice reads, "Setting up Google Drive for desktop," suggesting that the installation process is ongoing. The overall layout follows Google's minimalist design philosophy, making the transition clear and user-friendly.
Congratulations! Drive for Desktop is now installed on your system and you can start to save files to the Google Drive directory in your filesystem. Any folders previously backed up by Backup and Sync will now be backed up by Drive for Desktop as will as any files saved to the Google Drive directory in your filesystem.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Google_Drive/Migrating_from_Backup_and_Sync_to_Drive_for_Desktop&oldid=11683"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/BarracudaSpamFirewall/SearchingQuarantine contains the following information: 






︗BarracudaSpamFirewall/SearchingQuarantine

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
To visit your spam quarantine, log in to the system using any of our firewalls using your UMIACS email address (username@umiacs.umd.edu) and password:
bubs.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://bubs.umiacs.umd.edu)
pompom.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://pompom.umiacs.umd.edu)
From this you will see a drop-down box that says "select filter" (see picture below)
The image displays a user interface for the Barracuda Email Security Gateway, specifically the "Quarantine Inbox" section. At the top left, there is a blue navigation bar with the branding "Barracuda" and a label reading "Email Security Gateway." Below this, a white card titled "Quarantine Inbox" highlights the filter options. 

In the center, a drop-down menu for filtering options is visible, labeled "Subject" with a default option of "contains" selected, indicating the user can search email subjects that include specified text. To the right of this menu, there is an "Apply Filter" button.

The main area showcases a table with a list of quarantined email messages, each entry consisting of blacked-out text obscuring the sender’s email address and subject line for privacy. The rows include columns for "Time Received," "From," "Subject," and "Actions." The "Actions" column includes clickable options like "Deliver," "Whitelist," and "Delete." A warning notice at the bottom informs users that messages older than 21 days will be removed, indicating the strategic management of email quarantine policies. The current message log count is noted as 21.
There are three different filters, "from", "subject", and "message". "From" will allow you to search the emails based on who sent them. "Subject" will allow you to search based on the subject of emails. Message will allow you to search in the body of the email. To the right of the filter, you can either select "contains" or "doesn't contain". This will tell the filter to check if something contains the text you search for or doesn't contain the text you search for. For example if your filter is "subject" and you select "contains" and search for "binary" this will be the result.
The image is a screenshot of the user interface for the Barracuda Email Security Gateway, specifically showcasing the "Quarantine Inbox" section. At the top, a blue navigation bar features the Barracuda logo alongside the label "Email Security Gateway." Below this, a white card titled "Quarantine Inbox" displays filter options for managing quarantined emails.

In the center, there is a prominent drop-down menu labeled "Subject," with a default filter option set to "contains." Users can type specific text into this filter to search for emails. To the right of this menu is an "Apply Filter" button. The main content area features a table listing quarantined email entries, obscured for privacy with the sender's email and subject blacked out.

Columns in the table are labeled "Time Received," "From," "Subject," and "Actions." The "Actions" column provides buttons for user interactions—options like "Deliver," "Whitelist," and "Delete" are prominently displayed. A warning message at the bottom emphasizes that messages older than 21 days will be automatically removed, underlining the importance of regular email review. The current message log count is shown as one. The overall layout is clean and user-friendly, designed for efficient email management.
If your filter is "subject" and you select "doesn't contain" "binary", all of the emails that don't have "binary" in the subject will be shown.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BarracudaSpamFirewall/SearchingQuarantine&oldid=10124"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/OptLocal contains the following information: 






︗OptLocal

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Note: Please see Modules, which is now our preferred method of providing locally-built software to the Institute, as well as its various labs and centers.


/opt/local is managed via a Stow system.
If you are looking for a specific piece of software you can list the directory /opt/local/stow.  Some software is linked in with the stow command directly into bin,lib,man,sbin directories in /opt/local.
This only pertains to RHEL7 and above.  The software previously was found in /usr/local.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=OptLocal&oldid=9431"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/NASUsers contains the following information: 






︗NASUsers

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search


I'm ready to assist with descriptions of the images. Please provide the images you would like described, and I'll offer you detailed textual descriptions for each one.

These services are currently being deprecated in favor of the UMIACS Object Store. Please see OBJ. Depending on when your account was installed, you may or may not have web space or personal FTP access.

︗Web Pages
Please see  Personal Web Space.

︗None
Your FTP site is online at

 ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/username(The prior text links to ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/username)

On any supported UNIX workstation, you can access your FTP site as

 /fs/ftp/pub/username

Windows users can map it as a network drive from

 \\umiacs-webftp\ftp-umiacs\pub

Please note that anyone with an internet connection can log in and download these files. Do not use your FTP site to store confidential data.
This file system has regular backups with our TSM service and has Snapshots for easy user restores.

︗Usage Guidelines
Personal NAS is configured to be highly available and modest in both size and usage. Please store large or heavily accessed datasets in a dedicated project storage directory that is tuned for your application.
Please avoid storing shared project data in personal storage allocations. Separating project data from personal data will simplify administration and data management for both researchers and staff.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=NASUsers&oldid=10695"

Privacy policy

(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/JavaDisableBrowser contains the following information: 






︗JavaDisableBrowser

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Chrome/Chromium
2 Firefox
3 Safari
4 Internet Explorer


︗None
Enter about:plugins in the address bar.
Find the Java plugin and click the Disable link.
︗Firefox
Enter about:addons in the address bar.
Click the Plugins tab on the left and find the Java plugin and click the Disable button on the right hand side.
︗Safari
Enter the menu,  Safari > Preferences
Click the Security tab (Picture of a Lock) and uncheck the Enable Java checkbox
︗Internet Explorer
Enter the Tools Menu (Gear icon in upper right corner) > Internet Options
Click the Security tab and clicking the Custom Level button at the bottom of the window
Scroll down in the Security Settings box until you see “Scripting of Java Applets,” and click the Disable or Prompt radio button.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/CUDA contains the following information: 






︗CUDA

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
CUDA(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CUDA) is a parallel computing platform and programming model invented by NVIDIA. It enables dramatic increases in computing performance by harnessing the power of the graphics processing unit (GPU).

︗Prerequisites
NVIDIA GPU device
NVIDIA Driver


It looks like you haven't provided any images for me to describe. Please upload the images, and I'll be happy to create detailed textual descriptions for each one.

If you are unsure if your device is CUDA capable, please contact staff.

︗Getting Started
Load the CUDA Environmental variables via  GNU Modules
Multiple versions are available.  See the modules documentation and module list cuda for more information.
 module load cuda
Obtain a copy of the cuda samples:
rsync -a /opt/common/cuda/<CUDA Version>/samples/ ~/cuda_samples
Build and run the device query
 cd ~/cuda_samples/1_Utilities/deviceQuery/ && make && ./deviceQuery
Assuming the deviceQuery complication completed without error, you should now see output listing the details of the GPUs in your system.  If desired you can compile additional samples by switching to their respective directory and running 'make'





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=CUDA&oldid=11637"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/CoreServices contains the following information: 






︗CoreServices

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search


Authentication: User accounts such as UMIACS accounts, and collaborator accounts, how to request an account, and how to reset account password.

Operating Systems Support: List of operating systems supported at UMIACS.

Email: Email offering at UMIACS and configuring the spam filter.


Mailing Lists: Mail aliases and Mailman mailing lists.

Printing: Printing guide for different operating systems and locations of UMIACS' public printers.

Backups: Instruction on how to backup personal devices using Google Drive.


Network Attached Storage: NFS home directories and project directories.

Local Data Storage: Data storage options such as local scratch, network scratch, nfshomes, etc.

Web Services: UMIACS web hosting services, i.e. hosting a personal website.


UMIACS Object Store: Get started on UMIACS' Object Store; learn about buckets, keys, and how to access the object store.

Revision Control (Git): Brief intro to GitLab.

Programming Languages: List of commonly used programming languages at UMIACS by the faculty and students.


High Performance Computing: Information regarding different clusters such as Nexus, CML, Vulcan, etc. and the SLURM resource scheduler.

Virtual Private Networking: How to install and configure UMIACS' Pulse Secure VPN.

Storage Device Destruction: Make a request to securely destroy data.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=CoreServices&oldid=11920"
