〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/DigitalLoanerForm contains the following information: 






︗DigitalLoanerForm

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Overview
To digitally complete a loaner form provided by  UMIACS Staff, follow these steps.

︗Prerequisites
Adobe Acrobat DC (available from Terpware(The prior text links to https://terpware.umd.edu/) free to all students, staff, and faculty) or Adobe Acrobat Reader DC(The prior text links to https://get.adobe.com/reader/) (free to everyone)
︗Procedure
Download the form that has been provided by UMIACS staff. Open it in either Adobe Acrobat DC or Adobe Acrobat Reader DC.
If need be, here is a blank form(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/images/b/b1/LoanerForm_fillable.pdf).
Click on Tools on the top menu, find Fill & Sign under Forms & Signatures, and click Add and/or Open.
The image displays a screenshot of Adobe Acrobat Pro DC with a focus on the interface for the loaner form titled "LoanerForm_fillable.pdf." The top section features the application's title bar showing the file name. Below, the main toolbar highlights the "Tools" option in red, indicating the user should navigate to this feature. Underneath, the "Forms & Signatures" section is prominently displayed, with icons for actions such as "Fill & Sign" and "Prepare." 

To the left, there's an “Open” button, allowing users to open additional options for the form. The background is a clean white, providing a stark contrast to the red accents used for the highlighted "Tools" menu. The layout is orderly, suggesting a user-friendly experience that guides users in completing their loaner forms digitally. Overall, the image conveys a clear instructional step within the process of digitally filling out forms.
Click Fill and sign under the area that says You with the Fill & Sign menu.
The image displays a screenshot of the Adobe Acrobat Pro DC interface, specifically featuring the digital loaner form titled "LoanerForm_fillable.pdf." At the top, the title bar indicates the file name and application title. Below, the main toolbar highlights the "Tools" option in bright red, urging users to navigate to this section. 

In the central region, a prominent box titled "Fill & Sign" illustrates the process for filling out the form. An illustration of a document with lines and a pen conveys the action of completing form fields. Below the illustration, it includes text indicating that users must fill in fields and sign. 

A large, bold blue button labeled "Fill and sign" at the bottom encourages user interaction, emphasizing the action to be taken. The background is a clean white, providing a stark contrast to the red and blue elements, enhancing readability. This orderly layout is designed to facilitate a straightforward user experience, guiding the user in electronically completing the loaner form. Overall, the image serves as a visual aid to demonstrate a critical step in the digital form-filling process.
Take note of the following notice in the top right of the application and click OK.
The image displays a notification dialog box within the Adobe Acrobat interface. The background of the dialog is a dark gray, contrasting sharply with the white text, which is clearly legible. The message informs the user that the author of the form has specified which fields are fillable. The text reads: “The author of this form has specified the fields which you can fill. Click on any field to start filling form.” Below this message, there is a prominent "OK" button, inviting the user to proceed by acknowledging the information. The overall design of the dialog maintains a clean and professional appearance, typical of software interfaces, ensuring that the user can easily understand the instruction. The simplicity of the design communicates clarity, enhancing the user experience, and assisting users in successfully completing the form as intended.
Fill out fields that have been specified as appropriate. At minimum, this should be at least the Description of Equipment field for all items, and for any equipment that has a University Inventory Number (red tag) and/or serial number, these fields for that equipment as well. If you have been in contact with UMIACS Staff previously, they may have pre-filled some of these fields for you. Leave the signature field blank.
The image displays a screenshot of the "Loaner Form" in Adobe Acrobat Pro DC. At the top, the title reads "Institute for Advanced Computer Studies, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742." Below, a structured table presents fields for filling out equipment details. The left column is labeled "Description of Equipment," featuring three entries: "Dell workstation," "Keyboard," and "Mouse," with the workstation highlighted in red. The adjacent column shows "University Inventory Number," indicating that the workstation is assigned number "123456," while the other two items are marked as "n/a." The final column for "Serial Number" lists "ABCD" for the workstation, and "n/a" for the others.

Below the table, there are sections labeled "Date Due" and "Ticket ID," both left empty for user input. A statement emphasizes the borrower's responsibility for returning the equipment. The lower part of the form has designated fields for the user’s name, signature, and date, with "Matthew Baney" entered as the name, along with a filled-in date of "3/23/2020." The overall layout is clean, with a white background contrasting sharply against the light blue fields, enhancing readability and facilitating user interaction with the form.
Click on Sign on the Fill & Sign top menu, and then Add Signature (if you have previously generated a signature, that existing signature will appear instead and you can choose it and skip the next step).
The image showcases the interface of Adobe Acrobat Pro DC featuring the digital loaner form titled "LoanerForm_fillable.pdf." At the top, the application’s file title is displayed prominently, alongside standard navigation options. The main section emphasizes the "Fill & Sign" feature, highlighted in a contrasting purple bar with the "Sign" option illustrated using a pen icon. Below, a bright blue button labeled "Add Signature" is framed in a red box, indicating where users can input their signatures.

The layout is organized, with a clean white background that enhances readability against the colorful elements. The options for adding a signature are clearly delineated, guiding the user through the process. To the left, a gray area suggests where the form's contents might be filled in. The overall design promotes a user-friendly experience, with noticeable prompts that facilitate the form completion process. This image visually supports the instructions for signing documents electronically, reiterating the ease of use that Acrobat Pro provides in this context.
Click Apply at the bottom to use the auto-generated signature from Adobe. You can choose to either draw or upload an image instead if you would like, but the auto-generated one is sufficient.
The image displays an interface from Adobe Acrobat Pro DC used for adding a digital signature. At the top, there are options for "Type," "Draw," and "Image," indicating the methods available for creating a signature. Below these options, the name "Matthew Baney" is displayed in a styled, cursive font, representing the signature being created. A red marker flag with the text “Sign” is positioned to the left of the name, highlighting its significance.

The interface has a clean and minimalistic design, with a light grey background that ensures good contrast with the black text. Below the signature area, there is a checkbox labeled "Save signature," which allows users to store the signature for future use. 

At the bottom, two buttons are prominent: "Cancel" on the left, and "Apply" on the right, framed in blue, indicating that clicking this will finalize the signature placement. This organized layout guides users through the signature creation process, ensuring clarity and ease of use for digitally signing documents. Overall, the image effectively conveys the steps necessary for adding a signature to a document within Adobe Acrobat.
Place the signature in the signature field. Note that you will not be able to edit the form further after you save the PDF at this point.
The image displays a digital loan form titled "Loan Form," presented in a clean and structured layout under the header of the Institute for Advanced Computer Studies, University of Maryland. The top section identifies the institution and its address prominently. Below this, a neatly organized table outlines key information relevant to the equipment being borrowed. 

The first column, labeled "Description of Equipment," lists items including a "Dell Precision T5820," highlighted in red, along with "Keyboard" and "Mouse," which are noted as "n/a." The second column shows the "University Inventory Number," where the workstation is assigned the number "123456." The third column contains the "Serial Number," indicating "ABCDEFG" for the workstation while the other items are also marked "n/a."

Below the table, there are blank fields for "Date Due" and "Ticket ID." A statement details the borrower’s responsibility for returning the equipment. The lower portion of the form includes fields for "Name," where the name "Matthew Baney" is entered, a "Signature" field, and a filled-in date of "3/23/2020." The overall design emphasizes clarity and ease of use, with a white background that contrasts well with light blue form fields, facilitating user interaction.
Click File in the top left and Save As...
The image displays a screenshot of the Adobe Acrobat Pro DC interface, focused on the “File” menu options. The title bar at the top indicates the document being used is titled "LoanerForm_fillable.pdf." Within the menu, various options are visible, including "Open," "Reopen PDFs from last session," and "Create." The most prominent feature is the "Save As..." option highlighted in a red box, drawing attention to its importance in the digital form-filling process. This option is designed for saving documents under a new name or in a different location. The layout is clean with a light background, ensuring that the text is easily readable. The organization of the menu aligns with standard software practices, thereby promoting user familiarity and facilitating efficient navigation. Overall, the image serves as an instructional reference for users on how to save their completed forms digitally.
Click Choose a Different Folder... on the Save As PDF menu.
The image displays a screenshot of the "Save As PDF" dialog in Adobe Acrobat Pro DC. At the top, the title "Save As PDF" is prominently displayed. On the left side, a navigation pane allows users to choose between different file locations, including "My Computer," "Document Cloud," and an option to "Add Account." The “My Computer” option is highlighted to indicate selection. 

In the central area, there are checkboxes for file options such as "Reduce File Size" and "Restrict Editing," but neither is selected. The right section features a distinguishable blue button labeled "Choose a Different Folder..." framed in a red box, emphasizing its significance as a call to action. Below this, there is a blank space where users can anticipate seeing recent folders for saving files.

The overall layout of the dialog is clean and functional, with a light background that enhances clarity and readability against the darker text and colored options. This interface facilitates user interaction by clearly guiding them through the process of saving documents in a specified location on their computer.
Choose an appropriate location to save the file, rename the file to include the word 'signed', and save the file.
The image displays the "Save As PDF" dialog box in Adobe Acrobat Pro DC. At the top, the file name field shows "LoanerForm_signed.pdf," indicating that the user intends to save the completed loaner form with a specific name, emphasizing the status of the document. Below this, a dropdown menu labeled "Save as type" defaults to "Adobe PDF Files (*.pdf)," ensuring proper file format selection.

On the right, a prominent blue button labeled "Save" is enclosed in a red box, indicating its importance as the final action. The interface has a clean design, featuring a light gray background that enhances readability of the text and buttons involved. An unselected button labeled "Settings..." appears just above the "Save" button, suggesting additional options for customizing the save process.

At the left side, there’s a collapsible pane labeled "Hide Folders," facilitating navigation through different file locations, ensuring ease of use in selecting where to save the document. Overall, the image clearly illustrates the last steps in finalizing and saving the form, making it user-friendly for those completing the process.
Attach the signed form to the originating request that prompted staff to direct you to this page.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/EmailMigration/SelfMigration contains the following information: 






︗EmailMigration/SelfMigration

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS has wound down its Exchange and IMAP mailbox Email services as of June 30th 2020 to comply with the UMD Institutional Email(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0015077) standard.
The Division of IT handled the migration for some individuals that previously forwarded their UMD mail to their UMIACS mailbox. We sent an email to all users that were covered by this on May 1st 2020 with the subject line "UMIACS Email Migration".  If you received this email, you do not need to do anything on this page.
If you did not receive this email and are instead being directed here by a message received on May 5th 2020 with the subject line "UMIACS Email Self-Migration", you needed to update your email preference in our Directory app(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info) before June 2nd 2020 at 9am. If you did not do this, on June 2nd 2020 at 9am, the UMIACS Technical Staff updated your email forward to be your corresponding @umd.edu email address if you have/had one, or the last known email address we had on record for you if you do not and you used either our Exchange or IMAP service.
If you do not have a @umd.edu address and would like to update your email forwarding address to be a different one from the one that we changed it to:

Log into our Directory app(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info).
Under the 'Email' section, change the listed address under Forward to the address of your choosing.
Click Submit at the bottom of the page.
Begin checking new email to your @umiacs.umd.edu address at the address you just chose.
︗Importing Email to UMD Mailbox
If you would like to import email from your previous provider into your UMD mailbox, follow these steps.  This cannot be done by UMIACS staff as we have no administrative access to your UMD mailbox.  If you run into any issues, please contact the Division of IT(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport/).  Choose the appropriate section based on your previous UMIACS email preference.

︗Exchange
 Contact staff if you would like an archive of your UMIACS mailbox.  It will be a single file in PST file format, provided via a download link.
Download the archive of your email from the link provided by staff.
Download and install G Suite Migration for Microsoft Outlook(The prior text links to https://tools.google.com/dlpage/gsmmo/).
Follow DivIT's instructions(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport/?sys_kb_id=4792cfe137a4e640a90963d2b3990efd&id=kb_article_view) to import your email from the PST file.
︗IMAP
 Contact staff if you would like an archive of your UMIACS mailbox.  It will be several files (one file per email folder that you had in your IMAP mailbox) in MBOX file format, compressed into a tarball and provided via a download link.
Download the archive of your email from the link provided by staff and decompress it into the individual MBOX files.
Download and install Mozilla Thunderbird(The prior text links to https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/) and install the ImportExportTools NG add-on(The prior text links to https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/) for it.
Follow DivIT's instructions(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport/?id=kb_article_view&sys_kb_id=40da60261baa881036c3a9fbbc4bcb3e) to import your email from the MBOX files.
︗Forward
Search for instructions from your previous provider.  We cannot encompass instructions for all possible providers here, though if you are able to export email in either PST or MBOX file format, you can follow the steps in either the Exchange or IMAP sections (respectively) to import email.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=EmailMigration/SelfMigration&oldid=9322"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe_PacketFence_Network contains the following information: 






︗Iribe Wired Network

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Iribe PacketFence Network)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Captive Portal Network
UMIACS provides a wired network in Iribe for connecting transient devices like laptops.
This is a Captive Portal Network and hence requires authentication for access. You will be required to authenticate using your UMIACS credentials the first time you navigate to a webpage. 
Once authenticated, your access will be valid for 24 hours before needing to authenticate again.
FAQS

How do I check the status of my registration?
https://packetfence00.iribe.umd.edu/status(The prior text links to https://packetfence00.iribe.umd.edu/status)
How do I disconnect?
https://packetfence00.iribe.umd.edu/networklogoff(The prior text links to https://packetfence00.iribe.umd.edu/networklogoff)
How do I request this wired network be made available at my desk?
Email the request to staff@umiacs.umd.edu with the label of the yellow network jack you are trying to connect.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Iribe_Wired_Network&oldid=10161"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Caffe contains the following information: 






︗Caffe

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Caffe(The prior text links to https://caffe.berkeleyvision.org/) is a deep learning framework.

︗None
On machines with GPUs and the NVIDIA driver installed, you can build Caffe with CUDA and cuDNN. Please note that there may be newer versions of CUDA and cuDNN available in the  module tree than the listed ones below.
Run nvidia-smi -L to verify the NVIDIA driver is installed and can see your GPUs:

$ nvidia-smi -L
GPU 0: GeForce GTX TITAN X (UUID: GPU-dd20c890-3d0f-942f-6e85-7b43c6bd03c5)
GPU 1: GeForce GTX TITAN X (UUID: GPU-b1d93efa-3d89-bb58-d4cb-b517ead36b27)

Add the modules, clone the Caffe repository, configure the Makefile options, and build.

$ module add cuda/8.0.44 cudnn/v5.1
$ git clone https://github.com/BVLC/caffe.git
Cloning into 'caffe'...
remote: Counting objects: 37328, done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (11/11), done.
remote: Total 37328 (delta 11), reused 7 (delta 7), pack-reused 37310
Receiving objects: 100% (37328/37328), 47.48 MiB | 17.52 MiB/s, done.
Resolving deltas: 100% (24927/24927), done.
$ cd caffe/
$ cp Makefile.config.example Makefile.config

# Set the following options in Makefile.config (uncomment). Make sure there are no trailing whitespace after these options.
# USE_CUDNN := 1
# BLAS := open
# CUDA_DIR := /opt/common/cuda/cuda-8.0.44/

$ make
...
$ make test
...

︗Matlab
If you need to use then please use Matlab 2015a and make sure you do the following commands in addition to what is above.  Currently Matlab 2015a only supports GCC 4.7.x for compiling mex files.

module add matlab/2015a gcc/4.7.4
make matcaffe

︗CPU Only
To build Caffe with CPU-only capability, follow these instructions.

git clone https://github.com/BVLC/caffe.git 
cd caffe
cp Makefile.config.example Makefile.config
# set the following options in a Makefile.config 
# CPUONLY := 1 
# BLAS := open 
make 
make test 
make runtest





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Caffe&oldid=10781"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/CompromisedPasswordFiltering contains the following information: 






︗CompromisedPasswordFiltering

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS passwords, in accordance with best practices recommended by NIST, will not allow passwords to be used that have been included in a known data breach.  UMIACS systems will check that a new password you wish to set is not among hundreds of millions of compromised passwords.
We use the Have I Been Pwned (HIBP)(The prior text links to https://haveibeenpwned.com/Passwords) corpus of passwords as the data source of passwords that are checked against.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=CompromisedPasswordFiltering&oldid=8172"

(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SSH/Keys contains the following information: 






︗SSH/Keys

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
SSH can utilize public key encryption to authenticate and authorize users.  This can be considered more secure especially if you secure your private key with a pass-phrase.  The keys themselves are not susceptible to brute force attacks like normal passwords over SSH are.

︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Create and store the key pair

2.1 Windows
2.2 Linux/MacOS/Bash and Git Bash (for Windows)


3 Copy the public key

3.1 Windows
3.2 Linux/MacOS/Bash and Git Bash (for Windows)


4 Adding Keys to SSH Clients (Windows Only)
5 Batch clusters
6 SSH Agents


︗Overview
Prerequisites
If using batch clusters (e.g. SLURM) please read  Batch clusters prior to creating a new key.
Determine your OS (and if Windows, what you will be using to create the key)
Windows
Git Bash: follow instructions for Linux/MacOS/Bash and Git Bash (for Windows)
PuTTY: follow instructions for Windows (and PuTTY subsections)
TTSSH2: follow instructions for Windows (and TTSSH2 subsections)
 Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL): follow instructions for 'Linux/MacOS/Bash and Git Bash (for Windows)'
Linux: follow instructions for 'Linux/MacOS/Bash and Git Bash (for Windows)'
MacOS: follow instructions for 'Linux/MacOS/Bash and Git Bash (for Windows)'
Steps
 Create and store the key pair
 Copy the public key
If Windows,  Adding Keys to SSH Clients (Windows Only)
Note: UMIACS still requires multi-factor authentication if you are connecting from the public internet for security reasons. If you first connect to our VPN, you should then be able to use the keys as normal.

Additional Considerations
The  SSH Agents section is not a required component of creating and using an SSH key, but can be very useful if you choose to create a password to protect your SSH key, but find yourself needing to enter that password many times in a session.  SSH Agents allow you to temporarily use your SSH key without a password for a set period of time. Please see the  SSH Agents section for more information.
︗Create and store the key pair
The first step is to generate a key which will create two files filled with long strings of characters.  A public key file that you may distribute to any machine you want to use it on and a private key that needs to be kept secure.  Allowing anyone to read this private key will compromise the security of the key and could allow someone to access any resources secured by this key without your consent. There are a number of different key types but rsa is the most compatible.  

︗Windows
Git Bash
See  Linux/MacOS/Bash and Git Bash (for Windows)
PuTTY
Click on the start menu and search for PuTTYgen. Open the application
Verify that you are attempting to create an "SSH2 RSA" key by clicking on the appropriate box
Click generate and follow the instructions for generating your keys
Add passphrase if wanted and save both the public and private keys
TTSSH2
Open the application
Cancel the first box
Go to setup on the menu bar and go to SSH KeyGenerator
Click generate and follow the instructions for generating your key
Add passphrase if wanted and save both the public and private keys
︗None
Create a new key with a password
You can run the command ssh-keygen -t rsa to generate the new public and private key.  It will prompt you for a file to create the private key and then for the public key append .pub extension and store it in the same directory.  Pressing enter at the passphrase step twice will create a key without a pass-phrase.
Note: If you change the file in which to save the key, please ensure that it still starts with 'id', such as 'id_umiacs_rsa'.

Example: -bash-4.2$ ssh-keygen -t rsa
Generating public/private rsa key pair.
Enter file in which to save the key (/home/username/.ssh/id_rsa):
Created directory '/home/username/.ssh'.
Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase):
Enter same passphrase again:
Your identification has been saved in /home/username/.ssh/id_rsa.
Your public key has been saved in /home/username/.ssh/id_rsa.pub.
The key fingerprint is:
32:bf:db:74:1b:7e:d7:c6:4b:b5:6f:a8:82:55:3f:bf username@localhost.localdomain
The key's randomart image is:
+--[ RSA 2048]----+
|                 |
|                 |
|                 |
|            .    |
|      o S  . .  .|
|       +  .   o o|
|        .o. o  B.|
|        .+.o o+ O|
|        o...+o E+|
+-----------------+

Create a new key without a password
You can simplify the existing example above by telling it you do not want a pass-phrase and can run the command ssh-keygen -t rsa -N "".
Note: If you change the file in which to save the key, please ensure that it still starts with 'id', such as 'id_umiacs_rsa'.

Example: -bash-4.2$ ssh-keygen -t rsa -N ""
Generating public/private rsa key pair.
Enter file in which to save the key (/home/username/.ssh/id_rsa):
Created directory '/home/username/.ssh'.
Your identification has been saved in /home/username/.ssh/id_rsa.
Your public key has been saved in /home/username/.ssh/id_rsa.pub.
The key fingerprint is:
ff:7a:99:28:fc:63:d6:10:44:4c:2e:68:76:44:76:7a username@localhost.localdomain
The key's randomart image is:
+--[ RSA 2048]----+
|       .+++      |
|       + +o      |
|      + +.E      |
|     o . o.      |
|        S  .     |
|         ..      |
|       .  .+ o   |
|        o =.=    |
|         =o+.    |
+-----------------+

Modify permissions
Modify the permissions of your .ssh directory as well as the private key file that you just created with chmod.

chmod 700 ~/.ssh 
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_rsa

If you named your file something other than id_rsa, change id_rsa to the name of the file.

︗Copy the public key
Once you have a generated a key pair you will want to add it to one or more computers to allow you to access them.  

︗Windows
For Windows hosts you can use WinSCP(The prior text links to http://winscp.net/eng/download.php) to copy the public key file onto a remote host. The root file system for the Bash Subsystem for Windows is located under C:\Users\username>\AppData\Local\lxss\

︗None
This can be done with the ssh-copy-id command and it will prompt you the first time for your current password (NOT your pass-phrase). You can replace localhost with any other hostname you want to copy the key to. You can also specify an alternate user or identity file if you need to, please man ssh-copy-id for more information within your terminal. This command will ensure that not only it copies your key but secures the file so that no one can tamper and add additional authorized keys to the file on the remote host. 

Example: -bash-4.2$ ssh-copy-id localhost
/bin/ssh-copy-id: INFO: attempting to log in with the new key(s), to filter out any that are already installed
/bin/ssh-copy-id: INFO: 1 key(s) remain to be installed -- if you are prompted now it is to install the new keys
username@localhost's password:

Number of key(s) added: 1

Now try logging into the machine, with:   "ssh 'localhost'"
and check to make sure that only the key(s) you wanted were added.

︗None
PuTTY
Open PuTTY and enter the fully qualified domain name (FQDN)(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fully_qualified_domain_name) for the host you wish to connect to.
Go to the Connections tab on the side panel and click on the data subsection.
Under data enter your default user into the first box. (Auto-login Username)
Go to the SSH section of the side panel and then go to the Auth Section.
Under Auth click on the browse and navigate to the saved private key.
Go back to session on the side panel and save your settings by typing in a name in saved sessions pressing the save button.
TTSSH2
Open the application.
Cancel the first box.
Go to setup on the menu bar and go to SSH Authentication.
Enter your username, Click on the option labeled "Use RSA ... key to log in", then use the private key button located next to this line to navigate to your private key file, and click Ok.
︗Batch clusters
Our SLURM clusters process jobs in batch and require the ability to SSH without entering a password. When creating a key for use with SLURM, follow the above instructions for creating keys without passwords.
After creating this key pair please make sure you follow the  copy the public key instructions above to localhost. This will ensure that your key will be usable on all the cluster nodes since they have a shared home directory.

︗SSH Agents
While it is very useful to protect your SSH key pair with a pass-phrase it can very time consuming to re-type the pass-phrase over and over. SSH provides a agent that runs in the background and allow you add a key(s) to it with a time limit that they will be unlocked for.

ssh-agent bash
ssh-add -t $TIME

The time specified by -t is specified in seconds.
Example:
(The following would start a bash shell with passwordless SSH active for 30 minutes.)

ssh-agent bash
ssh-add -t 1800

You will be prompted for your passphrase and, when entered correctly, you will be able to SSH without entering a password. You can check what keys are load when you are running inside a ssh-agent by using the command ssh-add -l.

Example: bash-4.2$ ssh-add -l
2048 ee:83:10:c8:2f:2c:17:5e:ef:80:42:7e:ff:75:9e:53 /home/username/.ssh/id_rsa (RSA)

︗FTP/macOS/Finder

From UMIACS
(Redirected from FTP/OSX/Finder)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
FTP services can be accessed from supported machines running macOS. This is a guide on how to access the UMIACS FTP service using macOS Finder.

︗Contents

1 Opening up macOS Finder
2 Accessing the public folder

2.1 Access as an owner
2.2 Access as a collaborator




︗Opening up macOS Finder
To open up macOS Finder, click on the macOS Finder icon on the dock at the bottom of your desktop.

The image shows a horizontal dock at the bottom of a macOS desktop, featuring a series of application icons. The focus is on the Finder icon, which is a stylized face consisting of two eyes and a smiling mouth against a blue background. The Finder icon is highlighted within a red square, indicating its selected status. Surrounding the Finder icon are various other application icons, including a mail client, calendar, notes, and a web browser. The appearance of the dock is clean and modern, with a smooth gradient background in shades of blue. The icons are uniform in size, arranged in a linear fashion, providing easy access to frequently used applications. The overall aesthetic reflects the sleek design typical of macOS, emphasizing usability and efficiency in accessing files and applications. The Finder icon is highlighted with a red square


︗Accessing the public folder
The owner of the public folder can publish and modify files from a supported machine. External collaborators can only download files published by the owner. 

︗Access as an owner
First, bring up the address bar in macOS Finder by pressing Command + Shift + G.

The image depicts a macOS Finder window displayed prominently against a dark background. At the top, the title "Macintosh HD" indicates the selected drive. The window features a sidebar on the left listing various folders such as Applications, Library, System, and Users. At the center, there is a "Go to Folder" input box highlighted against the dark interface, where users can enter a specific directory path. This box is dark gray with rounded edges, and contains a "Cancel" button with an ‘X’ icon, which allows dismissal of the dialog.

A large red rectangular border encapsulates the "Go to Folder" dialog, drawing attention to it. Beneath this dialog, the text "COMMAND + SHIFT + G" is prominently displayed in large, bold, red font, indicating the keyboard shortcut necessary to open this feature in Finder. The layout is sleek and modern, characterized by a minimalist aesthetic that is signature to Apple’s design philosophy. Overall, the image serves as an instructional guide on how to access specific folders using keyboard shortcuts within macOS Finder. Bring up the "go to the folder"
 
In order to access your public folder,
type in the following into the address bar of Finder:

/fs/ftp/pub/<username> - where <username> should be replaced with your username
The image depicts a macOS Finder window prominently displayed against a dark background. The top of the window shows the title "Macintosh HD," indicating the active storage drive. On the left sidebar, various folder categories are neatly listed, including Applications, Library, System, and Users, enhancing ease of navigation. The center of the window features a "Go to Folder" input box, presented in dark gray with rounded edges, where users can enter directory paths. This input box is bordered by a large red rectangle, drawing attention to it. Within the box, the text “/fs/ftp/pub/<username>” is highlighted, indicating where users should input their specific usernames. To the right of the input is a gear icon, suggesting additional options or settings. A bold, red text beneath the box reads “COMMAND + SHIFT + G,” indicating the keyboard shortcut to open this feature. Overall, the sleek and minimalist design reflects the aesthetic principles of Apple's interface, while providing a straightforward instructional guide on accessing specific public folders. Enter the path to access the pub folder


︗Access as a collaborator
External collaborators can access the public folders through the Finder's "Connect to Server" feature. The "Connect to Server" window can be opened by pressing Command + K on your keyboard.

The image displays a macOS "Connect to Server" window within the Finder interface, set against a dark-themed background. The window has clean, rounded corners and is centrally positioned with a prominent red border that highlights it. At the top is a labeled text box marked "Server Address," where users can input a specific server address for connection. Below this text box, another area titled "Favorite Servers" is displayed, indicating previously saved server addresses, enhancing usability. To the right, two buttons - "Browse" and "Connect" - are available for user interaction, aiding in either navigating available servers or establishing a connection. Below this window, the text "COMMAND + K" is displayed in bold, red font, signaling the keyboard shortcut to access this feature effectively. To the left, a sidebar outlines locations like "Users," "Documents," and various folders, providing easy navigation within the Finder. The overall aesthetic is modern and sleek, emphasizing functionality while remaining visually appealing, characteristic of Apple's design philosophy. Open the "Connect to Server" window

Then, enter the following address into the server address bar and then click on the "Connect" button.

ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/<username> - where <username> should be replaced with the desired collaborator's username
The image displays a macOS "Connect to Server" dialog box, set against a dark-themed Finder interface. This window features rounded corners and is highlighted by a prominent red border, drawing attention to its importance. At the top, a labeled text box shows the server address format: "ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/<username>," indicating where users should input their username. Below, the "Favorite Servers" section is empty, implying no saved addresses yet, enhancing usability for new users. To the left, there are options to navigate or save regularly accessed servers with a "+" button for adding favorites. The "Browse" and "Connect" buttons on the right facilitate user interaction, simplifying the connection process. The background features various folder icons, including "Macintosh HD," arranged in a list format, illustrating active navigation within the file system. The overall design emphasizes a clean, modern interface aligned with Apple’s aesthetic, focusing on user experience and functionality. The image serves as a practical instructional guide for connecting to an FTP server on macOS, reinforcing the steps necessary for collaboration. Enter the path to access the public folder

After that you will be prompted with a window where you should choose to connect as a guest and then click "Connect" once more.

The image features a macOS dialog box designed for connecting to an FTP server. This window appears against a dark gray background, emphasizing its modern design. At the top, a text prompt reads, "Enter your name and password for the server ‘ftp.umiacs.umd.edu’," indicating where users should input their credentials. The connection options are laid out clearly, with two radio buttons labeled "Guest" and "Registered User." The "Guest" option is selected and highlighted within a bright red rectangular border, drawing attention to it.

Beneath these options, there are empty fields labeled "Name" and "Password," where users can enter their respective details depending on their access type. A checkbox is provided, labeled "Remember this password in my keychain," allowing for easier future access if checked. At the bottom, two buttons are visible: "Cancel" on the left and "Connect" on the right, facilitating user decisions. The overall layout is user-friendly, maintaining the sleek, functional style characteristic of macOS interfaces, ensuring a straightforward experience for users attempting to connect to the FTP server. Select Guest


The image features a macOS dialog box for connecting to the FTP server "ftp.umiacs.umd.edu." The window is set against a dark gray background, emphasizing its modern macOS design. At the top, there’s a prompt reading, "Enter your name and password for the server ‘ftp.umiacs.umd.edu’," instructing users where to input their credentials. Below this prompt, there are connection options with two radio buttons: "Guest" and "Registered User." The "Guest" option is highlighted in a bright blue, indicating it is selected, while the "Registered User" option remains unselected. 

Two input fields labeled "Name" and "Password" are found beneath the radio buttons, where users can enter their respective information based on their connection choice. A checkbox labeled "Remember this password in my keychain" is available, facilitating easier future access if checked. At the bottom of the dialog, there are two buttons: "Cancel" on the left, which allows users to exit without connecting, and a prominent "Connect" button on the right, framed in red, clearly signaling the option to proceed. The overall layout is user-friendly, maintaining Apple's minimalist aesthetic while streamlining the connection process for users. Click Connect

︗ATL/ConferenceRooms

From UMIACS
(Redirected from ConferenceRooms/ATL3100A)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The following is the list of UMIACS-managed conference rooms in the Atlantic building. General topics:

 Using the Solstice Mersive Pods
 Recording and Streaming
 Using Zoom
︗Contents

1 ATL 3100A

1.1 Sources

1.1.1 Room PC
1.1.2 Solstice
1.1.3 Laptop


1.2 Shutting Down


2 ATL 3100C/3100D/3373

2.1 Sources

2.1.1 Room PC
2.1.2 Laptop
2.1.3 Solstice


2.2 Shutting Down




︗ATL 3100A
This conference room comes equipped with a touch panel that can be used to control the video and audio source(s) and level(s) being used to project to the displays in the room. There is a Room PC ("PC Main"), a Solstice Pod ("Solstice"), and an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Laptop").
There is also an "Audio Override" output device that you can project any of the input sources to. This decouples the source audio from the source video so that you can send audio from one source to the audio output while maintaining video from a difference source. The primary use of this is to be able to prevent echoing and have teleconferencing participants be able to hear the room audience when using both a laptop and the room PC to present. With both devices in the same teleconference session, leave "Laptop" as the source video and switch the audio override to "PC Main" to display what is on the laptop but use the microphones spread throughout the room to hear the audience.
The image displays a control panel interface for managing audiovisual equipment within a conference room. The screen, part of a CRESTRON system, is divided into sections with clearly marked buttons and icons. At the top left corner, there's a prominent red button labeled "Shutdown A/V System," designed for powering down all equipment safely. Adjacent to it is a "Device Control" button, likely used for additional settings.

The central portion of the screen features icons representing different input and output options. There are two main source options: "Laptop" leading to a "Projector" and "Laptop Monitor". Below these are controls for selecting audio sources, indicated by an "Audio Override" button at the center.

The lower part of the interface offers further source choices, including "PC Main," "Solstice," "Blank," and "Laptop," signifying the arranged inputs available for the system. A horizontal instruction bar at the bottom reads, "First Select a Source To Be Routed Below, then the Destination," guiding users on how to operate the system effectively. The overall color scheme includes shades of blue and gray, providing a clear, functional design that facilitates user interaction.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP address has been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image displays a screen for the Solstice Pod labeled "ATL3100a-Pod," located in a conference room. The background features a vibrant, abstract representation of earthy textures and colors, including shades of brown, blue, and hints of green, suggesting a natural landscape or terrain. The time shown in the lower-left corner reads "9:44 AM," while the room number "3250" is prominently displayed above the title.

To the right, there are three clear instructional steps for users to connect their devices: 
1. "Connect your device to: INTERNAL"
2. "Browse to the address above"
3. "Connect"

Additionally, there is a note for Apple users indicating they can use AirPlay to connect to the "ATL3100a-Pod." The interface is user-friendly, with information laid out in an accessible format, and the overall color scheme predominantly features dark tones with lighter text for contrast. The design is intuitive, aimed at facilitating seamless integration of devices into the conference room's audiovisual system.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "Shutdown A/V System" button when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the displays for the room and raise the projector screen.
The image displays a control panel interface for audiovisual equipment within a conference room, specifically a CRESTRON system. The screen background is a soft blue, indicating the system is in the process of shutting down. Centrally located, the message reads "A/V System Shutting Down Please Wait," emphasizing the action being taken. Below the text, a circular loading symbol suggests ongoing processing, indicating that the shutdown sequence is initiated. 

The panel's design is clean and functional, with rounded corners and a matte finish that contrasts against the digital display. The word "CRESTRON" is prominently displayed at the bottom, signifying the brand of the control system. There are no additional buttons or controls visible on this screen, focusing solely on the shutdown process. The overall aesthetic is minimalist and user-friendly, guiding users through the shutdown protocol with clear communication on the state of the system. The simplicity of the design aims to reduce confusion and enhance user experience during the shutdown phase.

︗None
These conference rooms each come equipped with a simplified touch panel that can be used to control the video source being used to project to the display in the room as well adjust the audio level for the display. There is a Room PC ("Dedicated PC"), an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Table Laptop"), and a Solstice Pod ("Mersive Wireless").
The image shows a control panel interface designed for audiovisual equipment management in a conference room, specifically part of a CRESTRON system. The panel features a square touch screen with a blue background that displays operational controls for audio and video sources. At the top, there is a "SYSTEM POWER" button, indicating where users can manage the system’s power state.

The central area presents three primary options: "Dedicated PC," "Table Laptop," and "Mersive Wireless," each housed within rounded buttons for easy touch interaction. The layout is designed for intuitive navigation, facilitating quick source selection.

Above the source options, there are icons for volume control, including a speaker symbol for muting, a slider for adjusting the volume level, and a speaker icon on the far right, signifying overall audio settings. The overall color scheme combines various shades of blue, promoting clarity and usability.

The clean, functional design emphasizes user-friendliness, allowing participants to operate the audiovisual system effectively during meetings or presentations. The presence of easily accessible options highlights the room's preparedness for both wired and wireless connectivity.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP addresses have been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image depicts a large flat-screen display mounted on a wall, showing the interface for a Solstice Pod labeled "ATL3373-Pod." The screen features an abstract background characterized by vivid blue and earthy tones, akin to a textured landscape. In the upper left corner, the room designation is prominently displayed, “ATL3373 Pod,” along with the room number, “1259.” 

The current time in the lower right corner reads “10:06 AM,” providing a temporal context. To the right, a set of step-by-step instructions for users is clearly outlined in a user-friendly format. The steps include connecting to the network listed as “INTERNAL,” browsing to the specified address, and connecting. Below these instructions, a note clarifies that Apple users can utilize AirPlay to connect to the pod.

Overall, the interface is designed for ease of use, with a clean layout that ensures accessibility and clarity. The contrasting text color enhances readability against the dynamic background, making it simple for users to engage with the technological setup in the conference room.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "System Power" button and select "Power Off" when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the display for the room.
The image displays a control panel interface designed for managing audiovisual equipment in a conference room. Centrally positioned is a small touch screen encased in a white frame, featuring a blue background. This interface includes two prominent buttons labeled “Power On” and “Power Off,” each displayed in rectangular blue boxes with white text, highlighting their functionalities. The layout is simple and user-friendly, ensuring easy navigation for users who need to operate the audiovisual systems.

On the left side of the screen, there is a backward arrow symbol next to the word “BACK,” which likely allows users to return to the previous menu or options. The overall design emphasizes clarity and accessibility, facilitating swift operation in a conference environment. The minimalist aesthetic, with an absence of clutter, focuses on essential functions, making it straightforward for users to power the system on or off as required. The interface appears to be responsive, aimed at enhancing user experience for everyone utilizing the conference room facilities.

Privacy policy

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/R contains the following information: 






︗R

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
This page contains steps for installing R on Windows.

︗Contents

1 Basic Installation
2 Customized Options
3 Customized Startup Environment
4 Opening R scripts with RScript


︗Basic Installation
To retrieve the latest version of R from here: http://cran.r-project.org/(The prior text links to http://cran.r-project.org/)
Select "Download R for Windows" from the top of the screen
Then click "Install R for the first time" on the first line
This will take you to a download page, click "Download R<version number> for Windows" to begin the installation
Navigate to the directory you downloaded the installer to.
Run the .exe and step through the installer.
The image displays a computer screen showing the "R for Windows 3.1.1 Setup Wizard" interface. The window is bordered by a standard title bar displaying "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1" in the upper-left corner. At the center of the window is a prominent message that welcomes the user to the installation process. The text advises the user that the installation will set up R version 3.1.1 on their computer and recommends closing all other applications before continuing the installation. 

To the right of this message, there is a clickable "Next >" button, encouraging the user to proceed, while at the bottom, a "Cancel" button allows them to exit the setup if they choose not to continue. The background features a simple blue gradient design with an icon representing a computer and installation process, reinforcing the software installation theme. The layout appears clean and user-friendly, with clear instructions and an intuitive interface. Overall, the image conveys a straightforward initiation for users looking to install R software on their Windows operating system.
Note: There will be a warning when you start the installer that says the full installation requires administrative privileges, disregard this message.
The image displays a computer interface for the "R for Windows 3.1.1" setup wizard. The window is rectangular with a light gray background and includes a prominent title bar at the top that reads "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." In the center of the window is an informational message alerting the user that administrative privileges are required for the installation. The message outlines that without these privileges, the user may face limitations in associating R with certain file types.

To the right of the text, an icon representing the letter "R" is present, symbolizing the software. Below the main message, there are three buttons: "Back," "Next," and "Cancel." The "Next" button, highlighted in blue, encourages the user to proceed with the installation, while the "Back" button allows them to revisit the previous screen, and "Cancel" provides an option to exit the setup altogether.

The layout is simple and user-friendly, designed to guide users through the installation process clearly, underscoring the necessity of having proper administrative access.
Accept the License Agreement and continue.
The image depicts a computer screen displaying the "R for Windows 3.1.1 Setup" interface. The interface features a rectangular window with a light gray background and a prominent title bar at the top, labeled "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." In the central portion of the window, there is a message titled "Information," instructing users to read important details before proceeding with the installation.

The main text below highlights the GNU General Public License, elaborating on users' rights regarding software sharing and modification. The content explains that everyone is permitted to copy and distribute the document, emphasizing the importance of freedom in software use.

At the bottom of the window, there are three notable buttons: "Back," "Next," and "Cancel." The "Next" button is highlighted, encouraging users to continue. The layout is designed for clarity and user-friendliness, with a simple aesthetic that remains focused on guiding users effectively through the setup process. An "R" icon is positioned on the right side of the window, symbolizing the software being installed.
When prompted, choose an installation folder wherever you would like it within your home directory.
The image displays a computer interface for the "R for Windows 3.1.1" setup process. The window is rectangular with a light gray background. The top features a title bar labeled "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." Below this, a prominent informational message prompts the user to select a destination location for the R installation, specifying that it will install in the folder displayed. The folder path, "C:\Users\daw\Documents\R\R-3.1.1," is shown in an editable text box, allowing users to navigate or change the installation directory. 

To the right of the text box, there's a "Browse..." button for users who wish to select another location. At the bottom of the interface, there are three navigation buttons: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel." The "Next" button is highlighted, indicating the recommended action to proceed with the installation. Additionally, a note mentions that at least 1.2 MB of free disk space is required, reinforcing the installation requirements. The overall aesthetic is clean and user-friendly, aimed at guiding users through the installation process smoothly.
Select the components that you wish to install, the defaults for this is fine.
The image depicts a computer screen displaying the "R for Windows 3.1.1" installation interface, specifically focused on selecting components to install. The window is rectangular, set against a light gray background, with a title bar at the top that reads "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." 

At the center of the window, there is a heading titled "Select Components," guiding users on which parts of the software to install. Below the heading, a list delineates the components available for installation, including "Core Files," "32-bit Files," "64-bit Files," and "Message Translations," each with a corresponding size in megabytes that indicates the disk space required. 

A dropdown menu labeled "User installation" is visible, allowing users to toggle between different installation options. The checkboxes next to each component are pre-selected, indicating the default recommended choices. 

At the bottom, three navigation buttons are present: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel," with the "Next" button highlighted in blue, indicating it as the primary action for the user to proceed. A message at the bottom states that the current selection requires at least 101.0 MB of disk space, providing users with important installation requirements. Overall, the design is structured to facilitate an easy and informed setup process.
If you wish to customize the options for the startup environment then click Yes when prompted and proceed to the below section. If you are unsure what these are, select "No" (can still be changed later).
The image shows a computer screen displaying the setup interface for "R for Windows 3.1.1." The rectangular window features a light gray background with a clear title bar at the top that reads "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." Centrally located within the window is the title "Startup options," immediately followed by a prompt asking users if they wish to customize the startup options. Two radio buttons are presented: the first labeled "Yes (customized startup)" and the second labeled "No (accept defaults)," allowing users to choose their preferred setup method.

Underneath the options, a clear instruction is provided: "Please specify yes or no, then click Next." This emphasizes user engagement by directing their next action. At the bottom, three navigation buttons are visible: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel," with the "Next" button highlighted to indicate it as the primary call to action. The interface design is straightforward and intuitive, aimed at ensuring a smooth user experience during the installation process. An "R" icon appears on the right side, reinforcing the branding of the software. Overall, the image conveys a simple yet effective setup step, intended for a user-friendly installation experience.
︗Customized Options
Name the folder that will appear in the start menu. The default "R" is acceptable for this.
The image shows a computer screen featuring the "R for Windows 3.1.1 Setup" interface during the process of selecting the Start Menu folder for the software installation. The window is rectangular with a light gray background and includes a title bar at the top that reads "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." 

In the center of the window, there’s a prompt titled "Select Start Menu Folder," instructing users to determine where the program's shortcuts will be placed in the Start Menu. Below this, the text states that the default folder for shortcuts will be "R," which appears in an editable text box. Users can simply click "Next" to accept the default or click the "Browse..." button to choose another location. 

At the bottom of the window, there are three buttons: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel." The "Next" button is highlighted in blue, indicating it's the primary action to proceed. There's also an option to not create a Start Menu folder, indicated by a checkbox. The layout is clean and straightforward, making it easy for users to follow the installation steps with minimal confusion.
Finalize your installation options and hit Next to begin the installation.
The image displays a computer screen showcasing the "R for Windows 3.1.1" installation interface specifically for selecting additional tasks during the setup process. The window is rectangular, set against a light gray background, with a title bar at the top reading "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." 

In the center, the heading "Select Additional Tasks" prompts users to choose optional tasks to perform while installing R. Below this header, there are two sections: "Additional icons" and "Registry entries." Under "Additional icons," a checkbox is marked for "Create a desktop icon," indicating it is the default action. Two more options are provided, "Create a Quick Launch icon" with an empty checkbox and a statement about saving the version number in the registry, also with an empty checkbox.

At the bottom of the window, navigation buttons are displayed: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel," with the "Next" button highlighted in blue, guiding the user to proceed to the next step. The overall design is user-friendly, facilitating an intuitive decision-making process during the R installation.
After stepping through the dialog, R will install itself to the folder you specified.
Finish and close the setup. R is now installed locally on your account.
The image displays a computer screen showcasing the completion interface for the "R for Windows 3.1.1 Setup Wizard." The window is rectangular with a light blue background. ︗Customized Startup Environment
From the customized startup environment options prompt, if you wish to go through the customized startup environment dialog, select "Yes" here. Any of these options can be altered at a later time after installation if you decide you have a change in preference.

The overall layout is designed to be user-friendly, facilitating a smooth decision-making process during the installation.
The first prompt will determine which interface you wish to use. MDI (one main window for all R programs) or SDI (separate windows for each R program) If you have a preference, select which option you prefer.
The image displays a computer interface for the "R for Windows 3.1.1" installation setup, specifically focused on selecting the display mode. The rectangular window features a light gray background and a title bar at the top reading "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." 

At the center of the window, a heading titled "Display Mode" presents the options for the user to choose between two interface styles: "MDI (one big window)" and "SDI (separate windows)." Each option is accompanied by a circular radio button for selection, allowing users to make a straightforward choice regarding their preferred layout for working within the software.

Further instruction is provided beneath the options, advising users to select their preference and then click the "Next >" button to proceed. Below, there are navigation buttons: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel," with the "Next" button highlighted, indicating the recommended action to move forward. An "R" icon appears on the right side of the window, reinforcing the software's branding. Overall, the layout is simple and user-friendly, facilitating easy navigation through the installation process.
Next, determine how you wish the help format to be displayed. You can choose from either plain text format or HTML formatted.
The image displays the setup interface for "R for Windows 3.1.1," specifically focused on selecting the help style. The window is rectangular with a light gray background and a title bar at the top labeled "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." At the center is the heading "Help Style," which prompts users to choose their preferred format for help documentation. 

Two options are available: a circular radio button next to "Plain text" and another next to "HTML help." The user is instructed to select one of these formats before proceeding, with a request to click the "Next" button afterward. The interface appears clean and organized, promoting ease of use. 

Below the options, three navigation buttons are visible: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel," with the "Next" button highlighted to indicate it is the primary action for the user. An "R" icon on the right serves to reinforce the branding of the software. Overall, the layout is user-friendly, designed to ensure a smooth decision-making process for configuring help display preferences during the installation.
Finally, determine how you would like R to handle the proxy settings in Internet Explorer, whether you would like to use the standard settings or make use of internet2.dll.
The image displays a computer interface for the "R for Windows 3.1.1" installation process, focusing on Internet Access settings. The rectangular window has a light gray background, with a title bar at the top that reads "Setup - R for Windows 3.1.1." 

At the center of the window is a prompt regarding the Internet Access configuration, asking if the user wishes to use the "internet2.dll" for Internet Explorer's proxy settings. The question emphasizes the choice between two options, indicated by circular radio buttons: "Standard" and "Internet2." The "Standard" option is highlighted, suggesting it's the default selection, while the "Internet2" option provides an alternative for users who may require different settings.

Instructions guide users to specify their desired setting before clicking the highlighted "Next" button to continue. At the bottom of the interface, there are navigation buttons: "< Back," "Next >," and "Cancel," ensuring straightforward navigation through the installation process. An "R" icon appears on the right side, reinforcing the R software's branding. The design is clean and organized, promoting user engagement and clarity during setup.
The startup environment customization for R is now finished. See the above sections for the following steps.
︗Opening R scripts with RScript
Users can open a file with R to a command terminal window via RScript.

From within the \bin\x64 folder at the location that you installed R to you can run: Rscript path\to\file\test.R

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/UserReport contains the following information: 






︗UserReport

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
All accounts in UMIACS are sponsored by a faculty member.  We provide our faculty members reports to give them information on status of the account(s) they have sponsored.

︗Fields
username - UMIACS username for the account.
uidnumber - Numeric identifier for this accounts UMIACS username.
gidnumber - Numeric identifier for this accounts UMIACS default group.
name - Display name if set or their full name if display name is not set.
sponsors - List of UMIACS usernames for account sponsors (; separator).
groups - List of UMIACS unix groups the user is a member of (; separator).
secgroups - List of UMIACS security groups the user is a member of (; separator).
crs - List of ComputationalResources the user is allowed to access in UMIACS (; separator).
emailtype - How UMIACS handles their username@umiacs.umd.edu email.
installed - Date and time when the account was first installed in UMIACS.
lastlogon - Date and time when the account was last authenticated with a password.  Due to active directory technical design may not be completely accurate in the last 5-14 days.
recoverysms - Does the user have a recovery SMS number on file for automated password resets.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=UserReport&oldid=9316"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Snapshots contains the following information: 






︗Snapshots

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Snapshots are a implementation of copy-on-write(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copy-on-write) that allows for a file system to quickly take a point-in-time copy of the file system and provide access to the data through a .snapshot directory. Snapshots provide a fast, user-accessible way to recover data that has been accidentally deleted or corrupted within a recent time window, rather than having to retrieve the data from comparatively slow tape backups. They also help to span the time gap between  full backups.
We provide snapshots on our Isilon, ZFS, VAST, and Qumulo filers to certain file systems. If you are ever unsure if a particular volume has snapshots enabled, please contact the  Help Desk.

︗Snapshot Retention Policy
Our core file systems are on a 4 hour snapshot cycle.  



Snapshot Name

Retention Length

When is it taken?


Hourly

24-32 hours

Every day 12am, 4am, 8am, 12pm, 4pm


Daily

2 days

Every day 8pm or 12am


Weekly

1 week

Every Saturday 8pm or Sunday 12am

In other words, we retain up to either 6 or 8 hourly snapshots, 2 daily snapshots and 1 weekly snapshot. Hourly snapshots may be superseded by daily snapshots, and daily snapshots may be superseded by the weekly snapshot.

︗Snapshot Restoring
If you have deleted a file by mistake and you need to get it back, you can use the snapshots directory to recopy the file.  It generally will not be visible, even when viewing hidden directories.
It will be either:

.snapshot for the Isilon, VAST, or Qumulo filers
.zfs/snapshot for the ZFS filer
The inside of one of these will look something like:
Isilon filesystem:

$ pwd
/nfshomes/username
$ cd .snapshot
$ ls
nfshomes_2024-09-14_00:00  nfshomes_2024-09-16_04:00                           
nfshomes_2024-09-15_00:00  nfshomes_2024-09-16_08:00                           
nfshomes_2024-09-15_16:00  nfshomes_2024-09-16_12:00                           
nfshomes_2024-09-15_20:00  Weekly_nfshomes_2024-09-08_00:00                    
nfshomes_2024-09-16_00:00  Weekly_nfshomes_2024-09-15_00:00

ZFS filesystem:

$ pwd
/nmhomes/username
$ cd .zfs/snapshot
$ ls
zfs-auto-snap_daily-2024-09-14-2000   zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-16-0000     
zfs-auto-snap_daily-2024-09-15-2000   zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-16-0400     
zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-15-0400  zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-16-0800     
zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-15-0800  zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-16-1200     
zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-15-1200  zfs-auto-snap_weekly-2024-09-14-2000     
zfs-auto-snap_hourly-2024-09-15-1600

For an example of file restoration, please see  this page.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Snapshots&oldid=12025"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Google_Drive contains the following information: 






︗Google Drive

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Google Drive(The prior text links to https://drive.google.com/) is a file storage and synchronization service developed by Google. At UMD, all current faculty, staff, and students have unlimited Google Drive storage when using their UMD-provided account.
Google's overarching documentation for Google Drive can be found here: https://support.google.com/drive/(The prior text links to https://support.google.com/drive/)

︗Desktop Apps
Google currently offers a single unified app to interact with Drive that can be downloaded here (Windows/macOS):

Google Drive for Desktop: https://support.google.com/drive/answer/7329379(The prior text links to https://support.google.com/drive/answer/7329379)
If you previously used Google Drive Backup and Sync, please follow our migration steps  here.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Google_Drive&oldid=10144"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Accounts/Collaborator contains the following information: 






︗Accounts/Collaborator

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
A Collaborator account is a sponsored provisional account for non-UMIACS members that provides access to UMIACS applications such as GitLab,  Object Storage, and MediaWiki instances. Collaborator accounts do not provide login access to UMIACS computers or access to networked file storage. Any access to GitLab repositories,  ObjectStore buckets, etc. fall under their account sponsor and/or the PI.  Access to your group's resources is mediated through Security Groups, which can be managed in our UMIACS Directory Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/secgroup/).

︗None
A UMIACS Account holder has to sponsor the Collaborator Account.   This is done in our UMIACS Requests Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/collaborators/new).  This will send an email to the Collaborator to set their details (including a username and password).  Once the Collaborator has created their account, an email will be sent to both the account sponsor and the Collaborator that the account is ready to use.

︗None
This can be done in the UMIACS Requests Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/collaborators). You can view a list of Collaborators that you directly sponsor. The following management actions are available:

Send Password Reset: An email will be sent to the Collaborator with a link to reset their password.
Remove Sponsorship: Staff will be notified to remove the selected accounts from your sponsorship.
You can also view Collaborators who are sponsored by users that you sponsor. Actions include:

Take Over Sponsorship: Staff will be notified to transfer sponsorship to you, and the original sponsor of the Collaborator will be notified.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Accounts/Collaborator&oldid=12044"

︗Services/Compute/HPC

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS provides integration and maintenance of High Performance Computational (HPC) clusters.

HPC systems at UMIACS are current built on top of RHEL 7 and SLURM.  The individual configuration and scheduler are suited to the needs of each individual group.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/PerlDevelEnvironment contains the following information: 






︗PerlDevelEnvironment

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Currently, there are the following Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) for Perl available on the market. You may wish to try each of them and decide which is best for your tasks. ActiveState (www.activestate.com) is a big player in this field.

UNIX/Linux
The good old emacs or any text editor that does syntax highlighting.
Komodo from ActiveState. It used to be free but not any more. http://www.activestate.com/Products/Komodo/(The prior text links to http://www.activestate.com/Products/Komodo/)
Windows
VisualPerl from ActiveState. This is a plugin for MS Visual Studio .NET. With it, you can write compile and debug perl code all within VS.NET. If you are familiar with VB and VC development, this is the best tool for you.  http://www.activestate.com/Products/Visual_Perl/(The prior text links to http://www.activestate.com/Products/Visual_Perl/)
Komodo from ActiveState. Yes, it's available for Windows too.  http://www.activestate.com/Products/Komodo/(The prior text links to http://www.activestate.com/Products/Komodo/)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=PerlDevelEnvironment&oldid=9078"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Mattermost contains the following information: 






︗Mattermost

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS provides local support for a trusted on premise messaging platform using Mattermost(The prior text links to https://mattermost.com).  It supports direct one to one messaging, teams with public and private channels, extensive search capablities and file sharing.  This is a web based platform hosted in one of our physical on-premise data centers.

 https://mattermost.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://mattermost.umiacs.umd.edu)

This is integrated into our GitLab authentication system with its MFA requirement.  When signing in it will prompt you to use GitLab to login and if you haven't already then log in with the UMIACS Single Single Sign On.
The image displays a user interface screen for "UMIACS Mattermost." At the top, the title is prominently displayed in bold, stating "UMIACS Mattermost." Underneath, there is a tagline that reads, "All team communication in one place, searchable and accessible anywhere," emphasizing the platform's functionality. Below this text, there is a section labeled "Teams you can join," which features a text input box where users can type to search for available teams. The specific team "umiacs" is indicated as an option, suggesting that users can join this team by selecting it. The design is clean and minimalist, with a white background and black text to ensure readability. The layout is intuitive, guiding the user to interact with the input field. The overall aesthetic reinforces the idea of simplicity and efficiency in team communication via the Mattermost platform.
You will be presented with which Teams you would like to join by default and you can select the UMIACS Team.  Faculty, Labs, and Centers may request a private Team for their research groups, labs, or centers by  contacting staff.

︗User Documentation
Mattermost maintains extensive documentation(The prior text links to https://docs.mattermost.com/guides/user.html) about using the service including Teams, Channels and Direct Messages.  It supports rich text messaging formatting(The prior text links to https://docs.mattermost.com/help/messaging/formatting-text.html) including using markdown and other simple techniques.

︗Applications
There are a number of desktop and mobile applications that can be downloaded(The prior text links to https://mattermost.com/download/#mattermostApps).  You will need to enter the URL for our service when using these applications, https://mattermost.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://mattermost.umiacs.umd.edu) to sign in and use the service.

︗Data Retention
Teams will be archived if there is no activity for 6 months within the team channels.  User account data will be archived when their UMIACS accounts are archived.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Mattermost&oldid=10306"
