〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/IntelCompilers contains the following information: 






︗IntelCompilers

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search

On any RedHat host we have support for using the new  Intel® C/C++ Composer XE for Linux and Intel® Fortran Composer XE for Linux and some of the older version of the C/C++ and Fortan compilers that were shipped by Intel.
To setup your environment you will need to either load a  GNU Module file or source some config files depending on your shell and architecture.

︗Module File
Rather than sourcing the scripts as mentioned below, you can load a pre-configured  GNU Module file to the same end. You can run the following on RHEL7+/Ubuntu hosts to prepare your environment for either C/C++ or Fortran compilation:

   module load intel/2020.1

︗None

Intel C/C++ Versions


Version

RHEL7+/Ubuntu Path


10.0.026

/opt/common/intel/cc/10.0.026


11.1

/opt/common/intel/Compiler/11.1/current


2011.1

/opt/common/intel/composerxe-2011


13.1.1

/opt/common/intel/composer_xe_2013_sp1.1.106

To use a version you need to source the bin/iccvars.csh for tcsh/csh users or bin/iccvars.sh for bash users.  Additionally you need to specify the architecture on the command line when sourcing. For 32bit users that is ia32 and for 64bit that is intel64.
Example for a tcsh/csh user using the 64bit 13.1.1 version of the compiler on a RHEL7+ host:

  source /opt/common/intel/composer_xe_2013_sp1.1.106/bin/iccvars.csh intel64

You can then use the icpc to compile with the Intel C++ Compiler or icc to compile with the Intel C Compiler.

︗Fortran

Intel Fortran Versions


Version

RHEL7+/Ubuntu Path


10.0.026

/opt/common/intel/fc/10.0.026


11.1

/opt/common/intel/Compiler/11.1/current


2011.1

/opt/common/intel/composerxe-2011


13.1.1

/opt/common/intel/composer_xe_2013_sp1.1.106

To use a version you need to source the bin/ifortvars.csh for tcsh/csh users or bin/ifortvars.sh for bash users.  Additionally you need to specify the architecture on the command line when sourcing. For 32bit users that is ia32 and for 64bit that is intel64.
Example for a tcsh/csh user using the 64bit 13.1.1 version of the compiler on a RHEL7+ host:

  source /opt/common/intel/composer_xe_2013_sp1.1.106/bin/ifortvars.csh intel64

You can then use the ifort command to compile with the Intel Fortran Compiler.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=IntelCompilers&oldid=9426"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/MacOSPrinting contains the following information: 






︗MacOSPrinting

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
We support printing from user managed macOS 13.x or later machines. 
Note: You must be on a UMIACS network directly or connected to the VPN in order to print.

︗System Settings
To start, open your System Settings from the Dock or Applications folder.  Once you have opened it, click Printers & Scanners.
The image displays the "Printers & Scanners" section of macOS System Settings. The interface is set against a soft gradient background, featuring a warm tone that transitions from light beige to pale yellow. On the left side, a vertical sidebar includes various options such as "Desktop & Dock," "Displays," "Wallpaper," and others, with "Printers & Scanners" highlighted in blue to indicate selection.

In the main area, there is a title labeled "Printers & Scanners" at the top. Below this title, the section states "No Printers" indicating that no printers are currently configured. The right-hand side contains fields showing "Default printer" as "Last Printer Used" and "Default paper size" as "US Letter." There is a prominent button labeled "Add Printer, Scanner, or Fax..." situated at the bottom of the window, allowing users to initiate the process of adding a new printer. The overall layout is clean and minimalistic, embodying Apple’s design ethos of simplicity and user-friendliness.

︗None
On the Printers & Scanners page,  create a new local printer by clicking the Add Printer, Scanner, or Fax... button that is below the printer list.

︗Add Printer
This will bring up the Add Printer dialog.

Note: If you just want basic printing, use the steps below. If you would like to enable all the advanced options for the printer, jump over this section to "Enabling Advanced Printer Options".


Jump over to the IP tab
Set Protocol to Internet Printing Protocol - IPP
Set Address to print.umiacs.umd.edu
Set the Queue to printers/queue; in this example for cps432-3208 it would be printers/cps432-3208.  You have to make sure the queue is prefixed by printers/. For clarification, the queue is typically the printer name.
Set Name to the name of the printer you are trying to use. This makes it easily Identifiable in your list of printers.
It will always select Generic Postscript Printer.  If you need to access the more advanced features of a queue/printer or you were not able to print by choosing Generic Postscript Printer, you will need to take extra steps, please see the Advanced section at the bottom of this page.
Select Add
You will be asked about enabling duplex. If you know the printer has the option, which is true for most of our printers, go ahead and enable it. Then hit OK. If you're not sure, just leave it disabled. You can always enable it after the queue is added.
The image shows a dialog box for adding a printer in the macOS user interface. The window features a clean and minimalistic design typical of Apple products, with rounded corners and a soft white background. At the top, there are icons representing different functionalities related to printers and network connections. 

The main area includes several labeled fields:

- **Address:** This field displays "print.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating a network printer's address.
- **Protocol:** The selected option reads "Internet Printing Protocol - IPP," suggesting that this is a networked printer setup.
- **Queue:** This specifies "printers/cps432-3208," showing the designated printer queue for this specific printer.
- **Name:** The user has entered "Color Printer 3208" in this field, indicating the desired name for easy identification.
- **Location:** The location field states "IRB 3208," presumably where the printer is situated.
- **Use:** The option for printing has been set to "Generic PostScript Printer," suggesting a default driver choice.

At the bottom right corner, a prominent "Add" button is available, inviting users to complete the configuration. The overall appearance is intuitive and user-friendly, focused on streamlining the printer setup process.
You should now be able to print to this printer/queue from any macOS print menu.

︗Enabling Advanced Printer Features
Some printers may have features not accessible with the default drivers provided above. If this is the case, follow the guide below to identify, and install your print drivers from their manufacturer.

Note: If you already installed the printer with generic drivers, you will need to highlight the printer and click -, before attempting to add it again. You may also need a system update to get the latest drivers from Apple, if your printer does not have software drivers listed in the next steps.

Step 1:  Locate your printers name and search for its Make and Model here: http://print.umiacs.umd.edu/printers/(The prior text links to http://print.umiacs.umd.edu/printers/)

Step 2:  Follow the Add Printer steps above until you get to Generic Postscript Printer. Select Software, then Add.

The image illustrates a dialog box for adding a printer within the macOS interface. It features a sleek, modern design consistent with Apple's aesthetic, characterized by rounded corners and a soft white background. At the top of the window, there are small icons representing printer functionalities, including network connectivity.

The main section contains labeled fields where users input relevant information to configure the printer. The "Address" field displays "print.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating the network address for the printer. The "Protocol" field shows "Internet Printing Protocol - IPP," specifying the method of connection. In the "Queue" field, "printers/cps432-3208" denotes the printer's designated queue.

A "Name" field contains "Color Printer 3208," which identifies the printer, while the "Location" field states "IRB 3208," suggesting the physical location of the printer. The "Use" dropdown shows "Generic PostScript Printer," highlighting the selected driver for printing tasks.

At the bottom right, a prominent "Add" button invites users to finalize their setup. The overall interface is user-friendly, designed to facilitate seamless printer configurations.

Step 3:  A window labeled "Printer Software" will now pop up. Scroll through the list to find your specific make and model of printer. Click on it, and hit Ok.
NOTE: If you cannot find the printer's make and model and need Advanced Printing Features, try downloading the drivers from Apple's website(The prior text links to https://support.apple.com/kb/dl1888?locale=en_US%7C) and reinstalling the printer from step 1.
The image is a user interface window from a macOS device, showcasing the "Printer Software" selection dialog. The window features a minimalist design typical of Apple's aesthetic, with a soft white background and rounded corners. At the top, there is a search field labeled "Filter," allowing users to quickly narrow down printer options. Below this, a list displays various printer models, including the DYMO Label Printer, multiple Epson models, a range of HP DeskJet Series printers, and several Oki and Zebra label printers. Each entry is presented in a straightforward manner, with the printer names clearly legible. At the bottom of the window, two buttons are visible: "Cancel" on the left, allowing users to exit without making changes, and "OK" on the right, highlighted in blue, prompting the user to confirm their selection. This interface enhances user interaction by making printer selection intuitive and efficient, reflecting Apple's commitment to usability and design elegance.
Step 4:  Click Add on the next window and it should install your printer's software suite. You should have a list of options (if they are available) that looks similar this:
The image is a dialog box from the macOS interface labeled "Add Printer," displaying the setup options for a printer named "Color Printer 3208." The design reflects Apple's clean and minimalist aesthetic, featuring rounded corners and a soft white background. At the top, a small icon representing a printer is prominently displayed, providing a visual cue about the dialog's purpose. 

The main body of the dialog consists of a message that instructs users to verify that their printer's options are accurately shown to utilize its features fully. Below this message, there is a checkbox labeled "Duplex Printing Unit," which indicates whether the printer is equipped to handle double-sided printing. The checkbox is currently unchecked, allowing users to enable this feature if applicable.

At the bottom right, two buttons are visible: "Cancel," allowing users to exit the dialog without changes, and "OK," highlighted in blue, inviting users to confirm the settings. The overall layout emphasizes usability, making the printer setup straightforward and intuitive for users.
Final Step: Enable the Options you wish to use, Click OK.  You should now be able to print to this printer/queue from any macOS print menu.

︗Printing With Stapler
For print jobs using the stapler, follow the guide below.  Printers with staplers are located in Iribe, in rooms 3149, 3208, 4149, 4208, and 5208.
To add/ connect to a printer with stapling capabilities:

Step 1: Follow the "Enabling Advanced Printer Features" guide until you reach Step 4.

Step 2: In the window that appears labeled "Setting up [your printer name]" set "HP 3-Bin Stapler/Stacker" to "Mailbox Mode".

The image depicts a macOS dialog box titled "Setting up ‘5208 Printer w/ Stapler...’." This sleek window features a dark gray background, consistent with Apple's minimalist design principles. At the top left is a small printer icon, indicating the type of configuration being addressed.

The main body of the dialog consists of a clear message prompting users to ensure that the printer's options are displayed accurately. Below, there are several fields labeled "Tray 3," "Tray 4," "Tray 5," and "Tray 6," each indicating "Not Installed," showing the current status of these trays. 

At the bottom, a section specifically addresses the "HP 3-Bin Stapler/Stacker," where users can select "Mailbox Mode" as an operational setting. A checkbox labeled "Require User Access Code" is also present, allowing for an optional security feature.

At the bottom right corner, there are two buttons: "Cancel," which allows users to exit the dialog without saving changes, and "OK," highlighted in blue, inviting users to confirm their printer setup choices. The interface is designed for ease of use, ensuring a straightforward configuration process for advanced printer features.

Step 3: Select "OK" in the bottom right corner.

To Print: To complete the print job using the stapler once the printer has been added:

Step 1: In Preview, when trying to print, select the "Show Details" button in the bottom left corner.

The provided image shows a print dialog interface from a macOS system, specifically designed for printing documents. The layout is clean and minimalist, consistent with Apple's design philosophy. 

At the top of the dialog, the selected printer is identified as "5208." Below, various options for printing parameters are displayed. The "Presets" dropdown is set to "Default Settings." Users can specify the number of copies to print, currently set to one, and there is a checkbox for "Two-Sided" printing, indicating the option for duplex printing is available. 

In the "Pages" section, the selection is set to "All," and under "Paper Size," "US Letter" is indicated, showing the dimensions suitable for standard letter-sized paper (8.50 by 11.00 inches). The "Orientation" section has icons for portrait and landscape layouts. 

Furthermore, an "Auto Rotate" box is checked to automatically adjust page orientation if needed. The "Scale" is set to 92%, with an option to "Fit Entire Image" or "Fill Entire Paper." 

At the bottom, two buttons are present: "Cancel," allowing users to abort the operation, and "Print," highlighted in blue, inviting users to initiate the printing process. The interface overall emphasizes user-friendliness and clarity in selecting printing options.

Step 2: In the middle right, where it says "Preview," select "Printer Features" instead of "Preview".

The image displays a macOS print dialog interface for a printer labeled "5208." The design follows Apple's minimalist aesthetic, featuring a soft gray background with rounded corners. At the top, the selected printer is identified, and several options allow users to customize their printing preferences. The "Presets" dropdown is set to "Default Settings," with the option for copies set to one and a checkbox for "Two-Sided" printing, indicating duplex capabilities. 

The "Pages" section specifies "All," meaning the entire document will print, while the "Paper Size" is set to "US Letter," which corresponds to standard dimensions of 8.50 by 11.00 inches. Below, orientation options are represented by icons for both portrait and landscape, accompanied by an "Auto Rotate" option. The "Scale" is pre-set to 92%, with alternative fitting options available.

At the bottom of the window, two buttons labeled "Cancel" and "Print" invite user interaction, with the "Print" button highlighted in blue for emphasis. The overall layout supports intuitive navigation, reinforcing ease of use in the printing process.

Step 3: Set "Feature Sets" to "Finishing".

The image shows a macOS print dialog interface for the printer labeled "5208," following Apple's sleek, minimalist design ethos. The top section identifies the selected printer and includes a "Presets" dropdown set to "Default Settings," with options for "Copies" set to one. There’s a checkbox for "Two-Sided" printing, indicating the printer's capability for duplex printing.

This interface showcases a well-organized layout, emphasizing user-friendly navigation and clear functionality.

Step 4: A "Staple" dropdown list will appear at the bottom of the window.  Select your preferred staple option.

The image shows a macOS print dialog interface labeled for the printer "5208." The layout adheres to Apple's minimalist design style, featuring a soft gray background and rounded corners. At the top of the dialog, the printer’s name is displayed alongside the "Presets" dropdown, set to "Default Settings," which allows users to select their preferred print options.

In the "Orientation" section, icons representing portrait and landscape layouts are present, alongside an "Auto Rotate" feature. The "Scale" is adjusted to 92%, with options to “Fit Entire Image” or “Fill Entire Paper” also available.

At the bottom, various functional buttons are displayed: "Cancel," allowing users to abort the print job, and "Print," prominently highlighted in blue, encouraging the initiation of printing. An "Output Bin" dropdown offers choices for the output location, and a "Staple" feature set is ready to choose from, enhancing the dialog's usability for advanced printing options.

Step 5: Press "Print" in the bottom right corner.

︗Printing Stored Jobs
Pre-requisite: Requires  advanced print features to be enabled.
If you are printing a sensitive document and do not want the printer to print it right away, you can configure a stored job. The stored job lets you hold a print job until you enter a PIN to release the job. You can configure a stored job following the instructions below:

Go to File > Print or Press Command + P to open the Printer menu.
Select the printer where you want to send the print job.
Click the dropdown list under Copies & Pages and select Job Storage.
The image displays a macOS print dialog for a printer named "B/W Printer 3208." The layout follows Apple's minimalist design, featuring a dark background with a clean, organized structure. At the top, the printer selection shows "B/W Printer 3208," accompanied by a dropdown for "Presets" set to "Default Settings." Below, there is a section labeled "Copies & Pages," with options displayed in a dropdown menu for various printing parameters like layout, color matching, and finishing options. The current selection for copies is set to one.

To the left, a preview area shows a faint image, hinting at the document intended for printing. Users can indicate the specific pages to print, with a range input available. The bottom area contains functional buttons: "Cancel," allowing users to exit the dialog without changes, and "Print," highlighted in blue, prompting the user to proceed with printing. Overall, the interface presents a user-friendly experience for configuring print jobs while adhering to Apple’s design principles of simplicity and clarity.
From the Mode dropdown list, select Personal Job (or Stored Job if you want to share the document with others).
The image presents a macOS print dialog interface specifically for a printer labeled "B/W Printer 3208." The design adheres to Apple's minimalist aesthetic, featuring a dark background that enhances readability. At the top, users can see the selected printer name prominently displayed alongside a dropdown menu for "Presets," set to "Default Settings." The interface includes a section labeled "Mode," where the user has selected "Personal Job" from a list that also includes options like "Quick Copy" and "Proof and Hold."

Below this, there are fields for the job name, where "The Jedi Manifest" is entered, and a checkbox for the "Use PIN to Print" option, indicating that a 4-digit PIN is required to release the job. The bottom area features two buttons: "Cancel," allowing users to exit without making changes, and "Print," highlighted in blue to emphasize the action. At the bottom left, text informs users that the job will be stored on the printer and printed only upon PIN entry. The overall interface is intuitive, emphasizing ease of use while adhering to Apple's focus on clarity and functionality.
Leave the username to default or specify a custom username.
Check the box Use PIN to Print and enter a 4-digit number. Hit Print.
The image displays a macOS print dialog interface for the "B/W Printer 3208." The background is dark, following Apple's minimalist design, and features clear, organized fields. At the top, the selected printer is labeled, along with a dropdown menu for "Presets" set to "Default Settings." 

The central section contains a dropdown under "Modes," where "Personal Job" is chosen, indicating that the print job is intended for private storage and retrieval. Below that, the user is prompted to fill in a "Job Name" field, which currently displays "The Jedi Manifest," suggesting a customized title for easy identification. 

There is an option to check a box labeled "Use PIN to Print," emphasizing that a four-digit PIN will be necessary to release this stored job at the printer. 

The bottom of the dialog features two functional buttons: "Cancel" for exiting without changes and "Print," prominently highlighted in blue, encouraging the user to proceed. An instructional note clarifies that the job will not print until the PIN is entered at the printer's control panel. Overall, the interface is designed for user-friendliness and clarity in managing print jobs securely.
To print the stored jobs:

From the Home screen of the printer tap on Print from Job Storage (or Print > Print from Job Storage).
In the Stored Job to Print screen, select the name of the folder where the job is stored. By default, the name of the folder will be your username unless you customized it earlier.
Select the name of the document and enter the PIN.
Hit Print.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SFTP contains the following information: 






︗SSHFileTransferProtocol

From UMIACS
(Redirected from SFTP)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
SSH File Transfer Protocol (SFTP(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSH_file_transfer_protocol)) is a network protocol used to securely transfer and manage files on remote systems.  SFTP is layered on top of the SSH protocol, and is preferred over FTP as a method of remote file transfer.
Warning: running interactive programs in your shell initialization files, such as starting another shell, causes SFTP to fail. See Shell on how to correctly change the shell you are using

︗Connecting to an SFTP Server
Under Red Hat Enterprise Linux, Ubuntu Linux, and macOS, the following command from a terminal will connect a client computer to a remote host.

sftp bkirz@$HOSTNAME.umiacs.umd.edu 
Replace $HOSTNAME with the name of the host you are trying to connect.
For UMIACS supported Windows hosts, a SFTP client is already installed. For other hosts, you can download and install winSCP(The prior text links to http://winscp.net/eng/download.php), which will enable SSH and SFTP access.

︗Further Information
More information about SFTP can be found at http://www.openssh.org/(The prior text links to http://www.openssh.org/).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=SSHFileTransferProtocol&oldid=10384"

︗PrinterTroubleshooting

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Common Printing Error Solutions
If you are having trouble trying to print a PDF, try the following: 


Choose File >>> Print, and then click Advanced.
The image displays a computer interface for print settings, specifically within a dialog box titled "Print." The interface is predominantly light gray with black and white text. At the top, the box shows the name of the document to be printed, "C:\Users\user\Documents," alongside other tabs including "Properties" and "Advanced." Below, there are several sections labeled "Page to Print," "Print Range," and "Page Sizing & Handling."

The "Page Sizing & Handling" area contains options like "Fit," "Poster," "Multiple," and "Booklet," with "Fit" selected, suggesting the user wants to scale the document to fit the page size. The "Scan Options" area includes checkboxes for selections like "Duplex" and "Choose paper source by PDF page size." 

In the bottom right corner, buttons labeled "Print," "Cancel," and "Page Setup" are visible. Overall, the layout signifies a straightforward printing interface, enabling users to customize their print settings effectively before finalizing the print job.
Click to enlarge image
Select the Print As Image check box, and click Ok. Then click print.
The image features a computer dialogue box titled "Advanced Print Setup," set against a light gray background. This interface is likely from a printing software, such as Adobe Acrobat, and provides various options for configuring print settings. At the top, there are two drop-down menus: one for selecting the PostScript language version, with "Language Level 2" already indicated, and another for font and resource policy settings, where the option "Send by Range" is selected.

Below these menus, the panel presents checkboxes for different options: “Download Asian Fonts,” “Discolored background correction,” and various color management settings. Three specific checkboxes stand out: “Let printer determine colors,” “Treat grays as K-only grays,” and options related to preserving specific color formats. 

A prominent checkbox labeled “Print As Image” is highlighted, suggesting it is the primary focus of this setup. The lower section contains buttons labeled "OK," "Cancel," and possibly options for additional commands not fully visible. The overall design is simple and functional, emphasizing clarity for user interaction.
Click to enlarge image
For more information visit Adobe quick fix(The prior text links to http://helpx.adobe.com/acrobat/kb/quick-fix-print-pdf-image.html).

For other printing errors try the following:


If using Windows, try using a pcl queue for MS/Office applications and a ps queue for Adobe applications.
Try using a different printer model.
Try using a different print queue.
New print queues can be added with directions for respective operating systems on our printing page.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SetGID contains the following information: 






︗SetGID

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The setgid bit works in two ways, one for files and one for directories.

︗SetGID Files
The setgid bit for files will force when a file is executed to set its group ID to the GID that of the binary instead of the user that is running it.  This mode has no effect for files that are not executable.  To a lesser extent than SetUID this can lead to security issues when the group in question has some files that would be allowed to be read or written when otherwise not permitted.  There are very limited uses for this feature these days and its use is discouraged.

︗SetGID Directories
SetGID directories have a much more benign behavior.  When this bit is set on a directory all filesystem creations underneath that directory will inherit the group from the directory.  UMIACS policy is to keep users' default UID and GID.  So for users who wish to have certain directory trees have consistent groups the use of SetGID directories is useful.  The SetGID directory bit will force all files created under that directory to have the same GID.  Any directories created will also be given the same GID and the SetGID bit so that the same policy is applied at the next level of directory down.
Before we give an example of how to use the sticky bit please see the documentation about umask.  SetGID will only work on the GID and the setting a sticky bit and will not change any other permissions.  By default the umask is 022 and is a bit too restrictive for the use of SetGID effectively.  (002 or 007 will be the appropriate setting depending if you want Others to be able to read/execute or not)
First an example of what our default group is and what other groups we belong to:

[username@novelty ~/staff]$ id
uid=9001(username) gid=29001(username) groups=15114(umadmin),29001(username)

Now we have created a directory called staff that we want to share with the umadmin group (which is not my default group)

[username@novelty ~/staff]$ ls -la .
drwxr-xr-x  2 username username   96 Jun 16 11:34 .

We are going to set the new group to umadmin and set rwxrwxr-x permissions.  Then finally we will add the SetGID bit.

[username@novelty ~/staff]$ chgrp umadmin .
[username@novelty ~/staff]$ chmod 775 .
[username@novelty ~/staff]$ chmod g+s .

Now you can see we have a directory that is correctly set up,

[username@novelty ~/staff]$ ls -la .
drwxrwsr-x  2 username umadmin   96 Jun 16 11:34 .

We are going to use umask of 002 since we want to allow others to read the files.
We are going to now create a test file and test directory,

[username@novelty ~/staff]$ touch test
[username@novelty ~/staff]$ mkdir testdir

Now as you can see we have the correct groups and permissions being used to create both files directories,

[username@novelty ~/staff]$ ls -la
drwxrwsr-x  3 username umadmin   96 Jun 16 12:58 .
-rw-rw-r--  1 username umadmin    0 Jun 16 12:58 test
drwxrwsr-x  2 username umadmin   96 Jun 16 12:58 testdir





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=SetGID&oldid=9837"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/Mailroom contains the following information: 






︗Iribe/Mailroom

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search

The mailroom is located in room 5109.

If you are  ordering items through UMIACS, UMIACS staff is automatically notified by the mailroom when packages are ready for pickup. We will bring them to the UMIACS HelpDesk for processing, and then contact you when items are ready for pickup.

Otherwise, you can have items you order shipped to
<your name>
5109 Brendan Iribe Center for Computer Science and Engineering 
8125 Paint Branch Drive
College Park, MD 20742
The mailroom will then contact you when items are ready for pickup.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Perl contains the following information: 






︗Perl

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Perl is a general-purpose programming language originally developed for text manipulation and now used for a wide range of tasks including system administration, web development, network programming, GUI development, and more.
The language is intended to be practical (easy to use, efficient, complete) rather than beautiful (tiny, elegant, minimal). Its major features are that it's easy to use, supports both procedural and object-oriented (OO) programming, has powerful built-in support for text processing, and has one of the world's most impressive collections of third-party modules.

︗Contents

1 Perl Versions

1.1 RHEL
1.2 Ubuntu
1.3 Windows


2 Installing Modules
3 Documentation


︗Perl Versions
While most modern operating systems ship with a version of Perl, UMIACS also maintains multiple versions.

︗RHEL
For RHEL, different versions of Perl can be found via  GNU Modules.
The versions in /usr have PerlLocalLib support to allow users an easy way to install and maintain their own perl modules:
RHEL 7
/usr/bin/perl -  5.16.3
/opt/local/stow/perl-5.10.1
/opt/local/stow/perl-5.18.4
/opt/local/stow/perl-5.20.2
︗Ubuntu
For Ubuntu hosts, different version of Perl can be install through the  Ubuntu Software Center 
The versions in /usr and /opthave PerlLocalLib support to allow users an easy way to install and maintain their own perl modules:
Ubuntu Trusty 14.04
/usr/bin/perl - 5.18.2
︗Windows
ActiveState Perl can be installed on your PC upon request. Contact staff(The prior text links to mailto:staff@umiacs.umd.edu) for details.
If you find that you need a version of Perl that is not readily available, you can always build it from source.(The prior text links to http://www.cpan.org/src/)

︗Installing Modules
In order to ensure backwards compatibility and functionality, we prefer that users create their own installations of perl modules so that we can keep the central versions of Perl as vanilla as possible. The following instructions will show you how to  setup and install local copies of Perl Modules.

︗Documentation
You can find full documentation for any version of Perl at  http://www.cpan.org/modules/INSTALL.html(The prior text links to http://www.cpan.org/modules/INSTALL.html). You can also find Perl tutorials (which can be fonud under the Manuals menu).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Perl&oldid=9428"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/LDAP contains the following information: 






︗LDAP

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol
UMIACS uses this for a variety of system information and for most users it is the source of authentication and can be used to lookup users, offices and email addresses of UMIACS users.

Server - ldap://ldap.umiacs.umd.edu
BaseDN - dc=umiacs,dc=umd,dc=edu
People - ou=people,dc=umiacs,dc=umd,dc=edu




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=LDAP&oldid=4865"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/OBJ contains the following information: 






︗OBJ

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 UMIACS Object Store
2 Terminology
3 Getting Started
4 Buckets
5 Keys (files)
6 Hosting a Website in your Bucket
7 Deleting Keys (files)
8 Clients
9 Access Key and Secret Key
10 LabGroups
11 Managing LabGroups
12 Requesting a LabGroup


︗UMIACS Object Store
An object store is a web-based storage solution focused on reliability, scalability and security. It is best suited for public content storage/distribution, archiving data or secure data sharing between users. Our Object Store can be used through the web interface(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj), the command line UMobj utilities, third-party graphical  clients, and even programmatically using many popular programming languages.  We support a subset of the Amazon Simple Storage Services (S3) API(The prior text links to http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/Welcome.html), built around a technology called Ceph(The prior text links to http://ceph.com/).

︗Terminology
S3-like storage thinks in terms of buckets and keys. Keys are analogous to files. A bucket is simply a container to a set of keys. There is no actual hierarchy inside of a bucket, but the standard UNIX path separator, a forward slash (/) at the end of a Key name, is interpreted by many clients (including this web site and our UMobj utilities) as being a directory delimiter. This allows you to copy data from your local filesystems to your buckets through umobj or third-party clients. You may specify who has what types of access to your buckets via Access Control Lists (ACLs) at the bucket level or the individual key level.
Your data is protected from individual machine failure via replication within the cluster. All data is checksummed in accordance with the Amazon S3 protocol to ensure that data in transit is valid before it is accepted by the cluster. However, there are no backups or snapshots of this data in the cluster, so if a user deletes a key or bucket in the Object Store, there is no way to restore that information.

︗Getting Started
UMIACS users are allocated 50GB of storage.  Faculty are allocated 10TB. To get started, log in(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj) and you will be redirected to the initial help page.  You can also find the link from our https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu) site as "OBJbox Object Store".

︗Buckets
You can create and browse your buckets (containers that hold data) by visiting your buckets(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/buckets/) page. You can also set bucket-level Access Control Lists (ACLs) from this page. Bucket-level ACLs get implicitly inherited to all the keys within the bucket. However, individual keys can have additional specific ACLs applied for more granular control.
Bucket names must be unique. When you create a bucket it will notify you if the name is already taken.

︗None
After selecting a bucket, you will be able to create folders and upload files within that bucket. Listed files can be downloaded, deleted, or assigned a specific ACL by the key owner/creator.
Please note: Local file system ownership and permissions, and special files (such as symlinks) can not be represented in the Object Store. We highly suggest that if you are securing data into the Object Store and need these to be faithfully maintained that you use a local archive tool (tar, zip, etc..) to collect the data and then upload the resulting archive file(s).

︗Hosting a Website in your Bucket
Please visit OBJ/WebHosting for more information.

︗None
Within the web interface you can delete files one-by-one. If you want to remove a bunch of files, you will need to use a different client as described below.
This is dangerous as there are no backups of files in the Object Store. Be careful to only delete the data you intend to delete.

︗Clients
There are several clients that can be used (sometimes with a limited set of features) on your desktop to gain access to the Object Store. All supported UMIACS systems running RHEL8 have a copy of our UMobj(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/staff/umobj/blob/master/README.md#umobj) utilities preinstalled which provide command line access to the Object Store. We also have an article in our wiki on  third party clients that lists and explains the details. These clients need to be configured with your Access and Secret Keys as described below.

︗Access Key and Secret Key
Each user has one or more pairs of Access Keys and Secret Keys that are used as a credential to not expose your password when using the Object Store. These can be obtained by clicking on your username(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/user/) in the upper right-hand corner. You'll use these to identify and authenticate yourself to the Object Store.
Please treat your Secret Key(s) the same as a password and do not plaintext it over email/otherwise or share it with any other individuals.
When using the umobj(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/staff/umobj/blob/master/README.md#umobj) utilities, you will need to make sure you have added these credentials in your local shell initialization files. There are links to files that have these automatically generated for the 3 most popular UNIX shell families (bash/sh, csh/tcsh, and zsh). Please make sure that whatever file(s) you copy these credentials into can not be read by other users (eg. chmod 600 filename).
Note: Each Access Key and Secret Key are specific to a particular object store, so if you are accessing multiple object stores you may want to write the credentials for each to separate files and then source each file when you want to use the associated object store. Please  contact staff if you have any questions.

︗LabGroups
LabGroups allow a group of users to share data while avoiding the need for complex ACLs by maintaining group ownership. Designated LabGroup managers can grant granular access (read, write, full control, manager) to buckets owned by the LabGroup. All objects owned by a LabGroup count against the group quota. LabGroups can be navigated using the menu with username in the top right corner of the page. Note: this will only appear if you are a member of at least one LabGroup. At this point, you can browse the Object Store as the LabGroup and obtain your unique Access Key and Secret Key pair using the instructions above. To switch to another LabGroup or back to your own buckets, click the menu again and select another user or group.

︗Managing LabGroups
LabGroups have many different levels of membership: Managers, FULL_CONTROL, READ/WRITE, and READ. Managers can add or remove LabGroup Members while every other access level cannot. If you hold the Manager role in a LabGroup, you can add and remove users using the Manage LabGroups(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/labgroup/list/) page, which is available under the Manage menu at the top of the page. After selecting a LabGroup, you can add users by typing their username into the search field and selecting a membership role.

︗Requesting a LabGroup
To request a LabGroup for your project, please  contact staff.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=OBJ&oldid=11801"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/OpenCVVersions contains the following information: 






︗OpenCVVersions

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Windows

1.1 Without CUDA
1.2 Visual Studio Project Set-Up
1.3 More Information




︗Windows
These directions are for 64-bit systems.
First, we install OpenCV

Download the desired version of OpenCV from here(The prior text links to https://opencv.org/releases/)
Double click the downloaded executable to install, and select  run at the prompt
Choose a home directory as installation location  home directory as shown below, where "username" is the actual username.
Click extract, to install OpenCV files
The image depicts a graphical user interface (GUI) window for a file extraction process using the 7-Zip application. The window is titled "7-Zip self-extracting archive." At the top, there is a title bar showing the application's name. Below this title is the extraction path field labeled "Extract to," which displays a default filepath: "C:\Users\username\Documents\". This is where the extracted files will be saved. The window features two buttons at the bottom: "Extract" on the left and "Cancel" on the right, allowing the user to proceed with or abort the extraction process.

The background of the window showcases a blurred view of a Windows 7 desktop, characterized by its iconic blue taskbar and the vibrant color scheme of the Windows logo in the lower right corner. The overall design of the window follows the standard aesthetic of older Windows operating systems, with a simple and functional layout. The image conveys a sense of computer usage, highlighting the process of file management and software installation typical in operating system interactions.
Click to enlarge
︗Without CUDA

The path to the folder you extracted is from here on refered to as {OPENCV}

Next, we setup environmental variables

Navigate to Control Panel -> System and Security -> System
Select Advanced system settings from the sidebar
In the Advanced tab click the Environment Variables... button
Check if a Variable called Path exists in the list of user variables (the top variables)
If it exists, click edit to edit the variable, and add a semicolon, then the following to the end of the Path value {OPENCV}\build\x64\vc10\bin
If it does not, press the New button and set the variable name to Path and the value to the path to your opencv directory ({OPENCV})
︗Visual Studio Project Set-Up
Go to Project -> Properties
Configuration Properties -> C/C++ -> General
Additional Include Directories...add: '{OPENCV}\build\include;'
Configuration Properties -> VC++ Directories
Executable Directories...add: '{OPENCV}\build\x64\vc10\bin;'
Library Directories...add: '{OPENCV}\build\x64\vc10\lib;{OPENCV}\build\x64\vc10\staticlib;'
︗More Information
For using OpenCV with Visiual Studio; http://docs.opencv.org/doc/tutorials/introduction/windows_install/windows_install.html#windows-installation(The prior text links to http://docs.opencv.org/doc/tutorials/introduction/windows_install/windows_install.html#windows-installation)
For using OpenCV with CUDA; http://blog.cuvilib.com/2011/03/22/how-to-build-opencv-2-2-with-gpu-cuda-on-windows-7/(The prior text links to http://blog.cuvilib.com/2011/03/22/how-to-build-opencv-2-2-with-gpu-cuda-on-windows-7/)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=OpenCVVersions&oldid=9077"

︗UbuntuPrinting

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Overview
Printing from your personal Ubuntu laptop or desktop is supported.  If you are sitting at a supported UMIACS Ubuntu LTS desktop then please see our common UNIX/Linux printing documentation for CUPS.  This documentation may not work for all versions of Ubuntu.

︗Printer Accessibility
In order to print you will need to be on the UMIACS internal network, either via a wired proxy drop or an SSH tunnel.

︗Connecting to a printer
In order for printing to function properly, you must complete ALL of the following steps:

Open your system settings and search for the 'Printers' dialog box.
Click "Additional Settings" and "Add" in the new box that pops up. This will bring up the 'New Printer' dialog box.
The image depicts a graphical user interface (GUI) from an Ubuntu operating system, focusing on the printer settings. The left side of the screen displays a vertical menu labeled "Devices," which includes options for "Displays," "Keyboard," "Mouse & Touchpad," "Printers," "Removable Media," "Thunderbolt," "Wacom Tablet," and "Color." 

In the main window on the right, a message reads "No printers," indicating that no printers are currently configured. Below this message, there are two buttons: "Add a Printer..." and "Additional Printer Settings..." with the latter being highlighted in red. At the top right corner, there is a section titled "Printers - localhost," showcasing the status connected to the local host and reiterating that "There are no printers configured yet."

An icon of a printer is displayed, along with a green "+" symbol button suggesting functionality to add a printer. The overall color scheme features a soft gradient of red and orange in the background, typical of the Ubuntu branding. The layout is organized and user-friendly, guiding users through the process of printer configuration in Ubuntu.
Open up a web browser and navigate to http://print.umiacs.umd.edu/printers(The prior text links to http://print.umiacs.umd.edu/printers)
Find the name of the printer that you wish to connect to. If you are unsure of which one to pick, see the  selecting a print queue page.
Navigate back to the 'New Printer' dialog box.
Under the "Enter Device URI" field, enter ipp://print.umiacs.umd.edu:631/printers/ with the name of the printer added at the end. For instance, to add cps432-3208 (color printer in IRB 3208), you would enter ipp://print.umiacs.umd.edu:631/printers/cps432-3208 in the field.
The image presents a graphical user interface (GUI) from an Ubuntu operating system, specifically within the printer setup section. The window is titled "New Printer" and prominently features a sidebar on the left labeled "Devices.” This menu contains selectable items such as "Generic CUPS-BRF," "Enter URI," and "Network Printer."

In the main area to the right, users are prompted to "Enter device URI," with a text field pre-filled with the URI "ipp://print.umiacs.umd.edu:631/printers/cps432-3208." Below this field, there’s an explanatory note stating a format example for inputting other printer URIs. The interface is designed for easy user interaction, with "Cancel" and "Forward" buttons at the bottom right, the latter highlighted, indicating the next step in the process.

The overall visual aesthetic includes a standard dark header, while the primary window background adheres to the Ubuntu design theme, with a light gray color scheme. The organization is clear, facilitating a straightforward process for users to input printer details and proceed with configuration.
Click "Forward". You will now see a list of printer models. From that list, select the brand of the printer as noted in step 4, and click Forward.
The image displays a graphical user interface (GUI) from an Ubuntu operating system related to printer configuration, specifically the "Choose Driver" section of the "New Printer" setup. The window features a simple layout with a white background and a dark header. At the top, a title reads "New Printer," indicating the current function.

In the main area, there are two options presented: a radio button for "Select printer from database," which is highlighted, and another for "Provide PPD file." Below this, a dropdown menu lists various printer manufacturers, with the cursor currently hovering over "HP," highlighted in orange. Other manufacturers displayed include Gestetner, Heidelberg, Hitachi, IBM, and more. 

At the bottom of the window, three buttons are present: "Back," "Cancel," and "Forward," with the "Forward" button highlighted, indicating the next step in the process. The overall design maintains a user-friendly approach, consistent with Ubuntu's aesthetic. The clean structure and clear labeling guide users through selecting the correct printer driver efficiently.
Select the specific model of the printer as noted in step 4.  Then click Forward.
The image showcases a graphical user interface (GUI) on an Ubuntu operating system, specifically within the "New Printer" setup section labeled "Choose Driver." The window is structured with a simple layout consisting of a white background and a dark header. The title "New Printer" is prominently displayed at the top. 

To the left, a list of printer models is shown, showcasing various HP Color LaserJet models, including "Color LaserJet M552" and "Color LaserJet M651." The model "Color LaserJet M652 M653" is highlighted in orange, indicating it is currently selected. On the right side, a corresponding driver for the selected model is displayed: "HP Color LaserJet M652 M653 Postscript." 

At the bottom, three buttons are available: "Back," "Cancel," and "Forward," with the "Forward" button highlighted, suggesting progression to the next step in the configuration. The overall design reflects a user-friendly approach typical of Ubuntu interfaces, ensuring clear navigation through the printer setup process. The choice of colors, fonts, and layout emphasizes clarity and usability.
Select any additional features available for the printer (i.e. duplexing, trays), and then click Forward.
The image shows a graphical user interface (GUI) on an Ubuntu operating system labeled "New Printer," focusing on installable options for an HP printer. The interface features a clean and minimalist design with a light background and a dark header. Three dropdown menus are displayed in the central section, indicating the availability of different input trays: 

- **Tray 3:** Options include "HP 550-Sheet Input Tray."
- **Tray 4:** Options include "HP 2000-Sheet Input Tray."
- **Tray 5:** Options include "HP 550-Sheet Input Tray" again.

Each dropdown menu is functional and allows users to select specific hardware configurations. At the bottom of the window, there are three action buttons: "Back," "Cancel," and "Forward." The "Forward" button is highlighted, indicating the next step in the printer configuration process. The interface is user-friendly and designed to assist users in customizing their printer settings effectively. The color scheme is consistent with Ubuntu branding, ensuring cohesiveness in the user experience.
Give a short name to the printer or leave everything default and hit Apply.
The image shows a graphical user interface (GUI) titled "New Printer" from an Ubuntu operating system, specifically focused on describing a printer. The window features a clean design with a light background and a dark header. 

In the central section, there are three fields for user input: 
1. **Printer Name**: A pre-filled field displays "HP-Color-LaserJet-M652-M653," suggesting a naming convention.
2. **Description**: An optional field is ready for input, prompting users to enter a human-readable description, with an example shown: "HP LaserJet with Duplexer."
3. **Location**: Another optional field for specifying a location, which suggests examples like "Lab 1."

At the bottom of the window, there are action buttons: "Back," "Cancel," and "Apply," with the "Apply" button highlighted, indicating the completion of this setup step. The overall layout facilitates a straightforward process, allowing users to succinctly define printer specifications before proceeding. The design adheres to the Ubuntu aesthetic, promoting ease of use and clarity in printer configuration.
Verify this process by printing a test page.  You should get the default Ubuntu test page.  If you just get a page with a string of text then the printer is not properly configured, and you should verify the settings.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Fixing_Stuck_Standing_Desk contains the following information: 






︗Fixing Stuck Standing Desk

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
If your electric adjustable standing desk is stuck, and will no longer move when the up / down button is pressed, try the following steps:


 Disconnect the table from outlet / power source 
 Disconnect the controller cable (blue end) from the power box located either underneath desktop or to desk frame
 Disconnect both table leg cables from the M1 and M2 connectors 
 Connect the cable from the table leg on the same side as the up / down controls to the M1 connector 
Note: You must connect  a cable to the M1 connector BEFORE connecting anything to the M2 connector
 Connect the cable from the second leg to the M2 connector 
 Reconnect the controller cable (blue end) 
 Reconnect the table to outlet / power source 
 Press and hold the down button for 5 seconds, after which you should feel a very slight movement 
Note: It is very important that the down button be held for the full 5 seconds

︗Issues After Steps Above
If your desk either moves in the opposite direction of button pressed, or only moves a short distance before stopping and becoming stuck again, repeat steps listed above but switching which legs go to the M1 and M2 connectors.  This will result in the leg on the OPPOSITE side of the up/down controls being connected to the M1 connector first, then the leg on the same side as the up/down controls being connected second.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Fixing_Stuck_Standing_Desk&oldid=8653"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Network/VPN/Android contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN/Mobile

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Network/VPN/Android)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Download and Install the Pulse Secure Client
3 Configuring the Client
4 Using the Client


︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (mobile data or wireless)
︗Download and Install the Pulse Secure Client
Pulse Secure for iOS and Android enables secure connectivity over SSL VPN to internal UMIACS resources.  The app can be downloaded for free from the App Store or Google Play:

iOS (App Store): https://apps.apple.com/us/app/pulse-secure/id945832041(The prior text links to https://apps.apple.com/us/app/pulse-secure/id945832041)
Android (Google Play): https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.pulsesecure.pulsesecure&hl=en_US(The prior text links to https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.pulsesecure.pulsesecure&hl=en_US)
︗Configuring the Client
When the client is first launched, it will prompt you to accept its license agreement.  Click 'Accept' to continue.
You may need to enter a Corporate E-mail address or URL before continuing. Enter vpn.umiacs.umd.edu.
The image displays the login screen of the Pulse Secure Client mobile application, specifically designed for secure VPN access. The background features a subtle gray color with a network-like pattern composed of interconnected nodes and lines, suggesting digital connectivity. At the top, the Pulse Secure logo is prominently displayed, featuring a green shield-like icon alongside the brand name in white font.

In the center, a welcome message reads, "Welcome to the Pulse Secure Client," in bold, clear text. Below this greeting, there is a prompt instructing users to enter their corporate email address or the provided URL, which specifically mentions "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu". This input field is designed with rounded edges and is visually distinct, indicating where users should type their information.

The bottom of the screen features a large green button labeled "Submit," inviting user interaction. There are additional navigation options at the very bottom of the screen, including "About," "Join Meeting," and "Support," which are subtly presented in a smaller font. The overall design is clean and user-friendly, appropriate for a mobile application focused on secure connectivity. 
After clicking on 'Submit', a page titled 'Add a Connection' will pop up. You will then be prompted for some basic information.  You will need to provide the following information and then click 'Save' or 'Add' (depending on client version).
Connection Name: UMIACS VPN
Username: <your UMIACS username>
The image titled "Add a Connection" is a screenshot of a mobile application interface, specifically for the Pulse Secure VPN Client. The background is dark gray, which provides a modern and streamlined look. At the top, there is a section indicating the action to be taken: “Save any changes,” followed by an option checkbox stating, “This will be your default connection,” which is checked.

In the central area, there are labeled input fields for various connection details. The first field, labeled "Connection Name," is noted as optional. Below this, the "URL" field is pre-filled with "https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu," emphasized to guide users on where to connect. The subsequent "Username" field is also optional, allowing users to input their credentials.

Next, there’s an "Authentication" label, with the word "Password" next to it, indicating that this is the method of authentication to be used. Additional options for "Realm" and "Role" are mentioned below, both labeled as optional, indicating flexibility in configuration. At the bottom of the screen, a prominent green button labeled "Save" invites action. The overall design is user-friendly, supporting efficient entry for users setting up a VPN connection. 
︗Using the Client
After the client has been configured, you can simply hit the 'Connect' button to start the VPN Connection.
The image depicts a mobile application interface for the Pulse Secure VPN Client. The background is a uniform dark gray, creating a sleek, modern appearance. At the top, the title "Pulse Secure" is prominently displayed. Below this, a green-bordered box labeled "Connection" highlights the current VPN connection: "UMIACS VPN," accompanied by a URL indicating the connection endpoint, "https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu." 

The interface features a circular toggle or dot next to "UMIACS VPN," suggesting that this is the active or selected connection. Beneath the connection details, there is a rectangular button labeled "Connect," which is colored in a muted gray. The button's size and distinct position encourage user interaction. 

At the bottom of the screen, a navigation bar contains icons representing home, activity, and settings, all designed with simple, recognizable shapes. The display suggests user-friendly functionality aimed at easy VPN connectivity while maintaining a professional, clean aesthetic suitable for enterprise use. 
Enter your UMIACS password, and hit 'Sign in'.
The image displays the login interface of the Pulse Secure VPN Client, tailored for UMIACS users. The background is a dark gray, creating a modern and understated aesthetic. Prominently featured is the UMIACS logo, positioned at the top with a subtle shadow effect enhancing its visibility.

In the center, a white dialog box captures the user’s attention. It is labeled “UMIACS VPN” in bold, clear text, inviting users to initiate their secure session. Below this title, there are two input fields, one labeled “Username” and the other “Password,” both clearly outlined for easy data entry. A dropdown menu is available for user selection, marked as “UMIACS Users,” suggesting that users may have multiple options under this category.

At the bottom of the dialog box, a large green button labeled “Sign In” stands out, inviting action. The design emphasizes functionality and ease of use, ensuring users can easily log in to access secure resources. A cancel option is also visible at the top left, providing an alternative action. Overall, the interface is user-friendly, aiming to facilitate a seamless login experience. 
Choose your preferred method of multi-factor authentication.
The image showcases the login screen of the Pulse Connect Secure mobile application for UMIACS users. The interface is structured with a clean and modern design, featuring a light gray background that emphasizes usability. At the top, the UMIACS logo is prominently displayed, indicating the application’s affiliation. Below this, a welcoming message states, “Welcome to the Pulse Connect Secure,” setting a friendly tone for the user.

In the central area, a text box bears the UMIACS logo again, providing a consistent branding element. Below this, three large rectangular buttons, all in a vibrant green color, facilitate user interaction. The buttons are labeled as follows: “Send Me a Push,” “Call Me,” and “Enter a Passcode,” allowing users multiple options for multi-factor authentication. The buttons’ size and color draw attention, making it easy for users to identify their choices.

A settings icon is located to the top right, suggesting additional configuration options, while the overall layout remains straightforward and user-friendly, designed for quick and efficient access to secure resources. 
You are now connected.  You connection status is verified by the VPN symbol in the top status bar.
The image displays the interface of the Pulse Secure VPN Client on a mobile device. The background is a dark gray, contributing to a modern aesthetic. At the top, the header reads “Pulse Secure” in large, clear text, indicating the application’s purpose. Just below, a bright green box clearly outlines the current VPN connection, labeled “UMIACS VPN.” Next to this label, a circular dot indicates the connection status is active, and the connection URL “https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu” is displayed, with dots obscuring part of the link, suggesting secure access.

At the center of the interface, a prominent button labeled "Disconnect" in green invites user interaction, suggesting this is the action to end the VPN session. Below this, a user’s identifier is presented as “UMIACS\likim,” accompanied by a timer indicating the duration of the connection—“23:59:47.” 

The bottom of the screen features a navigation bar with icons, including a home icon, reflecting accessibility to other app functions. The overall layout is streamlined for efficiency, emphasizing ease of use for managing VPN connections. 
To stop the VPN tunnel, click 'Disconnect'.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Network/VPN/macOS contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN/macOS

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Ivanti Connect Secure Client.  Alternatively, you can establish a connection through a web browser(The prior text links to https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu/), but this may fail if you have an outdated version of Ivanti Connect Secure already installed.

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
3 Checking VPN Status
4 Setup Security Requirement (Follow these steps if you encounter an error while connecting through the Ivanti Secure client)


︗Prerequisites
macOS 13.x or higher as of the current version of the Ivanti Connect Secure Client
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
Download the client:
macOS Ivanti Connect Secure Client(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/ivanti-connectsecure/macOS/PulseSecure-mac-22.7.3-installer.dmg)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up-to-date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Open the client and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.
The image shows a blank user interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, designed for macOS. The window features a clean, minimalistic layout with a light background. At the top, centered text reads "Connections" in bold, indicating the section for managing VPN connections. Below the title is a large, empty white area that signifies no connections are currently added or available to display. 

In the bottom left corner, there are two buttons depicted: a green plus sign (+) for adding new connections and a pencil icon for editing existing ones, both indicating that the user can perform actions for managing connections but currently has none listed. Overall, the interface is intuitive and straightforward, aimed at users who need to manage VPN connections efficiently. The design emphasizes functionality, allowing users to quickly add or edit connections once they are configured. [macOS] Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection
In the 'Name' field, enter a descriptive name for this vpn Connection.
In the 'Server URL' enter 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'
The image displays a user interface from the Ivanti Secure Access Client for macOS, which is designed for managing VPN connections. The interface features a light gray background that provides a minimalist aesthetic. Prominently at the top center, the title "Connections" is displayed in bold, indicating the section where users manage their VPN connections.

A dialog box is present in the center of the interface, labeled for creating a new connection. The box contains fields for entering the connection type, name, and server URL. The "Type" field allows selection between "Policy Secure (UAC)" and "Connect". Below this is the "Name" field, where "UMIACS VPN" is pre-filled as a suggested connection name. The "Server" field includes "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu" as the server address.

Two buttons at the bottom of the dialog box are labeled "Connect" and "Add", with a "Cancel" option available as well. The overall layout is user-friendly, designed to facilitate quickly adding and managing VPN connections. The interface emphasizes clarity and functionality, making it accessible to users configuring VPN settings. [macOS] Enter the name of the vpn server
Enter your UMIACS credentials and hit connect.
The image displays a user login interface for the UMIACS VPN on macOS. The window features a light gray background, enhancing visibility and minimizing distraction. At the top, the UMIACS VPN logo is prominently displayed, signifying the application's identity. Below the logo, two clearly labeled text fields are present for user input: "User Name" and "Password," both outlined in a subtle pink border to draw attention. 

Next to the "User Name" field, users can type their credentials, while the "Password" field remains obscured for security. Below the input fields is a checkbox labeled "Save settings," allowing users to save their credentials for quicker access in the future. 

At the bottom right corner, two buttons are visible: "Cancel," which lets users exit the interface without logging in, and "Connect," which initiates the VPN connection upon entering valid credentials. The layout maintains a clean and functional design, aimed at providing a straightforward user experience for connecting to the UMIACS VPN service. [macOS] Enter UMIACS Credentials
Complete the  MFA Verification Step. For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box.
The image displays a user interface for the UMIACS VPN multi-factor authentication on macOS. The window is set against a light gray background, which maintains focus on the user input areas. At the top, the UMIACS VPN logo is clearly visible, reinforcing the application’s branding. The interface includes two labeled text fields: the first is for "Secondary User Name," where a username is pre-filled as "lilikaj," while the second one is for the "Secondary Password," indicated by a series of dots for security.

Below the input fields, there is a checkbox labeled "Save settings," which enables users to store their credentials for future logins. In the lower right corner, there are two buttons: "Cancel," which allows users to exit the interface without proceeding, and "Connect," highlighted in a pink color, initiating the connection process once valid credentials are entered. The design is clean and user-friendly, aimed at facilitating a smooth login experience during the VPN authentication process. This simplicity underscores the importance of security in accessing sensitive information. [macOS] Enter a secondary password.
The Ivanti VPN multi-factor authentication implementation relies on a secondary authentication source to fulfill the  MFA requirement.  As a result, you will be prompted for credentials twice.


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.


Please provide the images you would like me to describe.

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN. You can close the window and the VPN will remain connected.
If you encounter an error, please refer to the "Setup Security Requirement" section bellow.

︗Checking VPN Status
In the top right hand corner, on your status bar, you should see an S icon in a black circle. If there's a green arrow, that means you are connected! If there is nothing, that means you are not.
The image shows a macOS status bar displayed at the top of the screen. This status bar is characterized by a light blue gradient background, typical of the macOS interface. Various icons are arranged from left to right, indicating system statuses and active services. 

On the left side, there are four red icons; these could represent notifications or alerts from different applications. A black Bluetooth icon follows, alongside a crescent moon icon, which typically indicates "Do Not Disturb" mode is activated. An icon representing battery status is next, showing the current charge level.

Centralized within the status bar is a Wi-Fi icon that appears to have a strong signal based on the filled segments. Adjacent to it, there are other icons for connectivity and system monitoring, alongside system date and time display, which reads "Thu Mar 16 12:21 PM" for the first part and "12:45 PM" for the second part, suggesting that a time update occurred shortly after.

The overall arrangement emphasizes macOS's functional and intuitive design, providing users with essential information at a glance. [macOS] The top image is connected, the bottom image is not.
You can click this icon, as well, and it will show you the status of your connection.
The image displays a macOS status bar dropdown menu for the Ivanti Secure Access Client, indicating that the user is connected to the UMIACS VPN. The status bar has a light blue gradient background with various icons representing system statuses. The dropdown features a header stating "Open Ivanti Secure Access Client," followed by a message confirming the client is currently connected. Below this is the connection name, "UMIACS VPN," marked with a green check icon, indicating an active connection. There's also an arrow suggesting more options related to this connection. At the bottom, an "Exit" option allows users to close the dropdown menu. The overall design emphasizes clarity, providing users with essential information about their VPN status at a glance, ideal for quick access on the macOS interface. [macOS] The Pulse drop down menu.
If the icon is not in the status bar, you can find Pulse Secure in your Applications folder. There you will see a list of connections.


︗None
Click the Apple logo at the top left of your desktop
Click System Settings
Click Privacy & Security
Scroll to the Security section and select App Store and identified developers
You will have to enter your credentials
Click Next to the message "System Software From Developers "Pulse Secure LLC" was blocked from loading" if prompted.
Click Allow to enable the extension.
Close the System Settings window.

Privacy policy
About UMIACS
Disclaimers


(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WebSensitiveInformation contains the following information: 






︗WebSensitiveInformation

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Overview
In order to maintain maximum security, we do not store any sensitive information on our web servers. Such information is encrypted in memory upon receipt and sent to a designated email address, the owner of which will decrypt it using a email encryption/decryption program.
The recommended email encryption/decryption software at UMIACS is WinPT (Windows Privacy Tray), a small and powerful software from http://winpt.wald.intevation.org/(The prior text links to http://winpt.wald.intevation.org/). It is freely available to all users. It must be noted that you need GnuPG 1.4.11 or higher installed on your computer to use WinPT. You can download GnuPG for free from the GnuPG website(The prior text links to https://www.gnupg.org/).

︗WinPT Instructions
The first time you run this program, you will be asked to generate your "keypair". A keypair contains a public key, which is usually used for encryption, and a private key, which is used for decryption.
Now you are ready to encrypt and decrypt messages. To do so: 

Simply copy the text you wish to encrypt/decrypt into the Windows clipboard (i.e., use "copy" or "ctrl-v")
Click on the WinPT icon in the lower-right corner of the screen
Select the approriate menu item
Follow the on-screen prompts.
To have others send you encrypted messages, you must give them your public key. To do so:
export your public key (There are three different ways to do this, reference this manual(The prior text links to http://www.mavi1.org/web_security/cryptography/pgp/gnupg-frontend/WinPT/winpt-handbook-0.2rc2.pdf) to decide which is best for you.), and send it to the other side. Never distribute your private key.
In the case of the standard UMIACS setup for accepting sensitive information online, such as credit card information, social security number, etc, it is mandatory that we use encrypted messages. Send your public key to webmaster@umiacs.umd.edu and clearly indicate which online form this is for.

︗Extra Links
For an even more in-depth guide, consult this(The prior text links to http://sebsauvage.net/winpt_en.html) over-simplified WinPT Tutorial.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=WebSensitiveInformation&oldid=6209"
