︗WindowsPrinting

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Introduction
2 Printing Outside of UMIACS / Laptop Printing
3 Pre-Installation Knowledge on Printing at UMIACS
4 Installation of printer queue

4.1 Troubleshooting


5 Removing a printer queue
6 Duplex Printing
7 Store and Print PIN-Protected Jobs


︗Introduction
This will guide you through the process of installing and using the printers available within UMIACS.

︗None
If you are off the UMIACS network, you must first connect to the VPN on Windows. After you are connected, follow the instructions for adding a printer queue below. Please note that you must be on the VPN whenever you print.

︗Pre-Installation Knowledge on Printing at UMIACS
 Printer Queue Naming

︗Installation of printer queue
Please note that this applies to machines on any UMIACS network. This includes all proxy networks, the vast majority of machines in the labs, and machines connected to the UMIACS VPN - but not a wireless network (e.g., eduroam, umd-guest) alone. 

Go to Start and search "\\printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu" in the search box.
The image displays a Windows search interface where a user is typing the command `\\printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu` into the search bar located at the bottom left. The left side shows a panel with icons for different applications, documents, settings, and feedback options. The main area on the right showcases the search result, labeled as "Best match," indicating the entered command. It features an icon of a computer screen and the text "Run command." Below the result, links for "Open" and "Open file location" are available, suggesting that the user can execute this command to access the printer settings at UMIACS. The overall layout is typical of Windows 10 or a similar operating system version, characterized by a clean interface with a dark sidebar and a light background for the results. The focus is on the network printer setup for users within the UMIACS network.
You will be prompted with a box for authentication if you are not signed into Windows with your UMIACS account (e.g. on a laptop or self-supported machine).  Make sure to prefix 'UMIACS\' to your username.  (For example, if your username was 'johndoe' you would enter 'UMIACS\johndoe' in the username box.)
Check the box for 'Remember my credentials' before clicking OK or you may not be able to add printer queues in the next step.
The image displays a Windows Security prompt for entering network credentials. At the top, the window title reads "Windows Security," indicating its purpose for authentication. There are two fields where users must input their credentials: the first line specifies "Enter your credentials to connect to: printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu," highlighting the required network. The username field features a placeholder labeled "UMIACS\username," where users are expected to replace "username" with their actual username in the specified format. Below this, a black dot field represents the password input, protecting the user’s privacy. 

A checkbox labeled "Remember my credentials" is available, allowing users to save their credentials for future access. At the bottom, a red error message reads, "The user name or password is incorrect," indicating that the entered details were not valid, thus aiding the user in troubleshooting potential login issues. Below this message are two buttons: "OK" and "Cancel," providing the user with the option to either confirm their entry or exit the authentication window. The overall color scheme is neutral, with a light gray background complementing darker text for clarity.
A list of printer queues will appear.  Select your desired printer by double clicking on the queue.
The image presents a Windows File Explorer interface displaying network printers accessible through the UMIACS network. Located at the top, the path reads `\\printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu`, indicating that the user is browsing printers connected to this network. The left sidebar includes standard navigation options such as "Quick access," "This PC," "Desktop," and "Network," alongside a prominent display of the "Network" section.

On the right side, there are numerous printer icons arranged in a grid-like layout, with each printer represented by a stylized image showing a printer with paper and a green indicator suggesting connectivity. The printer names are shown beneath each icon, comprising a series of codes (e.g., `cps224-3100p`, `cps432-3208`), which likely identify specific models and locations. The grid continues to the right and down, with a total of 59 items listed on the page.

The overall interface is clean and organized, characteristic of a Windows operating system, with a white background and black text. The highlight on the selected printer (`cps432-3208`) indicates active selection, suggesting that the user is ready to interact with this specific printer.
Wait for the printer driver installation.  This may take a minute or two to complete.
The image shows a Windows Printer Installation progress window. At the top, the window title reads "Windows Printer Installation," indicating the process of setting up a network printer. Below the title, the message "Connecting to cps432-3208 on printers" specifies the printer model being connected. The main feature of the window is a horizontal progress bar beneath the text, which is partially filled in green, signifying that the installation is underway. The progress bar is set against a light gray background, creating a clear contrast that aids visibility. 

To the right of the progress bar is a "Cancel" button, which allows users to abort the installation process if needed. The overall design is characteristic of Windows interfaces, focusing on user-friendliness and clarity. The layout conveys a sense of ongoing activity in the printer setup, suggesting that the installation may take additional time. No additional graphics or distracting elements are present, keeping the focus on the installation status.
Once done, you can start using the printer.
The image depicts a Windows printer queue interface for the printer labeled "cps432-3208." The window's title bar indicates that it's showing the queue for the selected printer. The interface is divided into a grid with distinct columns: "Document Name," "Status," "Owner," "Pages," "Size," and "Submitted." Currently, these columns are empty, suggesting that no print jobs are currently queued or active for this printer. 

At the bottom, a horizontal scroll bar indicates that there may be more information accessible to the right, although no additional items are currently displayed. The overall design is minimalist, characteristic of Windows operating systems, featuring a clean white background and dark text. There are no visual cues indicating any ongoing print jobs or issues, and the interface appears user-friendly, allowing users to manage print tasks efficiently once they are submitted. The absence of content potentially implies that users can expect to see their documents listed here once they initiate print jobs for this printer.
︗Troubleshooting
If you receive the following error when attempting to add a printer queue, the issue may be that your computer is configured for a higher level of printer security than is default at UMIACS as a result of the PrintNightmare vulnerability(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PrintNightmare).

The image presents a Windows error message titled "Add Printer" with a prominent red circle icon that features a white "X," indicating a connection issue. The message reads, "Connect to Printer" in blue text, followed by the error description: "Windows cannot connect to the printer. Access is denied." This suggests that the user lacks the necessary permissions to access the printer, which may imply an authentication issue or insufficient user rights on the network.

Overall, the message is set against a minimalistic white background, typical of Windows error notifications, which emphasizes clarity. At the bottom of the window, a single button labeled "OK" allows the user to close the message. The layout is simple and user-friendly, focusing on conveying the error and guiding users towards acknowledging it. The overall presentation is aimed at assisting users in troubleshooting printer access problems within the Windows operating system environment.
To resolve this error:

Click on the Start menu and type "cmd" in the run bar.
The image displays a Windows search interface showcasing a user typing the command "cmd" into the search bar located at the bottom left of the screen. The left panel features icons for various applications, documents, and settings. In the main area, the search result labeled "Best match" highlights the Command Prompt option with an icon depicting a black terminal window. Below the search result, users have options to "Open," "Run as administrator," or "Open file location." The background maintains the clean and familiar design of Windows 10, characterized by a dark sidebar contrasting with a lighter main interface. On the desktop behind the search interface, several colorful application icons and folders are visible, suggesting an active workspace. Overall, the image emphasizes the functionality of accessing the Command Prompt for further administrative tasks, such as printer troubleshooting.
Right-Click on the cmd button, and select "Run as Administrator" - THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT!
The image shows a Windows search interface featuring a user inputting the command "cmd" into the search bar located at the bottom left corner of the screen. The left panel displays the "Best match" option highlighting the Command Prompt application, represented by an icon depicting a black terminal window. Below the highlighted search result, users can select options to "Open," "Run as administrator," or "Open file location." The background is a familiar Windows layout characterized by a dark sidebar and a lighter main interface, providing a clear and user-friendly environment. Visible icons on the desktop behind the search interface suggest an active workspace. The overall design emphasizes functionality and ease of use, indicating this interface is for accessing command line tools for further administrative tasks or troubleshooting.
Select "Yes" when it asks if you want to allow the following program to make changes.
The image displays a User Account Control (UAC) prompt on a Windows interface. The prompt is set against a bright yellow background, indicating the warning nature of the message. At the top, the question reads, "Do you want to allow this app from an unknown publisher to make changes to your device?" This highlights that the user is being asked to grant administrative privileges for the application, specifically "cmd.exe," which is the Command Prompt. 

Below the question, the details mention the publisher as "Unknown," suggesting that the application is not recognized by Windows as a trusted source. The file origin is indicated as "Hard drive on this computer," confirming that the request is coming from a local installation. 

Two buttons are presented at the bottom: "Yes" and "No." The "Yes" button, when clicked, would permit the app to proceed with the changes, while "No" would cancel the action. The interface is typical of a Windows security alert, designed for clarity and user awareness before allowing potentially significant actions on the system.
From the Command Prompt, run these commands in order:
reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows NT\Printers\PointAndPrint" /v RestrictDriverInstallationToAdministrators /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f
reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print" /v RpcAuthnLevelPrivacyEnabled /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f
net stop spooler /y && net start spooler
The image depicts a Command Prompt interface on a Windows operating system, showcasing the process of modifying printer settings. The title bar indicates that this is an Administrator Command Prompt, suggesting elevated privileges. The command lines entered include various commands to adjust registry settings related to printer installation and permissions. 

Key text elements include:
1. **Registry Modifications**: 
   - The first command aims to change the restriction for driver installation to administrators only.
   - The second command adjusts the privacy settings for RPC authentication related to printing.
   
2. **Print Spooler Status**: 
   - Subsequent output indicates actions taken on the Print Spooler service, specifically that it was stopped and then restarted.

The interface background is dark, with light text, typical of Command Prompt environments, ensuring high visibility of the commands and outputs. Each line's formatting clearly distinguishes commands from the system responses. Overall, this image illustrates advanced troubleshooting for printer connectivity issues within a Windows environment, emphasizing user interaction with system settings through command-line operations.
Attempt to add the printer queue again.
︗Removing a printer queue
To remove a printer queue, open the Start menu and search for and go to Control Panel. Next, click on "View devices and printers." To remove the queue, right click on the printer and select "Remove device". If you wish to add the printer back, follow the instructions above.

The image displays the "Devices and Printers" interface within a Windows operating system. A list of connected devices is shown, with a focus on the printer labeled "cps432-3208," which is connected via the printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu network. The designated printer is visually highlighted, indicated by a green checkmark suggesting it's the active device. Below the printer's name, key information is detailed, including its state as "Ready," the model designation as "HP Universal Printing PS (v6.0.0)," and its category categorized as "Printer."

On the right side, a context menu is open, providing several options for user interaction. These include setting the printer as the default, accessing printing preferences, viewing printer properties, creating a shortcut, troubleshooting, and the option to "Remove device." The overall interface is organized in a grid layout with printer icons, enhancing user accessibility. The background is a clean, light design, typical of Windows, making the textual information easily readable. This image exemplifies printer management capabilities within Windows, emphasizing functionality for users requiring device customization and control.
︗Duplex Printing
Many printers in UMIACS support duplex (2 sided) printing. To make the duplex printing default, first make sure the appropriate printer queue is installed via the directions above. Afterwards, go to start, then “Devices and Printers.”
Once the printer has been installed proceed by right clicking on the queue then selecting “Printing preferences.”

The image displays the "Devices and Printers" interface within a Windows operating system. A highlighted printer named "cps432-3208" appears on the left, representing a network printer connected via the UMIACS network. Identified with an icon of a printer, it carries a green checkmark to indicate it's the selected device, coupled with the designation "HP Universal Printing PS (v6.0.0)" below it. 

The right-click context menu is shown, with several options for user interaction such as "Set as default printer," "Printing preferences," "Printer properties," "Create shortcut," "Remove device," and "Troubleshoot." The organized grid layout presents the printer alongside other connected devices, while a clean, light background enhances readability. 

The information conveys a user-friendly environment, allowing easy management of connected printers. Overall, the interface exemplifies capabilities for printer management within Windows, emphasizing efficiency and functionality for users needing to customize printer settings or monitor device status.
After a few seconds the following menu will come up. Make sure you are on the “Printing Shortcuts” tab and select the “EcoSMART Settings” option then click on okay. This modification will allow you to print 2-sided whenever you choose to use this printer.

The image displays a "Printing Preferences" window for the printer labeled "cps432-3208." This interface provides a collection of saved print settings that the user can select easily. On the left side, a list of printing shortcuts shows two options: "Factory Defaults" and a highlighted "EcoSMART Settings." The highlighted option indicates that the EcoSMART settings are currently selected, implying that these settings will be applied for printing.

Right of the shortcuts list, key parameters related to the printing setup are presented. The paper size is specified as "8.5 x 11 inches" in a dropdown menu, with the default option set to "Letter." The paper source is labeled as "Automatically Select," signifying the printer’s capability to choose the source paper based on availability. 

Additional options list the number of pages per sheet, set as "1 page per sheet" and confirm duplex printing with "Yes, flip over" selected for printing on both sides. At the bottom of the window, buttons for "OK," "Cancel," and "Apply" are visible, with the focus on the "OK" button, indicating readiness to confirm the selected settings. The overall design is clean and user-friendly, enhancing the experience of configuring print jobs.
︗Store and Print PIN-Protected Jobs
PIN-protected jobs provide a way to ensure jobs are not printed until you are ready to pick them up. This can be useful if you have a sensitive job that you want to print on a public printer at UMIACS. Follow the below steps to store a job and then print it at the printer.
Create a stored job

From the software program, select the Print option.
Select the printer from the list of printers, and then select Properties or Preferences (name varies by software program)
Click the Job Storage tab.
Under Job Storage Mode, select Personal Job.
The image displays the "Printing Preferences" window for a printer labeled "cps432-3208." In this window, users can configure how their print jobs are managed, focusing on job storage options. The left section highlights various job storage modes, with "Personal Job" selected, emphasizing that this job will not print until it is retrieved from the printer's control panel. 

To the right, fields allow for customization of the user's name and job name—options are provided to use either a predefined or custom name. Below, the "Make Job Private/Secure" dropdown indicates an option for ensuring privacy. At the bottom, buttons for "OK," "Cancel," and "Help" are visible, with clear instructions conveyed in the text to guide the user. The overall design maintains a clean interface, characteristic of HP's printing software, featuring well-organized sections for easy navigation and comprehension. This image underscores the importance of security and personal management in printing tasks, particularly for sensitive documents.
In the drop-down menu under Make Job Private/Secure, select PIN to print, and type in a 4-digit number.
The image displays the "Printing Preferences" window for the printer labeled "cps432-3208." This interface allows users to manage how their print jobs are stored and secured. The left section highlights various job storage modes, with "Personal Job" selected, indicating that the print job will remain unprinted until requested via the printer's control panel. 

To the right, users can input their username, with an area for customizing the job name below. A dropdown menu for "Make Job Private/Secure" is present, showcasing the selected option "PIN to print." Below this, a field for entering the 4-digit PIN number allows users to further secure their job. The design maintains a clean and organized layout typical of HP’s printing software, with buttons for "OK," "Cancel," and "Help" readily visible at the bottom, encouraging user interaction.

The overall tone of the interface emphasizes privacy and control over printed documents, making it easy for users to ensure sensitive jobs are only printed when they choose to retrieve them from the printer.
Note: You will need to provide the entered PIN (4-digit number) at the printer's control panel.
Click the OK button to close the Document Properties/Preferences dialog box. In the Print dialog box, click Print.
Print a stored job
After you have created a stored job using the instructions above, follow these steps to print from the printer's control panel.

From the Home screen on the printer control panel, select Print.
Select Print from Job Storage.
The image features the touchscreen interface of an HP printer's control panel. At the foreground, a large, prominently outlined rectangular button labeled "Print from Job Storage" is highlighted in red, indicating the user's current selection. To the right, two additional buttons are visible: "Print from USB Drive" and "HP JetAdvantage," both presented within blue rectangles, suggesting different print options available to the user. The buttons feature icons that symbolize their functions—one depicting a storage disk for job storage, another with a USB symbol, and a cloud icon for HP JetAdvantage, which likely refers to cloud printing services.

The interface itself is sleek and user-friendly, typical of modern printer control panels, with a light background ensuring clarity and readability of the options presented. Below the buttons, a horizontal progress bar, partially filled, indicates ongoing processing of a task, though it is not explicitly detailed what this relates to. At the top, the logo for HP adds branding and context, while the "Reset" and "Sign In" options are visible in the corners, emphasizing user control and customization. Overall, the layout conveys functionality and ease of navigation for users interacting with their print jobs.
Select Choose, and then select the name of the folder where the job is stored.
The image shows a touchscreen interface of a printer's control panel, specifically the "Stored Job to Print" menu. At the top, the title "Stored Job to Print" indicates the current selection context. Below this, there are two entries displayed: "Untitled" and "XXXXXXXXXX," where "XXXXXXXXXX" represents a stored job with a custom name, likely input by the user. Each entry has a right-facing arrow, suggesting that users can select either job for printing.

On the right side of the screen, two buttons are visible: "Select" in a blue rectangular box and "Cancel" in a blue box with an exclamation mark, indicating the option to abort the action or proceed. The overall layout is clean, with a soft background allowing for clear visibility of the text and options. The interface is designed for user-friendly navigation, emphasizing ease of access to stored print jobs. This setup is particularly useful for managing printouts securely, allowing users to retrieve sensitive documents when they are ready.
Select the name of the job, enter your chosen PIN (4-digit number), and click Ok.
The image displays a touchscreen interface of a printer's control panel, specifically the PIN input screen for securing print jobs. At the top, a text field is labeled "Enter PIN," indicating where users should input their 4-digit PIN. Below this, a numeric keypad is presented within a red-bordered grid, featuring the numbers 1 through 9, arranged in a three-by-three format, along with 0 at the bottom. Each button is large enough for easy tapping.

To the right of the keypad, a small button with an "X" icon likely serves as a cancel option, allowing users to exit the PIN entry screen. Below the grid, there is another button outlined in blue, featuring a downward-facing arrow and a symbol that may represent 'OK' or 'Enter' function, facilitating the final submission of the entered PIN.

The overall color scheme is neutral, with soft backgrounds enhancing visibility and readability. This interface emphasizes user control and security, ensuring that print jobs remain confidential until the correct PIN is provided.
Select Print to print the job.
The image features a touchscreen interface of an HP printer's control panel, specifically displaying the "Print from Job Storage" menu. At the top, the title "Print from Job Storage" indicates the context of this operation. Below, a delineated section labeled "Stored Job to Print" showcases an entry labeled "XXXXXXXXXX > new 1.txt," suggesting a stored document waiting for printing. 

The details section provides key information, showing the "Job Name" as "new 1.txt" and the "User Name" as "SIREN\XXXXXXXXXX," likely a user-specific identifier. This allows for easy recognition of the print job's origin and content.

In the lower right corner, there’s a large green button outlined in red labeled "Print," indicating the action to be taken. Adjacent to it, a numeric display shows "1," which likely denotes the number of copies to print.

The overall design is clear and user-friendly, ensuring immediate visibility of job details and easy access to initiate printing. The interface promotes straightforward interaction for users retrieving their print jobs while maintaining organizational integrity and clarity.
Note: The print job is deleted from memory after it prints.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Setting_File_Permissions_in_Windows contains the following information: 






︗Setting File Permissions in Windows

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗None
Right-click the file or directory you would like to change permissions for and click on 'Properties.'
In this example: We will be changing the permissions of a Folder named "ExampleFolder", which is owned by "GenericUser" but has granted permissions to another user, named "Example". We will be looking at these permissions.
After the properties menu comes up, select the tab labeled 'Security'.
The image displays the Properties window of a folder named "ExampleFolder" on a Windows operating system. The window is divided into sections, with the title "ExampleFolder Properties" at the top. Below the title, the file path is indicated as "C:\Users\GenericUser\Documents\ExampleFolder." 

On the left side, there is a list labeled "Group or user names," showing four entries: SYSTEM, GenericUser, Example, and Administrators. Each entry is accompanied by a corresponding icon. The currently selected group is "SYSTEM."

The right section shows "Permissions for SYSTEM," with checkboxes indicating permissions allowed or denied. The permissions listed are "Full control," "Modify," "Read & execute," "List folder contents," "Read," and "Write." Some of these permissions have checkmarks under the "Allow" column, while one permission, "Write," shows an empty checkbox under "Allow."

At the bottom of the window, there are buttons for "OK," "Cancel," and "Apply," alongside a link for "Advanced" settings for finer permissions control. The color scheme is primarily white with blue accents, typical of Windows dialog boxes.
Click on the button at the bottom of the menu labeled 'Advanced'.
The image depicts the "Advanced Security Settings" dialog for a folder named "ExampleFolder" in a Windows operating system environment. The top of the window displays the folder path: "C:\Users\GenericUser\Documents\ExampleFolder," with the owner specified as "GenericUser." 

The interface is divided into sections, including tabs labeled "Permissions," "Auditing," and "Effective Access." In the main section, there is a list of permission entries with columns for "Type," "Principal," "Access," "Inherited from," and "Applies to." Each entry shows specific user or group permissions regarding the folder. 

The "Principal" column lists users like "Example," "SYSTEM," "Administrators," and "GenericUser," all of which are granted "Full control," allowing them complete management over the folder and its contents. They are identified by their computer names. 

At the bottom of the window, there are action buttons: "Add," "Remove," "Edit," "OK," "Cancel," and "Apply," alongside an option to disable inheritance of permissions. The overall color scheme is a clean white background with gray and blue accents, typical of Windows file management dialogs.
Select the user that you would like to change permissions for, and select "Edit". In this case: We are changing the permissions of the user named "Example".
The image displays a Windows dialog box titled "Permission Entry for ExampleFolder" used for adjusting file permissions. At the top, the selected principal user is labeled as "Example (DESKTOP-D0L8R09\Example)," indicating that edits will apply to this user. Below, two dropdown menus specify the type of permission as "Allow" and the scope as "This folder, subfolders and files."

On the left, a list of basic permissions includes checkboxes for various access rights: "Full control," "Modify," "Read & execute," "List folder contents," "Read," and "Write." All permissions except "Write" are checked under "Allow," indicating the user has most rights except for write access. There is also an option for "Special permissions," which is not selected.

A checkbox at the bottom allows for restricting the application of these permissions to the current container only. The dialog includes two buttons at the bottom labeled “OK” and “Cancel,” with a "Clear all" option to remove selected permissions. The overall color scheme features a clean white background with blue accents typical of Windows interfaces.
Select the permissions you would like this user to have. To view more granular permissions, Select "Show Advanced permissions".
The image titled "Permission Entry for ExampleFolder" features a Windows dialog box used for configuring file permissions. The topmost section identifies the principal user as "Example (DESKTOP-D0L8R09\Example)." Below, two dropdown menus indicate the permission type as "Allow" and scope as "This folder, subfolders and files."

In the central part of the dialog, a checklist provides various permission options. Each option displays either a checked box or an empty checkbox, with permissions such as "Full control," "Modify," "Read & execute," "List folder contents," "Read," and "Write." Among these, only the "Write" option remains unchecked under "Allow," indicating the user does not have write access. 

An additional section, labeled "Advanced permissions," offers more granular choices, featuring checkboxes for permissions like "Read attributes," "Create files/write data," and "Delete," among others. A checkbox at the bottom advises that the permissions can be limited to the current folder. Action buttons "OK," "Cancel," and "Clear all" are positioned at the bottom right, with a clean white background augmented with blue accents typical of Windows design.
Apply or deny permissions for each user which needs to be updated.
Apply all changes by clicking the 'OK' or 'Apply' button at the bottom of each menu as necessary.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Setting_File_Permissions_in_Windows&oldid=9338"

︗Iribe/Faxing

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The HP LaserJet Enterprise Flow MFP M633 labelled "ps432-4208" in room 4208 in the Iribe Center, in addition to being a black/white printer, also has faxing capability configured (send/receive). The fax number is 301-314-9115 (x49115). HP's guide for using this model of fax can be found here on page 15(The prior text links to http://h10032.www1.hp.com/ctg/Manual/c05791986).
Please keep in mind UMD phone syntax still applies when using this machine; you will need to dial 9 and then 1 before faxing to any number external to the university(The prior text links to https://it.umd.edu/phone#place).

Privacy policy
About UMIACS
Disclaimers


(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Remote_Desktop contains the following information: 






︗Remote Desktop

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Introduction
2 How to Connect

2.1 Windows
2.2 macOS
2.3 UNIX

2.3.1 freerdp
2.3.2 xfreerdp




3 Redirecting Resources on Windows

3.1 Audio Redirection
3.2 Other Resource Redirection


4 Redirecting Resources on Mac

4.1 Folder/Drive Redirection
4.2 Other Resource Redirection




︗Introduction
Remote Desktop allows you to connect to another computer from a network that is compatible. Currently, at UMIACS, this feature is only supported for Windows hosts using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). If you need to remotely connect to a UNIX host, please see SecureShell. With RDP, you can control your Windows desktop environment through a graphical user interface. Mouse and keyboard movements are transferred over a network to a Windows host running an RDP server, which sends screen refreshes back. 
To access an RDP enabled machine, you must be on the UMIACS physical network or VPN. You must also be authorized to access and remotely control the host you are requesting. If a remote session is active, it is not possible for another user to log onto the console in-person. Attempting to use RDP when a computer is in use by another user could force the existing user to logoff and lose their work. You should always quit RDP by logging off of the remote computer. Simply quitting the RDP client can cause you to stay logged in and prevent other users from accessing the remote host, even at the physical console.

︗How to Connect
Prerequisites:
Connected to the  UMIACS VPN or be within the UMIACS network border.
Be a member of the 'Remote Desktop Users' group on the remote machine. Please  contact staff if you do not have remote access to a machine you feel you should.
︗Windows
For connecting to Windows client over RDP, we recommend the native Windows 'Remote Desktop Connection' client. 

To start the RDC client, click the "Start'" or "Windows" button on the taskbar. In the menu, navigate to "All Programs," "Accessories," then select "Remote Desktop Connection". Alternatively, you can search for "Remote Desktop Connection" in the Start menu's search field.
Once RDC client starts, type the name of the RDP/Windows host you are trying to access. The name should be the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FDQN), e.g. desktop.ad.umiacs.umd.edu where desktop is replaced by the name of the desktop you are trying to connect to. At this point, click "Connect" to initiate the RDP session.
The image shows a user interface of the "Remote Desktop Connection" application on a Windows computer. The window features a blue and white color scheme with the title "Remote Desktop Connection" prominently displayed at the top. Below the title, there are input fields where a user can enter connection details. 

The first field labeled "Computer:" contains the text "desktop.ad.umiacs.umd.edu," which indicates the specific host name of the remote computer to connect to. The second field is labeled "User name:" and states "None specified," suggesting that the user has not yet entered their credentials. 

At the bottom of the window, there are two buttons: "Connect," which is highlighted in blue, and "Help," which is less emphasized. An option to expand further settings is indicated by the "Show Options" button in the bottom left corner. The overall layout is user-friendly and designed for inputting connection credentials to establish a remote session effectively.
Upon reaching the Windows Security prompt, enter your UMIACS credentials. Please note that the username must be in the format UMIACS\username, where username is replaced by your UMIACS username. The slash must also be a back slash and not a forward slash. If the username is either not correct or not the desired account, click on "More choices" and select "Use another account". Click "Ok" when you are done.
The image features a Windows Security prompt, displayed in a rectangular dialog box against a dark background. At the top, the caption reads "Enter your credentials," indicating the purpose of this interface. Below the title, a descriptive text states, "These credentials will be used to connect to [redacted].ad.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating the server to which the user is attempting to connect.

Two input fields are present: the first labeled “UMIACS\username” where users are expected to input their username. The text box contains a placeholder suggesting that the username should be in the specified format. The second field is for password entry, represented by a series of dots to obscure the entered characters, ensuring privacy.

At the bottom, there are three buttons: "OK" for submitting the credentials, "Cancel" for abandoning the connection attempt, and a checkbox labeled "Remember me," allowing users to save their credentials for future sessions. A link labeled "More choices" is also visible, hinting at additional options for credential entry. The overall design is standard for Windows authentication dialogs, prioritizing functionality and user accessibility.
After the connection is started, a warning message may alert you to an identity verification failure. For UMIACS machines, you can ignore this and proceed by checking the box and selecting "Yes".
The image depicts a warning dialog from a Windows Remote Desktop Connection (RDC) application, indicating an issue with verifying the identity of a remote computer. At the top, a bold yellow banner alerts the user with the message: "The identity of the remote computer cannot be verified. Do you want to connect anyway?" Below it, there's a notification stating that the remote computer could not be authenticated due to a security certificate problem, elaborating that proceeding may be unsafe.

The certificate details are displayed prominently in two sections. The first section titled "Certificate name" includes a placeholder example showing "Name in the certificate from the remote computer: [redacted].ad.umiacs.edu." 

In the second section, "Certificate errors," it lists the encountered issues, specifically that the certificate does not come from a trusted certifying authority, indicated by a warning triangle icon. 

At the bottom, the user faces a critical decision: buttons for responding to the warning include "Yes," "No," and an option to "View certificate." There’s also a checkbox suggesting not to raise this warning for future connections, enhancing user experience. The overall layout adheres to standard Windows design principles, with an emphasis on security awareness.
You should now be viewing the remote computer. To terminate the session, you should logout of Windows.
To switch between your current host and the remote host, click the minimize or "-" button on the top connection bar. With RDC, the clipboard can be transferred between the remote and current host while the RDC client is running and logged in.

Alternatively, you can use the Microsoft Remote Desktop application from the Windows Store, which is available for download here.(The prior text links to https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/p/microsoft-remote-desktop/9wzdncrfj3ps?activetab=pivot%3Aoverviewtab)

Open Microsoft Remote Desktop.
Click "Add" in the top right corner.
The image depicts the user interface of the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a Windows device. The background is predominantly black, creating a sharp contrast with the text and icons. At the top, the title "Remote Desktop" is displayed in a simple, clean font. Below that, a prominent message reads, "Connect to apps and desktops," clearly indicating the purpose of this interface.

Underneath, there is instructional text explaining that users need to add a remote PC to connect and can also incorporate remote resources available to them. The font is white and easy to read against the dark background, enhancing visibility.

In the upper right corner, there are two icons: one for adding connections, represented by a plus sign (“+”), and another for window settings, depicted as a gear symbol. These elements are designed to ensure a user-friendly experience. On the lower right side of the screen, a subtle logo featuring interconnected circles can be seen, perhaps indicating connectivity or network status. Overall, the interface is modern, streamlined, and aims to provide a straightforward user experience for remote connections.
Next, click "Desktop - Connect to a PC".
The image displays the user interface of the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a Windows device. The background is predominantly black, which provides a stark contrast to the text and icons, enhancing readability. At the top, the title "Remote Desktop" is elegantly presented. Below this title, a large, clear message reads, "Connect to apps and desktops," indicating the application's primary function. 

The instruction further elaborates that to begin, users must add a remote PC they wish to connect to, emphasizing the purpose of the interface. To the right, there's a sidebar labeled "Choose what to add," featuring a highlighted option "Desktop" for connecting to a PC and a secondary option for "Remote resources" to access applications from the organization. 

In the upper right corner, two icons are visible: a plus sign ("+") for adding new connections and a gear symbol for accessing settings, both designed for efficient user navigation. Overall, the interface is modern and streamlined, aimed at providing a straightforward and user-friendly experience for initiating remote connections.
Type the name of the RDP/Windows host you are trying to access in PC Name. The name should be the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FDQN), e.g. "desktop.ad.umiacs.umd.edu". Once you have filled that out, click Save.
The image illustrates the user interface of the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a Windows device. The background is predominantly black, creating a strong contrast with white text. At the top, the title "Remote Desktop" is presented in a clear, simple font. A central message prompts users to "Connect to apps and desktops," indicating the application’s main function. 

On the right side, a sidebar labeled "Add a desktop" contains input fields for connection configuration. The "PC name" field is pre-filled with "desktop.ad.umiacs.umd.edu," highlighting the remote computer's domain name. Below that, the "User account" section allows users to select their preferred login method, with an option labeled "Ask me every time" currently chosen.

An optional "Display name" field prompts users to assign a nickname for the connection, further enhancing organization within the app. At the bottom right, a prominent blue "Save" button facilitates the finalization of connection settings. Additionally, a text link offers assistance with connection issues, signaling the user-friendly design intended for seamless operation in a remote access context.
Now, you should be on a page where you will see the PC you have just added. Double-click the PC and enter your UMIACS credentials. Please note that the username must be in the format UMIACS\username (this must be a back slash and not a forward slash). Then, click Connect.
The image shows the user interface of the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a Windows device. The background is predominantly black, contrasting with the elements displayed. At the top, the title "Remote Desktop" is labeled clearly. Below this, there's a collapsible section titled "Saved Desktops," which displays a grey tile representing a saved desktop connection. The tile features a simplistic white icon of a computer monitor centered within it, effectively illustrating its function. Below the icon, a label reads "desktop.ad.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) of the remote machine for connection. 

In the upper right corner are two functional icons: a '+' plus sign to add a new desktop and a gear icon for settings, both enhancing usability. The overall layout is streamlined for user navigation, emphasizing functionality while maintaining a modern aesthetic. The design prioritizes clarity with a focus on providing essential information for connecting to remote desktops straightforwardly.
The image displays a Windows login prompt for a Remote Desktop Connection application. The background is dark, providing a stark contrast to the text and input fields. At the top, the header reads "Log in," indicating the purpose of the dialog. Below this, there are two labeled input fields: the first for the "Username," which is filled with a placeholder email format, "User@contoso.com," suggesting the expected input format. The second input is for the "Password," with the prompt "Enter password" and obscured characters indicating security.

Below the input fields, there's an option labeled "Remember me" represented by a checkbox, allowing users to save their login credentials for future access. At the bottom, two buttons are present: "Cancel," in a darker tone, and "Connect," highlighted to indicate the action button for submitting the login details. The overall design focuses on clarity and user-friendliness, facilitating quick input for remote desktop access.
If it asks to "Accept certificate and connect?", press Connect.
︗macOS
For connecting to Windows client over RDP, we recommend the 'Microsoft Remote Desktop' application(The prior text links to https://apps.apple.com/us/app/microsoft-remote-desktop-10/id1295203466?mt=12).  Another, although less preferred, options is the CoRD client.

Open the 'Microsoft Remote Desktop Application' and select '+ New' to create a new device profile
The image depicts the user interface of the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a macOS device. The top portion features a dark gray toolbar, which includes several icons and a search bar. The icons consist of a grid-like menu, a settings gear, and a prominent plus sign (“+”) allowing users to add a new connection. A dropdown menu appears when hovering over the plus sign, offering options to "Add PC" or "Add Workspace." 

Below the toolbar, two tabs labeled “PCs” and “Workspaces” categorize the functionalities. The background displays an underlying view of a desktop environment with multiple windows opened, providing a glimpse of the active applications. The overall design is sleek and modern, with a focus on user accessibility, making it easy for users to initiate remote connections efficiently. The color scheme emphasizes a professional aesthetic, enhancing the visual appeal while maintaining clarity for user actions.
Fill in the'PC Name' field with the name of the remote host you wish to connect to. If you wish to redirect resources from the remote machine to your local machine, please see the section titled 'Redirecting Resources on Mac' below. Then press the blue add button in the bottom right corner.
The image displays a dialog box from the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a macOS device for adding a new PC connection. The background of the window is a dark gray, which enhances the visibility of the white text and icons. At the top, there are input fields labeled "PC name" and "User account." The "PC name" field is pre-filled with "fakePC09," indicating the name of the remote computer the user intends to connect to. The "User account" drop-down menu shows "Ask when required," suggesting the user will be prompted for credentials upon connection.

Below these fields, the dialog offers several options: a "Friendly name," which is marked as optional for personal identification of the connection; a "Group" option that specifies the connection category; and a "Gateway" field with no gateway selected. A few checkboxes are present, allowing users to enable options like reconnecting if the connection is dropped and connecting to an admin session.

At the bottom, there are two buttons: "Cancel," which is darker in tone, and a prominent blue "Add" button for finalizing the connection setup. Overall, the interface maintains a clean, user-friendly design, facilitating easy configuration for remote connections.
You will now see the device listed below. Double click it to start the connection.
The image displays the user interface of the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a macOS device. The background is predominantly dark gray, which enhances visibility for the displayed elements. At the top, the application features a toolbar containing icons for a grid menu, a settings gear, and a prominent plus sign (“+”) for adding a new connection. Below the toolbar, two tabs, “PCs” and “Workspaces,” categorize functionalities. 

The main section presents a tile labeled "fakePC09," with a simplistic white icon depicting a computer monitor, visually identifying the connection. This tile highlights the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) of the remote machine. Below the icon, a user-friendly edit icon allows for quick modifications. The design is modern and sleek, prioritizing clarity, usability, and efficient navigation for users wishing to initiate remote desktop connections.
You will then be prompted for the username and password used to log into the remote host. After typing in both the username and password, press the blue continue button.
The image displays a login prompt from the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a macOS device. The background is dark gray, enhancing the contrast with the input fields and text. At the top, the title reads "Enter Your User Account," clarifying the purpose of the dialog. 

There are two labeled fields: the first for the "Username," which is pre-filled with "myUsername," suggesting that users should enter their account information. Below this, a "Password" field allows users to input their credentials, with hidden characters indicating security. A checkbox labeled "Show password" is visible, enabling users to view their entered password if selected.

At the bottom of the dialog, two buttons are present: "Cancel," which is darker in appearance, and "Continue," prominently highlighted in blue, indicating the action to proceed with the connection. The overall layout is clean and straightforward, prioritizing ease of use and clarity for users entering their login information to access a remote desktop session.
If you see a screen appear that looks like the one pictured below, press the blue continue button. You should then be connected to the remote host.
The image displays a security warning dialog from the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on macOS, alerting the user about a potential issue with the remote connection's security certificate. The dialog features a dark background with a prominent message stating, "You are connecting to the RDP host 'termsrv06'. The certificate couldn’t be verified back to a root certificate. Your connection may not be secure. Do you want to continue?" 

At the top left, there is a padlock icon with a red warning symbol, indicating a security concern. Below the main message, two buttons are provided: "Cancel," which allows the user to abort the connection attempt, and "Continue," highlighted in blue, signaling the option to proceed despite the warning. Additionally, a link to "Show Certificate" is available, enabling users to view details about the certificate in question. The layout prioritizes user clarity while reminding them of the potential risks involved in continuing with the connection.
︗UNIX
︗freerdp
If you are trying to access a Windows host via RDP on an Ubuntu machine, you should use the rdesktop client from the command line. This should be preinstalled, so there is no configuration that needs to happen. 
To use rdesktop, open a shell prompt and type the following command, replacing values as appropriate: 

rdesktop -r clipboard:CLIPBOARD -g <GEOMETRY> -d UMIACS -u <USERNAME> <HOSTNAME>
Key: 

<GEOMETRY>: Percent of remote host's screen to mirror on the client
<USERNAME>: Your UMIACS username (Do not include domain name)
<HOSTNAME>: Fully Qualified Domain Name (FDQN) of the desired remote host
Once you have connected, you will be directed to a Windows login screen where you can complete the login process.

︗xfreerdp
Xfreerdp is the replacement for rdesktop included with newer Linux hosts, starting with RHEL7 and Ubuntu 12.04/14.04. You should use the xfreerdp client from the command line. This is preinstalled on these newer hosts. 
The command for xfreerdp is a bit different than rdesktop. To connect via RDP to a remote host with xfreerdp, type the following command, replacing values as appropriate: 

 xfreerdp -d UMIACS -u <USERNAME> --plugin cliprdr -g <GEOMETRY> <HOSTNAME>
Similar to rdesktop, here is an explanation of the values above:

<GEOMETRY>: Percent of remote host's screen to mirror on the client
<USERNAME>: Your UMIACS username (Do not include domain name)
<HOSTNAME>: Fully Qualified Domain Name (FDQN) of the desired remote host
As with any of these RDP solutions, closing xfreerdp (using the top bar or using CTRL+C) without logging out could cause considerable problems for other users of the workstation. If you are using a shared workstation, please be sure to logout after you are finished with the remote machine using the Start menu.

︗Redirecting Resources on Windows
Resource redirection must be set up before connection is established.
︗Audio Redirection
This allows the remote desktop to access the audio capture and playback devices on the user's desktop.
Click the "Show Options" drop down menu
Navigate to the "Local Resources" tab
Click the "Settings" button in the Remote audio box
Select preferred audio preferences
Select "OK
Select "Connect"
︗Other Resource Redirection
This allows the remote desktop to access the drives, printers, and video capture devices on the user's desktop.
Click the "Show Options" drop down menu
Navigate to the "Local Resources" tab
Click the "More" button in the Local devices and resources box
Click the checkbox next to the resources you would like to redirect
Select "OK"
Select "Connect"
︗Redirecting Resources on Mac
If you have already created the PC connection, right click over the PC connection you wish to add resource redirection to, then select 'Edit'.
︗None
This allows the remote machine to access specified folders on your local machine.
Located halfway down the screen, select the 'Folders' tab.
Check the box titled 'Redirect folders,' if not checked already
Either select the folder(s) already listed you wish to access from the remote machine by checking the box next to the desired folder, or select the '+' button, then import and select the folder(s) you wish to access.
Press the blue 'Add' button in the bottom right corner, or if you wish to direct other resources as well, see 'Other Resource Redirection' below.
The image depicts the "Add PC" dialog box from the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a macOS device. The background is a dark gray, providing a clear contrast for the input fields and options presented. At the top, there are fields labeled “PC name” and “User account.” The “PC name” field is pre-filled with "fakePC09," indicating the specific remote computer the user intends to connect to. The “User account” drop-down menu displays "Ask when required," suggesting that the user will be prompted for login credentials during the connection process.

Below these fields, users can configure folder redirection settings. A checkbox titled “Redirect folders” is checked, indicating that the user wants to access specific folders during the remote session. Below this, a list displays folders available for redirection, with columns for “Name,” “Path,” and “Read-only” status. In this case, a folder named “ClearCellGame” is listed with its corresponding path shown. The overall layout is user-friendly, featuring a prominent blue "Add" button for finalizing the settings, alongside a "Cancel" button in a darker tone, allowing for easy navigation and configuration within the application.
︗Other Resource Redirection
This will allow for camera, printer, and/or microphone access to be shared between machines.
Located halfway down the screen, select the 'Devices and Audio' tab.
Ensure the boxes next to the services you would like to redirect are checked.  For video, ensure that the 'Microphone' and 'Camera' boxes are checkmarked.  For printer access, ensure that the 'Printers' box is checkmarked. Please be mindful to keep 'Clipboard' checkmarked, as that is what allows you to copy and paste between your local machine and the remote machine.
Press the blue 'Add' button in the bottom right corner.
The image displays the "Add PC" dialog within the Microsoft Remote Desktop application on a macOS device. The interface features a dark gray background that creates a clear contrast with the light text and interface elements. At the top, there are two input fields: the “PC name” field is populated with "fakePC09," indicating the intended remote host, while the “User account” dropdown shows "Ask when required," suggesting the user will need to input credentials at the time of connection.

Beneath the input fields, the dialog allows for configuration of resource redirection during the remote session. This includes checkboxes for various device types under the "Redirect" section: "Printers," "Smart cards," "Clipboard," "Microphone," and "Cameras," with the last three options currently selected, denoting shared access amongst devices. Additionally, there’s a specific setting labeled "Play sound" with the selection "On this computer," indicating where audio output will occur during the session.

At the bottom, two buttons are present: a blue "Add" button for confirming the configuration and a darker "Cancel" button for aborting the action. Overall, the layout is user-friendly and designed for efficient navigation while setting up a remote connection.

︗WindowsPrinting

From UMIACS
(Redirected from WindowsPrintingUMIACS)

Jump to search
