︗Introduction
This will guide you through the process of installing and using the printers available within UMIACS.

︗None
If you are off the UMIACS network, you must first connect to the VPN on Windows. After you are connected, follow the instructions for adding a printer queue below. Please note that you must be on the VPN whenever you print.

︗Pre-Installation Knowledge on Printing at UMIACS
 Printer Queue Naming

︗Installation of printer queue
Please note that this applies to machines on any UMIACS network. This includes all proxy networks, the vast majority of machines in the labs, and machines connected to the UMIACS VPN - but not a wireless network (e.g., eduroam, umd-guest) alone. 

Go to Start and search "\\printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu" in the search box.
The image depicts a Windows operating system interface, specifically showcasing the search function. The bottom portion features the Windows search bar displaying the text "\\printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu", indicating an attempt to access a network printer address. Above this, a results section shows "Best match" highlighted, indicating that the search has successfully located the network printers path. An icon representing a monitor appears next to the text, suggesting the command initiates a connection to networked printers. The layout is standard for Windows, with rounded corners and a light background that contrasts the text. There are options to "Open" or "Open file location", providing additional actions related to the found network path. The application menu is visible on the left side, featuring icons for accessing various applications, settings, and documents. Overall, the image conveys a utility function for managing printer connections within a networked environment, reflecting a user-friendly approach to system navigation in Windows.
You will be prompted with a box for authentication if you are not signed into Windows with your UMIACS account (e.g. on a laptop or self-supported machine).  Make sure to prefix 'UMIACS\' to your username.  (For example, if your username was 'johndoe' you would enter 'UMIACS\johndoe' in the username box.)
Check the box for 'Remember my credentials' before clicking OK or you may not be able to add printer queues in the next step.
The image displays a Windows Security dialog box prompting the user to enter their network credentials to connect to the printer network at "printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu." The dialogue is set against a light gray background, characteristic of the Windows interface. At the top, the title "Windows Security" is indicated, signifying the purpose of the dialog. Below, a field labeled "Enter your credentials to connect to:" contains a text box where the username should be entered in the format "UMIACS\username." A masked text field below indicates where the password should be entered, represented by bullet points. The "Domain" field specifies "UMIACS." 

Additionally, there is a checkbox labeled "Remember my credentials," which is checked, suggesting that the user opts to save their credentials for future logins. At the bottom, two buttons labeled "OK" and "Cancel" are provided for user action. A red warning message states, "The user name or password is incorrect," implying an error in the authentication process. Overall, the image captures a moment of user interaction with Windows security settings related to network printer access.
A list of printer queues will appear.  Select your desired printer by double clicking on the queue.
The image showcases a Windows file explorer window displaying the contents of a network directory labeled "printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu." The top navigation bar includes a file path indicating the current folder location within the network. In this directory, there are multiple printer icons arranged in a grid format, each labeled with distinct names, such as "cps224-3100p" and "cps432-3208." The printer icons are stylized with a modern design, featuring a small display screen and a paper tray, positioned on a green base to signify availability.

On the left sidebar, options for quick access and local drives are visible, with the "Network" section highlighted. A search bar at the top-right corner allows users to search for specific printer addresses. One printer icon, "cps432-3208," is highlighted in blue, indicating that it is selected. The overall layout is clean and user-friendly, typical of the Windows interface, designed to facilitate easy access and management of network printers. The image conveys a practical overview of available printers within a structured network environment.
Wait for the printer driver installation.  This may take a minute or two to complete.
The image shows a Windows printer installation progress dialog. The dialog is framed with rounded corners, typical of the Windows interface, and has a white background. At the top, the title "Windows Printer Installation" is boldly displayed. Below this, the message "Connecting to cps432-3208 on printers" is shown, indicating the specific printer model being accessed. A green progress bar occupies the central part of the dialog, visually demonstrating the status of the connection process; it has a percentage indicated by the length of the colored bar, suggesting the action is underway. The remaining section of the dialog features a "Cancel" button, enabling users to halt the installation if needed. The overall composition is clean and simple, embodying the user-friendly nature of Windows prompts. This image conveys a moment of technical interaction, highlighting the common task of connecting to a network printer within a Windows environment, and suggests a seamless integration process for users.
Once done, you can start using the printer.
The image depicts a printer queue window for the printer labeled "cps432-3208" on a Windows operating system interface. The window features a clean and organized layout typical of Windows applications. At the top, the title specifies the printer name and its connection, emphasizing its operational status within the network. 

Below the title, there are five columns labeled "Document Name," "Status," "Owner," "Pages," "Size," and "Submitted" which are intended to display information about print jobs in the queue. However, the table currently appears empty, indicating no active or pending documents for printing. The interface is predominantly white, enhancing readability, with clear font usage for easy identification of each column's purpose.

A horizontal scrollbar at the bottom suggests that the window may accommodate more content than is currently displayed, while the presence of a drop-down menu in the top-right corner indicates options for altering the view or settings related to the printer queue. Overall, the image conveys a straightforward user interface aimed at managing print jobs efficiently within a networked environment.
︗Troubleshooting
If you receive the following error when attempting to add a printer queue, the issue may be that your computer is configured for a higher level of printer security than is default at UMIACS as a result of the PrintNightmare vulnerability(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PrintNightmare).

The image shows a Windows error dialog titled "Add Printer." It features a rounded rectangular window typical of the Windows interface, set against a light background. At the top, an orange circular icon with an “X” indicates an error. Below this, the message reads, "Connect to Printer," indicating that there is an issue with printer connectivity. The message continues, stating, "Windows cannot connect to the printer. Access is denied," which implies a permissions issue preventing the user from connecting to the specified printer. At the bottom, there is a single "OK" button, allowing the user to acknowledge the error and close the dialog. The overall design of the dialog is utilitarian, focusing on presenting essential information clearly and concisely, emphasizing the problem of connectivity within a networked environment. This image conveys the frustrations users may encounter when attempting to connect to printers without appropriate permissions or configurations in a Windows operating system.
To resolve this error:

Click on the Start menu and type "cmd" in the run bar.
The image shows a Windows operating system interface, specifically the search function. At the bottom, the search bar displays the text "cmd," indicating that a user is searching for the Command Prompt application. In the results section, "Best match" highlights this application with an associated icon, which resembles a black command window, denoting that it is used for executing commands. Options to "Open," "Run as administrator," and "Open file location" appear, providing actions the user can take. The background features a typical Windows desktop layout, with various application icons and a taskbar, suggesting an active user environment. The overall design is clean, utilizing a blue color palette for enhanced readability, reflecting a user-friendly search experience typical of Windows interfaces. This image captures a moment when a user is preparing to access advanced system settings or execute commands, indicating a level of technical engagement with the device.
Right-Click on the cmd button, and select "Run as Administrator" - THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT!
This image shows a Windows operating system interface featuring the search function. The main context is the search bar at the bottom, where the term "cmd" is displayed, indicating a search for the Command Prompt application. The left panel highlights the "Best match" result of the search, showing the cmd application with options to "Open," "Run as administrator," and "Open file location." This area is designed to facilitate user navigation and command execution. The right side includes a small icon of the Command Prompt, depicted as a black window, confirming that the user is searching for a command-line interface. The background features a typical desktop environment with various icons, emphasizing an active user workspace in Windows. The overall composition reflects a user-friendly interaction aiming to access advanced system features, illustrating a blend of visual clarity and functional design inherent to Windows interfaces.
Select "Yes" when it asks if you want to allow the following program to make changes.
The image displays a User Account Control (UAC) window from the Windows operating system. The main focus is on a warning prompt that indicates a request for permission to allow the "cmd.exe" application to make changes to the computer. The header is highlighted in yellow, emphasizing its importance, while the body of the dialog box is set against a light gray background for clarity. The message reads: "Do you want to allow this app from an unknown publisher to make changes to your device?" This indicates that the system is asking for user consent before proceeding with the command prompt execution.

Below the warning message, the application name "cmd.exe" is noted along with the publisher's status labeled as "Unknown," further emphasizing the security measures in place. Additionally, it specifies the file origin as "Hard drive on this computer." At the bottom of the dialog, there are two prominent buttons: "Yes," which the user can click to allow the process, and "No," to deny it. The overall layout of the prompt is functional and straightforward, designed to facilitate user interaction while ensuring system security.
From the Command Prompt, run these commands in order:
reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows NT\Printers\PointAndPrint" /v RestrictDriverInstallationToAdministrators /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f
reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print" /v RpcAuthnLevelPrivacyEnabled /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f
net stop spooler /y && net start spooler
The image displays a Command Prompt window in a Windows operating system environment. The screen background is black, typical of Terminal interfaces, and the text appears in white, indicating that the Command Prompt is being used to execute commands. At the top left, the window title reads "Administrator: Command Prompt," suggesting that the user has elevated privileges. 

Multiple lines of commands and outputs are visible:

1. A command to modify the registry settings for printer driver installation.
2. Confirmation that the operation completed successfully.
3. A command to stop and restart the Print Spooler service, with outputs indicating each operation's success.

The text contains specifics like registry paths and command syntaxes, emphasizing technical interaction with the system. The presence of the command prompt cursor indicates that the user can input further commands. Overall, the image conveys a moment of administrative control and troubleshooting within the Windows environment, particularly focused on printer management.
Attempt to add the printer queue again.
︗Removing a printer queue
To remove a printer queue, open the Start menu and search for and go to Control Panel. Next, click on "View devices and printers." To remove the queue, right click on the printer and select "Remove device". If you wish to add the printer back, follow the instructions above.

The image displays the "Devices and Printers" window from a Windows operating system, showcasing the printers available to the user. In the central area, there is an icon of the printer labeled "cps432-3208" which is connected to the network at "printers.ad.umiacs.umd.edu". This printer's icon is highlighted, indicating it is currently selected, and there is a green checkmark showing it is operational. Next to it, there are several other printer icons, including one for "Adobe PDF." 

A contextual menu appears when hovering over the selected printer, offering options such as "See what’s printing," "Set as default printer," "Printing preferences," "Printer properties," "Create shortcut," "Remove device," "Troubleshoot," and "Properties." Each option is clearly listed, providing straightforward actions for managing the printer.

The overall design is clean, with a light background allowing for easy identification of different printer statuses. The interface reflects a standard user experience in Windows, aimed at facilitating effective management of printer settings and preferences.
︗Duplex Printing
Many printers in UMIACS support duplex (2 sided) printing. To make the duplex printing default, first make sure the appropriate printer queue is installed via the directions above. Afterwards, go to start, then “Devices and Printers.”
Once the printer has been installed proceed by right clicking on the queue then selecting “Printing preferences.”

The image displays a Windows "Devices and Printers" window from the Control Panel, showing connected printers. Prominently featured is the printer labeled "cps432-3208," which has a green checkmark indicating operational status. The interface includes other nearby printer icons, including one for "Adobe PDF." The selected printer's icon is surrounded by a blue highlight, signifying it's currently focused upon by the user. 

An action menu appears upon right-clicking this printer icon, offering several options such as: "See what's printing," "Set as default printer," "Printing preferences," "Printer properties," "Create shortcut," "Remove device," "Troubleshoot," and "Properties." These options are displayed in a list format for easy accessibility, emphasizing user control over printer management tasks. 

The window's design features a clean, light background that enhances readability, with a clear organizational layout typical of Windows interfaces. The integration of various actions allows for straightforward printer management by users, facilitating both viewing and altering printer settings efficiently.
After a few seconds the following menu will come up. Make sure you are on the “Printing Shortcuts” tab and select the “EcoSMART Settings” option then click on okay. This modification will allow you to print 2-sided whenever you choose to use this printer.

The image displays the "Printing Preferences" window for the printer labeled "cps432-3208" within a Windows operating system environment. The interface is characterized by a clear layout, typical of HP printer settings, featuring multiple tabs at the top such as "Advanced," "Printing Shortcuts," "Paper/Quality," "Effects," "Finishing," and "Services." 

In the center, under "Printing shortcuts," a list showcases two options: "Factory Defaults" and "EcoSMART Settings." The latter is selected, indicated by a blue highlight, which signifies the user's choice for quick access to these settings. To the right, essential information is displayed regarding the current paper size (8.5 x 11 inches), paper source (Automatically Select), pages per sheet (1 page per sheet), and duplex printing option ("Yes, flip over") for two-sided printing. 

At the bottom of the window, there are buttons for "Save As...," "Delete," "Reset," and "OK," along with the HP logo, creating a professional appearance while facilitating user actions related to print settings. Overall, the image represents a user-friendly interface designed to customize printing preferences efficiently.
︗Store and Print PIN-Protected Jobs
PIN-protected jobs provide a way to ensure jobs are not printed until you are ready to pick them up. This can be useful if you have a sensitive job that you want to print on a public printer at UMIACS. Follow the below steps to store a job and then print it at the printer.
Create a stored job

From the software program, select the Print option.
Select the printer from the list of printers, and then select Properties or Preferences (name varies by software program)
Click the Job Storage tab.
Under Job Storage Mode, select Personal Job.
The image displays the "Printing Preferences" window for a printer, designed in a clean, user-friendly layout characteristic of HP printer settings within a Windows operating system. The window includes various tabs at the top, such as "Advanced," "Printing Shortcuts," "Paper/Quality," “Effects,” “Finishing,” “Job Storage,” “Color,” and “Services.” 

In the central section, under the "Job Storage Mode," the option "Personal Job" is prominently highlighted in red, indicating that this setting is currently selected. This setting emphasizes that jobs will only print upon request from the printer's control panel. Below this, the "Make Job Private/Secure" section features a drop-down selection, currently set to "None," with an area for entering a username marked "User name"—indicating customization options available for the user.

To the right, fields for "Job Name" and additional notification options help customize the printing experience further. The interface is visually organized with clear section labeling and buttons for "OK" and "Cancel" at the bottom, which allow users to finalize their settings or exit. The HP logo in the lower corner reinforces the document's authenticity, while the green background indicates it's part of printer interface settings. Overall, this image illustrates the technical aspects of configuring a PIN-protected printing process, enhancing user privacy and control over print jobs.
In the drop-down menu under Make Job Private/Secure, select PIN to print, and type in a 4-digit number.
The image displays the "Printing Preferences" window for a printer, designed in a user-friendly layout typical of HP printer settings within a Windows environment. The window is divided into sections, with multiple tabs at the top, including "Advanced," "Printing Shortcuts," "Paper/Quality," “Effects,” “Finishing,” “Job Storage,” “Color,” and “Services.” 

In the main area, under "Job Storage Mode," the option "Personal Job" is prominently highlighted, indicating this setting's current selection. Below this, the "Make Job Private/Secure" section features a drop-down menu set to "PIN to print," suggesting that to initiate printing, a 4-digit PIN must be entered. Adjacent to this is a masked input field for entering the PIN, indicated by bullets, emphasizing security. 

Additional fields for "User Name" and "Job Name" allow for further customization. The layout is visually organized, with clear section headings and buttons like "OK" and "Cancel" at the bottom, facilitating user interaction effectively. The HP logo reinforces the legitimacy of the dialog, while the light background color enhances readability. This image represents key functionalities for enabling secure printing, focusing on user privacy.
Note: You will need to provide the entered PIN (4-digit number) at the printer's control panel.
Click the OK button to close the Document Properties/Preferences dialog box. In the Print dialog box, click Print.
Print a stored job
After you have created a stored job using the instructions above, follow these steps to print from the printer's control panel.

From the Home screen on the printer control panel, select Print.
Select Print from Job Storage.
The image displays the control panel of an HP printer, featuring a user interface designed for print management. In the center, there are three main options displayed in rectangular buttons: "Print from Job Storage," "Print from USB Drive," and "HP JetAdvantage." The "Print from Job Storage" option is highlighted with a red border, indicating that it is the currently selected choice. The other buttons are colored blue and feature relevant icons: a disk icon for Job Storage, a USB icon for printing from a USB drive, and a cloud icon for HP JetAdvantage services. Below the buttons, a loading bar is partially filled, suggesting the printer is processing a command or awaiting user interaction. The background is light gray, with some darker elements including a "Reset" button and a "Sign In" option located at the top, indicating user authentication features. Overall, the image conveys a straightforward and intuitive interface, aimed at facilitating user access to various printing functions, particularly for stored print jobs, enhancing convenience and security in printing tasks.
Select Choose, and then select the name of the folder where the job is stored.
The image displays a control panel interface of a printer, specifically focused on the "Stored Job to Print" menu. At the top, the title "Stored Job to Print" is prominently presented in clear font. Below this, there are two listings: "Untitled" and a folder labeled "XXXXXXXXXX," indicating available stored print jobs. Each entry features an arrow indicating that they can be selected for further details or action. The layout is straightforward, with a light background providing contrast against the darker text, and the overall design is functional, emphasizing usability. At the bottom-right, two buttons are visible—“Cancel!” in a bolder style and "Select," both designed for user interaction. The presence of a small icon resembling a trash can on the left suggests an option to delete a selected job. The image conveys a user-friendly approach for accessing and managing print jobs stored in the printer's memory, highlighting the convenience of retrieving sensitive or scheduled print tasks.
Select the name of the job, enter your chosen PIN (4-digit number), and click Ok.
The image displays a touchscreen interface for entering a PIN at a printer. At the top, there is a text box labeled "Enter PIN," where the user will input their numeric password. Below, a numeric keypad is arranged in a 3x3 grid format, with numbers 1 to 9 and a 0 positioned in the last row for easy access. Each button is rectangular and clearly labeled, providing an intuitive layout for numerical entry. 

To the right of the keypad, a small button features an "X" icon, likely for canceling the entry, and another button below it shows a printer icon with a downward arrow, suggesting that it will execute the print job once the PIN has been entered. The overall color scheme of the interface is light, with the buttons standing out against the background for clear visibility. This interface conveys a straightforward and secure method for users to access their stored print jobs, emphasizing both privacy and functionality.
Select Print to print the job.
The image displays a touchscreen interface for a printer, focused on the "Print from Job Storage" feature. At the top, the title "Print from Job Storage" is prominently displayed, providing clear context for the user. Below, the section labeled "Stored Job to Print" lists a specific job identified as "new 1.txt," with a preceding identifier indicated by "xxxxxxxxx," suggesting it's a job stored under a particular user's profile. 

The job details section includes two lines: "Job Name," showcasing "new 1.txt," and "User Name," represented as "SIREN\xxxxxxxxx," indicating the user associated with the print job. On the bottom right, there is a square button outlined in red featuring a green print icon, which suggests this is the action to initiate the printing of the selected job. A numeric selector next to it indicates the quantity of copies to be printed, currently set to "1."

The layout is organized, designed for ease of use, with the interface reflecting user-friendly design principles typical of modern printers. The overall focus on accessibility and clarity enhances the printing experience, especially for users managing stored documents.
Note: The print job is deleted from memory after it prints.

Privacy policy
About UMIACS
Disclaimers


(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Windows_Account_Migration_March_2018 contains the following information: 






︗Windows Account Migration March 2018

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
When: Saturday, March 24th 2018 from 8am-11:59pm

︗Introduction
Currently UMIACS provides two user authentication stores, our Linux/UNIX Kerberos5 realm and Windows Active Directory (PC). To simplify the user experience we will be consolidating authentication into a single new Active Directory domain (UMIACS).  At the end of the consolidation, you will be able to use a single password for all UMIACS services.
To prepare for this change, UMIACS staff need to migrate all UMIACS Windows accounts to a new domain. This migration starts by moving your account from our existing Windows Active Directory domain (PC\username) to a new one (UMIACS\username). After this migration is completed we will follow up with an announcement detailing the final steps of the password consolidation process.
No files or emails will be lost as part of this migration.​

︗Actions you need to take
Log off your Windows workstation (if you have one) prior to 8am on Saturday, March 24th, otherwise you will be forcibly logged out at this time.
︗Service impact during this Migration
Your password will NOT change.
Authentication to the Pulse Secure VPN will not be available during this migration window. Existing sessions will not be terminated, allowing you to continue using the VPN through the migration.  Two days prior to the migration, we will extend the default VPN session limit to 48 hours in order to minimize your disruption. If you require the VPN during this time please make sure you authenticate and maintain your connection before the outage window starts.
Windows workstations will be unavailable to log into during this migration window.
Exchange email access will be interrupted during this migration window.  Exchange email will be delivered however will not be accessible from phones, Outlook, or Outlook Web Access until after the migration has concluded.
︗After the migration has completed
We will post an announcement on https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu) when the migration has completed and will also send a follow-up email.
Your Windows account format will change from PC\username to UMIACS\username where you are required to specify a domain. You must use this username format going forward. Services that will require this new format:
Outlook Web Access for Exchange email users
Phone email setup for Exchange email users
Remote Desktop workstation access
Saved network drive(The prior text links to https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/4026635/windows-map-a-network-drive) credentials, which can be updated via Credential Manager(The prior text links to https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/4026814/windows-accessing-credential-manager)






Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Windows_Account_Migration_March_2018&oldid=9331"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Reserve contains the following information: 






︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Reserve

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
This page will show you how to reserve rooms through Google Calendar.  Most all the steps will generally be the same for  moderated and  auto-accept rooms with the former requiring an additional step at the end for moderation to happen.

︗Steps
Navigate to https://calendar.google.com(The prior text links to https://calendar.google.com).  The image shows a screenshot of the Google Calendar interface for April 2019. The calendar occupies the central portion of the screen, displaying the days of the week from Thursday, April 4 (highlighted with a blue circle) to Sunday, April 7, on the right side. The hours of the day are vertically listed from 11 AM to 10 PM on the left side. 

Beneath the calendar, there is a sidebar with the title "My calendars," which includes checkboxes for "Liam Monahan," "Reminders," and "Tasks." "Other calendars" is denoted as a separate section beneath. 

A red dot indicates an event scheduled at 8 PM on Thursday, April 4, while the time slots for other hours remain empty. The interface features a minimalistic design with a white background, emphasizing the calendar entries, which are displayed in a clean and straightforward manner. Icons for creating new events and managing calendars appear at the top left, hinting at the user-friendly navigation of the application. 
Ensure that you are logged into your UMD account.  Only these accounts can schedule rooms.  Terpmail accounts will not work; it must be just your @umd.edu email address account.  Switch or add an account if not: Google has instructions here(The prior text links to https://support.google.com/docs/answer/2405894?co=GENIE.Platform%3DDesktop&hl=en).  When adding an account you will be prompted by Google for your email/phone.  This is your UMD username that you use to log into the UMD Central Authentication System (CAS) appended with @umd.edu.  For example username@umd.edu.  You will then be redirected to the UMD CAS login page if you don't have a current session open. The image is a screenshot of the Google Calendar interface for April 2019. The central focus is on a weekly calendar view displaying Thursday, April 4, through Sunday, April 7, with Thursday highlighted by a blue circle. The left sidebar features sections like "My calendars," showing items checked such as "Liam Monahan," "Reminders," and "Tasks," and a separate area labeled "Other calendars." 

The vertical time slots range from 11 AM to 10 PM, indicating available hours for scheduling. A prominent red dot denotes an event scheduled for 8 PM on Thursday, April 4, while the remaining slots for that day are empty, indicating no other events are planned. The interface is designed in a minimalistic style with a clean white background, enhancing visibility of the calendar entries. 

At the top, there are navigation icons for creating new events and managing calendars. In the upper right corner, the user account information is displayed, indicating that the account is managed by UMD.edu, associated with the email address shown, "lmonahan@umd.edu." 
Click "Create" to start adding event details. The second image is a screenshot of the Google Calendar event creation window. At the top, there’s a header reading "Add title" in a bold font, prompting the user to name the event. Below, the date, "Thursday, April 4, 2019," is shown with time slots indicating the event runs from 8:00 PM to 9:00 PM. A note below mentions the time zone and specifies that the event does not repeat. 

On the left, there are options to add guests and select a location, with a button labeled "Add Google Meet video conferencing" highlighted in blue, suggesting this feature can be integrated into the event. The image also displays the presence indicator for a specific user, "Matthew R. Baney," showing that this person is busy, with default visibility settings and a notification set to 10 minutes before the event.

The overall interface is clean and organized, with a white background and blue accents. In the bottom right corner, a prominent blue "Save" button is visible, indicating that finalizing the event will be completed here. 
Search for the room you wish to schedule by clicking the "Rooms" tab on the right. Rooms are of the form "IRB XXXX".  Note: You can search available rooms only or all rooms. Rooms that appear with strikethough text are not available to reserve at the time(s) you have chosen. ### Image 1: Google Calendar Interface (April 2019)

The image displays a screenshot of the Google Calendar interface, focused on the week of April 4 to April 7, 2019. The central part shows a weekly view with Thursday, April 4, highlighted by a blue circle, indicating it is the current selected date. Vertical time slots range from 11 AM to 10 PM on the left side, suggesting the hours available for event scheduling. A red dot marks an event scheduled for 8 PM on Thursday, while the rest of the day’s time slots appear unfilled. To the left, a sidebar labeled "My calendars" lists checked items such as "Liam Monahan," "Reminders," and "Tasks." Below this, a section for "Other calendars" is visible. The calendar interface is characterized by a minimalistic design, with a clean white background and straightforward navigation icons at the top left for creating events, reinforcing its user-friendly nature. In the upper right corner, the user's UMD email address indicates the account management. The overall visual is clear and organized.

### Image 2: Event Creation Window in Google Calendar

The second image features the Google Calendar event creation window. At the top, a bold header reads "Add title," prompting users to name their event. Below this, the date—Thursday, April 4, 2019—is displayed, along with designated time slots indicating the event duration from 8:00 PM to 9:00 PM. A note mentions the timezone and clarifies that the event does not repeat. On the left side, users can add guests and select locations, with a highlighted option to "Add Google Meet video conferencing," showing integration capabilities for online meetings. The presence indicator reveals that a user named "Matthew R. Baney" is busy, outlined by visibility settings. The interface is clean, with a white background and blue accents, and a prominent blue "Save" button located at the bottom right invites the user to finalize the event details. 
Select a room and finish filling out your event details.  ### Image Descriptions

#### Image 1: Google Calendar Interface (April 2019)
The image displays a screenshot of Google Calendar, capturing the week of April 4-7, 2019. The interface prominently features a weekly view, with Thursday, April 4, highlighted in a blue circle, indicating the current date. To the left, vertical time slots ranging from 11 AM to 10 PM showcase available scheduling hours. A red dot signifies an event at 8 PM on the highlighted Thursday, while other time slots for that day are empty, suggesting no additional events. The sidebar titled "My calendars" includes checked items like "Liam Monahan," "Reminders," and "Tasks," with a distinct section for "Other calendars." The design is minimalistic, emphasizing simplicity and clarity, supported by a clean white background. Navigation icons at the top left facilitate user actions such as creating events. The upper right corner displays the user's UMD email address, reinforcing account management with the university.

#### Image 2: Event Creation Window in Google Calendar
This image shows the Google Calendar event creation window. At the top, the bold header states "Add title," prompting users to name their event. Below, it indicates the event is scheduled for April 5, 2019, from 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM, with a note mentioning it doesn't repeat. Users can select a location labeled "IRB-3137 (CMNS)" along with an option to add video conferencing, highlighted in blue. A notification setting is adjustable, allowing for a reminder time. The left section displays the organizer's email, showing that the user is busy with default visibility settings. At the bottom, a description box outlines the event's content about a guest lecture, including details about provisions (cookies). The clean interface maintains a white background, blue accents, and a prominent blue "Save" button in the upper right, indicating action completion. 
Hit "Save" and your reservation will be created.  ### Image Descriptions

#### Image 1: Google Calendar Interface (April 2019)
The first image is a screenshot of Google Calendar, showcasing the week spanning April 4 to April 7, 2019. The central focus is on a weekly view, with Thursday, April 4, marked by a blue circle to denote the current date. On the left, vertical time slots are listed from 11 AM to 10 PM, indicating the hours available for scheduling. A prominent red dot indicates an event set for 8 PM on that Thursday, while the rest of the day's slots appear empty, suggesting no other planned activities. The sidebar, labeled "My calendars," displays checked items such as "Liam Monahan," "Reminders," and "Tasks," along with a section titled "Other calendars." The interface's minimalistic design features a clean white background, emphasizing ease of navigation, with icons for creating events at the top left. In the upper right, the user’s UMD email address is visible, confirming the account type, while the overall layout is clear and user-friendly.

#### Image 2: Event Creation Window in Google Calendar
The second image presents the Google Calendar event creation window. At the top, the bold header reads "Add title," prompting users to input the event name. Below, the date—Thursday, April 4, 2019—is shown, and the specified time slots indicate the event lasts from 8:00 PM to 9:00 PM, with a note indicating the event does not repeat. On the left, users can add guests and select a location, with a highlighted button to "Add Google Meet video conferencing," emphasizing integration options. There is a presence indicator showing that "Matthew R. Baney" is marked as busy, with default visibility settings in place. The interface maintains a clean aesthetic with a distinct white background and blue accents, culminating in a blue "Save" button at the bottom right, guiding users to finalize their event details.
If this is a  moderated room, an email for approval will be sent to the moderator(s) at this point.  Your reservation is not valid until one of the moderators for the room approves.
If this is an  auto-accept room, your reservation is valid immediately.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WindowsDisplayModes contains the following information: 






︗WindowsDisplayModes

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
To start, open Settings through your start menu by searching for it or clicking the gear icon.

The image depicts the Windows Settings interface on a computer. The top section of the window features a search bar labeled "Find a setting," allowing users to quickly locate specific settings. Below this, there is a title indicating "Windows Settings." 

The left side of the display lists multiple categories, with icons representing each setting, such as a globe for "Network & Internet," a person for "Accounts," and a pencil for "Personalization." The "System" option is highlighted in a prominent red box, indicating it is currently selected. 

Under the "System" category, related options like "Display, sound, notifications, power" are shown. Additional categories, such as "Devices," "Phone," "Ease of Access," and "Privacy," are laid out below, each accompanied by respective icons.

The overall color scheme is light, with a white background and colored icons, giving a modern, clean appearance typical of Windows interfaces. The design emphasizes accessibility and ease of navigation, helping users adjust their system settings efficiently.

Once you have opened it, click System.

The image displays the "Display" settings interface from the Windows operating system. The layout is simple and functional, with a predominantly light gray background. At the top, a search bar labeled "Find a setting" allows users to quickly search for options. Below this, the "System" category is highlighted in a bold red box, indicating users are currently within this section, specifically viewing "Display."

In the center, two rectangular boxes numbered "1" and "2" represent the connected displays. The first box is highlighted in red, suggesting it is the primary display, while the second is shown in gray. Below these boxes, there are two buttons labeled "Identify" and "Detect," facilitating the identification and detection of connected displays.

The bottom half contains a "Brightness and color" section with a slider for adjusting brightness. Below this, there is an option for "Night light," indicating it's turned on, with settings for the duration displayed underneath. The overall design promotes user accessibility and ease, characteristic of modern Windows interfaces, with a clean aesthetic and intuitive layout.

Click Display on the left bar if it is not already selected and scroll to the bottom of the page.

The image depicts the "Display" settings interface of the Windows operating system. It features a light gray background, creating a clean look conducive to usability. At the top, a search bar labeled "Find a setting" allows users to search directly for specific options. The title "Display" is located prominently, indicating the section users are currently viewing, within the broader "System" settings category.

Center stage are two rectangular boxes numbered "1" and "2," representing connected monitors, with the first box highlighted in red, signifying it as the primary display. Underneath these boxes are buttons labeled "Identify" and "Detect," facilitating interaction with multiple displays. The lower part of the window contains options related to configuring display settings, including different choices for multiple displays: "Duplicate these displays," "Extend these displays," "Show only on 1," and "Show only on 2." The option currently highlighted is "Extend these displays," presented in a red box, indicating an active selection. Overall, the interface is designed for intuitive navigation, with options clearly delineated and visually accessible.

By default, the displays are used in extended mode. If you wish to switch to mirror mode, select the Duplicate these displays option.

There are also 2 more options here then there normally are, Show only on 1 and Show only on 2.

Show only on 1 will only use the screen that you normally use for your computer, leaving the TV blank.
Show only on 2 will only use the TV as the screen, leaving the screen that you normally use blank.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=WindowsDisplayModes&oldid=8418"

︗Services/Support

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS provides hardware and operating system (OS) support for university-owned systems across its various labs and centers.  

︗Hardware Services
In-warranty hardware diagnostic and replacement
Hardware Integration
︗Operating System Services
OS Deployment and integration with other UMIACS Services
Security Updates
Backups
University-Licensed Software
︗Contact UMIACS Technical Support


Mail: 

staff@umiacs.umd.edu


Phone: 

(301) 405-1775(The prior text links to tel:+13014051775)


Help Desk: 

3109 Iribe Center

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms/AutoAccept contains the following information: 






︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms/AutoAccept

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Auto-accept  rooms will allow users to schedule them from the panel (12 hours in advance for up to 2 hours at a time) or through UMD's Google Calendar interface.  The room will auto-accept the reservation if there is no conflict on the calendar.
Instructions on reserving a room are  here.



Room

Occupancy

Notes


IRB-1119

6




IRB-2119

6




IRB-2143

6




IRB-3119

6




IRB-4119

6




IRB-4145

6




IRB-5107

12




IRB-5111

6




IRB-5119

6




IRB-5161

12



︗Large Conference Room Capabilities
Rooms 5107 and 5161 have the following setup.

Single Display (LCD)
Single camera conferencing via room PC
Laptop presentation via HDMI or Mersive Solstice
︗Small Conference Room Capabilities
Every other room on this page has the following setup.

Single Display (LCD)
Software Conferencing via room PC
Laptop presentation via HDMI or Mersive Solstice
︗Conference Rooms with Phone Capabilities
Some auto-accept IRB conference rooms have soft dialing enabled from the Crestron pads.
To answer a call: Start the system, select phone, and hit the "dial/answer" button. To dial out, use prefix 91 for external numbers. (For campus extensions, just dial the 5 digit extension.) Below are the list of phone numbers associated with auto-accept conference rooms. 



Room

Phone Number


IRB-5107

301-314-9974


IRB-5161

301-314-9983

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Nexus/MC2 contains the following information: 






︗Nexus/MC2

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The previous standalone cluster for MC2(The prior text links to https://cyber.umd.edu/about)'s compute nodes have folded into Nexus as of mid 2022.
The Nexus cluster already has a large pool of compute resources made possible through college-level funding for UMIACS and CSD faculty. Details on common nodes already in the cluster (Tron partition) can be found  here.
Please  contact staff with any questions or concerns.

︗Contents

1 Submission Nodes
2 Resources
3 QoS
4 Jobs
5 Storage


︗Submission Nodes
You can SSH to nexusmc2.umiacs.umd.edu to log in to a submission host.
If you store something in a local directory (/tmp, /scratch0) on one of the two submission hosts, you will need to connect to that same submission host to access it later. The actual submission hosts are:

nexusmc200.umiacs.umd.edu
nexusmc201.umiacs.umd.edu
︗Resources
The MC2 partition has nodes brought over from the previous standalone MC2 Slurm scheduler. The compute nodes are named twist##.

︗QoS
MC2 users have access to all of the  standard job QoSes in the MC2 partition using the mc2 account.
The additional jobs QoSes for the MC2 partition specifically are:

highmem: Allows for significantly increased memory to be allocated.
huge-long: Allows for longer jobs using higher overall resources.
Please note that the partition has a GrpTRES limit of 100% of the available cores/RAM on the partition-specific nodes in aggregate plus 50% of the available cores/RAM on legacy## nodes in aggregate, so your job may need to wait if all available cores/RAM (or GPUs) are in use.

︗Jobs
You will need to specify --partition=mc2 and --account=mc2 to be able to submit jobs to the MC2 partition. 

[username@nexusmc200 ~]$ srun --pty --ntasks=4 --mem=8G --qos=default --partition=mc2 --account=mc2 --time 1-00:00:00 bash
srun: job 218874 queued and waiting for resources
srun: job 218874 has been allocated resources
[username@twist00 ~]$ scontrol show job 218874
JobId=218874 JobName=bash
   UserId=username(1000) GroupId=username(21000) MCS_label=N/A
   Priority=897 Nice=0 Account=mc2 QOS=default
   JobState=RUNNING Reason=None Dependency=(null)
   Requeue=1 Restarts=0 BatchFlag=0 Reboot=0 ExitCode=0:0
   RunTime=00:00:06 TimeLimit=1-00:00:00 TimeMin=N/A
   SubmitTime=2022-11-18T11:13:56 EligibleTime=2022-11-18T11:13:56
   AccrueTime=2022-11-18T11:13:56
   StartTime=2022-11-18T11:13:56 EndTime=2022-11-19T11:13:56 Deadline=N/A
   PreemptEligibleTime=2022-11-18T11:13:56 PreemptTime=None
   SuspendTime=None SecsPreSuspend=0 LastSchedEval=2022-11-18T11:13:56 Scheduler=Main
   Partition=mc2 AllocNode:Sid=nexusmc200:25443
   ReqNodeList=(null) ExcNodeList=(null)
   NodeList=twist00
   BatchHost=twist00
   NumNodes=1 NumCPUs=4 NumTasks=4 CPUs/Task=1 ReqB:S:C:T=0:0:*:*
   TRES=cpu=4,mem=8G,node=1,billing=2266
   Socks/Node=* NtasksPerN:B:S:C=0:0:*:* CoreSpec=*
   MinCPUsNode=1 MinMemoryNode=8G MinTmpDiskNode=0
   Features=(null) DelayBoot=00:00:00
   OverSubscribe=OK Contiguous=0 Licenses=(null) Network=(null)
   Command=bash
   WorkDir=/nfshomes/username
   Power=

︗Storage
All data filesystems that were available in the standalone MC2 cluster are also available in Nexus.
MC2 users can also request  Nexus project allocations.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Nexus/MC2&oldid=12055"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/JavaVersions contains the following information: 






︗Java

From UMIACS
(Redirected from JavaVersions)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Java can be obtained in one of two flavors: Java Runtime Environment (JRE) or Java Development Kit (JDK). Unless you do programming in Java, JRE is usually sufficient for running programs and applets written in Java. JRE is also included in JDK so there is no need to install both.  There are two main flavors of Java that we have support for Oracle Java(The prior text links to http://www.oracle.com/us/technologies/java/overview/index.html) and OpenJDK(The prior text links to http://openjdk.java.net/).

︗None
The version of Java running can be checked by running the following command on any RHEL/Ubuntu machine. Alternative JDK and JRE options can be found in /usr/lib/jvm. bash-4.2$ java -version
︗Windows
JRE is installed on all supported workstations by default and auto-updated to the latest version periodically. If for some reason your machine does not have Java, you may send a request to staff(The prior text links to mailto:staff@umiacs.umd.edu) to have JRE or JDK installed on your machine.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Java&oldid=7145"

︗HPC

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation

Privacy policy
About UMIACS

(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Apptainer contains the following information: 






︗Apptainer

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Apptainer(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org) is a container platform that doesn't elevate the privileges of a user running the container.  This is important as UMIACS runs many multi-tenant hosts (such as Nexus) and doesn't provide administrative control to users on them.  While Docker(The prior text links to https://www.docker.com) is popular, the most typical setups require a daemon that has administrative level privileges that makes it not tenable.
Apptainer was previously branded as Singularity.  You should still be able to run commands on the system with singularity, however you should start migrating to using the apptainer command.

︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Nexus Containers

2.1 Bind Mounts
2.2 Shared Containers


3 Docker Workflow Example


︗Overview
You can find out what the current version is that we provide by running the apptainer --version command.  If this instead says apptainer: command not found and you are using a UMIACS-supported host, please  contact staff and we will ensure that the software is available on the host you are looking for it on.

# apptainer --version
apptainer version 1.2.5-1.el8

Apptainer can run a variety of images including its own format and Docker images(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org/docs/user/main/docker_and_oci.html).  To create images from definition files, you need to have administrative rights. You will need to either use Podman to accomplish this on UMIACS-supported hosts, or alternatively do this on a host that you have full administrative access to (laptop or personal desktop) rather than a UMIACS-supported host.
If you are going to pull large images, you may run out of space in your home directory. We suggest you run the following commands to setup alternate cache and tmp directories.  We are using /scratch0 but you can substitute any large enough local scratch directory, network scratch directory, or project directory you would like.

export WORKDIR=/scratch0/$USER
export APPTAINER_CACHEDIR=${WORKDIR}/.cache
export APPTAINER_TMPDIR=${WORKDIR}/.tmp
mkdir -p $APPTAINER_CACHEDIR
mkdir -p $APPTAINER_TMPDIR


We do suggest you pull images down into an intermediate file (SIF file) as you then do not have to worry about re-caching the image.

$ apptainer pull cuda12.2.2.sif docker://nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8
INFO:    Converting OCI blobs to SIF format
INFO:    Starting build...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob d5d706ce7b29 done
Copying blob b4dc78aeafca done
Copying blob 24a22c1b7260 done
Copying blob 8dea37be3176 done
Copying blob 25fa05cd42bd done
Copying blob a57130ec8de1 done
Copying blob 880a66924cf5 done
Copying config db554d658b done
Writing manifest to image destination
Storing signatures
2022/10/14 10:31:17  info unpack layer: sha256:25fa05cd42bd8fabb25d2a6f3f8c9f7ab34637903d00fd2ed1c1d0fa980427dd
2022/10/14 10:31:19  info unpack layer: sha256:24a22c1b72605a4dbcec13b743ef60a6cbb43185fe46fd8a35941f9af7c11153
2022/10/14 10:31:19  info unpack layer: sha256:8dea37be3176a88fae41c265562d5fb438d9281c356dcb4edeaa51451dbdfdb2
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:b4dc78aeafca6321025300e9d3050c5ba3fb2ac743ae547c6e1efa3f9284ce0b
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:a57130ec8de1e44163e965620d5aed2abe6cddf48b48272964bfd8bca101df38
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:d5d706ce7b293ffb369d3bf0e3f58f959977903b82eb26433fe58645f79b778b
2022/10/14 10:31:49  info unpack layer: sha256:880a66924cf5e11df601a4f531f3741c6867a3e05238bc9b7cebb2a68d479204
INFO:    Creating SIF file...

$ apptainer inspect cuda12.2.2.sif
...
maintainer: NVIDIA CORPORATION <sw-cuda-installer@nvidia.com>
name: ubi8
org.label-schema.build-arch: amd64
org.label-schema.build-date: Wednesday_24_January_2024_13:53:0_EST
org.label-schema.schema-version: 1.0
org.label-schema.usage.apptainer.version: 1.2.5-1.el8
org.label-schema.usage.singularity.deffile.bootstrap: docker
org.label-schema.usage.singularity.deffile.from: nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8
...

Now you can run the local image with the run command or start a shell with the shell command.  

Please note that if you are in an environment with GPUs and you want to access them inside the container you need to specify the --nv flag. Nvidia has a very specific driver and libraries that are required to run CUDA programs, so this is to ensure that all appropriate devices are created inside the container and that these libraries are made available in the container .
$ apptainer run --nv cuda12.2.2.sif nvidia-smi -L
GPU 0: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti (UUID: GPU-8e040d17-402e-cc86-4e83-eb2b1d501f1e)
GPU 1: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti (UUID: GPU-d681a21a-8cdd-e624-6bf8-5b0234584ba2)

︗Nexus Containers
In our Nexus environment we have some example containers based on our pytorch_docker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker) project.  These can be found in /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch.
You can just run one of the example images by doing the following (you should have already allocated a interactive job with a GPU in Nexus).  It will use the default script(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker/-/blob/master/tensor.py) found at /srv/tensor.py within the image.

$ hostname && nvidia-smi -L
tron38.umiacs.umd.edu
GPU 0: NVIDIA RTX A4000 (UUID: GPU-4a0a5644-9fc8-84b4-5d22-65d45ca36506)

$ apptainer run --nv /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch/pytorch_1.13.0+cu117.sif
99 984.5538940429688
199 654.1710815429688
299 435.662353515625
399 291.1429138183594
499 195.5575714111328
599 132.3363037109375
699 90.5206069946289
799 62.86213684082031
899 44.56754684448242
999 32.466392517089844
1099 24.461835861206055
1199 19.166893005371094
1299 15.6642427444458
1399 13.347112655639648
1499 11.814264297485352
1599 10.800163269042969
1699 10.129261016845703
1799 9.685370445251465
1899 9.391674041748047
1999 9.19735336303711
Result: y = 0.0022362577728927135 + 0.837898313999176 x + -0.0003857926349155605 x^2 + -0.09065020829439163 x^3

︗Bind Mounts
To get data into the container you need to pass some bind mounts(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org/docs/user/main/bind_paths_and_mounts.html).  Apptainer containers will not automatically mount data from the outside operating system other than your home directory.  Users need to manually bind mounts for other file paths.
--bind /fs/nexus-scratch/<USERNAME>/<PROJECTNAME>:/mnt
In this example, we will exec an interactive session with GPUs and binding our Nexus scratch directory which allows us to specify the command we want to run inside the container.

apptainer exec --nv --bind /fs/nexus-scratch/username:/fs/nexus-scratch/username /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch/pytorch_1.13.0+cu117.sif bash

You can now write/run your own pytorch python code interactively within the container or just make a python script that you can call directly from the apptainer exec command for batch processing.


︗Shared Containers
Portable images called Singularity Image Format or .sif files can be copied and shared.  Nexus maintains some shared containers in /fs/nexus-containers.  These are arranged by the application(s) that are installed.

︗Docker Workflow Example
We have a pytorch_docker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker) example workflow using our GitLab as a Docker registry.  You can clone the repository and further customize this to your needs. The workflow is:

Run Docker on a laptop or personal desktop on to create the image, or use Podman on a UMIACS-supported system.
Tag the image and and push it to your repository (this can be any docker registry)
Pull the image down onto one of our workstations/clusters and run it with your data.
$ apptainer pull pytorch_docker.sif docker://registry.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker
INFO:    Converting OCI blobs to SIF format
INFO:    Starting build...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 85386706b020 done
...
2022/10/14 10:58:36  info unpack layer: sha256:b6f46848806c8750a68edc4463bf146ed6c3c4af18f5d3f23281dcdfb1c65055
2022/10/14 10:58:43  info unpack layer: sha256:44845dc671f759820baac0376198141ca683f554bb16a177a3cfe262c9e368ff
INFO:    Creating SIF file...

$ apptainer exec --nv pytorch_docker.sif python3 -c 'from __future__ import print_function; import torch; print(torch.cuda.current_device()); x = torch.rand(5, 3); print(x)'
0
tensor([[0.3273, 0.7174, 0.3587],
        [0.2250, 0.3896, 0.4136],
        [0.3626, 0.0383, 0.6274],
        [0.6241, 0.8079, 0.2950],
        [0.0804, 0.9705, 0.0030]])

Privacy policy
About UMIACS
Disclaimers


(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/ConferenceRooms/ATL3100D contains the following information: 






︗ATL/ConferenceRooms

From UMIACS
(Redirected from ConferenceRooms/ATL3100D)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The following is the list of UMIACS-managed conference rooms in the Atlantic building. General topics:

 Using the Solstice Mersive Pods
 Recording and Streaming
 Using Zoom
︗Contents

1 ATL 3100A

1.1 Sources

1.1.1 Room PC
1.1.2 Solstice
1.1.3 Laptop


1.2 Shutting Down


2 ATL 3100C/3100D/3373

2.1 Sources

2.1.1 Room PC
2.1.2 Laptop
2.1.3 Solstice


2.2 Shutting Down




︗ATL 3100A
This conference room comes equipped with a touch panel that can be used to control the video and audio source(s) and level(s) being used to project to the displays in the room. There is a Room PC ("PC Main"), a Solstice Pod ("Solstice"), and an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Laptop").
There is also an "Audio Override" output device that you can project any of the input sources to. This decouples the source audio from the source video so that you can send audio from one source to the audio output while maintaining video from a difference source. The primary use of this is to be able to prevent echoing and have teleconferencing participants be able to hear the room audience when using both a laptop and the room PC to present. With both devices in the same teleconference session, leave "Laptop" as the source video and switch the audio override to "PC Main" to display what is on the laptop but use the microphones spread throughout the room to hear the audience.
The image features a touchscreen control panel, presumably for an audio-visual (A/V) setup in a conference room. The panel is predominantly light grey with various interactive icons. At the top, a prominent red button labeled "Shutdown A/V System" is displayed, indicating a functionality to power down the setup after use.

Below, there are two main sections: one for source selection and another for destination routing. The source icons include "Laptop," "PC Main," "Solstice," and "Blank." A blue dot in the center is labeled "Audio Override," suggesting that audio settings can be adjusted independently of video sources.

To the right, the "Laptop Monitor" and "Projector" icons indicate options for displaying content. The bottom of the panel includes instructions stating, "First Select a Source To Be Routed Below, then the Destination," guiding the user through the functionality of the system. The overall layout is user-friendly, designed for intuitive navigation in managing the room's A/V components.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP address has been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image displays a digital interface from a screen labeled "ATL3100a-Pod," located in a conference room setting. The background features an abstract representation of a colorful landscape, blending hues of deep blue and earthy tones, which adds a modern aesthetic to the display. The top-left corner identifies the pod as "3250" along with a timestamp reading "9:44 AM."

On the right side of the screen, there are clear instructions for connecting devices, listed in a step-by-step format: 
1. "Connect your device to INTERNAL"
2. "Browse to the address above"
3. "Connect"

These instructions guide users through the process of connecting to the pod. Below the steps, there is a note indicating that "Apple users can AirPlay to ATL3100a-Pod," highlighting the compatibility for Apple devices and encouraging ease of use. The overall layout is clean, with contrasting colors that enhance legibility, making it user-friendly for individuals unfamiliar with the technology in the room.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "Shutdown A/V System" button when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the displays for the room and raise the projector screen.
The image shows a Crestron touchscreen control panel displaying a simple yet clear message: "A/V System Shutting Down Please Wait." The background of the screen is a soft, light blue, providing a calming contrast to the text, which is in bold, black font. The message is centralized on the screen, making it the focal point. Below the text, a circular loading icon is visible, indicating that the shutdown process is currently underway. 

The panel frame is light grey, complementing the minimalist design. There are no additional visual elements or distractions, allowing users to focus solely on the shutdown notification. At the top of the panel, there is a narrow black strip, likely housing an interface element or sensor. This design choice enhances the user experience by providing a clean interface for users transitioning out of the conference room. Overall, the image illustrates the final stage of using the room's audio-visual system, emphasizing a smooth and user-friendly shutdown process.

︗None
These conference rooms each come equipped with a simplified touch panel that can be used to control the video source being used to project to the display in the room as well adjust the audio level for the display. There is a Room PC ("Dedicated PC"), an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Table Laptop"), and a Solstice Pod ("Mersive Wireless").
The image features a Crestron touchscreen control panel mounted on a conference room wall. The panel has a blue background, prominently displaying four main options in rectangular buttons: "Dedicated PC," "Table Laptop," "Mersive Wireless," and a system power button marked "SYSTEM POWER" at the top. The text is highlighted in white, creating a stark contrast against the blue. 

At the top of the interface, two speaker icons are visible, one for volume up and the other for volume down, allowing users to adjust audio levels. A graphical volume level indicator is displayed beside these controls. 

Overall, the layout is simple and user-friendly, with primary functions easily accessible for individuals using the conference room's audio-visual setup. The design aims to facilitate efficient operation, making it clear for users to select their preferred source while controlling audio output effectively. The panel’s sleek framework enhances the modern aesthetic of the conference space.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP addresses have been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image displays a digital interface from a conference room system labeled "ATL3373-Pod." The background features an abstract design with swirling blue and earth-toned patterns, creating a visually striking yet professional aesthetic. In the top-left corner, the pod is identified with the name "ATL3373" and a timestamp indicating "10:06 AM." Below this, the display shows the internal information denoted by "INTERNAL" alongside a link likely providing instructions for connection.

To the right, clear step-by-step instructions guide users through the connection process:
1. "Connect your device to INTERNAL"
2. "Browse to the address above"
3. "Connect"

An additional note at the bottom highlights that "Apple users can AirPlay to ATL3373-Pod," informing users about compatibility with Apple devices. The overall layout is clean and easy to read, with a dark sidebar contrasting the colorful background, emphasizing usability for individuals unfamiliar with the technology. This design facilitates straightforward interaction, ensuring a smooth experience in utilizing the conference room's resources.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "System Power" button and select "Power Off" when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the display for the room.
The image depicts a Crestron touchscreen control panel mounted on a wall in a conference room. The screen has a simple blue background with two large, clearly labeled buttons: "Power On" and "Power Off," each featuring a light blue highlight for easy visibility. Below these buttons is a smaller button labeled "BACK," which is indicated by a leftward arrow. A circular sensor or button is located in the bottom left corner of the panel, suggesting a user interface element.

The overall layout is minimalist, promoting easy navigation for users unfamiliar with advanced technology. The buttons are positioned centrally on the screen, making them the focal point. The simplicity of the interface emphasizes efficient operation for starting or shutting down the audio-visual system in the room. The design caters to a user-friendly experience, minimizing confusion during operation and ensuring that users can quickly manage the conference room's power settings.
