︗ConferenceRooms/TouchPanel

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
All  conference rooms in the  Brendan Iribe Center and some in the  Atlantic Building come equipped with touch panels that can be used to control the video and audio source(s) and level(s) being used to project to the display(s) in the room.

︗Contents

1 Basic Usage

1.1 Moderated Rooms
1.2 Auto-Accept Rooms
1.3 Huddle Rooms


2 Common Options

2.1 Solstice
2.2 Laptop Device
2.3 Room PC


3 Shutting Down


︗Basic Usage
Assuming the room was previously in a 'shut down' state, the display will look like this when you first come up to it.
The image features a touch panel screen displaying information related to the Brendan Iribe Center for Computer Science and Engineering at the University of Maryland. The screen is predominantly white with black and colorful elements. At the top, the logo of the University of Maryland is prominently displayed, featuring a red and gold shield with the university's name beneath in bold black text: "UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND." The center of the screen features the name of the facility, "BRENDAN IRIBE CENTER," also in bold black letters, followed by the subtitle “FOR COMPUTER SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING.” Below this, in smaller text, is a prompt that reads “Touch Screen to start,” indicating that interaction is required to proceed. The touch panel is framed by a light-colored bezel with the brand logo “CRESTRON” at the bottom, signifying the technology used. The overall presentation is clean and formal, conveying a sense of professionalism and purpose consistent with an academic environment.The image portrays a touch panel screen typically found in conference rooms, specifically for the Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science at the University of Maryland. The screen has a simple layout with a predominantly light blue background. Prominently featured is the center's logo, which comprises a circular design with four quadrants in blue, red, yellow, and green hues, encapsulating an abstract representation of the center's focus on quantum information.

Beneath the logo, the text reads, “JOINT CENTER FOR QUANTUM INFORMATION AND COMPUTER SCIENCE” in a clear and formal font, predominantly in dark blue. Centered below this is a prompt instructing users to "Touch Screen to start," which invites interaction and engagement with the panel. On the right side of the screen are navigation buttons, which include icons for home, settings, and volume control, framed within a light-colored bezel bearing the "CRESTRON" branding at the bottom. The overall aesthetic appears modern, professional, and suited for an academic environment, reinforcing the emphasis on technology and innovation within the center.
Touch the panel as directed to start it up. This will turn on the display(s) for the room and lower the projector screens if any are present.
The image displays a touch panel screen, specifically designed for audio-visual control in conference rooms. The screen has a pale blue background with the message "A/V System Starting Please Wait" prominently displayed in dark, bold text. Underneath the text, a spinning loading icon indicates that the system is in the process of initializing. The panel is framed by a light-colored bezel with the “CRESTRON” brand logo located at the bottom, signifying the technology employed in the system. The layout is simple and direct, designed for easy readability and user engagement, reflecting a professional atmosphere intended for academic or business settings. The overall aesthetic suggests a focus on functionality and clarity, typical of modern touch panel technology in collaborative environments.
Once the startup completes, you will see a number of different options depending on what the capabilities of the room are:

︗ Moderated Rooms
The image displays a touch control panel designed for managing audio-visual systems in a conference room setting. The screen features a predominantly light blue background, providing a clear, modern aesthetic. At the top of the panel, there are two prominent buttons: "Shutdown A/V System" in red and "Device Control" in a darker shade, indicating their importance. 

Beneath these, two larger icons represent the "Projector" and "Monitor," each depicted with simple graphics for easy identification. A central section labeled "Shared Video" denotes the function to send video to designated systems. Below this, there are selectable source options: "Blank," "PC1," "PC2," "Solstice," "Laptop," "Tuner," "BluRay," and two camera options labeled "Camera A" and "Camera B." Each option is presented within rectangular buttons for user interaction. 

The "CRESTRON" brand logo is prominently displayed at the bottom, emphasizing the technology used. Overall, the interface is intuitive, designed to facilitate seamless operation in a professional environment.
These (larger) rooms have a number of options for sources to display and multiple places to display them to. All of the source options available in the smaller conference rooms are also available in these rooms. The exact options on each moderated room's panel may vary, as the capabilities vary room to room.
Of note in these rooms specifically is the "Device Control" option at the top of the source/destination menu, which takes you to another menu where you can manage volume, and (in some rooms) lighting, microphones, and settings for other integrated devices such as the room's Blu-ray player, TV tuner, or room cameras. This is also where you mute or unmute the lectern mic, if there is one.
The image displays a touch control panel designed for audio-visual management in a conference room. The screen features a light blue and gray interface, prominently displaying various control options. At the top, two significant buttons are highlighted: "Shutdown A/V System" in red, and "Select Video Source" in blue, indicating their primary functions. Below these, the central section is dedicated to lighting controls, with the heading "LIGHTING" at the top, listing options such as "ALL ON," "Presentation," "Notetaking," "Dim," and "ALL OFF" in a bold dark font for easy visibility.

To the left, there are icons for different media sources, including "BluRay," "Cameras," "TV," and "Tuner," enhancing user interaction. The right side includes volume controls, featuring a visual representation for "Vol Up" and "Vol Down," with a muted microphone icon indicating that the lectern mic is currently muted. The screen is framed by a thick black bezel, with the "CRESTRON" brand logo at the bottom, emphasizing the technological element. Overall, the interface is straightforward and user-friendly, reflecting a professional setting suitable for academic or corporate use.

︗ Auto-Accept Rooms
The image depicts a touch control panel designed for managing audio-visual systems in a conference room setting. The screen features a clean, bright white background with a prominent heading at the top that reads "Select Source To Be Displayed" in a clear, black font. Below this heading, there are three distinctive options displayed in a well-organized manner. 

The first option, "Solstice," is presented in a bold font surrounded by a wireless symbol icon, indicating the wireless display feature. The next two options, "LAPTOP DEVICE" and "ROOM PC," are illustrated with accompanying graphical icons: a cable connector for the Laptop Device and a desktop computer icon for the Room PC, enhancing user comprehension. 

Each option is framed within rectangular buttons with rounded edges, making them visually distinct and inviting interaction. The screen is also framed by a light-colored bezel, with the "CRESTRON" brand logo visibly positioned at the bottom center, signifying the technology used. At the very bottom, the "University of Maryland" crest subtly reinforces the institutional context of the touch panel. The overall design emphasizes functionality and ease of use, suitable for a professional academic environment.
These rooms have the ability to display an external device's screen wirelessly using  Solstice, an external device's screen wired via HDMI, or the room PC's screen (the room PC is attached to the back of the display in the room).

︗ Huddle Rooms
The image shows a touch control panel screen designed for managing audio-visual systems in a conference room, specifically within the University of Maryland's facilities. The screen has a clean, bright white background. At the top, a clear prompt reads "Select Source To Be Displayed" in black, easy-to-read font, guiding users on the next steps. Below this heading are two prominent icons: the first represents "Solstice," depicted as a wireless symbol to indicate wireless display capabilities, highlighted in dark against the light background. Adjacent to it is the second option, "LAPTOP DEVICE," illustrated with a visual of a laptop connector and a male USB connector, indicating a wired connection. 

Each option is framed within rounded rectangular buttons, making them visually distinct and inviting user interaction. The bottom section of the screen features the "University of Maryland" crest, which reinforces the institutional context. The entire interface is designed for quick comprehension and ease of use, reflecting a modern and professional aesthetic tailored for academic environments, with the "CRESTRON" brand logo located at the bottom, indicating the technology in use.
These rooms have the ability to display an external device's screen wirelessly using  Solstice or wired via HDMI. They do not have room PCs, so you must bring your own device(s).

︗Common Options
The three source options you will commonly choose from on these panels are "Solstice", "Laptop Device" (just "Laptop" on some panels), and "Room PC" (the third option only in non-huddle rooms).
In auto-accept and huddle rooms, the volume control for each of these sources can be found one you select that source. In moderated rooms, the volume control is on the Device Control menu, as mentioned above.

︗Solstice
The image depicts a touch control panel utilized for managing audio-visual systems in a conference room setting. The screen features a light blue background with prominent, clearly labeled buttons. At the top left, there is a red button labeled "Shutdown A/V System" and a black button labeled "Select Source," indicating key functions. The main section of the screen displays the status message "SOLSTICE DEVICE SOURCE SELECTED" in bold text, with a line below prompting the user to "Please follow the on-screen instructions."

To the right, a vertical volume control section is visible, which includes three buttons: "Vol Up," "Vol Down," and "Mute." Each of these options is represented with intuitive graphics, enhancing user interaction. The "CRESTRON" brand logo is positioned at the bottom of the frame, emphasizing the technology in use. The overall design is modern and user-friendly, making it suitable for a professional academic environment, and it facilitates easy navigation for users managing conference room technologies.
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the room-specific details (IP address, room code) have been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in a room.
The image shows a large screen displaying instructions for connecting to a Solstice Wireless Display system in a conference room. The background features a striking, abstract design resembling a mixture of natural elements, with colors ranging from deep blue to earthy reds and browns, creating a dynamic visual presence. On the right side of the screen, there are clear, step-by-step instructions presented in a bold, white font against a dark background. The instructions include:

1. “Connect your device to INTERNAL”
2. “Browse to the address above”
3. “Connect”

The top of the screen has a header that states “Have questions? Visit mersive.com/go or call 303.291.3775,” indicating resources for assistance. 

At the bottom, the current time is displayed as "2:34 PM," alongside the room identifier "IRB Pod." The overall layout is user-friendly and designed to facilitate easy connection for users intending to share content wirelessly, reflecting a modern and professional atmosphere appropriate for academic or corporate settings.

︗Laptop Device
The image depicts a touch control panel used for managing audio-visual systems in a conference room. The screen has a light blue background, providing a modern and professional appearance. At the top, two prominent buttons are displayed: a red button labeled "Shutdown A/V System" and a dark blue button labeled "Select Source." Below these buttons, the main section of the screen specifies, "LAPTOP DEVICE SOURCE SELECTED," indicating the current input source. 

A list of checks is presented in clear black text, guiding users with three numbered items: 1) "Laptop device is on," 2) "HDMI or VGA cable is connected," and 3) "Device display setting is set to mirror or extend to projector." These instructions are designed for simplicity and user engagement. On the right side, a volume control section is visible, featuring buttons for "Vol Up," "Vol Down," and "Mute," each represented with intuitive graphics. The touch panel is framed by a light-colored bezel with the "CRESTRON" branding at the bottom, highlighting the technology used. Overall, the interface is user-friendly, emphasizing functionality in an academic or corporate setting.
Connect your device to either the HDMI cable or VGA/aux cables coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Room PC
The image displays a touch control panel utilized for managing audio-visual systems in a conference room environment, specifically branded with "CRESTRON." The screen features a light blue background that evokes a clean and modern aesthetic. At the top, two prominent buttons—one red labeled "Shutdown A/V System" and one black labeled "Select Source"—are clearly visible, indicating their primary functions for users. 

In the central area, a message reads "ROOM PC SOURCE SELECTED," prominently displayed, guiding the user to confirm their selection. Below this message, there are specific instructions formatted as a checklist, guiding the user to verify that the Room PC is operational: 1) "Room PC is on," 2) "Room PC monitor is on." 

To the right, there is a vertical volume control section featuring buttons for "Vol Up," "Vol Down," and "Mute," each represented with intuitive graphics to enhance user interaction. The interface is designed for ease of use, reflecting a professional atmosphere appropriate for academic or corporate settings.
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "Shutdown A/V System" button when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the display(s) for the room and raise the projector screens if any are present.
The image displays a touch panel screen specifically designed for managing audio-visual systems in a conference room. The background is a soft light blue, providing a calming aesthetic. At the center of the screen, the message reads "A/V System Shutting Down Please Wait" in a clear, bold black font. Below the text, a circular loading icon indicates that the system is in the process of shutting down. The panel is framed by a thin, light-colored bezel, with the “CRESTRON” brand logo clearly visible at the bottom, emphasizing the technology employed in the system. The overall design is simple and streamlined, reflecting a professional environment suitable for academic or corporate settings. The layout suggests functionality and ease of use, allowing users to understand that the audio-visual components are being powered down efficiently.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SLURM/ArrayJobs contains the following information: 






︗SLURM/ArrayJobs

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Here is an example to get you started using array jobs in SLURM.

︗Array computation example job
Save this code to a file called test.py.

import time

print('start at ' + time.strftime('%H:%M:%S'))

print('sleep for 10 seconds ...')
time.sleep(10)

print('stop at ' + time.strftime('%H:%M:%S'))

︗Submission script
Save this to a file called array.sh and you should be able to submit the job as sbatch array.sh.

#!/bin/bash

#####################
# job-array example #
#####################

#SBATCH --job-name=example
#SBATCH --array=1-16        # run 16 jobs at the same time 
#SBATCH --time=0-00:05:00   # run for 5 minutes (d-hh:mm:ss)
#SBATCH --mem-per-cpu=500MB # use 500MB per core

# all bash commands must be after all SBATCH directives

# define and create a unique scratch directory
SCRATCH_DIRECTORY=/scratch0/${USER}/job-array-example/${SLURM_JOBID}
mkdir -p ${SCRATCH_DIRECTORY}
cd ${SCRATCH_DIRECTORY}

cp ${SLURM_SUBMIT_DIR}/test.py ${SCRATCH_DIRECTORY}

# each job will see a different ${SLURM_ARRAY_TASK_ID}
echo "now processing task id:: " ${SLURM_ARRAY_TASK_ID}
python test.py > output_${SLURM_ARRAY_TASK_ID}.txt

# after the job is done we copy our output back to $SLURM_SUBMIT_DIR
cp output_${SLURM_ARRAY_TASK_ID}.txt ${SLURM_SUBMIT_DIR}

# we step out of the scratch directory and remove it
cd ${SLURM_SUBMIT_DIR}
rm -rf ${SCRATCH_DIRECTORY}

# happy end
exit 0





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=SLURM/ArrayJobs&oldid=11731"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Unix_groups contains the following information: 






︗Unix groups

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UNIX groups are useful for sharing file and directory permissions with other users in the UMIACS system. Each UMIACS account is by default a member of its own group, defined by that username. An account can be made member to any number of additional groups.

︗Contents

1 Creating Groups & Adding Users
2 Applying the Group
3 Verifying and Changing Group Permissions
4 Deleting Groups


︗None
A user may create up to 5 UNIX groups via the Directory tool(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/groups/).

Click Create UNIX Group on the Groups page(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/groups/)
Enter in the group name and a brief description of what the organization of users in the group is for, then click create group.
Click on the link of the newly created group, add a valid UMIACS user into the available text box, click add user. NOTE: The user creating the group is not added to that group by default, and must be explicitly added after creation.
︗Applying the Group
In order to apply the group to a file or directory to which you want to grant all members some set of permissions use the command
chgrp group-name file-name
This will grant the specified group ownership of the file, at the level of access that the previous group possessed.

︗Verifying and Changing Group Permissions
To see the permissions that the group has for a specific file/directory use  ls -l  and the group permissions will be the 5,6,7th characters of the permissions listing.
To change the permissions of the group on that file/directory, if you own the group, use
chmod g+r/w/x file-name 
︗Deleting Groups
Deleting groups will be managed by UMIACS staff. If you would like to delete a group, please submit a ticket through JIRA.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Unix_groups&oldid=7349"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/VPN/OSX contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN/macOS

From UMIACS
(Redirected from VPN/OSX)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Ivanti Connect Secure Client.  Alternatively, you can establish a connection through a web browser(The prior text links to https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu/), but this may fail if you have an outdated version of Ivanti Connect Secure already installed.

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
3 Checking VPN Status
4 Setup Security Requirement (Follow these steps if you encounter an error while connecting through the Ivanti Secure client)


︗Prerequisites
macOS 13.x or higher as of the current version of the Ivanti Connect Secure Client
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
Download the client:
macOS Ivanti Connect Secure Client(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/ivanti-connectsecure/macOS/PulseSecure-mac-22.7.3-installer.dmg)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up-to-date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Open the client and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.
The image displays the interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, which is typically used for managing VPN connections on macOS. The window is mainly white with a light gray frame, characterized by a polished, minimalist design that is common in macOS applications. At the top center, the title "Ivanti Secure Access Client" is prominently displayed in black text, indicating the application's purpose.

Beneath the title, there is a label reading "Connections," also in black, suggesting this section is dedicated to managing VPN connections. The area below is predominantly blank, with no listed connections visible, which implies the client is currently in a state where no VPN profiles have been configured. 

In the bottom left corner, there are two buttons represented by icons: a plus sign (+) and a pencil or edit icon (✏️). The plus sign likely indicates an option to add a new connection, while the pencil icon suggests editing existing connections. Overall, the interface is efficient and user-friendly, designed for users to easily manage their VPN settings. [macOS] Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection
In the 'Name' field, enter a descriptive name for this vpn Connection.
In the 'Server URL' enter 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'
The image displays a pop-up window from the Ivanti Secure Access Client interface, specifically designed for establishing VPN connections on a macOS device. The window has a white background with a faint light gray border, maintaining the minimalist aesthetic typical of macOS applications. 

At the top, the title “Ivanti Secure Access Client” is prominently displayed in black text, followed by a section labeled “Connections.” Below this label, there are input fields for configuration. 

The first field, labeled “Type,” includes a dropdown for users to select the connection type, accompanied by an information icon indicating further details. Below that, a designated space is provided to input a name, where "UMIACS VPN" is already written in a bold, black font. 

The subsequent input field shows the server URL as "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu," written in a clear, readable format. 

At the bottom, there are three buttons: “Connect,” “Cancel,” and “Add,” with the “Add” button highlighted in pink, suggesting it's the primary action for users. The entire layout is organized and user-friendly, facilitating the easy input of necessary details to connect to the UMIACS VPN. [macOS] Enter the name of the vpn server
Enter your UMIACS credentials and hit connect.
The image displays a login window for the UMIACS VPN on a macOS interface. The window features a sleek, minimalist design typical of macOS applications, with a light gray background and rounded corners. At the top, the UMIACS logo is visible, indicating the identity of the application. 

In the center, there are two input fields labeled "User Name:" and "Password:," both in a clear, black font. The "User Name" field is highlighted with a pink border, suggesting it's currently active or focused for user input. The password input field shows a series of dots, indicating it's meant for confidential information, ensuring user privacy.

Below the input fields, a checkbox labeled "Save settings" allows users to choose whether to save their credentials for future logins. There are also two buttons: "Cancel," which is on the left, and "Connect," which is prominently highlighted on the right, suggesting it as the main action to proceed with the login. The overall layout is intuitive, facilitating quick and efficient access for users wishing to connect to the UMIACS VPN. [macOS] Enter UMIACS Credentials
Complete the  MFA Verification Step. For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box.
The image displays a login window for the UMIACS VPN on a macOS device, characterized by a sleek, minimalist design typical of macOS applications. The window features rounded corners and a light gray background, conveying a modern aesthetic. At the top center, the UMIACS logo is prominently displayed, indicating the application's affiliation.

In the main area of the window, there are two labeled input fields. The first field is for the “Secondary User Name,” which contains placeholder text showing "lilika" typed in a standard black font. This indicates that this field is currently active for user data entry. The second field, labeled "Secondary Password," displays a series of dots, signifying a secure input intended for confidential passwords.

Beneath the input fields, there is a checkbox labeled "Save settings," allowing users to save their credentials for future logins. The window includes two buttons at the bottom: "Cancel" on the left in a standard format, and "Connect" on the right, highlighted in pink, suggesting it is the primary action for engaging with the VPN. This layout facilitates user interaction for connecting to the UMIACS VPN effectively. [macOS] Enter a secondary password.
The Ivanti VPN multi-factor authentication implementation relies on a secondary authentication source to fulfill the  MFA requirement.  As a result, you will be prompted for credentials twice.


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.


I can help describe the images based on the provided text, but I currently don't have access to view them. If you could share the contents or context of each image, I’d be glad to provide detailed descriptions!

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN. You can close the window and the VPN will remain connected.
If you encounter an error, please refer to the "Setup Security Requirement" section bellow.

︗Checking VPN Status
In the top right hand corner, on your status bar, you should see an S icon in a black circle. If there's a green arrow, that means you are connected! If there is nothing, that means you are not.
The image showcases a macOS menu bar situated at the top of the screen, characterized by a clear blue background. It features a series of icons that represent various applications and system features. On the left, there are three icons highlighted in red, likely indicating notifications or updates related to specific applications. Following these, a Bluetooth symbol appears, accompanied by an icon for Do Not Disturb mode, represented by a crescent moon, and then a battery indicator showcasing power status.

The next section shows the Wi-Fi connection status, illustrated with radiating lines, suggesting an active connection. The right side of the menu bar displays the date and time—"Thu Mar 16 12:21 PM"—along with a secondary time: "Thu Mar 16 12:45 PM." The combination of icons and text presents a user-friendly interface for monitoring system status and accessing applications quickly, maintaining a sleek and organized aesthetic typical of macOS design. [macOS] The top image is connected, the bottom image is not.
You can click this icon, as well, and it will show you the status of your connection.
The image displays the macOS menu bar with a blue background. In the top right corner, a dropdown menu from the Ivanti Secure Access Client is shown. The menu includes options such as "Open Ivanti Secure Access Client" and indicates the client's connection status as "Connected." The UMIACS VPN is highlighted with a green checkmark, signifying an active connection. Below it, there’s an arrow indicating that more options are available for that connection. An "Exit" option is also present at the bottom of the menu. The surrounding icons represent various macOS features and applications, including a Bluetooth symbol, battery indicator, and Wi-Fi status, all contributing to a clean and modern macOS interface. The background reveals subtle hints of cherry blossoms, adding a touch of color to the otherwise minimalist design. This interface effectively communicates the user's VPN status and provides easy access to further options. [macOS] The Pulse drop down menu.
If the icon is not in the status bar, you can find Pulse Secure in your Applications folder. There you will see a list of connections.


︗None
Click the Apple logo at the top left of your desktop
Click System Settings
Click Privacy & Security
Scroll to the Security section and select App Store and identified developers
You will have to enter your credentials
Click Next to the message "System Software From Developers "Pulse Secure LLC" was blocked from loading" if prompted.
Click Allow to enable the extension.
Close the System Settings window.

︗SecGroups

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Security Groups are authentication groups that control access to various applications in UMIACS. They provide fine-grained access control to wikis, source code repositories, and certain web applications.

︗None
You can view and edit the secgroups you belong to using the SecGroups(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/secgroup/) section of the directory app.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=SecGroups&oldid=8487"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Network/VPN/Ivanti contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN/Ivanti

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
As of August 14th 2022, users will start to see changes in the naming convention, versioning, and icons of the Pulse Secure Client. 

Pulse Secure Client is being renamed to Ivanti Secure Access Client.
The Pulse Secure Desktop Client icon is replaced with Ivanti Secure Access Icon.
The image features the icon for the "Ivanti Secure Access Client," set against a dark background. The icon is composed of a stylized graphic that illustrates a hand holding a key, symbolizing security and access. The design employs a gradient color scheme transitioning from orange to red, which conveys a sense of warmth and urgency. The hand is depicted in white, standing out prominently against the vibrant backdrop. Below the icon, the text "Ivanti Secure Access Client" is displayed in a clean, modern font, presumably in white for visibility, creating a stark contrast that enhances legibility. The overall composition is simple yet effective, capturing the essence of a digital tool focused on providing secure access, while the color scheme suggests importance and reliability in securing network communications. The design aligns with contemporary interface aesthetics, making it easily recognizable for users familiar with VPN and secure access applications. [Ivanti] Ivanti Secure Access Client Icon
The Pulse Secure Client Menubar/system Tray icon is replaced with Ivanti Secure Access Menubar/System Tray Icon (Disconnected, Connected & Suspending respectively)
The image showcases a series of three icons representing the Ivanti Secure Access Client in different states: Disconnected, Connected, and Suspending. Each icon features a white key symbol, which signifies security and access, set against differently colored backgrounds. 

1. **Disconnected Icon:** On the left, the icon is set against a gradient of dark gray, transitioning to a medium gray. The key is centered and simple, implying that the service is currently inactive.

2. **Connected Icon:** The middle icon displays a vibrant red background, symbolizing active connectivity. The key maintains its white color and central placement. This color choice conveys alertness and active engagement with the secure access client.

3. **Suspending Icon:** The rightmost icon features a gradient background that transitions from orange to yellow, suggesting a state of temporary inaccessibility or waiting. The white key remains prominent, ensuring the message of security is clear even in this suspended state.

The overall design is minimalist yet effective, using color transitions to communicate different states while maintaining clarity and visual integrity. The icons collectively represent the functionality and status of the Ivanti Secure Access Client in a user-friendly manner. [Ivanti] Ivanti Secure Access Menubar system tray icon
Users have an option to switch between the Classic UI and New-UX to maintain user experience per individual preference.
The image displays the interface of the "Ivanti Secure Access Client." The layout appears modern and minimalistic, primarily featuring a light gray background that sets a soft tone for the display. On the left side, there is a vertical menu bar in a darker gray, offering eight options. The top option is labeled "UI Mode," with a dropdown that includes "Admin Setting" and "New UX" highlighted in a bright blue font, signifying the selected mode.

The main area showcases the title "Ivanti Secure Access Client" prominently at the top. Beneath it, there's a circular icon representing network connectivity, with the text "No Active Connections" clearly visible, indicating the current status of the VPN connection. Below this, two horizontal placeholders or tabs are visible, along with a plus sign icon, suggesting the option to add connections or settings. The overall design emphasizes clarity and user-friendliness, aligning with contemporary software aesthetics focused on secure access solutions. The interface appears intuitive, reflecting Ivanti's commitment to enhancing user experience in network management. [Ivanti] New-UX mode
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Secure Access client
After the VPN maintenance users will automatically be prompted to upgrade the client. This will pull an up to date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
We have also provided the installers below:

Windows 64 bit Ivanti Secure Access Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/b/bb/PulseSecure22.2R1.x64.msi)
Windows 32 bit Ivanti Secure Access Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/1/12/PulseSecure22.2.R1.x86.msi)
Ubuntu 64 bit Ivanti Secure Access Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/9/92/Pulsesecure_22.2.R1_amd64.deb)
MacOS Ivanti Secure Access Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/3/31/PulseSecure_22.2.R1.dmg)

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SSH/MFA contains the following information: 






︗SecureShell/MFA

From UMIACS
(Redirected from SSH/MFA)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Example

2.1 Duo Push to ___
2.2 Phone call to XXX-XXX-XXXX
2.3 SMS passcodes to XXX-XXX-XXXX
2.4 Enter passcode or tap YubiKey

2.4.1 Code shown in Duo app or hardware token
2.4.2 YubiKey tap




3 Wrapping up
4 Considerations


︗Overview
UMIACS has rolled out multi-factor authentication requirements when using SSH to connect to our public-facing hosts to provide better account and data security. Public-facing hosts are hosts that are reachable via the Internet (e.g. via ping(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ping_(networking_utility))) without first establishing a connection to our VPN. If you first connect to our VPN, you will not need to additionally multi-factor authenticate when using SSH. This is because our VPN already requires multi-factor authentication to establish a connection, and all subsequent SSH attempts after connecting to our VPN will pass through the tunnel created (already within the UMIACS border).
SSH has two different authentication methods that we currently support on all of our internal hosts: interactive password authentication and  public key authentication. Multi-factor authentication-enabled SSH on our public-facing hosts only supports interactive password authentication, with the secondary factor coming from our Duo instance. We do not currently support public key based authentication and Duo multi-factor authentication on our public-facing hosts. Please note that unfortunately U2F(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_2nd_Factor) hardware tokens registered with Duo are not supported for SSH login specifically. Other hardware tokens such as a YubiKey(The prior text links to https://www.yubico.com/products/yubikey-5-overview/) or Duo's own hardware token(The prior text links to https://guide.duo.com/tokens) will still work.

︗Example
The initial command or session setup for connecting to a host with multi-factor authentication enabled over SSH is the same as one that does not have it enabled. Our example for connecting to a host over SSH can be found  here. In the below example, we are also SSH-ing to a Nexus node e.g. ssh username@nexusgroup00.umiacs.umd.edu
Once you enter the command (if using a native terminal) or start the session (PuTTY or other terminal emulators), you will be presented with the following prompt:

Password:

Enter your UMIACS password here (the same as if you were using interactive password authentication to connect to an internal host). After correctly entering your password, you will be taken to the following prompt. Please note: The options shown here will vary depending on what/how many devices you have registered with our Duo instance. In this example, we have a mobile phone that has the Duo app installed, a tablet (iPad) that has the Duo app installed, a Duo hardware token, and a YubiKey all registered against our UMIACS Duo instance.

Password:
Duo two-factor login for username

Enter a passcode or select one of the following options:

 1. Duo Push to XXX-XXX-1234
 2. Duo Push to iPad (iOS)
 3. Phone call to XXX-XXX-1234
 4. SMS passcodes to XXX-XXX-1234

Passcode or option (1-4):

(if you have a registered phone, the last 4 digits shown will be replaced with the last 4 digits of the phone number you specifically have registered)
The numbered options here correspond to different methods that Duo can take to authenticate you, and are more or less identical to the options that would be presented to you via a GUI if you were attempting to sign into another of our multi-factor authentication secured services, such as our Directory application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/auth/login). You can also enter the passcode 

︗Duo Push to ___
This will send a push notification to the Duo app on whichever device you chose for you to accept to proceed.

Passcode or option (1-4): 1

Pushed a login request to your device...

︗Phone call to XXX-XXX-XXXX
This will call your registered phone and ask you to press any key on your phone to proceed.

Passcode or option (1-4): 3

Calling your phone...
Dialing XXX-XXX-1234...

(After answering) 

Answered. Press any key on your phone to log in.
︗SMS passcodes to XXX-XXX-XXXX
This will send a one time passcode to your registered phone via SMS and then redisplay the prompt. Type the passcode received at the new prompt (which will show the first number of the passcode sent as a hint) to proceed.

Passcode or option (1-4): 4

New SMS passcodes sent.

Duo two-factor login for username

Enter a passcode or select one of the following options:

 1. Duo Push to XXX-XXX-1234
 2. Duo Push to iPad (iOS)
 3. Phone call to XXX-XXX-1234
 4. SMS passcodes to XXX-XXX-1234 (next code starts with: 1)

Passcode or option (1-4): 1234567

︗Enter passcode or tap YubiKey
In addition, you can also enter the code shown in your Duo app for UMIACS, the code shown on a registered hardware token, or tap your YubiKey to emit a code:

︗Code shown in Duo app or hardware token
The image displays a rectangular, white card labeled "DUO-PROTECTED" at the top, indicating an association with UMIACS (University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies). The UMIACS logo is positioned on the left side, prominently featuring the organization's name in a bold, modern font. Below this label, the text "UMIACS" is displayed clearly. The central focus of the card is a six-digit code, "672 239," rendered in a large, bold, black font for easy readability. The card has a clean, minimalist design, devoid of additional graphics or colors beyond the white background and black text. This imagery conveys the essence of security and access control, emphasizing the importance of multi-factor authentication within the UMIACS network. Overall, the card serves as a tangible representation of security measures in place for user authentication.
(if in the Duo app)

Enter a passcode or select one of the following options:

 1. Duo Push to XXX-XXX-1234
 2. Duo Push to iPad (iOS)
 3. Phone call to XXX-XXX-1234
 4. SMS passcodes to XXX-XXX-1234

Passcode or option (1-4): 672239

The image features a Duo hardware token, a compact, oval-shaped device primarily black in color. At the top, the word "DUO" is displayed in bold, modern lettering, instantly recognizable as a brand associated with multi-factor authentication. Below this branding, there is a digital display screen that showcases a six-digit numeric code, "123456," indicating a temporary authentication code used for secure login. To the left of the screen is a prominent green button, suggesting it may be used to generate or confirm the displayed code. The device is attached to a small metal keyring, emphasizing its portability and ease of access for users. Overall, the token's design is minimalistic, straightforward, and functional, encapsulating the essence of security and user-friendly authentication mechanisms prominent in modern cybersecurity practices. The clear display and color contrast enhance readability, making it a practical tool for users needing to verify their identity during login processes.
(if using a hardware token)

Enter a passcode or select one of the following options:

 1. Duo Push to XXX-XXX-1234
 2. Duo Push to iPad (iOS)
 3. Phone call to XXX-XXX-1234
 4. SMS passcodes to XXX-XXX-1234

Passcode or option (1-4): 123456

︗YubiKey tap
Simply tap the sensor on your YubiKey plugged into the device you are using to SSH to have it emit a string of characters and automatically hit Enter.

Enter a passcode or select one of the following options:

 1. Duo Push to XXX-XXX-1234
 2. Duo Push to iPad (iOS)
 3. Phone call to XXX-XXX-1234
 4. SMS passcodes to XXX-XXX-1234

Passcode or option (1-4): kffuastenhldrhfhadafdarivuntddugrvjvllddjjuget

︗Wrapping up
After finishing your method of choice for using Duo to multi-factor authenticate, you will be logged in and can operate as normal.

Success. Logging you in...
Last login: Wed Feb 17 12:00:00 2021 from ...
[username@nexusgroup00 ~]$

Subsequent SSH attempts from the window you have already connected via will not require multi-factor authentication, even if the host you are trying to SSH to is another public-facing host. This is because at this point the point of origin for the network traffic behind the connection attempt is coming from within the UMIACS border, rather than the rest of the Internet.

[username@nexusgroup00 ~]$ ssh nexusgroup01.umiacs.umd.edu
username@nexusgroup01.umiacs.umd.edu's password:
Last login: Wed Feb 17 11:59:00 2021 from ...
[username@nexusgroup01 ~]$

︗Considerations
Since there is now an additional step to log in to our public-facing hosts if not using our VPN, we would recommend first establishing a connection over our VPN if you anticipate needing to SSH to several different hosts or need to open several different terminal windows concurrently. As mentioned previously, you do not need an additional multi-factor authentication step when using SSH if you first connect to our VPN since it is already secured by multi-factor authentication.
An alternative would be to use a terminal multiplexer(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_multiplexer) such as Screen or Tmux to minimize the number of times you need to multi-factor authenticate. Terminal multiplexers allow you to start several different processes out of one terminal display, and also detach from and later reattach to each of the processes.

︗Branding

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS seeks to have a strong, easily-recognizable brand both on Campus and among peer institutions.  These branding resources may prove useful.

︗Contents

1 UMIACS Logo
2 Alternatives

2.1 UMIACS Logo Without Tagline
2.2 Horizontal Alternative 1
2.3 Horizontal Alternative 2




︗UMIACS Logo
This is the preferred logo if your visual presentation target has the available space.
The image depicts the logo for the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). The logo features a stylized representation of a building, characterized by angular lines and a modern architectural design. The structure includes various rectangular sections and a curved element, suggesting a combination of contemporary and traditional architecture. 

The building is illustrated in a simplified manner with minimal detail, primarily outlined in black, while the façade is detailed with red dots resembling windows. The name "UMIACS" is prominently displayed in bold, capital letters, with "UMI" in red and "ACS" in black, creating a visually striking contrast. 

Beneath the name, the full title—"University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies"—is presented in a smaller, standard font, indicating the formal name of the institution. The logo's color scheme emphasizes professionalism and modernity, intended to create a strong and recognizable brand identity for UMIACS. Overall, it conveys a commitment to advanced research and technology in the academic sphere.

︗Alternatives
︗UMIACS Logo Without Tagline
The image showcases the logo of the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). It features a stylized depiction of a building, characterized by its angular lines and modern architectural design. The building consists of various geometric shapes, with a primary structure that includes a prominent curved feature and multiple rectangular sections. The use of black outlines gives the logo a sleek and professional appearance, while the façade is embellished with red dots, representing windows.

The name "UMIACS" is prominently featured beneath the building illustration, rendered in bold, capital letters. The "UMI" portion is highlighted in red, contrasting sharply with the "ACS," which is in black, thereby enhancing readability and visual impact. Additionally, below this main title is the full designation of the institution, "University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies," presented in a smaller and more standard font, reinforcing the formal identity of UMIACS. The overall color scheme of red and black aims to convey a sense of modernity and commitment to academic excellence in technology and research.

︗Horizontal Alternative 1
The image depicts the logo for the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). Central to the design is a stylized architectural illustration featuring angular lines and various geometric forms, symbolizing modern design. This includes a prominent curved structure alongside multiple rectangular components. The overall representation uses a minimalist style, primarily outlined in black, enhancing its sleek appearance.

The façade of the building is adorned with red dots, representing windows, which infuse the design with a sense of depth and detail. Below the illustration is the word "UMIACS," rendered boldly in capital letters, with "UMI" in a striking red and "ACS" in black, creating a strong visual contrast that enhances legibility. Beneath this is the full name of the institution—"University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies"—presented in a smaller, standard font. 

The color scheme of red and black conveys professionalism and modernity, effectively establishing a recognizable brand identity for UMIACS, reflecting its commitment to advanced research and technological innovation.

︗Horizontal Alternative 2
The image features the logo for the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). It showcases a stylized illustration of a building that embodies modern architectural elements, characterized by angular lines and a combination of geometric forms. The building's design includes a prominent curved section along with several rectangular components, enhancing its contemporary feel. 

The logo is predominantly outlined in black, reinforcing a sleek and professional appearance. The façade is decorated with red dots that resemble windows, adding depth and interest to the design. Below the architectural illustration, the word "UMIACS" is prominently displayed in bold, capital letters, with "UMI" rendered in a striking red color, contrasting against "ACS," which is in black. This contrast not only enhances legibility but also serves to create a strong visual impact.

Beneath this main title, the full name, "University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies," is presented in a smaller, more standard font, underscoring the formal identity of the institution. The overall color scheme of red and black conveys a sense of professionalism and modernity, reflecting UMIACS's commitment to advanced research and technology.

︗FileTransferProtocol

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search


I understand your instructions, but please provide the images you would like to have described.

Our FTP service is deprecated in favor of the UMIACS Object Store. Please see OBJ. Depending on when your account was installed, you may or may not have FTP access.

UMIACS provides FTP services for transferring data to external collaborators.  Since the FTP protocol is conducted entirely in plaintext, external users login to the service as anonymous, and internal users can access the file directories internally.  Users will never authenticate over FTP with their UMIACS account.  Please see SFTP for more information on a secure file transfer protocol.

︗Publishing datasets via FTP


I'm ready to help! Please provide the images you would like described.

This part of our FTP service is deprecated in favor of the UMIACS Object Store. Please see OBJ.

Users can place data to be externally accessible in their public FTP space, which is located from the FTP service as

ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/<username>/
To upload data to your public site, you can upload data to either

/fs/ftp/pub/<username> from supported UNIX machines
\\umiacs-webftp\ftp-umiacs\pub\<username> from supported Windows machines




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=FileTransferProtocol&oldid=10694"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Creating_service_admin_user_on_OSX contains the following information: 






︗Creating service admin user on macOS

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Creating service admin user on OSX)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
When taking an Apple product to the Terrapin Tech store(The prior text links to https://it.umd.edu/terrapin-tech), it is critical that you create a Service Admin User on your computer before having it serviced. The technicians at the store require an admin user name and password, and if the pre-existing password is the same as your UMIACS domain login password, revealing it to the technicians would represent a security vulnerability. To remedy this, you must create a new temporary user account with administrator privileges that the technicians can use to service your machine. 

︗Creating the new account
Make sure you are logged in to an administrator account on your MacBook.
Navigate to System Preferences. (Click on the Apple Logo at the top lefthand side of the screen, and select "System Preferences" from the dropdown menu.)
From the System Preferences menu, select "Users and Groups" .
On the righthand side of the screen where it lists the users currently on the machine, click on the 'Add User' button.
By default, the new account will be set to a Standard account. Select the "New User" dropdown menu and choose "Administrator" from the list.
The image depicts a user interface for creating a new user account on a macOS system. The main panel is dark, highlighting the forms and dropdown menus in a clean, straightforward design. At the top, the "New User" section includes a dropdown menu permitting the selection of account types, showing options for "Administrator," "Standard," and "Sharing Only," with "Administrator" currently selected. 

Below this, there are labeled fields for "Full Name," "Account Name," "Password," and "Verify." The "Full Name" field likely instructs the user to input the complete name of the new account holder, while "Account Name" suggests a name for the home folder. The "Password" field has a secured entry, prompting the user to create an original password. A note underneath indicates the password must meet a minimum of four characters. Additionally, there's an optional "Password Hint" field to aid in remembering the password.

At the bottom, the interface offers buttons labeled "Cancel" and "Create User," allowing the user to either abort the action or create the new account. The overall aesthetic is consistent with macOS design, featuring sleek lines and a minimalist approach.
The new user's full name should be "Service Admin," and the account name should be "serviceadmin".
The password is up to you, so long as it's not the same as your UMIACS account password or your UMD Directory ID password.
The image showcases a user interface for creating a new user account on a macOS system, set against a dark background typical of the macOS aesthetic. At the top of the panel, labeled "New User," a dropdown menu is visible, which is currently set to "Administrator," indicating the type of account being created. Below this, there are input fields clearly labeled for "Full Name," "Account Name," and "Password," each occupying separate lines.

The "Full Name" field is pre-filled with "Service Admin," which is the designated full name for the account. The "Account Name" field contains "serviceadmin," indicating the name for the home folder associated with this new user. The "Password" and "Verify" fields contain obscured inputs, ensuring security, with a note below them stating password requirements—specifically, that it must have at least four characters.

Additionally, a "Password Hint" field is included, suggesting a hint to help remember the password. At the bottom of the panel, there are two buttons: "Cancel" on the left, allowing users to abort the process, and "Create User" on the right to finalize the account creation. The overall layout is clean and minimalist, aligning with modern design principles.
Select "Create User".
When prompted by the Terrapin Tech sore, you should give this account's credentials to the technician, not your UMIACS account credentials. Once the service is completed, the account can be deleted.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Creating_service_admin_user_on_macOS&oldid=11488"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/UMIACS_Account contains the following information: 






︗Accounts

From UMIACS
(Redirected from UMIACS Account)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
This page outlines the various account types at UMIACS and their management methods.
Do not share any UMIACS-affiliated account for any purpose. Action may be taken against your account if you do so.

︗Contents

1 UMIACS Account
2 Guest / Collaborator Account
3 Request a UMIACS account
4 Password Requirements
5 Changing account password

5.1 If you know your current password
5.2 If you do not know your current password


6 Sponsored Accounts
7 All Accounts Related Pages


︗UMIACS Account
A full UMIACS account consists of the following components:

 Active Directory Account
Provides access to UMIACS-supported computers,  secgroup controlled resources, web services such as GitLab, and the VPN.
 Jira Account
Provides access to the JIRA Request Tracker. Please note that it is possible to set a separate password for this account, at which point it will no longer be synced from your Active Directory Account. Changing your Jira password DOES NOT change your Active Directory Account password.
︗None
 Collaborator Accounts
Sponsored account to provide access to UMIACS Web Services for non-UMIACS collaborators.
︗Request a UMIACS account
Fill out the account request form located at the UMIACS Account Request webapp(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/new).  Please note that for the PI field you will be entering your PI/Professor/Sponsor's account name here at UMIACS.  Also indicate any labs you are a member of in the notes field to speed up access to your lab's resources. 
Once the form is submitted, it will send an email with a link to verify your email address.  You must click this link to verify your email address before the system will send email to your PI to review the account request.  Accounts can take anywhere from a few hours to a day for installation, depending on how quickly your PI approves your account.

︗Password Requirements
We have the following policies in regards to our ActiveDirectory passwords:

Minimum Password Length : 8 Characters (more is allowed)
Minimum Character Classes : 3 Character Classes
English uppercase characters (A - Z)
English lowercase characters (a - z)
Base 10 digits (0 - 9)
Non-alphanumeric (For example: !, $, #, or %)
Unicode characters
Password cannot contain (or match a substring of 3+ sequential characters) of your username or any part of your first or last name.
Password was not previously used in last 5 passwords.
Password has not been  compromised in a known data breach.
It is your responsibility to secure your password. Please choose a strong password, do not use your UMIACS password for any other service, and only connect using secure protocols.
UMIACS staff members do not store your password in a retrievable format, so if you forget your password, you must reset it (next section).

︗Changing account password
︗If you know your current password
You can use the UMIACS Password Web Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/password) to change your password.
︗If you do not know your current password
You can reset your password yourself(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/password/forgot) if you know your username and have already registered a mobile phone number and alternate E-mail address in our Directory Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info/).
If your account was a UMIACS Collaborator Account, your password can be reset by your sponsor via our Requests Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/collaborators/).
You can stop by the UMIACS Help Desk in room 3109 Iribe Center with a photo ID.
If you are unable to physically stop by the UMIACS Help Desk, you can have your account sponsor (PI) work with the UMIACS Help Desk to receive a temporary password on your behalf.  The account sponsor will then be responsible for conveying the password to you in a secure manner. (e.g., Telephone, where they could identify you by voice)
︗Sponsored Accounts
You can view a list of the accounts you sponsor in the UMIACS Account Management Web Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/sponsored/). Clicking on an account's display name will bring you to a management page where you can see details such as the installation date or email forward. From here you can edit your relationship to the account.
You can also request to remove your sponsorship or modify the expiration date, but these require staff action and are not immediate. 

︗All Accounts Related Pages
Accounts/Collaborator

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Microsoft_Office_Activation contains the following information: 






︗Microsoft Office Activation

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
This article is about how to manually force Microsoft Office to activate and obtain a license from the university KMS server.

︗Contents

1 When do I need to do this?
2 How to Activate Office

2.1 Simple Activation Method
2.2 Command Line Activation Method




︗None
Most users will not need to do this in order to use Microsoft Office. The only time this will need to be done is if Office is installed on a host that goes an extended length of time (180 days or more) without connecting to the campus network (either physically or through a VPN) and needs to be activated in a hurry.

︗How to Activate Office
Please note that you need to be connected to either the wired campus network, campus WiFi, the campus VPN(The prior text links to https://terpware.umd.edu/Windows/Title/1840), or the  UMIACS VPN to activate. The below steps will assume you have already established a network connection. Please also note that your time must be correct (i.e. set via the Internet) and set to the US Eastern timezone for this to work. You can try running w32tm /resync on the command line below in step 4 before running the other commands listed in that step and subsequent ones to resync your time if the commands fail at first.
Once you are on the campus network follow these instructions:

︗Simple Activation Method
Open any Office product (Word, PowerPoint, etc.). This should automatically activate Office. If it fails to activate, follow the instructions below:

︗Command Line Activation Method
Please note that your time must be correct for this to work, make sure you are in the East Coast timezone and your time is set via the internet, try running "w32tm /resync" on the command line.

Search for Command Prompt in the Start menu, right click it, and choose "Run as administrator".
The image depicts the Windows search interface showing the "Command Prompt" application. On the left side, there is a search bar with the text “command prompt” entered, which has auto-generated suggestions below. The most prominent suggestion is “Command Prompt” itself, highlighted in blue. 

To the right of this suggestion, options are presented under the app name, including "Open" for launching the application normally, “Run as administrator” for opening it with elevated privileges, “Open file location” for navigating to the app's installation directory, and “Pin to taskbar” for creating a shortcut on the taskbar for easy access.

The overall user interface has a dark theme with a grey background, blending into a black rectangle representing the Command Prompt icon, which typically signifies a command-line interface. The search results appear in a rectangular box, comprising various user interface elements typical of Windows operating systems. The browser at the bottom of the image indicates some web-related functionality, suggesting that the user may access additional resources or information directly from the search results.
Run the following command to determine the bitness of your operating system. This will help you determine which commands you need to run as you continue:
wmic os get osarchitecture
The image showcases a Command Prompt interface on a Windows operating system. The black rectangular window displays a command line with a white text output. The command entered is "wmic os get osarchitecture," followed by the response "OSArchitecture" and "64-bit," indicating the system's architecture. The cursor is positioned at the end of the command line, suggesting readiness for further input.

The interface is minimalistic, with the typical Command Prompt aesthetic — a dark background and light-colored text. This specific layout allows users to execute commands and view system information quickly. Surrounding elements typical of Windows, including the title bar (not fully visible), suggest that the application is running in a standard windowed mode. Overall, the image effectively captures a specific interaction with the Windows Command Prompt, reflecting a technical and informational context relevant to users familiarizing themselves with system architecture commands.
The path entered for the rest of the commands will differ slightly depending on the bitness of your operating system and your version and bitness of Office. See here(The prior text links to https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/about-office-what-version-of-office-am-i-using-932788b8-a3ce-44bf-bb09-e334518b8b19?ui=en-us&rs=en-us&ad=us) for how to check Office version and bitness. The remaining instructions assume Office 2016 (or newer) 64-bit on Windows 64-bit.
64-bit Office, 64-bit Windows: "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS"
32-bit Office, 64-bit Windows: "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS"
32-bit Office, 32-bit Windows: "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS"
Set the correct KMS server.
cscript "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS" /sethst:kms.umd.edu
The image displays a Command Prompt interface on a Windows operating system, characterized by its black background and light green text. At the top of the window, the command input indicates the directory path as "C:\WINDOWS\system32>". Below this, the user has executed a script with the command `cscript "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS" /sethst:kms.umd.edu`. The output text confirms successful execution of the command with the message "Successfully applied setting," framed by lines of dashes that add a structured aesthetic to the display. 

The Command Prompt is visually minimalist, focused on text output without additional graphic elements. The version of Windows Script Host is noted as "Version 5.812," providing context about the environment in which the command is running. This environment is typical for users attempting to activate Microsoft Office via a KMS server, making the image relevant to IT professionals and students needing these activation commands. The overall simplicity emphasizes the command line's functionality over visual flair, aligning with standard technical documentation styles.
Force an activation against the KMS server.
cscript "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS" /act
The image captures a Command Prompt window on a Windows operating system, displaying the process of activating Microsoft Office via the command line. The window features a dark background with light gray text, typical of the Command Prompt's minimal interface design. The command executed is `cscript "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS" /act`, indicating an attempt to activate the Office installation. 

Above this command, there is a line stating "Processing..." followed by various detailed outputs, including an "Installed product key detected" message that describes the Office version and product information. The SKU ID, license name, and license description indicate that the product is "Office 16, Office16ProPlusVL_KMS_Client edition," along with a note about the activation status. It confirms "<Product activation successful>" towards the end, indicating that the activation process was completed without errors.

The interface conveys a clear technical context, relevant to users engaging with system-level scripts for software activation, and is visually focused on functionality rather than aesthetics.
Check the licensing status.
cscript "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS" /dstatus
This example shows 1 license, being the standard Office installation.
The image displays a Command Prompt interface on a Windows operating system, characterized by its classic dark theme and light text. The command input shows a path: `C:\WINDOWS\system32>`, indicating the current directory in the system. Below this line, the user executed the command `cscript "C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\OSPP.VBS" /dstatus`, which is intended to check the licensing status of Microsoft Office. 

The output presents a series of structured lines detailing important licensing information. It displays the PRODUCT ID and SKU ID, confirming the Office version as "Office 16, Office16ProPlusVL_KMS_Client edition." The LICENSE STATUS reveals that the license is currently in a valid state, albeit with a note marking it as "---LICENSED---". It also shows an ERROR CODE (0x400F040) that prompts the user to ensure the product is activated. Additional details include a REMAINING GRACE period of 179 days, indicating time left before the license needs to be renewed. 

Overall, the image captures a technical context essential for users checking the activation status of their Microsoft Office installation, with a focus on clarity and function over aesthetics.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Microsoft_Office_Activation&oldid=11965"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/JavaDevelEnvironment contains the following information: 






︗JavaDevelEnvironment

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The recommended choice of development environment for Java is the Sun ONE Development Studio, formerly known as Forte for Java. It is backed by Sun, the creator of Java, and is freely available. It is written entirely in Java, therefore you can run it on any OS and platform for which JDK is available, including Unix, Linux, Windows and Mac. See the Sun site for more information: http://wwws.sun.com/software/sundev/jde/index.html(The prior text links to http://wwws.sun.com/software/sundev/jde/index.html)
An alternative is Borland's JBuilder. We've had negative feedback on this product from our users in the past.
Microsoft's Visual J++ (version 6 and the .NET version) is not compatible with the new language specifications and therefore is not recommended.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=JavaDevelEnvironment&oldid=1647"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Password contains the following information: 






︗Accounts

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Password)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
This page outlines the various account types at UMIACS and their management methods.
Do not share any UMIACS-affiliated account for any purpose. Action may be taken against your account if you do so.

︗Contents

1 UMIACS Account
2 Guest / Collaborator Account
3 Request a UMIACS account
4 Password Requirements
5 Changing account password

5.1 If you know your current password
5.2 If you do not know your current password


6 Sponsored Accounts
7 All Accounts Related Pages


︗UMIACS Account
A full UMIACS account consists of the following components:

 Active Directory Account
Provides access to UMIACS-supported computers,  secgroup controlled resources, web services such as GitLab, and the VPN.
 Jira Account
Provides access to the JIRA Request Tracker. Please note that it is possible to set a separate password for this account, at which point it will no longer be synced from your Active Directory Account. Changing your Jira password DOES NOT change your Active Directory Account password.
︗None
 Collaborator Accounts
Sponsored account to provide access to UMIACS Web Services for non-UMIACS collaborators.
︗Request a UMIACS account
Fill out the account request form located at the UMIACS Account Request webapp(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/new).  Please note that for the PI field you will be entering your PI/Professor/Sponsor's account name here at UMIACS.  Also indicate any labs you are a member of in the notes field to speed up access to your lab's resources. 
Once the form is submitted, it will send an email with a link to verify your email address.  You must click this link to verify your email address before the system will send email to your PI to review the account request.  Accounts can take anywhere from a few hours to a day for installation, depending on how quickly your PI approves your account.

︗Password Requirements
We have the following policies in regards to our ActiveDirectory passwords:

Minimum Password Length : 8 Characters (more is allowed)
Minimum Character Classes : 3 Character Classes
English uppercase characters (A - Z)
English lowercase characters (a - z)
Base 10 digits (0 - 9)
Non-alphanumeric (For example: !, $, #, or %)
Unicode characters
Password cannot contain (or match a substring of 3+ sequential characters) of your username or any part of your first or last name.
Password was not previously used in last 5 passwords.
Password has not been  compromised in a known data breach.
It is your responsibility to secure your password. Please choose a strong password, do not use your UMIACS password for any other service, and only connect using secure protocols.
UMIACS staff members do not store your password in a retrievable format, so if you forget your password, you must reset it (next section).

︗Changing account password
︗If you know your current password
You can use the UMIACS Password Web Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/password) to change your password.
︗If you do not know your current password
You can reset your password yourself(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/password/forgot) if you know your username and have already registered a mobile phone number and alternate E-mail address in our Directory Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info/).
If your account was a UMIACS Collaborator Account, your password can be reset by your sponsor via our Requests Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/collaborators/).
You can stop by the UMIACS Help Desk in room 3109 Iribe Center with a photo ID.
If you are unable to physically stop by the UMIACS Help Desk, you can have your account sponsor (PI) work with the UMIACS Help Desk to receive a temporary password on your behalf.  The account sponsor will then be responsible for conveying the password to you in a secure manner. (e.g., Telephone, where they could identify you by voice)
︗Sponsored Accounts
You can view a list of the accounts you sponsor in the UMIACS Account Management Web Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/sponsored/). Clicking on an account's display name will bring you to a management page where you can see details such as the installation date or email forward. From here you can edit your relationship to the account.
You can also request to remove your sponsorship or modify the expiration date, but these require staff action and are not immediate. 

︗All Accounts Related Pages
Accounts/Collaborator

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/URL contains the following information: 






︗URL

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Uniform Resource Locator
( also refered to as a URI though not exactly the same)

  protocol://dns.address:port/path/to/requested/information

︗None
This is most commonly http://, https:// or ftp://.  But can be smb://, afp://, rss://, etc.
Please note that file:/// is used in places and the extra / refers the root of the local file system

︗dns.address
Is either a fully qualifed domain name (FQDN) or can be a short domain name if your local name service resolver is configured to try certain sub domains.

︗:port
This is always optional and is always a numeric value, eg.  :8000

︗None
This is optional but most of the time you will see some path information appended to your [URL]





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=URL&oldid=2196"
