︗Windows/LaptopSupport

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 UMIACS Windows Laptop Support
2 Hardware Base Requirements
3 Support Levels

3.1 UMIACS Enterprise Laptop Support
3.2 UMIACS Base Laptop Support
3.3 UMIACS Hardware Support




︗UMIACS Windows Laptop Support
In order to meet the demanding requirements of mobile computing best practices and security policies, UMIACS provides a range of supported laptop options for devices that will run and/or are shipped with a Windows operating system.  In order to qualify for UMIACS support of any level, the laptop hardware must meet the following  Base Requirements.

︗Hardware Base Requirements
University Owned Hardware
Business or professional model line from a tier one manufacturer (e.g. Dell, HP, Microsoft)
3+ years OEM warranty/support (i.e. no refurbished equipment or third-party vendor warranties)
Readily available manufacturer diagnostic tools
Readily available hardware drivers
Other hardware may be considered on a case-by-case basis, subject to staff evaluation.

︗Support Levels
Note: Dual-boot laptops are only eligible for UMIACS Hardware Support.  If you later set up or attempt to set up dual-boot on a system that UMIACS staff previously configured with either Enterprise or Base level support, we cannot offer any help if you run into issues with the dual-booting process or either operating system thereafter.

︗UMIACS Enterprise Laptop Support
UMIACS Enterprise laptop support provides a secure computing platform with automated backups and security updates.  Staff will install an Enterprise version of Microsoft Windows, as well as a range of software suites including F-Secure Client Security, Ivanti Security Scan, Microsoft Office, and MATLAB.  We will also encrypt the hard drive using BitLocker.  This option is ideal for those dealing with sensitive data, or those who want a worry-free experience. Staff will check in with you if we notice extended periods of security update inactivity on the laptop.

What we provide:
Hardware diagnostics and support
Operating System installation with university licensed software pre-installed
 Data archival upon return of the device to us
Data protection (BitLocker)
Security updates (Ivanti)
Data backups (Google Drive/Drive for Desktop)
︗UMIACS Base Laptop Support
UMIACS Base laptop support serves as a primer for a development laptop.  Staff will install an Enterprise version of Microsoft Windows, as well as a range of software suites including F-Secure Client Security, Microsoft Office, and MATLAB.   We will also encrypt the hard drive using BitLocker.  You are then responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the Operating System and any data stored on the laptop.

What we provide:
Hardware diagnostics and support
Operating System installation with university licensed software pre-installed
 Data archival upon return of the device to us
Data protection (BitLocker)
What's left for you:
Security updates
Data backups and protection (you can set up Google Drive/Drive for Desktop yourself if you would like)
︗UMIACS Hardware Support
The UMIACS Hardware Support provides basic hardware diagnostics and warranty repairs, while allowing you to have full control over the software and data stored on your laptop.

What we provide:
Hardware diagnostics and support
What's left for you:
Everything else. If the hardware is University-owned, you can download institutionally licensed copies of software such as the Windows OS itself and other common applications like Microsoft Office on it from Terpware(The prior text links to https://terpware.umd.edu/Windows) and install them yourself. If you do not have access to Terpware, please contact the HelpDesk.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Windows/LaptopSupport&oldid=11361"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Screen contains the following information: 






︗Screen

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Introduction
2 Usage
3 Common Keyboard Shortcuts
4 Important Notes
5 .screenrc
6 Useful Links


︗Introduction
GNU Screen, or "screen", is a window management program available on UMIACS Linux hosts that allows multiplexing of a single terminal between multiple virtual consoles. Screen is also capable of separating programs from the shell that initially started it which allows a program to continue running even if the connection to the host has been lost. For this reason screen is typically used when a network connection is unstable and the process must remain running even if an SSH connection has dropped. Screen is also useful when a process may be slow and other processes need to be running. 

︗Usage
To invoke screen, simply use the following command in a terminal:

# screen

Alternatively, to start a program with screen:

# screen vi program.c

This will invoke screen and, in the newly-created window, start editing the file program.c in vi.
You can have as many screen sessions as you’d like on a single host, however, keeping track of many sessions can become difficult. As a way to solve this screen offers the capability to give each session a unique name when you start it using the following:

# screen -S [session name]

If you need to end your ssh session, but want your processes to keep running you can detach the screen session with:

# screen -d

Then exit as normal.
If you have multiple screen sessions you can detach and reattach them at any time. To list the current screen sessions running on a host use:

# screen -ls

The output will be similar to this:

# username@tron02:~$ screen -ls
#  There are screens on:
# 	26598.screenTest1	(Detached)
# 	18457.pts-0.tron02	(Detached)
# 2 Sockets in /var/run/screen/S-username.

To reconnect to a specific screen session you may use either the screen number or name to reconnect using ‘screen -r’

# username@tron02:~$ screen -r 26598

or

# username@tron02:~$ screen -r screenTest1

︗Common Keyboard Shortcuts
Ctrl-A is the metacharacter for commands in screen; press it before every key command.  Some useful commands in screen:

Ctrl-A + c (Creates a new window.)
Ctrl-A + d (detach from current session)
Ctrl-A + [0-9] (Switches to the window corresponding to the number, window 0 is the first window initialized by screen.)
Ctrl-A + " (Presents a selection of screen windows from which to choose.)
Ctrl-A + Shift-A Rename the current screen window
Ctrl-A + <SPC> / Ctrl-A + <BKSPC> (Switch to the next / previous window.)
Ctrl-A + k (Kill the current window.)
Ctrl-A + \ (Kill the screen session and all its windows.)
See the documentation here(The prior text links to http://www.gnu.org/software/screen/manual/screen.txt) to see a full list of Ctrl-A commands (Section 5.1: Default Key Bindings).

︗Important Notes
If you start a screen session that will run a program within a session that has only one window, such as by issuing the command 

# screen program.c 

then when the program exits the screen session will terminate as well. This has the potential to hide any output you may want from your program since the screen session will exit. To solve this issue you can either make sure your shell is not set to auto-logout, or ensure that you have multiple windows open in the screen session so that it will not terminate when the program exits.

︗.screenrc
Similar to .bashrc, the file .screenrc in a user's home directory can be used to customize a screen session's startup behavior.  Commands listed in this file will be executed upon starting screen, and can be useful to set up your environment to display important information such as the window number and name, the name of the host you're connected to, or altering the key sequences for screen commands. See the link here(The prior text links to http://www.gnu.org/software/screen/manual/screen.txt) for more information about screen commands (Section 5.2: Command Summary).

︗Useful Links
The main page at www.gnu.org.(The prior text links to http://www.gnu.org/software/screen/)
GNU Screen documentation(The prior text links to http://www.gnu.org/software/screen/manual/screen.txt) (also accessed through man screen).




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Screen&oldid=10377"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Matlab contains the following information: 






︗Matlab

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS has institutional Matlab licenses through UMD that cover Linux, Windows, and macOS. To access them, you have to be using a University owned computer. Please note that only Matlab versions R2020a and newer are supported by the University's license server.
If you would like to install the institutional version of Matlab on a self-supported machine, please  contact staff and we can provide you install media.

︗Contents

1 Linux
2 Windows
3 macOS
4 License Information

4.1 Toolbox Shortnames


5 Matlab Customizations


︗Linux
Modules are the preferred way to interact with Matlab on UMIACS-supported Linux machines. The Modules page will provide information on adding Matlab into your environment and using it.

︗Windows
All UMIACS-supported Windows machines should come with a pre-installed version of Matlab. Please  contact staff if you would like a later version installed.

︗macOS
Please  contact staff if you would like Matlab installed on a UMIACS-supported macOS machine.

︗License Information
Campus has a limited number of seats for Matlab itself, as well as the various toolboxes, managed by a cluster of network license servers(The prior text links to https://www.mathworks.com/help/install/administer-network-licenses.html). As such, you must have network connectivity to be able to use the University's licenses. When calling functions in a toolbox, Matlab will automatically check out a license for that toolbox, making it temporarily unavailable to other users. If, while attempting to use Matlab, you run into a license manager error stating that the maximum number of users for Matlab has been reached, this likely indicates that all of campus' available licenses are in use. To check the number of licenses available for a specific toolbox, please see the below sections:

︗Toolbox Shortnames
The toolbox names themselves don't always work with licensing commands; rather, Matlab has a set of shortnames which can be passed to these commands. The following are the valid shortnames:

Aerospace_Blockset   
Aerospace_Toolbox
Antenna_Toolbox  
Bioinformatics_Toolbox  
Communication_Blocks  
Communication_Toolbox  
Compiler  
Control_Toolbox  
Curve_Fitting_Toolbox  
Data_Acq_Toolbox  
Database_Toolbox  
Datafeed_Toolbox  
Distrib_Computing_Toolbox  
Econometrics_Toolbox  
Excel_Link  
Fin_Derivatives_Toolbox
Fin_Instruments_Toolbox  
Financial_Toolbox  
Fixed_Income_Toolbox  
Fixed_Point_Toolbox
Fuzzy_Toolbox 
GADS_Toolbox  
Identification_Toolbox  
Image_Acquisition_Toolbox  
Image_Toolbox  
Instr_Control_Toolbox  
MAP_Toolbox  
MATLAB  
MATLAB_Builder_for_Java  
MATLAB_Coder  
MATLAB_Excel_Builder  
MATLAB_Report_Gen  
MPC_Toolbox  
Neural_Network_Toolbox  
Optimization_Toolbox
OPC_Toolbox  
PDE_Toolbox
Phased_Array_System_Toolbox  
Real-Time_Workshop  
Robotics_System_Toolbox 
Robust_Toolbox
RTW_Embedded_Coder
Signal_Blocks  
Signal_Toolbox
SimEvents  
SimMechanics  
Simscape  
SIMULINK  
Simulink_Control_Design
Simulink_Design_Optim  
Stateflow  
Stateflow_Coder  
Statistics_Toolbox  
Symbolic_Toolbox  
Video_and_Image_Blockset  
Virtual_Reality_Toolbox  
Wavelet_Toolbox

If you are having problems, feel free to contact  UMIACS Staff, however please note that the Matlab license servers are hosted by campus' Division of Information Technology.

︗Matlab Customizations
You can tweak your Matlab experience using a file "startup.m". If this file is present in the current working directory where you launch Matlab, it will be executed. You can perform a variety of tasks using this file. These include (but are not limited to) customizing the window environment, setting variables for later use, and enabling use of 3rd party toolboxes. Alternatively, you can use the userpath env variable to set a path other than the current working directory for startup and 3rd party toolbox locations. Please see the following links for more information:

Mathworks: Startup.m(The prior text links to http://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/matlabrc.html)
Mathworks: Userpath function(The prior text links to https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/userpath.html)

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/UpdatingMozillaSoftware contains the following information: 






︗UpdatingMozillaSoftware

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Like most applications, it is important to keep your browser and email clients up-to-date to combat security flaws and gain new functionality. The instructions on this page should help you update Mozilla Firefox and Thunderbird.
You can also find installers and documentation for the latest versions of Firefox and Thunderbird here:

Firefox: http://www.getfirefox.com(The prior text links to http://www.getfirefox.com)
Thunderbird: http://www.getthunderbird.com(The prior text links to http://www.getthunderbird.com)
︗Contents

1 Determining the Installed  Version
2 Updating Mozilla Firefox (Windows & Mac)
3 Updating Mozilla Thunderbird (Windows & Mac)
4 Troubleshooting


︗Determining the Installed  Version
You can find out what version of Firefox or Thunderbird you have installed on you computer by opening up the application and choosing:

"Help > About Mozilla [application]" from the menu bar on Windows
"Firefox > About [application]" from the menu bar on macOS
where [application] is either "Firefox" or "Thunderbird".

︗None
By default Mozilla Firefox will automatically update by itself. If it is currently disabled it can be enable with the following steps:
First navigate to options (Windows) or preferences (Mac).
Once in the options (Windows) or preferences (Mac) you navigate to the Firefox Updates section
Once in the Firefox Updates section you will see an option to “Automatically install updates”. If this is not already enabled it is recommended to enable this.
Click on pictures to enlarge them


The image displays a user interface of the Mozilla Firefox browser on a Windows operating system. It shows a settings menu with various options represented by icons and labels. In the top left section, a magnifying glass icon is visible, indicating a search function. Below it, two options— "New Window" and "New Private Window"—are represented by corresponding icons.

The central portion features icons for "Print," "History," "Full Screen," and "Find" functions, all clearly labeled. The "Options" section is highlighted with a gear icon, indicating settings preferences. Other icons signify "Add-ons" and a customizable option at the bottom.

Overall, the interface is minimalist, featuring a predominantly white background with gray icons and text for clarity. This depiction emphasizes user accessibility, as it allows quick navigation to critical browser functions. The design suggests an intention to enhance user experience by making essential options readily available. Step 1: Navigate to options (Windows)
The image showcases the user interface of the Mozilla Firefox browser on a macOS operating system. The design features a dark theme, with the top menu bar displaying various options related to the browser. The left side presents the "Firefox" dropdown menu containing choices such as "About Firefox," "Preferences," and "Services," each represented by clear text. The "Preferences" option is highlighted for emphasis, indicating its significance when adjusting browser settings.

To the right, the search bar is visible, prominently labeled with a cursor positioned in it, suggesting that the user is about to enter a search query. The search bar has a Google logo, indicating that Google is the default search engine. The overall color scheme consists of dark grays and blacks, offering a sleek, modern aesthetic. This user interface design prioritizes accessibility and ease of use, allowing for straightforward navigation to crucial functions. The presence of clearly defined options reflects a focus on enhancing the user experience in managing browser settings efficiently. Step 1: Navigate to preferences (Mac)


The image illustrates the options menu of the Mozilla Firefox browser on a Windows operating system. The interface features a light color scheme, predominantly white, with various sections and settings organized for user accessibility. On the left side, multiple tabs are visible, including "General," "Tabs," "Content," "Applications," "Privacy," "Security," "Sync," and the highlighted "Advanced," indicated by a prominent gear icon.

The central portion contains a list of settings under the "Advanced" tab, which encompasses categories such as "Accessibility," "Browsing," and "System Defaults." Each category includes checkboxes for user preferences, such as enabling autocorrect, using hardware acceleration, and checking spelling while typing. 

At the bottom, three buttons labeled "OK," "Cancel," and "Help" are present, providing options for users to finalize or exit their selections. An arrow points to the "Advanced" tab, emphasizing its significance. This user-friendly layout signifies an emphasis on customization and ease of use for managing browser settings effectively. Step 2: Navigate to advanced tab (Windows)
The image displays the "Firefox Updates" section of the Mozilla Firefox browser interface on a macOS operating system, set against a dark-themed background. At the top left, a summary message informs users that they should keep Firefox updated for optimal performance, stability, and security. It features the current version—72.0.1 (64-bit)—along with a link labeled "What's new?" prompting users to learn about the latest changes.

Below this, a status indicator confirms that "Firefox is up to date," accompanied by a button for checking for updates. The section titled "Allow Firefox to" provides three options: "Automatically install updates (recommended)," "Check for updates but let you choose to install them," and "Automatically update search engines." Each option has corresponding checkboxes, with the recommended setting pre-selected.

The minimalist design prioritizes user accessibility, with white text on a dark background enhancing readability. Overall, this interface emphasizes straightforwardness and user guidance for managing browser updates effectively. Step 2: Navigate to Firefox Updates (Mac)


The image depicts the "Options" menu of the Mozilla Firefox browser on a Windows operating system. It features a clean, organized layout with a light background, predominantly white, and sections clearly defined for ease of navigation. The interface includes several tabs at the top, such as "General," "Data Choices," "Network," "Update," and others, with the "Update" tab highlighted.

Within the "Firefox updates" section, there are three distinct options for managing updates. The first, labeled “Automatically install updates (recommended: improved security),” is selected, indicated by a filled radio button. Below this, a checkbox for the option "Warn me if this will disable any of my add-ons" is also visible, which is currently unchecked. The other options include "Check for updates, but let me choose whether to install them," and "Never check for updates (not recommended: security risk)," both of which are empty.

At the bottom of the screen, buttons for "OK," "Cancel," and "Help" provide users with options for confirming or exiting their selections. The design emphasizes user accessibility and security. Step 3: Navigate to updates (Windows)
The image displays the "Firefox Updates" section of the Mozilla Firefox browser interface on a macOS system, set against a dark-themed background. At the top, there is a clear message urging users to keep Firefox updated for optimal performance, stability, and security. Below this message, the current version is indicated as "72.0.1 (64-bit)," alongside a link labeled "What's new?" that enables users to explore the latest features and changes.

A status indicator is visible, confirming "Firefox is up to date," complemented by a button for users to manually check for updates. The section is titled "Allow Firefox to," offering three distinct options for managing updates: “Automatically install updates (recommended)” which is checked, “Check for updates but let you choose to install them,” and “Automatically update search engines.” Each option includes checkboxes, reflecting a user-friendly design.

The overall aesthetic and functionality prioritize accessibility with white text on a dark background, enhancing readability. This layout emphasizes clarity and user guidance, ensuring that users can effectively manage their browser updates. Step 3: Navigate to Automatic Updates (Mac)


If you do not want to have Mozilla Firefox auto-update you can check manually for updates with the following steps:
First navigate to options (Windows) or preferences (Mac).
Navigate to the Firefox Updates section (Windows and Mac)
If an update is available click “Update to “Version”’ Button (Windows and Mac)
Click “Restart to Update” button (Windows and Mac)
Click on pictures to enlarge them

On the left, there are options for "New Window" and "New Private Window," each accompanied by a distinct icon—a window and a mask icon respectively. The central area showcases additional icons for "Print," "History," "Full Screen," and "Find," all clearly labeled for easy identification. 

Highlighted prominently is the "Options" section, denoted by a gear icon, which allows users to access settings. At the bottom right, two key functions are outlined: "Customize," indicated with an arrow pointing towards a gear, and an icon for syncing. The overall layout features a clean white background with gray icons, contributing to a minimalist aesthetic aimed at enhancing user accessibility. This design reflects a focus on user experience, allowing quick navigation to important browser functionalities. Step 1: Navigate to Help (Windows)

The overall design, with its clean layout and simple color scheme, underscores a focus on user-friendliness and accessibility. Step 2: Navigate to about Firefox (Windows)

The image displays the "About Mozilla Firefox" window on a Windows operating system. The interface features a bright, light blue background with rounded corners and a prominent orange fox graphic, which represents the Mozilla Firefox logo. In the upper center of the window, the text "Firefox" is boldly displayed, followed by the version number "29.0." Below this, there is a brief description explaining that Firefox is a global community dedicated to maintaining an open and accessible web.

Centered in the window is a blue button labeled "Check for Updates," which is highlighted and arrows point to it, indicating its importance. At the bottom, there are options for "Licensing Information," "End-User Rights," and "Privacy Policy," displayed in smaller text. The overall design emphasizes user engagement, showcasing accessibility options and encouraging users to ensure their browser is up-to-date, thus enhancing performance and security. The clean layout, combined with a friendly color palette, reflects Mozilla’s commitment to user experience and community involvement. Step 3: Click “Check for Updates” button (Windows)

The minimalist layout, with white text on a dark background, ensures readability and user accessibility, promoting effective navigation and management of the browser’s update settings. Overall, this presentation emphasizes straightforwardness and encourages users to keep their browser secure and up to date. Step 4:Click “Restart to Update" button (Mac)


︗None
By default Mozilla Thunderbird will automatically update by itself. If it is currently disabled it can be enable with the following steps.
First navigate to options->options(Windows) or preferences(Mac).
Once in the options(Windows) or preferences(Mac) you navigate to the advanced tab.
Once on the advanced Tab you navigate to Updates.
Once in the updates tab you will see an option to “Automatically install updates”. If this is not already enabled it is recommended to enable this.
Click on pictures to enlarge them


The image shows a user interface from Mozilla Thunderbird on a Windows operating system. It features a light blue taskbar at the top containing several options. On the left side, a white area represents the message pane, which is empty, indicating that no emails are currently displayed. A blue search bar is visible at the top left, suggesting user engagement for searching emails. 

To the right, an options menu is opened, revealing a dropdown with various settings such as "Add-ons," "Options," and "Account Settings." The "Options" section is emphasized, indicated by the arrow cursor hovering over it, implying that the user intends to select it for further action. Other menu items include "Mail Toolbar," "Quick Filter Bar," and "Toolbar Layout," allowing users to customize their email interface.

The overall layout is clean and minimalist, employing a light color scheme that enhances readability and accessibility. This user-focused design highlights Mozilla's commitment to providing an intuitive email management experience. Step 2: Navigate to options->options (Windows)
The image depicts the menu interface of the Mozilla Thunderbird email client on a macOS operating system. The top menu bar is visible, featuring the application name "Thunderbird" in blue, followed by standard menu options including "File," "Edit," and "View." The dropdown menu under "Thunderbird" is open, showcasing various options, with "Preferences" highlighted, indicated by the cursor hovering over it.

A red arrow points explicitly to the "Preferences" option, emphasizing the action of selecting it. This layout suggests user navigational guidance within the software. The background is a gradient of light blue, contributing to a visually appealing aesthetic that enhances readability. The design maintains a clean, minimalist style, promoting user accessibility and making it easy for the user to locate settings necessary for managing the email client effectively. Overall, this interface exemplifies intuitive software design geared towards user friendliness. Step 1: Navigate to preferences (Mac)


The image displays the "Options" menu of the Mozilla Thunderbird email client on a Windows operating system. The interface features a light gray background that highlights various tabs at the top, including "General," "Display," "Composition," "Chat," "Security," "Attachments," and "Advanced." The "Advanced" tab is prominently indicated with a red arrow pointing towards it, suggesting that the user is either currently selecting or should navigate to it.

To the left, smaller checkbox options are visible under the categories of "Scrolling" and "System Integration," with settings including options such as "Use autoscrolling" and "Always check to use Thunderbird as the default mail client on startup." The central area showcases buttons like "Check Now" for system integration tasks and links to "Advanced Configuration" options.

At the bottom of the menu, the buttons "OK," "Cancel," and "Help" are positioned for user interaction. Overall, the design emphasizes user-friendly navigation and highlights the importance of easy access to customization preferences within Thunderbird, thereby enhancing the overall user experience. Step 2: Navigate to advanced tab (Windows)
The image showcases the "Thunderbird Start Page" settings interface on a macOS operating system. It features a clean layout with a predominantly light gray background, enhancing readability. On the left side, a customizable section titled "Thunderbird Start Page" includes options to show the start page in the message area and its location link—a default setup that can be reset to default settings. The "Default Search Engine" field identifies Google as the chosen search engine, with an option to add from a file.

Below, the interface presents settings related to new message arrival notifications. An alert section indicates that preferences for the app icon can be changed, and below it, users can browse and select a default sound file for new message alerts, accompanied by a "Play" button to test the sound. A red arrow highlights this sound file selection area, suggesting it is a focal point for user action. Overall, this minimalist design prioritizes user convenience and accessibility, aligning with modern software interface standards. Step 2: Navigate to advanced tab (Mac)


The image depicts the "Options" menu for Mozilla Thunderbird on a Windows operating system. It features a predominantly white interface with clearly defined sections and tabs. At the top, there are several tabs including "General," "Display," "Composition," "Chat," "Security," "Attachments," and "Advanced," with the "Update" tab prominently selected. 

In the "Automatically check for updates to" section, there are options checked for "Thunderbird" and "Installed Add-ons." Below, a dialog prompts users about their update preferences, offering choices: "Ask me what I want to do" and "Automatically download and install the update," which are accompanied by checkboxes. An important alert reads "Warn me if this will disable any of my add-ons," indicating potential changes to user settings during updates. 

At the bottom, standard action buttons "OK" and "Cancel" are visible. The overall layout emphasizes user accessibility, allowing for straightforward navigation of update preferences, reflecting a focus on enhancing user experience in managing email updates efficiently. Step 3: Navigate to updates(Windows)
The image presents the "Update" section of the Mozilla Thunderbird interface on a macOS operating system. The top portion showcases the version number, "68.4.1 (64-bit)," with a link for "Release notes" indicating the current software's details. A status message confirms that "Thunderbird is up to date," enhancing user assurance regarding their software's security and performance.

Below, two radio button options are clearly visible for managing updates. The first option, "Automatically install updates (recommended: improved security)," is selected, highlighted by a filled circle, suggesting that users are advised to enable this for better security. The second option, "Check for updates, but let me choose whether to install them," remains unselected, allowing users to customize their update preferences.

Additionally, buttons labeled "Show Update History" and "Check for Updates" are present, offering quick access to relevant actions related to updates. The organized layout, featuring a light background, enhances readability and user engagement, reflecting Thunderbird's commitment to a streamlined and user-friendly email management experience. Step 3: Navigate to updates (Mac)


If you do not want to have Mozilla Thunderbird auto-update you can check manually for updates with the following steps:
First navigate to help->about Thunderbird (Windows) and about Thunderbird (Mac).
Click the check for updates button (Windows and Mac).
Click “Update & Restart” button (Windows) and “Restart to Update” button (Mac).
Click on pictures to enlarge them

On the right side of the interface, a dropdown menu appears, showcasing several options, with "Options" prominently highlighted, suggesting the user intends to access the settings. There are also entries like "File," "View," "Tools," and a list of management features such as "Activity Manager." The "Help" option at the bottom is emphasized with a red arrow pointing towards it, indicating its significance for user support.

The layout is clean, utilizing a minimalist aesthetic with a light color scheme that enhances readability and user accessibility. This design reflects user-friendly navigation, emphasizing ease of access to essential functionalities while promoting effective email management. Step 1: Navigate to Help (Windows)

The interface features a light blue background with rounded edges, prominently presenting the Mozilla Thunderbird logo, which is a stylized blue bird, on the left side. At the center-top, the word "Thunderbird" is displayed in bold, followed by the version number "24.4.0" in slightly smaller text beneath.

A brief description highlights the purpose of Thunderbird, noting that it's part of a global community developed by Mozilla aimed at enhancing internet accessibility. Below this, there is a section indicating the user is currently on the release update channel, along with a clearly labeled blue button saying "Check for Updates," which is highlighted with an arrow pointing towards it to denote user action.

At the bottom of the window, links to "Licensing Information," "End User Rights," and "Privacy Policy" are presented in smaller text. The overall design is structured for clarity and ease of use, encouraging users to engage with the update process for improved performance and security. Step 3: Click “Check for Updates” button (Windows)
The image displays the settings interface for the "Thunderbird Start Page" on a macOS operating system. The layout features a light gray background, enhancing readability and accessibility. On the left, there's a customizable section titled "Thunderbird Start Page" with an option to show the start page in the message area, alongside a location link that users can reset to default. The default search engine is set to Google, indicated in a dropdown menu with options to add from a file.

Below, settings related to new message notifications are visible, including preferences for the application icon. Users can adjust the sound file for new message alerts, with an option to play the selected sound attached to a “Play” button. A red arrow points to the sound file selection area, highlighting its importance for user interaction. Additional user-friendly buttons and icons support easy navigation and customization. This clean, minimalist design reflects modern software standards, centering on user convenience and efficient management of email settings. Step 2: Navigate to Advanced Tab (Mac)


The image presents the "About Mozilla Thunderbird" window on a Windows operating system, characterized by a light blue background with rounded edges. On the left side, the stylized Mozilla Thunderbird logo, a blue bird, is prominently displayed. At the center-top, the application name "Thunderbird" is shown in bold text, followed by the version number "24.4.0" in a slightly smaller font. Below this, a description explains that Thunderbird is a product of a global community dedicated to enhancing internet accessibility.

The window indicates the user’s current channel status as being on the release update channel. A blue button labeled "Update & Restart" is highlighted, with an arrow pointing towards it to emphasize the required action. Below, additional links for "Licensing Information," "End-User Rights," and "Privacy Policy" are available in smaller text, providing further user information.

The overall design focuses on clarity and usability, encouraging users to engage with the update process to improve the application's performance and security. This layout reflects Thunderbird's commitment to user accessibility and community involvement. Step 4: Click “Update & Restart" button (Windows)
The image presents the "Thunderbird Updates" section from the Mozilla Thunderbird interface on a macOS operating system. The layout features a light gray background that enhances readability. At the top, the version number "68.4.1 (64-bit)" is prominently displayed, alongside a link for "Release notes," allowing users to explore current software details. Below, a status message confirms that "Thunderbird is up to date," providing users with assurance regarding their software's performance and security.

The section titled "Allow Thunderbird to" includes two radio buttons for managing updates. The first option, "Automatically install updates (recommended: improved security)," is highlighted, indicating it is the preferred choice for users seeking improved security through automatic updates. The second option, "Check for updates, but let me choose whether to install them," is unselected, allowing for user customization.

Buttons labeled "Show Update History" and "Check for Updates" are also present, facilitating quick access to relevant actions related to updates. The organized layout, featuring a clear structure and light background, reflects Thunderbird's commitment to providing a streamlined, user-friendly email management experience. Step 3: Navigate to Updates (Mac)
The image depicts the "Thunderbird Updates" section from the Mozilla Thunderbird interface on a macOS operating system. The layout features a light gray background, making the text easy to read. At the top, the version number "68.4.1 (64-bit)" is prominently displayed next to a link titled "Release notes," providing users with insight into the software's current state.

Beneath the version information, a status message confirms that "Thunderbird is up to date," assuring users about the software's performance and security. The section titled "Allow Thunderbird to" includes crucial options for managing updates: the first option, "Automatically install updates (recommended: improved security)," is filled in, emphasizing its importance for safety; the second option, "Check for updates, but let me choose whether to install them," is unselected, allowing for user discretion.

Additional buttons labeled "Show Update History" and "Check for Updates" are present, offering convenient access to relevant functions concerning updates. Overall, the organized structure and visually clear design underscore Thunderbird's commitment to user-friendly email management. Step 4: Click on "Check for Updates" button (Mac)
The image displays the "Thunderbird Updates" section of the Mozilla Thunderbird interface on a macOS operating system. The layout features a light gray background that enhances readability. At the top, the current version, "68.3.1 (64-bit)," is prominently displayed alongside a link titled "Release notes," providing users with details about the latest software updates.

Beneath the version information, a status message confirms that "Thunderbird is up to date," offering reassurance regarding the software's performance and security. The section titled "Allow Thunderbird to" includes two key options for managing updates: the first option, "Automatically install updates (recommended: improved security)," is filled in, emphasizing its significance for maintaining user security; the second option, "Check for updates, but let me choose whether to install them," is unselected, allowing for user customization of update preferences.

Additional buttons for "Show Update History" and "Restart to update Thunderbird" are present, facilitating quick access to relevant functions related to updates. Overall, the organized structure and visually clear design reflect Thunderbird's commitment to user-friendly email management and software upkeep. Step 5: Click on "Restart to update Thunderbird" button (Mac)


︗Troubleshooting
If for some reason Firefox or Thunderbird refuses to update using the methods described above, please stop by the HelpDesk and have a technician assist you.

︗UMIACS Public Printers

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Umiacs Public Printers)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Access to Public Printers

1.1 Public Printers in room 3208
1.2 Public Printers in room 4149
1.3 Public Printers in room 4208
1.4 Public Printers in room 5208


2 How to Print


︗Access to Public Printers
If you need to print but there are no printers accessible in your lab, we have four locations across multiple floors in the Iribe Center with publicly accessible printers.

︗Public Printers in room 3208
Color Printer: cps432-3208 HP Color LaserJet Enterprise M653
Black/White Printer: ps432-3208 HP LaserJet Enterprise Flow MFP M633

︗Public Printers in room 4149
Color Printer: cps432-4149 HP Color LaserJet Enterprise M653
Black/White Printer: ps432-4149 HP LaserJet Enterprise Flow MFP M633

︗Public Printers in room 4208
Color Printer: cps432-4208 HP Color LaserJet Enterprise M653
Black/White Printer: ps432-4208 HP LaserJet Enterprise Flow MFP M633

ps432-4208 also has faxing capability, outlined  here
︗Public Printers in room 5208
Color Printer: cps432-5208 HP Color LaserJet Enterprise M653
Black/White Printer: ps432-5208 HP LaserJet Enterprise Flow MFP M633

︗How to Print
If you are unsure of how to connect to these printers, please see our other articles on printing in UMIACS.

 Windows Printing Guide
 macOS Printing Guide

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Automounter contains the following information: 






︗Automounter

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The Automounter that is utilized in UMIACS is autofs.  Almost all file systems are mounted with NFS.  You can utilize the automounter by just changing directory into the target or into a directory underneath the target.  Many of our file systems are mounted this way, the most common being:

/nfshomes
/fs/nexus-scratch




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Automounter&oldid=11806"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Mpich1sub.sh contains the following information: 






︗Mpich1sub.sh

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
#!/bin/bash
# Special PBS control comments
#PBS -l nodes=8,walltime=60

# Set up the path
PATH=/usr/local/stow/mpichgm-1.2.7p1-20/bin:$PATH
export $PATH

cd ~/mpich1test/
echo $PBS_NODEFILE
# Run the program
mpirun -np $( wc -l < $PBS_NODEFILE ) ./alltoall-mpich1





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Mpich1sub.sh&oldid=2733"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Network/VPN contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search


I'm ready to assist with the image descriptions once you provide the images you want described. Please share them!

As of August 14th 2022, Pulse Secure Client has been rebranded as Ivanti Secure Access Client. Please follow this link for more information on this - Ivanti Secure Access Client.


A virtual private network (VPN) extends a private network across a public network, and enables users to send and receive data across shared or public networks as if their computing devices were directly connected to the private network. UMIACS currently provides VPN access through a Ivanti Connect Secure(The prior text links to https://www.ivanti.com/products/connect-secure-vpn) SSL VPN to all users except  class accounts.
Please note that enrollment in our MFA is mandatory to connect using the UMIACS VPN. Enrollment steps can be found  here.

︗Contents

1 Getting Connected

1.1 Client Setup
1.2 VPN Troubleshooting
1.3 Multi-Factor Authentication




︗Getting Connected
Once connected to the VPN you can use the  Remote Desktop client to access a Windows machine, as well as access a number of other non-public UMIACS resources.

︗Client Setup
Operating Systems:
Configuring a Windows VPN Connection
Configuring a macOS VPN Connection
Configuring a Linux VPN Connection
Mobile Devices:
 Configuring a Mobile (iOS/Android) device
︗VPN Troubleshooting
Troubleshoot common VPN issues
︗Multi-Factor Authentication
 Configuring Multi-Factor authentication




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Network/VPN&oldid=11854"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/FTP/macOS/Finder contains the following information: 






︗FTP/macOS/Finder

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
FTP services can be accessed from supported machines running macOS. This is a guide on how to access the UMIACS FTP service using macOS Finder.

︗Contents

1 Opening up macOS Finder
2 Accessing the public folder

2.1 Access as an owner
2.2 Access as a collaborator




︗Opening up macOS Finder
To open up macOS Finder, click on the macOS Finder icon on the dock at the bottom of your desktop.

The image features a macOS user interface, specifically displaying the dock at the bottom of the screen. In the dock, various application icons are visible, representing programs typically found on a macOS system. Among these icons, the Finder icon, which resembles a blue and white face within a square, is highlighted with a red square around it, indicating it is the currently active or selected application. 

The background is a solid light blue color, creating a clean and minimalistic aesthetic emblematic of macOS design philosophy. The icons to the left of the Finder icon include a mixture of utility, communication, and media applications, all uniformly sized and arranged horizontally. The right side of the dock features additional applications, such as a music player and a browser, along with a Trash icon at the far right. Overall, the image captures the organized and user-friendly nature of the macOS operating system's interface. The Finder icon is highlighted with a red square


︗Accessing the public folder
The owner of the public folder can publish and modify files from a supported machine. External collaborators can only download files published by the owner. 

︗Access as an owner
First, bring up the address bar in macOS Finder by pressing Command + Shift + G.

The image is a screenshot of a macOS Finder window, prominently displaying a high-contrast dark mode interface. At the top of the window, the title "Macintosh HD" is visible, indicating the primary hard drive. The left sidebar shows a navigation menu with various folders such as "Applications," "Library," "System," and "Users," each denoted by a folder icon. The main area of the Finder window features a section labeled "Go to Folder," which is a gray input box where users can type a specific folder path. This box is empty and slightly faded to indicate it's ready for input.

A highlighted message at the bottom of the image, written in bold red font, reads "COMMAND + SHIFT + G," guiding users on how to activate the "Go to Folder" feature. The background is dark, emphasizing the elements within the window and the red text, which stands out against the subdued color scheme. The overall layout reflects a user-friendly interface typical of macOS, illustrating the pathways to access specific folders on the system. Bring up the "go to the folder"
 
In order to access your public folder,
type in the following into the address bar of Finder:

/fs/ftp/pub/<username> - where <username> should be replaced with your username
The image shows a macOS Finder window in dark mode, prominently featuring the title "Macintosh HD" at the top. Below the title, there is a sidebar displaying several folder icons, including "Applications," "Library," "System," and "Users." The main area of the Finder window has a highlighted gray input box labeled "Go to Folder," indicating that users can enter a specific folder path. This box contains the text "/fs/ftp/pub/<username>", where "<username>" is a placeholder for the user’s actual username, demonstrating how to access a public folder.

A distinct red rectangle surrounds the input box, providing emphasis and drawing attention to the text within it. The overall background is dark, which enhances the visibility of the white text and the red highlight. The window layout is clean and organized, characteristic of macOS design principles. The screenshot effectively conveys instructions for using the macOS Finder interface to navigate to a specific folder, combining minimalist aesthetics with practical functionality. Enter the path to access the pub folder


︗Access as a collaborator
External collaborators can access the public folders through the Finder's "Connect to Server" feature. The "Connect to Server" window can be opened by pressing Command + K on your keyboard.

The image depicts a macOS "Connect to Server" window displayed in dark mode. It features a rectangular modal dialog with rounded corners, prominently framed in a vibrant red outline, drawing attention to its importance. At the top, there is a labeled input field titled "Server Address," where users can enter the FTP address for connection. Below this field is a section for "Favorite Servers," accompanied by icons for adding or removing favorites. The "Browse" button is located to the right of the server address input, further facilitating user navigation.

The background of the window is primarily dark, enhancing the legibility of the white text and elements within. Below the dialog, in bold red text, is the instruction "COMMAND + K," indicating the keyboard shortcut to open this window. To the left, a sidebar contains "Favorites" such as Users, AirDrop, and others, while the bottom area clearly shows “Macintosh HD” as the currently selected item. This layout exemplifies macOS's intuitive design, making it easy for users to connect to remote servers efficiently. Open the "Connect to Server" window

Then, enter the following address into the server address bar and then click on the "Connect" button.

ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/<username> - where <username> should be replaced with the desired collaborator's username
The image depicts a macOS "Connect to Server" window, showcasing a streamlined dark mode interface. The window features a rounded rectangular dialog box with a vibrant red outline, emphasizing its importance. At the top, there is a labeled input field marked "Server Address," where users are instructed to enter the FTP address, specifically formatted as "ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/<username>." The placeholder "<username>" signals users to input their specific usernames.

Beneath the server address field, a section labeled "Favorite Servers" includes icons for managing favorite connections. To the right of the address input, a blue "Browse" button is present, allowing for easier navigation. The window maintains a dark background that enhances the visibility of white text and other elements, creating a clean, user-friendly appearance.

The bottom half of the window displays a directory listing with items categorized as "Folder" under the "Kind" column, indicating that the user is currently navigating through folder structures. This overall layout, consistent with macOS design principles, facilitates efficient server connection management for users. Enter the path to access the public folder

After that you will be prompted with a window where you should choose to connect as a guest and then click "Connect" once more.

The image displays a macOS dialog box for connecting to an FTP server. The interface showcases a dark mode design, which lends a sophisticated, modern aesthetic. At the top of the dialog, there is a prominent title instructing users to enter their name and password for the server "ftp.umiacs.umd.edu." Below the title, a selection labeled "Connect As" features two radio buttons: one for "Guest" highlighted with a red outline and one for "Registered User." This visual designation emphasizes the choice between connecting as a guest or as a registered user.

Below these options, there are labeled input fields for "Name" and "Password," both empty, suggesting user input is necessary. A checkbox option for remembering the password in the keychain is positioned under the password field, indicating a convenience feature for users. The overall background of the dialog is dark, enhancing the contrast of white text and making elements easily legible. At the bottom, there are two buttons: "Cancel" and "Connect," facilitating user navigation tasks. The design adheres to macOS principles of usability and clarity. Select Guest


The image showcases a macOS dialog box designed for connecting to an FTP server, featuring a dark mode interface that enhances readability. At the top, there’s a title instructing users to enter their name and password for the server “ftp.umiacs.edu.” Below the title is the “Connect As” section, which includes two radio buttons. The option for “Guest” is highlighted with a red outline, creating a visual distinction from the “Registered User” option, which remains unhighlighted.

Underneath, there are input fields labeled “Name” and “Password,” both empty, prompting the user to fill in their credentials. A checkbox for remembering the password in the keychain is located below the password field, enhancing user convenience. The background of the dialog is dark gray, which contrasts sharply with the white text and elements, making them easily discernible.

At the bottom of the dialog, two buttons are present: “Cancel” in a subdued style and “Connect” in a blue button encased in a bold red rectangle, drawing focus toward the action the user needs to take. This design arrangement promotes an intuitive and efficient user experience while accessing the FTP server. Click Connect

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/RHEL7 contains the following information: 






︗RHEL7

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Red Hat Enterprise Linux(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux) 7 is an operating system published by Red Hat, Inc., which is currently a subsidiary of IBM.

︗Contents

1 Features
2 Kernel and Performance
3 Virtualization
4 File System Capabilities
5 Security


︗Features
A summary of important improvements are listed below.

︗Kernel and Performance
Based on Linux 3.10.0-957 kernel.
Initial process is changed to systemd.
Includes Security-Enhanced Linux(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security-Enhanced_Linux).
︗Virtualization
Users can run virtual machines within RHEL 7 using its built-in Kernel-based Virtual Machine(The prior text links to https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html/virtualization_getting_started_guide/chap-virtualization_getting_started-products), or KVM. UMIACS also supports the use of Apptainer, a container application that is an alternative to Docker.

︗File System Capabilities
The default file system is now XFS. Here is an overview of the supported file systems in RHEL7. The information in this section is taken from this Redhat page(The prior text links to https://access.redhat.com/articles/796293) unless otherwise noted.

XFS(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XFS)
"[RHEL7] supports XFS filesystem sizes of up to 500 TB."
"XFS supports journaling to minimize data loss in the event of a system crash. Journal data are written to the log section while the file system is active and read when the filesystem is mounted (to recover any data not already written to disk)."
ext4(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ext4)
"The maximum standalone filesystem size for ext4 filesystems...[is]...50 TB."
Btrfs(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Btrfs)
This an "an unsupported Technology Preview," and should be used with caution.
︗Security
In addition to the standard Linux security architecture, RHEL7 includes Security-Enhanced Linux(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security-Enhanced_Linux), a module which implements a mandatory access control(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandatory_access_control) model. Tutorials for configuring SELinux in RHEL are available here(The prior text links to https://access.redhat.com/articles/217213).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=RHEL7&oldid=11278"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/BashForWindows10 contains the following information: 






︗BashForWindows

From UMIACS
(Redirected from BashForWindows10)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Microsoft has partnered with Canonical, the makers of Ubuntu, to create a release of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), which allows Windows users to use Linux command line tools such as such as grep, sed, git on Windows files through Bash. 

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Installation
3 Use
4 External Links


︗Prerequisites
In order to install Bash/WSL, you must be running a 64-bit version of Windows 10 version 1607 or later, any version of Windows 11, or Windows Server 2019 or later. In Windows, open the Settings app > System > About to check if your Windows version is compatible. 

︗Installation
First, turn on Developer Mode, open the Settings app > Update & security > For developers > Select the Developer radio button
Enable the Windows Subsystem for Linux, this can be done by turning on the feature through the Windows Features program or through a PowerShell session.
For the GUI method: Go to Control Panel > Programs and Features > Turn Windows features on or off (this will require local administrator privileges > Check the box for Windows Subsystem on Linux
For PowerShell method (in an elevated/administrator session) use the command:  Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux 
Restart the system.
Open a command prompt or PowerShell session, and then run bash.
After accepting the license, the Ubuntu user mode image will be installed.
︗Use
Simply run bash in a command prompt or PowerShell session to enter bash. The first time Bash is installed on Windows, a prompt will appear to create a Unix user. This Unix user account is completely separate from the Windows user account and has  sudo  permissions on the WSL. There is no GUI that is installed, nor can be installed. 

The Linux installation is located at %localappdata%\lxss\, which is a hidden system folder. 

I understand you're looking for detailed descriptions of images related to the "BashForWindows" wiki page, but I currently don't have access to the images you are referencing. If you provide those images, I can help describe them in detail. Please upload the images you'd like described.

Do not use Windows tools to edit the files or sub-files within this directory as corruption of the Linux files could occur.
 Windows storage and files can then be accessed from /mnt/..., such as /mnt/c/Users/myAccount.
︗External Links
Bash On Ubuntu On Windows(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/about)
Installation Guide(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/install_guide)
Command Reference(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/reference)
FAQ(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/faq)
Linux User Account Explanation(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/user_support)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BashForWindows&oldid=10833"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Python contains the following information: 






︗Python

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Python(The prior text links to https://www.python.org/) is a widely used general-purpose, high-level programming language.

︗Contents

1 Python Versions
2 Python Environment
3 Installing Modules

3.1 Unix/Linux Alternate Module Installation

3.1.1 'User' scheme
3.1.2 'Prefix' scheme
3.1.3 Python Virtual Environment


3.2 Windows Alternate Module Installation

3.2.1 Prefix Scheme






︗Python Versions
Most modern *NIX distributions ship with a system version of Python.  If the system version is not sufficient, there are multiple versions of Python available via  GNU Modules.  If you find that you need a version of Python that is not currently available through GNU Modules, you can always build it from source(The prior text links to https://www.python.org/downloads/).
If you are using Windows, you can install your required version of Python without Administrator credentials.  Please see the  Windows Python page.

︗Python Environment
Python utilizes a variable called 'PYTHONPATH', which is similar to the PATH variable used in many shells.  The PYTHONPATH variable tells the Python interpreter where to look to find modules.
To view your python path:

bash:~$ python -c 'import sys; print sys.path'
You can add directories to your PYTHONPATH either through your shell, or in your Python code itself:

bash:~$ PYTHONPATH=$PYTHONPATH:/location/to/directory

                 ...or...

>>> sys.path.append('/location/to/directory')
︗Installing Modules
While some of the Versions of Python available in GNU modules provide a default set of modules pre-installed, you may wish to install your own.  Typically you will not have access to the global Python install location, so you will have to install modules using an alternative method.

︗None
︗None
The user scheme allows a user to install the module into the site userbase (python -c 'import site; print site.USER_BASE').  This file location is included in the PYTHONPATH by default.

bash:~$ python setup.py install --user
︗None
The prefix scheme allows a user to install a module into a location of their choice.  Please note: This location will need to be added to the PYTHONPATH in order for the module to be found by the Python interpreter. 

bash:~$ python setup.py install --prefix="/path/to/location"
︗ Python Virtual Environment
A Python Virtual Environment is an isolated working copy of Python which allows you to work on a specific project without worry of affecting other projects.  For more information on setting up a virtualenv, please see the  Python Virtual Environment page.

︗Windows Alternate Module Installation
︗Prefix Scheme
Python on Windows has a simpler layout, and as such the prefix scheme has traditionally been used to install additional packages into a separate location.

python setup.py install --prefix="\Temp\Python"




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Python&oldid=10698"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/BarracudaSpamFirewall contains the following information: 






︗BarracudaSpamFirewall

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Introduction
2 Mail Flow Through Barracudas
3 Scoring
4 Quarantine
5 Quarantine Passthrough
6 Whitelists, Blacklists & Bayesian Filtering
7 More Information


︗Introduction
UMIACS has deployed a system with 2 Barracuda Networks spam firewalls. This allows for enterprise level Virus and Spam scoring and filtering for our email architecture. You can log in to the system either of the 2 firewalls using your UMIACS email address (username@umiacs.umd.edu) and password:

bubs.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://bubs.umiacs.umd.edu)
pompom.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://pompom.umiacs.umd.edu)
︗Mail Flow Through Barracudas
The first time your mail flows through one of the Barracudas it will send you a mail with a new username and password. Subsequently you will receive every day (unless you configure otherwise) a mail at approx. 3:30pm EST from the Barracuda with your quarantine summary. Please note that auto log-in through the link provided in the summary does not work due to a recent firmware upgrade on the Barracudas. Please use the links provided above to log in.
︗Scoring
The Barracudas will score every message that passes through them and inject varying message headers based on that score.  You can then create email filters based on these headers to filter out messages that are tagged as spam by the Barracudas. See BarracudaSpamFirewall/Scoring for more details.

︗Quarantine
Mail that has been deemed as spam will be kept on the Barracudas in quarantine.  It will not be delivered to your mailbox unless you configure the Barracudas to do so.
Your quarantine will be preserved for 21 days. If mail is held for longer, then it will be purged.
If you receive a security warning in your browser after clicking this link, you may need to add the UMIACS Certificate Authority
You can search your spam quarantine with the following steps BarracudaSpamFirewall/SearchingQuarantine
︗Quarantine Passthrough
If you wish to have the mail that would ordinarily be quarantined by Barracuda delivered to your mailbox instead you can configure this using the Barracuda web configuration.
You can enable this functionality with the following guide BarracudaSpamFirewall/QuarantinePassthrough
︗None
You may also setup whitelists, blacklists, and Bayesian filtering options through the Preferences tab at the top of the Barracuda web portal.
︗More Information
For more information on how to use the Barracuda please download the user's guide:
https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/images/5/5a/Barracuda_usersguide.pdf(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/images/5/5a/Barracuda_usersguide.pdf)





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BarracudaSpamFirewall&oldid=10019"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WindowsSubsystemForLinux contains the following information: 






︗BashForWindows

From UMIACS
(Redirected from WindowsSubsystemForLinux)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Microsoft has partnered with Canonical, the makers of Ubuntu, to create a release of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), which allows Windows users to use Linux command line tools such as such as grep, sed, git on Windows files through Bash. 

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Installation
3 Use
4 External Links


︗Prerequisites
In order to install Bash/WSL, you must be running a 64-bit version of Windows 10 version 1607 or later, any version of Windows 11, or Windows Server 2019 or later. In Windows, open the Settings app > System > About to check if your Windows version is compatible. 

︗Installation
First, turn on Developer Mode, open the Settings app > Update & security > For developers > Select the Developer radio button
Enable the Windows Subsystem for Linux, this can be done by turning on the feature through the Windows Features program or through a PowerShell session.
For the GUI method: Go to Control Panel > Programs and Features > Turn Windows features on or off (this will require local administrator privileges > Check the box for Windows Subsystem on Linux
For PowerShell method (in an elevated/administrator session) use the command:  Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux 
Restart the system.
Open a command prompt or PowerShell session, and then run bash.
After accepting the license, the Ubuntu user mode image will be installed.
︗Use
Simply run bash in a command prompt or PowerShell session to enter bash. The first time Bash is installed on Windows, a prompt will appear to create a Unix user. This Unix user account is completely separate from the Windows user account and has  sudo  permissions on the WSL. There is no GUI that is installed, nor can be installed. 

The Linux installation is located at %localappdata%\lxss\, which is a hidden system folder. 

I understand your request, but I don't have any images to describe. If you have images to provide, please upload them, and I'll create detailed descriptions based on their visual content.

Do not use Windows tools to edit the files or sub-files within this directory as corruption of the Linux files could occur.
 Windows storage and files can then be accessed from /mnt/..., such as /mnt/c/Users/myAccount.
︗External Links
Bash On Ubuntu On Windows(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/about)
Installation Guide(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/install_guide)
Command Reference(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/reference)
FAQ(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/faq)
Linux User Account Explanation(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/user_support)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BashForWindows&oldid=10833"
