〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms/TouchPanel contains the following information: 






︗ConferenceRooms/TouchPanel

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Iribe/ConferenceRooms/TouchPanel)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
All  conference rooms in the  Brendan Iribe Center and some in the  Atlantic Building come equipped with touch panels that can be used to control the video and audio source(s) and level(s) being used to project to the display(s) in the room.

︗Contents

1 Basic Usage

1.1 Moderated Rooms
1.2 Auto-Accept Rooms
1.3 Huddle Rooms


2 Common Options

2.1 Solstice
2.2 Laptop Device
2.3 Room PC


3 Shutting Down


︗Basic Usage
Assuming the room was previously in a 'shut down' state, the display will look like this when you first come up to it.
The image depicts a touch panel display located at the Brendan Iribe Center for Computer Science and Engineering, part of the University of Maryland. The background of the screen is a clear, light blue color. Prominently displayed in the center is the university's logo, featuring a circular emblem in red and yellow, which reflects the state flag of Maryland. Below the logo, the text reads "UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND" in bold black letters, followed by "BRENDAN IRIBE CENTER FOR COMPUTER SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING" in a smaller, less bold font. At the bottom of the screen, there is an instruction that says "Touch Screen to start," indicating that user interaction is required to proceed. The touch panel appears to be modern and has a sleek design, with a border that suggests a high-tech environment. At the lower edge, the word "CRESTRON" is visible, indicating the manufacturer of the touch panel system. This image serves as an interface for users to initiate the operation of the conference room's audiovisual systems.The image depicts a modern touch panel interface, likely part of the audiovisual system in a conference room at the Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science. The display background is a soft gradient blue, enhancing readability. Centered on the screen is a circular emblem featuring a multicolored design with segments in red, blue, yellow, and white, symbolizing diversity and innovation in science. Above the logo, the text reads "JOINT CENTER FOR QUANTUM INFORMATION AND COMPUTER SCIENCE" in a clear, professional font, emphasizing the institution’s focus.

Beneath the logo, there is a clear instruction prompting users to "Touch Screen to start," indicating an interactive element of the system that must be engaged to initiate usage. The interface suggests a user-friendly design conducive to ease of operation. The lower edge of the screen includes the word "CRESTRON," indicating the manufacturer of the touch panel system, which is known for its high-tech solutions. The overall layout conveys a sense of professionalism and advanced technology, suitable for a scholarly or technical environment.
Touch the panel as directed to start it up. This will turn on the display(s) for the room and lower the projector screens if any are present.
The image features a modern touch panel display set within a sleek, light-colored frame, indicative of a high-tech environment. The screen’s background is a subtle light blue, contributing to a calm and professional ambiance. Centered on the display is the text “A/V System Starting” in a bold, black font, clearly conveying that the audiovisual system is initializing. Below this message, the words “Please Wait” are presented in a slightly smaller font size, reinforcing the instruction for users to be patient during the startup process. A simple loading icon, resembling a spinning wheel, is situated beneath the text, visually indicating progress during the system startup. At the bottom of the screen, the word “CRESTRON” is visible, denoting the manufacturer of the touch panel. The overall layout strikes a balance between functionality and modern aesthetic, making it clear and user-friendly for individuals preparing to use the conference room's audiovisual features. This image serves as a visual cue for users to anticipate the system's readiness for interaction.
Once the startup completes, you will see a number of different options depending on what the capabilities of the room are:

︗ Moderated Rooms
The image features a high-tech Crestron touch panel display designed for controlling audiovisual systems in a conference room. The touchscreen is framed in a sleek black casing, contributing to a modern aesthetic. The user interface is prominently displayed against a bright, lightly colored background, facilitating ease of use.

At the top, two main buttons are visible: “Shutdown A/V System” in a bold red box, indicating an option for powering down the system, and “Device Control” in a gray box, suggesting management options for connected devices. Below this, graphical icons represent two destinations: a projector and monitor, allowing users to route their selected audiovisual sources to these devices.

Subsequent sections reveal the instructions for operation: a prompt reads, “First Select a Source To Be Routed Below, then the Destination,” guiding users in navigation. Seven selectable source icons lie beneath this text, including options for devices like PCs, Solstice, Laptop, Tuner, and a BluRay player, each depicted with intuitive icons. The display captures a clean, organized layout, promoting efficient interaction in a professional environment.
These (larger) rooms have a number of options for sources to display and multiple places to display them to. All of the source options available in the smaller conference rooms are also available in these rooms. The exact options on each moderated room's panel may vary, as the capabilities vary room to room.
Of note in these rooms specifically is the "Device Control" option at the top of the source/destination menu, which takes you to another menu where you can manage volume, and (in some rooms) lighting, microphones, and settings for other integrated devices such as the room's Blu-ray player, TV tuner, or room cameras. This is also where you mute or unmute the lectern mic, if there is one.
The image displays a Crestron touch panel, an advanced touchscreen interface for managing audiovisual systems in a conference room. The panel is framed in a sleek black casing, emphasizing its modern design. The interface showcases a light-colored background that enhances visibility and ease of use.

At the top of the screen, there are two prominent buttons: "Shutdown A/V System" in a bold red box, signaling a power-down option, and "Select Video Source" in a contrasting black box, indicating the user's choice for input. Below these buttons, the section labeled "LIGHTING" features several options in a simple grid layout, including "ALL ON," "Presentation," "Notetaking," "Dim," and "ALL OFF," which provide control over room lighting conditions.

On the right-hand side, the "VOLUME" section displays controls for adjusting the audio levels, with icons illustrating options for increasing ("Vol Up") or decreasing ("Vol Down") volume. The "LECT MIC Muted" indicator suggests the microphone's status for presentations. Overall, the interface is organized, user-friendly, and tailored for efficient operation within a professional environment.

︗ Auto-Accept Rooms
The image displays a Crestron touch panel interface designed for selecting audiovisual sources in a conference room at the University of Maryland. The panel is framed in a sleek white casing. The background is a clean white, enhancing visibility and modernity. At the top of the display, the instruction "Select Source To Be Displayed" is prominently shown in a bold black font.

Below this instruction, three main options are available for selection: "Solstice," represented with a wireless signal icon, indicates the ability to connect devices wirelessly. The "LAPTOP DEVICE" option is illustrated with a straightforward graphic of a laptop and cable, suggesting a wired connection through HDMI or AUX. The final option, "ROOM PC," shows an icon of a desktop computer, highlighting access to the in-room PC system. 

Centered on the screen, the University of Maryland logo is placed at the bottom, reinforcing the institutional branding. The overall interface is user-friendly, with clear icons and text that facilitate easy navigation in a professional setting, indicating a focus on functionality and technology integration in the conference room environment.
These rooms have the ability to display an external device's screen wirelessly using  Solstice, an external device's screen wired via HDMI, or the room PC's screen (the room PC is attached to the back of the display in the room).

︗ Huddle Rooms
The image depicts a Crestron touch panel interface situated in a conference room, designed for selecting audiovisual sources. The panel is encased in a sleek white frame, contributing to a modern aesthetic. The background is a clean, light gray, enhancing the visibility of the displayed information. At the top of the screen, the instruction "Select Source To Be Displayed" is prominently featured in a bold black font, indicating the primary action for users.

Beneath this instruction, two main options are presented: "Solstice," depicted with a wireless signal icon, representing the capability to connect devices without cables, and "LAPTOP DEVICE," illustrated with a graphic of a laptop connecting to a cable, indicating a wired connection option via HDMI. 

Centered at the bottom of the screen is the University of Maryland logo, reinforcing the institutional branding. The overall layout is user-friendly, with clear icons and text to facilitate easy navigation, maintaining a focus on functionality and technology integration within the conference room environment.
These rooms have the ability to display an external device's screen wirelessly using  Solstice or wired via HDMI. They do not have room PCs, so you must bring your own device(s).

︗Common Options
The three source options you will commonly choose from on these panels are "Solstice", "Laptop Device" (just "Laptop" on some panels), and "Room PC" (the third option only in non-huddle rooms).
In auto-accept and huddle rooms, the volume control for each of these sources can be found one you select that source. In moderated rooms, the volume control is on the Device Control menu, as mentioned above.

︗Solstice
The image showcases a Crestron touch panel interface for managing audiovisual settings in a conference room, framed in a sleek white casing. The screen displays a light blue background, which enhances readability. At the top left, a bold red button labeled "Shutdown A/V System" indicates a power-down option, while a grey box on the right states "Select Source," suggesting the user is to choose an input. Below this, the message "SOLSTICE DEVICE SOURCE SELECTED" is displayed prominently, signaling that a specific input source has been activated. Beneath this, a prompt, "Please follow the on-screen instructions," guides users on their next steps.

On the right side, the "VOLUME" section features three circular buttons: "Vol Up," "Vol Down," and "Mute," each with intuitive graphics indicating their functions. A vertical slider next to these buttons visually represents the current volume level, ensuring ease of audio management. The overall design is clean and organized, providing a user-friendly interface that facilitates efficient interaction in a professional setting. The branding at the bottom indicates that this system is part of the Crestron product line, known for advanced audiovisual solutions.
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the room-specific details (IP address, room code) have been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in a room.
The image displays a large flat-screen television showcasing a Solstice Wireless Display interface in a conference room. The background features a dramatic, textured pattern resembling colorful, flowing molten rock or abstract swirls, combining earthy tones of orange, red, and deep blue. Prominently featured on the left side of the screen is a section labeled "IRB Pod," with the letters obscured by black rectangles, indicating a specific room designation. 

The user instructions are displayed in a clear, white font on the right, guiding users on how to connect their devices. The steps include: 1) "Connect your device to INTERNAL," 2) "Browse to the address above," and 3) "Connect." Below this, an additional note instructs Apple users to utilize AirPlay to connect to "IR Pod" after initially connecting via the Solstice app.

At the bottom of the screen, the current time reads "2:34 pm," framed by a sleek black interface. The user-friendly design facilitates easy navigation, with clear instructions meant to optimize the use of the conference room’s audiovisual capabilities. Overall, the image conveys a modern, high-tech environment suitable for professional gatherings.

︗Laptop Device
The image features a Crestron touch panel interface designed for managing audiovisual systems within a conference room. Housed in a sleek, light gray frame, the touchscreen showcases a clear and organized layout against a soft blue background that enhances readability. At the top, two prominent buttons are visible: a bold red “Shutdown A/V System” box indicating a power-off option, and a dark blue box labeled “Select Source” for choosing the input method.

Centered on the display is the message “LAPTOP DEVICE SOURCE SELECTED,” confirming that the system is set to retrieve input from a laptop. Below this messaging are three instructional points outlined in concise bullet format, guiding users to ensure the laptop is powered on and that the HDMI or VGA cable is securely connected. The third instruction prompts users to check the display settings of their device to confirm it is set to mirror or extend the projection.

To the right, practical volume controls are shown, featuring “Vol Up,” “Vol Down,” and “Mute” buttons, allowing for audio adjustments. The entire interface emphasizes user-friendliness and efficient control in a professional setting, indicative of a modern audiovisual management system.
Connect your device to either the HDMI cable or VGA/aux cables coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Room PC
The image displays a Crestron touch panel located in a conference room, designed for managing audiovisual systems. The interface is framed in a sleek white casing, emphasizing a modern appearance. The background of the screen is a light blue, contributing to a calm and professional atmosphere. Prominently at the top are two buttons: a red box labeled "Shutdown A/V System" for powering down the system, and a black box labeled "Select Source" for input selection.

In the center of the display, the message "ROOM PC SOURCE SELECTED" is clearly visible, confirming the selected audiovisual input. Below this, there are two instructional bullet points: “1. Room PC is on” and “2. Room PC monitor is on,” guiding users to ensure that both components are operational. To the right, the "VOLUME" section features three buttons with intuitive icons for volume control: "Vol Up," "Vol Down," and "Mute." The interface is organized and user-friendly, facilitating efficient use for individuals in a conference setting. Overall, the design reflects a user-centric approach integrated with advanced technology.
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "Shutdown A/V System" button when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the display(s) for the room and raise the projector screens if any are present.
The image presents a Crestron touch panel display set against a sleek frame, indicative of modern technology in a conference room. The screen features a calm light blue background, creating a professional atmosphere. Centrally positioned is the message "A/V System Shutting Down" rendered in bold black font, effectively conveying the action currently underway. Below this primary message, the words "Please Wait" are inscribed in smaller text, further instructing users on the system’s status.

At the bottom of the display, the "CRESTRON" logo is prominently featured, linking the interface back to its manufacturer, known for advanced audiovisual solutions. A simple loading icon, resembling a spinning wheel, is situated beneath the text, visually indicating the shutdown process is in progress. This interface is designed to communicate clearly with users, ensuring they understand that the audio-visual system is in the process of powering down. Overall, the layout is straightforward and user-friendly, facilitating efficient usage within a professional setting.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/AlternativePickup contains the following information: 






︗AlternativePickup

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Overview
Please note that as of Fall 2021 with the University returning to fully onsite operation, you must have rationale other than COVID-19 precautions alone to make use of this service. Please pick up all other orders at our HelpDesk.

︗Procedure
Please let us know that you want to pick up or drop something off by  contacting staff and letting us acknowledge and confirm your request before coming on-campus. We will not be able to service you if you arrive without letting us know beforehand.
Please provide in your initial request:

Your name
What you are looking to pick up or drop off.  Note: For large or heavy items, we may request that they only be picked up using car transportation instead of allowing on foot pickup to prevent accidental damage.
If applicable, the color, make, and model of vehicle that you are planning on stopping by in
The rough 15-minute window that you are planning on stopping by in
During pickup:

Please ensure you have a photo ID. Staff will be checking for ID before handing off any items.
Call the Help Desk at (301) 405-1775(The prior text links to tel:+13014051775) when you are physically standing (on foot) or parked (in a vehicle) at the loop in parking lot GG1 behind AVW.
We will bring out your items either by hand or on a cart.
We will verify your ID and give you the items.
︗Map
The image is a simplified map depicting a portion of a university campus, specifically showing the layout and key buildings relative to parking areas. The map is oriented with north at the top and includes labeled structures such as the A.V. Williams building, Engineering Annex, and Wind Tunnel. There are several parking lots marked, including GG1, positioned prominently along the right side of the image.

Highlighted in red is a looped drop-off area behind the A.V. Williams building, indicating where pickups and drop-offs should occur. The pathways connecting various buildings are illustrated with light lines, and landscaping elements such as trees and grassy areas are visually represented, enhancing the understanding of the physical space. The layout suggests a navigable route for individuals traveling by foot or vehicle, illustrating the university’s spatial organization and accessibility features.

Overall, the map effectively conveys essential navigation details for users needing to locate specific areas for campus services.
From the main entrance to campus (off US Rt. 1):

Make your first right to turn onto Paint Branch Drive.
Continue straight past the Brendan Iribe Center and Wind Tunnel buildings on your right.
Continue straight at the stop sign at Stadium Drive and straight past the Engineering Annex and A.V. Williams buildings on your right.
Make a right at the stop sign immediately past A.V. Williams to enter lot GG1.
Follow the path through the parking lot to reach the loop behind the A.V. Williams building.
From the Paint Branch Drive entrance (off MD Rt. 193):

Continue straight past the Xfinity Center and recreational fields as well as parking lots RR2 and XX1 on your right.
Continue straight at the stop sign at Regents Drive and straight past the Biomolecular Sciences and A. James Clark Hall buildings on your right.
Make a left at the stop sign immediately past A. James Clark Hall to enter lot GG1.
Follow the path through the parking lot to reach the loop behind the A.V. Williams building.
For a full campus map, please visit https://maps.umd.edu/map/(The prior text links to https://maps.umd.edu/map/).

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/ConferenceRooms/Solstice contains the following information: 






︗ConferenceRooms/Solstice

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Solstice(The prior text links to https://www.mersive.com/products/solstice/) is a wireless and content sharing solution. It enables multiple users to connect simultaneously to a shared display using laptops and mobile devices over an existing wireless network without the need for cables or additional hardware.
All conference rooms in the  Brendan Iribe Center and some in the  Atlantic Building are equipped with Solstice Mersive Pods(The prior text links to https://www.mersive.com/product/the-solstice-pod/).

︗Contents

1 Welcome Screen
2 Downloading Solstice User App
3 How to Connect to a Display
4 Mirror Your iOS Device Screen Using AirPlay
5 Share Your Windows Device Screen Using Miracast


︗Welcome Screen
When viewing a Solstice display that does not have a current collaboration session, you will see the Welcome Screen containing the Solstice display name, a screen key, network information, user connection instructions, and the Solstice display menu.
The image displays a digital screen interface titled "Round Table" prominently at the top. Below the title is a timestamp showing "2:11 pm." The background features a panoramic view of a mountain landscape, predominantly showcasing rugged peaks and valleys that are vividly illuminated by soft light, indicating either sunrise or sunset, giving off hues of deep red and purples.

On the right side, a detailed panel provides essential information for users looking to connect to the display. The panel lists two connection options: "Ethernet" with the IP address "192.168.34.132" and "Miracast" with a corresponding link labeled "192.168.34.132." There is also an instructional note at the bottom that advises users to “Apple screen on [their devices] to Round Table,” indicating how to connect via Apple devices. The overall design of the screen is clean and modern, emphasizing clarity for user interaction. The spatial arrangement ensures that all elements are easily readable, highlighting the functional aspect of the display in a collaborative setting.

︗Downloading Solstice User App
 Solstice User App
︗How to Connect to a Display
Ensure you are connected to either the UMD wireless or wired network.
Open the Solstice user app.
Search for a specific display by name/IP in the search bar.
When prompted, enter in the screen key listed on the Solstice display.
The user app will join the collaboration session with full media posting and control rights.
︗Mirror Your iOS Device Screen Using AirPlay
Solstice supports full mirroring of iOS 7+ devices (Apple iPhones and iPads) that feature Apple’s AirPlay functionality. AirPlay mirroring is accomplished through the device’s native AirPlay feature, using a similar process as connecting to an Apple TV.

Ensure the iOS device is on the WiFi network used to connect to the Solstice display.
Swipe upward from the bottom or downward from the upper-right corner of your screen to open the iOS Control Center.
Tap the Screen Mirroring button and select the desired Solstice display from the list that appears.
If the desired display does not appear in the AirPlay menu of your device, open the Solstice App and connect to the desired display, then repeat steps 2 and 3.
If prompted, enter the screen key visible on the Solstice display. Your device will connect wirelessly to the display and your screen will be streamed in real-time.
To stop mirroring your screen to the display, swipe upward from the bottom or downward from the upper-right corner of your screen to open the iOS Control Center, tap the Airplay button, then tap Stop Mirroring.
︗Share Your Windows Device Screen Using Miracast
If your organization has enabled streaming with Miracast, users without the Solstice user app can connect and share their screen to the display using Miracast capabilities on their Windows device. 
Screen mirroring on an Android device may not support audio streaming.

On your Windows laptop, hit the Windows key + P.
In the menu that appears, click Connect to a wireless display. A list of displays appears. Note: If the display is enabled for Miracast but you do not see it in the list of available displays, try scrolling down to ensure it is not hidden.
Select the Solstice display. If prompted for a PIN, enter the screen key from the display. Your device will connect wirelessly to the display and your screen will be streamed in real-time.
To change how your device handles the display, hit the Windows key + P, then select one of the display options that appear. Mersive recommends using the Duplicate setting when streaming with Miracast.
To stop Miracast streaming to the display, hit the Windows key + P, click Connect to a wireless display, then click Disconnect.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=ConferenceRooms/Solstice&oldid=10126"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Nexus/Apptainer contains the following information: 






︗Apptainer

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Nexus/Apptainer)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Apptainer(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org) is a container platform that doesn't elevate the privileges of a user running the container.  This is important as UMIACS runs many multi-tenant hosts (such as Nexus) and doesn't provide administrative control to users on them.  While Docker(The prior text links to https://www.docker.com) is popular, the most typical setups require a daemon that has administrative level privileges that makes it not tenable.
Apptainer was previously branded as Singularity.  You should still be able to run commands on the system with singularity, however you should start migrating to using the apptainer command.

︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Nexus Containers

2.1 Bind Mounts
2.2 Shared Containers


3 Docker Workflow Example


︗Overview
You can find out what the current version is that we provide by running the apptainer --version command.  If this instead says apptainer: command not found and you are using a UMIACS-supported host, please  contact staff and we will ensure that the software is available on the host you are looking for it on.

# apptainer --version
apptainer version 1.2.5-1.el8

Apptainer can run a variety of images including its own format and Docker images(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org/docs/user/main/docker_and_oci.html).  To create images from definition files, you need to have administrative rights. You will need to either use Podman to accomplish this on UMIACS-supported hosts, or alternatively do this on a host that you have full administrative access to (laptop or personal desktop) rather than a UMIACS-supported host.
If you are going to pull large images, you may run out of space in your home directory. We suggest you run the following commands to setup alternate cache and tmp directories.  We are using /scratch0 but you can substitute any large enough local scratch directory, network scratch directory, or project directory you would like.

export WORKDIR=/scratch0/$USER
export APPTAINER_CACHEDIR=${WORKDIR}/.cache
export APPTAINER_TMPDIR=${WORKDIR}/.tmp
mkdir -p $APPTAINER_CACHEDIR
mkdir -p $APPTAINER_TMPDIR


We do suggest you pull images down into an intermediate file (SIF file) as you then do not have to worry about re-caching the image.

$ apptainer pull cuda12.2.2.sif docker://nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8
INFO:    Converting OCI blobs to SIF format
INFO:    Starting build...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob d5d706ce7b29 done
Copying blob b4dc78aeafca done
Copying blob 24a22c1b7260 done
Copying blob 8dea37be3176 done
Copying blob 25fa05cd42bd done
Copying blob a57130ec8de1 done
Copying blob 880a66924cf5 done
Copying config db554d658b done
Writing manifest to image destination
Storing signatures
2022/10/14 10:31:17  info unpack layer: sha256:25fa05cd42bd8fabb25d2a6f3f8c9f7ab34637903d00fd2ed1c1d0fa980427dd
2022/10/14 10:31:19  info unpack layer: sha256:24a22c1b72605a4dbcec13b743ef60a6cbb43185fe46fd8a35941f9af7c11153
2022/10/14 10:31:19  info unpack layer: sha256:8dea37be3176a88fae41c265562d5fb438d9281c356dcb4edeaa51451dbdfdb2
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:b4dc78aeafca6321025300e9d3050c5ba3fb2ac743ae547c6e1efa3f9284ce0b
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:a57130ec8de1e44163e965620d5aed2abe6cddf48b48272964bfd8bca101df38
2022/10/14 10:31:20  info unpack layer: sha256:d5d706ce7b293ffb369d3bf0e3f58f959977903b82eb26433fe58645f79b778b
2022/10/14 10:31:49  info unpack layer: sha256:880a66924cf5e11df601a4f531f3741c6867a3e05238bc9b7cebb2a68d479204
INFO:    Creating SIF file...

$ apptainer inspect cuda12.2.2.sif
...
maintainer: NVIDIA CORPORATION <sw-cuda-installer@nvidia.com>
name: ubi8
org.label-schema.build-arch: amd64
org.label-schema.build-date: Wednesday_24_January_2024_13:53:0_EST
org.label-schema.schema-version: 1.0
org.label-schema.usage.apptainer.version: 1.2.5-1.el8
org.label-schema.usage.singularity.deffile.bootstrap: docker
org.label-schema.usage.singularity.deffile.from: nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8
...

Now you can run the local image with the run command or start a shell with the shell command.  

Please note that if you are in an environment with GPUs and you want to access them inside the container you need to specify the --nv flag. Nvidia has a very specific driver and libraries that are required to run CUDA programs, so this is to ensure that all appropriate devices are created inside the container and that these libraries are made available in the container .
$ apptainer run --nv cuda12.2.2.sif nvidia-smi -L
GPU 0: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti (UUID: GPU-8e040d17-402e-cc86-4e83-eb2b1d501f1e)
GPU 1: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti (UUID: GPU-d681a21a-8cdd-e624-6bf8-5b0234584ba2)

︗Nexus Containers
In our Nexus environment we have some example containers based on our pytorch_docker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker) project.  These can be found in /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch.
You can just run one of the example images by doing the following (you should have already allocated a interactive job with a GPU in Nexus).  It will use the default script(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker/-/blob/master/tensor.py) found at /srv/tensor.py within the image.

$ hostname && nvidia-smi -L
tron38.umiacs.umd.edu
GPU 0: NVIDIA RTX A4000 (UUID: GPU-4a0a5644-9fc8-84b4-5d22-65d45ca36506)

$ apptainer run --nv /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch/pytorch_1.13.0+cu117.sif
99 984.5538940429688
199 654.1710815429688
299 435.662353515625
399 291.1429138183594
499 195.5575714111328
599 132.3363037109375
699 90.5206069946289
799 62.86213684082031
899 44.56754684448242
999 32.466392517089844
1099 24.461835861206055
1199 19.166893005371094
1299 15.6642427444458
1399 13.347112655639648
1499 11.814264297485352
1599 10.800163269042969
1699 10.129261016845703
1799 9.685370445251465
1899 9.391674041748047
1999 9.19735336303711
Result: y = 0.0022362577728927135 + 0.837898313999176 x + -0.0003857926349155605 x^2 + -0.09065020829439163 x^3

︗Bind Mounts
To get data into the container you need to pass some bind mounts(The prior text links to https://apptainer.org/docs/user/main/bind_paths_and_mounts.html).  Apptainer containers will not automatically mount data from the outside operating system other than your home directory.  Users need to manually bind mounts for other file paths.
--bind /fs/nexus-scratch/<USERNAME>/<PROJECTNAME>:/mnt
In this example, we will exec an interactive session with GPUs and binding our Nexus scratch directory which allows us to specify the command we want to run inside the container.

apptainer exec --nv --bind /fs/nexus-scratch/username:/fs/nexus-scratch/username /fs/nexus-containers/pytorch/pytorch_1.13.0+cu117.sif bash

You can now write/run your own pytorch python code interactively within the container or just make a python script that you can call directly from the apptainer exec command for batch processing.


︗Shared Containers
Portable images called Singularity Image Format or .sif files can be copied and shared.  Nexus maintains some shared containers in /fs/nexus-containers.  These are arranged by the application(s) that are installed.

︗Docker Workflow Example
We have a pytorch_docker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker) example workflow using our GitLab as a Docker registry.  You can clone the repository and further customize this to your needs. The workflow is:

Run Docker on a laptop or personal desktop on to create the image, or use Podman on a UMIACS-supported system.
Tag the image and and push it to your repository (this can be any docker registry)
Pull the image down onto one of our workstations/clusters and run it with your data.
$ apptainer pull pytorch_docker.sif docker://registry.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/pytorch_docker
INFO:    Converting OCI blobs to SIF format
INFO:    Starting build...
Getting image source signatures
Copying blob 85386706b020 done
...
2022/10/14 10:58:36  info unpack layer: sha256:b6f46848806c8750a68edc4463bf146ed6c3c4af18f5d3f23281dcdfb1c65055
2022/10/14 10:58:43  info unpack layer: sha256:44845dc671f759820baac0376198141ca683f554bb16a177a3cfe262c9e368ff
INFO:    Creating SIF file...

$ apptainer exec --nv pytorch_docker.sif python3 -c 'from __future__ import print_function; import torch; print(torch.cuda.current_device()); x = torch.rand(5, 3); print(x)'
0
tensor([[0.3273, 0.7174, 0.3587],
        [0.2250, 0.3896, 0.4136],
        [0.3626, 0.0383, 0.6274],
        [0.6241, 0.8079, 0.2950],
        [0.0804, 0.9705, 0.0030]])

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Gurobi contains the following information: 






︗Gurobi

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Gurobi Optimizer is a suite of solvers for mathematical programming. It can be accessed through our module tree with the command module add gurobi. More information on our  Modules page
Documentation can be found at https://www.gurobi.com/documentation/(The prior text links to https://www.gurobi.com/documentation/)

︗Error 10009
Gurobi will not work on the Nexus submission nodes since they have a public IP address and will give the error message "Error 10009: Server must be on the same subnet". 
If you encounter this error, try running the command in a SLURM job. If you're still having issues, please contact the HelpDesk.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Gurobi&oldid=11259"

Privacy policy

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WindowsJuniperVPN contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN/Windows

From UMIACS
(Redirected from WindowsJuniperVPN)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Ivanti Connect Secure Client.  Alternatively, you can establish a connection through a web browser(The prior text links to https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu/), but this may fail if you have an outdated version of Ivanti Secure already installed.
NOTE: If your computer has an ARM-based processor, you will need a different installer than the standard Windows one. Please refer to the instructions below.

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client
3 Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client (ARM processors)
4 Checking VPN Status


︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client
Download the client:
Windows 64 bit Pulse Secure Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/f/ff/PulseSecure22.7.3.x64.msi)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up to date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Start the client if it is not already running - it usually starts by default on bootup.
The image shows a Windows operating system interface, specifically the Start Menu. At the top of the menu, the "Best match" section highlights the "Ivanti Secure Access Client," with an associated icon that features a stylized red and white design. Below this, the menu lists other applications, including "Instagram" visualized with its recognizable logo, and "System Information."

Further down, the "Settings" section includes options like "Internet Options," "Printers & scanners," and "Wi-Fi settings," indicating that the user can manage their device’s network and printer settings from this interface. Lastly, the "Search the web" section allows users to conduct internet searches, with links to results for "instagram" and "indeed," suggesting a user-oriented focus on commonly used applications and online resources.

The bottom of the image features a taskbar with icons for the search function, application shortcuts, and system notifications, set against a blurred background that implies the user is interacting with a modern Windows desktop environment. The overall color scheme is a blend of soft blues and grays, typical of the Windows design aesthetic. [Windows] Start the client from the Start Menu.
If the client is already running, double click its icon from the status bar.
The image displays a screenshot of a Windows taskbar, specifically the system tray area at the bottom right corner of the screen. The background is dark, enhancing the visibility of the icons. There are several icons representing different applications and system notifications. 

1. The first icon, featuring a stylized orange Java logo, likely indicates the presence of Java software.
2. Next is a pink soundwave icon, suggesting audio-related features, possibly for voice communication.
3. A gray cloud with a red "X" over it indicates a cloud application, suggesting a connection issue or alert.
4. The fourth icon is a shield combined with a yellow triangle, possibly representing security software with a warning indication.
5. A key icon suggests a password or security management application.
6. A red triangle with an exclamation point highlights a critical alert or notification.
7. The final icons include those for system settings and hardware status, such as volume control and battery information.

The overall aesthetic is clean and modern, consistent with a contemporary Windows interface, and the icons are designed to be intuitive for users familiar with Windows operating systems. [Windows] Double click its status icon to open.
and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.
The image depicts the user interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, designed for establishing secure network connections. The window features a minimalist design with a light gray background. At the top, the title "Ivanti Secure Access Client" is displayed prominently. The main focus of the interface is the "Connections" section, highlighted in a greenish-blue. 

Within this section, the "UMIACS" connection is listed with a checkmark symbol next to it, indicating that it is currently connected. To the right, there is an "Add Connection" button, depicted with a plus (+) symbol, allowing users to create new network connections. 

The bottom of the window features two buttons: "Close" on the right, and a faint status bar with copyright information. Overall, the interface is clean and user-friendly, utilizing a simple layout and soft color palette, enabling users to manage their VPN connections efficiently. [Windows] Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection.
Enter a name for your VPN connection and the server URL 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'
The image displays the user interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, specifically focused on the "Edit Connection" dialog. The window features a clean, minimalist design with a light gray background, emphasizing clarity and usability. At the top, the title "Ivanti Secure Access Client" is visibly printed in a standard font. 

The main portion of the dialog comprises two sections: one for selecting the connection type, allowing users to choose between “Policy Secure (UAC)” and “Connect Secure (VPN),” which is indicated by a dropdown menu. Below this, there are two input fields. The first field is labeled "Name," where the user has entered "UMIACS," likely representing the designated VPN connection name. The second field is marked "Server URL," pre-filled with the address "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating where the connection will be established.

At the bottom of the dialog, three buttons are prominently displayed: “Connect,” “Save,” and “Cancel,” allowing users to apply their choices or exit the dialog. The overall aesthetic is professional, aligning with a contemporary software interface aimed at enhancing user experience in managing VPN connections. [Windows] Enter the name of the VPN server.
Enter your UMIACS credentials and hit connect.
The image features the user interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client designed for connecting to the UMIACS VPN. The interface has a clean, minimalist design with a light gray background. At the top, the Ivanti logo is prominently displayed alongside the title "Connect to: UMIACS." Below the title, there are two input fields: the first field labeled "User Name" is filled with the example username "savory20," while the second field labeled "Password" is empty, indicated by a blank space where the user would input their password.

Below the input fields, there's a checkbox labeled "Save settings," which allows users to opt for storing their login details for future connections. At the bottom of the dialog, two buttons are clearly visible: "Connect" on the left, allowing users to initiate the connection process, and "Cancel" on the right, providing an option to exit the interface without logging in. The overall aesthetic is professional, with straightforward usability, tailored for effective management of VPN credentials and connections. [Windows] Enter UMIACS credentials.
Enter Secondary Password for  MFA. For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box.
The image displays the user interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, designed for connecting to the UMIACS VPN. It features a light gray background that emphasizes usability and clarity. At the top, the Ivanti logo is prominently visible alongside the title "Connect to: UMIACS." Below this title are two input fields: the field labeled "Secondary User Name" contains the example username "savory20," indicating it is a pre-filled entry. Adjacent to it, the "Secondary Password" field is blank, inviting the user to input their password.

Beneath the password input, there is a checkbox labeled "Save settings," which allows users to store their login details for convenience in future sessions. At the bottom of the interface, two buttons—“Connect” on the left and “Cancel” on the right—are clearly articulated, enabling users to either proceed with the connection or exit the interface without action. The overall design is professional and straightforward, aimed at facilitating effective management of VPN credentials for secure connections. [Windows] Enter Secondary Password.
The Pulse VPN multi-factor authentication implementation relies on a secondary authentication source to fulfill the MFA requirement.  As a result, you will be prompted for credentials twice.


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.


I'm ready to assist with your request for detailed image descriptions. Please provide the images you want to describe, and I'll generate the text according to your specifications.

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN.
Please note, 32-bit clients are no longer supported by Ivanti!

︗None
ARM processors cannot natively run x64 or x86 programs without special emulation. However, not all x86 programs run smoothly even with emulation. As such, the best course of action for these sorts of machines is using the version of Pulse Secure that is specifically made for ARM processors.

Download the client:
Windows 64 bit ARM Pulse Secure Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/c/c6/PulseSecure22.7.3.ARM64.msi)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up to date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Follow all post-download steps in the above section.
︗Checking VPN Status
In the bottom right hand corner, in your status bar, you should see an S icon. If there's a green arrow, that means you are connected! If there is nothing, that means you are not.
The image displays a Windows taskbar, focusing on the system tray area located at the bottom right corner of the screen. The background is dark, enhancing the visibility of the various application icons. From left to right, the first icon features a stylized orange Java logo, representing Java software. Next, a pink soundwave icon suggests audio-related functionalities, possibly for voice communication. A gray cloud icon with a red "X" over it indicates a cloud application experiencing a connection issue.

Following this, there's a blue shield icon combined with a yellow triangle, symbolizing security software and a potential warning. Next, a key icon suggests a password or security management tool. A red triangle with an exclamation mark highlights a critical alert. Lastly, icons for system settings and hardware status, including volume control and battery information, are displayed. The overall aesthetic appears clean and modern, consistent with a contemporary Windows interface, ensuring user familiarity and ease of use. The arrangement emphasizes quick access to essential system notifications and application statuses. 
You can hover over this icon and it will show you the status of your connection.
The image displays a close-up of a Windows taskbar, specifically focusing on the system tray area at the bottom right corner of the screen. The background has a dark tone, enhancing the clarity of the various application icons. Prominently in the center is a gray square icon symbolizing the Ivanti Secure Access Client, indicating that the VPN is connected. Additionally, there is a key icon for password management and a red triangle with an exclamation point, indicating critical notifications. The overall aesthetic is clean and modern, consistent with contemporary Windows design, facilitating user navigation and quick access to application status and notifications.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Podman contains the following information: 






︗Podman

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Podman(The prior text links to https://podman.io/) is a daemonless container engine alternative to Docker(The prior text links to https://www.docker.com/).  We don't support Docker in many of our environments as it grants trivial administrative control over the host the Docker daemon runs on.  Podman on the other hand has the ability to run containers in user namespaces.  This means that for every user name space in the kernel you create the processes within it will map to a new uid/gid range.  For example, if you are root in your container, you will not be uid 0 outside the container, but instead you will be uid 4294000000.
We still believe that Apptainer is the best option for running containerized workloads on our clustered based resources.  Podman is a good option for developing the containers to be run via Apptainer or building a deliverable for a funding agency.  Please  contact staff if you would like Podman installed on a workstation or standalone server.  More information on Podman running rootless can be found here(The prior text links to https://github.com/containers/podman/blob/main/docs/tutorials/rootless_tutorial.md).

︗Contents

1 Getting Started

1.1 Storage


2 GPUs
3 Example


︗Getting Started
To get started there are a few things that you need to configure.
First, run the podman command.  If it says command not found or you get an ERRO like the one below about no subuid ranges, and you are on a workstation or standalone (non-cluster) server, please  contact staff with the error and the host that you are using.  We will need to do some steps to setup the host you want ready.

$ podman
ERRO[0000] cannot find mappings for user username: No subuid ranges found for user "username" in /etc/subuid
Error: missing command 'podman COMMAND'
Try 'podman --help' for more information.

︗Storage
Containers are made up of layers for the image and these are stored in the graphroot setting of ~/.config/containers/storage.conf which by default will be in your home directory.  With our home directories being available over NFS there is an issue(The prior text links to https://www.redhat.com/sysadmin/rootless-podman-nfs) that due to the user name space mapping described above you will not be able to access your home directory when you are building the layers.
You need to update the graphroot setting to a local directory on the host.  The file ~/.config/containers/storage.conf may not exist until you run podman the first time, however you can manually create it.

[storage]
  driver = "vfs"
  graphroot = "/scratch0/username/.local/share/containers/storage"
...

When building larger images, it may fill up the default directory for imageCopyTmpDir (/var/tmp). If this happens, you will need to specify a different directory using the environment variable TMPDIR. For example:

export TMPDIR="/scratch0/example_tmp_directory"
︗GPUs
Running Podman with the local Nvidia GPUs requires some additional configuration steps that staff has to add to any individual workstation or standalone (non-cluster) server that runs Podman.  This includes ensuring the nvidia-container-runtime package is installed.
For example you can run nvidia-smi from within the official Nvidia CUDA containers with a command like this, optionally replacing the tag for different CUDA versions/OS images:

$ podman run --rm --hooks-dir=/usr/share/containers/oci/hooks.d docker.io/nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8 nvidia-smi
Thu Apr 16 18:47:04 2020
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| NVIDIA-SMI 535.129.03             Driver Version: 535.129.03   CUDA Version: 12.2     |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| GPU  Name                 Persistence-M | Bus-Id        Disp.A | Volatile Uncorr. ECC |
| Fan  Temp   Perf          Pwr:Usage/Cap |         Memory-Usage | GPU-Util  Compute M. |
|                                         |                      |               MIG M. |
|=========================================+======================+======================|
|   0  NVIDIA RTX A6000               Off | 00000000:01:00.0 Off |                  Off |
| 30%   28C    P8               6W / 300W |      2MiB / 49140MiB |      0%      Default |
|                                         |                      |                  N/A |
+-----------------------------------------+----------------------+----------------------+

+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Processes:                                                                            |
|  GPU   GI   CI        PID   Type   Process name                            GPU Memory |
|        ID   ID                                                             Usage      |
|=======================================================================================|
|  No running processes found                                                           |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

The full list of tags can be found at https://hub.docker.com/r/nvidia/cuda/tags(The prior text links to https://hub.docker.com/r/nvidia/cuda/tags).

︗Example
To build your own image you can start from an example we have https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker).
First clone the repository, change directory and build the image with podman.

git clone https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker.git
cd gpudocker
podman build -t gpudocker .

Then you can run the test script to verify.  Notice that we pass the local directory test as a path into the image so we can run a script.  This can also be useful for your data output data as well as if you write anywhere else in the container it will not be available outside the container.

$ podman run --volume `pwd`/test:/mnt --hooks-dir=/usr/share/containers/oci/hooks.d gpudocker python3 /mnt/test_torch.py
GPU found 0: GeForce GTX 1080 Ti
tensor([[0.3479, 0.6594, 0.5791],
        [0.6065, 0.3415, 0.9328],
        [0.9117, 0.3541, 0.9050],
        [0.6611, 0.5361, 0.3212],
        [0.8574, 0.5116, 0.7021]])

If you instead want to push modifications to this example to your own container registry such that you can pull the container image down later, please see the README.md located in the example repository itself.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Snapshots:Example contains the following information: 






︗Snapshots:Example

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Note that in this example, the directory .snapshot could also be .zfs/snapshot depending on the filer serving your host. You can try to ls -l one and if it doesn't exist, try the other.


For this example, the user is logged into host with the username username, and a virtual environment directory named virtualenv exists in the home directory.

username@host:~/virtualenv$ pwd
/nfshomes/username/virtualenv

A Python file named virtualenv.py exists in the directory.

username@host:~/virtualenv$ ls
appveyor.yml      docs         scripts    tox.ini
AUTHORS.txt       LICENSE.txt  setup.cfg  virtualenv_embedded
bin               MANIFEST.in  setup.py   virtualenv.py
CONTRIBUTING.rst  README.rst   tests      virtualenv_support

username@host:~/virtualenv$ ls -lah virtualenv.py
-rwxrwxr-x. 1 username username 98K Jun 12 13:54 virtualenv.py

Remove it from the current working directory.

username@host:~/virtualenv$ rm virtualenv.py

Verify that the file is removed.

username@host:~/virtualenv$ ls
appveyor.yml  CONTRIBUTING.rst  MANIFEST.in  setup.cfg  tox.ini
AUTHORS.txt   docs              README.rst   setup.py   virtualenv_embedded
bin           LICENSE.txt       scripts      tests      virtualenv_support

Change directory into the most recent weekly snapshot.  In this case, it's Weekly_nfshomes_2024-06-23_00:00.

username@host:~/virtualenv$ ls /nfshomes/username/.snapshot
nfshomes_2024-06-25_00:00  nfshomes_2024-06-27_04:00
nfshomes_2024-06-26_00:00  nfshomes_2024-06-27_08:00
nfshomes_2024-06-26_12:00  nfshomes_2024-06-27_12:00
nfshomes_2024-06-26_16:00  Weekly_nfshomes_2024-06-16_00:00
nfshomes_2024-06-26_20:00  Weekly_nfshomes_2024-06-23_00:00
nfshomes_2024-06-27_00:00

username@host:~/virtualenv$ cd /nfshomes/username/.snapshot/Weekly_nfshomes_2024-06-23_00\:00/virtualenv

The file still exists in the snapshot.

username@host:~/.snapshot/Weekly_nfshomes_2024-06-23_00:00/virtualenv$ ls
appveyor.yml      docs         scripts    tox.ini
AUTHORS.txt       LICENSE.txt  setup.cfg  virtualenv_embedded
bin               MANIFEST.in  setup.py   virtualenv.py
CONTRIBUTING.rst  README.rst   tests      virtualenv_support

Copy the file back to the original directory.

username@host:~/.snapshot/Weekly_nfshomes_2024-06-23_00:00/virtualenv$ cp virtualenv.py /nfshomes/username/virtualenv/

Change back to the original directory.

username@host:~/.snapshot/Weekly_nfshomes_2024-06-23_00:00/virtualenv$ cd /nfshomes/username/virtualenv/

Confirm that the file is restored from the snapshot.

username@host:~/virtualenv$ ls
appveyor.yml      docs         scripts    tox.ini
AUTHORS.txt       LICENSE.txt  setup.cfg  virtualenv_embedded
bin               MANIFEST.in  setup.py   virtualenv.py
CONTRIBUTING.rst  README.rst   tests      virtualenv_support





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Snapshots:Example&oldid=12026"
Category: Snapshots

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/VPN contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN

From UMIACS
(Redirected from VPN)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search


Please provide the images you would like to have described, and I'll create detailed textual descriptions for each one.

As of August 14th 2022, Pulse Secure Client has been rebranded as Ivanti Secure Access Client. Please follow this link for more information on this - Ivanti Secure Access Client.


A virtual private network (VPN) extends a private network across a public network, and enables users to send and receive data across shared or public networks as if their computing devices were directly connected to the private network. UMIACS currently provides VPN access through a Ivanti Connect Secure(The prior text links to https://www.ivanti.com/products/connect-secure-vpn) SSL VPN to all users except  class accounts.
Please note that enrollment in our MFA is mandatory to connect using the UMIACS VPN. Enrollment steps can be found  here.

︗Contents

1 Getting Connected

1.1 Client Setup
1.2 VPN Troubleshooting
1.3 Multi-Factor Authentication




︗Getting Connected
Once connected to the VPN you can use the  Remote Desktop client to access a Windows machine, as well as access a number of other non-public UMIACS resources.

︗Client Setup
Operating Systems:
Configuring a Windows VPN Connection
Configuring a macOS VPN Connection
Configuring a Linux VPN Connection
Mobile Devices:
 Configuring a Mobile (iOS/Android) device
︗VPN Troubleshooting
Troubleshoot common VPN issues
︗Multi-Factor Authentication
 Configuring Multi-Factor authentication

Privacy policy
About UMIACS
Disclaimers


(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Umask contains the following information: 






︗Umask

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
umask(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umask) is the way the UNIX operating system determines what default permissions that files and directories are created with.
With no umask files are created with permissions 666 or 110110110 in binary, and directories are created with permissions 777 or 111111111 in binary.  The umask is represented similarly as three digits, each representing a 3 bits. For each bit that is set to 1 in the umask the corresponding bit of any files or directories that are created is set to 0. In binary operations it is equivelent to bitwise negating the umask and then doing a bitwise and on that negation and the default for the object being created. 
The three popular umasks are 022, 002 and 007.

︗Contents

1 umask 022
2 umask 002
3 umask 007
4 umask 000
5 Setting umask


︗umask 022
This as the example shows above that you will get full rwx for the user, r-x for the group and r-x for other.  This is the default in almost all of our operating systems.

        777  111 111 111
  umask 022  000 010 010   
      = 755  111 101 101

︗umask 002
This would give full rwx for the user, full rwx for the group and give only r-x for other.  This is helpful when you want your default group (or a SetGID directory) to have full control over the files and directories you create while allowing everyone else read and execute permissions.

        777  111 111 111
  umask 002  000 000 010   
      = 775  111 111 101

︗umask 007
This will give the user and group full rwx permissions and give other no permissions.

        777  111 111 111
  umask 007  000 000 111   
      = 770  111 111 000

︗umask 000
Please never use this umask as it will give full control to user, group and other.   In other words it makes the directory or file world read, write and executable and can be a large security risk to you and your colleagues.


︗Setting umask
Your umask is tied to your current shell and can be set with the shell builtin command umask. If issued without an argument the umask will return the current umask, occasionally omitting any leading zeros. To set a umask issue the umask command with umask you want to use.

[gnorts:~] username% umask 
022
[gnorts:~] username% umask 002
[gnorts:~] username% umask
002


However most of the time, you find yourself in a work environment where the same umask is what you want to use all the time, and you don't want to have to think about it. In that you case you want to set your umask in your shell initialization file. For bash the initialization file is .profile or .bash_profile and for tcsh the initialization files is .cshrc or .tcshrc. These files behave mostly like scripts and the umask command can be entered without any additional syntax as seen in the example bellow:

 [username@nexuscfar01 ~]$ cat .cshrc 
 setenv EDITOR vim
 umask 002

Or for example if you use Bash you can run this command.

 echo 'umask 002' >> ~/.bash_profile





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Umask&oldid=11013"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/ClassAccounts contains the following information: 






︗ClassAccounts

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Getting an account

2.1 Registering for Duo


3 Cleaning up your account before the end of the semester
4 Personal Storage
5 Group Storage
6 Cluster Usage

6.1 Example
6.2 Available Nodes




︗Overview
UMIACS Class Accounts support classes for all of UMIACS/CSD via the Nexus cluster.  Faculty may request that a class be supported by following the instructions  here.

︗Getting an account
Your TA or instructor will request an account for you. Once this is done, you will be notified by email that you have an account to redeem.  If you have not received an email, please contact your TA or instructor. You must redeem the account within 7 days or else the redemption token will expire.  If your redemption token does expire, please contact your TA or instructor to have it renewed.
Once you do redeem your account, you will need to wait until you get a confirmation email that your account has been installed.  This is typically done once a day on days that the University is open for business.
Any questions or issues with your account, storage, or cluster use must first be made through your TA or instructor.

︗Registering for Duo
UMIACS requires that all Class accounts register for MFA (multi-factor authentication) under our Duo instance (note that this is different than UMD's general Duo instance). You will not be able to log onto the class submission host until you register.
If you see the following error in your SSH client, you have not yet enrolled/registered in Duo.

Access is not allowed because you are not enrolled in Duo. Please contact your organization's IT help desk.

In order to register, visit our directory app(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory) and log in with your Class username and password. You will then receive a prompt to enroll in Duo. For assistance in enrollment, please visit our  Duo help page.
Once notified that your account has been installed and you have registered in our Duo instance, you can SSH to nexusclass.umiacs.umd.edu with your assigned username and your chosen password to log in to a submission host.
If you store something in a local directory (/tmp, /scratch0) on one of the two submission hosts, you will need to connect to that same submission host to access it later. The actual submission hosts are:

nexusclass00.umiacs.umd.edu
nexusclass01.umiacs.umd.edu
︗Cleaning up your account before the end of the semester
Class accounts for a given semester are liable to be archived and deleted after that semester's completion as early as the following:

Winter semesters: February 1st of same year
Spring semesters: June 1st of same year
Summer semesters: September 1st of same year
Fall semesters: January 1st of next year
It is your responsibility to ensure you have backed up anything you want to keep from your class account's personal or group storage (below sections) prior to the relevant date.

︗Personal Storage
Your home directory has a quota of 30GB and is located at:

/fs/classhomes/<semester><year>/<coursecode>/<username>

where <semester> is either "spring", "summer", "fall", or "winter", <year> is the current year e.g., "2021",  <coursecode> is the class' course code as listed in UMD's Schedule of Classes(The prior text links to https://app.testudo.umd.edu/soc/) in all lowercase e.g., "cmsc999z", and <username> is the username mentioned in the email you received to redeem the account e.g., "c999z000".
You can request up to another 100GB of personal storage if you would like by having your TA or instructor  contact staff. This storage will be located at

/fs/class-projects/<semester><year>/<coursecode>/<username>

︗Group Storage
You can also request group storage by having your TA or instructor  contact staff to specify the usernames of the accounts that should be in the group. Only other class accounts in the same class can be added to the group. The quota will be 100GB multiplied by the number of accounts in the group and will be located at

/fs/class-projects/<semester><year>/<coursecode>/<groupname>

where <groupname> is composed of:

the abbreviated course code as used in the username e.g., "c999z"
the character "g"
the number of the group (starting at 0 for the first group for the class requested to us) prepended with 0s to make the total group name 8 characters long
e.g., "c999zg00".

︗Cluster Usage
You may not run computational jobs on any submission host.  You must  schedule your jobs with the SLURM workload manager.  You can also find out more with the public documentation for the SLURM Workload Manager(The prior text links to https://slurm.schedmd.com/quickstart.html).
Class accounts only have access to the following submission parameters in SLURM:

--partition - class
--account - class
--qos - default, medium, and high
You must specify at least the partition parameter manually in any submission command you run. If you do not specify any QoS parameter, you will receive the QoS default.
You can view the resource limits for each QoS by running the command show_qos. The value in the MaxWall column is the maximum runtime you can run a single job for each QoS, and the values in the MaxTRES column are the maximum amount of CPU cores/GPUs/memory you can request for a single job using each QoS.
Please note that you will be restricted to 32 total CPU cores, 4 total GPUs, and 256GB total RAM across all jobs you have running at once. This can be viewed with the command show_partition_qos.

︗Example
Here is a basic example to schedule a interactive job running bash with a single GPU in the partition class, with the account class, running with the QoS of default and the default CPU/memory allocation/time limit for the partition.

bash-4.4$ hostname
nexusclass00.umiacs.umd.edu

bash-4.4$ srun --partition=class --account=class --qos=default --gres=gpu:1 --pty bash
srun: Job time limit was unset; set to partition default of 60 minutes
srun: job 1333337 queued and waiting for resources
srun: job 1333337 has been allocated resources

bash-4.4$ hostname
tron14.umiacs.umd.edu

bash-4.4$ nvidia-smi -L
GPU 0: NVIDIA RTX A4000 (UUID: GPU-55f2d3b7-9162-8b02-50de-476a012c626c)

︗Available Nodes
You can list the available nodes and their current state with the show_nodes -p class command.  This list of nodes is not completely static as nodes may be pulled out of service to repair/replace GPUs or other components.

$ show_nodes -p class
NODELIST             CPUS       MEMORY     AVAIL_FEATURES                   GRES                             STATE
tron06               16         128520     rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302P,Ampere      gpu:rtxa4000:4                   idle
tron07               16         128520     rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302P,Ampere      gpu:rtxa4000:4                   idle
tron08               16         128520     rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302P,Ampere      gpu:rtxa4000:4                   idle

tron10               16         128524     rhel8,Zen,EPYC-7313P,Ampere      gpu:rtxa4000:4                   idle
tron11               16         128524     rhel8,Zen,EPYC-7313P,Ampere      gpu:rtxa4000:4                   idle
tron12               16         128525     rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302P,Ampere      gpu:rtxa4000:4                   idle
tron13               16         128520     rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302P,Ampere      gpu:rtxa4000:4                   idle

You can also find more granular information about an individual node with the scontrol show node command.

$ scontrol show node tron06
NodeName=tron06 Arch=x86_64 CoresPerSocket=16
   CPUAlloc=0 CPUEfctv=16 CPUTot=16 CPULoad=0.08
   AvailableFeatures=rhel8,Zen,EPYC-7302P,Ampere
   ActiveFeatures=rhel8,Zen,EPYC-7302P,Ampere
   Gres=gpu:rtxa4000:4
   NodeAddr=tron06 NodeHostName=tron06 Version=23.02.6
   OS=Linux 4.18.0-513.11.1.el8_9.x86_64 #1 SMP Thu Dec 7 03:06:13 EST 2023
   RealMemory=126214 AllocMem=0 FreeMem=107174 Sockets=1 Boards=1
   State=IDLE ThreadsPerCore=1 TmpDisk=0 Weight=340 Owner=N/A MCS_label=N/A
   Partitions=class,scavenger,tron
   BootTime=2024-01-29T09:35:12 SlurmdStartTime=2024-02-05T15:14:20
   LastBusyTime=2024-02-16T15:59:38 ResumeAfterTime=None
   CfgTRES=cpu=16,mem=126214M,billing=638,gres/gpu=4,gres/gpu:rtxa4000=4
   AllocTRES=
   CapWatts=n/a
   CurrentWatts=0 AveWatts=0
   ExtSensorsJoules=n/s ExtSensorsWatts=0 ExtSensorsTemp=n/s

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SearchingQuarantine contains the following information: 






︗BarracudaSpamFirewall/SearchingQuarantine

From UMIACS
(Redirected from SearchingQuarantine)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
To visit your spam quarantine, log in to the system using any of our firewalls using your UMIACS email address (username@umiacs.umd.edu) and password:
bubs.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://bubs.umiacs.umd.edu)
pompom.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://pompom.umiacs.umd.edu)
From this you will see a drop-down box that says "select filter" (see picture below)
The image displays a user interface for the Barracuda Email Security Gateway, specifically focusing on the "Quarantine Inbox" section. At the top, there are tabs labeled "Quarantine Inbox" and "Preferences," with a prominent "Sign out" option in the upper right corner. Below these tabs, a dropdown menu is visible, labeled "Subject" with an adjacent button that reads "Apply Filter." This allows users to specify search criteria for quarantined emails.

A gray banner indicates a warning: "Messages older than 21 days will be removed," suggesting a time limit for emails in quarantine. The main section lists quarantined messages in a table format. Rows display several columns like "Time Received," "From," "Subject," and "Actions." The "From" column shows email addresses, while many "Subject" entries are obscured by black bars, likely indicating sensitive information. In the "Actions" column, buttons for “Deliver,” “Whitelist,” and “Delete” allow users to manage the emails. The visual layout features a clean design with a blue and gray color scheme, promoting ease of navigation while managing quarantined messages.
There are three different filters, "from", "subject", and "message". "From" will allow you to search the emails based on who sent them. "Subject" will allow you to search based on the subject of emails. Message will allow you to search in the body of the email. To the right of the filter, you can either select "contains" or "doesn't contain". This will tell the filter to check if something contains the text you search for or doesn't contain the text you search for. For example if your filter is "subject" and you select "contains" and search for "binary" this will be the result.
The image depicts a user interface for the Barracuda Email Security Gateway, specifically the "Quarantine Inbox" section. At the top are navigation tabs labeled "Quarantine Inbox" and "Preferences," with a prominent "Sign out" link in the upper right corner. Below these tabs, there is a filtering dropdown labeled "Subject," accompanied by options that allow users to specify conditions such as "contains" or "doesn't contain." Next to this is an "Apply Filter" button.

A gray warning banner above the email listings alerts users that "Messages older than 21 days will be removed," emphasizing a retention policy for quarantined emails. The main area of the interface showcases a table with columns titled "Time Received," "From," "Subject," and "Actions." Each row represents a quarantined email, with the "From" column displaying the sender's email address and the "Subject" column obscured by black bars, likely to protect sensitive information. The “Actions” column features buttons labeled “Deliver,” “Whitelist,” and “Delete,” allowing users to manage their quarantined messages more effectively. The color scheme is primarily blue and gray, contributing to a clean, professional appearance.
If your filter is "subject" and you select "doesn't contain" "binary", all of the emails that don't have "binary" in the subject will be shown.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BarracudaSpamFirewall/SearchingQuarantine&oldid=10124"
