︗InputMethodEditors

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Input method editors or IMEs make it easier to type in languages (usually but not limited to East Asian ones) that are made up of thousands of characters that can't fit on a standard keyboard

︗Adding an IME
IMEs are a per user setting and can be added/removed/customized without any need for administrative privileges. To add an IME to your account please follow these instructions.

Click the Windows button and open the control panel. The image displays a Windows operating system interface, specifically the Start menu against a bright blue desktop background. It captures a portion of the Taskbar with various icons visible, including applications like "VLC media player," "Sticky Notes," and "Snipping Tool," indicating common programs that users might access quickly. 

Prominently featured in the menu is the "Control Panel," which is highlighted with a red circle, emphasizing its importance in navigating system settings. The tooltip under "Control Panel" reads "Change settings and customize the functionality of your computer," providing context for its function. A grey box labeled "Identity Finder Password Vault" is positioned above, hinting that it is a software tool related to password management.

The bottom of the Start menu shows options to access all programs, with a button to log off the current user. Overall, this image gives a clear view of how users can access and utilize the Control Panel for system customization on a Windows computer.
Click "Clock, Language, and Region". The image depicts a section of the Windows Control Panel, specifically highlighting an area titled “Clock, Language, and Region.” This section features several identifiable icons within a predominantly light blue interface. The icon associated with "Clock" resembles a traditional clock face with a green border, while the "Language and Region" part is indicated by a globe, suggesting international settings. Underneath this heading, there is a sub-option “Change display language,” which signifies functionality related to language settings for the operating system.

Adjacent to this, there is another section titled “Ease of Access,” identified by a circular icon that looks like a network of interconnected dots. The tooltip accompanying "Clock, Language, and Region" provides a concise description of its purpose, indicating that it allows users to change the date, time, time zone, language settings, and formats for numbers, currencies, and dates. The background displays a classic Windows desktop aesthetic, characterized by a deep blue hue, which reinforces the familiar operating environment. Overall, the image conveys essential information regarding navigating language and regional settings within a Windows operating system.
Click "Change keyboards or other input methods". The image displays a part of the Windows Control Panel, specifically the section labeled "Clock, Language, and Region." It showcases a light blue interface with identifiable icons and text options. At the top, under the “Date and Time” category, users can set and adjust the system clock or time zone, along with options for adding clocks for diverse time zones. Below this, the "Region and Language" section is highlighted prominently, featuring a green-colored globe icon that suggests international settings.

Within this section, user-friendly text describes various options available to manage language settings. The option “Change keyboards or other input methods” is central, circled in red to draw attention, indicating its relevance for users looking to modify input methods. Nearby, additional options are provided for installing display languages and changing formats for dates and currencies.

The background is a standard deep blue typical of Windows desktops, reinforcing the context of a familiar user interface. Overall, the image effectively communicates essential steps for navigating the language and input settings in the Windows operating system.
On the dialogue box that appears, click the "Change Keyboards" button. The image shows a section of the Windows Control Panel, specifically under the "Region and Language" settings. The interface is predominantly light blue, characteristic of standard Windows themes. Central to the image is a prominent white box containing the heading "Keyboards and other input languages." 

Within this box, the option "Change keyboards..." is clearly highlighted in red, drawing immediate attention to its functionality, which allows users to modify their keyboard settings for different languages. The text above instructs users on how to change their keyboard or input language, providing a brief guide to navigate through these settings. 

The layout is clean, with additional potential options subtly listed, yet they are less emphasized than the "Change keyboards..." button. The top part of the interface features tabs labeled "Formats," "Location," "Keyboards and Languages," and "Administrative," indicating a multi-faceted menu structure. The surrounding background is slightly blurred, suggesting an active desktop environment, reinforcing the functionality of this Control Panel section. Overall, the image conveys essential guidance for users seeking to adjust their keyboard language settings in Windows.
A new dialogue box will open with a list of your currently installed input methods (aka keyboards), on this dialogue box click the "Add" button to add a new input method. The image depicts a dialogue box from the Windows operating system, specifically focusing on language inputs. The interface is organized and features a light blue background typical of Windows themes. On the left side, the language “English (United States)” is outlined, with subcategories for “Keyboard” and “Other,” indicating the different input services available for this language. Directly under "English," the "US" keyboard and "Ink Correction (64Bit Only)" are listed, showing the current input methods available.

Prominently featured on the right side of the dialogue box is a blue button labeled “Add…” which is circled in red for emphasis, drawing the user's attention to the action it represents. This button signifies the option to add additional input languages or keyboards, which is crucial for user customization of language settings. 

The layout is intuitive, with clear labeling, and includes minimal additional options at the bottom, such as “Remove” and “Properties,” to manage existing languages. Overall, the image effectively communicates how users can customize their language input in Windows.
Another dialogue box will open with a list of languages, scroll through these until you find the language you want to add and click the "+" to expand the list, then expand the keyboard subtree to see a list of IMEs for that language. Check any of the IMEs that you want to enable and then click the "Ok" button. The image depicts a Windows dialogue box labeled "Add Input Language." The interface features a light blue background, consistent with typical Windows themes. At the top, there is a clear instruction, "Select the language to add using the checkboxes below," indicating the task for the user. 

On the left side, languages such as "Catalan" and "Chinese (Simplified, PRC)" are listed with checkboxes next to them. The "Keyboard" option opens a drop-down tree under the "Chinese (Simplified)" header, revealing several input methods, including "Microsoft Pinyin AB," "US Keyboard," and various versions of QuanPin and ZhengMa, each accompanied by checkboxes.

The interface prominently highlights the "Chinese (Simplified) - Microsoft Pinyin AB" option, making it the focal point. To the right, there are buttons marked "OK," "Cancel," and "Preview," with "OK" encircled in red to catch the user's attention. This setup indicates that clicking "OK" will confirm the selected language input. Overall, the image effectively communicates the process of adding input languages within the Windows operating system.
The dialogue box should have closed and you will now see your changes displayed in the list of active IMEs. Click "Apply" to close the dialogue box and apply your changes. The image depicts a Windows dialogue box related to language input settings. The interface has a light blue background, typical of Windows, and features a clear title "Installed services," indicating available input languages. On the left side, "English (United States)" is displayed with its subcategories: "Keyboard" and "Other," showing the "US" keyboard and an "Ink Correction" option marked as "64Bit Only." Below this, "Chinese (Simplified, PRC)" is listed, highlighting the "Chinese (Simplified) - Microsoft Pinyin AE" input method under the "Keyboard" subtree.

Prominently positioned within the dialogue are action buttons, with the "Add..." button in blue and an "Apply" button encircled in red, drawing immediate attention. Below, options for "Remove" and "Properties" are also visible. The layout is intuitively organized, allowing users to easily manage their input languages. This image effectively communicates the process for customizing input settings in the Windows operating system, reinforcing user interaction with the system's language configurations. Overall, it captures both the functionality and user-friendly nature of the language input settings.
The new IME should now be setup. If this is the first time you've added an IME a new icon should appear in the bottom right corner of your screen near the taskbar that allows you to switch between IMEs and configure them. The image shows the Windows taskbar, specifically the language input menu. At the bottom left, a blue icon represents the current input language, labeled "EN" for English (United States). This icon is encircled in red, drawing attention to its significance. Directly above this, a dropdown menu displays the active input methods. The highlighted option is "Chinese (Simplified, PRC)," indicated by "CH," also circled in red for emphasis. The menu includes the option to "Show the Language bar," suggesting further settings related to language inputs. The time displayed on the right side reads 2:27 PM, dated 5/14/2015, providing context for when this setup was captured. The interface maintains a classic Windows aesthetic, showcasing a clear and intuitive design that allows users to easily switch between input languages. Overall, the image exemplifies the accessibility of language settings within the Windows environment, particularly for users who frequently switch between different languages and input methods.
To configure an IME or access the help pages about it to learn how to use it, click the Options Menu icon on the right side of the language bar. The image displays a portion of the Windows taskbar, showcasing the input method editor (IME) options. In the bottom left corner, a blue icon labeled "CH," representing Chinese (Simplified), is highlighted within a red circle, indicating that it is the currently active input language. Above this icon, a dropdown menu is visible, featuring several options related to the IME. The "Help" option is prominently circled in red for emphasis, suggesting that users can access assistance regarding the IME features. Other options include "Options..." for configuration, "Soft Keyboard," "User-defined Phrase Tool," and "Secondary Inputs," all indicating functionality to enhance language input. The timestamp in the bottom right, showing 2:49 PM on 5/14/2015, provides context for when the screenshot was taken. The overall layout maintains a classic Windows aesthetic, demonstrating an intuitive design for users to easily navigate language settings and seek help. This image effectively illustrates the accessibility and feature-rich environment of the IME within the Windows operating system.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/EnvironmentalVariables contains the following information: 






︗EnvironmentalVariables

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
In UNIX and Windows many of the commands run have variables that are parsed from a user's environment.

︗None
The most common variable is the PATH variable, which will add additional paths to search for programs to be run from the command line. These can be set in many ways but we will cover the most popular: tcsh and bash. You can see your PATH variable by using the built-in echo command in the shell.  When printing out environment variables you will need to prefix the variable with the $ sign.

$ echo $PATH
/usr/kerberos/bin:/usr/local/bin:/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/X11R6/bin

In almost all cases you will want to append to either the beginning or end of your PATH variable and not replace it fully as this will most likely decrease the functionality of your shell.  For example, if you wanted to add the path /opt/UMtorque/bin to the end of your PATH then you could do the following,

tcsh/csh
setenv PATH ${PATH}:/opt/UMtorque/bin
bash/sh
export PATH=${PATH}:/opt/UMtorque/bin
These can be either typed into your shell directly or added to your shell's initialization files so every time you spawn a shell it will get this new PATH.

︗None
To modify the Windows PATH Environmental Variable do the following: 

Go to Control Panel and click on User Accounts. Then click on the User Accounts heading within User Accounts.
On the left pane, click Change my environment variables.
Under User Variables for <username> choose the PATH variable.
If there is none, click New and put PATH for the Variable name.
Click Edit and append the location you are trying to add. Different paths are separated by semicolons.
To verify that the PATH variable has been modified properly do the following:

Open a new Command Prompt (Start -> Accessories -> Command Prompt).
Type in PATH.
The updated PATH should be printed.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=EnvironmentalVariables&oldid=10331"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Lamsub.sh contains the following information: 






︗Lamsub.sh

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
#!/bin/bash

#PBS -lwalltime=0:10:0
#PBS -lnodes=8

# Set up the path
export PATH=/usr/local/stow/lam-7.1.4/bin:$PATH

echo starting
/usr/local/stow/lam-7.1.4/bin/mpiexec -machinefile ${PBS_NODEFILE} /nfshomes/xhe/torquejobs/lamtest/alltoall-lam 
echo ending





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Lamsub.sh&oldid=2739"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/VPN/Windows contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN/Windows

From UMIACS
(Redirected from VPN/Windows)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Ivanti Connect Secure Client.  Alternatively, you can establish a connection through a web browser(The prior text links to https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu/), but this may fail if you have an outdated version of Ivanti Secure already installed.
NOTE: If your computer has an ARM-based processor, you will need a different installer than the standard Windows one. Please refer to the instructions below.

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client
3 Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client (ARM processors)
4 Checking VPN Status


︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client
Download the client:
Windows 64 bit Pulse Secure Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/f/ff/PulseSecure22.7.3.x64.msi)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up to date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Start the client if it is not already running - it usually starts by default on bootup.
The image shows a Windows Start Menu interface displayed on a desktop screen. The menu is divided into two main sections: an application section and a settings section. In the upper part, the "Best match" search result highlights the "Ivanti Secure Access Client" application, indicated by an icon featuring a red and white design. Below that, several apps are listed, including prominent icons for "Instagram" and "System Information." 

In the "Settings" section, options such as "Internet Options," "Printers & scanners," and "Wi-Fi settings" are visible, each representing standard Windows functionalities. The lower portion of the menu includes a search bar labeled "Search the web," where users can input queries, with suggested search terms shown, such as "i - See web results," "instagram," and "indeed." The overall color scheme is a blend of dark blues and blacks, typical of modern Windows themes, with white text providing clarity. The menu is designed for user-friendliness, allowing quick navigation through applications and settings. [Windows] Start the client from the Start Menu.
If the client is already running, double click its icon from the status bar.
The image depicts a Windows taskbar notification area, commonly known as the system tray, located at the bottom right of the screen. The background of this area is a dark color, likely black or dark gray, which enhances the visibility of the icons. 

In the notification area, several application icons are arranged neatly. Notable icons include a Java coffee cup, indicated by an orange square, a sound or microphone symbol represented by a pink waveform, a red X in a cloud icon suggesting a connectivity issue, a blue shield symbol for security, a yellow warning triangle denoting a potential issue, a key icon for security or access, and a presentation-style icon that could represent an app like PowerPoint. 

These icons hint at various functionalities and statuses of running applications on the system. The overall design is clean and minimalistic, adhering to modern UI principles, allowing users to quickly identify app statuses or notifications. Each icon serves to streamline the management of active applications and system functions for the user. [Windows] Double click its status icon to open.
and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.
The image displays the interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, which is used for establishing VPN connections. The window is framed in a light gray color with rounded edges, presenting a simple and user-friendly layout. At the top of the window, there are menu options labeled "File" and "Help." Below this, the primary section titled "Connections" prominently features the UMIACS connection, highlighted in a visually distinct manner with a green checkmark indicating that it is currently connected.

To the right of the connection listing, there are buttons including a “+” symbol for adding a new connection, and an "Add Connection" text link, both in green, suggesting an active and positive action. The background of the connection area is light gray, providing contrast to the blue highlight of the UMIACS connection. The lower part of the interface contains a "Close" button, also in gray, allowing users to exit the application.

Overall, this interface effectively communicates the status of the VPN connection, guiding users in managing their secure connections efficiently. [Windows] Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection.
Enter a name for your VPN connection and the server URL 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'
The image displays an interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, specifically in the "Edit Connection" mode. This window has a light gray background with a slightly rounded rectangular shape, contributing to a modern aesthetic. At the top left, there are options labeled "File" and "Help," indicating standard menu functionality typically found in desktop applications.

In the central part of the window, there are fields for user input. The first section asks for the "Type" of connection, represented by a dropdown menu that includes options like "Policy Secure (UAC)" or "Connect Secure (VPN)." Below that is the "Name" input box, prefilled with the text "UMIACS," allowing users to designate a label for their VPN connection.

The "Server URL" field is displayed directly beneath, where users are instructed to enter the VPN endpoint as "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu." At the bottom, three buttons are visible: "Connect," "Save," and "Cancel," with "Connect" and "Save" highlighted for user action. Lastly, there is a "Close" button on the bottom right to exit the window. The overall layout is user-friendly, guiding users to establish a secure connection efficiently. [Windows] Enter the name of the VPN server.
Enter your UMIACS credentials and hit connect.
The image displays the login interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, designed for connecting to the UMIACS VPN. The window has a light gray background with rounded corners, creating a modern aesthetic. At the top, the Ivanti logo stands out in red against the gray, signifying the application's identity. Centrally, there are two input fields labeled "User Name" and "Password." The "User Name" field is pre-filled with "savory20," while the "Password" field is blank, indicating that the user should enter their password here. Below the password input, there is a checkbox labeled "Save settings," which allows users to opt for future sessions to remember their login details, enhancing convenience.

At the bottom right, two buttons are visible: "Connect," which is highlighted to encourage action, and "Cancel," allowing users to abort the login process. The overall interface is user-friendly and straightforward, designed to facilitate easy access to the VPN service while maintaining security. The clean design and logical layout assist users in quickly entering their credentials for a smooth connection process. [Windows] Enter UMIACS credentials.
Enter Secondary Password for  MFA. For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box.
The image displays the login interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client designed for connecting to the UMIACS VPN. The background is light gray with rounded corners, creating a sleek, modern appearance. At the top left, the Ivanti logo is prominently displayed in red, branding the application. Centrally located are two input fields: the first labeled "Secondary User Name," which is pre-filled with "savory20," and the second labeled "Secondary Password," left blank for user input. Below these fields is a checkbox labeled "Save settings," allowing users to opt-in for future sessions to remember their login details. 

At the bottom right, two buttons “Connect,” highlighted in a brighter tone to prompt action, and “Cancel,” which enables users to abort the login attempt. The overall layout emphasizes user experience, guiding users seamlessly through the login process while preserving security protocols. This interface effectively captures the essential elements for secure access to the VPN, with clear visual cues and input areas that facilitate ease of use. [Windows] Enter Secondary Password.
The Pulse VPN multi-factor authentication implementation relies on a secondary authentication source to fulfill the MFA requirement.  As a result, you will be prompted for credentials twice.


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.


I'm ready to assist with the descriptions once you provide the images. Please upload the images you'd like me to describe.

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN.
Please note, 32-bit clients are no longer supported by Ivanti!

︗None
ARM processors cannot natively run x64 or x86 programs without special emulation. However, not all x86 programs run smoothly even with emulation. As such, the best course of action for these sorts of machines is using the version of Pulse Secure that is specifically made for ARM processors.

Download the client:
Windows 64 bit ARM Pulse Secure Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/c/c6/PulseSecure22.7.3.ARM64.msi)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up to date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Follow all post-download steps in the above section.
︗Checking VPN Status
In the bottom right hand corner, in your status bar, you should see an S icon. If there's a green arrow, that means you are connected! If there is nothing, that means you are not.
The image shows a Windows taskbar notification area, set against a dark background that emphasizes the visibility of the icons. Several application icons are arranged neatly and are recognizable due to their distinct designs: a Java logo depicted as a coffee cup in an orange square, a pink waveform icon representing sound or microphone functions, a red cross in a cloud symbol indicating a connectivity problem, a blue shield representing security features, a yellow warning triangle suggesting potential issues, and a key icon related to access or security functions. Additionally, there is a presentation-style icon, possibly for a program like PowerPoint. The overall interface is minimalist and modern, adhering to contemporary design standards, allowing users to efficiently manage notifications and statuses of active applications. Each icon serves a functional purpose, streamlining user interaction with the system and enabling quick identification of application statuses. 
You can hover over this icon and it will show you the status of your connection.
The image depicts the Windows taskbar notification area, commonly referred to as the system tray, situated in the bottom right corner of the screen. The background is dark, enhancing the visibility of various application icons. Prominent among these is an orange square representing a Java logo, a pink waveform symbol for sound, a red 'X' in a cloud indicating a connectivity issue, a blue shield for security, a yellow warning triangle suggesting potential issues, and a key icon related to access security. Centrally, a distinct icon with a red and white design signifies the Ivanti Secure Access Client, which is currently connected, as indicated by the tooltip that reads "Ivanti Secure Access Client: Connected." A presentation-style icon appears next, likely for PowerPoint. Overall, the arrangement is clean and modern, enabling users to quickly view and manage notifications or statuses of active applications, with each icon serving a specific function essential for user interaction.

︗Network/VPN/macOS

From UMIACS
(Redirected from (N/A)Network/VPN/OSX)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Ivanti Connect Secure Client.  Alternatively, you can establish a connection through a web browser(The prior text links to https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu/), but this may fail if you have an outdated version of Ivanti Connect Secure already installed.

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
3 Checking VPN Status
4 Setup Security Requirement (Follow these steps if you encounter an error while connecting through the Ivanti Secure client)


︗Prerequisites
macOS 13.x or higher as of the current version of the Ivanti Connect Secure Client
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
Download the client:
macOS Ivanti Connect Secure Client(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/ivanti-connectsecure/macOS/PulseSecure-mac-22.7.3-installer.dmg)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up-to-date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Open the client and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.
The image shows a graphical user interface (GUI) of the Ivanti Secure Access Client, displayed on a macOS device. The window is rectangular with a light gray background. At the top, an orange icon symbolizing security is centered above the title "Ivanti Secure Access Client." 

The primary content area is labeled "Connections," indicating that this is where users can manage their VPN connections. The section underneath is blank, suggesting that no connections have been set up yet. 

On the bottom left corner, there are two icons: one resembling a plus sign "+" and the other a pencil or edit symbol. These icons are typically used for adding new connections or editing existing ones, respectively. The overall layout is clean and minimalistic, emphasizing functionality and ease of use. The design aligns with macOS aesthetics, featuring rounded corners and a simple navigation style. This environment suggests preparation for VPN connection setup or management. [macOS] Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection
In the 'Name' field, enter a descriptive name for this vpn Connection.
In the 'Server URL' enter 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'
The image displays a graphical interface of the Ivanti Secure Access Client on a macOS device, designed for establishing VPN connections. The main window features a rectangular shape with a light gray background, creating a clean and uncluttered appearance. At the top, an orange icon representing security is centrally positioned above the title "Ivanti Secure Access Client," signaling the purpose of the application.

A prominent section titled "Connections" is located in the upper half of the window, indicating that this is where users manage their VPN configurations. Below this title, a pop-up dialog appears with multiple input fields relevant for setting up a new VPN connection.

In the dialog box, there are fields labeled "Type," "Name," and "Server," with the name field already populated with "UMIACS VPN," and the server field filled with "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu." The buttons at the bottom, "Connect," "Cancel," and "Add," allow users to proceed with connection setup, abort, or save the new VPN configuration, respectively.

The design elements harmonize with the overall macOS aesthetic, emphasizing user-friendliness and minimalism, hinting at a seamless setup process for accessing UMIACS resources securely. [macOS] Enter the name of the vpn server
Enter your UMIACS credentials and hit connect.

At the top, an orange icon representing security is prominently displayed, followed by the title "UMIACS VPN." Below the title, two input fields labeled "User Name" and "Password" are centrally positioned, indicating where users should enter their credentials for accessing the VPN.

The "User Name" field is outlined with a distinct pink border, highlighting the area for user input, while the "Password" field remains blank. Below these fields, there are three buttons: "Cancel," which is intended to abort the connection process; and "Connect," which allows users to initiate their VPN connection after entering their credentials. Additionally, a checkbox labeled "Save settings" is present, enabling users to store their login information for future sessions. This interface exemplifies a clean, user-friendly design typical of macOS applications, focusing on simplicity and straightforward functionality for users connecting to the VPN. [macOS] Enter UMIACS Credentials
Complete the  MFA Verification Step. For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box.
The image displays a user interface for the UMIACS VPN on a macOS device, presented within a rectangular dialog box against a muted gray background. At the top, an orange icon symbolizing security is featured before the title "UMIACS VPN." Below this title are two input fields: one labeled "Secondary User Name," which already contains the name "lilikaj," and the other labeled "Secondary Password," which is visually obscured with dots to indicate entered characters.

Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.


I'm ready to help you with image descriptions. Please provide the images you'd like me to describe, and I'll create detailed textual descriptions for each one.

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN. You can close the window and the VPN will remain connected.
If you encounter an error, please refer to the "Setup Security Requirement" section bellow.

︗Checking VPN Status
In the top right hand corner, on your status bar, you should see an S icon in a black circle. If there's a green arrow, that means you are connected! If there is nothing, that means you are not.
The image displays the macOS menu bar at the top of the screen, highlighting various icons representing system functionalities and applications. The background is a soft blue gradient. 

Prominently featured on the left side are red icons, which likely indicate notifications or apps running in the background. Next to these, gray icons represent Bluetooth, Do Not Disturb, and the battery status, showing that Bluetooth is active and the device is currently charging. 

Next to the center, various icons represent Wi-Fi connectivity and sound settings. The connection is strong, indicated by the Wi-Fi icon displaying multiple bars. On the far right side, the date and time are visible, with the date showing "Thu Mar 16," and the time reflecting two different timestamps: "12:21 PM" and "12:45 PM." 

Overall, the layout is clean and organized, typical of macOS design, allowing users quick access to critical system features and real-time notifications. [macOS] The top image is connected, the bottom image is not.
You can click this icon, as well, and it will show you the status of your connection.
The image displays the macOS menu bar featuring a drop-down menu from the Ivanti Secure Access Client. The background is a soft blue, hinting at a spring or outdoor setting, likely with pink cherry blossoms blurred behind it. The menu contains several options: "Open Ivanti Secure Access Client," indicating a clickable action to launch the application, and a status indicator saying "Ivanti Secure Access Client: Connected," suggesting that the VPN connection is active.

In the list, "UMIACS VPN" is clearly highlighted, marked with a green check, confirming the connection's active status. The options also include an arrow indicating further actions can be taken with the UMIACS VPN. The bottom of the menu shows an "Exit" option, which allows users to close the client. Overall, the layout emphasizes usability and provides immediate status feedback regarding the VPN connection, maintaining the clean design typical of macOS applications. [macOS] The Pulse drop down menu.
If the icon is not in the status bar, you can find Pulse Secure in your Applications folder. There you will see a list of connections.


︗None
Click the Apple logo at the top left of your desktop
Click System Settings
Click Privacy & Security
Scroll to the Security section and select App Store and identified developers
You will have to enter your credentials
Click Next to the message "System Software From Developers "Pulse Secure LLC" was blocked from loading" if prompted.
Click Allow to enable the extension.
Close the System Settings window.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Shell contains the following information: 






︗Shell

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Changing your shell
You can use our web application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info/) to change your default shell for new access, a specific ComputationalResource or all your shells in all ComputationalResources.
Warning: Attempting to change your shell by starting a new shell in the initialization files for your current shell can result in issues in services such as sftp

︗Adding paths
Please choose what type of Shell you are using.   You can type the following in a terminal to see what shell you are using,
echo $SHELL

Bash
Tcsh
sh
csh
zsh
ksh




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Shell&oldid=6864"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/MailingLists contains the following information: 






︗MailingLists

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS has 2 types of mailing lists, simple ones in our LDAP (also known as mailaliases) and Mailman mailing lists. Please contact the HelpDesk if you would like either of these types of mailing lists created.

︗Mailaliases
These are simple Email redirects that allow for <listnamehere>@umiacs.umd.edu to be forwarded to a set list of email addresses. This is ideal for situations where you have a set number of addresses in mind (i.e. no membership changes) and do not need to do any other moderation on the list.

︗Mailman
These are more complicated lists that have a robust set of administrative tools:

Mailman List Administrators Guide
Mailman FAQ




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=MailingLists&oldid=8588"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WindowsPermissions contains the following information: 






︗Setting File Permissions in Windows

From UMIACS
(Redirected from WindowsPermissions)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗None
Right-click the file or directory you would like to change permissions for and click on 'Properties.'
In this example: We will be changing the permissions of a Folder named "ExampleFolder", which is owned by "GenericUser" but has granted permissions to another user, named "Example". We will be looking at these permissions.
After the properties menu comes up, select the tab labeled 'Security'.
The image displays a Windows file properties dialog box titled “ExampleFolder Properties.” At the top, the path indicates that the folder is located at "C:\Users\GenericUser\Documents\ExampleFolder." The window features four main tabs: General, Sharing, Security, and Previous Versions. 

In the "Security" tab, the "Group or user names" section lists four users/groups: SYSTEM, GenericUser (identified by the PC's name as a part of a longer identifier), Example, and Administrators. Each user/group has corresponding permissions displayed in a grid format. 

The permissions for SYSTEM include "Full control," "Modify," "Read & execute," "List folder contents," "Read," and "Write," with checkmarks indicating allowed permissions. A gray checkbox under "Full control" signifies the default permission status. 

At the bottom of the dialog, users can see buttons labeled "Edit," "OK," "Cancel," and "Apply." An "Advanced" link is also present for accessing more detailed permissions settings. The overall interface is characteristic of Windows 10, emphasizing clarity and accessibility for user interaction with folder permissions.
Click on the button at the bottom of the menu labeled 'Advanced'.
The image displays the "Advanced Security Settings" dialog box for a folder named "ExampleFolder" located at "C:\Users\GenericUser\Documents\ExampleFolder." The top portion includes the folder's name, the owner's name (GenericUser), and a link to change ownership. Below, there are tabs labeled "Permissions," "Auditing," and "Effective Access." 

In the central section, a table lists four entries detailing user permissions. Each entry includes the following columns: Type, Principal, Access, Inherited from, and Applies to. 

The users listed are: 
1. Example, with "Full control" access.
2. SYSTEM, also with "Full control."
3. Administrators, with "Full control."
4. GenericUser, again with "Full control."

The "Inherited from" column indicates where permissions originate for each. An option to "Edit" is available for modifying permission settings, alongside buttons to add or remove users and settings for disabling inheritance. 

At the bottom, the dialog includes buttons labeled "OK," "Cancel," "Apply," and a checkbox option to replace child permissions, emphasizing user-focused adjustments to folder security settings. The interface follows the standard design of Windows applications, with a clear, structured layout for ease of use.
Select the user that you would like to change permissions for, and select "Edit". In this case: We are changing the permissions of the user named "Example".
The image titled "Permission Entry for ExampleFolder" displays a Windows dialog box used for setting permissions on a folder named "ExampleFolder." At the top, the principal is identified as "Example (DESKTOP-D0L8R09\Example)," and it specifies that permissions are being modified for "This folder, subfolders, and files." 

In the central section, there is a grid labeled "Basic permissions," which includes various checkboxes representing different permissions that can be assigned. The permissions listed are "Full control," "Modify," "Read & execute," "List folder contents," "Read," and "Write." All permissions except for "Special permissions" are checked, indicating they are allowed for the specified principal. 

To the right, there is an option labeled "Show advanced permissions," allowing for more detailed settings. At the bottom, there is a checkbox that, when selected, would restrict these permissions to only the objects or containers within the current folder. The dialog includes buttons at the bottom for "OK," "Clear all," and "Cancel," allowing users to apply or dismiss changes. The overall interface is reflective of the Windows 10 aesthetic, with a clear and straightforward layout for user-friendly interaction.
Select the permissions you would like this user to have. To view more granular permissions, Select "Show Advanced permissions".
The image titled "Permission Entry for ExampleFolder" shows a Windows dialog box used to modify folder permissions. At the top, the principal is labeled as "Example (DESKTOP-D0L8R09\Example)" and the type indicates "Allow." This dialog is specifically for permissions on "This folder, subfolders, and files." 

The central area features a grid under "Advanced permissions," with multiple checkboxes representing different permissions. The permissions include "Full control," "Traverse folder / execute file," "List folder / read data," "Read attributes," and more, with the respective boxes checked for permissions granted. To the right, additional permission options are displayed, including "Write attributes" and "Delete," most of which are unchecked.

A checkbox at the bottom allows the user to restrict permissions to only the current folder's contents. The buttons "OK," "Clear all," and "Cancel" are positioned at the bottom right, facilitating user interaction with the permission settings. The design reflects a standard Windows 10 aesthetic, emphasizing usability and clarity for adjusting folder security settings.
Apply or deny permissions for each user which needs to be updated.
Apply all changes by clicking the 'OK' or 'Apply' button at the bottom of each menu as necessary.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Quota contains the following information: 






︗Quota

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Quotas

1.1 RPC Quotas
1.2 Tree Quotas


2 Calculating Space Usage


︗Quotas
︗RPC Quotas
File systems that support RPC quotad quotas are reported to the user by the quota command.  Home directories that are mounted from our Isilon NAS will support these kinds of quotas.
To find out what your current quota is, first run df . to find out what file system you are currently mounted from (in this example it is  data.isilon.umiacs.umd.edu:/ifs/umiacs/homes/username). Please note that the Use% here is for the entire file system and not your user-specific home directory.

# df .
Filesystem                                            1K-blocks  Used Available Use% Mounted on
data.isilon.umiacs.umd.edu:/ifs/umiacs/homes/username   5138048    32   5138016   1% /nfshomes/username

Then run quota and that line will list your quota information for that file system.  If you see errors such as "Error while getting quota from ..." you may safely ignore these as some of our file systems do not report quotas correctly.

$ quota
Disk quotas for user username (uid 13337):
     Filesystem  blocks   quota   limit   grace   files   quota   limit   grace
data.isilon.umiacs.umd.edu:/ifs/umiacs/homes/username
                     24  5138024 5242880              10  10276045 10485760

If you have hit your RPC quota and haven't realized it, you may see some strange issues. For example, you will not be able to write-out files (although 'touch' and file concatenation will succeed). Some applications such as vi will throw "FSync" errors. Similarly, commands such as wget will appear to succeed but your files will be zero-length.

︗Tree Quotas
An alternate style of quota management is done through tree quotas that show up in how much space is available in the file system by using the df command to inspect either the current path (no arguments given) or a given path.
For example to show my /nfshomes/username home directory quota, I can just use df ~

$ df ~
Filesystem                                            1K-blocks  Used Available Use% Mounted on
data.isilon.umiacs.umd.edu:/ifs/umiacs/homes/username   5138048    32   5138016   1% /nfshomes/username

︗Calculating Space Usage
When you are looking to diagnose how much space you are using you often want to know how much storage the immediate directories are taking in a certain folder.  The utility to do this is du.  Since *NIX operating systems use the concept of .. for the previous directory simple file globs like .* don't provide exactly what you need since in certain places like your home directories there are a lot of dot files or hidden files (eg. .somename).  To identify all files and directories from the current directory you can use something like du -hs .[^.]* *.

-bash-4.2$ du -hs .[^.]* *
48K     .bash_history
94M     .cache
160K    .compiz
3.0M    .config
32K     .gconf
64K     .gnupg
48K     .history
48K     .ICEauthority
4.2M    .local
29M     .mozilla
224K    .ssh
48K     .viminfo
48K     .Xauthority
48K     .xsession-errors
7.2M    catkin_ws
32K     Desktop
32K     Documents
57M     Downloads
32K     Music
32K     perl5
32K     Pictures
32K     Public
32K     Templates
32K     Videos





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Quota&oldid=11465"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WebSpace contains the following information: 






︗WebSpace

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS provides static web space hosting for research/lab pages and user pages.

︗Contents

1 Hosting websites in UMIACS Object Store (preferred method)
2 Main Website and Lab Pages
3 Personal Web Space

3.1 UMIACS Object Store
3.2 Nexus File Space


4 Adding A Password Protected Folder To Your Web Space
5 Restricting Content based on IP address


︗None
Please refer to the section "Hosting a Website in your Bucket" on the UMIACS Object Store Help Page(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/help) or visit OBJ/WebHosting. This is currently our most updated and reliable method for hosting websites.

︗Main Website and Lab Pages
http://www.umiacs.umd.edu
You can access the main website and lab sites for editing in two ways:

From Unix as /fs/www - and can be remotely accessed by SFTP to a supported Unix host (eg. Nexus).
From Windows as \\umiacs-webftp\www-umiacs - and remotely accessed by the same file share over the VPN.
Faculty members and authorized users can modify their own public profiles on the main UMIACS homepage. For instructions, see ContentManagement.

︗Personal Web Space
Your personal website URL at UMIACS is

http://www.umiacs.umd.edu/~username
where username is your UMIACS username.  You can set this page to redirect to any page of your choice by setting the Home Page attribute in your UMIACS directory entry(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info/).
In general, large files or directories for distribution related to a lab's research should go into the specific lab's web tree, not your individual web tree.  Remember that your webpage is not permanently continued upon your departure from UMIACS.
UMIACS currently supports hosting a personal website on the Object Store.

︗UMIACS Object Store
This is the preferred method of hosting a personal website at UMIACS. Please see the UMIACS Object Store (OBJ) Help Page(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/help) for more information on creating a website within OBJ. Once you create your website in OBJ, you will need to set your directory Home Page to the bucket's URL (the URL that ends in umiacs.io).

︗Nexus File Space


Please provide the images from the wiki, and I will generate detailed textual descriptions for each one.

This service has been deprecated.

This is primarily a legacy method for users who already have their websites configured this way. If you believe that your circumstances require your personal website to be hosted on this file space, please contact the  Help Desk. (This does not affect existing users who already have websites hosted on the Nexus file space.)
You will need set your directory Home Page attribute to http://users.umiacs.umd.edu/~username(The prior text links to http://users.umiacs.umd.edu/~username), where username is your UMIACS username (similar to your personal URL above). You can access your website for editing in two ways:

From Unix as /fs/www-users/username - and can be remotely accessed via SFTP to a supported UNIX host.
From Windows as \\umiacs-webftp\www-users\username - and remotely accessed by the same file share over the VPN.
︗Adding A Password Protected Folder To Your Web Space


Please provide the images from the wiki, and I will generate detailed textual descriptions for each one.

This method will NOT work in the UMIACS Object Store.

1) Create the directory you want to password protect or cd into the directory you want to password protect.
2) Create a file called .htaccess ( vi .htaccess) in the directory you wish to password protect.
3) In the file you just created, type the following lines 

AuthUserFile "/your/directory/here/".htpasswd
AuthName "Secure Document"
AuthType Basic
require user username

For example, if you were going to protect the /fs/www-users/username/private directory and you want the required name to be class239, then your file would look like this:

AuthUserFile /fs/www-users/username/private/.htpasswd
AuthName "Secure Document"
AuthType Basic
require user class239

4) Create a file called .htpasswd in the same directory as .htaccess. You create this file by typing in htpasswd -c .htpasswd username in the directory area to be protected.
In the example above, the username is class239 so you would type htpasswd -c .htpasswd class239
You will be prompted to enter the password you want. The .htpasswd file will be created in the current directory and will contain an encrypted version of the password.
To later change the username, edit the .htaccess file and change the username. If you want to later change the password, just retype the above line in step 4 and enter the new password at the prompt.

︗Restricting Content based on IP address
It is possible to have pages on your webspace only accessible to clients connecting from certain IP addresses. In order to accomplish this, cd in to the directory you wish to restrict, and edit your .htaccess or httpd.conf file. The example below shows how to make content only viewable to clients connecting from the UMD WiFi in Apache 2.2.

SetEnvIF X-Forwarded-For "^128\.8\.\d+\.\d+$" UMD_NETWORK
SetEnvIF X-Forwarded-For "^129\.2\.\d+\.\d+$" UMD_NETWORK
SetEnvIF X-Forwarded-For "^192\.168\.\d+\.\d+$" UMD_NETWORK
SetEnvIF X-Forwarded-For "^206\.196\.(?:1[6-9][0-9]|2[0-5][0-9])\.\d+$" UMD_NETWORK
SetEnvIF X-Forwarded-For "^10\.\d+\.\d+\.\d+$" UMD_NETWORK
Order Deny,Allow
Deny from all
Allow from env=UMD_NETWORK

The SetEnvIF directive will modify one's environment if the specified attribute matches the provided regular expression. In this example, IP addresses that are forwarded from an IP within UMD's IP space are tagged with UMD_NETWORK. Then, all traffic to the example directory is blocked unless it has the UMD_NETWORK tag. See the following pages for a more in depth explanation of the commands used.
.htaccess(The prior text links to https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/howto/htaccess.html), SetEnvIf(The prior text links to https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_setenvif.html#setenvif), Order(The prior text links to https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_authz_host.html#order), Deny(The prior text links to https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_authz_host.html#deny), Allow(The prior text links to https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_authz_host.html#allow)





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=WebSpace&oldid=10693"

(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/OBJbox contains the following information: 






︗OBJ

From UMIACS
(Redirected from OBJbox)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 UMIACS Object Store
2 Terminology
3 Getting Started
4 Buckets
5 Keys (files)
6 Hosting a Website in your Bucket
7 Deleting Keys (files)
8 Clients
9 Access Key and Secret Key
10 LabGroups
11 Managing LabGroups
12 Requesting a LabGroup


︗UMIACS Object Store
An object store is a web-based storage solution focused on reliability, scalability and security. It is best suited for public content storage/distribution, archiving data or secure data sharing between users. Our Object Store can be used through the web interface(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj), the command line UMobj utilities, third-party graphical  clients, and even programmatically using many popular programming languages.  We support a subset of the Amazon Simple Storage Services (S3) API(The prior text links to http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/Welcome.html), built around a technology called Ceph(The prior text links to http://ceph.com/).

︗Terminology
S3-like storage thinks in terms of buckets and keys. Keys are analogous to files. A bucket is simply a container to a set of keys. There is no actual hierarchy inside of a bucket, but the standard UNIX path separator, a forward slash (/) at the end of a Key name, is interpreted by many clients (including this web site and our UMobj utilities) as being a directory delimiter. This allows you to copy data from your local filesystems to your buckets through umobj or third-party clients. You may specify who has what types of access to your buckets via Access Control Lists (ACLs) at the bucket level or the individual key level.
Your data is protected from individual machine failure via replication within the cluster. All data is checksummed in accordance with the Amazon S3 protocol to ensure that data in transit is valid before it is accepted by the cluster. However, there are no backups or snapshots of this data in the cluster, so if a user deletes a key or bucket in the Object Store, there is no way to restore that information.

︗Getting Started
UMIACS users are allocated 50GB of storage.  Faculty are allocated 10TB. To get started, log in(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj) and you will be redirected to the initial help page.  You can also find the link from our https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu) site as "OBJbox Object Store".

︗Buckets
You can create and browse your buckets (containers that hold data) by visiting your buckets(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/buckets/) page. You can also set bucket-level Access Control Lists (ACLs) from this page. Bucket-level ACLs get implicitly inherited to all the keys within the bucket. However, individual keys can have additional specific ACLs applied for more granular control.
Bucket names must be unique. When you create a bucket it will notify you if the name is already taken.

︗None
After selecting a bucket, you will be able to create folders and upload files within that bucket. Listed files can be downloaded, deleted, or assigned a specific ACL by the key owner/creator.
Please note: Local file system ownership and permissions, and special files (such as symlinks) can not be represented in the Object Store. We highly suggest that if you are securing data into the Object Store and need these to be faithfully maintained that you use a local archive tool (tar, zip, etc..) to collect the data and then upload the resulting archive file(s).

︗Hosting a Website in your Bucket
Please visit OBJ/WebHosting for more information.

︗None
Within the web interface you can delete files one-by-one. If you want to remove a bunch of files, you will need to use a different client as described below.
This is dangerous as there are no backups of files in the Object Store. Be careful to only delete the data you intend to delete.

︗Clients
There are several clients that can be used (sometimes with a limited set of features) on your desktop to gain access to the Object Store. All supported UMIACS systems running RHEL8 have a copy of our UMobj(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/staff/umobj/blob/master/README.md#umobj) utilities preinstalled which provide command line access to the Object Store. We also have an article in our wiki on  third party clients that lists and explains the details. These clients need to be configured with your Access and Secret Keys as described below.

︗Access Key and Secret Key
Each user has one or more pairs of Access Keys and Secret Keys that are used as a credential to not expose your password when using the Object Store. These can be obtained by clicking on your username(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/user/) in the upper right-hand corner. You'll use these to identify and authenticate yourself to the Object Store.
Please treat your Secret Key(s) the same as a password and do not plaintext it over email/otherwise or share it with any other individuals.
When using the umobj(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/staff/umobj/blob/master/README.md#umobj) utilities, you will need to make sure you have added these credentials in your local shell initialization files. There are links to files that have these automatically generated for the 3 most popular UNIX shell families (bash/sh, csh/tcsh, and zsh). Please make sure that whatever file(s) you copy these credentials into can not be read by other users (eg. chmod 600 filename).
Note: Each Access Key and Secret Key are specific to a particular object store, so if you are accessing multiple object stores you may want to write the credentials for each to separate files and then source each file when you want to use the associated object store. Please  contact staff if you have any questions.

︗LabGroups
LabGroups allow a group of users to share data while avoiding the need for complex ACLs by maintaining group ownership. Designated LabGroup managers can grant granular access (read, write, full control, manager) to buckets owned by the LabGroup. All objects owned by a LabGroup count against the group quota. LabGroups can be navigated using the menu with username in the top right corner of the page. Note: this will only appear if you are a member of at least one LabGroup. At this point, you can browse the Object Store as the LabGroup and obtain your unique Access Key and Secret Key pair using the instructions above. To switch to another LabGroup or back to your own buckets, click the menu again and select another user or group.

︗Managing LabGroups
LabGroups have many different levels of membership: Managers, FULL_CONTROL, READ/WRITE, and READ. Managers can add or remove LabGroup Members while every other access level cannot. If you hold the Manager role in a LabGroup, you can add and remove users using the Manage LabGroups(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/labgroup/list/) page, which is available under the Manage menu at the top of the page. After selecting a LabGroup, you can add users by typing their username into the search field and selecting a membership role.

︗Requesting a LabGroup
To request a LabGroup for your project, please  contact staff.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WindowsPython contains the following information: 






︗WindowsPython

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Python can be user installed.
Below are installation instructions for both .exe and MSI installers. MSI installers have been discontinued for Python version 3.5 and above. 

︗Contents

1 Installing Python via .exe
2 Installing Python via MSI
3 Installing Modules

3.1 Using an executable
3.2 Using python
3.3 Using easy_install


4 Popular Executable Modules


︗Installing Python via .exe
Download Python application of the version you want from here(The prior text links to https://www.python.org/download/). Note that there are options for the 32-bit or 64-bit version, but you might need to do some searching.
Click run, to run the installer.
The image depicts a pop-up window from a Windows operating system, typically encountered during the download of executable files. The window features a light yellow background with rounded corners, prominently displaying a message that reads, "Do you want to run or save python-3.5.2-amd64.exe (28.7 MB) from python.org?" This indicates that a user has attempted to download the Python installer, specifically a 64-bit version of Python 3.5.2. Below the message, there is a warning stating, "This type of file could harm your computer," alerting the user about potential risks associated with executable files.

The pop-up includes three buttons at the bottom: "Run," "Save," and "Cancel," providing the user with options to either execute, store the file on their device, or abort the process. The button "Save" has a drop-down arrow, suggesting additional options might be available when clicked. The overall layout is structured and straightforward, consistent with standard dialog boxes in the Windows environment, focusing on user safety and decision-making regarding file downloads.
Select Install Now. Make sure that you uncheck the "Install launcher for all users" box. Leaving this checked will cause the installation to fail.
The image depicts the installation interface for Python 3.5.2 (64-bit) on a Windows operating system. The window has a predominantly white background with a yellow-and-blue logo of the Python language in the lower left corner. At the top, prominently labeled, is "Python 3.5.2 (64-bit) Setup." 

Central to the interface is a message instructing users to select "Install Now" to install Python with default settings or choose "Customize" to adjust installation features. Below this, the path for the default installation is displayed: “C:\Users\[username]\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python35,” indicating where Python will be stored. 

To the left of the "Install Now" button, which is highlighted, there's an icon resembling a checklist. Additionally, users can customize installation options, indicated by a button labeled "Customize installation."

Check boxes are present beneath the main options for installing the launcher for all users and adding Python 3.5 to the system PATH, although both options are unchecked. The interface is user-friendly and clean, designed for straightforward installation. The window includes a Cancel button at the bottom right, allowing users to exit the setup.
Finish the installation here(The prior text links to https://www.python.org/download/).
This installer will automatically allow you to access Python from the command line by just typing py instead of the full path.

︗Installing Python via MSI
Download Python windows MSI installer from here(The prior text links to https://www.python.org/download/). Note that there are options for the 32-bit or 64-bit version, but you might need to do some searching.
Click run, to run the installer.
The image displays a pop-up window typical of the Windows operating system, presenting the user with a prompt concerning a file download. The window features a light yellow background with rounded corners, indicating user-facing design. At the center is a message asking, "Do you want to run or save python-2.7.12.msi (18.0 MB) from python.org?" This message highlights that the user is downloading the Python installer for version 2.7.12. Below this is a cautionary note stating, "This type of file could harm your computer," serving as a warning about the potential risks associated with executing installer files.

The dialog box provides three interactive buttons at the bottom: "Run," "Save," and "Cancel." The "Run" button suggests executing the installer immediately, while "Save" allows the user to store the file on their device, and "Cancel" aborts the download process. The "Save" button features a drop-down arrow, indicating additional saving options. This interface emphasizes user safety and clarity, offering straightforward choices regarding managing downloaded executable files in a Windows environment.
Select a home directory as the install folder (i.e.C:\Users\[YOURUSERNAME]\Documents\Pythonx.x.x)  where x represents the version number.
The image displays the setup interface for Python version 2.7.12 on a Windows operating system. The window features a clean, light gray background with a prominent Python logo—a blue and yellow stylized snake—positioned at the top left. At the top of the window is the title "Python 2.7.12 Setup." 

Central to the display is a message prompting the user to "Select Destination Directory," directing them to choose a folder for the installation files. To facilitate this, there are navigational buttons: a "Documents" shortcut to quickly access the documents folder, an "Up" button to navigate to the previous directory, and a "New" button to create a new directory. 

The area below this message showcases the current selected path, indicating "C:\Users\aberi\Documents\Python2.7," accompanied by an empty selection box for users to visually navigate through available directories. 

At the bottom of the window, standard navigation buttons are displayed: "Back," "Next," and "Cancel," allowing users to either return to the previous step, proceed to the next, or terminate the setup process. The overall design prioritizes user-friendliness, with intuitive options for directory selection.
Finish the installation.
If you want to be able to access Python from the command line by just typing python instead of the full path (i.e. \temp\pythonfolder\python) you have to add the python folder to your path.

Navigate to Control Panel -> System and Security -> System
Select Advanced system settings from the sidebar
In the Advanced tab click the Environment Variables... button
Check if a Variable called Path exists in the list of user variables
If it exists, add the python directory to the end of the Path value separated by a semicolon (i.e. C:\Things\In\Path;C:\Path\To\Python\Folder)
If it does not, press the New button and set the variable name to Path and the value to the path to your python directory


︗Installing Modules
︗Using an executable
Alternatively, python executable modules can be found on the web, and the executable installed

︗Using python
Modules can be installed as the normally would using python.
For instance if the python directory is in your path you merely navigate to the module directory and run:

python setup.py install

︗Using easy_install
These steps assume that Visual Studio is installed (It is by default)
First, we configure python to work with Visual Studio

Open the file msvc9compiler.py  from  the location C:\Path\To\Python\Folder\...\Lib\distutils\msvc9compiler.py  using a text editor such as notepad
Replace the line containing toolskey = "VS%0.f0COMNTOOLS" % version  with the following toolskey = "vs110COMNTOOLS" , where 110 is a three digit number corresponding to the version number of Visual Studio 2012
To do this, type  Ctr + a  to highlight all the text, and type  Ctrl + f  to search for the line to be replaced, and edit the file to replace it
Also replace the line containing  mfinfo = self.manifest_get_embed_info(target_desc, Id_args)  with the line:  mfinfo = None 
Next we install the module

Download the easy_install graphical installer from here(The prior text links to https://bootstrap.pypa.io/ez_setup.py)
Run the downloaded file, it should open a command line and finish the installation
The installed files should be located in  C:\Path\To\Python\Folder\..\Scripts
There are several different python modules, so note the name of the module you want to install. numPy will be installed here.
Open a command prompt, by pressing the start button, and searching  cmd  
The image displays a search interface from the Windows 7 operating system, likely the Start menu. The screen features a pale blue background with the default Windows wallpaper, including light clouds and a green hill. A search box at the top labeled "Search programs and files" contains the text "cmd," indicating the user is searching for the command prompt application.

Below the search box, results are categorized into three sections: "Programs," "Documents," and "Files." The "Programs" section shows one entry labeled "cmd," which likely refers to the Command Prompt application. In the "Documents" section, there are eleven entries, including various files associated with Python scripts, such as "cmd.cython-34," "test_cmd_line_script," and "test_config_cmd." The entries are listed with accompanying icons, making it clear they are documents.

The "Files" section includes a reference to "setuptools-3.5.1," exemplifying related installation files. The interface allows users to easily navigate and select files or programs from their computer, enhancing efficiency in accessing applications within the Windows environment. The bottom of the screen features the "Log off" button, signifying a user-friendly layout.
At the prompt, type the full path to easy_install executable and the name of the python module you need. ie.  C:\Path\To\Python\Folder\..\Scripts\easy_install.exe module_Name
where module_Name is the name of the module, numPy in this case
The image depicts a Windows Command Prompt interface on a computer running Windows 7. The window features a dark background with white text, showing command-line outputs. At the top, it displays "Administrator: C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe," indicating that the user is operating with administrative privileges. Below this, a command line shows the path "C:\Users\Mfango\Documents\Python3.4.1\Scripts\easy_install.exe," suggesting that the user is navigating to execute the `easy_install` program, a tool for installing Python modules.

The command prompt entry, "easy_install numPy," indicates that the user is attempting to install the Python module named NumPy. However, the line that follows states, "No urls, filenames, or requirements specified (see -h for help)," suggesting an error or oversight in the command input, possibly due to missing parameters or incorrect syntax. The overall interface clearly communicates a context for command line operations and the installation of Python packages, typical for users managing Python environments or troubleshooting installation issues. The visual layout, featuring bordered sections of text against a solid background, is characteristic of command-line interfaces in Windows systems.
Click to enlarge
Finally, press enter to run and install the module
