〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Nexus/Gamma contains the following information: 






︗Nexus/GAMMA

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Nexus/Gamma)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The GAMMA(The prior text links to https://gamma.umd.edu/) lab has a partition of GPU nodes available in the Nexus. Only GAMMA lab members are able to run non-interruptible jobs on these nodes.

︗Contents

1 Access
2 Quality of Service
3 Hardware
4 Example
5 Storage

5.1 Home Directories
5.2 Project Directories
5.3 Scratch Directories

5.3.1 Network Scratch Directory
5.3.2 Local Scratch Directories


5.4 Datasets




︗Access
You can always find out what hosts you have access to submit via the Nexus#Access page.  The GAMMA lab in particular has a special submission host that has additional local storage available.

nexusgamma00.umiacs.umd.edu
Please do not run anything on the login node. Always allocate yourself machines on the compute nodes (see instructions below) to run any job.

︗Quality of Service
GAMMA users have access to all of the  standard job QoSes in the gamma partition using the gamma account.
The additional job QoSes for the GAMMA partition specifically are:

huge-long: Allows for longer jobs using higher overall resources.
Please note that the partition has a GrpTRES limit of 100% of the available cores/RAM on the partition-specific nodes in aggregate plus 50% of the available cores/RAM on legacy## nodes in aggregate, so your job may need to wait if all available cores/RAM (or GPUs) are in use.

︗Hardware


Nodenames

Type

Quantity

CPU cores per node

Memory per node

GPUs per node


gammagpu[00-04,06-09]

A5000 GPU Node

9

32

256GB

8


gammagpu05

A4000 GPU Node

1

32

256GB

8




Total

10

320

2560GB

80

︗Example
From nexusgamma00.umiacs.umd.edu you can run the following example to submit an interactive job.  Please note that you need to specify the --partition and --account.  Please refer to our SLURM documentation about about how to further customize your submissions including making a batch submission.  The following command will allocate 8 GPUs for 2 days in an interactive session.  Change parameters accordingly to your needs.  We discourage use of srun and promote use of sbatch for fair use of GPUs.

$ srun --pty --gres=gpu:8 --account=gamma --partition=gamma --qos=huge-long bash
$ hostname
gammagpu01.umiacs.umd.edu
$ nvidia-smi -L
GPU 0: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-cdfb2e0c-d69f-354b-02f4-15161dc7fa66)
GPU 1: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-be53e7a1-b8fd-7089-3cac-7a2fbf4ec7dd)
GPU 2: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-774efbb1-d7ec-a0bb-e992-da9d1fa6b193)
GPU 3: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-d1692181-c7de-e273-5f95-53ad381614c3)
GPU 4: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-ba51fd6c-37bf-1b95-5f68-987c18a6292a)
GPU 5: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-c1224a2a-4a3b-ff16-0308-4f36205b9859)
GPU 6: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-8d20d6cd-abf5-2630-ab88-6bba438c55fe)
GPU 7: NVIDIA RTX A5000 (UUID: GPU-93170910-5d94-6da5-8a24-f561d7da1e2d)

You can also use SBATCH to submit your job.  Here are two examples on how to do that.

$ sbatch --pty --gres=gpu:8 --account=gamma --partition=gamma --qos=huge-long --time=1-23:00:00 script.sh

OR

$ sbatch script.sh

// script.sh //

#!/bin/bash
#SBATCH --gres=gpu:8
#SBATCH --account=gamma
#SBATCH --partition=gamma
#SBATCH --qos=huge-long
#SBATCH --time=1-23:00:00

python your_file.py

︗Storage
There are 3 types of user storage available to users in GAMMA:

Home directories
Project directories
Scratch directories
There is also read-only storage available for Dataset directories.
GAMMA users can also request  Nexus project allocations.

︗Home Directories
You have 30GB of home directory storage available at /nfshomes/<username>.  It has both Snapshots and  Backups enabled.
Home directories are intended to store personal or configuration files only.  We encourage you to not share any data in your home directory.  You are encouraged to utilize our GitLab infrastructure to host your code repositories.
NOTE: To check your quota on this directory, use the command df -h ~.

︗Project Directories
You can request project based allocations for up to 8TB and up to 180 days with approval from a GAMMA faculty member.  
To request an allocation, please  contact staff with the faculty member(s) that approved the project in the conversation.  Please include the following details:

Project Name (short)
Description
Size (1TB, 2TB, etc.)
Length in days (30 days, 90 days, etc.)
Other user(s) that need to access the allocation, if any
These allocations will be available from /fs/gamma-projects under a name that you provide when you request the allocation.  Near the end of the allocation period, staff will contact you and ask if you would like to renew the allocation (requires re-approval from a GAMMA faculty member).

If you are no longer in need of the storage allocation, you will need to relocate all desired data within two weeks of the end of the allocation period.  Staff will then remove the allocation.
If you do not respond to staff's request by the end of the allocation period, staff will make the allocation temporarily inaccessible.
If you do respond asking for renewal but the original faculty approver does not respond within two weeks of the end of the allocation period, staff will also make the allocation temporarily inaccessible.
If one month from the end of the allocation period is reached without both you and the faculty approver responding, staff will remove the allocation.
This data is backed up nightly.

︗Scratch Directories
Scratch data has no data protection, there are no snapshots and the data is not backed up. 
There are two types of scratch directories:

Network scratch directory
Local scratch directories
︗Network Scratch Directory
You are allocated 100GB of scratch space via NFS from /gammascratch/$username.  It is not backed up or protected in any way.
This directory is automounted so you may not see your directory if you run ls /gammascratch but it will be mounted when you cd into your /gammascratch directory.
You may request a permanent increase of up to 200GB total space without any faculty approval by  contacting staff.  If you need space beyond 200GB, you will need faculty approval. 
This file system is available on all submission, data management, and computational nodes within the cluster.

︗Local Scratch Directories
These file systems are not available over NFS and there are no backups or snapshots available for these file systems.

Each computational node that you can schedule compute jobs on has one or more local scratch directories.  These are always named /scratch0, /scratch1, etc.  These directories are local to each node, ie. the /scratch0 on two different nodes are completely separate.
These directories are almost always more performant than any other storage available to the job.  However, you must stage data to these directories within the confines of your jobs and stage the data out before the end of your jobs.
These local scratch directories have a tmpwatch job which will delete unaccessed data after 90 days, scheduled via maintenance jobs to run once a month during our monthly maintenance windows.  Again, please make sure you secure any data you write to these directories at the end of your job.
Gamma has invested in a 20TB NVMe scratch file system on nexusgamma00.umiacs.umd.edu that is available as /scratch1.  To utilize this space, you will need to copy data from/to this over SSH from a compute node.  To make this easier, you may want to setup SSH keys that will allow you to copy data without prompting for passwords.
The /scratch1 directory on nexusgamma00.umiacs.umd.edu doesn't have a tmpwatch. The files in this directory need to be manually removed once they are no longer needed.
︗Datasets
We have read-only dataset storage available at /fs/gamma-datasets.  If there are datasets that you would like to see curated and available, please see  this page.
The list of GAMMA datasets we currently host can be viewed here(The prior text links to https://info.umiacs.umd.edu/datasets/list/?q=GAMMA).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Nexus/GAMMA&oldid=11906"

︗MacOSDisplayModes

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
To start, open your System Preferences from the Dock or Applications folder. 
The image displays a MacOS "System Preferences" interface. The window is rectangular with a light gray background and a prominent search bar at the top right corner. The upper section reads "System Preferences" in a bold font. Below this, there are multiple icons arranged in a grid format representing different system settings. Each icon is simple and colorful, depicting various functions: for instance, a monitor symbolizes "Displays," while other icons represent "Energy Saver," "Keyboard," "Mouse," and more.

The "Displays" icon is highlighted with a red square, indicating it is currently selected. This icon shows a stylized computer monitor. The layout is organized into two rows, with each icon clearly labeled below it. The lower section includes additional icons such as "Touch ID," "User Groups," and "Accessibility." The overall aesthetic is clean and user-friendly, typical of a MacOS design, suggesting functionality and ease of access to system settings.
Once you have opened it, click Displays.
The image shows the "Displays" settings interface from a MacOS system, specifically the "Built-in Retina Display" panel. The window is rectangular with a light gray background that enhances readability. At the top, there is a prominent search bar, indicated by a magnifying glass icon, suggesting that users can search for specific settings.

In the center of the window, a laptop icon is displayed, depicting a MacBook with the screen showing a webpage. Below the laptop image, several sections are presented: "Resolution," "Brightness," and a checkbox for "Automatically adjust brightness." The resolution option is set to "Default for display," while a slider allows for brightness adjustment, accompanied by an option for "True Tone," which enhances color consistency based on lighting conditions.

Additionally, there’s an "AirPlay Display" section showing currently selected as "Off" and a checkbox labeled "Show mirroring options in the menu bar when available." The overall design is sleek and user-friendly, typical of Apple’s interface aesthetics, facilitating easy navigation and settings adjustment.
Go to the Arrangement tab.
The image depicts the “Built-in Retina Display” settings interface from a MacOS system, specifically focused on the “Arrangement” tab. The window is rectangular with a light gray background, complemented by a light border. At the top, the title "Built-in Retina Display" is displayed in a simple font, followed by navigation tabs for "Display," "Arrangement," "Color," and "Night Shift," indicating the user's current section is “Arrangement.”

In the center, two blue rectangles represent the displays in extended mode, positioned side by side. A dotted line between them suggests they can be rearranged, with instructions provided above that state, "To rearrange the displays, drag them to the desired position." Below the rectangles, a red checkbox labeled "Mirror Displays" is prominently highlighted, indicating an option to mirror the displays.

Further down, the "AirPlay Display" section shows "Off," and a checkbox for "Show mirroring options in the menu bar when available" is visible. The aesthetic is minimalistic and sleek, reflecting the user-friendly design typical of MacOS, facilitating easy navigation and settings adjustment for users.
By default, the displays are used in extended mode. If you wish to switch to mirror mode, select the mirror checkbox.

︗Clear Cache

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
If a webpage is loading correctly for others but incorrectly for you, cleaning your cache will most likely resolve this.
If you need to clear the cache on your browser, please follow the link below specific to the browser that you are using.

︗Contents

1 Google Chrome
2 Firefox
3 Safari
4 Microsoft Edge


︗Google Chrome
https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/32050?co=GENIE.Platform%3DDesktop&hl=en(The prior text links to https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/32050?co=GENIE.Platform%3DDesktop&hl=en)

︗Firefox
https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-clear-firefox-cache(The prior text links to https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-clear-firefox-cache)

︗Safari
https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/clear-your-browsing-history-sfri47acf5d6/mac(The prior text links to https://support.apple.com/guide/safari/clear-your-browsing-history-sfri47acf5d6/mac)

︗Microsoft Edge
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/10607/microsoft-edge-view-delete-browser-history(The prior text links to https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/10607/microsoft-edge-view-delete-browser-history)

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/LANDesk contains the following information: 






︗Windows Patch Management

From UMIACS
(Redirected from LANDesk)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
In order to combat the ever increasing number of 3rd party security vulnerabilities on Windows machines, UMIACS staff has deployed Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager. As security threats have evolved from the operating system to applications we have had to take this step in order to maintain operational security for the Institute. Currently the updates are focused on applications that are exposed to the internet such as web browsers, teleconferencing solutions, Adobe Flash, Java, etc.
Ivanti is currently deployed on all UMIACS-supported Windows desktops as well as  Enterprise supported Windows laptops and home machines.

︗Automated Scanning
Patches are deployed during the week leading up to the maintenance window. Specifically, they will always be released on the Wednesday that falls between the 9th and the 15th of every month, and typically in the morning.

Desktops will scan for updates to be installed every night sometime between 7pm and 9pm. If you are not logged in during those times, the system will automatically install the patches and reboot if necessary. If you remain active on your system during those times, you will see a popup with the scan beginning and (once patches are downloaded) a prompt from Ivanti asking to begin installing patches.
Laptops will scan for updates to be installed at least once every day (assuming the laptop is powered on). This will only occur when the laptop has an active Internet connection (wired or wireless). You will see a popup with the scan beginning and (once patches are downloaded) a prompt from Ivanti asking to begin installing patches.
Installation can be deferred until lock/logoff if desired. If you do not respond to the prompt within a given amount of time, installation will automatically proceed:

Desktops: 24 hours
Laptops: 3 hours
If a reboot is required after installation finishes, you will receive another pop up. It is highly suggested to reboot right away due to system instability and vulnerability. However, reboot can be deferred for up to 6 days if desired. If you do not respond to the prompt within a given amount of time, the machine will automatically reboot:

Desktops: 24 hours
Laptops: 9 hours
If you interrupt the installation process between when the first patch begins installing and when the last patch finishes installing, Ivanti may ask to reboot before continuing to install the remaining patches next time it pops up. This is by design. If you would like to avoid multiple reboots on a machine that is used intermittently (such as a laptop), we would recommend starting a manual scan just before you stop using the machine for the night and then letting the machine download and apply all patches overnight. See below section for how to do this.

︗Manual Scanning
This should only need to be done on laptops or home machines in the event that Ivanti has not had a large enough time window to scan your computer recently, but can be optionally done if you see fit. Please note you will need an active Internet connection for this to work, however you do not need to be on the UMIACS VPN.

Search for "Security Scan" from the Start menu and click the result that shows up (should show a shield icon). The scan will begin. Patches will be detected and downloaded.
Note: The scan may fail on the "Checking for other running scanners" step if Ivanti is already running an invisible scan in the background. If this occurs, wait 10-15 minutes and then retry the scan.
The image depicts a Windows desktop interface, showcasing the search function. On the left side, there is a vertical taskbar featuring icons for various applications and settings, including a gear icon representing settings, which is often found at the bottom. The main focus is on the search box at the top, with the text "Security Scan" displayed as the best match for a desktop application. 

Below this, a list of search suggestions populates the interface, indicating related terms such as "security scanner," "security scanning," and variations for free or additional tools. Each suggestion is accompanied by a small icon, contributing to a clear and organized layout. The desktop's background appears to be a neutral color, emphasizing the search bar and suggestions. The overall visual aesthetics reflect a typical Windows layout, which conveys a user-friendly approach to searching for applications or tools, particularly focused on security management within a computing environment.The image displays the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager interface in scan mode. The background is predominantly black, contrasting with the white and red elements, with the Ivanti logo prominently featured in the top left corner. The main section of the window lists detected actions in a vertical format, including multiple security updates and patches denoted by unique identifiers such as "4011185_INTL detected" and "MS16-080_INTL detected." Each entry shows its status, with several marked as “Done.”

At the bottom of the window, there is a progress bar indicating that a file is currently being downloaded, with a URL displayed that links to the source file. This visual indicates an active process in managing security compliance on a Windows system. A "Close" button is located in the bottom right corner, allowing users to exit the interface. Overall, the window reflects a focused workflow on monitoring and updating security patches efficiently, underscoring Ivanti's role in maintaining system integrity and security management.
After all patches have been downloaded, you will be prompted to allow the install to begin.
The image displays the interface of the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager in scan mode. The predominant background color is black, which creates a stark contrast with the white text and red elements, including the Ivanti logo located in the upper left corner. The central section of the window details the detected vulnerabilities and pending updates for the user's computer, presented in a numbered list. Each entry lists a specific software vulnerability, encompassing information such as the software's name, a brief description of the vulnerability, and a unique identification number in parentheses, typical for tracking purposes.

A progress bar is situated at the bottom, indicating ongoing updates, alongside a countdown showing when automatic updates will begin. Two buttons are placed at the lower part of the interface: "Wait till lock or logoff" and "Start now." The "Close" button is located in the lower right corner, allowing for exiting the interface. This layout reflects the software's focus on security management by clearly informing users about required actions and maintaining an organized approach to system updates and vulnerabilities.
After all patches have been installed, you may be prompted to reboot.
The image shows a notification window from the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager indicating that a reboot is required for changes to take effect. The background is predominantly black, with the Ivanti logo displayed prominently at the top left, featuring a red and white color scheme. The main body of the window contains a message stating that the software has been updated and a reboot is necessary. It also provides instructions for users who may have questions, including a contact number for the helpdesk and an email address.

Below the message, there are two dropdown options for users: a "Remind me in" menu, where users can set a reminder time, and a countdown timer showing the time remaining before the automatic reboot. The “Reboot now” and “Remind me later” buttons are clearly indicated at the bottom right, facilitating user interaction. The overall layout is clean and straightforward, designed to ensure users understand the necessity of the reboot for security updates, emphasizing the importance of maintaining system integrity.
If you do not want to reboot immediately, you can click on the 'Remind me in:' drop down menu and click 'More options...'
The image shows a notification window from the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager, indicating that a reboot is essential for changes to take effect. The interface features a stark black background, contrasting sharply with the prominent red and white Ivanti logo in the top left corner. The central message reads that the computer's software has been updated, stressing the need for a reboot with clear, straightforward language.

Below the main message, there's additional information offering contact details for assistance, including a helpdesk phone number and an email address for inquiries. Users are presented with a "Remind me in:" dropdown menu, which includes options like "1 minute," "10 minutes," "1 hour," and "4 hours," catering to various preferences. A countdown timer below informs users how long they have before the automatic reboot occurs, currently set at "Rebooting in 23 hours, 59 min, 41 sec."

At the bottom right corner, two visible buttons—“Reboot now” and “Remind me later”—allow for user interaction, enhancing usability. The overall design is intentionally clean and functional, ensuring users understand the importance of complying with the reboot requirement for security updates.
Click the 'Remind me on' radio button and choose a date and time before the deadline (it will tell you what the deadline is). Then click 'Remind me later'.
The image depicts a notification window from the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager, indicating that a reboot is necessary for changes to take effect. The background is black, contrasting with the red Ivanti logo at the top left. The message emphasizes that a software update has been completed and that a reboot is required. Two main options for deferring the reboot are available: selecting a time for a reminder today or choosing a specific date from a calendar interface. The dropdown menu for time selection allows users to pick from various options, including hours and minutes formatted in a user-friendly manner. 

The calendar shows the month of November 2019, highlighting the current day and allowing users to select a future date if preferred. Below the calendar, it states that users can defer the reboot until a specified date. At the bottom right are two buttons: “Reboot now,” allowing instant rebooting, and “Remind me later,” which facilitates postponing the action. The overall design is straightforward and functional, aimed at helping users manage system updates effectively while ensuring clarity in communicating the necessity of the reboot.
After reboot, run another scan and verify no patches are detected. If a patch is continually failing, please  contact staff.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Recording contains the following information: 






︗ConferenceRooms/Recording

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Recording)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Background
Open Broadcaster Software (OBS)(The prior text links to https://obsproject.com/) is free and open source software for video recording and live streaming. It is simple to set up and highly customizable. At UMIACS, it is the software we recommend to users looking to either record or stream on either their personal computers or in a conference room or auditorium setting.

︗Conference Quick Setup
Below are steps outlining how to start recording or streaming your meetings. If, at any point, you have questions or need other assistance, feel free to reach out to the  UMIACS Help Desk. 

Select the source you'd like to route to the computer via the "Shared Media" option on the Crestron control panel. This will route the source through the A/V Bridge to the conference room computer.
Download (windows zip file)(The prior text links to https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/releases) and/or launch OBS on the conference room computer and do not run the auto-configuration wizard.
Set up video.
Click the + under the Sources pane at the bottom and select Video Capture Device. Leave everything at default and hit OK.
Ensure the proper device is selected to get the video to show up. In larger conference rooms and auditoriums with an A/V cabinet, this will usually be called 'AV Bridge'.
Click OK and resize the window to take up the entirety of the canvas.
If the output appears blurry or fuzzy, try setting the Resolution/FPS Type to Custom by right clicking the source -> Properties and changing it from Device Default. This seems to be particularly important in the larger conference rooms and auditoriums, as the A/V stack's default resolution is not the highest supported one (720p). Change resolution to the highest available one. You probably want to leave FPS at Match Output FPS.
Ensure audio settings look OK.
The default microphone for the system should already be set up to record audio. It is listed as Mic/Aux under the Mixer pane at the bottom. If you want to use an alternate microphone, click on the cog -> Properties and change the device.
Keep in mind that by default, Desktop Audio is recorded as well. If the user running the conference expects to play media during the conference that they do not want being picked up in the stream or recording itself, click the megaphone icon under Desktop Audio by default to mute it.
Set up either streaming, recording, or both as follows.
Streaming:

Go to File -> Settings -> Stream and select the service you want to use (99% of the time probably YouTube or Twitch).
Locate your stream key for the account you want to use. For YouTube/Twitch, there is a helpful link right there that takes you to the proper place to get this.
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/live_dashboard(The prior text links to https://www.youtube.com/live_dashboard), near the bottom
Twitch: https://www.twitch.tv/username/dashboard/settings(The prior text links to https://www.twitch.tv/username/dashboard/settings), at the top (replace username with your username). You can also link your account directly if you want.
Enter your key and hit OK.
Click Start Streaming under the Control pane at the bottom.
Recording:

Go to File -> Settings -> Output and change the recording path to something appropriate and click OK. If in a conference room, this should be an external SSD or the internal drive. We have observed that using external HDDs may introduce dropped frames due to encoding lag because of I/O bottlenecks.
Click Start Recording under the Control pane at the bottom.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=ConferenceRooms/Recording&oldid=10082"

︗Network/VPN/Mobile

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Network/VPN/IOS)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Download and Install the Pulse Secure Client
3 Configuring the Client
4 Using the Client


︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (mobile data or wireless)
︗Download and Install the Pulse Secure Client
Pulse Secure for iOS and Android enables secure connectivity over SSL VPN to internal UMIACS resources.  The app can be downloaded for free from the App Store or Google Play:

iOS (App Store): https://apps.apple.com/us/app/pulse-secure/id945832041(The prior text links to https://apps.apple.com/us/app/pulse-secure/id945832041)
Android (Google Play): https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.pulsesecure.pulsesecure&hl=en_US(The prior text links to https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.pulsesecure.pulsesecure&hl=en_US)
︗Configuring the Client
When the client is first launched, it will prompt you to accept its license agreement.  Click 'Accept' to continue.
You may need to enter a Corporate E-mail address or URL before continuing. Enter vpn.umiacs.umd.edu.
The image depicts the welcome screen of the Pulse Secure Client app on a smartphone. The background is a grayish color, featuring a subtle geometric or network pattern, suggesting connectivity. At the top, the Pulse Secure logo is prominently displayed, featuring a stylized green "P" and a gray checkmark, indicating security and reliability.

Centered on the screen is a large, bold title that reads "Welcome to the Pulse Secure Client" in white text, making it easy to read against the darker background. Below this, there is instructional text that states, "Please enter either your corporate email address or the URL provided by your company," also in white. 

The input field for the URL is visible, with the placeholder text "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu" indicating where users should enter their VPN connection details. A green button labeled "Submit" is located beneath the input field, inviting user interaction. The upper right corner shows the battery level at 25%, and the device appears to be connected through Verizon, indicating the user's network provider. Overall, the screen conveys a user-friendly interface designed for seamless connectivity. 
After clicking on 'Submit', a page titled 'Add a Connection' will pop up. You will then be prompted for some basic information.  You will need to provide the following information and then click 'Save' or 'Add' (depending on client version).
Connection Name: UMIACS VPN
Username: <your UMIACS username>
The image titled "Add a Connection" showcases a smartphone screen, likely depicting the Pulse Secure Client interface. The background is a dark gray, providing a sleek, modern aesthetic. At the top, there’s a clear label indicating the action: "Add a Connection." Below this, the user is prompted to save changes, with a checkbox stating, "This will be your default connection," marked as selected.

The form fields are neatly organized, beginning with "Connection Name," accompanied by a note indicating it is optional. Following that, there is a field for the URL, pre-filled with "https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu," suggesting users should access this specific VPN. The "Username" field is labeled as optional and below it, the "Authentication" section specifies "Password," indicating the method for accessing the VPN.

Additional fields for "Realm" and "Role" are also present but noted as optional. At the bottom, a prominent green button marked "Save" invites user interaction, clearly indicating the next step in the connection setup. Overall, the layout emphasizes user-friendliness while ensuring necessary information can be efficiently inputted. 
︗Using the Client
After the client has been configured, you can simply hit the 'Connect' button to start the VPN Connection.
The image titled "Pulse Secure" displays the interface of the Pulse Secure Client app on a smartphone. The background is a dark gray, providing a clean and modern aesthetic. At the top, the app's name "Pulse Secure" is prominently displayed. Below this title is a section labeled "Connection," highlighted by a green border, emphasizing its importance.

Within this section, the user sees a connection option labeled "UMIACS VPN," followed by its URL "https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating the specific address for the VPN connection. A circular radio button suggests this is the selected connection. Beneath this information is a large gray button labeled "Connect," inviting the user to initiate the VPN connection.

In the top right corner, the display shows the time as 15:22 and the battery level at 71%, indicating the device's status. The bottom of the screen features a navigation bar with icons for various functions, though the details of these icons are not specified. Overall, the layout conveys a user-friendly design focused on facilitating quick access to the VPN connection. 
Enter your UMIACS password, and hit 'Sign in'.
The image titled "UMIACS VPN Sign-In" showcases a smartphone screen displaying the login interface for the UMIACS VPN service. The screen has a dark gray background, contributing to a sleek and professional aesthetic. At the top, the VPN URL "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu" is visible in a small font, alongside a "Cancel" button in the upper right corner, providing navigation options for the user.

At the bottom of the input fields, a large green "Sign In" button invites user action, making the next step clear and accessible. The battery status at 71% and the time at 15:25 on the top right corner further contextualize the smartphone's operational status. Overall, the interface is designed for an intuitive user experience that facilitates secure access to UMIACS resources. 
Choose your preferred method of multi-factor authentication.
The image titled "UMIACS Login" displays a smartphone screen presenting the login interface for the Pulse Connect Secure app. The top of the screen showcases the UMIACS logo in a bold font, prominently featuring the letters "UMIACS" against a light gray background. Below the logo, a welcoming message reads, "Welcome to the Pulse Connect Secure," indicating the purpose of the application.

Each button is highly legible and easily distinguishable due to its bright color and size, promoting user engagement and interaction. 

To the right of the buttons is a gear icon labeled "Settings," suggesting additional configuration options for the users. The device status indicator in the upper portion of the screen shows the battery level at 85% and that it is connected to the Sprint network. Overall, the layout is clean and functional, ensuring a user-friendly experience while facilitating secure access to UMIACS resources. 
You are now connected.  You connection status is verified by the VPN symbol in the top status bar.
The image titled "Pulse Secure" shows the interface of the Pulse Secure Client app on a smartphone screen. The display features a dark gray background, creating a modern and sleek ambiance. At the top, the title "Pulse Secure" is clearly visible, indicating the app's name. Below, a connection section labeled "Connection" is framed with a green outline for emphasis.

Overall, the interface emphasizes user-friendliness and accessibility. 
To stop the VPN tunnel, click 'Disconnect'.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Archives contains the following information: 






︗Archives

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗UMIACS Archives
UMIACS archives data for a period of 5 years.
What we generally do archive:

persistent local data from primary drives on UMIACS-supported machines (Windows/macOS only)
data from accounts that are closed (metadata, network home directories, GitLab repositories, etc.)
data from retired non-scratch, non-project storage spaces (network home directories)
What we generally do not archive:

/tmp and /scratch directories (as discussed on our page about  data storage)
Temporary project directories
External drives that were attached to a UMIACS-supported machine
Data that migrated forward from one UMIACS-supported machine to a new UMIACS-supported machine
Data that was handed off into the care of the end-user or PI via external drive
Data from drives that failed and was not under backup protection (unavailable for us to archive)
Any data from self-supported machines




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Archives&oldid=10970"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/BitLocker contains the following information: 






︗BitLocker

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
See also: BitLocker/PersonalUse if you want to secure an external hard drive with BitLocker.

︗Contents

1 Overview
2 BitLocker at UMIACS

2.1 Recovery Key Prompts
2.2 Temporarily Suspending Bitlocker




︗Overview
BitLocker Drive Encryption is a data protection feature available in all modern versions of Windows. Having BitLocker integrated with the operating system addresses the threats of data theft or exposure from lost, stolen, or inappropriately decommissioned computers.
Data on a lost or stolen computer is vulnerable to unauthorized access, either by running a software-attack tool against it or by transferring the computer's hard disk to a different computer. BitLocker helps mitigate unauthorized data access by enhancing file and system protections. BitLocker also helps render data inaccessible when BitLocker-protected computers are decommissioned or recycled.
Official Microsoft documentation can be found at https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/device-security/bitlocker/bitlocker-overview(The prior text links to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/device-security/bitlocker/bitlocker-overview)

︗BitLocker at UMIACS
All of our supported personal office workstations as well all  enterprise or base-supported laptops and home machines will have BitLocker enabled by UMIACS staff as part of each machine's install process.

︗Recovery Key Prompts
Ordinarily, no interaction should be required with BitLocker to keep it in a functional state. However, a few circumstances may lead to BitLocker detecting changes to the system boot information and prevent the computer from reaching Windows. This is by design.
The image displays a text-based user interface for entering a recovery key for Windows BitLocker Drive Encryption. The background is a solid black, creating a stark contrast with the white text displayed on the screen. At the top, "Windows BitLocker Drive Encryption Recovery Key Entry" is prominently displayed, indicating that users need to authenticate access to a BitLocker-protected drive. Below that, there's a prompt reading "Enter the recovery key for this drive," followed by a series of blank boxes labeled as "Drive Label" and "Recovery Key ID" where the user is expected to input information.

The instructions specify using the function keys (F1 - F9) to input digits 1 through 9 and the F10 key for 0. Additionally, it mentions utilizing the TAB, SHIFT-TAB, HOME, and ARROW keys for navigation within the input fields, while the UP and DOWN ARROW keys can modify previously entered digits. At the bottom, the options "ENTER=Continue" and "ESC=Exit" suggest actions for the user following their input. This interface highlights the importance of entering the correct recovery key to regain access to the encrypted drive.
Some factors that may cause this (not exhaustive):

BIOS or firmware updates -- some manufacturer automatic driver update utilities include these by default - beware!
DVDs or USB drives inserted or plugged in during boot
Malware on the system
The first step should always be to disconnect any external devices and then power the machine off and back on. This ensures that the hardware configuration of the machine is the same as it was when UMIACS staff initially enabled BitLocker. If the prompt still pops up, please contact UMIACS staff for further troubleshooting.

︗Temporarily Suspending Bitlocker
In the event that you encounter the recovery screen above, after booting back into Windows, follow these steps to ensure the prompt does not appear on subsequent reboots. The first two steps can also be taken proactively if you know you will be making a change that affects BitLocker. (see above)

Search for BitLocker in the Start menu and click on "Manage BitLocker".
The image depicts a Windows operating system interface displaying the "Start" menu with a focus on managing BitLocker drive encryption. The left side of the image shows the vertical taskbar with a dark background, featuring a home icon at the top, which indicates the user is accessing the main menu. The text area includes a search bar with the term "Bitlocker" entered.

In the results section, the item labeled "Manage BitLocker" is highlighted in blue, signaling it as the top choice for user selection, with an accompanying icon resembling a lock, indicating security features. Below that, a secondary line states "Control panel," identifying the location of this option. The settings below the main option include "Change device encryption settings," providing additional functionality related to data security. 

The right side of the image has a lighter background, distinguishing it from the taskbar for clarity. This compact layout emphasizes user accessibility to the BitLocker management functions pertinent to data encryption, crucial for protecting sensitive information on their devices.
Click "Suspend protection" on the Operating system drive and hit yes to the confirmation prompt.
The image depicts a user interface from a Windows operating system, specifically showcasing BitLocker management for the operating system drive (C:). At the top, the section is labeled "Operating system drive" in a clear, bold font, immediately identifying the context of the display. Below this title is the designation "OSDisk (C:)" accompanied by a small icon that symbolically represents a hard drive with a padlock, indicating that BitLocker encryption is active. This visual element reinforces the security aspect of the drive.

Directly under the drive label, features related to BitLocker are presented as clickable options. The phrase "BitLocker on" is also displayed, highlighting that encryption is enabled. Three icons represent actionable tasks: "Suspend protection," depicted by a padlock icon with a line through it, suggesting a temporary disabling; "Back up your recovery key," emphasized with a shield icon, indicating a protective measure; and "Turn off BitLocker," represented by another shield icon but with a more explicit warning connotation. This layout is designed for user accessibility, making it easy to manage encryption settings while ensuring that sensitive information is well-guarded.The image depicts a Windows pop-up dialog box concerning BitLocker Drive Encryption. The background of the dialog is white, contrasted by a light blue title bar displaying "BitLocker Drive Encryption" in bold text. Below the title, a clear message reads: "Do you want to suspend BitLocker protection?" This prompt indicates the potential risks of suspending protection, stating that "your data won't be protected" and explaining situations where this might be necessary, such as updates to firmware, hardware, or the operating system. 

Two buttons are visible at the bottom of the dialog box: a blue rectangular button labeled "Yes" on the left and another labeled "No" on the right, allowing users to make their choice. The overall design is clean and straightforward, facilitating user comprehension of the consequences of suspending BitLocker protection, with a focus on security implications. The message's phrasing conveys urgency about the need for careful consideration before proceeding, emphasizing the importance of data protection.
If you are doing something to the computer that would ordinarily trigger BitLocker recovery, perform that operation now. Then after you boot back into Windows, click "Resume protection".
The image displays a user interface from a Windows operating system related to the management of BitLocker Drive Encryption. The screen has a light background that enhances readability. At the top, the title "Operating system drive" is prominently featured, followed directly below by "OSDisk (C:)" which indicates the drive being managed. A small icon of a padlock over a hard disk further illustrates that BitLocker is currently enabled.

Underneath this label, a clear warning states "BitLocker suspended," marked by a yellow triangle icon that signifies caution. Below this information, three clickable options are presented, each accompanied by relevant icons. The first option, "Resume protection," represented by a shield icon, suggests re-enabling BitLocker protections. The second option, "Back up your recovery key," is illustrated by another shield icon and promotes data security. The final option, "Turn off BitLocker," uses a warning icon and explicitly suggests that users should consider the implications before proceeding. This interface provides an accessible layout for users managing encryption settings, emphasizing security measures for sensitive data.
BitLocker will resume and commit the current boot configuration.
The image shows a Windows operating system interface focused on managing BitLocker Drive Encryption settings for the operating system drive, labeled as "OSDisk (C:)" in clear, bold font. The section prominently indicates that BitLocker is activated, as seen with the message "BitLocker on" situated directly below the drive label. An icon illustrates a hard drive with a padlock, symbolizing active encryption. 

Beneath this header, three clickable options are presented, each with specific icons: "Suspend protection," represented by a padlock with a line through it, suggesting a temporary deactivation; "Back up your recovery key," illustrated by a shield icon, emphasizing protective measures; and "Turn off BitLocker," represented by another shield icon that carries a cautionary undertone, urging users to consider the consequences of disabling encryption. 

The overall layout is user-friendly, with a clean and organized design, enhancing accessibility to important encryption management functions, which are critical for safeguarding sensitive data stored on the device.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BitLocker&oldid=11219"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/FTP/Windows/Explorer contains the following information: 






︗FTP/Windows/Explorer

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
FTP services can be accessed from supported Windows machines. This is a guide on how to access the UMIACS FTP service using Windows Explorer.

︗Opening up Windows Explorer
To open up Windows Explorer, click the folder icon on the taskbar on the bottom of your desktop.

The image features a section of a Windows desktop taskbar, primarily showcasing the folder icon highlighted in red. The taskbar has a sleek, light blue background accentuated by a slight gradient. To the left, an icon representing the Windows start menu appears, recognizable by the four green, blue, yellow, and red blocks forming a window shape. Next to it, there's an Internet Explorer icon, characterized by its blue 'e' within a circular swirl, indicating web browsing capabilities. The overall layout suggests a typical Windows interface, with the highlighted folder icon indicating the user's point of interaction to open the Windows Explorer application. This icon is prominently located in the center of the taskbar and symbolizes file management on Windows, representing access to files and folders on the system. The arrangement of these elements demonstrates an intuitive design for user navigation on a Windows machine. Windows - Click "File/Windows Explorer" 
Alternatively, click on the Start menu, and type in "Windows Explorer" in the search box (For Windows 10, type "File Explorer").

The image shows a Windows 7 Start menu interface with a search function prominently displayed at the bottom. The text box at the bottom indicates that the user has typed “windows explorer.” In the main section of the menu, the only visible program in the list is “Windows Explorer,” which is highlighted. The program icon is a blue folder, indicating file management capabilities. 

The interface has a light gray background, typical of Windows, and the text is displayed in a standard font. At the bottom right, the “Log off” button is present, facilitating user session management. In the bottom left corner, there is a visual representation of the Windows logo, alongside an Internet Explorer icon characterized by a stylized blue 'e' within a circular swirl, indicating the availability of web browsing. The overall design conveys a clean, user-friendly navigation system aimed at efficiently locating programs and features on a Windows machine. Windows - Click "File/Windows Explorer" 
︗Accessing Public Folder in FTP
In the address bar, type in the following address to access users' public folders:

\\umiacs-webftp\ftp-umiacs\pub\<username>
The image displays a Windows Explorer address bar showcasing the path to an FTP public folder. The path reads, "\\umiacs-webftp\ftp-umiacs\pub\<username>", where "<username>" is highlighted with a red arrow indicating the user-centric focus. The background is a soft light blue, typical of Windows Explorer, providing a clean and professional appearance. 

On the left side of the address bar, there is a folder icon symbolizing the current directory location. To the right of this icon, several function buttons are visible, including “Organize,” which implies options for file management, “Burn,” likely for creating discs, and “New folder,” suggesting an ability to create new directories within the current path. The overall layout emphasizes user accessibility and navigational ease, indicating that the user is positioned to access a specific public folder on the UMIACS FTP server. This visual presentation not only illustrates the functional aspect of connecting to FTP but also communicates a straightforward directory management system inherent to Windows products. Windows - Enter FTP public folder address in the address bar 
External collaborators can only download files published by the owner. Owner of the public folder can publish and modify files from a supported Windows machine.
Alternatively, collaborators can access public folders through web browser. 
Open up a web browser. In the address bar, type in the following address:

ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/<username>/ - to access users' public folders.
The image features a web browser's address bar prominently displaying the FTP URL `ftp://ftp.umiacs.umd.edu/pub/<username>`. The address bar is located at the top of the browser window, characterized by a light blue color. A red arrow points to the `<username>` placeholder, emphasizing its importance in accessing specific user folders on the FTP server. To the left of the address bar, there is a round back arrow indicating navigation options for the user. Additionally, a tab for the active page can be seen, signifying that this window is currently open. The layout of the address bar suggests an intuitive interface aimed at facilitating user interactions with FTP services. The design conveys a straightforward method for accessing public folders, reinforcing the utility of FTP as a means to share files effectively. Overall, the image encapsulates a familiar web browsing environment, focusing on user accessibility to the UMIACS FTP directory system. Enter FTP public folder address in web browser 
Collaborators can click on file title to download a published file.

The image displays a pop-up window within a web browser, indicating a file download prompt for an Excel worksheet titled "test2.xlsx." The window is titled "Opening test2.xlsx" and provides details that it is an Excel Worksheet of 8.5 KB in size, originating from the FTP server at ftp.umiacs.umd.edu. 

The interface features an interactive option labeled "What should Firefox do with this file?" Below this, three choices are listed: "Open with Microsoft Excel (default)," "Save File," and an additional checkbox reading "Do this automatically for files like this from now on." The prominent use of a soft blue border around the window offers a distinct separation from the browser background. Additionally, the file's name and size are positioned at the top of the dialogue. 

Further down, the current date and time of the last modification for the file are displayed in a simple font. The overall design emphasizes user options for managing downloads efficiently, demonstrating an intuitive approach to file retrieval and application launching in a web-based environment. The background is a pale gradient, enhancing the readability of the text and options presented. Click on file title to download file

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/NautilusThumbnails contains the following information: 






︗NautilusThumbnails

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗None
Open a file browser window.
In the top bar click 'File -> Preferences'
The image displays a computer desktop environment featuring a file manager interface. The background is a gradient of light blue and turquoise, creating a serene atmosphere. On the left side, there is an application menu open, showcasing options such as "New Window," "Sidebar," "Preferences," "Keyboard Shortcuts," and "Quit." These options are set against a light gray background that contrasts with the vibrant hues of the desktop.

In the central area of the image, the file manager window is prominently displayed. It features several icons representing various folders and files. The folder icons are designed in a simplistic beige color, giving a clean, organized appearance. There are also several file icons represented as purple diamonds, indicating different types of documents or applications. The window has a title bar that labels it as "Home," suggesting that the user is exploring their home directory.

The layout demonstrates ease of navigation, with clearly defined sections for user folders like "Documents," "Downloads," and "Desktop." Overall, the image conveys a user-friendly interface typical of modern computing environments.
Navigate to the 'Search & Preview' tab.
The image displays a user interface for application preferences, specifically focused on the "Search & Preview" tab. The layout is clean and organized, featuring a rectangular dialog box against a light gray background that allows for easy readability. 

At the top, three tabs are visible: "Views," "Behavior," and "List Columns," with "Search & Preview" highlighted, indicating this is the active section. In the main body of the dialog, there are three distinct sections labeled "Search," "Thumbnails," and "File count."

The "Search" section includes an option to configure the search scope, with radio buttons for choices like "On this computer only," "All locations," and "Never."

Below that, the "Thumbnails" section provides options to control thumbnail display. It includes choices like "Files on this computer only," "All files," and "Never," along with a parameter that allows files smaller than 10 MB to be shown when selected.

Lastly, the "File count" section offers options to count files within folders, with similar radio button choices as above. Overall, the layout conveys a user-friendly interface typical of modern software settings, prioritizing convenience and accessibility.
Under the thumbnails section select 'Never'.
Exit the window.
︗Clean up existing thumbnail files
Thumbnails are stored in the following directory:

~/.cache/thumbnails/
Removing that directory will clean up the thumbnails.

︗Checking Thumbnail space usage
The following command shows the current disk space utilization of the thumbnails:

du -sh ~/.cache/thumbnails/

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Perl/Environment contains the following information: 






︗Perl/Environment

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
We recommend using local::lib to create your own directory of Perl packages downloaded from CPAN.  This will create an isolated collection of packages, that will not affect the system version of Perl.  This allows users to quickly bootstrap a local Perl Module library.


︗Contents

1 Creating an Environment
2 Module Management

2.1 Installing Modules
2.2 Listing Installed Modules


3 Creating additional Environments


︗Creating an Environment
You will first need to download a copy of local::lib. This can be found by searching local::lib at http://search.cpan.org/(The prior text links to http://search.cpan.org/)
Decompress and extract the package:
-bash-3.2$ gunzip local-lib-2.000019.tar.gz
-bash-3.2$ tar xvf local-lib-2.000019.tar

Configure and then install the environment:
-bash-3.2$ cd local-lib-2.000019
-bash-3.2$ perl Makefile.PL --bootstrap
-bash-3.2$ make test && make install

Add the newly created environment to your initialization scripts.  After this step is complete, you will need to start a new shell.
echo 'eval $(perl -I$HOME/perl5/lib/perl5 -Mlocal::lib)' >>~/.bashrc
Note: Depending on your current initialization script setup, you may need to add the line generated by the above command to your .bash_profile as well. (Or the tcsh equivalent)

︗Module Management
︗Installing Modules
Once your environment has been created and properly sourced, you can then install packages with cpan as your normally would:

-bash-3.2$ cpan -i Date::Tolkien::Shire;

For more information on module installation, see  http://www.cpan.org/modules/INSTALL.html(The prior text links to http://www.cpan.org/modules/INSTALL.html)

︗Listing Installed Modules
The following command will list all the Perl Modules installed in the currently sourced environment:

-bash-3.2$ perldoc perllocal

︗Creating additional Environments
By default your environment will be created in the ~/perl5 directory.  It is possible to create multiple environments by specifying a directory in when building the environment:

-bash-3.2$ cd local-lib-2.000019
-bash-3.2$ perl Makefile.PL --bootstrap=/Path/to/Second/Environment
-bash-3.2$ make test && make install

It is important to keep in mind that you will need to adjust the line in your initialization scrips to reflect the location of the Environment you wish to use.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Perl/Environment&oldid=7047"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SecureShellTunneling contains the following information: 






︗SecureShellTunneling

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Port Forwarding

1.1 OpenSSH
1.2 PuTTY


2 SOCKS Proxy

2.1 OpenSSH
2.2 PuTTY
2.3 Example: SOCKS proxy, Browser configuration




︗Port Forwarding
︗OpenSSH
When you want to just forward a specific port locally to a remote port with Linux or macOS systems.   


This example will create a local port 9999 that will be forwarded to the remote host webserver.umiacs.umd.edu and its port 8000 through the host nexusclip00.umiacs.umd.edu.
        ssh -NfL 9999:webserver.umiacs.umd.edu:8000 nexusclip00.umiacs.umd.edu

This example will create a local port 13389 that will be forwarded to a remote host that is running a RDP client like Windows through the host nexusclip00.umiacs.umd.edu
        ssh -L 13389:my-desktop.ad.umiacs.umd.edu:3389 nexusclip00.umiacs.umd.edu

The following example outlines how to use SSH tunnel for printing to the UMIACS CUPS server.
        ssh $<USERNAME>@nexusclip00.umiacs.umd.edu -T -N -L 3631:print.umiacs.umd.edu:631

Once the tunnel is established you can follow the normal  Printing instructions substitution 'print.umiacs.umd.edu' for 'localhost:3631', or print via the a command such as the following:
        lpr -H 127.0.0.1:3631 -P $<PRINTER NAME> $<FILENAME>


︗PuTTY
Windows users can achieve the same types of tunnels using PuTTY or a similar SSH client. In PuTTY, the port forwarding configuration dialogue can be found under "Connection>SSH>Tunnels".
The image depicts the PuTTY configuration interface on a Windows operating system, specifically focusing on the settings for SSH port forwarding. 

In the left pane, multiple categories are listed under "Category" such as "Keyboard," "Bell," "Features," and several others related to connection settings. The "Connection" category is expanded, highlighting options for "Data," "Proxy," "Telnet," "Rlogin," and "SSH" settings.

The main area displays "Options controlling SSH port forwarding." Here, specific options allow the user to configure forwarding settings. There is a checkbox for "Local ports accept connections from other hosts" and another for "Remote ports do the same (SSH-2 only)." Below, the section labeled "Forwarded ports" lists a port forwarding entry marked "L8888," indicating a local forwarding setup to the remote destination "clipsm301.umiacs.umd.edu:8000."

Further down, a section titled "Add new forwarded port" contains fields for the "Source port" set to "8889" and the "Destination," which is configured to "clipsm301.umiacs.umd.edu:8000." At the bottom, there are options for selecting the address type (Auto, IPv4, or IPv6) and buttons labeled "Open," "Cancel," and "Add."

The interface is rich in visual detail, with a color scheme typical of Windows applications, primarily blue and white, and the layout is organized for ease of user navigation.
This example will create a local port 8889 that is attached to the remote host clipsm301.umiacs.umd.edu on its port 8000.

︗SOCKS Proxy
︗OpenSSH
SSH can also tunnel all traffic coming into a certain port through a SOCKS v5 proxy.  Many browsers and some operating systems can be setup to then connect to this proxy to allow them again to look like they are coming from the host name you specify in your SSH command. 

ssh -ND 7777 nexusclip00.umiacs.umd.edu
Please note: when you configure proxy settings for a browser (or your whole operating system) all the traffic for that browser (or the OS) will be sent through the proxy.  This can have performance implications.

︗PuTTY
Windows users can tunnel traffic coming into a certain port through a SOCKS v5 proxy by using PuTTY or a similar SSH client. Many browsers and some operating systems can be setup to connect to this proxy to allow them to look like they are coming from the host name you specify.
In PuTTY under Sessions set the Host Name:
The image depicts the PuTTY configuration window on a Windows operating system, showcasing the options available for setting up a new SSH session. The primary focus is on the "Session" category, clearly outlined on the left pane, which includes additional subcategories such as "Logging," "Terminal," "Keyboard," and others.

At the top, the main area directs users to specify the "Host Name (or IP address)" and the port number—set to "22" by default. Below this, the "Connection type" is indicated as SSH, with options for Raw, Telnet, and Rlogin also visible. 

A section for "Saved Sessions" allows users to manage previously stored sessions, with "Default Settings" highlighted and options to Load, Save, or Delete stored configurations. The window features common Windows UI elements, including buttons labeled "Open," "Cancel," and "Help" at the bottom. 

The overall design includes a primarily white and light gray color scheme, with blue accents, typical of many Windows applications, emphasizing clarity and ease of navigation. The layout effectively supports user interaction for configuring SSH connections.
Then under Connection > SSH > Tunnels enter a port number and set the type of forwarding to "Dynamic" and press add:
The image depicts the PuTTY configuration interface on a Windows operating system, specifically for SSH port forwarding. The left pane lists several categories, including "Terminal," "Window," and "Connection," with the "Connection" section expanded to reveal subcategories like "Data," "Proxy," and "SSH." The main area of the interface focuses on the "Options controlling SSH port forwarding."

Here, the "Port forwarding" section contains two checkboxes: one labeled "Local ports accept connections from other hosts" and another for "Remote ports do the same (SSH-2 only)." The "Forwarded ports" section indicates an entry for port "D7777," with the option to remove it.

At the bottom, users can add a new forwarded port, with fields labeled "Source port" set to "7777" and "Destination" available for specification. Users can choose the type of destination connection—Local, Remote, or Dynamic—along with selecting the address type (Auto, IPv4, or IPv6). The interface design exhibits a typical Windows color scheme, primarily white and blue, with clearly labeled buttons for "Open," "Cancel," and "Help," facilitating easy navigation for configuration.
Click Open and log into the host.
As long as this PuTTY window is open and you are logged in, you can use the SOCKS proxy.
Please note that when you configure proxy settings for a browser or your whole operating system, all the traffic for that browser or your OS will be sent through the proxy.  This can have performance implications.

︗None
There are too many variations here to cover them all, but they all follow the same general pattern and the following example should be generally applicable. We'll use Firefox for this example. Screenshots are from Firefox 37.0.2.

Under Preferences > Advanced > Network > Connection > Settings..., choose Manually proxy configuration:.
Enter 127.0.0.1 for the proxy.
Enter the port you chose earlier for dynamic forwarding (7777 in the example above).
Check Use this proxy server for all protocols, and then click OK.
NOTE: this will continue to send all browser traffic through your SSH tunnel until the configuration is reverted. The SSH connection must be established for traffic to pass through to the destination network. Firefox has a very useful plugin called "FoxyProxy" that allows conditional proxies to be set up, if you're interested in adding some intelligence/complexity to your proxy configuration.
The image displays the "Advanced" settings of the Firefox browser on a Mac operating system, focusing on the "Network" tab. The layout consists of a white background with a gray header labeled "Advanced," featuring several icons for different settings categories, such as "General," "Data Choices," "Network," "Update," "Certificates," and more. 

In the central area, the "Connection" section offers options to configure how Firefox connects to the Internet, with a button labeled "Settings..." inviting user interaction. Below this, a status message indicates the current web content cache usage, noting a size of 224 MB out of a specified disk space limit, which the user can customize. Options for managing the cache include a "Clear Now" button and a checkbox for overriding automatic cache management with an input field to set the limit.

Further down, there's a segment titled "Offline Web Content and User Data," which indicates that the application cache is currently using 0 bytes, with a button to clear this cache. An informational message suggests a user action if certain web applications prompt for offline storage. Overall, the interface is organized for clarity, with a professional aesthetic typical of macOS applications. The image displays the "Advanced" settings menu of the Firefox browser on a Mac operating system, specifically focusing on network configuration options. The interface includes a light gray header labeled "Advanced" with various icons representing different setting categories like "General," "Data Choices," and "Network." The main section titled "Configure Proxies to Access the Internet" is clearly visible, showcasing several options for setting up network connections.

In this section, radio buttons allow users to select between “No proxy,” “Auto-detect proxy settings for this network,” “Use system proxy settings,” or the highlighted “Manual proxy configuration.” The "Manual proxy configuration" section lists fields for HTTP Proxy, SSL Proxy, FTP Proxy, and SOCKS Host, all set to the local IP address “127.0.0.1,” indicating the use of a local proxy. Each entry includes a corresponding Port field, all set to “7777.” 

Additional options include checkboxes for using the proxy for all protocols and specifying no proxy for certain addresses. Below, there are buttons labeled "Reload" and "OK," facilitating user actions. The overall layout is clean and intuitive, typical of macOS design, ensuring usability and accessibility.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/VS_Code contains the following information: 






︗VS Code

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Visual Studio (VS) Code(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/) is a multi-platform source-code editor developed by Microsoft. It can be used with a variety of programming languages and can have its base functionality extended through extensions available via its marketplace(The prior text links to https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/vscode). The base editor itself is free, but some extensions may require paid subscriptions.

︗Contents

1 Cluster Usage

1.1 Best Practices

1.1.1 Use only as a code editor
1.1.2 Do not open large files
1.1.3 Clean up when done




2 Common Issues


︗Cluster Usage
It can be convenient when using our SLURM computing clusters to open a connection to a VS Code Server(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/vscode-server) session on the submission node(s) that you have access to via VS Code's Remote - SSH extension(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/ssh). Steps to set this up can be found here(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/ssh#_installation). Use your UMIACS username and the fully qualified domain name (FQDN)(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fully_qualified_domain_name) of the submission node you want to connect to. Password authentication does not provide an option to save your password, so for convenience, you may want to set up an  SSH key.
For a list of active issues with the Remote - SSH extension, please see Microsoft's GitHub tracker here(The prior text links to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-remote-release/labels/ssh).

︗Best Practices
Because of the multi-tenant nature of our submission nodes, using the Remote - SSH extension to connect to a VS Code Server running on a submission node can have adverse affects on other users simultaneously using the submission nodes if not properly managed. The following is a list of "best practices" that we ask you please follow to minimize the chance of impacting others on submission nodes. We have compiled the list through observation as well as through discussion with users.

︗Use only as a code editor
VS Code can perform many common file management operations, such as moving, copying, or deleting files or directories. However, the overhead of providing progress updates / status messages through VS Code's UI can cause load spikes that result in other processes on the submission node (both system-level and other users') slowing down. This is especially the case if operating on thousands to millions of small image or video files. In extreme cases, it can seem as though the submission node is wholly unresponsive.
The best way to combat this is to use VS Code as just a code editor as strictly as you can (meaning creating new and/or editing existing source code files only). Use standard command-line programs such as mv/cp/rm in VS Code's terminal window or a separate application's terminal window for local file management instead, or use the techniques advertised  here for larger data transfers between nodes.

︗Do not open large files
Files that you open in VS Code's text editor on a remote machine through the Remote - SSH extension are loaded entirely into RAM on the remote machine. Because of the persistence of VS Code Server processes, opening several unique files may result in them all remaining in RAM for extended periods of time even if you no longer have tabs open for them in the Tab Bar.
As such, please refrain from opening large files (more than a few MB) in VS Code itself on submission nodes. Either use a lighter-weight command-line based text editor such as vim(The prior text links to https://www.vim.org/) or otherwise on the submission node itself, or first  transfer the files that you would like to open to either a less-used remote machine or your local machine before opening them.
If you absolutely need to open one or more large files for a very brief period of time on a submission node, please clean up your server session on that node (see below section) as soon as possible when done.

︗Clean up when done
If you are done using VS Code for an extended period of time (several hours / overnight), consider manually killing your server session on the submission node when exiting. By default, VS Code Server will keep the processes used by your session active for a few hours after you disconnect, keeping the VS Code Server processes on the submission node you were using alive, despite no longer actively being used.
This can be done by opening the Command Palette(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/userinterface#_command-palette) (Ctrl+Shift+P) and searching "Kill VS Code Server on Host...".

The image depicts a visual representation of the Visual Studio Code (VS Code) interface focused on the command palette feature. The top portion shows a search bar with the text “>Kill VS Code Server on Host…”, indicating an action option within the command palette. Below this, the categorized selection highlights the choice "Remote-SSH: Kill VS Code Server on Host..." marked as “recently used.” 

The background features a dark theme typical of coding environments, with shades of gray and blue dominating the color scheme, enhancing visual clarity against the lighter text. The design elements maintain a clean interface, emphasizing functionality with clear categories and readable font size. The overall spatial arrangement conveys a user-friendly experience, allowing quick access to command executions essential for managing the VS Code Server on a host while using the Remote - SSH extension. This image effectively communicates an active coding utility critical for developers working in remote environments.
Select the submission node you were using and click on it.

The image displays a user interface from Visual Studio Code (VS Code), specifically focusing on the command palette feature utilized for connecting to submission nodes. At the top, there's a search input bar partially filled with the text "nexus," indicating an active search query. Below this bar, two connection options are presented in a dark-themed list format. Each option is labeled "nexus" followed by the domains "00.umiacs.umd.edu" and "01.umiacs.umd.edu," visually differentiated with a slightly lighter blue highlight against the dark background. This arrangement facilitates easy recognition and selection for connecting to specific nodes. The overall color scheme features dark gray with blue accents, typical of coding environments, contributing to a clean and user-friendly interface. The design emphasizes readability and navigational efficiency, essential for developers practicing remote integration through the VS Code Remote - SSH extension. This image effectively illustrates a common interaction point for users managing their connections to remote computing resources.
Wait a few seconds and you should get a message confirming the command went through.

The image displays a notification from Visual Studio Code (VS Code) confirming the action of terminating a server session. The message reads "Killed VS Code Server on nexus" followed by the specific node identifier "00.umiacs.umd.edu." The notification is presented in a dark-themed interface, consistent with VS Code's aesthetic, which enhances visibility of the text against the background. On the right side, a button labeled “Open Logs” is visible, indicating the option for users to access log information related to this action. The source of this notification is specified as "Remote - SSH," underlining the context in which the server session was terminated. The overall layout is minimalist, focusing on clarity and immediate feedback for the user. The dark gray and blue color scheme aligns with common design principles in coding environments, promoting a clean and efficient user experience. This image illustrates an essential utility feature, emphasizing user control over remote server management within VS Code.
The next time you connect to the same submission node, you will have a fresh VS Code session on it.

︗Common Issues
If you are having trouble SSH'ing to a submission node with VS Code, check if your home directory is full.

Connect to one of your Nexus submission nodes via SSH not using VS Code.
 Remote connect to a server
Navigate to your home directory. cd ~
Check if it is full. df -h .
If it is full (Avail 0), delete some files to free up at least ~100MB of space. Filesystem                                    Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
data.isilon.umiacs.umd.edu:/ifs/umiacs/homes   30G   30G     0 100% /fs/nfshomes
Try connecting with VS Code again.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=VS_Code&oldid=11945"

Privacy policy

(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Network/Troubleshooting/DNS contains the following information: 






︗Network/Troubleshooting/DNS

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
We have experienced a number of issues in the past with home internet providers not correctly handling DNS resolution for UMIACS hostnames. This can affect connectivity to UMIACS.
In the face of this, here are a few last-resort options for bypassing problematic DNS services.

︗Contents

1 Google DNS
2 OpenDNS
3 How to change your default DNS servers
4 Manual Lookup


︗Google DNS(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Public_DNS)
IP Addresses:

8.8.8.8
8.8.4.4
︗OpenDNS(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenDNS)
IP Addresses:

208.67.222.222
208.67.220.220
208.67.222.220
208.67.220.222
︗How to change your default DNS servers
Windows:
Go to Control Panel -> Network and Internet -> Network and Sharing Center.
Click "Change adapter settings" on the left.
Right click on the network adapter you're using, choose "Properties" from the context menu.
Select "Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4)" and click on the "Properties" button.
If not selected, choose "Use the following DNS server addresses:"
Enter the public DNS addresses you desire to use.
Click OK, and close the remaining windows.
macOS: System Settings > Network > Wi-Fi/Ethernet > Details > DNS
Linux: Edit your /etc/resolv.conf file and change the IP addresses after "nameserver" to any of those listed above.
︗Manual Lookup
If you are having problems getting to UMIACS hosts, you can use our name servers to resolve those specific host names and then connect using the IP addresses you lookup. Our name servers are 128.8.120.19, 128.8.120.50, and 128.8.132.75. To use this information to get the IP address of the host somehost.umiacs.umd.edu, you would use the command nslookup somehost.umiacs.umd.edu 128.8.120.19, from a Windows, macOS, or Linux command prompt / terminal.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Network/Troubleshooting/DNS&oldid=11515"
