〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms contains the following information: 






︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Types of Rooms
2 Common Tasks
3 Viewing
4 Scheduling
5 Room Capabilities


︗Types of Rooms
 Moderated Rooms
These seminar and large conference areas must have reservations accepted by the designated moderator(s) for the room. They have room PCs, so bringing your own device is not required to use the display.
 Auto-Accept Rooms
These 6-12 person rooms will automatically accept reservations without requiring moderation. They have room PCs, so bringing your own device is not required to use the display.
 Huddle Rooms
These 1-3 person rooms can only be reserved at the touch panel. They cannot be scheduled ahead of time through Google Calendar. They do not have room PCs, so you must bring your own device to use the display.
︗Common Tasks
 Viewing one or more rooms
 Reserving a room
 [For moderators] Approving a room request
 [For moderators] Enabling notifications for pending requests
︗Viewing
Conference room availability can be  viewed with UMD’s Google Calendar system or from a touch panel outside each individual room.  The touch panel quickly allows you to see the status of the room: red if the room is reserved right now and green if it is open.
We also offer a list of conference rooms scheduled with the UMD Google Calendar system.

︗Scheduling
Conference rooms are  reserved with UMD’s Google Calendar system along with a touch panel outside the room.  The touch panel quickly allows you to see the status of the room: red if the room is reserved right now and green if it is open.  You can walk up to the panel and reserve the room if it is unoccupied within the next 12 hours (non-moderated rooms only).

︗Room Capabilities
Our conference rooms have different AV capabilities depending on what equipment each specific room is equipped with (which is generally based on the size of the room).  In all rooms, you should at a minimum be able to either plug in your laptop to display to the projector and screen(s), or use the  Solstice Mersive Pod found in each room to display wirelessly.
Topics:

 Using the Touch Panel
 Using the Solstice Mersive Pods
 Recording and Streaming
 Using Zoom




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Iribe/ConferenceRooms&oldid=10707"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SLURM/JobStatus contains the following information: 






︗SLURM/JobStatus

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Job Status

1.1 squeue
1.2 sstat
1.3 sacct


2 Job Codes


︗Job Status
SLURM offers a variety of tools to check the status of your jobs before, during, and after execution. When you first submit your job, SLURM should give you a job ID which represents the resources allocated to your job. Individual calls to srun will spawn job steps which can also be queried individually.

︗squeue
The squeue command shows job status in the queue. Helpful flags:

-u username to show only your jobs (replace username with your UMIACS username)
--start to estimate start time for a job that has not yet started and the reason why it is waiting
-s to show the status of individual job steps for a job (e.g. batch jobs)
Examples:

[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ squeue -u username
             JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
               162      tron helloWor username  R       0:03      2 tron[00-01]

[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ squeue --start -u username
             JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST          START_TIME  NODES SCHEDNODES           NODELIST(REASON)
               163      tron helloWo2 username PD 2020-05-11T18:36:49      1 tron02               (Priority)

[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ squeue -s -u username
         STEPID     NAME PARTITION     USER      TIME NODELIST
          162.0    sleep      tron username      0:05 tron00
          162.1    sleep      tron username      0:05 tron01

︗sstat
The sstat command shows metrics from currently running job steps. If you don't specify a job step, the lowest job step is displayed.

sstat --format JobID,NTasks,nodelist,MaxRSS,MaxVMSize,AveRSS,AveVMSize <$JOBID>.<$JOBSTEP>

[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ sstat --format JobID,NTasks,nodelist,MaxRSS,MaxVMSize,AveRSS,AveVMSize 171
       JobID   NTasks             Nodelist     MaxRSS  MaxVMSize     AveRSS  AveVMSize 
------------ -------- -------------------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- 
171.0               1               tron00          0    186060K          0    107900K 
[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ sstat --format JobID,NTasks,nodelist,MaxRSS,MaxVMSize,AveRSS,AveVMSize 171.1
       JobID   NTasks             Nodelist     MaxRSS  MaxVMSize     AveRSS  AveVMSize 
------------ -------- -------------------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- 
171.1               1               tron01          0    186060K          0    107900K 

Note that if you do not have any jobsteps, sstat will return an error.

[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ sstat --format JobID,NTasks,nodelist,MaxRSS,MaxVMSize,AveRSS,AveVMSize 172
       JobID   NTasks             Nodelist     MaxRSS  MaxVMSize     AveRSS  AveVMSize 
------------ -------- -------------------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ----------
sstat: error: no steps running for job 237

If you do not run any srun commands, you will not create any job steps and metrics will not be available for your job. Your batch scripts should follow this format:

#!/bin/bash
#SBATCH ...
#SBATCH ...
# set environment up
module load ...

# launch job steps
srun <command to run> # that would be step 1
srun <command to run> # that would be step 2

︗sacct
The sacct command shows metrics from past jobs.

[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ sacct
       JobID    JobName  Partition    Account  AllocCPUS      State ExitCode 
------------ ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- -------- 
162          helloWorld       tron      nexus          2  COMPLETED      0:0 
162.batch         batch                 nexus          1  COMPLETED      0:0 
162.0             sleep                 nexus          1  COMPLETED      0:0 
162.1             sleep                 nexus          1  COMPLETED      0:0 
163          helloWorld       tron      nexus          2  COMPLETED      0:0 
163.batch         batch                 nexus          1  COMPLETED      0:0 
163.0             sleep                 nexus          1  COMPLETED      0:0 

To check one specific job, you can run something like the following (if you omit .<$JOBSTEP>, all jobsteps will be shown):

sacct  --format JobID,jobname,NTasks,nodelist,MaxRSS,MaxVMSize,AveRSS,AveVMSize,Elapsed -j <$JOBID>.<$JOBSTEP>
[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ sacct --format JobID,jobname,NTasks,nodelist,MaxRSS,MaxVMSize,AveRSS,AveVMSize,Elapsed -j 171
       JobID    JobName   NTasks        NodeList     MaxRSS  MaxVMSize     AveRSS  AveVMSize    Elapsed 
------------ ---------- -------- --------------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- ---------- 
171          helloWorld              tron[00-01]                                               00:00:30 
171.batch         batch        1          tron00          0    119784K          0    113120K   00:00:30 
171.0             sleep        1          tron00          0    186060K          0    107900K   00:00:30 
171.1             sleep        1          tron01          0    186060K          0    107900K   00:00:30 

︗Job Codes
If you list the current running jobs and your job is in PD (Pending), SLURM will provide you some information on what the reason for this in the NODELIST parameter.  You can use scontrol show job <jobid> to get all the parameters for your job to help identify why your job is not running.

[username@nexusclip00 ~]$ squeue -u username
JOBID  PARTITION     NAME     USER     ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
1           tron     bash     username PD       0:00      1 (AssocGrpGRES)
2           tron     bash     username PD       0:00      1 (Resources)
3           tron     bash     username PD       0:00      1 (Priority)
4           tron     bash     username PD       0:00      1 (QOSMaxGRESPerUser)
5           tron     bash     username PD       0:00      1 (ReqNodeNotAvail, Reserved for maintenance)

Some common ones are as follows:

Resources - The cluster does not currently have the resources to fit your job in your selected partition.
Priority - The cluster has reserved resources for higher  priority jobs in your selected partition.
QOSMax*PerUser or QOSMax*PerUserLimit - The quality of service (QoS) your job is requesting to use has some limit per user (CPU, mem, GRES, etc.).  Use show_qos and show_partition_qos to identify the limit(s) and then use scontrol show job <jobid> for each of your jobs running in that QoS to see the resources they are currently consuming.
AssocGrpBilling - The SLURM account you are using has a limit on the overall billing amount available in total for the account.  Use sacctmgr show assoc account=<accountname> where user= to identify the limit, replacing <accountname> with the account you are submitting your job with.  You can see all jobs running under the account and their billing values by running squeue -A <accountname> -O "JobId:.18 ,Partition:.9 ,Name:.8 ,UserName:.8 ,StateCompact:.2 ,TimeUsed:.10 ,NumNodes:.6 ,ReasonList:45 ,tres-alloc:80". The billing value will be part of the tres-alloc string for each job.
ReqNodeNotAvail - None of the nodes that could run your job (based on requested partition/resources) currently have the resources to fit your job.  Alternatively, if you also see Reserved for maintenance, there is a reservation in place (often for a  maintenance window).  You can see the current reservations by running scontrol show reservation.  Often the culprit is that you have requested a TimeLimit that will conflict with the reservation.  You can either lower your TimeLimit such that the job will complete before the reservation begins, or leave your job to wait until the reservation completes.
SLURM's full list of reasons/explanations can be found here(The prior text links to https://slurm.schedmd.com/job_reason_codes.html).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=SLURM/JobStatus&oldid=12005"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Java contains the following information: 






︗Java

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Java can be obtained in one of two flavors: Java Runtime Environment (JRE) or Java Development Kit (JDK). Unless you do programming in Java, JRE is usually sufficient for running programs and applets written in Java. JRE is also included in JDK so there is no need to install both.  There are two main flavors of Java that we have support for Oracle Java(The prior text links to http://www.oracle.com/us/technologies/java/overview/index.html) and OpenJDK(The prior text links to http://openjdk.java.net/).

︗None
The version of Java running can be checked by running the following command on any RHEL/Ubuntu machine. Alternative JDK and JRE options can be found in /usr/lib/jvm. bash-4.2$ java -version
︗Windows
JRE is installed on all supported workstations by default and auto-updated to the latest version periodically. If for some reason your machine does not have Java, you may send a request to staff(The prior text links to mailto:staff@umiacs.umd.edu) to have JRE or JDK installed on your machine.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Java&oldid=7145"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/RHEL contains the following information: 






︗RHEL7

From UMIACS
(Redirected from RHEL)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Red Hat Enterprise Linux(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux) 7 is an operating system published by Red Hat, Inc., which is currently a subsidiary of IBM.

︗Contents

1 Features
2 Kernel and Performance
3 Virtualization
4 File System Capabilities
5 Security


︗Features
A summary of important improvements are listed below.

︗Kernel and Performance
Based on Linux 3.10.0-957 kernel.
Initial process is changed to systemd.
Includes Security-Enhanced Linux(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security-Enhanced_Linux).
︗Virtualization
Users can run virtual machines within RHEL 7 using its built-in Kernel-based Virtual Machine(The prior text links to https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html/virtualization_getting_started_guide/chap-virtualization_getting_started-products), or KVM. UMIACS also supports the use of Apptainer, a container application that is an alternative to Docker.

︗File System Capabilities
The default file system is now XFS. Here is an overview of the supported file systems in RHEL7. The information in this section is taken from this Redhat page(The prior text links to https://access.redhat.com/articles/796293) unless otherwise noted.

XFS(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XFS)
"[RHEL7] supports XFS filesystem sizes of up to 500 TB."
"XFS supports journaling to minimize data loss in the event of a system crash. Journal data are written to the log section while the file system is active and read when the filesystem is mounted (to recover any data not already written to disk)."
ext4(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ext4)
"The maximum standalone filesystem size for ext4 filesystems...[is]...50 TB."
Btrfs(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Btrfs)
This an "an unsupported Technology Preview," and should be used with caution.
︗Security
In addition to the standard Linux security architecture, RHEL7 includes Security-Enhanced Linux(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security-Enhanced_Linux), a module which implements a mandatory access control(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandatory_access_control) model. Tutorials for configuring SELinux in RHEL are available here(The prior text links to https://access.redhat.com/articles/217213).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=RHEL7&oldid=11278"

︗None

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Windows_Activation contains the following information: 






︗Windows Activation

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Windows Licensing
Windows uses an activation model for each UMD-licensed install. The installs will have to verify activation every 180 days. Activation and renewal is performed via the campus Key Management Server KMS, which is not available from off campus. For onsite desktops, this is not a problem. However, for laptops or home machines it poses a complication. As long as the laptop or home machine is periodically on the campus wireless or connects to the UMIACS or campus VPN, renewal activation will be performed automatically.
You must only use the below procedure on University owned hardware.
Please follow the below steps if you are receiving a message that your license is going to expire soon or that Windows is not activated.

︗Activation
Please note that you need to be connected to either the wired campus network, campus WiFi, the campus VPN(The prior text links to https://terpware.umd.edu/Windows/Title/4010), or the  UMIACS VPN to activate. The below steps assume you have already established a network connection. Please also note that your time must be correct (i.e. set via the Internet) and set to the US Eastern timezone for this to work. You can try running w32tm /resync on the command line below in step 4 before running the other commands listed in that step to resync your time if the commands fail at first.

Click on the Start menu and type "cmd" in the run bar.
The image depicts a Windows 10 search interface, focusing on the search bar where the user has typed “cmd.” This search action reveals the “Best match” results on the left side, prominently highlighting the command prompt application (cmd) with a black icon beside the name. The title indicates it can be run as a command. Below the application title, there are several options: "Open," "Run as administrator," and "Open file location." 

In the background, the desktop shows various application icons like MATLAB, VLC media player, and others, suggesting a busy user environment. The overall color scheme is a combination of dark blues and whites typical of Windows 10, with a clean and modern layout. The taskbar at the bottom contains the Windows logo and application shortcuts, demonstrating a responsive, organized workspace. The emphasis on running CMD as administrator signals the need for elevated permissions, aligning with the context of following specific steps in the activation process outlined in the accompanying text.
Right-Click on the cmd button, and select "Run as Administrator" - THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT!
The image features the Windows 10 search interface prominently displaying the user interface where "cmd" has been entered into the search bar. On the left side of the screen, the results list identifies "cmd" (the Command Prompt) as the "Best match" with a black icon alongside. Below it, options to "Open," "Run as administrator," and "Open file location" are clearly visible, emphasizing the importance of elevated permissions for activation tasks.

In the background, the desktop environment displays multiple application icons, including MATLAB and VLC Media Player, indicating an active workspace. The desktop is primarily characterized by a modern color scheme featuring dark blues contrasted with white text, typical of Windows 10. The taskbar at the bottom is visible, showcasing the Windows logo and various application shortcuts, which enhances the organized nature of the user's digital environment. The overall layout reflects a clean, functional setup, where the user is likely preparing to execute command-line operations essential for the Windows activation process.
Select "Yes" if you get a prompt to allow the following program to make changes.
The image shows a User Account Control (UAC) dialog box from a Windows operating system. The box has a yellow-orange background, alerting the user to a security prompt. The dialog asks, "Do you want to allow this app from an unknown publisher to make changes to your device?" indicating that an action requiring administrative privileges is being initiated.

The title of the dialog box reads "User Account Control," while the app attempting to gain permissions is identified as "cmd.exe." Below this, it states, "Publisher: Unknown" and "File origin: Hard drive on this computer," implying that the command prompt application is being activated from the local system without verified origin credentials.

At the bottom of the dialog, there are two buttons: "Yes," on the left, which allows the operation to proceed, and "No," on the right, which would cancel the request. The option to "Show more details" is available, providing the user an opportunity to learn further about the application. The design aligns with typical Windows interface elements, emphasizing the importance of careful decision-making regarding software permissions.
From the Command Prompt, run these commands in order:
Windows 10/11:cscript c:\windows\system32\slmgr.vbs -skms kms.umd.edu:1688
cscript c:\windows\system32\slmgr.vbs -ipk NPPR9-FWDCX-D2C8J-H872K-2YT43
cscript c:\windows\system32\slmgr.vbs -ato
The image shows a Command Prompt window on a Windows operating system, highlighted with the header “Administrator: Command Prompt.” The text indicates the Windows version (10.0.18362.719) and includes the Microsoft copyright notice. The commands executed in the prompt are shown in sequential order, indicating steps taken for Windows activation.

1. The first command is `cscript c:\windows\system32\slmgr.vbs -skms kms.umd.edu:1688`, which sets the Key Management Service (KMS) address. Beneath this, a confirmation message indicates that the KMS machine has been set successfully.

2. The second command, `cscript c:\windows\system32\slmgr.vbs -ipk NPPR9-FWDCX-D2C8J-H872K-2YT43`, shows that a product key was installed successfully.

3. The third command, `cscript c:\windows\system32\slmgr.vbs -ato`, activates Windows, with a message confirming successful activation of the Enterprise edition.

The text is primarily white against a black background, representing typical Command Prompt aesthetics. The screen conveys a successful series of activation steps, essential for university-managed devices, with an overall sense of completion and functionality.
After these commands have run, the Key Management Server should have activated your Windows computer. You can also run: cscript c:\windows\system32\slmgr.vbs -xpr to see when the current activation expires.
The image shows a Windows Script Host dialog box prominently displayed in a simple, white interface. The title bar identifies the dialog as “Windows Script Host,” indicating a system message related to software activation. Centered within the box is critical information: it specifies that the operating system is “Windows(R), Enterprise edition,” which confirms the version in use. Below this, a warning text states, “Volume activation will expire 5/8/2022 1:53:07 PM,” providing a clear deadline for users regarding the activation status.

The layout includes a single button labeled “OK” at the bottom right, encouraging the user to acknowledge the message. The overall color scheme is minimalistic, with black text against a light background, allowing for easy readability. The informational tone of the dialog suggests urgency for the user to address the activation issue before the specified expiration date, reflecting the necessity of compliance for continued use of the software.
If you are unable to activate, please see the message at the top of this section. If you are still unable to activate, and the computer you are attempting to activate is owned by the Institute for Advanced Computer Studies, please contact  UMIACS staff with information about your problem. Otherwise, please contact the Division of IT(The prior text links to https://itsupport.umd.edu/itsupport).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Windows_Activation&oldid=11258"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Vulcan contains the following information: 






︗Nexus/Vulcan

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Vulcan)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The compute nodes from Vulcan's previous standalone cluster have folded into Nexus as of the scheduled  maintenance window for August 2023 (Thursday 08/17/2023, 5-8pm).
The Nexus cluster already has a large pool of compute resources made possible through college-level funding for UMIACS and CSD faculty. Details on common nodes already in the cluster (Tron partition) can be found  here.
Please  contact staff with any questions or concerns.

︗Contents

1 Usage
2 Nodes
3 Partitions
4 Accounts
5 QoS
6 Storage

6.1 Home Directories
6.2 Scratch Directories

6.2.1 Network Scratch Directory
6.2.2 Local Scratch Directories


6.3 Datasets
6.4 Project Storage
6.5 Object Storage


7 Migration

7.1 Home Directories




︗Usage
You can SSH to nexusvulcan.umiacs.umd.edu to log in to a submission host.
If you store something in a local directory (/tmp, /scratch0) on one of the two submission hosts, you will need to connect to that same submission host to access it later. The actual submission hosts are:

nexusvulcan00.umiacs.umd.edu
nexusvulcan01.umiacs.umd.edu
All partitions, QoSes, and account names from the standalone Vulcan cluster have been moved over to Nexus. However, please note that vulcan- is prepended to all of the values that were present in the standalone Vulcan cluster to distinguish them from existing values in Nexus. The lone exception is the base account that was named vulcan in the standalone cluster (it is also named just vulcan in Nexus).
Here are some before/after examples of job submission with various parameters:



Standalone Vulcan cluster submission command

Nexus cluster submission command


srun --partition=dpart --qos=medium --account=abhinav --gres=gpu:gtx1080ti:2 --pty bash

srun --partition=vulcan-dpart --qos=vulcan-medium --account=vulcan-abhinav --gres=gpu:gtx1080ti:2 --pty bash


srun --partition=cpu --qos=cpu --pty bash

srun --partition=vulcan-cpu --qos=vulcan-cpu --account=vulcan --pty bash


srun --partition=scavenger --qos=scavenger --account=vulcan --gres=gpu:4 --pty bash

srun --partition=vulcan-scavenger --qos=vulcan-scavenger --account=vulcan --gres=gpu:4 --pty bash

Vulcan users (exclusively) can schedule non-interruptible jobs on Vulcan nodes with any non-scavenger job parameters. Please note that the vulcan-dpart partition has a GrpTRES limit of 100% of the available cores/RAM on all vulcan## in aggregate nodes plus 50% of the available cores/RAM on legacy## nodes in aggregate, so your job may need to wait if all available cores/RAM (or GPUs) are in use. It also has a max submission limit of 500 jobs per user simultaneously so as to not overload the cluster. This is codified by the partition QoS named vulcan.
Please note that the Vulcan compute nodes are also in the institute-wide scavenger partition in Nexus. Vulcan users still have scavenging priority over these nodes via the vulcan-scavenger partition (i.e., all vulcan- partition jobs (other than vulcan-scavenger) can preempt both vulcan-scavenger and scavenger partition jobs, and vulcan-scavenger partition jobs can preempt scavenger partition jobs).

︗Nodes
There are currently 46  GPU nodes available running a mixture of NVIDIA RTX A6000, NVIDIA RTX A5000, NVIDIA RTX A4000, NVIDIA Quadro P6000, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti, and NVIDIA Tesla P100 cards. There are also 4 CPU-only nodes available.
All nodes are scheduled with the SLURM resource manager.

︗Partitions
There are three partitions available to general Vulcan SLURM users.  You must specify a partition when submitting your job.

vulcan-dpart - This is the default partition. Job allocations are guaranteed. Only nodes with GPUs from architectures before NVIDIA's Ampere architecture(The prior text links to https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/data-center/ampere-architecture/) are included in this partition.
vulcan-scavenger - This is the alternate partition that allows jobs longer run times and more resources but is preemptable when jobs in other vulcan- partitions are ready to be scheduled.
vulcan-cpu - This partition is for CPU focused jobs. Job allocations are guaranteed.
There are a few additional partitions available to subsets of Vulcan users based on specific requirements.

vulcan-ampere - This partition contains nodes with GPUs from NVIDIA's Ampere architecture(The prior text links to https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/data-center/ampere-architecture/). Job allocations are guaranteed.
As of Thursday 02/29/2024 at 12pm, there is a 4 hour time limit on interactive jobs in this partition. If you need to run longer jobs, you will need to modify your workflow into a job that can be submitted as a batch script.
As of Thursday 03/21/2024 at 5pm, there is a limit of 4 CPUs and 48G memory maximum per GPU requested by a job. If you need to run jobs with more CPUs/memory, you will either need to request more GPUs in the job or use a different partition.
Submission is restricted to the Slurm  accounts of the faculty who invested in these nodes:
Abhinav Shrivastava (vulcan-abhinav)
Jia-Bin Huang (vulcan-jbhuang)
Christopher Metzler (vulcan-metzler)
Matthias Zwicker (vulcan-zwicker)
︗Accounts
Vulcan has a base SLURM account vulcan which has a modest number of guaranteed billing resources available to all cluster users at any given time.  Other faculty that have invested in Vulcan compute infrastructure have an additional account provided to their sponsored accounts on the cluster.
If you do not specify an account when submitting your job, you will receive the vulcan account.  If your faculty sponsor has their own account, it is recommended to use that account for job submission.
The current faculty accounts are:

vulcan-abhinav
vulcan-djacobs
vulcan-jbhuang
vulcan-lsd
vulcan-metzler
vulcan-rama
vulcan-ramani
vulcan-yaser
vulcan-zwicker
$ sacctmgr show account format=account%20,description%30,organization%10
             Account                          Descr        Org
-------------------- ------------------------------ ----------
                 ...                            ...        ...
              vulcan                         vulcan     vulcan
      vulcan-abhinav   vulcan - abhinav shrivastava     vulcan
      vulcan-djacobs          vulcan - david jacobs     vulcan
      vulcan-jbhuang         vulcan - jia-bin huang     vulcan
          vulcan-lsd           vulcan - larry davis     vulcan

        vulcan-yaser          vulcan - yaser yacoob     vulcan
      vulcan-zwicker      vulcan - matthias zwicker     vulcan
                 ...                            ...        ...

Faculty can manage this list of users via our Directory application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/secgroup/) in the Security Groups section.  The security group that controls access has the prefix vulcan_ and then the faculty username.  It will also list slurm://nexusctl.umiacs.umd.edu as the associated URI.
You can check your account associations by running the show_assoc command to see the accounts you are associated with.  Please  contact staff and include your faculty member in the conversation if you do not see the appropriate association. 

$ show_assoc
      User          Account MaxJobs       GrpTRES                                                                              QOS
---------- ---------------- ------- ------------- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
       ...              ...     ...                                                                                            ...
   abhinav           vulcan      48                                       vulcan-cpu,vulcan-default,vulcan-medium,vulcan-scavenger
   abhinav   vulcan-abhinav      48                           vulcan-cpu,vulcan-default,vulcan-high,vulcan-medium,vulcan-scavenger
       ...              ...     ...                                                                                            ...

You can also see the total number of Track-able Resources (TRES) allowed for each account by running the following command. Please make sure you give the appropriate account that you are looking for. As shown below, there is a concurrent limit of 64 total GPUs for all users not in a contributing faculty group.

$ sacctmgr show assoc account=vulcan format=user,account,qos,grptres
      User    Account                  QOS       GrpTRES
---------- ---------- -------------------- -------------
               vulcan                        gres/gpu=64
                  ...                                ...

︗QoS
You need to decide the QOS to submit with which will set a certain number of restrictions to your job.  If you do not specify a QoS when submitting your job using the --qos parameter, you will receive the vulcan-default QoS assuming you are using a Vulcan account.
The following sacctmgr command will list the current QOS.  Either the vulcan-default, vulcan-medium, or vulcan-high QOS is required for the vulcan-dpart partition.  Please note that only faculty accounts (see above) have access to the vulcan-high QoS.
The following example will show you the current limits that the QOS have. The output is truncated to show only relevant Vulcan QoS.

$ show_qos
                Name     MaxWall                        MaxTRES MaxJobsPU                      MaxTRESPU 
-------------------- ----------- ------------------------------ --------- ------------------------------ 
...
          vulcan-cpu  2-00:00:00                cpu=1024,mem=4T         4                                
      vulcan-default  7-00:00:00       cpu=4,gres/gpu=1,mem=32G         2                                
       vulcan-exempt  7-00:00:00     cpu=32,gres/gpu=8,mem=256G         2                                
         vulcan-high  1-12:00:00     cpu=16,gres/gpu=4,mem=128G         2                                
        vulcan-janus  3-00:00:00    cpu=32,gres/gpu=10,mem=256G                                          
       vulcan-medium  3-00:00:00       cpu=8,gres/gpu=2,mem=64G         2                                
       vulcan-sailon  3-00:00:00     cpu=32,gres/gpu=8,mem=256G                              gres/gpu=48 
    vulcan-scavenger  3-00:00:00     cpu=32,gres/gpu=8,mem=256G                                          
...

$ show_partition_qos
                Name MaxSubmitPU                      MaxTRESPU              GrpTRES 
-------------------- ----------- ------------------------------ -------------------- 
...
              vulcan         500                                 cpu=1760,mem=15824G 
    vulcan-scavenger         500                                                     
...

︗Storage
Vulcan has the following storage available.  Please also review UMIACS  Local Data Storage policies including any volume that is labeled as scratch.
Vulcan users can also request  Nexus project allocations.

︗Home Directories
You have 30GB of home directory storage available at /nfshomes/<username>.  It has both Snapshots and  Backups enabled.
Home directories are intended to store personal or configuration files only.  We encourage you to not share any data in your home directory.  You are encouraged to utilize our GitLab infrastructure to host your code repositories.
NOTE: To check your quota on this directory, use the command df -h ~.

︗Scratch Directories
Scratch data has no data protection including no snapshots and the data is not backed up. There are two types of scratch directories in the Vulcan compute infrastructure:

Network scratch directory
Local scratch directories
︗Network Scratch Directory
You have 300GB of scratch storage available at /vulcanscratch/<username>.  It is not backed up or protected in any way.  This directory is automounted so you will need to cd into the directory or request/specify a fully qualified file path to access this.
You may request a temporary increase of up to 500GB total space for a maximum of 120 days without any faculty approval by  contacting staff.  Once the temporary increase period is over, you will be contacted and given a one-week window of opportunity to clean and secure your data before staff will forcibly remove data to get your space back under 300GB.  If you need space beyond 500GB or for longer than 120 days, you will need faculty approval and/or a project directory.
This file system is available on all submission, data management, and computational nodes within the cluster.

︗Local Scratch Directories
Each computational node that you can schedule compute jobs on has one or more local scratch directories.  These are always named /scratch0, /scratch1, etc.  These are almost always more performant than any other storage available to the job.  However, you must stage their data within the confine of their job and stage the data out before the end of their job.
These local scratch directories have a tmpwatch job which will delete unaccessed data after 90 days, scheduled via maintenance jobs to run once a month at 1am.  Different nodes will run the maintenance jobs on different days of the month to ensure the cluster is still highly available at all times.  Please make sure you secure any data you write to these directories at the end of your job.

︗Datasets
We have read-only dataset storage available at /fs/vulcan-datasets.  If there are datasets that you would like to see curated and available, please see  this page.
The list of Vulcan datasets we currently host can be viewed here(The prior text links to https://info.umiacs.umd.edu/datasets/list/?q=Vulcan).

︗Project Storage
Users within the Vulcan compute infrastructure can request project based allocations for up to 10TB for up to 180 days by  contacting staff with approval from the Vulcan faculty manager (Dr. Shrivastava).  These allocations will be available from /fs/vulcan-projects and /fs/cfar-projects under a name that you provide when you request the allocation.  Near the end of the allocation period, staff will contact you and ask if you would like to renew the allocation for up to another 180 days (requires re-approval from Dr. Shrivastava).

If you are no longer in need of the storage allocation, you will need to relocate all desired data within two weeks of the end of the allocation period.  Staff will then remove the allocation.
If you do not respond to staff's request by the end of the allocation period, staff will make the allocation temporarily inaccessible.
If you do respond asking for renewal but the original faculty approver does not respond within two weeks of the end of the allocation period, staff will also make the allocation temporarily inaccessible.
If one month from the end of the allocation period is reached without both you and the faculty approver responding, staff will remove the allocation.
Project storage is fully protected.  It has  snapshots enabled and is  backed up nightly.

︗Object Storage
All Vulcan users can request project allocations in the UMIACS Object Store(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/help). Please  contact staff with a short project name and the amount of storage you will need to get started.
To access this storage, you'll need to use a  S3 client or our UMobj command line utilities.
An example on how to use the umobj command line utilities can be found  here.  A full set of documentation for the utilities can be found on the umobj Gitlab page(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/staff/umobj/blob/master/README.md#umobj).

︗Migration
︗Home Directories
The Nexus uses NFShomes home directories - if your UMIACS account was created before February 22nd, 2023, you were using /cfarhomes/<username> as your home directory on the standalone Vulcan cluster. While /cfarhomes is available on Nexus, your shell initialization scripts from it will not automatically load. Please copy over anything you need to your /nfshomes/<username> directory at your earliest convenience, as /cfarhomes will be retired in a two phase process:

Fri 11/17/2023, 5pm: cfarhomes directories are made read-only
Thu 12/21/2023, 5-8pm (monthly maintenance window): cfarhomes directories are taken offline

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/NAGWareCompiler contains the following information: 






︗NAGWareCompiler

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search

The NAGWare Fortran compiler is available under /opt/common/NAGWare_f95* on our supported RHEL7/Ubuntu hosts. You can either load the binaries into your environment using  GNU Modules, reference the paths directly, else add them to your  PATH.

︗Example use of the compiler
Here is a very basic compilation and execution example of Hello World(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hello_world_program) using the NAGWare fortran compiler. This example will utilize a GNU Module available on all supported Linux hosts to quickly load the binaries and libraries into your environment. 
First, in a working directory, create a file hello.f95 with the following contents:

PRINT *, "Hello World!" 
END

Then, load the NAGWare modules into your environment and verify that the compiler is in your path (libraries, MANpages, and license server information will be loaded as well):

-bash-4.2$  module load nagware
-bash-4.2$  which f95
/opt/common/NAGWare_f95-5.1/bin/f95

Compile and then run the program:

-bash-4.2$  f95 -o hello hello.f95 
-bash-4.2$  ./hello 
 Hello World!

︗See Also
NAG Compiler Documentation Index(The prior text links to http://www.nag.com/nagware/np/doc_index.asp)
NAG Compiler Product Page(The prior text links to http://www.nag.com/nagware/np.asp)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=NAGWareCompiler&oldid=10386"

︗CCompilers

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
We currently have the following C/C++ compilers on the following platforms:

︗RHEL7
gcc-4.7.4 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-4.7.4
gcc-5.3.0 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-5.3.0
gcc-5.4.0 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-5.4.0
gcc-6.2.0 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-6.2.0
gcc-6.3.0 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-6.3.0
gcc-7.5.0 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-7.5.0
gcc-8.1.0 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-8.1.0
gcc-9.3.0 - /opt/local/stow/gcc-9.3.0
Intel Compilers
Portland Group Compilers
In order to load different versions of gcc into your environment, you can use Modules, which provides a way to add and later if needed remove environmental variables that provide access to UMIACS large set of software we offer. Please see our Modules page for more information on how to use Modules.
Also see: CDebuggers

︗Google Drive/Drive for Desktop

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
If you are migrating from Backup and Sync, please follow the migration steps  here.

︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Installation
3 Windows Setup
4 Mac Setup


︗Overview
Drive for desktop is an application for Windows and macOS that lets you quickly access Google Drive content directly from your operating system's file browser. Drive for desktop also automatically syncs local files and directories of your choosing to your Google Drive in the background. This allows you to continuously back up your data as you create or modify it on your local machine(s) without needing to manually upload each file to your Google Drive.
For Linux, you can set up Rclone(The prior text links to https://rclone.org/) with a cronjob to copy files to your Google Drive periodically. Instructions to do this can be found  here.

︗Installation
Drive for desktop can be downloaded here(The prior text links to https://www.google.com/drive/download).

The image shows a webpage from Google Drive, focused on promoting the Drive for Desktop application. At the top left, the Google Drive logo features a colorful triangular design. The main section contains a bold header stating, “Safely store your files and access them from any device,” conveying the software's convenience and security. Below the header, brief instructional text encourages users to choose folders to sync with Google Drive or back up to Google Photos.

Prominently displayed in the center is a blue button with the text "Download Drive for Desktop," highlighted with a circular red outline, drawing attention for visitors who wish to initiate the download. To the right, a graphical representation of the Drive interface is visible, showcasing folder organization and features related to syncing options. The design emphasizes user-friendliness, with clear labels such as “Google Photos” and options for managing content, presented in a clean, modern aesthetic. The overall color scheme is predominantly white, with blue accents, providing a professional and inviting appearance.
︗Windows Setup
Once downloaded, open the downloaded file. This should bring up the Drive for Desktop installation window. Select your preferences for appication shortcuts and desktop shortcuts and then select install.

The image depicts a screen for installing Google Drive on a computer. At the top, the recognizable Google Drive logo features a colorful triangular design composed of green, yellow, and blue sections. Below the logo, there is a clear heading, “Install Google Drive?” in a bold font, indicating the purpose of the window. 

Two checkbox options are presented: the first option allows users to add a shortcut to the desktop application, while the second offers to create shortcuts for Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides on the desktop. Both options are presented with a clean and simple design for ease of understanding. 

At the bottom of the window, a prominent circular button labeled “Install” is highlighted in red, indicating that it is the primary action you can take. To the right of this button is a “Close” button, providing an alternative choice for users who may wish to exit the window without proceeding. The overall color scheme is minimalist, utilizing white as the background with touches of color from the Google Drive logo, contributing to an enticing and user-friendly interface.
Another window should then pop-up asking you to sign in with your browser. Select this option and then sign in with your <DIRECTORYID>@umd.edu email address.

The image depicts a Google Drive sign-in window designed for users to access the Google Drive for Desktop application. At the top of the window, the recognizable Google Drive logo features a colorful triangular design, incorporating green, yellow, and blue. Underneath the logo, there is a prompt that reads "Sign in to continue to Google Drive for desktop," indicating the purpose of the window.

In the central area, there is an input field for the user to enter their email address, marked with a placeholder text "@umd.edu", suggesting this is intended for University of Maryland users. Below the input field, a line of text informs users that signing in will grant Google access to their name, email address, language preference, and profile picture.

At the bottom, there is a prominent blue button labeled "Next," which stands out against the mainly white background. This button invites users to proceed after entering their email. Additionally, a discreet “Forgot email?” link is positioned below the input field, providing an option for users who may have trouble recalling their email address. The overall layout is clean and straightforward, focusing on user-friendliness.
You will then be prompted with the UMD CAS window, sign in with your UMD credentials.

The image showcases a Central Authentication Service (CAS) login screen designed for user authentication. At the top, the bold heading “Central Authentication Service (CAS)” is prominently displayed. Below, there are two input fields: the first is labeled "DIRECTORY ID," where users are expected to enter their identifier, and the second is labeled "PASSWORD" for password entry. 

Both fields are accompanied by a placeholder for guidance. A checkbox labeled “DON’T REMEMBER LOGIN” is presented, allowing users to choose whether or not to have their information remembered. 

The design is straightforward and user-friendly, featuring a light background that contrasts with darker text for clarity. At the bottom of the layout, a large red button labeled “LOG IN” serves as the primary action button. Directly above this button, there’s a security reminder stating, “For security reasons, please log out and exit your Web browser when you finish accessing services that require authentication.” 

Additional text underlines that the Division of IT will never request passwords via email, promoting security awareness among users. Overall, the layout is clean and helps facilitate secure user access to online services.
Another window should then pop-up with the prompt: "Make sure that you downloaded this app from Google". You did, so go ahead and select Sign in.

The image features a sign-in prompt for Google Drive for Desktop. At the top is the recognizable Google logo, with a colorful triangular icon representing Google Drive. The main text reads, “Make sure that you downloaded this app from Google,” suggesting caution for users about app authenticity. Below this, there’s a specific email address displayed, indicating the user is likely part of the University of Maryland, as suggested by the “umd.edu” domain.

The layout includes a brief message instructing users not to sign in unless they are sure the app was downloaded from Google. Two action buttons are located at the bottom: a large, circular red "Sign in" button that draws the user's attention, and a smaller "Cancel" button. The overall color scheme is clean and minimalistic, predominantly white, which helps the text and buttons stand out. The clear, straightforward design aims to facilitate user navigation and promote security awareness regarding sign-ins.
Congratulations, Drive for Desktop is now successfully installed! Now, to select the folders you would like to have backed up, you need to go the the "Preferences" page. This can be found by selecting the up arrow in the bottom right corner in your taskbar, then select the Google Drive logo, then select the setting cog in the top of the window that pops-up, then select the "Preferences" option.

The image displays a screenshot of the Google Drive for Desktop application interface on a Windows taskbar. At the top left, the user’s email address is shown as "kfunka@umd.edu," indicating the account type. There’s a circular profile icon next to the email, which likely represents the user’s profile picture. Below this, two sections labeled "Activity" and "Notifications" are visible; "Activity" lists folders such as "Documents" and "My Laptop (1)," each marked with a check to indicate they are synced. 

To the right, a settings gear icon is prominently displayed, suggesting users can access preferences or adjustments. The bottom section of the image includes the standard Windows taskbar UI, showcasing various icons for programs. At the bottom right, a circular Google Drive icon in yellow is surrounded by a red circle, indicating the presence of Google Drive on this machine. The time "12:51 PM" appears on the taskbar next to the date, contributing to the contextual setting of the interface. The overall layout conveys an organized and user-friendly environment for managing synced files.
Once in the "Preferences" page, select "Add Folder" to add a folder to be backed up to your Google Drive.

The image displays the Google Drive Preferences window for organizing folder backups. At the top, the Google Drive logo features a colorful triangular design, symbolizing cloud storage. The main section emphasizes the message, “Safely back up your files,” highlighting the application’s primary purpose. Below this, an illustrative image depicts a stylized cloud with stacked files representing potential folders to sync, showcasing a vibrant array of colors, including red, blue, and yellow, which reinforces creativity and organization.

Centered prominently is a large, circular button labeled “Add folder,” encircled in red, drawing attention to its function. This button invites users to initiate the process of selecting local folders for backup. To the left, the text indicates two categories: “My Laptop” and “Google Drive,” showing where files can be uploaded from and managed. The overall design emphasizes simplicity and ease of use, with a clean white background making the elements visually accessible. The layout encourages user interaction through clear prompts and graphical representation, aiming to facilitate seamless backup processes for users.
At this point select any local folder on your machine that you would like to be backed up to your Google Drive. You can add as many folders as you would like by simply repeating the "Add Folder" step. You are also given the option to back up your photos to Google Photos instead of your drive, select the option of your preference.

The image displays a settings interface for Google Drive, focusing on backup and sync options. At the top, a checkbox is labeled "Documents," accompanied by a digital representation of storage space usage, currently showing "0.0B," indicating no data has been backed up yet. 

Two checkbox options are presented below: the first, "Sync with Google Drive," is highlighted, suggesting it is selected. This option pertains to the automatic upload of all files and folders, including photos and videos, indicating that any changes made will be synchronized in real-time. The second option, "Back up to Google Photos," is not checked, and it explains that it would upload only photos and videos, with no automatic sync for deletions or edits.

At the bottom right, a prominent blue "Done" button invites users to confirm their selections, while a "Cancel" option allows them to revert changes. The overall design is clean and user-friendly, against a white background with understated icons and clear text, emphasizing clarity for users managing their backup settings.
Additionally, you also have the option to customize how your files stored solely on your Google Drive will appear on your machine. If you select the "Google Drive" option in the preferences window under your computer name, you will be able to select how files are stored in the Google Drive directory that will now appear in your file browser. Select the option of your preference.

The image shows the Google Drive Preferences window for users to configure their Drive syncing options. At the top, the Google Drive logo appears as a colorful triangular design, reinforcing brand identity. The window is divided into sections, with the left sidebar displaying "My Laptop (1)" indicating that this is a specific device configuration. 

In the main area, a clear header reads “Google Drive,” followed by instructions to browse and open Drive from the computer. Below this, several radio buttons are presented for choosing syncing options. The first option, labeled “Streaming” uses less hard drive space and allows access to files without downloading them, indicating that only selected files can be saved locally. The second option, “Mirror files,” ensures all Google Drive files are available both in the cloud and on the computer, providing more robust offline access.

The color scheme is predominantly white with blue accents, maintaining a clean and professional appearance. The interface emphasizes clarity with icons and labels, ensuring users can easily navigate and customize their Google Drive experience. Overall, the design promotes user engagement and simplifies file management.


︗Mac Setup
Once downloaded, open the downloaded file and install Drive for Desktop. Once Drive for Desktop is installed it will show a sign in with browser window.

The image displays the sign-in window for Google Drive, set against a dark background that emphasizes its modern design. At the center, the iconic Google Drive logo—a triangular shape in green, yellow, and blue—is prominently displayed, symbolizing cloud storage. Below the logo, the text "Google Drive" is presented in a clear, bold font, indicating the purpose of the interface. 

A notable feature is the large button labeled "Sign in with browser," which stands out with its light blue coloring, inviting users to click for authentication. The minimalistic design enhances usability, eliminating distractions and focusing on the sign-in process. The window's rounded edges evoke a friendly, approachable interface. The overall color scheme of dark and light blue tones promotes a professional yet user-friendly environment. This layout is intended to streamline the signing-in process, making it straightforward for users to access their Google Drive content quickly.
Select the "Sign in with browser" option and then sign in with your <DIRECTORYID>@umd.edu email address.

The image features a Google Drive sign-in window designed for accessing the Google Drive for Desktop application. The top of the window prominently displays the recognizable Google Drive logo, a colorful triangular icon composed of green, yellow, and blue. Below the logo, a clear instruction reads "Sign in to continue to Google Drive for desktop," indicating the purpose of the window.

In the center, there is an input field marked for users to enter their email address, with a placeholder suggesting the format to be used is "@umd.edu," indicating that it is tailored for University of Maryland users. Beneath this input field, a note reassures users that signing in will allow Google to access their name, email address, language preference, and profile picture.

At the bottom of the window, a prominent blue button labeled "Next" stands out against the primarily white background, encouraging users to proceed after entering their email. Additionally, a small “Forgot email?” link is available for those who may have difficulty recalling their email address. The overall layout is clean and minimalist, focusing on simplicity and user-friendliness.
You will then be prompted with the UMD CAS window, sign in with your UMD credentials.

The image displays a Central Authentication Service (CAS) login screen. At the top, the title “Central Authentication Service (CAS)” is prominently featured in a bold font, clearly indicating the purpose of the page. Below this, there are two input fields: the first is labeled "DIRECTORY ID," where users are prompted to enter their unique identifier, and the second is labeled "PASSWORD," designated for entering their password. Each field has a light gray placeholder text, providing guidance on expected input.

A checkbox option marked “DON’T REMEMBER LOGIN” is positioned below the input fields, allowing users to choose whether or not to retain their login information. The design is clean and simple, utilizing a white background that enhances readability with dark text for contrast. At the bottom of the window, a prominent red button labeled “LOG IN” serves as the primary call to action. Above this button, a security reminder emphasizes the importance of logging out after use to maintain security. Additional text reassures users that the IT Division will not request passwords via email, reinforcing security awareness. The overall layout is user-friendly, facilitating quick and secure authentication.
Another window should then pop-up with the prompt: "Make sure that you downloaded this app from Google". You did, so go ahead and select Sign in.

The image displays a sign-in prompt for Google Drive for Desktop, set against a clean white background that emphasizes clarity. At the top, the Google Drive logo is prominently featured, showcasing its iconic triangular design in green, yellow, and blue, symbolizing cloud storage. In the central area of the prompt, the message reads, “Make sure that you downloaded this app from Google,” indicating a caution for users regarding the authenticity of the app. Below this, the specific email address “kfuneka@umd.edu” is displayed, suggesting that the user is associated with the University of Maryland.

Two action buttons are provided at the bottom: a large, circular red "Sign in" button that commands attention, and a smaller "Cancel" button for users opting to discontinue the process. Additional instructions inform users not to sign in unless they are confident about the app's source. The overall layout is minimalist and user-friendly, with a focus on security awareness, ensuring a straightforward navigation experience. The combination of the clear text and simple design is intended to facilitate user confidence when proceeding to sign in.
Congratulations, Drive for Desktop is now successfully installed! Now, to select the folders you would like to have backed up, you need to go the the "Preferences" page. This can be found by selecting the Google Drive logo in the top of your screen, then select the setting cog in the top of the window that pops-up, then select the "Preferences" option.

The image displays the Google Drive for Desktop interface on a Mac computer. At the top, a user icon with an email address suggests it belongs to a University of Maryland user, showing it uses 8.3GB of storage. Below this, a blue box featuring a green cloud with a checkmark indicates that files are synced successfully. 

The interface includes a menu that appears on the right, providing options such as "Preferences," "Error list," "Pause syncing," "About," "Help," "Send feedback," and "Quit," making it user-friendly for easy navigation and management of settings. 

The bold text at the bottom reads, “Your files are up to date,” indicating that sync activity is current, with additional text reminding users that activity on their files will be tracked here. The overall layout features a clean design with a gradient purple background, promoting clarity and ease of use. Cloud icons and checkmarks provide visual feedback, emphasizing that all operations are functioning as intended. The overall aesthetic conveys professionalism and efficiency, appealing to users managing backups and file syncing.
Once in the "Preferences" page, select "Add Folder" to add a folder to be backed up to your Google Drive.

The image displays the Google Drive Preferences window designed for users to manage their file backup options. At the top left, the Google Drive logo, a colorful triangular emblem, is prominently positioned, reinforcing brand identity. The window features two key sections: on the left, titled "My Laptop," indicating the specific device, while the right segment highlights "Google Drive," aiming to clarify where files will be backed up. 

The central area emphasizes the message, “Safely back up your files,” which underscores the application’s functionality. Below this text, a visual representation of stacked colored files is illustrated within a cloud icon, symbolizing the transfer of local folders to the cloud. A large, circular button labeled “Add folder” encircled in red is centrally placed, inviting interaction and drawing attention to the action of selecting folders for backup. 

The overall design is clean, with a predominantly white background and vivid colors for the graphics, promoting clarity and ease of navigation. The layout encourages users to engage with the app, emphasizing a straightforward and user-friendly approach to file organization.
At this point select any local folder on your machine that you would like to be backed up to your Google Drive. You can add as many folders as you would like by simply repeating the "Add Folder" step. You are also given the option to back up your photos to Google Photos instead of your drive, select the option of your preference.

The image depicts the settings interface for Google Drive, focusing on backup and sync options. At the top, a checkbox labeled "Documents" highlights the current folder being configured, displaying "0.0B" next to it, indicating no data has been backed up yet. Below, two prominent checkbox options are available: the first option, "Sync with Google Drive," is checked, indicating that all files and folders, including photos and videos, will be automatically uploaded and synchronized with Google Drive. The second option, "Back up to Google Photos," remains unchecked and specifies that it will only upload photos and videos without syncing changes to deletions or edits.

Additionally, a blue button labeled "Done" is positioned at the bottom right, inviting users to confirm their selections, while a "Cancel" option allows users to revert any changes made. The overall design is user-friendly, featuring a clean white background that emphasizes clarity, with clear labels and icons, making it accessible for users overseeing their backup preferences in an organized manner.
Additionally, you also have the option to customize how your files stored solely on your Google Drive will appear on your machine. If you select the "Google Drive" option in the preferences window under your computer name, you will be able to select how files are stored in the Google Drive directory that will now appear in your file browser. Select the option of your preference.

The image displays the Google Drive Preferences window, showcasing options for syncing files on a computer. At the top left, the Google Drive logo, featuring a colorful triangular design, reinforces brand identity. The left sidebar indicates the current device, labeled “My Laptop (1),” while the main section is titled “Google Drive,” suggesting how files will be accessed and managed.

Key features include two clear syncing options: "Streaming," described as using less hard drive space, allowing access to files without downloading them, and "Mirror files," ensuring all files are accessible both in the cloud and on the computer. Each option has a concise explanation beneath it, enhancing clarity.

A circular button for "Open in Explorer" encourages user interaction, and the layout maintains a clean aesthetic with ample white space and blue accents, promoting ease of use. Icons accompany text to guide users in making appropriate selections, while the overall design emphasizes a professional and user-friendly environment for managing Google Drive settings.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/MFA contains the following information: 






︗MFA

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is a method of confirming a user's claimed identity in which a user is granted access only after successfully presenting 2 or more pieces of evidence (or factors) to an authentication mechanism.  Valid factors include:

knowledge (something they and only they know)
possession (something they and only they have)
inherence (something they and only they are)
UMIACS utilizes the Duo security platform to allow mobile devices to serve as a second factor.

︗Common Tasks
 Getting Started
 Replacing a lost Duo MFA device




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=MFA&oldid=8535"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Mpich1.csh contains the following information: 






︗Mpich1.csh

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
setenv MPI_ROOT /usr/local/stow/mpichgm-1.2.7p1-20
setenv MPI_LIB  $MPI_ROOT/lib
setenv MPI_INC  $MPI_ROOT/include
setenv MPI_BIN $MPI_ROOT/bin
# add MPICH commands to your path (includes mpirun and mpicc)
set path=($MPI_BIN $path)
# add MPICH man pages to your manpath
if ( $?MANPATH ) then
     setenv MANPATH  $MPI_ROOT/man:$MANPATH
else
     setenv MANPATH  $MPI_ROOT/man
endif






Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Mpich1.csh&oldid=2735"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms/View contains the following information: 






︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms/View

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
This page will show you how to view room schedules through Google Calendar.

︗Steps
Navigate to https://calendar.google.com(The prior text links to https://calendar.google.com).  The image displays a Google Calendar interface for April 2019. In the upper left corner, the current month is indicated as "April 2019," with a small calendar icon next to it displaying the current date as the 4th. The layout includes a vertical sidebar on the left listing multiple calendars, with the user's calendar, "Liam Monahan," checked along with reminders and tasks. 

The main area of the calendar is divided into four days, starting from Thursday, the 4th, to Sunday, the 7th, with time slots listed from 11 AM to 10 PM. The time slots appear empty except for an event represented by a horizontal red line in the 8 PM slot on Thursday, indicating a scheduled appointment. 

Above the main calendar view, there are options for creating new events, with icons for navigation and settings on the right side. Key indicators include the time zone noted as GMT-04. The overall design is clean and organized, emphasizing a user-friendly interface for managing schedules. 
Ensure that you are logged into your UMD account.  Only these accounts can view rooms.   Switch or add an account if not: Google has instructions here(The prior text links to https://support.google.com/docs/answer/2405894?co=GENIE.Platform%3DDesktop&hl=en).  When adding an account you will be prompted by Google for your email/phone.  This is your UMD username that you use to log into the UMD Central Authentication System (CAS) appended with @umd.edu.  For example username@umd.edu.  You will then be redirected to the UMD CAS login page if you don't have a current session open. The image shows the Google Calendar interface for April 2019, primarily displaying the calendar layout from April 4th to April 7th. In the upper left corner, the month is indicated as "April 2019," with a small calendar icon next to it. The current date is marked as the 4th, which falls on a Thursday. The layout features a vertical sidebar on the left, showcasing various calendars, with "Liam Monahan" highlighted, along with reminders and tasks listed beneath it.

The main calendar area is structured vertically, showing time slots from 11 AM to 10 PM. Most of the time slots are empty except for one event marked by a horizontal red line in the 8 PM slot on Thursday, indicating a scheduled appointment. Above the calendar, there are icons for creating new events, along with navigation and settings options on the right side. 

The timezone is noted as GMT-04. The overall design is clean and organized, facilitating easy navigation and management of schedules. A user account is visible in the top right corner, indicating that the account is managed by UMD.edu, emphasizing the institutional context of the calendar use. 
Click on the cog in the top right and click Settings to open the settings menu.  The image displays a Google Calendar interface for April 2019, specifically focusing on Monday, the 8th, which is highlighted in a blue circular badge in the upper left corner. The month is stated as "April 2019" at the top, with a grid view showing the calendar days alongside the week numbers. The date reflects the 8th, a Monday, which is denoted prominently.

In the main section of the calendar, time slots are organized vertically, ranging from 10 AM to 10 PM. Most time slots are visibly empty, illustrating a clear day with ample free time, except for a significant appointment marked by a horizontal red line occupying the entire 10 AM time slot. The sidebar on the left includes the user's calendar options, showing entries such as “Matthew Robert Barney,” alongside other functional categories like "Reminders" and “Tasks."

At the top right, various icons are present for additional functionalities, including settings, search, and options to switch calendar views. The interface features a clean, organized layout, emphasizing simplicity and usability for schedule management. The time zone for this view is noted as GMT-04. 
Expand Add Calendar on the left pane and select Browse resources.  ### Image Description

The image displays the settings interface of Google Calendar, presented in a clean, organized layout. On the left, the menu options show categories like "General," "Language and region," "Time zone," and "Add calendar," each with expandable submenus. The primary focus is on the "General" settings, highlighting the options for language (English), country (United States), date format, and time format (1:00 PM). Below this, there is a section for time zones, indicating a primary time zone of "GMT-04:00 Eastern Time - New York." A checkbox option is visible to display a secondary time zone, which is not labeled yet.

The right side of the interface features a button for "Submit," indicating that changes can be saved after adjustments. The overall design is minimalistic and user-friendly, with bright white backgrounds and light gray accents for contrast. The interface suggests a focus on quick navigation and straightforward access to settings, making it easy for users to customize their calendar experience efficiently. 
Scroll down to IRB (the building code for Iribe) and tick the checkbox for each room that you want to add to your Google Calendar view.  The image features the settings interface for Google Calendar, focusing on the "Add Calendar" section. The layout is primarily white with minimalistic design elements, enhancing user experience through clarity and ease of navigation. On the left sidebar, the "General" options are visible, providing categories like "Create new calendar" and "Browse resources," each expandable for further choices.

The main section highlights the "IRB" category, with various conference room options listed vertically, such as "IRB-1119 (AGRN)" and "IRB-1143 (CMS)." Checkbox selectors are displayed next to each room for users to enable or disable their visibility in the calendar. Some entries have additional icons next to them, indicating separate functionalities, such as the eye icon for hidden calendars.

An active checkbox indicating the selected room is visible, while other options remain unchecked. The top right corner features an icon for user account management, emphasizing institutional affiliation. Overall, the interface emphasizes simplicity and efficient management of scheduling resources, with a focus on the organizational context of the UMD environment. 
Click the back arrow in the top left (not the browser back arrow) to return to the main Google Calendar view. All of the calendars you subscribed to (and their events) should now be visible. You can also untick individual calendars on the left pane to temporarily hide one or more of the calendars you subscribed to. Switching to Day view in the top right will also show you one column per room if you prefer.  The image shows a Google Calendar interface for April 8, 2019. Located in the upper left corner, the month is prominently labeled as "April 2019," with the specific date, the 8th, highlighted inside a blue circular badge. The layout presents a vertically organized time structure running from 10 AM to 10 PM. Most time slots are visibly empty, signifying an open schedule, except for one notable event depicted by a horizontal red line that spans the entire 10 AM slot, indicating a scheduled appointment. 

On the left, a sidebar displays the user's calendars, prominently featuring "Matthew Robert Barney" and listing various functional categories, such as "Reminders" and "Tasks." Checkboxes next to these options allow the user to customize their view. At the top right, the interface includes icons for settings, search, and calendar view options, reinforcing user control over the schedule. The overall design is clean and minimalistic, ensuring ease of navigation and focus on usability, with the time zone indicated as GMT-04, emphasizing a clear organizational structure.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/LaTeX contains the following information: 






︗LaTeX

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Background
2 LaTeX on Windows
3 LaTeX on Linux/UNIX

3.1 Checking installed packages
3.2 Compiling to PDF


4 Further Reading


︗Background
From the main Project Page(The prior text links to http://www.latex-project.org):
LaTeX is a high-quality typesetting system; it includes features designed for the production of technical and scientific documentation. LaTeX is the de facto standard for the communication and publication of scientific documents.

︗LaTeX on Windows
In Windows, it is highly recommended to use a full-featured suite such as TeX Live(The prior text links to https://www.tug.org/texlive/) or MiKTeX(The prior text links to http://miktex.org/). Both of these suites include everything required for end-to-end LaTeX compilation and filetype conversation. Please contact the HelpDesk for assistance with installing or using these on a UMIACS-supported Windows machine.

︗None
MacTeX(The prior text links to https://www.tug.org/mactex/) is available for macOS.
TeX Live(The prior text links to https://www.tug.org/texlive/) is available for Linux. For editing LaTeX files on RHEL7, Texmaker(The prior text links to https://www.xm1math.net/texmaker/) is available as a GNU module.
Most of our supported Linux systems come with the LaTeX command-line utilities, as well as TeX Live, installed. Supported RHEL7 workstations come with Tex Live 2013, but you can load a newer version of TeX Live as a GNU module.

︗Checking installed packages
TeX Live comes with tons of packages preinstalled. To get a list of installed packages, you must first load the TeX Live GNU module. You can then use the following command:

$ tlmgr list --only-installed
If you know which package you are looking for, you can pipe the output into grep to search for specific packages.

︗Compiling to PDF
The following is an example of compiling example.tex to a PDF.



    Compile the file into a DVI file by using the latex command.

    $ latex example.tex 
This is pdfTeX, Version 3.1415926-2.3-1.40.13 (TeX Live 2013)
[...]
[1] (./example.aux) )
Output written on example.dvi (1 page, 1692 bytes).
Transcript written on example.log.


    Use dvipdfmx to convert example.dvi into a PDF (dvipdf or dvipdfm usually would work as well).

    $ dvipdfmx example.dvi
example.dvi -> example.pdf
[1]
12211 bytes written


If your output PDF does not look quite right, you may need to use different conversion tools. Your workflow may necessarily vary depending on the contents of your document and how they are formatted and rendered.

︗Further Reading
LaTeX project documentation page(The prior text links to http://latex-project.org/guides)
More LaTex to PDF options(The prior text links to http://mintaka.sdsu.edu/GF/bibliog/latex/LaTeXtoPDF.html)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=LaTeX&oldid=8425"
