〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Mathematica contains the following information: 






︗Mathematica

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Mathematica is freely available to all University-owned machines. 
On our UMIACS-supported Linux hosts, Mathematica can be accessed through our Modules.

The command module add mathematica will add the default version of Mathematica to your Environment.
To see the versions of Mathematica that are available use the command module avail mathematica.
To add a specific version of Mathematica to your Environment (i.e. Mathematica 12.0) use the command module add mathematica/12.0
Further information can be found on our  Modules page.
For UMIACS-supported Windows machines, or other self-supported University-owned equipment, please contact  staff.

︗Activation
There is no automated way to activate Mathematica across our domain. As a result, each computer will have to be registered once against our hosted license server. Any user can go through this process, and it should persist indefinitely so long as the computer is not reinstalled.

Upon being prompted, click "Other ways to activate" in the bottom row: The image displays a computer screen showing the activation window for Wolfram Mathematica 10. The top of the window features a bold title in red, "Wolfram Mathematica 10," indicating the software version. The central area contains instructions to "Activate online" with a prompt that asks users to enter their "Activation Key." Below this, a text box is provided for inputting the key, labeled "Activation Key," with placeholder text displayed in parentheses suggesting the format of the key, which typically consists of alphanumeric characters.

At the bottom of the window, three buttons are visible. The first button, labeled "Quit," allows users to exit the activation process. The second button, highlighted with a bold arrow pointing to it, says "Other ways to activate," offering alternative methods for activation. The third button, labeled "Activate," is used to proceed with the activation once the key is entered. The overall layout is clean and user-friendly, with a professional aesthetic typical of software activation dialogs. The background appears light, allowing the text and buttons to stand out clearly.
Click "Connect to a network license server": The image depicts a software activation window for Wolfram Mathematica 10, prominently featuring a bold title in red at the top that reads "Wolfram Mathematica 10." The window is divided into sections that guide users through the activation process. There are three primary activation methods listed:

1. **Online Activation (Recommended)**: This section indicates that the computer must be connected to the internet.
2. **Manual Activation**: This option is provided for users encountering issues with online activation.
3. **Connect to a network license server**: This section, highlighted with an arrow, notes that this method should be used if the user is on a network that supports MathLM, specifying that it is the network license server for the product.

At the bottom of the window, a "Quit" button is visible, allowing users to exit the activation window. The overall layout is clean and professional, with a light background ensuring text readability. The design is user-friendly, emphasizing ease of navigation through the activation steps.
Enter "licserv.umiacs.umd.edu" as the license server. Click "Activate": In the image, the activation window for Wolfram Mathematica 10 is displayed prominently. The top of the window features a bold title in red, "Wolfram Mathematica 10," establishing the software version. Below the title, a section titled "Connect to a Network License Server" instructs users to enter the name or IP address of the server running the MathLM license server, specifically indicating a text box for input. The placeholder text within this box suggests entering "licserv.umiacs.umd.edu."

At the bottom of the window, there are three buttons: "Quit," which allows users to exit the activation process; "Other ways to activate," offering alternative activation methods; and the "Activate" button, highlighted with an arrow indicating its function to initiate the activation once the server name is entered. The layout of the window is user-friendly, with a light background that enhances readability, maintaining a professional aesthetic typical of software interfaces. The overall design facilitates easy navigation through the activation process.
Accept the terms, and click ok: The image shows a software activation window for Wolfram Mathematica 10, set against a light blue background. At the top, a bold title in red reads "Wolfram Mathematica 10," clearly indicating the software version. Below the title, instructions highlight the necessity of accepting the Mathematica License Agreement to proceed with the activation. The agreement text outlines important terms and conditions that users must acknowledge.

In the central part of the window, there is a checkbox labeled “I accept the terms of this agreement,” which the user must select to confirm their consent. Below this, there are three buttons aligned horizontally: on the left, the "Quit" button provides an option to exit the activation process; the middle button, labeled "Print," allows users to print the agreement for their records; and on the right, the "OK" button, highlighted to indicate its primary function, is for proceeding with the activation once the terms are accepted.

The overall design is clean and user-friendly, with a professional aesthetic typical for software dialog boxes, ensuring ease of navigation.
Mathematica should now be activated on the computer.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Mathematica&oldid=10703"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Services/EquipmentLoans contains the following information: 






︗Services/EquipmentLoans

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
There are a number of equipment and computing devices available for short-term loans.  General equipment loans are available for a maximum of 2-weeks.

︗Requesting a Loan
Request a loaner laptop or projector(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/equipment/).
Please  contact UMIACS Staff for the availability of other equipment requests. Common items we stock include external hard drives, mice, keyboards, tool sets, and more.
Please note that if you loan out a loaner laptop or any other device capable of storing data, UMIACS staff is not responsible for backing up any data you store and will promptly wipe the device upon it being returned. You must copy any data you wish to keep elsewhere before returning the device.
To digitally sign a loaner form, please see  this page.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Services/EquipmentLoans&oldid=11082"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Creating_service_admin_user_on_macOS contains the following information: 






︗Creating service admin user on macOS

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
When taking an Apple product to the Terrapin Tech store(The prior text links to https://it.umd.edu/terrapin-tech), it is critical that you create a Service Admin User on your computer before having it serviced. The technicians at the store require an admin user name and password, and if the pre-existing password is the same as your UMIACS domain login password, revealing it to the technicians would represent a security vulnerability. To remedy this, you must create a new temporary user account with administrator privileges that the technicians can use to service your machine. 

︗Creating the new account
Make sure you are logged in to an administrator account on your MacBook.
Navigate to System Preferences. (Click on the Apple Logo at the top lefthand side of the screen, and select "System Preferences" from the dropdown menu.)
From the System Preferences menu, select "Users and Groups" .
On the righthand side of the screen where it lists the users currently on the machine, click on the 'Add User' button.
By default, the new account will be set to a Standard account. Select the "New User" dropdown menu and choose "Administrator" from the list.
The image displays a macOS interface for creating a new user account. At the top, there is a dropdown menu labeled "New User" where the option for "Administrator" is selected, indicating the type of access for this new account. Below this, there are several input fields for entering user details. 

The "Full Name" field is present for entering the user's complete name, while the "Account Name" field shows a descriptive note indicating its use as the name for the home folder. A "Password" field requires a password to be entered, accompanied by a reminder about the password requirements, specifying that it should be four characters or more. There is also a "Verify" field to re-enter the password for confirmation, along with an optional "Password Hint" field, recommended for user assistance.

At the bottom of the interface, there are two buttons: one labeled "Cancel" to terminate the account creation process, and another labeled "Create User" to finalize the new user account setup. The overall color scheme is dark, typical of macOS design elements, offering a sleek, modern aesthetic.
The new user's full name should be "Service Admin," and the account name should be "serviceadmin".
The password is up to you, so long as it's not the same as your UMIACS account password or your UMD Directory ID password.
The image displays a macOS user account creation interface, set against a primarily dark background consistent with Apple's design aesthetics. At the top of the interface, there is a dropdown labeled "New User," where the option "Administrator" is selected, indicating that the new account will have administrator privileges. Below this, the fields for user details are laid out clearly.

The "Full Name" field is populated with the name "Service Admin," intended for identifying the account. The "Account Name" field shows "serviceadmin", which will designate the account's folder. Each password field is represented with asterisks, indicating input for privacy. A note specifies the password requirements, stating that the password must consist of at least four characters. 

A "Verify" field follows, which requires re-entering the password. An optional "Password Hint" field is also presented, suggesting a hint for future password recovery assistance. At the bottom, two buttons are visible: "Cancel" for aborting the action and "Create User" to finalize the new account’s creation. The layout is clean and user-friendly, focusing on essential user setup tasks.
Select "Create User".
When prompted by the Terrapin Tech sore, you should give this account's credentials to the technician, not your UMIACS account credentials. Once the service is completed, the account can be deleted.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Creating_service_admin_user_on_macOS&oldid=11488"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Docker contains the following information: 






︗Podman

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Docker)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Podman(The prior text links to https://podman.io/) is a daemonless container engine alternative to Docker(The prior text links to https://www.docker.com/).  We don't support Docker in many of our environments as it grants trivial administrative control over the host the Docker daemon runs on.  Podman on the other hand has the ability to run containers in user namespaces.  This means that for every user name space in the kernel you create the processes within it will map to a new uid/gid range.  For example, if you are root in your container, you will not be uid 0 outside the container, but instead you will be uid 4294000000.
We still believe that Apptainer is the best option for running containerized workloads on our clustered based resources.  Podman is a good option for developing the containers to be run via Apptainer or building a deliverable for a funding agency.  Please  contact staff if you would like Podman installed on a workstation or standalone server.  More information on Podman running rootless can be found here(The prior text links to https://github.com/containers/podman/blob/main/docs/tutorials/rootless_tutorial.md).

︗Contents

1 Getting Started

1.1 Storage


2 GPUs
3 Example


︗Getting Started
To get started there are a few things that you need to configure.
First, run the podman command.  If it says command not found or you get an ERRO like the one below about no subuid ranges, and you are on a workstation or standalone (non-cluster) server, please  contact staff with the error and the host that you are using.  We will need to do some steps to setup the host you want ready.

$ podman
ERRO[0000] cannot find mappings for user username: No subuid ranges found for user "username" in /etc/subuid
Error: missing command 'podman COMMAND'
Try 'podman --help' for more information.

︗Storage
Containers are made up of layers for the image and these are stored in the graphroot setting of ~/.config/containers/storage.conf which by default will be in your home directory.  With our home directories being available over NFS there is an issue(The prior text links to https://www.redhat.com/sysadmin/rootless-podman-nfs) that due to the user name space mapping described above you will not be able to access your home directory when you are building the layers.
You need to update the graphroot setting to a local directory on the host.  The file ~/.config/containers/storage.conf may not exist until you run podman the first time, however you can manually create it.

[storage]
  driver = "vfs"
  graphroot = "/scratch0/username/.local/share/containers/storage"
...

When building larger images, it may fill up the default directory for imageCopyTmpDir (/var/tmp). If this happens, you will need to specify a different directory using the environment variable TMPDIR. For example:

export TMPDIR="/scratch0/example_tmp_directory"
︗GPUs
Running Podman with the local Nvidia GPUs requires some additional configuration steps that staff has to add to any individual workstation or standalone (non-cluster) server that runs Podman.  This includes ensuring the nvidia-container-runtime package is installed.
For example you can run nvidia-smi from within the official Nvidia CUDA containers with a command like this, optionally replacing the tag for different CUDA versions/OS images:

$ podman run --rm --hooks-dir=/usr/share/containers/oci/hooks.d docker.io/nvidia/cuda:12.2.2-base-ubi8 nvidia-smi
Thu Apr 16 18:47:04 2020
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| NVIDIA-SMI 535.129.03             Driver Version: 535.129.03   CUDA Version: 12.2     |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| GPU  Name                 Persistence-M | Bus-Id        Disp.A | Volatile Uncorr. ECC |
| Fan  Temp   Perf          Pwr:Usage/Cap |         Memory-Usage | GPU-Util  Compute M. |
|                                         |                      |               MIG M. |
|=========================================+======================+======================|
|   0  NVIDIA RTX A6000               Off | 00000000:01:00.0 Off |                  Off |
| 30%   28C    P8               6W / 300W |      2MiB / 49140MiB |      0%      Default |
|                                         |                      |                  N/A |
+-----------------------------------------+----------------------+----------------------+

+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Processes:                                                                            |
|  GPU   GI   CI        PID   Type   Process name                            GPU Memory |
|        ID   ID                                                             Usage      |
|=======================================================================================|
|  No running processes found                                                           |
+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

The full list of tags can be found at https://hub.docker.com/r/nvidia/cuda/tags(The prior text links to https://hub.docker.com/r/nvidia/cuda/tags).

︗Example
To build your own image you can start from an example we have https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker).
First clone the repository, change directory and build the image with podman.

git clone https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker.git
cd gpudocker
podman build -t gpudocker .

Then you can run the test script to verify.  Notice that we pass the local directory test as a path into the image so we can run a script.  This can also be useful for your data output data as well as if you write anywhere else in the container it will not be available outside the container.

$ podman run --volume `pwd`/test:/mnt --hooks-dir=/usr/share/containers/oci/hooks.d gpudocker python3 /mnt/test_torch.py
GPU found 0: GeForce GTX 1080 Ti
tensor([[0.3479, 0.6594, 0.5791],
        [0.6065, 0.3415, 0.9328],
        [0.9117, 0.3541, 0.9050],
        [0.6611, 0.5361, 0.3212],
        [0.8574, 0.5116, 0.7021]])

If you instead want to push modifications to this example to your own container registry such that you can pull the container image down later, please see the README.md located in the example repository itself.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Podman&oldid=11934"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/MalwareRecovery contains the following information: 






︗MalwareRecovery

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS  staff fully handles malware removal for any UMIACS-supported system you may use. However, depending on the malware that we believe your machine to have been infected with, it is possible that private information may have been collected by a third party over the course of the infection and could still be used to cause further harm to your work or you personally. The longer the malware had time to propagate, the greater the risk is that this is the case. If you are being directed to this page, it is likely the case that we have determined that you are at risk and we highly recommend you change all passwords for applications and websites you have visited while the machine you used was infected with the malware. In addition, if you made any online purchases whilst using an infected machine please be sure to keep a close eye on your credit card transactions for the next several weeks after the machine has been cleansed.
Below are a collection of links for changing passwords on commonly-used websites:

UMIACS(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/password)
UMD(The prior text links to https://directory.umd.edu/password)
Google / Gmail(The prior text links to https://www.google.com/settings/security?service=ha_reset_pw)
Facebook(The prior text links to https://www.facebook.com/login.php?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fsettings)
LinkedIn(The prior text links to https://www.linkedin.com/uas/request-password-reset)
Lastly, please be sure to pay attention to the behavior of the previously infected machine whilst using it. If you notice any additional odd behavior or the behavior that originally tipped us off to the infection reoccurring it may be the case that we did not fully cleanse the system as we had hoped and you should email staff(The prior text links to mailto:staff@umiacs.umd.edu) or contact our HelpDesk ASAP so that we can further investigate.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=MalwareRecovery&oldid=7808"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SLURM/ClusterStatus contains the following information: 






︗SLURM/ClusterStatus

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Cluster Status

1.1 sinfo
1.2 scontrol
1.3 sacctmgr




︗Cluster Status
SLURM offers a variety of tools to check the general status of nodes/partitions in a cluster.

︗sinfo
The sinfo command will show you the status of partitions in the cluster. Passing the -N flag will show each node individually.

$ sinfo
PARTITION AVAIL  TIMELIMIT  NODES  STATE NODELIST
gamma        up   infinite      3   idle gammagpu[01-03]
scavenger    up   infinite      2  drain tron[50-51]
scavenger    up   infinite     21    mix tron[00-01,03-15,46-49,52-53]
scavenger    up   infinite     31   idle tron[02,16-45]
tron*        up 3-00:00:00      2  drain tron[50-51]
tron*        up 3-00:00:00     21    mix tron[00-01,03-15,46-49,52-53]
tron*        up 3-00:00:00     31   idle tron[02,16-45]

$ sinfo -N
NODELIST    NODES PARTITION STATE
gammagpu01      1     gamma idle
gammagpu02      1     gamma idle
gammagpu03      1     gamma idle
tron00          1 scavenger mix
tron00          1     tron* mix
tron01          1 scavenger mix
tron01          1     tron* mix
tron02          1 scavenger idle
tron02          1     tron* idle
tron03          1 scavenger mix
tron03          1     tron* mix
tron04          1 scavenger mix
tron04          1     tron* mix
...
tron52          1 scavenger mix
tron52          1     tron* mix
tron53          1 scavenger mix
tron53          1     tron* mix


︗scontrol
The scontrol command can be used to view the status/configuration of the nodes in the cluster. If passed specific node name(s) only information about those node(s) will be displayed, otherwise all nodes will be listed. To specify multiple nodes, separate each node name by a comma (no spaces).

$ scontrol show nodes tron05,tron13
NodeName=tron05 Arch=x86_64 CoresPerSocket=16
   CPUAlloc=28 CPUTot=32 CPULoad=47.32
   AvailableFeatures=rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302
   ActiveFeatures=rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302
   Gres=gpu:rtxa6000:8
   NodeAddr=tron05 NodeHostName=tron05 Version=21.08.5
   OS=Linux 4.18.0-348.20.1.el8_5.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Mar 8 12:56:54 EST 2022
   RealMemory=257538 AllocMem=157696 FreeMem=197620 Sockets=2 Boards=1
   State=MIXED ThreadsPerCore=1 TmpDisk=0 Weight=100 Owner=N/A MCS_label=N/A
   Partitions=scavenger,tron
   BootTime=2022-04-21T17:40:51 SlurmdStartTime=2022-04-21T18:00:56
   LastBusyTime=2022-04-22T11:21:16
   CfgTRES=cpu=32,mem=257538M,billing=346,gres/gpu=8,gres/gpu:rtxa6000=8
   AllocTRES=cpu=28,mem=154G,gres/gpu=7,gres/gpu:rtxa6000=7
   CapWatts=n/a
   CurrentWatts=0 AveWatts=0
   ExtSensorsJoules=n/s ExtSensorsWatts=0 ExtSensorsTemp=n/s

NodeName=tron13 Arch=x86_64 CoresPerSocket=16
   CPUAlloc=1 CPUTot=16 CPULoad=8.41
   AvailableFeatures=rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302P
   ActiveFeatures=rhel8,AMD,EPYC-7302P
   Gres=gpu:rtxa4000:4
   NodeAddr=tron13 NodeHostName=tron13 Version=21.08.5
   OS=Linux 4.18.0-348.20.1.el8_5.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Mar 8 12:56:54 EST 2022
   RealMemory=128525 AllocMem=65536 FreeMem=33463 Sockets=1 Boards=1
   State=MIXED ThreadsPerCore=1 TmpDisk=0 Weight=10 Owner=N/A MCS_label=N/A
   Partitions=scavenger,tron
   BootTime=2022-04-21T17:40:46 SlurmdStartTime=2022-04-21T17:54:51
   LastBusyTime=2022-04-22T13:04:57
   CfgTRES=cpu=16,mem=128525M,billing=173,gres/gpu=4,gres/gpu:rtxa4000=4
   AllocTRES=cpu=1,mem=64G,gres/gpu=4,gres/gpu:rtxa4000=4
   CapWatts=n/a
   CurrentWatts=0 AveWatts=0
   ExtSensorsJoules=n/s ExtSensorsWatts=0 ExtSensorsTemp=n/s

︗sacctmgr
The sacctmgr command shows cluster accounting information.  One of the helpful commands is to list the available QoSes. 

$ sacctmgr list qos format=Name,Priority,MaxWall,MaxJobsPU
      Name   Priority     MaxWall MaxJobsPU
---------- ---------- ----------- ---------
    normal          0
     dpart          0  2-00:00:00         8
       gpu          0    08:00:00         2

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/PrinterQueueNaming contains the following information: 






︗PrinterQueueNaming

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Printer Queues
UMIACS uses a centralized print server to manage all of the printers in the Institute.  See Printing for more details specific to your OS.  We have developed a naming scheme for our printer queues based on the colors the printer can produce, the type of queue, the building number, and the room number.
The naming scheme is as follows:

All color printers begin with a "c".  Black & white is the default so nothing extra is needed.
Then either "ps" for a PostScript-enabled queue or "pcl" for a Printer Command Language-enabled queue will appear.  PostScript and PCL are types of printer drivers.  If you are unsure what this means, use "ps" for PostScript.  PCL drivers may not always be available.
Then add the building number and a dash ("-"). E.g. add "432-" for IRB, "115-" for AVW, or "224-" for ATL.
Then add the room number. E.g. If the printer is in room 3208, add "3208".
The image displays a colorful and informative flowchart illustrating the naming convention for printer queues at UMIACS. The central text consists of "cps432-4208," represented in a vibrant gradient of blue, purple, and green colors. 

- **Color Indication**: The letter "c" in red signifies that this printer is a color printer. 
- **Driver Type**: Below this, “ps” in blue indicates the use of a PostScript or PCL driver. 
- **Building Number**: The "432" in purple denotes the building number, which is connected to a light purple arrow pointing upwards, indicating this signifies the building's identifier. 
- **Separator**: A dash (“-”) follows the building number, vividly drawn in purple.
- **Room Number**: “4208” in green represents the specific room number of the printer, accompanied by a green arrow pointing upwards, indicating that this segment defines the location of the room. 

These elements are visually emphasized with arrows, guiding the viewer through the components of the naming scheme, thereby conveying the systematic approach to organizing printer queues based on their characteristics and locations.

Some examples:

ps432-3208 is a black & white printer in Iribe 3208.
cps224-3261 is a color printer in Atlantic 3261.




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=PrinterQueueNaming&oldid=10783"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/IOSJuniperVPN contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN/Mobile

From UMIACS
(Redirected from IOSJuniperVPN)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Download and Install the Pulse Secure Client
3 Configuring the Client
4 Using the Client


︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (mobile data or wireless)
︗Download and Install the Pulse Secure Client
Pulse Secure for iOS and Android enables secure connectivity over SSL VPN to internal UMIACS resources.  The app can be downloaded for free from the App Store or Google Play:

iOS (App Store): https://apps.apple.com/us/app/pulse-secure/id945832041(The prior text links to https://apps.apple.com/us/app/pulse-secure/id945832041)
Android (Google Play): https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.pulsesecure.pulsesecure&hl=en_US(The prior text links to https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.pulsesecure.pulsesecure&hl=en_US)
︗Configuring the Client
When the client is first launched, it will prompt you to accept its license agreement.  Click 'Accept' to continue.
You may need to enter a Corporate E-mail address or URL before continuing. Enter vpn.umiacs.umd.edu.
The image displays a mobile app interface for the Pulse Secure Client, which is designed for VPN connectivity. The background is a dark gray color, overlaid with a subtle network pattern of interconnected lines and nodes, evoking a sense of digital connectivity. 

At the top, the logo for Pulse Secure is prominently displayed, featuring a stylized green "P" and an icon suggesting security. Below the logo, the welcoming message reads: "Welcome to the Pulse Secure Client," informing users about the app's purpose.

In the central part of the screen, there is a prompt that instructs the user to "Please enter either your corporate email address or the URL provided by your company." The specified URL, "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu," is visible in a text field where users can input their information. 

A green submission button labeled "Submit" is located beneath the input field, inviting interaction. The app also includes navigation options at the bottom such as "About," "Join Meeting," and "Support," depicted in a smaller font. The device status bar at the top shows a Verizon signal icon and the battery level at 25%. Overall, the layout is clean and user-friendly, designed for ease of use in a corporate environment. 
After clicking on 'Submit', a page titled 'Add a Connection' will pop up. You will then be prompted for some basic information.  You will need to provide the following information and then click 'Save' or 'Add' (depending on client version).
Connection Name: UMIACS VPN
Username: <your UMIACS username>
The image displays a mobile app interface within the Pulse Secure Client. The background is a dark gray, contributing to a sleek and modern aesthetic, and features a subtle network pattern of interconnected lines and nodes, symbolizing digital connectivity. At the top of the screen, there is a section indicating that users can save their changes, with a checkbox next to the statement "This will be your default connection."

Beneath this, various fields are laid out for user input. The "Connection Name" field is labeled as optional, followed by a URL field pre-filled with "https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu." Below this, the "Username" field is also labeled as optional. Next is the "Authentication" section, which indicates the method as "Password." There are additional fields for "Realm" and "Role," both marked as optional.

At the bottom of the interface, a prominent green button labeled "Save" invites user action. The device's status bar at the top shows a Verizon signal strength indicator and battery percentage at 72%. The overall layout is organized and user-friendly, designed to facilitate efficient configuration for connecting to the UMIACS VPN. 
︗Using the Client
After the client has been configured, you can simply hit the 'Connect' button to start the VPN Connection.
The image depicts the user interface of the Pulse Secure mobile application designed for VPN connectivity. The screen's background is a dark gray, enhancing the modern aesthetic and providing a high-contrast canvas for displayed elements. At the top, the application's name, "Pulse Secure," is prominently shown. Below it, a green-bordered section titled "Connection" features the label "UMIACS VPN," indicating the specific VPN connection option available to the user. The associated URL, "https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu," is displayed beneath the connection name.

Below this information is a large, gray button labeled "Connect," inviting users to initiate a VPN connection. The button is centrally located, making it easy to access. Additionally, the device's status bar at the top of the screen shows a Verizon signal icon and indicates a battery level of 71%, suggesting an active connection. Icons at the bottom of the screen depict common mobile app navigation options, including a home icon, enhancing user experience by providing easy access to other app functionalities. Overall, the layout is user-friendly, optimized for straightforward interaction in a corporate context. 
Enter your UMIACS password, and hit 'Sign in'.
The image displays the login interface of the Pulse Secure VPN application for mobile devices, set against a dark gray background that emphasizes a modern aesthetic. The top section features the UMIACS logo in a light gray, enhancing brand recognition. Centered in a white dialog box is the title "UMIACS VPN," inviting users to sign in to initiate their secure session. Below this title, two labeled input fields are present: "Username" and "Password," where users can enter their credentials. 

A drop-down menu labeled "UMIACS Users" is also visible, allowing users to select their account type, enhancing usability. At the bottom of the dialog box, a prominent green button labeled "Sign In" stands ready for user interaction. In the top left corner, there is a "Cancel" option, enabling users to exit the login screen easily. The device's status bar at the top shows a Verizon signal strength icon and a battery percentage of 71%, suggesting an active mobile connection. Overall, the layout is simple and intuitive, designed for efficient user experience in a corporate context. 
Choose your preferred method of multi-factor authentication.
The image displays the login interface of the Pulse Connect Secure application for UMIACS, designed for user authentication in VPN access. The background is a light gray, creating a clean canvas for the interface elements. At the top, the UMIACS logo is prominently featured in black, alongside the welcome message stating “Welcome to the Pulse Connect Secure.” Below, there’s a large white dialog box containing the UMIACS branding again.

In the center of the box are three green buttons, each for different multi-factor authentication options: "Send Me a Push," "Call Me," and "Enter a Passcode." These buttons are rectangular, enhancing the user-friendly design. To the right of the dialog box, there's a settings icon, allowing users to configure their preferences. 

The device’s status bar at the top indicates the battery level at 85% and that the mobile network is Sprint. The layout is intuitive, aimed at facilitating easy navigation for users trying to authenticate their VPN connection effectively. Overall, it conveys a professional and efficient digital security approach. 
You are now connected.  You connection status is verified by the VPN symbol in the top status bar.
The image shows the user interface of the Pulse Secure mobile application, specifically the connection status screen. The background is a dark gray, providing a sleek and modern aesthetic. At the top of the screen, the app's name, "Pulse Secure," is prominently displayed. Below it, a green-bordered section titled "Connection" is highlighted, indicating an active VPN connection labeled "UMIACS VPN." Underneath this, the associated URL "https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu" is visible, confirming the connection details.

A large green button labeled "Disconnect" is centrally located, inviting the user to terminate the VPN session. This button is easily recognizable due to its prominent placement. Below the connection information, the username associated with the VPN session, "UMIACS\likm," is shown along with a countdown timer displaying "23:59:47," indicating the remaining time for the session. The status bar at the top of the device shows a Verizon signal icon and battery percentage, suggesting an active mobile connection. Navigation icons appear at the bottom of the screen, enhancing usability. Overall, the layout is intuitive and designed for efficient user interaction. 
To stop the VPN tunnel, click 'Disconnect'.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Obj_Website contains the following information: 






︗OBJ/WebHosting

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Obj Website)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS'  Object Store has the ability to host websites. On the settings page for each bucket, there is a section allowing you to specify a configuration for a website hosted in your bucket. You can choose keys located in your bucket to act as the index file (what will be displayed when someone visits your website) and the error file (what will be displayed when an error is encountered loading your website). These settings can be updated at any time.
Because hosting a website through your bucket requires others to have access to any keys associated with your website, setting up a website configuration will automatically set the visibility of your bucket to public and remove the bucket level ACLs. You will not be able to set the bucket back to private without first removing the website configuration, which can be done on the bucket settings page.
Note: The Object Store only has the capability to support static content and client-side scripting in bucket websites.

︗Contents

1 Hosting a Website
2 Accessing the Website
3 Setting a Website as your personal UMIACS webpage
4 Disabling a Website
5 Misc


︗Hosting a Website
Hosting a website in OBJ is quite easy and can be done in a few simple steps. There are three different ways you can set up your OBJ bucket to host a static website.
First Method (Using the Web Interface):

Log into OBJ(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/obj/buckets/) and create a bucket. Make sure to choose a bucket name carefully since this will be part of the web URL. The image displays a user interface from the OBJ box, specifically the section for managing the "jayid-test" bucket. At the top of the screen, a white and light blue navigation bar indicates various functionalities like "Buckets," "Help," "Reports," and "Manage." Prominently featured in the center is the name of the bucket, "jayid-test," displayed in a bold font, implying a current selection or focus area.

Directly below this title, there's a search bar for locating files and folders within this bucket, indicating user-friendly navigation. The button labeled "Upload File" is highlighted with a bright orange circle, drawing attention to its importance. This button is likely used to initiate the uploading of files into the selected bucket, emphasizing functionality for users looking to manage content in their storage space. To the right of this button are additional options, including "New Directory" for creating folders and "Bucket Settings," suggesting organized management capabilities within the system. The overall aesthetic is clean and straightforward, designed to enhance user experience and accessibility.
Upload your index.html file and optional error.html file (and any other required files for your website) on the bucket that you just created.
Once the files are uploaded, click on Bucket Settings
On the settings page, click on the blue Make Public button. The image showcases a user interface from the OBJ platform, primarily focusing on the management of a bucket titled "jayid-test." At the top, a simple rectangular header displays the bucket name in large, bold text, indicating it is currently selected. Below this header, a vertical usage panel reveals that there are "0 objects" and "0 bytes" utilized in this bucket, along with the owner's name, "jayid07." 

Two arrows prominently indicate key actions: one pointing to the "Make Public" button, highlighted in blue, emphasizing the importance of changing the visibility settings. Below, there are fields for website hosting configuration, including "Key for Index file" where "index.html" is entered, and an optional field for the error page labeled "error.html." A "Submit" button is positioned beneath these fields, allowing users to finalize their settings. The right side of the interface contains instructional text explaining the implications of making the bucket public, stressing that this action will override existing Access Control Lists. The overall aesthetic is clean and organized, aimed at simplifying user interaction with the platform.
Under Website Hosting, enter the name of your index.html (and optionally error.html) file and hit Submit.

Second Method (Using the UMobj CLI):

Set up your environment variables.
On the shell enter mkobj <bucket_name> to create a bucket. Your bucket name must be unique. You can enter lsobj -l to see the existing buckets.
Copy all the required files to the bucket: cpobj [source_directory]/file_name <bucket_name>:. For example, cpobj /fs/www-users/jayid-test/index.html jayid-test:
Create a web configuration for your bucket:  webobj -m create -c website --index=index.html --error=error.html <bucket_name>
Make your bucket public: chobj -m public <bucket_name>
Third Method (Using a Graphical S3 Client):
Since there are many different graphical clients available, we won't be able to cover detailed instructions for all of them. The instruction below only applies to Cyberduck.

Please refer to S3Clients to download and install Cyberduck.
Log into Cyberduck using the instruction from the previous step.
Once logged in, right-click > New Folder.... Give a unique name to your bucket.
Right-click on the bucket you just created, and click on Upload.... You can upload multiple files at once.
Once all the files are uploaded, right-click on the same bucket, and click on info.
Under the Distribution (CDN) tab make sure to leave a checkmark next to Enable Website Configuration (HTTP) Distribution.The image showcases a user interface from the Cyberduck application, specifically focusing on the settings for the bucket named "jayid-test." The panel is divided into sections with a clean layout, primarily in light colors, emphasizing readability. At the top, there is a header labeled "Info - jayid07," indicating the user's information associated with the bucket.

The key feature is the "Delivery Method" section, prominently stating "Website Configuration (HTTP) Distribution," with a checkbox labeled "Enable Website Configuration (HTTP) Distribution" checked, indicating that this configuration is activated. Below this, the "Status Logging" section shows that logging is enabled with a hint that access logs are being recorded for the selected container.

Further down, there are fields labeled "Origin" and "CNAME," currently set as empty, suggesting they are optional or not utilized in this configuration. Finally, the "Index File Invalidation" section states the current index file as "index.html," with an option to invalidate cached files, indicating management capabilities over content delivery. The visual elements are arranged systematically to enhance user navigation and clarity in managing website settings.
Next, click on the drop-down menu next to Index File and select your index.html file (or whatever file you're using as your index file).
Under the Permission tab, add a permission by clicking on the cog icon on the bottom left and click on Everyone. Change the permission for Everyone to READ as shown on the image below.<The image showcases a user interface from a graphical file management application, likely a cloud storage service. It features a tabbed layout with a series of icons at the top for navigation, including "General," "Permissions," "Metadata," "Distribution (CDN)," and "S3." The focus is on the "Permissions" tab, where two tables are visible detailing the Access Control List (ACL) for a file named "index.html."

In the permissions table, the first row indicates a specific user, "Jayid Alam," who has been granted "FULL_CONTROL," giving them complete access to the file. The second row labeled "Everyone" shows a dropdown menu indicating that this group is granted "READ" permission, allowing all users to view the file without making changes. 

Two prominent red arrows point towards these rows, emphasizing the permissions and the importance of setting access levels adequately. Below the permissions table, a gray area suggests potential additional controls or features, though it remains empty. The overall color scheme is light, with dark text facilitating readability, making the interface user-friendly and intuitive for managing access settings effectively.
︗Accessing the Website
You can access the website by using the default URL which has the form https://<Bucket_name>.umiacs.io.

︗Setting a Website as your personal UMIACS webpage
If you are intending to use the site as your personal UMIACS webpage, once the bucket is configured and all the required files are uploaded, please log into your UMIACS Directory page(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info/) and update the Home Page attribute to https://<Bucket_name>.umiacs.io. Replace <Bucket_name> with the name of the bucket you created.
Afterwards, www.umiacs.umd.edu/~username will also redirect to your website.

︗Disabling a Website
If you no longer wish to host a website, you can disable the bucket's web configuration.
Using the web interface:

Click on the bucket where you are hosting your website and then click on Bucket Settings.
On the settings page you can, click on Remove Website Configuration. Alternatively, you can also click on the Make Private button to make your bucket private and remove any associated web configuration.
Using the CLI:
Enter the following command in the terminal: webobj -m delete -c website <bucket_name>
Using a Graphical S3 Client (Cyberduck):

Right-click on the bucket where you are hosting your website and click info.
Click on the Distribution (CDN) tab and uncheck the box Enable Website Configuration (HTTP) Distribution.
︗Misc
More commands for umobj(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/staff/umobj/blob/master/README.md%7C)
S3Clients




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=OBJ/WebHosting&oldid=10661"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/WindowsMigration contains the following information: 






︗Windows Account Migration March 2018

From UMIACS
(Redirected from WindowsMigration)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
When: Saturday, March 24th 2018 from 8am-11:59pm

︗Introduction
Currently UMIACS provides two user authentication stores, our Linux/UNIX Kerberos5 realm and Windows Active Directory (PC). To simplify the user experience we will be consolidating authentication into a single new Active Directory domain (UMIACS).  At the end of the consolidation, you will be able to use a single password for all UMIACS services.
To prepare for this change, UMIACS staff need to migrate all UMIACS Windows accounts to a new domain. This migration starts by moving your account from our existing Windows Active Directory domain (PC\username) to a new one (UMIACS\username). After this migration is completed we will follow up with an announcement detailing the final steps of the password consolidation process.
No files or emails will be lost as part of this migration.​

︗Actions you need to take
Log off your Windows workstation (if you have one) prior to 8am on Saturday, March 24th, otherwise you will be forcibly logged out at this time.
︗Service impact during this Migration
Your password will NOT change.
Authentication to the Pulse Secure VPN will not be available during this migration window. Existing sessions will not be terminated, allowing you to continue using the VPN through the migration.  Two days prior to the migration, we will extend the default VPN session limit to 48 hours in order to minimize your disruption. If you require the VPN during this time please make sure you authenticate and maintain your connection before the outage window starts.
Windows workstations will be unavailable to log into during this migration window.
Exchange email access will be interrupted during this migration window.  Exchange email will be delivered however will not be accessible from phones, Outlook, or Outlook Web Access until after the migration has concluded.
︗After the migration has completed
We will post an announcement on https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu) when the migration has completed and will also send a follow-up email.
Your Windows account format will change from PC\username to UMIACS\username where you are required to specify a domain. You must use this username format going forward. Services that will require this new format:
Outlook Web Access for Exchange email users
Phone email setup for Exchange email users
Remote Desktop workstation access
Saved network drive(The prior text links to https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/4026635/windows-map-a-network-drive) credentials, which can be updated via Credential Manager(The prior text links to https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/4026814/windows-accessing-credential-manager)






Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Windows_Account_Migration_March_2018&oldid=9331"

︗ContentManagement

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Introduction
UMIACS supports a web content management system that allows faculty members to add modify their user profile on the UMIACS website: https://www.umiacs.umd.edu(The prior text links to https://www.umiacs.umd.edu).

︗Logging in
You may log into the content management system at https://www.umiacs.umd.edu/user(The prior text links to https://www.umiacs.umd.edu/user) with your UMIACS username/password.  
The image depicts a webpage interface for the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS) user account login. The layout is clean and modern, featuring a predominantly light background with a textured upper header that contrasts with a solid dark border. The header includes the UMIACS logo prominently positioned, stating its full name and tagline.

Centered on the page is a user account login section. It contains fields labeled "Username or e-mail address" and "Password," both designed for user input. Below these fields is a "LOG IN" button, inviting users to access their accounts. There are also options for logging in with an alternate method, including a link for "Request new password." 

The text throughout is clear and legible, with emphasis on usability, suggesting simplicity in navigating the page. The footer includes copyright information, indicating the year 1995 and 2012 as significant dates for UMIACS. Overall, the design communicates professionalism and a focus on user experience.

︗Editing your profile
After logging in, your profile will be displayed.  You may begin editing your profile by clicking the "Edit" tab as shown below.
The image displays a webpage interface for the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). The top section presents the UMIACS logo and full name against a light background, offering a modern and professional appearance. Below the logo, a navigation bar lists options such as "Home," "People," "Research," "Publications," "Infrastructure," and "About us."

The primary content area includes a user interaction section featuring tabs labeled "View" and "Edit." The "Edit" tab is highlighted, indicating its active status, while an icon for shortcuts is visible. Below these tabs, there is space for user input that likely enables users to edit their profile or other content.

In the background, several individuals can be seen, though their features are indistinct, creating a blurred appearance. This might suggest a focus on community while maintaining privacy. The design emphasizes accessibility and usability, showcasing the importance of straightforward navigation for content management. Overall, the image supports the UMIACS commitment to an efficient web experience for users.
In order to modify the information that the site displays for your profile, please click the "UMIACS staff" link at the top-right of the page as shown below.  If you do not see this link, please  contact staff.
The image shows a webpage interface for logging into a user account for the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). The design features a clean, modern aesthetic, predominantly set against a light gray background. At the top, there is a navigation menu with a solid dark border, contrasting sharply with the light area below. 

In the center of the page, there is a user login section that includes fields for "Username" and "Password," both clearly labeled for easy input. A prominent "LOG IN" button is positioned to the right of these input fields, inviting user interaction. Below the login fields, an additional link is provided for users to request a new password, enhancing usability.

The header displays the UMIACS logo alongside its full name, anchoring the site’s branding. Overall, the design emphasizes clarity and accessibility, conveying a professional and user-friendly interface suitable for its audience. In the footer, copyright dates from 1995 to 2012 indicate the history of the website's management system.
You may:

Edit your name as plain text.
Edit your Academic Title or Research Focus as plain text.
Select multiple Research Groups that you are working with by holding the "command" key on Macs or the "Control" key on Windows.
Edit your Education field as plain text.
Edit you biography as filtered html, which can include basic tags such as anchors, images, lists, and definitions.   Plain text without markup will also be rendered properly.
Edit the location of your home page.
Edit your mailing address, telephone, or fax.
Please note that changes made to the default profile, without clicking "UMIACS Staff" will not be properly displayed on the site.
Please also note that changes may not be visible for up to five minutes due to our use of caching to increase performance and reliability.

︗Adding Bibliography Entries
After logging in, you may add bibliography entries for your books and papers.  Click on "Biblio/Publication" at the right edge of the screen as shown below.  
The image presents a webpage from the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). The layout is characterized by a clean and modern design, primarily set against a light gray background. At the top, the UMIACS logo and full name are prominently displayed. Below that, a navigation bar stretches across the page, featuring links such as "Home," "People," "Research," "Publications," "Infrastructure," and "About Us," along with additional options like "Site manual" and "Event."

Central to the image is a blurred section of individuals, suggesting a casual or community environment while maintaining anonymity. To the right, the page includes two main tabs: "View" and "Edit," where the "Edit" tab is highlighted, indicating its active state. Below the tabs, there's a content area for user interaction.

A red arrow points to the "Biblio/Publication" link on the right edge, emphasizing its importance for users wishing to add bibliography entries for academic work. The overall design conveys a focus on accessibility, user-friendly navigation, and an efficient web experience tailored for academic professionals.
Choose from the available content entry options shown below.
The image shows a webpage titled "Create Biblio / Publication," part of the content management system for the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS). The interface features a light gray background that contributes to a clean and modern aesthetic. At the top, there is a breadcrumb navigation indicating user location within the site.

Central to the image are several options for adding bibliography entries: "DOI LOOKUP," "PASTE BIBTEX RECORD," and "PASTE RIS RECORD." Each option is clearly presented as a clickable expandable section, suggesting user interaction. Beneath these options, there is a prominent button labeled "Next," prompting users to proceed with their selections.

Below this section, the phrase "Publication Type *" appears, accompanied by a drop-down menu labeled "Select Type...," requiring user input to choose the specific nature of their publication. This layout emphasizes straightforward navigation and user engagement, reinforcing the purpose of the interface as a tool for academic professionals to manage their bibliographic information efficiently. Overall, the design is functional and user-friendly, aligning with UMIACS's commitment to accessibility in managing academic resources.
You may enter a bibliography item with:

A Digital Object Identifier (DOI) from the handle system, if one has been issued for your publication.
A Bibtex record.
A RIS record.
Alternatively, you may manually enter your publication by selecting a "Publication Type" from the drop down box.  Subsequent web forms will prompt you for information.
Please note that changes may not be visible for up to five minutes due to our use of caching to increase performance and reliability.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/UsrLocal contains the following information: 






︗UsrLocal

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Note: Please see Modules, which is now our preferred method of providing locally-built software to the Institute, as well as its various labs and centers.


/usr/local is managed via a Stow system.
If you are looking for a specific piece of software you can list the directory /usr/local/stow.  Some software is linked in with the stow command directly into bin,lib,man,sbin directories in /usr/local.
For RHEL hosts, the software will be moving from /usr/local to /opt/local to work around some issues with the root user and problems with NFS.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=UsrLocal&oldid=9249"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/NFShomes contains the following information: 






︗NFShomes

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
You have 30GB of home directory storage available at /nfshomes/<username>.  It has both Snapshots and  Backups enabled.
Home directories are intended to store personal or configuration files only.  We encourage you to not share any data in your home directory.  You are encouraged to utilize our GitLab infrastructure to host your code repositories.
NOTE: To check your quota on this directory, use the command df -h ~.
Please note that you should never chmod your nfshomes directory to be world-writable given that it is where SSH keys and other authentication related files are stored.
If you to access this file system over CIFS i.e., from Windows and some other operating systems, the path to use is (substituting <username> with your UMIACS username):

 \\isilondata.umiacs.umd.edu\nfshomes\<username>

CIFS access is limited to machines in the domain.  Please use the VPN if you need access from outside UMIACS networks, such as from the campus wireless network.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=NFShomes&oldid=11957"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Network/Troubleshooting contains the following information: 






︗Network/Troubleshooting

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Occasionally network related issues may arise.  The following outlines basic troubleshooting methods.

︗Contents

1 Check Network Connection
2 PING
3 Trace Route
4 Other Things to consider
5 Change your default DNS server


︗Check Network Connection
Check that the ethernet cable is plugged in or that you are connected to a wireless network.
Check that you have an IP address.
Windows: type ipconfig /all into the command prompt
macOS/Linux/UNIX based hosts: type ifconfig -a into a terminal
︗PING
PING is a network utility that sends ICMP packets to a specified host to test network connectivity.

Open up a command prompt / terminal and type ping followed by the hostname or IP address of the host you want to test connectivity to.
bash$ ping google.com
PING google.com (74.125.228.34) 56(84) bytes of data.
64 bytes from iad23s06-in-f2.1e100.net (74.125.228.34): icmp_seq=1 ttl=52 time=4.52 ms
64 bytes from iad23s06-in-f2.1e100.net (74.125.228.34): icmp_seq=2 ttl=52 time=4.17 ms
64 bytes from iad23s06-in-f2.1e100.net (74.125.228.34): icmp_seq=3 ttl=52 time=4.41 ms
64 bytes from iad23s06-in-f2.1e100.net (74.125.228.34): icmp_seq=4 ttl=52 time=4.04 ms

On Linux/UNIX, you may want to add the -c flag followed by a number to specify how many times to ping the destination host.
If you are having trouble connecting to UMIACS services, we would suggest you test against one of our publicly accessible Nexus hosts like nexuscml00.umiacs.umd.edu or nexuscfar00.umiacs.umd.edu.

-bash-4.2$ ping nexuscml00.umiacs.umd.edu
PING nexuscml00.umiacs.UMD.EDU (128.8.121.4) 56(84) bytes of data.
64 bytes from nexuscml00.umiacs.umd.edu (128.8.121.4): icmp_seq=1 ttl=60 time=0.507 ms
64 bytes from nexuscml00.umiacs.umd.edu (128.8.121.4): icmp_seq=2 ttl=60 time=0.335 ms
64 bytes from nexuscml00.umiacs.umd.edu (128.8.121.4): icmp_seq=3 ttl=60 time=0.328 ms
64 bytes from nexuscml00.umiacs.umd.edu (128.8.121.4): icmp_seq=4 ttl=60 time=0.379 ms

︗Trace Route
The traceroute tool utilizes the IP protocol to track the route one's packets take through a network.  Traceroute is useful when trying to figure out why a host is unreachable because it shows where the connection failed.

Windows:
In a command prompt type "tracert" followed by the hostname or IP address of the host you want to test the route to.
C:\>tracert google.com
Tracing route to google.com [74.125.228.38]
over a maximum of 30 hops:
  1    <1 ms    <1 ms    <1 ms  gw-486.umiacs.umd.edu [192.168.86.1] 
  2    <1 ms    <1 ms    <1 ms  umfirewall00.umiacs.umd.edu [128.8.120.17] 
  3    13 ms    <1 ms    <1 ms  avw1hub-gw.umiacs.umd.edu [128.8.120.1] 
  4     1 ms    <1 ms    <1 ms  vlan8.css-priv-r1.net.umd.edu [128.8.6.129] 
  5    <1 ms    <1 ms    <1 ms  gi6-1.css-core-r1.net.umd.edu [128.8.0.117] 
  6    <1 ms    <1 ms    <1 ms  gi3-2.css-fw-r1.net.umd.edu [128.8.0.82] 
  7     1 ms     2 ms     2 ms  128.8.0.226 
  8     2 ms     2 ms     2 ms  107-0-84-29-static.hfc.comcastbusiness.net [107.0.84.29] 
  9     3 ms     2 ms     2 ms  xe-3-1-2-0-ar04.capitolhghts.md.bad.comcast.net [68.85.114.113] 
 10     5 ms     6 ms     4 ms  pos-5-7-0-0-cr01.ashburn.va.ibone.comcast.net [68.86.90.85] 
 11     4 ms     4 ms     5 ms  pos-0-2-0-0-pe01.ashburn.va.ibone.comcast.net [68.86.86.70] 
 12     4 ms     6 ms     4 ms  75.149.231.62 
 13    42 ms     4 ms     4 ms  209.85.252.80 
 14     5 ms     5 ms     5 ms  72.14.238.175 
 15     4 ms     4 ms     5 ms  iad23s06-in-f6.1e100.net [74.125.228.38] 
Trace complete.

macOS/Linux/UNIX:
In a terminal type 'traceroute' followed by the hostname or IP address of the host you want to test the route to.
bash$ traceroute google.com
traceroute: Warning: google.com has multiple addresses; using 74.125.228.72
traceroute to google.com (74.125.228.72), 64 hops max, 52 byte packets
 1  10.109.160.1 (10.109.160.1)  1.329 ms  1.086 ms  1.232 ms
 2  129-2-129-129.wireless.umd.edu (129.2.129.129)  2.780 ms  1.924 ms  2.127 ms
 3  te1-6.css-core-r1.net.umd.edu (128.8.0.121)  2.514 ms  2.293 ms  1.863 ms
 4  gi3-2.css-fw-r1.net.umd.edu (128.8.0.82)  2.429 ms  2.548 ms  2.284 ms
 5  128.8.0.226 (128.8.0.226)  3.838 ms  3.465 ms  3.635 ms
 6  107-0-84-29-static.hfc.comcastbusiness.net (107.0.84.29)  3.941 ms  3.445 ms  3.303 ms
 7  xe-3-1-2-0-ar04.capitolhghts.md.bad.comcast.net (68.85.114.113)  3.522 ms  4.333 ms  3.441 ms
 8  pos-5-1-0-0-cr01.ashburn.va.ibone.comcast.net (68.86.90.241)  7.269 ms
    pos-4-12-0-0-cr01.newyork.ny.ibone.comcast.net (68.86.90.173)  9.025 ms  7.192 ms
 9  pos-0-4-0-0-pe01.ashburn.va.ibone.comcast.net (68.86.86.146)  5.236 ms  5.636 ms  6.229 ms
10  75.149.231.62 (75.149.231.62)  5.186 ms  5.113 ms  6.725 ms
11  209.85.252.46 (209.85.252.46)  6.836 ms  6.352 ms  78.371 ms
12  72.14.238.247 (72.14.238.247)  7.823 ms  7.616 ms  8.331 ms
13  iad23s07-in-f8.1e100.net (74.125.228.72)  10.798 ms  13.383 ms  7.540 ms

Again, if you are having trouble connecting to UMIACS services, we would suggest you test against one of our publicly accessible Nexus host such as nexuscml00.umiacs.umd.edu or nexuscfar00.umiacs.umd.edu.

︗Other Things to consider
Is your IP address manually set?
In order for networking to function properly, a machine must have a unique IP address on its network.  In many cases IP address are assigned automatically via the DHCP protocol, but it is also possible to manually set an IP address.  If your machine happens to have a manually set IP address that conflicts with that of another host, networking issues may arise.
Are you behind a firewall?
Some establishments use firewalls to restrict certain types of traffic both in and out of their networks.  If you are having trouble accessing a specific service, this might be the case.  To get around this you can connect to the VPN, or use SSH tunneling.
Other useful commands:
dig: performs DNS lookups and displays the answers that are returned from the name server(s) that were queried
host: simple utility for performing DNS lookups
netstat (macOS/Linux/UNIX): shows network status
route print (Windows): shows network routing tables
︗Change your default DNS server
Please see  DNS troubleshooting to change your default DNS server.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Network/Troubleshooting&oldid=11254"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/BashForWindows contains the following information: 






︗BashForWindows

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Microsoft has partnered with Canonical, the makers of Ubuntu, to create a release of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), which allows Windows users to use Linux command line tools such as such as grep, sed, git on Windows files through Bash. 

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Installation
3 Use
4 External Links


︗Prerequisites
In order to install Bash/WSL, you must be running a 64-bit version of Windows 10 version 1607 or later, any version of Windows 11, or Windows Server 2019 or later. In Windows, open the Settings app > System > About to check if your Windows version is compatible. 

︗Installation
First, turn on Developer Mode, open the Settings app > Update & security > For developers > Select the Developer radio button
Enable the Windows Subsystem for Linux, this can be done by turning on the feature through the Windows Features program or through a PowerShell session.
For the GUI method: Go to Control Panel > Programs and Features > Turn Windows features on or off (this will require local administrator privileges > Check the box for Windows Subsystem on Linux
For PowerShell method (in an elevated/administrator session) use the command:  Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux 
Restart the system.
Open a command prompt or PowerShell session, and then run bash.
After accepting the license, the Ubuntu user mode image will be installed.
︗Use
Simply run bash in a command prompt or PowerShell session to enter bash. The first time Bash is installed on Windows, a prompt will appear to create a Unix user. This Unix user account is completely separate from the Windows user account and has  sudo  permissions on the WSL. There is no GUI that is installed, nor can be installed. 

The Linux installation is located at %localappdata%\lxss\, which is a hidden system folder. 

I'm ready to assist with detailed descriptions of images; however, I don't have the ability to see or process images at this moment. If you provide the images, I can help generate textual descriptions based on the information you provide.

Do not use Windows tools to edit the files or sub-files within this directory as corruption of the Linux files could occur.
 Windows storage and files can then be accessed from /mnt/..., such as /mnt/c/Users/myAccount.
︗External Links
Bash On Ubuntu On Windows(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/about)
Installation Guide(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/install_guide)
Command Reference(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/reference)
FAQ(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/faq)
Linux User Account Explanation(The prior text links to https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/commandline/wsl/user_support)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=BashForWindows&oldid=10833"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Duo contains the following information: 






︗Duo

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Duo(The prior text links to https://www.duo.com) is the multi-factor authentication (MFA) solution for both UMD centralized information technology resources (DivIT) and UMIACS local resources.  Multi-factor solutions ensure that you have something you know (i.e. your password) and something you have (phone/tablet/token) when trying to authenticate.  This ensures that phishing and other attempts to secure your password do not result in an account compromise and protect you and your data from unauthorized access.
Enrollment is discrete and must be done for both UMD (if you have a UMD appointment) and UMIACS individually.  You can enroll the same phone for both of these services, but not the same hardware token (if you use a token for UMD already).  The UMIACS Single Sign-On and our VPN require Duo authentication.
Do not share a registered Duo authentication factor with any other UMIACS user for any purpose. Action may be taken against your account if you do so.

The image depicts a user interface screen for a multi-factor authentication (MFA) process utilizing Duo. At the top, the heading "Other options to log in" is prominently displayed in bold red text, indicating alternative authentication methods available to users. Below this heading, various authentication options are listed in a clear, structured format.

1. **Duo Push**: The first option features an icon of a mobile device and instructs the user to send a push notification to an iOS device, obscured by "****" to protect sensitive information.

2. **Duo Mobile passcode**: This second entry includes an icon of a numeric display and prompts the user to enter a code generated by the Duo Mobile app.

3. **Text message passcode**: This option advises sending a passcode via text to an iOS device, similarly obscured.

4. **Phone call**: Next, this entry suggests calling the listed phone number (also obscured) associated with the iOS device for authentication.

5. **Bypass code**: The final option provides an instruction to enter a code obtained from the IT help desk.

At the bottom, a "Need help?" link is included, and "Secured by Duo" is noted, emphasizing the security infrastructure. The overall layout is functional and user-friendly, with icons and text organized for easy navigation. Duo Login Prompt
︗Contents

1 Enrollment
2 Management
3 Offline Use
4 Services
5 FAQ


︗Enrollment
Please refer to Duo's Enrollment(The prior text links to https://guide.duo.com/enrollment) guide which has comprehensive information on how to enroll your devices.  Your initial sign in for enrollment purposes must be done via our Directory application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/auth/login).
We encourage users to enroll with their smart phone as it provides the most seamless experience.  We also support iOS/Android Tablets, landlines, and U2F FIDO(The prior text links to https://fidoalliance.org/certification/fido-certified-products/) authenticator tokens (though these do not work with our VPN or MFA SSH services).

︗Management
Users can manage their UMIACS Duo settings as part of the required login to the Directory Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info).  Please follow the Duo guide for Managing Devices(The prior text links to https://guide.duo.com/manage-devices) when you see the Duo login prompt.
We suggest you register using a mobile phone or tablet that is always in your personal possession.  If/When you upgrade or dispose of your currently registered phone/tablet, please consider enrolling your new device before getting rid of your old device.  Activation of your new device will require you to successfully authenticate with a currently registered device.  If you no longer have the device but have kept the same phone number, you can select Call Me to have Duo call you to authenticate your session to manage/enroll your devices.  If you do not have access to your previous device(s) or the phone number, you will need to  contact staff for assistance.

︗Offline Use


The image displays a mobile interface for the Duo authentication application. At the top, the Duo logo is present, indicating the app's identity. Below it, details about the UMIACS service are shown, specifically the text “UMIACS” repeated prominently, suggesting that this account is tied to the University of Maryland Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (UMIACS).

The central focus is on a highlighted area containing a six-digit passcode, displayed as “229 711.” This passcode is essential for the authentication process, allowing users to securely log in to their UMIACS account. In a rectangular red outline, the word “Passcode” is labeled, emphasizing its importance. A "Copy" button is also visible, suggesting that users can easily copy the passcode for use elsewhere.

At the bottom is a refresh icon labeled “Refresh Passcode,” implying that users can generate a new passcode if needed. The overall dark background gives the design a sleek and modern look, promoting user engagement with the interface's functionality.

Duo Offline One-Time Code




The image presents a user interface screen for the Duo multi-factor authentication (MFA) process. The top section features a bold, red heading stating "Other options to log in," indicating the various methods users can select for authentication. Below this, five structured options are visible:

1. **Duo Push**: Accompanied by an icon of a mobile device, this option suggests sending a push notification to an iOS device.
2. **Duo Mobile passcode**: Highlighted with a red outline, users are instructed to enter a code generated by the Duo Mobile app. 
3. **Text message passcode**: This entry indicates sending a passcode via text to an iOS device.
4. **Phone call**: Suggests calling an obscured number associated with the iOS device for authentication.
5. **Bypass code**: Instructs users to enter a code obtained from the IT help desk.

The right side of the screen prompts users to "Enter your passcode" with a clear box, accompanied by a "Verify" button. A note at the bottom emphasizes the application's security, marked "Secured by Duo." The overall layout is clean and functional, designed for user-friendly navigation.

Entering Your Code




For use when phone data or calls are not available, there are 2 options. 
You may use the Duo App on their phone or tablet—without any internet connection—to generate one-time codes that will allow you to authenticate to Duo.  This code will be the input for the secondary login screen for the VPN or the passcode option in the Duo pane of web authentication.  To get a code from the app, open the app and tap on the entry labeled "Duo-protected UMIACS."  This will present a 6 digit passcode.
Alternatively, YubiKey hardware tokens can be used with Duo. Hardware tokens must be enrolled by the Technical staff, so if you are interested in procuring a hardware token for use with Duo, please  contact staff. We only support registering YubiKey tokens for this purpose, no other hardware token.

︗Services
The following UMIACS services are secured with our Duo MFA solution.


GitLab
Jira
 Object Storage
VPN
Directory(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory)
Requests(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests)
MediaWiki log ins
 SSH (when coming in from off-campus)

︗FAQ
I can no longer clone HTTPS Git repositories in GitLab. How do I work around this?
Since we now require more than just your username/password to log into GitLab, you cannot use your UMIACS credentials directly for accessing HTTPS Git repositories.  We encourage you to setup an SSH key(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/help/ssh/README.md#ssh) instead.  If you have a case where you need to use HTTPS, you can use a Personal Access Token(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/help/user/profile/personal_access_tokens.md) to accomplish this.  Ensure that you create the token with API scope.  You would then use your username as normal and use the token as the password.  Treat this token as a personal secret, as it is sufficient to act as your account within GitLab.
How do I authenticate with a Token?
We only currently support YubiKey tokens for our Duo deployment.  You can follow the instructions from Yubico(The prior text links to https://guide.duo.com/tokens); you will need to tap the YubiKey once you select the Enter a Passcode field.  It will create a passcode (will look something like kffuastenhldrhfhadafdarivuntddugrvjvllddjjuget) and send a return.
