Privacy policy
About UMIACS
Disclaimers


(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/MailmanListAdmin contains the following information: 






︗MailmanListAdmin

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Mailman List Administration

1.1 Managing a List

1.1.1 Membership Management
1.1.2 Privacy options
1.1.3 Archiving Options


1.2 General Settings
1.3 Moderated Lists

1.3.1 Setup
1.3.2 For list moderators






︗Mailman List Administration
The full documentation can be found at (among other places) the Mailman administrators guide: http://www.gnu.org/software/mailman/(The prior text links to http://www.gnu.org/software/mailman/)
Once UMIACS staff has created your list, they will tell you what the password is for managing this list. You'll need this password to do various list management things such as add/remove users, approve user subscription or postings for restricted lists, and tailor the list.
If staff was provided with a list of initial subscribers, these people will have already been subscribed. Tell your users that if they'd like to subscribe, they need only go to

 http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/listinfo/LISTNAME(The prior text links to http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/listinfo/LISTNAME)

even if the list is private (not advertised or listed).
They can also subscribe/unsubscribe by email by sending to

 LISTNAME-subscribe and LISTNAME-unsubscribe

respectively. In ALL of the above cases, the user will receive email confirming their action. They need to just reply to the mail for this to take effect.

︗Managing a List
To manage your list, go to:

  http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME(The prior text links to http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME)

You will be prompted for the aforementioned password. In general, most of the default settings are likely to be fine but you should know about the following capabilities and pieces of information.

Just because you are the list administrator doesn't mean you're subscribed to (or you have to be subscribed to) this list.
Messages sent out aren't necessarily delivered immediately; it could take up to 5 minutes.
︗Membership Management
  http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME/members(The prior text links to http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME/members)

This is where you can subscribe and unsubscribe users, hide their email addresses, and more.

To subscribe other people, on this form, enter their addresses in the text window under the "Mass Subscription" section. Please note that if the user you are adding has a UMD address, you should use that address in order to comply with the Institutional email standard(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport/?sys_kb_id=6b102078dbbec8d06aa4151748961927&id=kb_article_view&sysparm_rank=2&sysparm_tsqueryId=c11ba448db4788906aa4151748961904#institutional-email-standard).
If a user goes on vacation, you can change the option to "nomail" for them on this form turning off mailing to that individual until he/she returns. Of course, users can do this themselves as well.
If a user forgets their password, clicking on the user's email address on this form allows you to send them an email message containing their password.
︗Privacy options
  http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME/privacy(The prior text links to http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME/privacy)

This is where you can specify whether or not the list is visible to the world, whether or not administrative approval is required to subscribe to the list, who can view the list of subscribers, who can post to the list (is it open or moderated?), and more.

︗Archiving Options
  http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME/archive(The prior text links to http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admin/LISTNAME/archive)

This is where you can choose whether or not to archive messages send to the list. By default, messages are archived and are available only to subscribers of the list using their subscribing password at  http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/private/LISTNAME(The prior text links to http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/private/LISTNAME). You can change this to make messages available to the public or turn off archiving entirely. Archives are not searchable.

︗General Settings
Most of the defaults for lists are probably fine but a number of them bear special mention. 
Options under Subscribing under "Privacy options":

By default, no one can see the list.
If this is not the behavior you want, change the setting on the first item "Advertise this list when people ask what lists are on this machine?" from NO to YES, and then "Submit Your Changes" on the bottom of the page. Note that even if users can't see the list, they can still subscribe (or try to subscribe). They simply need to know the URL.
By default, anyone can subscribe to the list. (To ensure that someone can't subscribe someone else as a prank, Mailman sends a confirm email message to the users asking something like, "You have been subscribed to.... Are you sure you want to subscribe? Just REPLYing to this message will subscribe you").
If this is not the behavior you want, change the setting on the second item "What steps are required for subscription?" and click "Require approval" or "Confirm and approve" and then "Submit Your Changes" on the bottom of the page. Approval means that you, as the list administrator, will get a message saying USER@HOST wants to subscribe. You can then approve or discard their request.
Option under Membership exposure under "Privacy options":

By default, only list members can see the email addresses of other list members. Users can hide their own addresses from their list subscription page. Likewise, you can hide some users and not others from the "Membership Management" page.
If you want to broadly change visibility for all users, change the setting on the first item "Who can view subscription list?" and click either "Anyone" or "List admin only" and then "Submit Your Changes" on the bottom of the page.
︗Moderated Lists
︗Setup
If you want your list to be moderated (i.e. ONLY you and/or a few others can post to it), this can be set at the bottom of the "Membership Management" --> "Membership List" page. Make sure to also set this for all new members under "Privacy options" --> "Sender filters". If moderation is set, make sure the list admin (and/or whomever you want to be able to send to the list) has their moderation bit turned off.
List admins can add moderators to a list by entering their email addresses in the "The list moderator email addresses. Multiple moderator addresses, each on separate line is okay." box on the "General Options" page of the list's admin interface:

The image displays a user interface for managing a mailing list, focusing specifically on the "General list personality" section of the Mailman application. The top of the layout is characterized by a light gray background. 

In the first box, labeled "The public name of this list (make case-changes only)," there is a blank input field where the user can enter the public name for the mailing list, indicating it can be changed but requires case sensitivity. Below that, the second box is designated for entering "The list administrator email addresses. Multiple administrator addresses, each on separate line is okay." There is also an empty text area next to this label for input. This emphasizes the capability to input multiple addresses efficiently.

The key focus of the image is the highlighted red box, which states, "The list moderator email addresses. Multiple moderator addresses, each on separate line is okay." This area includes a blank input field, allowing users to input the email addresses of moderators, indicating how administrators can manage moderation within the list. The presence of linked texts for "Details for moderator" suggests further guidance for the user. Overall, the layout is simple and functional, designed for ease of administrative tasks regarding email list management.
As soon as the first moderator is added to the list, a list admin should set the moderator password and communicate it to the initial moderator(s). This password can only be changed by a list admin. It does not give full administrative access to the list.

︗For list moderators
Moderators and administrators will receive an email similar to the following if a message is being held for moderation:

The image shows an email notification template for a mailing list administrator requesting approval for a message posting. The email is framed in a simple, clean design. At the top, it includes a brief directive, "As list administrator, your authorization is requested for the following mailing list posting:", indicating its purpose.

Beneath this header, specific details about the posting request are presented in a clear, organized manner. There are four labeled items: "List," which specifies the name of the mailing list as "Testlist@lists.umiacs.edu"; "From," indicating the sender's email address (not specified in the image); "Subject," which remains blank in this instance; and "Reason," stating "Post to moderated list."

At the bottom, the email encourages the administrator to take action, stating, "At your convenience, visit:" followed by a hyperlink to the administrative approval page. The overall tone is formal yet straightforward, designed to facilitate quick and easy administration of the moderated mailing list. The use of bullet points and clear separation of sections helps ensure readability and efficiency for the administrator.
The provided URL can also be visited at any time to view the queue of messages pending moderation:

  http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admindb/LISTNAME(The prior text links to http://lists.umiacs.umd.edu/mailman/admindb/LISTNAME)

From here, if there are one or more messages pending moderation, you will see a summary of the messages broken down per-sender. Please note that the addresses in these screenshots are hidden for privacy, but will appear on the actual moderation page.
There are two ways messages from senders may appear on this interface, depending on whether or not the sender is a member of the list:

If the sender is a member of the list (but their moderation bit is on):
The image displays a user interface for a mailing list moderation system, showcasing a section labeled "From:" at the top. To the left, there's an area called "Action to take on all these held messages," which features four radio buttons for the options: Defer, Accept, Reject, and Discard. Below these options, there is a checkbox for "Preserve messages for the site administrator," along with another checkbox for "Forward messages (individually) to:" where an empty text field is provided for entering an email address.

The right side of the interface contains details of held messages. It includes a list format showing two messages, with hyperlinked message numbers for viewing each one individually. Each message entry reveals specific attributes such as "Subject," "Size," "Reason," and "Received" timestamp, presenting clear and organized information. Both messages have reasons listed as "Post to moderated list." The overall design is functional, facilitating easy navigation and efficient management of messages pending administrator action. The layout’s simplicity supports quick comprehension and decision-making for the list administrator.
If the sender is not a member of the list:
The image displays a user interface for a mailing list moderation system. At the left section, there are four radio buttons labeled "Defer," "Accept," "Reject," and "Discard," allowing the moderator to select an action for messages held for moderation. Below this, checkboxes are provided for "Preserve messages for the site administrator" and "Forward messages (individually) to:" with an accompanying empty text field for entering an email address. 

On the right side, the "From:" section details the source of the held message, showing specific information including the subject line labeled as "[1] Subject: After changing moderation settings." Additional details underline the size of the message (5603 bytes) and the reason for moderation, noted as "Post by non-member to a members-only list." The receipt timestamp is also included, indicating when the message was received (February 4, 2020, at 9:46:29 AM). A hyperlink at the bottom encourages users to click on the message number to view the individual message or all messages from that sender, facilitating efficient message management and decision-making for the moderator. The overall layout is clean and organized, emphasizing the functionality and clarity needed for effective list administration.
From these windows, you can choose an action (Defer, Accept, Reject, Discard) for all messages from a specific sender via the radio buttons in the left sub-window, or handle individual messages by clicking on the [#] hyperlinks next to each subject line.
The key difference between the two categories of held messages (from a moderated member vs. from a non-member) is how you can handle future messages from the respective senders in the future:

For moderated members, you can choose the "Clear this member's moderate flag" option in the window for that member to automatically allow future messages from them to the list.
For non-members, you can choose to either add the sender's email address to one of the automatic filters for non-members (Accept, Hold, Reject, or Discard) to automatically action their messages in the future. There is also an option to ban the sender's email address from subscribing to the list if you see fit.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/NFS contains the following information: 






︗NFS

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Network File System(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_File_System) (NFS) is a integral part of how our UNIX and UNIX-like operating systems communicate with each other.  We utilize both NFSv2 and NFSv3 protocols and do not at this time provide support for NFSv4.  However, for v2 and v3 unlike CIFS they do not have any authentication other than IP based host authentication.  This means many of our core file systems are very restricted to who they can be mounted by.
For almost all our users, NFS volumes will be automatically mounted via the Automounter including almost all home directories, web, and ftp file systems.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=NFS&oldid=10184"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Jira contains the following information: 






︗Jira

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Jira(The prior text links to https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira) is a request and bug tracker that UMIACS uses to provide our HelpDesk functionality to our users. It can be accessed here(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/jira).
It is a web based ticketing system that allows both users and staff to maintain greater control over their tickets and makes communication and resolution of issues a seamless process. 

︗Using Jira
Jira automatically creates accounts for UMIACS Account holders. If you have a UMIACS account, you can log in to Jira using the UMIACS Single Sign On service. Otherwise, when you email Jira, a ticket is created, and the email address your mail was sent from is added as a participant to the ticket -- this means that if you create a ticket using a non-UMIACS email address, you'll have to login to Jira using that email address to see the ticket.

︗If you have a UMIACS account
Simply login to Jira's Customer Portal(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/jira/servicedesk/customer/portal/) and select the UMIACS Single Sign On to login with your UMIACS credentials.

︗None
The first time you use a new email address to submit a ticket or are included as a participant on a ticket with a non-UMIACS email address, you will get an automated email containing a link to set a password for the newly-created Jira account. After you have set your full name and password, you can log in with this email address and password at the external user page(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/jira/servicedesk/customer/user/login?nosso). If you no longer have the automated email, you can also just go to the external user page, click Forgot your password?, and enter your email address as the username to set it.
The image displays a login interface for a Request Tracker system, designed to help users create an account. The top of the interface features a welcoming message that reads, "Welcome to Request Tracker!" Below this, there is an informative statement encouraging users to set a password for future logins.

The form includes three input fields. The first field labeled "Username" contains a partially obscured email address, formatted as "[username]@gmail.com," hinting at the user's contact. The second field prompts for the user's "Full name," which is currently empty, indicating that the user needs to input their information. The third field is titled "Password," which is also empty but includes a checkbox labeled "Show password" for clarity when entering a password.

At the bottom of the form, there is a blue button labeled "Save and continue," suggesting the next step in the registration process. The overall design is clean and straightforward, featuring a muted color palette that focuses user attention on the input fields. The interface is user-friendly, catering to individuals seeking to access the system for support or ticket management.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Jira&oldid=11871"

︗Network/VPN/Linux

From UMIACS
(Redirected from Network/VPN/Ubuntu)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Pulse Secure Client.

︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Pulse Secure client
Download the client:
64 bit Pulse Secure Client .deb for Debian-based Linux (e.g. Ubuntu)(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/6/66/Pulsesecure_22.7.R3_amd64.deb)
64 bit Pulse Secure Client .rpm for Fedora-based Linux (e.g. Red Hat)(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/c/c1/Pulsesecure-22.7-R3.x86_64.rpm)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up-to-date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Navigate to the download location in terminal. e.g.:  cd ~/Downloads
Install the package with dependencies, providing your password for sudo when requested.
For a Debian-based OS, run: sudo dpkg -i <insert_filename_here>.deb
The image shows a terminal window on an Ubuntu operating system. The interface displays a command-line interface with a dark purple background, typical of many Linux terminal environments. The terminal prompt indicates that the user is logged in as "user" and is currently in the "Downloads" directory.

The visible commands include:

1. **Navigating to the Downloads folder:** `cd ~/Downloads`
2. **Installing the Pulse Secure Client:** A command that combines using `sudo dpkg -i` to install the package named "PulseSecure.deb" along with a check for dependencies. The user is prompted for their password.
3. **Messages about package selection and installation:** Lines indicate the unselected package, status updates during the unpacking process, and the configured package's version number (5.3R4.2-639).
4. **Instructions for launching the Pulse Client:** A note prompts the user to refer to a README file for further instructions regarding usage.
5. **Checking for missing dependency packages:** The terminal is responsive, indicating the system is processing the commands entered.

Overall, the image captures the process of installing VPN software, illustrating technical activity typical within Linux operating systems. 
For a Fedora-based OS, run: sudo rpm -i <insert_filename_here>.rpm
The image displays a terminal window on a Fedora Linux operating system, showcasing a command-line interface against a dark-themed background. The top of the window indicates that the terminal session is taking place in the "Downloads" directory, with the user logged in as "user". 

Key commands are visible within the terminal:

1. The command `cd ~/Downloads` is used to navigate to the Downloads folder.
2. The command `sudo rpm -i pulsesecure-22.7-R3.x86_64.rpm` suggests the installation of the Pulse Secure Client, a VPN software package, with a prompt for the user's password.
3. Following the installation command, a message indicates the enabling of the pulse services during installation or upgrade processes.

The terminal window includes a blinking cursor, suggesting that it is active and ready for further input. The overall look reflects a typical technical environment for software installation, symbolizing routine tasks performed by users familiar with Linux systems. The use of commands and the terminal's responsiveness underscores the complexity and nuances of managing software applications in a Linux context. 
You will need to manually install the packages shown below before proceeding with the install:
For a Debian-based OS, run: sudo apt-get install libnss3-tools net-tools
For a Fedora-based OS, run: sudo dnf install libbsd webkit2gtk3
Start the client.
The image depicts the user interface of an Ubuntu operating system, specifically showcasing the application launcher. The background is a rich purple, common to the Ubuntu theme, providing a vibrant contrast to the displayed elements. 

In the center, the search bar is prominently visible, labeled "Pulse Secure," indicating the user is searching for or has focused on the Pulse Secure VPN application. Below the search bar, the application icon is displayed as a stylized logo; the logo features two main colors: green and black. The design includes a green checkmark-like shape that appears to wrap around a black waveform, symbolizing security and connectivity.

The application is listed under the "Applications" section, hinting that the system is configured to launch software efficiently. Additionally, on the left-hand side, there are various icons representing different categories of applications, exemplifying the organized layout typical of Ubuntu’s user interface. This image captures a moment in the navigation process towards launching the Pulse Secure Client, emphasizing functionality and user engagement within a Linux environment. 
and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.

The window features a clean and simple layout on a vibrant purple background, typical of the Ubuntu theme. This straightforward interface emphasizes the user-friendly design of VPN management in the Pulse Secure client, aimed at allowing users to easily set up and manage their VPN connections. Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection.
Enter a name for your VPN connection and the server URL 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'.
The image features two windows from the Pulse Secure VPN application on an Ubuntu operating system, set against a gradient background that transitions from purple to red. The left window is titled "Pulse Secure" and specialized for managing VPN connections. It prominently displays the heading "Connections" in bold text, with an empty white area beneath it where users will manage their VPN settings. Below this section, there is a copyright notice confirming that the application is owned by Pulse Secure, LLC, dated 2017.

The right window, labeled "Pulse Secure," is a configuration prompt for entering VPN details. It includes fields for the user to input a connection name, specifically suggesting "UMIACS VPN," and a designated URL input, which is partially filled with "vpn.umiacs.umd.edu." Both windows maintain a clean and user-friendly appearance, emphasizing functionality and ease of navigation characteristic of Ubuntu's design. Enter the name of the VPN server.
Enter your UMIACS credentials and hit connect.
The image showcases a dual-window view of the Pulse Secure VPN application on an Ubuntu operating system against a gradient background transitioning from purple to red. 

On the left, a smaller window displays the "Connections" interface. It is titled "Pulse Secure" and features a single connection entry labeled "UMIACS VPN," highlighted with a checkbox and accompanied by a "Connect" button beneath it. This window has a standard title bar with menu options like "File" and "About" visible at the top along with the copyright notice from 2017 by Pulse Secure, LLC.

To the right, the larger window presents the login screen for Pulse Connect Secure. The header includes the title "Welcome to the Pulse Connect Secure" and prompts the user to enter their credentials with fields for "username" and "password." Below these fields is a prominent "Sign In" button, indicating the next step to establish a secure session. 

The overall interface is clean and user-friendly, consistent with Ubuntu's design aesthetics, and emphasizes the functionality and security of the VPN application. Enter UMIACS credentials.
When prompted for a secondary password, enter one of three options below (push, phone, or <press YubiKey>).  For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box. 


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN. You can close the window and the VPN will remain connected.

︗Checking VPN Status
Launch the Pulse Client GUI.

︗Network/VPN/Windows

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Ivanti Connect Secure Client.  Alternatively, you can establish a connection through a web browser(The prior text links to https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu/), but this may fail if you have an outdated version of Ivanti Secure already installed.
NOTE: If your computer has an ARM-based processor, you will need a different installer than the standard Windows one. Please refer to the instructions below.

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client
3 Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client (ARM processors)
4 Checking VPN Status


︗Prerequisites
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Secure client
Download the client:
Windows 64 bit Pulse Secure Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/f/ff/PulseSecure22.7.3.x64.msi)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up to date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Start the client if it is not already running - it usually starts by default on bootup.

Below this, there are several listed applications, including "Instagram" and "System Information," along with categories like "Settings." The "Settings" submenu includes entries for "Internet Options," "Printers & scanners," and "Wi-Fi settings." At the bottom left, the taskbar is visible with icons for various applications and the Start Menu button, appearing as a Windows logo. This scene emphasizes software accessibility for users managing their VPN services and other settings, indicating the focus on network security and user configuration. The overall color scheme is primarily dark, creating a modern aesthetic. [Windows] Start the client from the Start Menu.
If the client is already running, double click its icon from the status bar.

and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.

The Pulse VPN multi-factor authentication implementation relies on a secondary authentication source to fulfill the MFA requirement.  As a result, you will be prompted for credentials twice.


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN.
Please note, 32-bit clients are no longer supported by Ivanti!

︗None
ARM processors cannot natively run x64 or x86 programs without special emulation. However, not all x86 programs run smoothly even with emulation. As such, the best course of action for these sorts of machines is using the version of Pulse Secure that is specifically made for ARM processors.

Download the client:
Windows 64 bit ARM Pulse Secure Client(The prior text links to /umiacs/images/c/c6/PulseSecure22.7.3.ARM64.msi)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up to date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Follow all post-download steps in the above section.
︗Checking VPN Status
In the bottom right hand corner, in your status bar, you should see an S icon. If there's a green arrow, that means you are connected! If there is nothing, that means you are not.
The image shows a segment of a Windows operating system taskbar, specifically the system tray. The tray has a dark background that contrasts with the colorful application icons displayed above. Prominent icons include a Java logo, sound wave symbol, and a cloud icon with an exit (X) sign, suggesting cloud service notifications. A shield icon, representing security, is accompanied by a key icon, likely indicating password or security management. Notably, a yellow triangle with an exclamation mark serves as a warning alert, suggesting attention may be needed for that application. Other icons depict a presentation symbol and what appears to be a remote access feature. This collection of icons emphasizes a focus on network and application management, essential for users navigating VPN connections and online activities, showcasing a modern and efficient layout designed for quick access to vital features within the Windows environment. 
You can hover over this icon and it will show you the status of your connection.
The image displays a section of the Windows operating system taskbar, specifically the system tray, which has a dark background that provides contrast to the colorful application icons. Prominent in the tray is a Java logo, a sound wave icon, and a cloud icon featuring an exit (X) sign, indicating possible notifications from a cloud service or VPN. A shield symbol represents security features, while a key icon suggests password management functionality. Notably, a yellow triangle with an exclamation mark indicates a warning or alert related to one of the applications, signaling that user action may be required. Other icons include a presentation symbol and an icon likely representing a remote access feature, emphasizing a focus on network and application management. The text hovering above the Ivanti Secure Access Client icon states "Connected," signifying an active VPN connection. This visual arrangement highlights the importance of efficient management of VPN connections and user security, showcasing a modern and accessible interface that allows users to quickly identify their status and respond to any alerts or notifications.

Privacy policy

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/OSXPrinting contains the following information: 






︗MacOSPrinting

From UMIACS
(Redirected from OSXPrinting)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
We support printing from user managed macOS 13.x or later machines. 
Note: You must be on a UMIACS network directly or connected to the VPN in order to print.

︗System Settings
To start, open your System Settings from the Dock or Applications folder.  Once you have opened it, click Printers & Scanners.
The image displays a macOS interface focused on the "Printers & Scanners" section of the System Settings. The background features a soft, gradient color typical of macOS aesthetics. On the left side, a vertical navigation menu includes various options such as "Search," "Displays," "Wallpaper," and "Printers & Scanners," which is highlighted in blue.

In the main area, the title "Printers & Scanners" appears prominently at the top. Below it, a message states "No Printers," indicating that no printers are currently added. The section contains fields showing "Default printer" marked as "Last Printer Used" and "Default paper size" set to "US Letter." There is a button labeled "Add Printer, Scanner, or Fax..." prominently displayed, emphasizing the action to add a new printer. 

Overall, the layout reflects a clean, user-friendly design characteristic of macOS, aimed at simplifying printer management. The absence of clutter allows users to focus on adding or managing printers, enhancing usability.

︗None
On the Printers & Scanners page,  create a new local printer by clicking the Add Printer, Scanner, or Fax... button that is below the printer list.

︗Add Printer
This will bring up the Add Printer dialog.

Note: If you just want basic printing, use the steps below. If you would like to enable all the advanced options for the printer, jump over this section to "Enabling Advanced Printer Options".


Jump over to the IP tab
Set Protocol to Internet Printing Protocol - IPP
Set Address to print.umiacs.umd.edu
Set the Queue to printers/queue; in this example for cps432-3208 it would be printers/cps432-3208.  You have to make sure the queue is prefixed by printers/. For clarification, the queue is typically the printer name.
Set Name to the name of the printer you are trying to use. This makes it easily Identifiable in your list of printers.
It will always select Generic Postscript Printer.  If you need to access the more advanced features of a queue/printer or you were not able to print by choosing Generic Postscript Printer, you will need to take extra steps, please see the Advanced section at the bottom of this page.
Select Add
You will be asked about enabling duplex. If you know the printer has the option, which is true for most of our printers, go ahead and enable it. Then hit OK. If you're not sure, just leave it disabled. You can always enable it after the queue is added.
The image displays a macOS dialog box titled "Add Printer" with a clean and minimalist design typically associated with Apple’s user interface. The box is predominantly white with rounded corners and shadows, set against a light backdrop that enhances readability. 

At the top, there are identifiable icons for navigation, indicating connectivity and printer selection. The dialog contains several input fields for users to enter relevant information. 

- **Address**: An editable field showing the text "print.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating the necessary server for the printer connection.
- **Protocol**: This is labeled "Internet Printing Protocol - IPP," indicating the selected printing protocol.
- **Queue**: The field contains the text "printers/cps432-3208," signifying the specific printer queue for sending print jobs.
- **Name**: An editable box is awaiting input for naming the printer, with a placeholder showing "Color Printer 3208."
- **Location**: The location field is filled with "IRB 3208," indicating where the printer is physically situated.
- **Use**: A dropdown option set to "Generic PostScript Printer," suggesting the type of driver assigned to the printer.

At the bottom, there's an "Add" button, suggesting users can confirm and proceed with adding the printer. The overall layout is user-friendly, emphasizing simplicity and ease of use for the user.
You should now be able to print to this printer/queue from any macOS print menu.

︗Enabling Advanced Printer Features
Some printers may have features not accessible with the default drivers provided above. If this is the case, follow the guide below to identify, and install your print drivers from their manufacturer.

Note: If you already installed the printer with generic drivers, you will need to highlight the printer and click -, before attempting to add it again. You may also need a system update to get the latest drivers from Apple, if your printer does not have software drivers listed in the next steps.

Step 1:  Locate your printers name and search for its Make and Model here: http://print.umiacs.umd.edu/printers/(The prior text links to http://print.umiacs.umd.edu/printers/)

Step 2:  Follow the Add Printer steps above until you get to Generic Postscript Printer. Select Software, then Add.

The image displays a macOS dialog box titled "Add Printer" with a clean and minimalist design characteristic of Apple's user interface. Dominated by a white color palette, the box has rounded edges, giving it a modern appearance. It consists of several labeled input fields arranged neatly. At the top, the "Address" field contains the text "print.umiacs.umd.edu," indicating the server for printer connectivity. Below, the "Protocol" is marked as "Internet Printing Protocol - IPP," specifying the chosen printing protocol.

The "Queue" field is filled with "printers/cps432-3208," indicating a specific printer queue for job submission. Below that, the "Name" input section shows "Color Printer 3208," designating the printer's title. The "Location" field reveals "IRB 3208," where the printer is physically located. In the "Use" dropdown menu, "Generic PostScript Printer" is selected, with options to Auto Select and other driver choices visible. The bottom features a prominent "Add" button, enabling users to confirm printer addition. The overall effect is user-friendly, emphasizing simplicity and functionality in printer setup.

Step 3:  A window labeled "Printer Software" will now pop up. Scroll through the list to find your specific make and model of printer. Click on it, and hit Ok.
NOTE: If you cannot find the printer's make and model and need Advanced Printing Features, try downloading the drivers from Apple's website(The prior text links to https://support.apple.com/kb/dl1888?locale=en_US%7C) and reinstalling the printer from step 1.
The image depicts a dialog box titled "Printer Software" on a macOS interface. The box is predominantly white with rounded corners, creating a clean and modern look typical of Apple’s design aesthetics. At the top, there's a search bar labeled "Filter," allowing users to narrow down choices of printers by typing keywords.

Below the search bar, a list displays various printer models and series, formatted in alternating shades of gray for clarity. Notable entries include "DYMO Label Printer," "Epson 24-Pin Series," "HP DeskJet Series," and "Zebra EPL1 Label Printer," among others. Each printer option is presented on a separate line, making it easy to read through the list.

At the bottom of the dialog box, there are two options: a "Cancel" button on the left and an "OK" button on the right, which is highlighted in blue, indicating the preferred action for confirming a selection. The overall layout emphasizes simplicity and usability, facilitating the process of selecting the appropriate printer software for the user’s needs.
Step 4:  Click Add on the next window and it should install your printer's software suite. You should have a list of options (if they are available) that looks similar this:
The image depicts a macOS dialog box labeled "Adding Printer" with the title "Setting up ‘Color Printer 3208…’". The box features a minimalist design typical of Apple’s interface, set against a soft gray background. At the top, a simple printer icon illustrates the dialog's purpose. Below the title, a message instructs users to ensure their printer’s options are accurately indicated for optimal use.

A checkbox is displayed, labeled "Duplex Printing Unit," allowing users to enable or disable double-sided printing options. This checkbox is currently unchecked. The layout is clean and organized, facilitating easy navigation and comprehension for the user.

At the bottom of the dialog, there are two prominent buttons: "Cancel" on the left, allowing users to exit the setup, and "OK" on the right, highlighted in blue, indicating the action to proceed with the current selections. Overall, the design emphasizes clarity and functionality, ensuring users can efficiently finalize their printer setup.
Final Step: Enable the Options you wish to use, Click OK.  You should now be able to print to this printer/queue from any macOS print menu.

︗Printing With Stapler
For print jobs using the stapler, follow the guide below.  Printers with staplers are located in Iribe, in rooms 3149, 3208, 4149, 4208, and 5208.
To add/ connect to a printer with stapling capabilities:

Step 1: Follow the "Enabling Advanced Printer Features" guide until you reach Step 4.

Step 2: In the window that appears labeled "Setting up [your printer name]" set "HP 3-Bin Stapler/Stacker" to "Mailbox Mode".

The image displays a macOS dialog box titled "Setting up ‘5208 Printer w/ Stapler…’" featuring a minimalist design typical of Apple’s interface, set against a dark gray backdrop. At the top left, an illustrative printer icon reinforces the box's function. Below the title, a message prompts users to ensure all printer options are correctly displayed for optimal use. 

The dialog contains several lines indicating printer trays, specifically "Tray 3," "Tray 4," "Tray 5," and "Tray 6," all marked as "Not Installed," signifying the absence of these paper trays. Each line includes a dropdown arrow for potential selection or configuration. Perhaps most notably, there is a section dedicated to the "HP 3-Bin Stapler/Stacker," labeled as "Mailbox Mode," indicating functionality related to the printer's stapling feature.

At the bottom of the dialog, two prominent buttons, "Cancel" on the left and "OK" on the right, facilitate user navigation. The "OK" button is highlighted in blue, suggesting it is the primary action to continue with the configuration. Overall, the layout emphasizes clarity and ease of use for efficient printer setup.

Step 3: Select "OK" in the bottom right corner.

To Print: To complete the print job using the stapler once the printer has been added:

Step 1: In Preview, when trying to print, select the "Show Details" button in the bottom left corner.

The image displays a macOS print dialog box titled "Print," specifically for the printer labeled "5208." The interface follows Apple’s minimalist design philosophy, featuring a predominantly gray and white color scheme. At the top, the selected printer’s name is clear, and the preset option shows "Default Settings." 

The section for "Copies" allows users to select how many copies they want, set to one, with an option for two-sided printing indicated by a checkbox. Below that, the "Pages" section defaults to "All," indicating that all pages of the document will be printed. The "Paper Size" is set to "US Letter," with dimensions showing 8.50 by 11.00 inches.

An "Orientation" option includes icons for portrait and landscape views, allowing for easy selection. An additional "Auto Rotate" option is checked, suggesting the system will adjust the orientation if necessary. There are settings for "Scale" with the current scale at 92%, and a selection for fitting the print to the page, offering two choices: "Print Entire Image" and "Fill Entire Paper." Lastly, at the bottom, options for "Cancel" and the highlighted "Print" button are present, indicating the action to finalize the print job.

Step 2: In the middle right, where it says "Preview," select "Printer Features" instead of "Preview".

The image displays a macOS print dialog titled "Print" for the printer "5208." It features a sleek, minimalist design with a predominantly gray and white color scheme, characteristic of Apple's interface. At the top, the printer name is clearly identified, accompanied by a preset option labeled "Default Settings." 

The first section allows the user to specify the number of copies, currently set to one, with a checkbox option for two-sided printing. The "Pages" field defaults to "All," indicating that the entire document will be printed. The "Paper Size" is preset to "US Letter," showcasing standard dimensions of 8.50 by 11.00 inches. 

Users can select their desired orientation through icons for portrait and landscape alignment, and there’s an "Auto Rotate" option checked, allowing the printer to adjust orientation as necessary. The "Scale" setting is currently at 92%, with choices for fitting the print to the page provided. 

At the bottom, users find "Cancel" and a highlighted "Print" button, which stands out, signaling the final action to initiate the print job. The layout is user-friendly, ensuring efficient navigation and setup for printing tasks.

Step 3: Set "Feature Sets" to "Finishing".

The image displays a macOS print dialog box titled "Print" for the printer labeled "5208." The interface features Apple's characteristic minimalist design with a gray and white color scheme. At the top, the selected printer's name is clearly indicated, alongside the preset option labeled "Default Settings." 

In the "Copies" section, users can specify the number of copies to print, set to one, with an available checkbox for enabling two-sided printing. The "Pages" section defaults to "All," meaning every page of the document will be printed. The "Paper Size" is standardized at "US Letter," measuring 8.50 by 11.00 inches. 

Orientation options allow users to select between portrait and landscape modes, with an "Auto Rotate" checkbox checked, suggesting that the printer will adjust the document's orientation if needed. Below, the "Scale" setting, currently at 92%, provides options for adjusting the document size to fit the page. 

At the bottom of the dialog, escape options "Cancel" and a prominent "Print" button are present, inviting the user to finalize the print job. The interface is designed for straightforward navigation, ensuring an efficient printing process.

Step 4: A "Staple" dropdown list will appear at the bottom of the window.  Select your preferred staple option.

The image showcases a macOS print dialog box titled "Print" for printer model "5208." The interface exhibits Apple's minimalist design, characterized by a predominantly gray and white color scheme, enhancing clarity and focus. At the top, the selected printer’s name, "5208," is prominently displayed alongside the preset option labeled "Default Settings." 

In the "Copies" section, users can choose the number of copies to print, currently set to one, with a checkbox available for enabling two-sided printing. The "Pages" selection defaults to "All," ensuring that the entire document will be printed. The "Paper Size" is set to "US Letter," with dimensions clearly listed as 8.50 by 11.00 inches.

The orientation options feature icons for portrait and landscape settings, accompanied by an "Auto Rotate" checkbox, which indicates that the printer will automatically adjust the orientation if necessary. 

In the "Feature Sets," the option is set to "Finishing," allowing for additional settings. The bottom of the dialog includes an "Output Bin" dropdown, currently set to "Automatically Select," and a "Staple" dropdown menu, offering several staple configurations such as "None," "One Staple Left Angled," and "One Staple Right Angled." 

Lastly, the prominent blue "Print" button invites users to begin the printing process, emphasizing usability and efficiency.

Step 5: Press "Print" in the bottom right corner.

︗Printing Stored Jobs
Pre-requisite: Requires  advanced print features to be enabled.
If you are printing a sensitive document and do not want the printer to print it right away, you can configure a stored job. The stored job lets you hold a print job until you enter a PIN to release the job. You can configure a stored job following the instructions below:

Go to File > Print or Press Command + P to open the Printer menu.
Select the printer where you want to send the print job.
Click the dropdown list under Copies & Pages and select Job Storage.
The image shows a macOS print dialog box prominently labeled "Print." At the top left, the selected printer is "B/W Printer 3208," with preset options indicated as "Default Settings." Below this, a dropdown menu allows users to select settings for "Copies & Pages," along with various other configurations. Currently, the number of copies is set to "1" with options for page selections featuring a range selection tool.

The layout maintains a minimalist aesthetic consistent with Apple's design philosophy, utilizing a dark background that enhances visual clarity. The left side of the dialog displays a preview thumbnail of the document to be printed, which appears to feature an old document or certificate with a seal.

Below the preview, there's an option to "Show Quick Preview," allowing users to see a larger representation of the document. The bottom right corner hosts the "Cancel" and "Print" buttons, the latter being highlighted to indicate the primary action for users wishing to finalize the print job. The dialog box clearly emphasizes user-friendliness and straightforward navigation for printing tasks.
From the Mode dropdown list, select Personal Job (or Stored Job if you want to share the document with others).
The image shows a macOS print dialog box titled "Print," prominently featuring the selected printer "B/W Printer 3208." The interface adopts a minimalist design typical of Apple’s aesthetic, marked by a dark background that enhances visibility. At the top, users can see the printer’s name alongside a dropdown menu for preset options, including "Quick Copy," "Proof and Hold," and "Stored Job." 

Below this dropdown, the "Mode" section allows selection between standard printing and stored configurations, with "Personal Job" currently highlighted. A field for entering the user's name has options for default or custom entries, while a "Job Name" input allows naming the print job, with the placeholder "The Jedi Manife" indicating a sample title. 

An option is available to check for existing job names, accompanied by a checkbox for enabling a PIN for printing. At the bottom, the dialog displays space for entering a PIN number, with buttons for "Cancel" and the highlighted "Print" action on the right. The design emphasizes clarity, ensuring straightforward navigation for users needing to configure advanced print settings.
Leave the username to default or specify a custom username.
Check the box Use PIN to Print and enter a 4-digit number. Hit Print.
The image displays a macOS print dialog box titled "Print," primarily showcasing the printer "B/W Printer 3208." The interface features a dark background that enhances the visibility of its minimalist elements, characteristic of Apple's design ethos. 

At the top, the selected printer name is clearly displayed, with the preset options marked as "Default Settings." Below that, an options dropdown is available under the label "Copies & Pages," where users can manage various printing configurations. The current setting for the number of copies is indicated as "1," accompanied by other options like selecting specific pages.

A key area within the dialog is the "Mode" dropdown, which allows users to choose among typical printing selections. "Personal Job" is highlighted in this case, indicating the user wishes to store the print job temporarily. Below this, fields for entering both the user's name and a custom job name are present, with the latter showing a placeholder titled "The Jedi Manife."

An essential checkbox labeled "Use PIN to Print" is selected, enabling enhanced security for the print job. At the bottom, options for "Cancel" and "Print" are available, with the "Print" button prominently highlighted, indicating it as the primary action for finalizing this print configuration.
To print the stored jobs:

From the Home screen of the printer tap on Print from Job Storage (or Print > Print from Job Storage).
In the Stored Job to Print screen, select the name of the folder where the job is stored. By default, the name of the folder will be your username unless you customized it earlier.
Select the name of the document and enter the PIN.
Hit Print.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/VScode contains the following information: 






︗VS Code

From UMIACS
(Redirected from VScode)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Visual Studio (VS) Code(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/) is a multi-platform source-code editor developed by Microsoft. It can be used with a variety of programming languages and can have its base functionality extended through extensions available via its marketplace(The prior text links to https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/vscode). The base editor itself is free, but some extensions may require paid subscriptions.

︗Contents

1 Cluster Usage

1.1 Best Practices

1.1.1 Use only as a code editor
1.1.2 Do not open large files
1.1.3 Clean up when done




2 Common Issues


︗Cluster Usage
It can be convenient when using our SLURM computing clusters to open a connection to a VS Code Server(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/vscode-server) session on the submission node(s) that you have access to via VS Code's Remote - SSH extension(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/ssh). Steps to set this up can be found here(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/ssh#_installation). Use your UMIACS username and the fully qualified domain name (FQDN)(The prior text links to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fully_qualified_domain_name) of the submission node you want to connect to. Password authentication does not provide an option to save your password, so for convenience, you may want to set up an  SSH key.
For a list of active issues with the Remote - SSH extension, please see Microsoft's GitHub tracker here(The prior text links to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-remote-release/labels/ssh).

︗Best Practices
Because of the multi-tenant nature of our submission nodes, using the Remote - SSH extension to connect to a VS Code Server running on a submission node can have adverse affects on other users simultaneously using the submission nodes if not properly managed. The following is a list of "best practices" that we ask you please follow to minimize the chance of impacting others on submission nodes. We have compiled the list through observation as well as through discussion with users.

︗Use only as a code editor
VS Code can perform many common file management operations, such as moving, copying, or deleting files or directories. However, the overhead of providing progress updates / status messages through VS Code's UI can cause load spikes that result in other processes on the submission node (both system-level and other users') slowing down. This is especially the case if operating on thousands to millions of small image or video files. In extreme cases, it can seem as though the submission node is wholly unresponsive.
The best way to combat this is to use VS Code as just a code editor as strictly as you can (meaning creating new and/or editing existing source code files only). Use standard command-line programs such as mv/cp/rm in VS Code's terminal window or a separate application's terminal window for local file management instead, or use the techniques advertised  here for larger data transfers between nodes.

︗Do not open large files
Files that you open in VS Code's text editor on a remote machine through the Remote - SSH extension are loaded entirely into RAM on the remote machine. Because of the persistence of VS Code Server processes, opening several unique files may result in them all remaining in RAM for extended periods of time even if you no longer have tabs open for them in the Tab Bar.
As such, please refrain from opening large files (more than a few MB) in VS Code itself on submission nodes. Either use a lighter-weight command-line based text editor such as vim(The prior text links to https://www.vim.org/) or otherwise on the submission node itself, or first  transfer the files that you would like to open to either a less-used remote machine or your local machine before opening them.
If you absolutely need to open one or more large files for a very brief period of time on a submission node, please clean up your server session on that node (see below section) as soon as possible when done.

︗Clean up when done
If you are done using VS Code for an extended period of time (several hours / overnight), consider manually killing your server session on the submission node when exiting. By default, VS Code Server will keep the processes used by your session active for a few hours after you disconnect, keeping the VS Code Server processes on the submission node you were using alive, despite no longer actively being used.
This can be done by opening the Command Palette(The prior text links to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/userinterface#_command-palette) (Ctrl+Shift+P) and searching "Kill VS Code Server on Host...".

The image displays a user interface from Visual Studio Code (VS Code), specifically showing the Command Palette feature. At the top, there’s a search input field containing the text “Kill VS Code Server on Host…”, which indicates the user's intent to terminate the server session. Below this, the suggestion "Remote-SSH: Kill VS Code Server on Host…" is highlighted, indicating it was recently used. The background is predominantly dark with blue accents that highlight selected elements, giving a sleek, modern appearance typical of code editing applications. The layout emphasizes ease of access to commands, which is crucial for developers managing multiple server sessions effectively. Overall, the interface illustrates a common action taken by users to manage resources in a remote coding environment, reflecting best practices in minimizing resource usage while maintaining efficiency in coding workflows.
Select the submission node you were using and click on it.

The image features a user interface element from Visual Studio Code (VS Code), specifically showcasing the search functionality within the Command Palette. Positioned at the top is a clear search input field, displaying the text "nexus," which indicates the user may be searching for a specific server to connect to. Below this input area, two suggestions appear: "00.umiacs.umd.edu" and "01.umiacs.umd.edu," both highlighted in blue against a dark background, suggesting they are viable options. The interface design emphasizes a modern aesthetic, with dark shades complemented by blue accents that enhance visibility, typical of developer tools. This arrangement facilitates quick access, making it easy for users to navigate and select submission nodes efficiently. The spatial relationship between the input field and the drop-down suggestions illustrates the interactive nature of VS Code, where users can quickly locate and connect to servers. Overall, the image encapsulates a functional aspect of remote server management, showcasing VS Code's utility in streamlining coding workflows for developers.
Wait a few seconds and you should get a message confirming the command went through.

The image depicts a notification panel from Visual Studio Code (VS Code), indicating a successful action taken by the user. The message displayed is "Killed VS Code Server on nexus," which confirms that the user terminated their server session on a specific node, identified as "00.umiacs.umd.edu." The text is set against a predominantly dark background, characteristic of VS Code's user interface, with blue text for the notification to draw attention. To the right, there is a prominent blue button labeled "Open Logs," suggesting an option for the user to access detailed logging information related to this action. Below the notification, the source is labeled as "Remote - SSH," indicating that this action was executed via the Remote - SSH extension of VS Code. The overall layout is clean and concise, emphasizing clarity in communicating important status updates to the user within a coding environment. This image illustrates an essential operation for managing remote development sessions effectively in VS Code.
The next time you connect to the same submission node, you will have a fresh VS Code session on it.

︗Common Issues
If you are having trouble SSH'ing to a submission node with VS Code, check if your home directory is full.

Connect to one of your Nexus submission nodes via SSH not using VS Code.
 Remote connect to a server
Navigate to your home directory. cd ~
Check if it is full. df -h .
If it is full (Avail 0), delete some files to free up at least ~100MB of space. Filesystem                                    Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
data.isilon.umiacs.umd.edu:/ifs/umiacs/homes   30G   30G     0 100% /fs/nfshomes
Try connecting with VS Code again.

Privacy policy

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/ConferenceRooms/ATL3373 contains the following information: 






︗ATL/ConferenceRooms

From UMIACS
(Redirected from ConferenceRooms/ATL3373)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The following is the list of UMIACS-managed conference rooms in the Atlantic building. General topics:

 Using the Solstice Mersive Pods
 Recording and Streaming
 Using Zoom
︗Contents

1 ATL 3100A

1.1 Sources

1.1.1 Room PC
1.1.2 Solstice
1.1.3 Laptop


1.2 Shutting Down


2 ATL 3100C/3100D/3373

2.1 Sources

2.1.1 Room PC
2.1.2 Laptop
2.1.3 Solstice


2.2 Shutting Down




︗ATL 3100A
This conference room comes equipped with a touch panel that can be used to control the video and audio source(s) and level(s) being used to project to the displays in the room. There is a Room PC ("PC Main"), a Solstice Pod ("Solstice"), and an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Laptop").
There is also an "Audio Override" output device that you can project any of the input sources to. This decouples the source audio from the source video so that you can send audio from one source to the audio output while maintaining video from a difference source. The primary use of this is to be able to prevent echoing and have teleconferencing participants be able to hear the room audience when using both a laptop and the room PC to present. With both devices in the same teleconference session, leave "Laptop" as the source video and switch the audio override to "PC Main" to display what is on the laptop but use the microphones spread throughout the room to hear the audience.
The image displays a close-up view of a touchscreen control panel from a conference room's audio/visual (A/V) system, designed by Crestron. The interface is organized into distinct sections and buttons for user interaction. 

At the top, there is a prominent red button labeled "Shutdown A/V System," indicating the option to power down the audio-visual setup. Below that, a central button labeled "Device Control" suggests additional options for managing connected devices. 

The panel features two main operational areas: one for selecting the source (Laptop and PC Main) and another for the destination (Projector and Laptop Monitor). The source buttons are represented as icons, including a laptop and a blank screen, while the destination buttons are similar, featuring visuals of a projector and a monitor. 

In the middle, a circular blue button labeled "Audio Override" allows control over audio settings, underscoring the importance of sound management in presentations. An instructional message at the bottom reminds users to first select a source to route and then choose a destination. The overall color scheme is predominantly light gray with blue and red accents, lending a professional and functional aesthetic.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP address has been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image displays a digital screen featuring the interface for the Solstice Pod in conference room ATL3100A. The background is an abstract, textural representation, possibly inspired by natural landscapes, with rich, dark tones interspersed with vibrant blues, greens, and earth tones creating a striking visual effect. At the top left, the text "ATL3100a Pod" is prominently displayed in a bold, light font, accompanied by the room number "3250" beside it, hinting at the room's functionality. 

In the lower part of the screen, the time reads "9:44 AM," indicating the current time. To the right, a set of three instructional steps appears in a clear, sans-serif font, briefly guiding users on how to connect their devices. The instructions include: "1. Connect your device to INTERNAL," "2. Browse to the address above," and "3. Connect." 

Additionally, a note mentions that "Apple users can AirPlay to ATL3100a-Pod," suggesting compatibility with Apple devices. The screen also features a black bar at the bottom with a URL area, partially obscured, underscoring the privacy measures in place. Overall, the interface merges functionality with an appealing aesthetic.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "Shutdown A/V System" button when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the displays for the room and raise the projector screen.
The image depicts a digital touchscreen control panel designed by Crestron, prominently displaying the message "A/V System Shutting Down Please Wait." The screen is predominantly light blue with a subtle textured background, indicating the process of the audio/visual (A/V) system powering down. At the center of the screen, the text is presented in a clear, bold font, ensuring visibility for users needing to shut down the system. Below the text, a loading icon provides a visual cue that the shutdown procedure is currently in progress. 

The panel's frame is a light gray color, complementing the blue of the screen. At the top of the panel, there is a narrow black strip, possibly housing sensors or additional control options, although no specific details about their functions are provided. The branding "CRESTRON" is subtly positioned at the bottom, reinforcing the professionalism and modernity of the technology. The overall appearance is clean and user-friendly, designed for efficient interaction in conference settings. This image conveys the importance of proper A/V system management within the context of staff and meeting functionality.

︗None
These conference rooms each come equipped with a simplified touch panel that can be used to control the video source being used to project to the display in the room as well adjust the audio level for the display. There is a Room PC ("Dedicated PC"), an HDMI cable to use a laptop or external device ("Table Laptop"), and a Solstice Pod ("Mersive Wireless").
The image showcases a digital touchscreen control panel for an audio-visual (A/V) system, prominently designed by Crestron. The panel features a sleek, rectangular shape with a predominantly blue interface against a light gray frame. A button labeled “SYSTEM POWER” is located at the top, providing the primary control for the A/V system.

Below it are additional icons for audio management: one for increasing volume and another for decreasing it, represented by speaker symbols. The central section displays three selectable options: “Dedicated PC,” “Table Laptop,” and “Mersive Wireless.” Each option is enclosed within rounded rectangular buttons, allowing for easy touch interaction.

The background is a gradient of blue tones, creating a professional appearance. The text is clearly legible in a lighter font, enhancing user-friendliness. The overall clean design emphasizes functionality, inviting users to easily manage their presentations while ensuring an efficient conference experience. The lack of clutter and intuitive layout reflects the technology's purpose in streamlining audio-visual management within the conference room setting.

︗Sources
︗Room PC
Use the wireless keyboard/mouse combo on the desk in the room to use the room PC. Choose the Conference account to sign into, which does not need a password. Please be sure to log off when you are done using the room PC, as the account is fully wiped when you log off, ensuring the next group using the room does not have access to anything you may have signed into.

︗Laptop
Connect your device to the HDMI cable coming out of the middle of the desk in the room to display your device to the room's display over a wired connection.

︗Solstice
This option will prompt you to look at the display in the room for instructions on how to display your device(s) to the room's display wirelessly. More specific instructions can be found  here. Note that the IP addresses have been blacked out in the below photo for privacy reasons, but will show properly when you are physically in the room.
The image showcases a large digital screen displaying the interface for the Solstice Pod in conference room ATL3373. The background features a captivating abstract design, inspired by natural landscapes, primarily encompassing deep, rich blue and green hues contrasted with lighter accents, creating a dynamic visual texture. ︗Shutting Down
Please be sure to touch the "System Power" button and select "Power Off" when you are done using the room to save energy and give the next group using the room a clean slate. This will turn off the display for the room.
The image showcases a digital control panel designed for managing audio-visual (A/V) systems. The panel features a rectangular touchscreen interface set against a white casing. The central display is predominantly dark blue, enhancing visibility of the options presented. At the center of the screen, two prominent buttons labeled “Power On” and “Power Off” allow users to easily activate or deactivate the system, each button in a bright blue hue with rounded edges for touch interaction.

Below these options is a smaller blue button labeled “BACK,” enabling users to return to the previous menu. The overall layout is straightforward and user-friendly, with clear separation between functional elements, ensuring efficient access for conference attendees. The design emphasizes simplicity and functionality, making it suitable for quick operations in a conference setting. The minimal color palette and clear labeling contribute to a professional appearance, reflecting the high-tech nature of the A/V equipment used in the room.

︗Nexus/CBCB

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The compute nodes from CBCB's previous standalone cluster have folded into Nexus as of mid 2023.
The Nexus cluster already has a large pool of compute resources made possible through college-level funding for UMIACS and CSD faculty. Details on common nodes already in the cluster (Tron partition) can be found  here.
Please  contact staff with any questions or concerns.

︗Contents

1 Submission Nodes
2 Nodes
3 Partitions
4 QoS
5 Jobs
6 Storage
7 Migration

7.1 Operating System / Software




︗Submission Nodes
You can SSH to nexuscbcb.umiacs.umd.edu to log in to a submission host.
If you store something in a local directory (/tmp, /scratch0) on one of the two submission hosts, you will need to connect to that same submission host to access it later. The actual submission hosts are:

nexuscbcb00.umiacs.umd.edu
nexuscbcb01.umiacs.umd.edu
︗Nodes
All nodes in CBCB-owned partitions (see below section) owned by CBCB faculty are named in the format cbcb##. The sets of nodes are:

22 nodes that were purchased in October 2022 with center-wide funding.  They are cbcb[00-21].
4 nodes from the previous standalone CBCB cluster that moved in as of Summer 2023.  They are cbcb[22-25].
A few additional nodes purchased by Dr. Heng Huang since then.  They are all remaining 'cbcb' named nodes.


Nodenames

CPU cores per node (CPUs)

Memory per node (type)

Local storage per node (type/location)

GPUs per node (type)

︗Partitions
There are two partitions available to general CBCB SLURM users. You must specify one of these two partitions when submitting your job.

cbcb - This is the default partition. Job allocations on all nodes except those also in the cbcb-heng partition are guaranteed.
cbcb-interactive - This is a partition that only allows interactive jobs; you cannot submit jobs via sbatch to this partition. Job allocations are guaranteed.
There is one additional partition available solely to Dr. Heng Huang's sponsored accounts.

cbcb-heng - This partition is for exclusive priority access to Dr. Huang's purchased GPU nodes. Job allocations are guaranteed.
︗QoS
CBCB users have access to all of the  standard job QoSes in the cbcb and cbcb-heng partitions using the cbcb account.
The additional job QoSes for the cbcb and cbcb-heng partitions specifically are:

highmem: Allows for significantly increased memory to be allocated.
huge-long: Allows for longer jobs using higher overall resources.
Please note that the partition has a GrpTRES limit of 100% of the available cores/RAM on the partition-specific nodes in aggregate plus 50% of the available cores/RAM on legacy## nodes in aggregate, so your job may need to wait if all available cores/RAM (or GPUs) are in use.
The only allowed job QoS for the cbcb-interactive partition is:

interactive: Allows for 4 CPU / 128G mem jobs up to 12 hours in length - can only be used via srun or salloc.
︗Jobs
You will need to specify --partition=cbcb and --account=cbcb to be able to submit jobs to the CBCB partition. 

[username@nexuscbcb00:~ ] $ srun --pty --ntasks=16 --mem=2000G --qos=highmem --partition=cbcb --account=cbcb --time 1-00:00:00 bash
srun: job 218874 queued and waiting for resources
srun: job 218874 has been allocated resources
[username@cbcb00:~ ] $ scontrol show job 218874
JobId=218874 JobName=bash
   UserId=username(1000) GroupId=username(21000) MCS_label=N/A
   Priority=897 Nice=0 Account=cbcb QOS=highmem
   JobState=RUNNING Reason=None Dependency=(null)
   Requeue=1 Restarts=0 BatchFlag=0 Reboot=0 ExitCode=0:0
   RunTime=00:00:06 TimeLimit=1-00:00:00 TimeMin=N/A

︗Storage
CBCB still has its current storage(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/cbcb-private/index.php/Storage) allocation in place.  All data filesystems that were available in the standalone CBCB cluster are also available in Nexus.  Please note about the change in your home directory in the migration section below.
CBCB users can also request  Nexus project allocations.

︗Migration
︗None
CBCB's standalone cluster submission and compute nodes were running RHEL7.  Nexus is exclusively running RHEL8, so any software you may have compiled may need to be re-compiled to work correctly in this new environment.  The CBCB module tree(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/cbcb/index.php/CBCB_Software_Modules) for RHEL8 may not yet be fully populated with RHEL8 software.  If you do not see the modules you need, please reach out to the CBCB software maintainers(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/cbcb/index.php/CBCB_Software_Modules#Contact).
