〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/KVM contains the following information: 






︗KVM

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
KVM (for Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is a full virtualization solution for Linux on x86 hardware containing virtualization extensions (Intel VT or AMD-V). It consists of a loadable kernel module, kvm.ko, that provides the core virtualization infrastructure and a processor specific module, kvm-intel.ko or kvm-amd.ko. KVM also requires a modified QEMU although work is underway to get the required changes upstream.
Using KVM, one can run multiple virtual machines running unmodified Linux or Windows images. Each virtual machine has private virtualized hardware: a network card, disk, graphics adapter, etc.
The kernel component of KVM is included in mainline Linux as of 2.6.20.
The system image for the virtual machine should be on local disk space.  Putting a running virtual machine on networked file space will result in poor performance for both the virtual machine, as well as other users of the filespace.

︗Contents

1 Getting Started
2 Creating a virtual machine

2.1 Initializing the machine
2.2 Forwarding Ports
2.3 Windows Example




︗Getting Started
In order to start using KVM on your machine, UMIACS Staff will first need to install the requisite packages and set a baseline configuration.  Please  contact staff along with a brief explanation of your goals for running a local virtual machine.  Note: Ubuntu requires you to be in the kvm group on the local host.
Once staff has installed the required packages you can then use the program 'virt-manager' to initialize and manager your virtual machines.

In a terminal run:
virt-manager -c qemu:///session
This will bring up a graphical interface which can be used to manage various aspects of your virtual machines.  The network that is available is called usermode networking which provides a NAT connection to the outside world.  See below about forwarding ports using qemu-kvm.
︗Creating a virtual machine
︗Initializing the machine
In virt-manager, highlight 'localhost' and then click the 'New' button.  This will bring up a new window that will guide you through configuring your virtual machine.  For the most part, you should stick with the default options.

︗Forwarding Ports
This functionality is only available by editing the XML file for your domain directly.  Libvirt(The prior text links to http://libvirt.org/drvqemu.html#qemucommand) has the capability to pass arguments directly to the qemu binary.  First create your VM with virt-manager and then shut it down.  Run in a shell virsh -c qemu:///session which will drop you into the virsh shell.   You can list your VMs both running and off by typing list --all.  Find the name of the VM and type edit NAME where NAME is the name of the VM.
You need to replace the <domain> tag in the first line to:

   <domain type='kvm' xmlns:qemu='http://libvirt.org/schemas/domain/qemu/1.0'>

Then you need to insert the following lines directly above the last line which should have the </domain> tag.  In this case the port 2222 will be forwarded to the port 22.   You may specify multiple ports here but each needs its own -redir line and the port specifications.

   <qemu:commandline>
      <qemu:arg value='-redir'/>
      <qemu:arg value='tcp:2222::22'/>
    </qemu:commandline>

Here is an example forwarding 3389 to 3389 (RDP) when running Windows (you may need to activate RDP within your Windows VM).

   <qemu:commandline>
      <qemu:arg value='-redir'/>
      <qemu:arg value='tcp:3389::3389'/>
    </qemu:commandline>

︗Windows Example
You can start a windows install with virt-install in a rather automated fashion.  Here is an example using a Windows 10 x64 ISO with 40G disk and 16GB of RAM. Please note that this should spawn virt-viewer automatically and show you the Windows installer screen.

virt-install --connect qemu:///session --name=win10 --os-type=windows --network user --disk path=/scratch0/username/win10.img,size=40 --cdrom=/scratch0/username/Win10x64.iso --graphics spice --ram=16384

︗Windows

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Windows is a desktop and server operating system made by Microsoft. For a list of what Windows versions we currently support, please see  this page.

︗Contents

1 Activation
2 Windows Servicing
3 Programming Environments
4 Other Resources


︗Activation
See Windows Activation if you need to activate Windows on a UMIACS supported desktop or laptop.
Related: See Microsoft Office Activation if you need to activate Microsoft Office on a UMIACS supported desktop or laptop.

︗Windows Servicing
See WindowsServicing for an overview of how we run Windows feature updates at UMIACS.

︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Moderated

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
These signature  rooms have a primary coordinator and a backup moderator.  The touch panels will not allow walk up reservations for these rooms; all reservations need to go through the moderation process.  You may  create a reservation by adding the room in Google Calendar.  The moderators will be notified and will either approve or deny your request.
Instructions on reserving a room are  here.

︗Large Seminar Capabilities
Rooms 3137 and 4105 are the two large seminar rooms and have the following setup.

Dual Display (Projector and LCD)
Dual camera conferencing via room PC
Laptop presentation via HDMI or  Mersive Solstice
Blu-ray playback, TV tuner
Lectern
︗Small Seminar and Large Conference Room Capabilities
Every other room on this page has the following setup.

Single Display (LCD)
Single camera conferencing via room PC
Laptop presentation via HDMI or  Mersive Solstice
︗Conference Rooms with Phone Capabilities
Some moderated IRB conference rooms have soft dialing enabled from the Crestron pads.
To answer a call: Start the system, select phone, and hit the "dial/answer" button. To dial out, use prefix 91 for external numbers. (For campus extensions, just dial the 5 digit extension.) Below are the list of phone numbers associated with moderated conference rooms.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/AddingUMIACSCertificateAuthority contains the following information: 






︗AddingUMIACSCertificateAuthority

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Introduction
2 Windows
3 Safari and Google Chrome (macOS)
4 Other Browsers (Unix)


︗Introduction
When you visit webpages encrypted with SSL, you may be presented with a warning about the site's security certificate not being trusted. These are normally important screens to pay attention to on the internet as a whole and UMIACS goes to great lengths to maintain a secure environment for our users.  However, it is not cost effective to provide commercial certs for all our public facing certificates.  In order to keep costs down we provide a UMIACS CA (certificate authority) that enables your web browser to trust our secure webpages. The following steps explain how to import this certificate based on your preferred web browser.

︗Windows
For most Windows browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Edge and Internet Explorer), certificate authorities are handled by Windows itself. These are the steps required to accept the certificate:

Click UMIACS Certificate Authority(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/images/7/7d/CA-cert.crt) to download the file.
Open the file and click "Install Certificate".
The image displays a Windows certificate information dialog box. The window is rectangular, featuring a white background with a gray title bar at the top. It includes an error message, indicated by a triangular warning icon with an exclamation mark, stating, "This CA Root certificate is not trusted. To enable trust, install this certificate in the Trusted Root Certification Authorities store." 

Key details in the dialog box show the certificate's information: it is issued to "UMIACS Certificate Authority" and also issued by the same authority. The validity dates range from September 19, 2016, to September 17, 2026. The content is organized into sections such as "General," "Details," and "Certification Path."

At the bottom of the dialog, a prominent button labeled "Install Certificates…" is highlighted with an arrow pointing to it, indicating the next action the user should take. The button is distinctly larger than other text elements, drawing attention to the importance of installing the certificate. The overall layout emphasizes the need for user action to resolve trust issues with the certificate.
In the dialog box opened, click "Next".
Choose "Place all certificates in the following store".
Choose "Browse", in the dialog box opened, Choose "Trusted Root Certification Authorities" and click "Ok".
The image depicts a user interface for the Certificate Import Wizard on a Windows system, designed for importing digital certificates. The wizard is presented in a rectangular window featuring a light gray background. The left side displays the main instruction, "Certificate Store," indicating areas where certificates are managed. 

On the left half, a radio button is selected next to "Place all certificates in the following store," directing user action. Below, a text box labeled "Certificate store" is empty, accompanied by a prominent blue button labeled "Browse…," visually emphasized by an arrow pointing at it. This element signifies the next step in the process. 

To the right, a secondary window titled "Select Certificate Store" showcases a hierarchical view of various storage options for certificates. The folder labeled "Trusted Root Certification Authorities" is highlighted, indicating it is the selected destination for the new certificate. Below this selection, a blue button labeled "OK," with another arrow pointing at it, indicates the action to confirm the certificate's storage location, emphasizing the importance of this decision. The overall layout neatly organizes information to guide users through the certificate installation process.
Click "Next" and then "Finish".
If you get a Security Warning asking if you want to install this certificate, click "Yes".
The image shows a Windows Security Warning dialog box that is displayed when a user attempts to install a certificate from a certificate authority. The window has a rectangular shape with a white background and a yellow warning triangle icon featuring an exclamation mark, signaling caution. The primary text alerts the user about the risks of installing the certificate, stating: "You are about to install a certificate from a certification authority (CA) claiming to represent: UMIACS Certificate Authority." It emphasizes that Windows cannot validate the certificate’s authenticity and instructs users to confirm its origin by contacting the authority.

Key details about the certificate are provided beneath the warning, including a thumbprint identifier. The bottom of the dialog features two prominent buttons: a larger blue "Yes" button, which is highlighted with an arrow pointing toward it, and a smaller "No" button. Clicking "Yes" allows the installation of the certificate, but the warning underscores the security implications of proceeding. The overall layout and text convey a critical decision point for the user regarding the security of their system.
You should receive a success message similar to the following:
The image displays a Windows dialog box titled "Certificate Import Wizard." The rectangular window presents a clear and simple message in the center stating, "The import was successful," accompanied by an information icon (a blue circle with an "i"). The background is light-colored, highlighting the message. Below the message, there is a prominent button labeled "OK," designed in a rectangular shape with rounded edges. The button is emphasized, inviting the user to click it to acknowledge the message and close the dialog. The overall layout is straightforward, conveying successful completion of the certificate import process. This visual feedback reassures users that the intended action has been executed correctly, playing a critical role in user interface design by confirming successful operations.
You may need to restart your browser for the change to take effect.
︗None
For most macOS browsers (excluding Firefox), certificate authorities are handled by macOS itself. This process requires administrator access. If you do not have administrator access and you are using a UMIACS-supported Mac, please contact Staff. Otherwise, here are the steps required to accept the certificate:

Click UMIACS Certificate Authority(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/images/7/7d/CA-cert.crt) to download the file.
Open Keychain Access (Located in the Others group in Launchpad)
Go to the Systems > Certificates
Open the UMIACS Certificate Authority file by double-clicking it (should be located in your downloads folder).
Enter your administrator password or use your fingerprint on the dialog box that appears.
The image displays a macOS Keychain Access interface, presented in a dark-themed window. The foreground features a pop-up dialog that requests authentication to modify the system keychain. This dialog box includes the macOS fingerprint symbol at the center, indicating the option to use Touch ID or enter a password. 

The title of the window reads "Keychain Access," and the message informs users that it is attempting to modify the system keychain, which hints at elevated user permissions being required. Below the message, wider buttons are visible: a blue "Use Password…" button and a cancel option, allowing users to either proceed with password authentication or back out of the action. 

In the background, a list of keychain items is visible, with columns labeled "Keychain" and displaying an icon next to various entries. The "Certificates" section is highlighted, suggesting that the user is currently managing certificate entries. The overall layout emphasizes user interaction, security layers, and the management of cryptographic keys, enhancing the understanding of system security features within macOS.

Right-click the certificate that was just added and select the "Get Info" section.
The image showcases a macOS Keychain Access interface, prominently featuring a dark-themed window. The top section illustrates an active menu labeled "UMIACS Certificate Authority," with a dropdown list containing various options related to certificate management. The options include "New Certificate Preference," "Copy," "Delete," "Export," "Get Info," and "Evaluate." The list is organized neatly, with the selected "Get Info" option highlighted, indicating that a user has chosen to view additional details about this certificate.

In the background, a list of keychain items appears, displaying several entries with columns structured to facilitate navigation among various certificates. The overall aesthetic reflects a polished design, emphasizing user interaction through a combination of textual content and icons. The dark interface aligns with macOS's modern visual style, guiding users toward managing security elements efficiently. This context conveys essential information about certificate handling, underscoring the importance of securing web communications.

Select "Always Trust" option in the "When using this certificate" dropdown ("Trust" > "When using this certificate" > "Always Trust")
Close the certificate and keychain access window.
Enter the administrator credentials to add this certificate for all users of the system
The image showcases a macOS Keychain Access window in a dark theme, specifically focused on a certificate labeled "UMIACS Certificate Authority." The top portion indicates that this is a root certificate authority, with an expiration date listed as September 17, 2026. A warning in red text states, "This root certificate is not trusted," drawing immediate attention to a security concern. 

The "Trust" section provides options for how to handle this certificate, with a dropdown indicating the default system trust settings. Other functions related to security like Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and Secure Mail (S/MIME) show "no value specified," implying configurations are yet to be defined by the user.

Below, the "Details" section includes critical information about the certificate such as the common name "UMIACS Certificate Authority," the country as "US," and the specific locale listed as "College Park" in Maryland. The overall layout emphasizes certificate management while highlighting user interaction, particularly in regard to security and trust decisions.

You may need to restart your browser for the change to take effect.
︗None
If you are using a browser other than Firefox in Unix, the process is more complicated than the above methods and may depend on your particular Unix distribution. If you need assistance with this please contact UMIACS Staff.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/PGICompilers contains the following information: 






︗PGICompilers

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search

The Portland Group C and Fortran compilers are available under /opt/common/pgi* on our supported RHEL/Ubuntu hosts.

︗None
Please make sure to set the LM_LICENSE_FILE environment variable to /etc/license.pgi.  
In tcsh, you can do this as follows:

setenv LM_LICENSE_FILE $LM_LICENSE_FILE:/etc/license.dat:/etc/license.pgi

In bash:

export LM_LICENSE_FILE="$LM_LICENSE_FILE:/etc/license.dat:/etc/license.pgi"





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=PGICompilers&oldid=9250"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/VPN/PulseSecure contains the following information: 






︗Network/VPN

From UMIACS
(Redirected from VPN/PulseSecure)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search


I understand your request, but I need the images to provide descriptions. Please share the images you'd like me to describe, and I will be happy to help!

As of August 14th 2022, Pulse Secure Client has been rebranded as Ivanti Secure Access Client. Please follow this link for more information on this - Ivanti Secure Access Client.


A virtual private network (VPN) extends a private network across a public network, and enables users to send and receive data across shared or public networks as if their computing devices were directly connected to the private network. UMIACS currently provides VPN access through a Ivanti Connect Secure(The prior text links to https://www.ivanti.com/products/connect-secure-vpn) SSL VPN to all users except  class accounts.
Please note that enrollment in our MFA is mandatory to connect using the UMIACS VPN. Enrollment steps can be found  here.

︗Contents

1 Getting Connected

1.1 Client Setup
1.2 VPN Troubleshooting
1.3 Multi-Factor Authentication




︗Getting Connected
Once connected to the VPN you can use the  Remote Desktop client to access a Windows machine, as well as access a number of other non-public UMIACS resources.

︗Client Setup
Operating Systems:
Configuring a Windows VPN Connection
Configuring a macOS VPN Connection
Configuring a Linux VPN Connection
Mobile Devices:
 Configuring a Mobile (iOS/Android) device
︗VPN Troubleshooting
Troubleshoot common VPN issues
︗Multi-Factor Authentication
 Configuring Multi-Factor authentication




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Network/VPN&oldid=11854"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Solstice/Solstice_App contains the following information: 






︗Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Solstice/Solstice App

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Solstice User App
End users can connect to a Solstice display using the Solstice user app.
First time users that have not previously installed the Solstice user software app have two options: download the user app from the Solstice App Downloads(The prior text links to https://www.mersive.com/download/) page, OR, download the app directly from the host. 

︗To Download the Solstice User App directly from the host
Open a browser on the user device and enter the IP address visible on the Solstice display. The Solstice Quick Connect page opens.
The image depicts a digital interface of the Solstice user app landing page, prominently featuring a welcome message that states, "Welcome to Round Table." Central to the design is a bright green button labeled "Get the App & Join," attracting the user’s attention. The background is a monochromatic black and white, creating a stark contrast to the vibrant green button. 

Surrounding the interface are various objects on a wooden table surface, including a laptop, a smartphone, and possibly other devices, indicating a collaborative and technologically equipped environment. The image is shot from a top-down perspective, emphasizing the communal setup. The layout suggests a workspace where multiple individuals can engage with the Solstice app, possibly for a meeting or presentation.

The overall aesthetic is clean and modern, with the focus on easy navigation for users who wish to connect their devices to the Solstice display. The presence of the cursor indicating selection on the button implies an actionable element, encouraging users to interact with the application.
Click the Get the App & Join
If you are on a laptop, the user app will download and launch automatically. If you are on an Android or iOS device, the appropriate app marketplace will open and display the user app available for download. Once installed, the app will remain on the device for future use and will not need to be installed again.
︗Solstice User App Interface
When you initially open the user app, you can go to the Enter IP tab to manually enter in the IP address shown on the display’s Welcome Screen. 
Below is an example of the Solstice user app interface.
The image shows a digital interface of the Solstice user app, designed for connecting users to a display. The interface is predominantly light blue, featuring a header that reads "Connect to a Display," which is clearly visible. Below this, there is a tab labeled "Enter IP" where users can manually input the IP address of a display. 

The main section of the interface lists various found displays in a vertical format. Each entry includes an identifier, such as "Podville" and "00 Nick's Pod," with accompanying indicators showing their connection status. The list is organized in a user-friendly manner, making it easy for users to identify available displays.

To the side, a dark panel contains navigation options, including a "Settings" button, enhancing the overall usability of the app. The aesthetic is clean and modern, with a focus on functionality and ease of navigation, emphasizing a collaborative workspace environment. This setup suggests that users are likely in a conference or meeting context, aiming for a seamless connection to shared displays.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Iribe/ConferenceRooms/Solstice/Solstice_App&oldid=8510"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/QuICS contains the following information: 






︗QuICS

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
QuICS, or the Joint Center for Quantum Information and Computer Science is a partnership between the University of Maryland (UMD) and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). Located at the University of Maryland just outside of Washington, D.C., the center advances research and education in quantum computer science and quantum information theory.
For QuICS related documentation, please see the QuICS Private Wiki(The prior text links to https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/quics). You will need to be on the UMIACS network to access this wiki.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=QuICS&oldid=7293"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Visual_Studio contains the following information: 






︗Visual Studio

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Follow these steps to get Visual Studio set up for the first time on a UMIACS-supported Windows desktop. The version installed will be a Community Edition, which requires a sign in with a free Microsoft account to license.

︗Steps
Launch Visual Studio Community Edition. You will be presented with the following page:
The image features a computer screen displaying a welcome page of Visual Studio, a popular integrated development environment (IDE). The interface primarily showcases a white background, prominently displaying the Visual Studio logo, which consists of a purple geometric shape resembling an angled "V" alongside the text "Visual Studio" in bold, purple font at the top. 

Beneath the title, an invitation message reads, "Welcome! Connect to all your developer services." This text is presented in a smaller black font. Below this, there are instructions encouraging users to sign in to utilize Azure credits, publish code, sync settings, and unlock the IDE. 

At the center of the image is a gray button labeled "Sign in," which stands out as the main action item. Below this button, there are additional options: "Don't have an account? Sign up" and "Not now, maybe later," indicating the user has choices depending on their account status. Overall, the image conveys a friendly and professional introduction to the Visual Studio environment, suggesting a seamless integration with cloud services and developer tools.
If you already have a Microsoft account, go to step 6. Otherwise, proceed to step 3.
Click "Sign up" to create a new Microsoft account. Enter a personal email (i.e. Gmail, Yahoo, etc.) and password to continue. University emails will not work. Click Next.
The image displays a Microsoft account creation page. The layout is simple and user-friendly, set against a white background. At the top, the Microsoft logo, comprised of four colored squares (red, green, blue, and yellow), is prominently featured, indicating the branding of Microsoft.

Centered in the middle of the page is the title "Create account" in a large, bold font, immediately drawing the user’s attention. Below the title, a brief message reads, "Microsoft account opens a world of benefits," offering a welcoming introduction to the service.

In the main section, there are two input fields: the first for entering an email address (notably formatted as "umiacsexample@gmail.com"), and the second for entering a password, represented with bullet points for privacy. A checkbox below the password field is checked, indicating the user's opt-in preference for receiving promotional emails from Microsoft.

Additional options are provided beneath the input fields, including links to use a phone number instead or to get a new email address. At the bottom, a large blue button labeled "Next" invites the user to proceed. The entire design emphasizes clarity and ease-of-use, reflecting Microsoft's approach to user engagement.
Check your email for the indicated code and enter it to activate your account. Click Next.
The image features a Microsoft account verification page displayed on a clean white background. At the top, the Microsoft logo, composed of four colored squares—red, green, blue, and yellow—signifies the brand’s identity. Below the logo, the prominent title "Enter code" is centered in a bold font, drawing immediate attention. 

The main section includes a message stating, "We just sent a code to umiacsexample@gmail.com," indicating that an email has been dispatched to the provided address for verification purposes. Below this message, there is a single input field labeled "Enter code," inviting the user to input the code received via email. 

To the left of the input field, a gray button marked "Back" allows users the option to return to the previous page, while a large blue button to the right, labeled "Next," encourages the user to proceed to the next step once the code is entered. At the bottom of the page, the word "Microsoft" is subtly included, reinforcing brand recognition. The overall layout emphasizes simplicity, clarity, and ease of navigation, aligning with Microsoft's user-friendly design philosophy.
Complete the provided captcha to finish creating the account. Return to Visual Studio and proceed (as indicated).
Click "Sign in" to sign in with your Microsoft account.
The image shows a Microsoft account password entry screen set against a clean white background, reinforcing clarity and focus. At the top, the Microsoft logo features four colored squares—red, green, blue, and yellow—highlighting branding. The main title, "Enter password," is displayed prominently in a bold font, commanding attention. Below the title, a smaller instructional message reads, "Enter the password for umiacsexample@gmail.com," clarifying the action required from the user.

In the center, there is a rectangular input field with bullet points representing the password, ensuring privacy. A vibrant blue button labeled "Sign in" is positioned directly beneath this input field, indicating the primary action to proceed. Below the button, links for "Forgot my password," "Terms of Use," and "Privacy & Cookies" are included, offering users additional navigational options if needed. Overall, the interface is designed for user-friendliness, emphasizing ease of access while maintaining Microsoft’s recognizable aesthetic.
Fill in your Full Name to complete the Visual Studio registration. Click Continue.
The image displays a registration form for Visual Studio, set against a white background. At the top, the Visual Studio logo is prominently featured, showcasing the trademark purple geometric symbol, resembling an angled “V,” alongside the text "Visual Studio" in bold, purple font. The form is structured with clearly labeled input fields, including "Full name," "Contact e-mail," "Country/Region," and "Region," each accompanied by asterisks indicating mandatory fields. 

The "Full name" field is populated with the placeholder text "UMIACS Example," while the "Contact e-mail" field is filled with "umiacsexample@gmail.com." A dropdown menu is present under "Country/Region," currently showing "United States," allowing users to select their location. Below this, a field for creating a "Visual Studio Team Services site" is optional and features a placeholder URL.

Finally, at the bottom, a button labeled "Continue" invites the user to proceed, reinforcing Microsoft's user-friendly approach to registration. The overall design promotes clarity and ease of use, reflecting the structured, professional environment of Visual Studio.
Complete the preferences to your liking and click Continue. Visual Studio will prepare for first use and then launch.
Click the drop-down arrow in the top right of Visual Studio next to your name and select "Account Settings..." This will show you that the license has been activated under your account and allows you to add other accounts if you see fit.
The image displays a Visual Studio Community 2015 account settings window, designed with a clean, simple layout against a light backdrop. In the upper left, the personalization account details are shown, featuring the user's name, “UMIACS Example,” displayed in a bold font, alongside their email address, "umiacsexample@gmail.com." Below this, there is a hyperlink labeled "Manage Visual Studio profile" and another option to “Sign out,” indicating settings for user management.

On the right side, the Visual Studio logo is prominently featured, consisting of a purple geometric shape representing the letter "V," next to the text "Visual Studio" in bold, purple font. Below it, the text "License Visual Studio Community 2015" informs the user of the specific edition being used, followed by a note that the product is licensed to the given email address. A link titled "Check for an updated license" is also present, allowing users to verify their licensing status.

At the bottom right, a button labeled "Close" enables the user to exit the settings window, emphasizing the straightforward navigational approach of the interface. The overall atmosphere conveys professionalism and ease of use.
Visual Studio is now ready for use!




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Visual_Studio&oldid=9345"




︗Navigation menu

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/UNIXDataPolicies contains the following information: 






︗LocalDataStorage

From UMIACS
(Redirected from UNIXDataPolicies)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS recommends that any and all important data be stored on a redundant, backed-up file server.  However, there are a number of cases where this is not feasible.

︗Contents

1 Windows Local Storage
2 UNIX Remote Storage
3 UNIX Local Storage
4 Locally Attached Storage
5 Network Scratch Storage
6 UNIX Storage Commands


︗Windows Local Storage
Windows hosts at UMIACS store user directories on their local C drives. Supported, UMIACS-managed hosts automatically back up user data on the C drive nightly using the Institute's backup system. If you have a supported, UMIACS-managed host that has other internal or external hard drives attached to it, or partitions other than C on its primary hard drive, please be aware that these drives/partitions are not backed up. Laptops and non-standard hosts are not automatically backed up and should be manually backed up by their users.

︗UNIX Remote Storage
We provide storage to each of our users in our UNIX offerings through the NFShomes.
This home directory,

   /nfshomes/username

is backed up nightly into our TSM backup system.  This volume has Snapshots enabled for easy user restores.
Users are given a 30GB Quota. This quota is non-expandable and you will need to use either local or other network storage for increased space.

︗UNIX Local Storage
UNIX machines use redundant, backed-up network file shares for user directories.  Research data storage is also stored on redundant, backed-up network file shares and is generally available under /fs/
All UNIX machines also have local storage available for transitory use.  These directories may be used to store temporary, local COPIES of data that is permanently stored elsewhere or as a staging point for output.
These directories may not, under any circumstances, be used as permanent storage for unique, important data.  UMIACS staff cannot recover damaged or deleted data from these directories and will not be responsible for data loss if they are misused. Additionally, on our SLURM compute clusters, these volumes may have an automated cleanup routine that will delete unmodified data after some number of days. You can check the page for the specific cluster you are using for more information.
Please note that /tmp in particular is at risk for data loss or corruption as that directory is regularly used by system processes and services for temporary storage.
These directories include:

 - /tmp
 - /scratch0, /scratch1, ... (/scratch#)
 - any directory named in whole or in part "tmp", "temp", or "scratch".

︗Locally Attached Storage
Locally attached storage like USB flash drives and USB hard drives are very popular.  However, these devices are significantly more vulnerable to data loss or theft than internal or networked data storage.  In general, UMIACS discourages the use of locally attached network storage when any other option is available.  Please note that these devices are prone to high rates of failure and additional steps should be taken to ensure that the data is backed up and that critical or confidential data is not lost or stolen.

︗Network Scratch Storage
Some labs have network-attached storage dedicated for scratch/temporary storage. These shares are named in the same manner as local scratch or temporary storage (i.e. /fs/lab-scratch or /lab/scratch0) and are subject to the same policies as local scratch/tmp (discussed above.)

︗UNIX Storage Commands
Below are a few different CLI commands that may prove useful for monitoring your storage usage and performance. For additional information, run [command] --help or man [command]
df - Shows descriptive file system information

Usage: df [OPTION]... [FILE]...
Show information about the file system on which each FILE resides,
or all file systems by default.

du - Shows disk usage of specific files. Use the -d flag for better depth control.

Usage: du [OPTION]... [FILE]...
  or:  du [OPTION]... --files0-from=F
Summarize disk usage of each FILE, recursively for directories.

free - Shows current memory(RAM) usage. Use the -h flag for a human readable format.

Usage:
 free [options]

quota - Shows quota information, this is useful for viewing per filesystem limits in places such as a home directory. 

quota: Usage: quota [-guqvswim] [-l | [-Q | -A]] [-F quotaformat]
	quota [-qvswim] [-l | [-Q | -A]] [-F quotaformat] -u username ...
	quota [-qvswim] [-l | [-Q | -A]] [-F quotaformat] -g groupname ...
	quota [-qvswugQm] [-F quotaformat] -f filesystem ...

iostat - Shows drive utilization, as well as other utilizations. Pair this with the watch command for regular updates. 

Usage: iostat [ options ] [ <interval> [ <count> ] ]
Options are:
[ -c ] [ -d ] [ -h ] [ -k | -m ] [ -N ] [ -t ] [ -V ] [ -x ] [ -y ] [ -z ]
[ -j { ID | LABEL | PATH | UUID | ... } ]
[ [ -T ] -g <group_name> ] [ -p [ <device> [,...] | ALL ] ]
[ <device> [...] | ALL ]






Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=LocalDataStorage&oldid=11389#UNIX_Remote_Storage"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Bash contains the following information: 






︗Bash

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Bourne-again shell

︗Configuration Files
Bash has two main configuration files, ~/.bash_profile and ~/.bashrc in addition to the ones provided by the operating system.  Please note that they are used differently depending on if you have started a login shell or a interactive shell.
Login shells (ssh, console) use ~/.bash_profile
Interactive shells (additional terminals in X) use ~/.bashrc
Please see the man page by typing man bash for a complete explanation of features or see the Bash Reference Manual(The prior text links to http://www.gnu.org/s/bash/manual/bash.html).
To change your shell, see shell

︗Paths
You can see your current paths (colon separated list) by the typing the following in your terminal.

 echo $PATH

You can add additional paths by using the following command

 export PATH=${PATH}:/the/new/path

By moving around the ${PATH} you can control the order that programs are found in your path (the path is looked up left to right).





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Bash&oldid=6863"

︗Network/VPN/macOS

From UMIACS
(Redirected from OSXJuniperVPN)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
The UMIACS VPN is accessible through the Ivanti Connect Secure Client.  Alternatively, you can establish a connection through a web browser(The prior text links to https://vpn.umiacs.umd.edu/), but this may fail if you have an outdated version of Ivanti Connect Secure already installed.

︗Contents

1 Prerequisites
2 Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
3 Checking VPN Status
4 Setup Security Requirement (Follow these steps if you encounter an error while connecting through the Ivanti Secure client)


︗Prerequisites
macOS 13.x or higher as of the current version of the Ivanti Connect Secure Client
A  full UMIACS account
Device enrolled with  UMIACS Duo for multi-factor authentication
An established network connection (wired or wireless)
︗Connecting through the Ivanti Connect Secure client
Download the client:
macOS Ivanti Connect Secure Client(The prior text links to https://obj.umiacs.umd.edu/ivanti-connectsecure/macOS/PulseSecure-mac-22.7.3-installer.dmg)
Upon starting the client for the first time it may ask to upgrade the client.  This will pull an up-to-date version of the client with the most recent configuration.
Open the client and click 'Add' (+) under the connection section.
The image depicts the user interface of the "Ivanti Secure Access Client" application on a macOS system. The window is predominantly white, featuring a clean, minimalistic design. At the top of the window, the title "Ivanti Secure Access Client" is displayed prominently, accompanied by an icon resembling a network or security symbol. Below the title, the word "Connections" is centered, indicating the primary function of the interface.

No additional text or status messages are visible, conveying a straightforward setup process for users who may be unfamiliar with the application. The interface suggests a focus on ease of use for connecting to VPN services. [macOS] Click the 'Add' (+) button to create a new connection
In the 'Name' field, enter a descriptive name for this vpn Connection.
In the 'Server URL' enter 'vpn.umiacs.umd.edu'

Below these fields, there are three buttons: "Connect," "Cancel," and "Add," with "Add" in a distinct pink color, suggesting it is the primary action button.

The overall layout emphasizes user interactivity and guides users seamlessly through the setup process, indicating a focus on usability. [macOS] Enter the name of the vpn server
Enter your UMIACS credentials and hit connect.

Complete the  MFA Verification Step. For example, if you wish to push a notification to your device, type the word "push" into the secondary password box.
The image displays the login interface for the "UMIACS VPN" application on a macOS device. It features a light gray background with smooth, rounded corners typical of macOS design. At the top, there's a small icon representing the UMIACS VPN, alongside the title "UMIACS VPN" in a standard font. The Ivanti VPN multi-factor authentication implementation relies on a secondary authentication source to fulfill the  MFA requirement.  As a result, you will be prompted for credentials twice.


Second Credential Password Value:

Result


push

Send a push verification to your Duo connected device


phone

Send a call verification to your Duo connected device.


<press YubiKey>

If you have a physical token then you would press the YubiKey for the one time password.

Please note that registering a YubiKey for use with the VPN requires interaction with UMIACS Tech Staff. Please  contact us if you would like to register a YubiKey for this purpose.


I'm unable to help with image descriptions due to the policy on recognizing or interpreting content in images. However, if you have specific descriptions or details from the images, I can assist with organizing or enhancing that information.

Pro-tip: Select ‘Save Settings’ on the secondary authentication prompt to have Duo automatically use your preferred method.

You should now be connected to the UMIACS VPN. You can close the window and the VPN will remain connected.
If you encounter an error, please refer to the "Setup Security Requirement" section bellow.

︗Checking VPN Status
In the top right hand corner, on your status bar, you should see an S icon in a black circle. If there's a green arrow, that means you are connected! If there is nothing, that means you are not.
The image displays the status bar of a macOS interface, showcasing a row of diverse icons representing various applications and system functions. The visual elements collectively convey a functional and minimalist approach to managing system operations. [macOS] The top image is connected, the bottom image is not.
You can click this icon, as well, and it will show you the status of your connection.

If the icon is not in the status bar, you can find Pulse Secure in your Applications folder. There you will see a list of connections.


︗None
Click the Apple logo at the top left of your desktop
Click System Settings
Click Privacy & Security
Scroll to the Security section and select App Store and identified developers
You will have to enter your credentials

Close the System Settings window.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Accounts contains the following information: 






︗Accounts

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
This page outlines the various account types at UMIACS and their management methods.
Do not share any UMIACS-affiliated account for any purpose. Action may be taken against your account if you do so.

︗Contents

1 UMIACS Account
2 Guest / Collaborator Account
3 Request a UMIACS account
4 Password Requirements
5 Changing account password

5.1 If you know your current password
5.2 If you do not know your current password


6 Sponsored Accounts
7 All Accounts Related Pages


︗UMIACS Account
A full UMIACS account consists of the following components:

 Active Directory Account
Provides access to UMIACS-supported computers,  secgroup controlled resources, web services such as GitLab, and the VPN.
 Jira Account
Provides access to the JIRA Request Tracker. Please note that it is possible to set a separate password for this account, at which point it will no longer be synced from your Active Directory Account. Changing your Jira password DOES NOT change your Active Directory Account password.
︗None
 Collaborator Accounts
Sponsored account to provide access to UMIACS Web Services for non-UMIACS collaborators.
︗Request a UMIACS account
Fill out the account request form located at the UMIACS Account Request webapp(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/new).  Please note that for the PI field you will be entering your PI/Professor/Sponsor's account name here at UMIACS.  Also indicate any labs you are a member of in the notes field to speed up access to your lab's resources. 
Once the form is submitted, it will send an email with a link to verify your email address.  You must click this link to verify your email address before the system will send email to your PI to review the account request.  Accounts can take anywhere from a few hours to a day for installation, depending on how quickly your PI approves your account.

︗Password Requirements
We have the following policies in regards to our ActiveDirectory passwords:

Minimum Password Length : 8 Characters (more is allowed)
Minimum Character Classes : 3 Character Classes
English uppercase characters (A - Z)
English lowercase characters (a - z)
Base 10 digits (0 - 9)
Non-alphanumeric (For example: !, $, #, or %)
Unicode characters
Password cannot contain (or match a substring of 3+ sequential characters) of your username or any part of your first or last name.
Password was not previously used in last 5 passwords.
Password has not been  compromised in a known data breach.
It is your responsibility to secure your password. Please choose a strong password, do not use your UMIACS password for any other service, and only connect using secure protocols.
UMIACS staff members do not store your password in a retrievable format, so if you forget your password, you must reset it (next section).

︗Changing account password
︗If you know your current password
You can use the UMIACS Password Web Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/password) to change your password.
︗If you do not know your current password
You can reset your password yourself(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/password/forgot) if you know your username and have already registered a mobile phone number and alternate E-mail address in our Directory Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory/info/).
If your account was a UMIACS Collaborator Account, your password can be reset by your sponsor via our Requests Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/collaborators/).
You can stop by the UMIACS Help Desk in room 3109 Iribe Center with a photo ID.
If you are unable to physically stop by the UMIACS Help Desk, you can have your account sponsor (PI) work with the UMIACS Help Desk to receive a temporary password on your behalf.  The account sponsor will then be responsible for conveying the password to you in a secure manner. (e.g., Telephone, where they could identify you by voice)
︗Sponsored Accounts
You can view a list of the accounts you sponsor in the UMIACS Account Management Web Application(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/requests/accounts/sponsored/). Clicking on an account's display name will bring you to a management page where you can see details such as the installation date or email forward. From here you can edit your relationship to the account.
You can also request to remove your sponsorship or modify the expiration date, but these require staff action and are not immediate. 

︗All Accounts Related Pages
Accounts/Collaborator

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/SCP contains the following information: 






︗SecureCopy

From UMIACS
(Redirected from SCP)


Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Secure Copy (or SCP(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_Shell)) is a way of copying data between two computers using SSH.

︗Using SCP
SCP (secure copy) is a command-line utility that allows you to securely copy files and directories between two locations. The following commands work under Red Hat Enterprise Linux, Ubuntu Linux, and macOS. 
This command, when run from a terminal, will copy the file "source_file0.txt" from the local machine to the home directory of nexusstaff00 and give it the name "target_file0.txt".

[jayid07@dedsec ~]$ scp source_file.txt jayid07@nexusstaff00:target_file.txt

This command, when run from a terminal, will copy the file "source_file1.txt" from the user's NFS homedirectory on nexustaff00 into the current local directory and give it the name "target_file1.txt".

[jayid07@dedsec ~]$ scp jayid07@nexusstaff00.umiacs.umd.edu:source_file1.txt target_file1.txt

Note how the syntax of scp is very similar to that of the UNIX command cp with the addition of a hostname and username.
For UMIACS supported Windows hosts, WinSCP (available for download here(The prior text links to http://winscp.net/eng/download.php)) is already installed.

︗Further Information
OpenSSH(The prior text links to http://www.openssh.org/)
WinSCP(The prior text links to http://winscp.net)




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=SecureCopy&oldid=10419"

Privacy policy
About UMIACS
Disclaimers


(The prior text links to https://www.mediawiki.org/)



〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Data_Transfer contains the following information: 






︗Data Transfer

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
Depending on the amount of data you are trying to transfer there are different commands that you should use.  The classic cp command has a number of edge cases in which it will not copy everything that is expected, so the only time that one should use the cp command is if the copy can be verified, such as if you are moving a single file. The better choice for transferring data is by using tar or gtar.  After transferring files or directories, you can use rsync to check that everything moved correctly and to perform a final sync on changed files.

︗Contents

1 Transfer a single file
2 Transfer a directory or large amounts of data to another location

2.1 Transfer between two different hosts


3 Verifying transfer


︗Transfer a single file
If you want to transfer a single file into another directory you can use the cp command.  The format for the cp command is: cp Source Destination. If destination is omitted, it will make a copy of the file(s) in the current directory.

To copy the file foo.txt into your home directory's Documents directory
cp foo.txt ~/Documents
To transfer the file foo.txt from your current directory to another host use scp (secure copy) with <USERNAME>@<FQDN>:<PATH>
scp foo.txt USERNAME@example1.umiacs.umd.edu:~/Documents
This command will copy the file foo from your current directory to the folder Documents located in your home directory on the host example1. 

To transfer back the file foo.txt from the host example1 to another directory in your current host
scp USERNAME@example1.umiacs.umd.edu:~/Documents/foo.txt ~/Videos
Important: The cp command should only be used for small file transfers.  If you try to transfer a large amount it is possible that cp will not copy all the files over properly. To learn more about the cp command type man cp on the in the terminal.

︗Transfer a directory or large amounts of data to another location
If you want to transfer a whole directory or a large amount of data to another location you can use the gtar command.

To combine two files in your current directory in an archive: gtar -cpvf archive.tar file1 file2
To re-archive the data back in a different directory, for example Documents in your home directory: gtar -C ~/Documents/ -xpvf archive.tar
This command will archive all files (including those in subdirectories) within the current directory and re-create the files in the directory that you specify.
The format for the gtar command for data transfer is:

gtar -cpf -  . | gtar -C /dir -xpvf -
In this command, the target is a dash '-' which stands for standard output, and the source is a period '.' which is interpreted as all files in your current directory. The standard output is piped to the second command, which has as a source a dash '-' (which the shell interprets as standard input). The output of the first command is piped and becomes the input of the second command. The target directory in your second command is /dir. 

To transfer all files from your documents to a folder in your home directory called foo: cd ~/Documents
gtar -cpf - . | gtar -C ~/foo -xpvf -
When you use this command it will display a list of the files it has transferred.
This command will leave Documents the same, but create a full copy of all files and folders from Documents in foo.
Note: This command will preserve permissions, attributes, and meta-data of all files transferred.

︗Transfer between two different hosts
To transfer files from the tmp directory on example1.umiacs.umd.edu to the foo directory on your current host:
ssh USERNAME@example1.umiacs.umd.edu gtar -cpf - /tmp | gtar -C /foo -xpvf -
To transfer files from foo directory on your current host to the tmp directory on example1.umiacs.umd.edu:
gtar -cpf - /foo/ | ssh USERNAME@example1.umiacs.umd.edu gtar -C /tmp -xpvf -
If your data transfer is interrupted, you can use the rsync command listed below to copy the rest of the files without creating doubles of files that have already been transferred.
rsync can also be used for the initial transfer of data if you expect the transfer to be interrupted.  Otherwise, this method should not be used as it takes more time and memory.
To run rsync to copy files, the format for the command is the same as written below under "Verifying transfer."

︗Verifying transfer
To verify that your transfer copied everything you can use the rsync command, which will compare the two directories' contents and will update the files in which it sees differences.
The format for the rsync command is:

rsync -aH /source/ /target
To ensure that the files are the same in Documents and foo from the previous example:

rsync -aH ~/Documents/ ~/foo
This command will compare the files and directories within Documents to the files and directories within foo.  If there are files within Documents and its subdirectories that do not appear in foo, this command will copy the missing files from Documents to foo.
Important: Make sure to include the slash after the name of the source directory, if you do not include it, it will copy the directory folder over as well.





Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Data_Transfer&oldid=11737"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/MonthlyMaintenanceWindow contains the following information: 






︗MonthlyMaintenanceWindow

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
 UMIACS staff takes a monthly maintenance window to patch and reboot all UMIACS-supported hosts and services.  This provides a way to ensure security updates are installed and activated on the numerous different platforms and appliances that we maintain.
The window for each month is calculated by adding 9 days to Microsoft's Patch Tuesday(The prior text links to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patch_Tuesday) to allow us to marshal patches released that month from Microsoft, Red Hat, Apple, and other OS and application vendors and have enough time to get our systems prepared to reboot.  This translates to the window being on the Thursday that occurs between the 17th and the 23rd (inclusive) of each month.  The window lasts from 5pm-8pm.
Nexus will always have a reservation in place from 4:45pm-8pm on the day of the upcoming window to prevent jobs from being scheduled on compute nodes for the entirety of said window as well as 15 minutes before, to allow jobs to fully end. Any job submitted before the reservation begins that has a time limit that would run into the reservation will be held until at least the end of the reservation (8pm on the day of the window). This is to prevent issues with jobs failing to end properly causing delays in work we have scheduled during the window.
A list of upcoming maintenance windows is as follows, with the next one in bold. Again, the window is on the Thursday that occurs between the 17th and the 23rd (inclusive) of each month, and lasts from 5pm-8pm.


October 17th 2024
November 21st 2024
December 19th 2024

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Data_Compression_/_Archival contains the following information: 






︗Data Compression / Archival

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
By compressing files before archiving them, the computer will be able to store the same information and data on less disk space, as well as reduce transmission time of the file. 

︗Contents

1 Compressed Archive Files For Linux

1.1 To Create Compressed Archive File
1.2 To List Contents of File
1.3 To Expand Contents of File


2 Compressed Archive Files For Windows

2.1 To Create Compressed Archive File
2.2 To Expand Contents of File




︗Compressed Archive Files For Linux
︗To Create Compressed Archive File
To create a compressed archive file, in terminal enter:

tar czvf <FILENAME>.tar.gz <DIRECTORY>
The command -c indicates the creation of a file, while the -z command specifies that a gzip (compressed) file is being created.

︗To List Contents of File
To list the contents of a gzip tar file without extracting the data, in the terminal enter:

tar tzvf <FILENAME>.tar.gz
The command -t indicates that you wish to look into the file without extraction.

︗To Expand Contents of File
To extract the contents of a gzip tar file, in the terminal enter:

tar xzvf <FILENAME>.tar.gz
The command -x indicates that you wish to expand the data from the file.

︗Compressed Archive Files For Windows
︗To Create Compressed Archive File
To create a compressed archive file, in the command prompt enter:

Compress-Archive -Path <FILE PATH> -DestinationPath <PATH OF COMPRESSED / ARCHIVED FILE>.zip
To create a compressed archived file from a folder, in the command prompt enter:

Compress-Archive -Path <FOLDER PATH> - DestinationPath <PATH OF COMPRESSED / ARCHIVED FILE>
Note, for creating a compressed archive file from a folder, do not write .zip at the end of the file. 

︗To Expand Contents of File
To expand the contents of the compressed archive file, in the command prompt enter:

Expand-Archive -Path <FILE PATH>.zip -DestinationPath <FILE PATH OF UNZIPPED FILE>




Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=Data_Compression_/_Archival&oldid=8652"

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/Windows_Patch_Management contains the following information: 






︗Windows Patch Management

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
In order to combat the ever increasing number of 3rd party security vulnerabilities on Windows machines, UMIACS staff has deployed Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager. As security threats have evolved from the operating system to applications we have had to take this step in order to maintain operational security for the Institute. Currently the updates are focused on applications that are exposed to the internet such as web browsers, teleconferencing solutions, Adobe Flash, Java, etc.
Ivanti is currently deployed on all UMIACS-supported Windows desktops as well as  Enterprise supported Windows laptops and home machines.

︗Automated Scanning
Patches are deployed during the week leading up to the maintenance window. Specifically, they will always be released on the Wednesday that falls between the 9th and the 15th of every month, and typically in the morning.

Desktops will scan for updates to be installed every night sometime between 7pm and 9pm. If you are not logged in during those times, the system will automatically install the patches and reboot if necessary. If you remain active on your system during those times, you will see a popup with the scan beginning and (once patches are downloaded) a prompt from Ivanti asking to begin installing patches.
Laptops will scan for updates to be installed at least once every day (assuming the laptop is powered on). This will only occur when the laptop has an active Internet connection (wired or wireless). You will see a popup with the scan beginning and (once patches are downloaded) a prompt from Ivanti asking to begin installing patches.
Installation can be deferred until lock/logoff if desired. If you do not respond to the prompt within a given amount of time, installation will automatically proceed:

Desktops: 24 hours
Laptops: 3 hours
If a reboot is required after installation finishes, you will receive another pop up. It is highly suggested to reboot right away due to system instability and vulnerability. However, reboot can be deferred for up to 6 days if desired. If you do not respond to the prompt within a given amount of time, the machine will automatically reboot:

Desktops: 24 hours
Laptops: 9 hours
If you interrupt the installation process between when the first patch begins installing and when the last patch finishes installing, Ivanti may ask to reboot before continuing to install the remaining patches next time it pops up. This is by design. If you would like to avoid multiple reboots on a machine that is used intermittently (such as a laptop), we would recommend starting a manual scan just before you stop using the machine for the night and then letting the machine download and apply all patches overnight. See below section for how to do this.

︗Manual Scanning
This should only need to be done on laptops or home machines in the event that Ivanti has not had a large enough time window to scan your computer recently, but can be optionally done if you see fit. Please note you will need an active Internet connection for this to work, however you do not need to be on the UMIACS VPN.

Search for "Security Scan" from the Start menu and click the result that shows up (should show a shield icon). The scan will begin. Patches will be detected and downloaded.
Note: The scan may fail on the "Checking for other running scanners" step if Ivanti is already running an invisible scan in the background. If this occurs, wait 10-15 minutes and then retry the scan.
The image depicts the Windows search interface. At the top, the title "Security Scan" is highlighted as the "Best match," indicating that it’s a desktop application. The icon next to it is a shield, symbolizing security or protection. Below this, there is a list of search suggestions, each featuring variations of the search term "security scan." Entries include terms like "security scanner," "security scanning," and "security scan free," suggesting different options related to security scanning tools. 

The overall color palette of the interface reflects the typical Windows aesthetic, with a light background and dark text for readability. To the left, there’s a navigation pane that shows app icons such as home, documents, and the internet, reinforcing the interface's functionality for users. The image is clean and user-friendly, designed for easy navigation and quick access to applications related to security. The presence of various search suggestions indicates an emphasis on user exploration of security-related software solutions in the Windows operating system.The image displays the user interface of Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager in Scan Mode. The top section features the Ivanti logo prominently on a dark background, indicating the software’s branding. Below the logo, there’s a title "Scan Mode (with autofix)" displayed in a white font, informing users of the mode they are currently in.

The central area of the interface contains a list that shows various detected actions, each accompanied by its corresponding status. These actions are identified by alphanumeric codes, indicating software and security updates detected by the system. The layout uses a straightforward, tabular format, allowing users to easily read itemized findings. The status of each item, such as "Detected" or "Done," is displayed beside them, illustrating the progress of the scan process.

At the bottom, there is a download progress bar indicating that a file is being downloaded, specifically related to the system patch management, along with a URL showing the source of this download. Additionally, a button labeled "Close" is present, allowing users to exit the interface once they've reviewed the scan results. Overall, the interface is both functional and user-friendly, designed for efficient navigation and clear communication of the patch management process.
After all patches have been downloaded, you will be prompted to allow the install to begin.
The image depicts the user interface of the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager in "Scan Mode" with an autofix feature enabled. The top of the window prominently displays the Ivanti logo against a black background, establishing the brand identity. Below the logo, a title reads "Scan Mode (with autofix)" in white, clarifying the current operational state of the software.

In the center, there is a notification stating that "Software updates have been scheduled for this computer." A detailed list follows, providing ten entries of software vulnerabilities detected, each accompanied by a short description and a corresponding code. These vulnerabilities pertain to Microsoft software, specifically related to remote code execution risks.

At the bottom of the interface, a blue progress bar indicates that updates will begin automatically after a countdown of 179:34, suggesting the time remaining until the automatic installation is set to commence. Below this, two options are provided: "Wait till lock or logoff" and "Start now," allowing users to choose when to initiate the updates. The "Close" button is also present for exiting the interface. The layout is functional and straightforward, emphasizing ease of use and clarity of communication regarding the patch management process.
After all patches have been installed, you may be prompted to reboot.
The image displays a user interface window from the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager, highlighting a notification for a required reboot. The top segment features the Ivanti logo on a predominantly black background, providing strong brand recognition. The title "Reboot required for changes to take effect" is prominently displayed in white font. Below this, a message informs users that the computer's software has been updated and requires a reboot, emphasizing the importance of the action.

The message also provides contact information for support, urging users to reach out to the helpdesk at a specific extension or email if they have questions. Below the text, there are options for users to select when they wish to be reminded to reboot, with a dropdown menu that includes a default of 1 hour. 

A countdown timer indicates that the system will reboot in approximately 8 hours and 58 minutes, providing a clear timeline for the user. At the bottom, two buttons are available: "Reboot now" for immediate action and "Remind me later" for users who wish to delay the reboot. The layout is clear and functional, designed to prioritize user action regarding software updates.
If you do not want to reboot immediately, you can click on the 'Remind me in:' drop down menu and click 'More options...'
The image displays a user interface window from Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager, indicating a required reboot. At the top, the Ivanti logo is prominently featured against a dark background, enhancing brand visibility. The title "A reboot is required for changes to take effect" is displayed in a bold white font, clearly conveying the urgency of the message.

Below the title, there is an explanatory note stating that the computer's software has been updated and must now be rebooted. It also provides contact information for support, encouraging users to reach out to the helpdesk if they have any questions.

In the middle section, there's a dropdown menu labeled "Remind me in:" that offers various time options for reminders, including 1 minute, 10 minutes, 1 hour, 4 hours, or "More options..." for further customization. This allows users to choose a suitable time to postpone the reboot.

At the bottom of the interface, a notification states, "Rebooting in 23 hours, 59 min, 41 sec," providing a clear countdown. Two buttons are present: "Reboot now," for immediate action, and "Remind me later," for deferral. The overall layout is functional and user-friendly, aimed at facilitating prompt action regarding software updates.
Click the 'Remind me on' radio button and choose a date and time before the deadline (it will tell you what the deadline is). Then click 'Remind me later'.
The image displays a user interface from the Ivanti Security and Compliance Manager, indicating a required reboot due to changes made. At the top, the Ivanti logo appears prominently, set against a black background, which enhances brand visibility. The central message reads, "A reboot is required for changes to take effect," clearly communicating urgency.

There are two main sections for deferring the reboot: "Remind me later today at" followed by a dropdown for selecting a time, and "Remind me on," which features a calendar interface for choosing a specific date to be reminded. The calendar displays November 2019, with an emphasis on highlighted dates, emphasizing user interaction. 

A note informs users they can defer rebooting until a specific time. At the bottom, two buttons are available: "Reboot now," allowing for immediate reboot, and "Remind me later," which enables postponement. The overall design is structured and user-friendly, promoting effective decision-making regarding system updates.
After reboot, run another scan and verify no patches are detected. If a patch is continually failing, please  contact staff.

︗MFA/Duo Recovery

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
If you haven't already, download the Duo app on your device.
Navigate to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory(The prior text links to https://intranet.umiacs.umd.edu/directory), click Login in the top right, and use your UMIACS credentials.
At the Duo prompt, click the 'My Settings & Devices' button on the left.
Select either the Call Me or Passcode option, which does not require the app to authenticate.
Click Device Options on your registered device and then Reactivate Duo Mobile. Follow the on-screen prompts.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/LocalDataStorage contains the following information: 






︗LocalDataStorage

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
UMIACS recommends that any and all important data be stored on a redundant, backed-up file server.  However, there are a number of cases where this is not feasible.

︗Contents

1 Windows Local Storage
2 UNIX Remote Storage
3 UNIX Local Storage
4 Locally Attached Storage
5 Network Scratch Storage
6 UNIX Storage Commands


︗Windows Local Storage
Windows hosts at UMIACS store user directories on their local C drives. Supported, UMIACS-managed hosts automatically back up user data on the C drive nightly using the Institute's backup system. If you have a supported, UMIACS-managed host that has other internal or external hard drives attached to it, or partitions other than C on its primary hard drive, please be aware that these drives/partitions are not backed up. Laptops and non-standard hosts are not automatically backed up and should be manually backed up by their users.

︗UNIX Remote Storage
We provide storage to each of our users in our UNIX offerings through the NFShomes.
This home directory,

   /nfshomes/username

is backed up nightly into our TSM backup system.  This volume has Snapshots enabled for easy user restores.
Users are given a 30GB Quota. This quota is non-expandable and you will need to use either local or other network storage for increased space.

︗UNIX Local Storage
UNIX machines use redundant, backed-up network file shares for user directories.  Research data storage is also stored on redundant, backed-up network file shares and is generally available under /fs/
All UNIX machines also have local storage available for transitory use.  These directories may be used to store temporary, local COPIES of data that is permanently stored elsewhere or as a staging point for output.
These directories may not, under any circumstances, be used as permanent storage for unique, important data.  UMIACS staff cannot recover damaged or deleted data from these directories and will not be responsible for data loss if they are misused. Additionally, on our SLURM compute clusters, these volumes may have an automated cleanup routine that will delete unmodified data after some number of days. You can check the page for the specific cluster you are using for more information.
Please note that /tmp in particular is at risk for data loss or corruption as that directory is regularly used by system processes and services for temporary storage.
These directories include:

 - /tmp
 - /scratch0, /scratch1, ... (/scratch#)
 - any directory named in whole or in part "tmp", "temp", or "scratch".

︗Locally Attached Storage
Locally attached storage like USB flash drives and USB hard drives are very popular.  However, these devices are significantly more vulnerable to data loss or theft than internal or networked data storage.  In general, UMIACS discourages the use of locally attached network storage when any other option is available.  Please note that these devices are prone to high rates of failure and additional steps should be taken to ensure that the data is backed up and that critical or confidential data is not lost or stolen.

︗Network Scratch Storage
Some labs have network-attached storage dedicated for scratch/temporary storage. These shares are named in the same manner as local scratch or temporary storage (i.e. /fs/lab-scratch or /lab/scratch0) and are subject to the same policies as local scratch/tmp (discussed above.)

︗UNIX Storage Commands
Below are a few different CLI commands that may prove useful for monitoring your storage usage and performance. For additional information, run [command] --help or man [command]
df - Shows descriptive file system information

Usage: df [OPTION]... [FILE]...
Show information about the file system on which each FILE resides,
or all file systems by default.

du - Shows disk usage of specific files. Use the -d flag for better depth control.

Usage: du [OPTION]... [FILE]...
  or:  du [OPTION]... --files0-from=F
Summarize disk usage of each FILE, recursively for directories.

free - Shows current memory(RAM) usage. Use the -h flag for a human readable format.

Usage:
 free [options]

quota - Shows quota information, this is useful for viewing per filesystem limits in places such as a home directory. 

quota: Usage: quota [-guqvswim] [-l | [-Q | -A]] [-F quotaformat]
	quota [-qvswim] [-l | [-Q | -A]] [-F quotaformat] -u username ...
	quota [-qvswim] [-l | [-Q | -A]] [-F quotaformat] -g groupname ...
	quota [-qvswugQm] [-F quotaformat] -f filesystem ...

iostat - Shows drive utilization, as well as other utilizations. Pair this with the watch command for regular updates. 

Usage: iostat [ options ] [ <interval> [ <count> ] ]
Options are:
[ -c ] [ -d ] [ -h ] [ -k | -m ] [ -N ] [ -t ] [ -V ] [ -x ] [ -y ] [ -z ]
[ -j { ID | LABEL | PATH | UUID | ... } ]
[ [ -T ] -g <group_name> ] [ -p [ <device> [,...] | ALL ] ]
[ <device> [...] | ALL ]






Retrieved from "https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php?title=LocalDataStorage&oldid=11389"
