Section X:
  
  
    Miscellaneous Policies
  (The prior text links to https://policies.umd.edu/miscellaneous-policies)

    Policy Number: X-1.00(A)
  
︗
    University of Maryland Policy on Acceptable Use of Information Technology Resources
  

(Approved by the President          
    April 05, 2006
)



Print this page











︗
            PRIMARY PRINCIPLES: FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION AND PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY
          

Freedom of expression and an open environment to pursue scholarly inquiry and for sharing of information are encouraged, supported, and protected at the University of Maryland. These values lie at the core of our academic community. Censorship is not compatible with the tradition and goals of the University. While some computing resources are dedicated to specific research, teaching, or administrative tasks that would limit their use, freedom of expression must, in general, be protected. The University does not limit access to information because of its content when it meets the standard of legality. The University's policy of freedom of expression applies to computing resources. Concomitant with free expression are personal obligations of each member of our community to use computing resources responsibly, ethically, and in a manner which accords both with the law and the rights of others. The University depends first upon a spirit of mutual respect and cooperation to create and maintain an open community of responsible users.

︗
            GENERAL
          

This policy sets forth standards for responsible and acceptable use of University information technology (IT) resources. These resources include computer systems, computer labs, applications, networks, software, and files. IT resources are provided to support the academic, research, instructional, and administrative objectives of the University. These resources are extended for the sole use of University faculty, staff, students, and all other authorized guests to accomplish tasks related to the status of that individual at the University, and consistent with the University’s mission.Those using University IT resources, whether at the University or elsewhere, are responsible for complying with security standards set forth by the Vice President and Chief Information Officer (VP/CIO), safeguarding identification codes and passwords, and for using them solely for their intended purposes. Individuals are solely responsible for their personal use of IT resources and are prohibited from representing or implying that statements related to such use constitute the views or policies of the University. The maintenance, operation, and security of IT resources require responsible University personnel to monitor and access systems and networks. To the extent possible in the electronic environment and in a public setting, a user’s privacy will be preserved. Nevertheless, that privacy is subject to applicable federal and state law, including the Maryland Public Information Act, and the needs of the University to meet its administrative, business, and legal obligations.

︗
            PROHIBITED CONDUCT
          

The following provisions describe conduct prohibited under this policy:Altering system software or hardware configurations without authorization; disrupting or interfering with the delivery or administration of IT resources.Attempting to access or accessing another's accounts, private files, e-mail messages, or intercepting network communication without the owner's permission except as appropriate to your job duties and in accordance with legitimate University purposes.Misrepresenting oneself as another individual in electronic communication.Installing, copying, distributing, or using digital content (including software, music, text, images, and video) in violation of copyright and/or software agreements or applicable federal and state law.Engaging in conduct that interferes with others’ use of shared IT resources.Using University IT resources for commercial or profitmaking purposes or to represent the interests of groups unaffiliated with the University or unassociated with the normal professional activities of faculty, staff or students without written authorization from the University.Ignoring individual departmental or unit lab and system policies, procedures, and protocols.Facilitating access to University IT resources by unauthorized users.Exposing sensitive or confidential information or disclosing any electronic information that one does not have the authority to disclose.Knowingly using IT resources for illegal activities. Criminal or illegal use may include obscenity, child pornography, threats, harassment, copyright infringement, University trademark infringement, defamation, theft, identity theft, and unauthorized access.

︗
            ENFORCEMENT
          

Violation of the provisions of this policy constitutes unacceptable use of IT resources, and may violate other University policies and/or state and federal law. Known or suspected violations should be reported to the appropriate University computing unit. Reports may also be sent to the security unit within the Office of Information Technology (abuse@umd.edu). If possible, reports should include a copy of any non-sensitive information relevant to the putative violation.Violations will be acted upon by the appropriate University authorities and/or law enforcement agencies. Violations may result in the restriction or revocation of access to IT resources; faculty, staff, or student disciplinary action; academic dishonesty proceedings through the Student Honor Council; or legal action.The VP/CIO or designee may suspend, block, relocate to a secure location, or restrict access to information and network resources when necessary to protect the integrity, security, or functionality of University IT resources or to protect the University from liability. Notice of such action will be provided to the designated security contact for the affected unit.

︗
            ADMINISTRATION
          

Individual areas within the University (including divisions, colleges, schools, and departments) may elaborate upon this policy with unit-specific policies as long as they do not violate the spirit and intent expressed elsewhere in this policy.Consistent with University System of Maryland requirements, this policy will be reviewed and updated annually or as needed based on the recommendations of the VP/CIO.

〙〘The following url: https://wiki.umiacs.umd.edu/umiacs/index.php/BitLocker/PersonalUse contains the following information: 






︗BitLocker/PersonalUse

From UMIACS



Jump to navigation
Jump to search
︗Contents

1 Overview
2 Prerequisites
3 Initializing the YubiKey and hard drive
4 Unlocking the drive

4.1 Unlocking the drive with the YubiKey
4.2 Unlocking the drive with the recovery password


5 Extra configuration

5.1 Set up Auto-unlock
5.2 Use an encrypted drive as a backup drive




︗Overview
BitLocker can be used on fixed hard drives (i.e. internal to your computer) as well as on portable hard drives (i.e. USB). If you want to hold a secure, offline copy of files that you want to be preserved, BitLocker To Go(The prior text links to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/information-protection/bitlocker/bitlocker-to-go-faq) with a portable hard drive with data to be stored and a hardware token as the key can be used together to do so.

︗Prerequisites
A portable hard drive formatted with an NTFS (preferred), FAT16, FAT32, or exFAT file system.
Any desktop edition of Windows 10/11 except Home. BitLocker encryption is not included as a feature of Windows 10/11 Home, though encrypted drives can still be accessed via Windows 10/11 Home.
A YubiKey security token(The prior text links to https://www.yubico.com/product/yubikey-5-nfc). Other security tokens may work, but this procedure will focus on using a YubiKey.
(optional) One or more (2+ strongly preferred) blank USB flash drives at least 500MB in size, formatted with any Windows-writable file system.
︗Initializing the YubiKey and hard drive
Log in locally to the machine you wish to use for encryption. This procedure will not work over Remote Desktop.
Download and install the YubiKey personalization tool(The prior text links to https://www.yubico.com/support/download/yubikey-personalization-tools/). Choose the first option (not the command line interface version). If you are using a UMIACS-supported workstation, please contact  UMIACS Staff to install this on your machine.
Insert your YubiKey into any USB slot on the machine you wish to use for encryption and launch the personalization tool. Select Static Password at the top and then Advanced.
The image showcases the YubiKey Personalization Tool interface, specifically in the "Static Password" mode. The upper section prominently features the title "YubiKey Personalization Tool" and the current mode selected, highlighted in red as "Static Password." Below this, there are two main buttons: "Scan Code" on the left, which allows quick programming of the YubiKey to emit a desired static password, and "Advanced," circled in blue, which provides options to program one or more YubiKeys for emitting complex, hard-to-guess static passwords. 

The right panel displays the YubiKey's status, confirming that both slots (1 and 2) are configured, alongside the firmware version (4.3.7) and serial number details. Several features supported by the YubiKey are also listed, showing checkmarks next to most, indicating active functionality, while one feature, marked "Universal 2nd Factor," shows a red X, suggesting it is not available. The background is light, and the overall design is clean and user-friendly, indicative of software aimed at secure password management and user authentication through the YubiKey device.
Select Configuration Slot 2(*) and change the password length to 48 chars. Then click all three Generate buttons in order to generate the identities and the secret key and finally Write Configuration. Click cancel (do not save) on the prompt that pops up to save the .csv file, as this saves the Public Identity, Private Identity, and Secret Key in plaintext. Ensure that "YubiKey has been successfully configured" is output in the Results window, and then click Exit in the top right to exit the tool.
(*) NOTE: The YubiKey token has two configuration slots. These are nearly functionally identical, but the key difference for the sake of this document is that Slot 2 requires you to hold the sensor on the device down for 2 seconds in order to activate, whereas Slot 1 instantaneously activates when you touch the sensor. We recommend using Slot 2 so that you do not mistakenly emit the password configured below. If you are already using Slot 2 on your YubiKey, slot 1 can still be used.
The image displays the interface of the YubiKey Personalization Tool, focused on the "Static Password" configuration mode. At the top, there's a bold title "YubiKey Personalization Tool," with a highlighted notification indicating that the YubiKey has been successfully configured for a password length of 48 characters. 

The interface is divided into several sections. In the left panel, users can select the configuration slot to program (either Slot 1 or Slot 2) with Slot 2 currently highlighted. Below this, options for programming multiple YubiKeys and configuring protection levels are provided. The "Password Parameters" section prominently shows the selected password length of 48 characters, with input fields for Public Identity, Private Identity, and Secret Key, which are filled with randomly generated values. 

There are buttons labeled "Generate" next to each key entry, allowing users to create new values. The bottom section of the image features an "Actions" group with a red "Write Configuration" button, along with other command options like "Stop," "Reset," and "Back." In the results area, confirmation is displayed that the YubiKey configuration was successful, alongside relevant firmware and serial number details on the right, and a list of features supported by the device. The overall design is clean and user-friendly, characterized by a light background and clear text.
Insert your portable hard drive into any USB slot and search BitLocker in the start menu to open the Manage BitLocker control panel item.
The image shows the Windows 10 start menu interface with the search function highlighted. At the top left, the search bar is active, displaying the term “bitlocker.” Below it, the search results indicate “Manage BitLocker” as the best match, marked in blue, along with an accompanying icon depicting a padlock and key over a disk. The panel on the right side details "Manage BitLocker" and indicates it leads to the Control Panel. It contains a large "Open" button, inviting the user to access the BitLocker management interface. The background is light grey, and the interface is clean and organized, emphasizing the ease of finding system utility tools. The entire image conveys a user-friendly environment designed for managing disk encryption through BitLocker, demonstrating how users can easily locate and access encryption settings on their Windows device.
Expand Removable data drives - BitLocker To Go by clicking the arrow on the right and then click Turn on BitLocker on the portable hard drive.
The image displays the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" interface from the Control Panel on a Windows operating system. At the top, the title prominently reads "BitLocker Drive Encryption," indicating the purpose of the menu to safeguard files from unauthorized access. The layout features sections for different types of drives: the operating system drive, fixed data drives, and removable data drives.

Under the "Operating system drive" category, the C: drive is listed with an indication that BitLocker is off. Below that, the "Fixed data drives" section shows another drive labeled "ARAXXOR (E:)," with BitLocker also turned off. The "Removable data drives - BitLocker To Go" section highlights a "Portable Hard Drive (F:)" with a blue link saying "Turn on BitLocker," enclosed in a red box for emphasis, suggesting this is a call to action for users to activate encryption for the drive.

The background is predominantly white, providing a clean and organized visual for users navigating the settings. Icons next to drive names further enhance identification and clarity, promoting an intuitive experience for managing drive encryption settings effectively.
BitLocker will initialize for a few seconds and then pop up with a menu asking how you want to unlock the drive. Choose Use a password to unlock the drive and physically touch the YubiKey's sensor for 3 seconds to get it to output the password you configured previously in each password field.
The image displays the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" setup interface for a portable hard drive labeled (F:). A prominent section at the top instructs users to choose how to unlock the drive. The option "Use a password to unlock the drive" is checked, indicated by a red box around it. Below this, the interface prompts users to enter and confirm their password, which is illustrated with black dots representing hidden characters for security. The text specifies that passwords should include uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, spaces, and symbols. An additional checkbox below allows users to choose "Use my smart card to unlock the drive," requiring the insertion of a smart card for access. The bottom right of the window features navigation buttons: "Next," which guides users forward in the encryption process, and "Cancel," which allows them to exit the setup. The background of the interface is light, creating a clear and user-friendly design conducive to secure password management. The overall layout emphasizes accessibility and ease of use in setting up encrypted access to the drive.
The menu should automatically advance to asking how you want to back up the recovery key. The recovery key is the only way to get into the encrypted drive if you lose the YubiKey. We strongly recommend the Save to a file option for reasons that we will get into. If you choose to print out the recovery key, store it somewhere safe such as a safe deposit box.
The image displays the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" setup interface for a portable hard drive labeled (F:). At the top, a clear instruction prompts users on how to back up their recovery key, emphasizing its importance should they lose their password or smart card. The main focus is on the option "Save to a file," which is highlighted with a blue button enclosed in a red box, indicating a recommended action. Below this, an alternative option reads "Print the recovery key," providing additional methods for securing access to the drive.

The interface includes a light background that enhances readability, with systematic organization guiding the user's eyes to critical choices. Navigation buttons at the bottom, such as "Next" and "Cancel," enable users to proceed or exit the setup easily. The design promotes a sense of security and accessibility, encouraging users to prioritize their recovery key's backup to maintain control over their encrypted data. Overall, the interface exemplifies user-friendly software aimed at aiding individuals in managing encryption effectively.
Plug in your first USB flash drive and choose to save the file on it.
The image displays the "Save BitLocker recovery key as" dialog box, showcasing a computer interface for saving a file. The window is structured with a standard file navigation layout at the top, indicating the target USB drive labeled "USB Drive (G:)." The file name field prominently highlights "BitLocker Recovery Key BF899444-4DB2-435B-AE89-562C6115306.TXT," suggesting this is a unique identifier for the recovery key. Below, the file type dropdown indicates that the file will be saved as a text file ("Text Files (*.txt)"), facilitating easy access and readability.

The overall aesthetic of the interface is clean and functional, with a light background that enhances text visibility. A "Save" button on the right allows users to proceed with saving the file, while a "Cancel" button offers an option to abort the action. The presence of navigation features such as back arrows and folder lists encourages user-friendly interaction, ensuring that individuals can quickly navigate to the desired save location. This setup underscores the importance of safeguarding the BitLocker recovery key for accessing encrypted drives.
If you previously had anything saved on your portable hard drive before formatting it as part of the prerequisites, choose to Encrypt entire drive. This is the safest way to ensure everything on the drive is protected. Otherwise (if this is a brand new blank drive), leave the default option of Encrypt used disk space only.
The image displays the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" interface for a portable hard drive labeled (F:). At the top of the window, the heading clearly states the purpose: to choose how much of the drive to encrypt. Two radio button options are presented for user selection. The first option, "Encrypt used disk space only (faster and best for new PCs and drives)," indicates a quicker process suitable for drives with little data. The second option, "Encrypt entire drive (slower but best for PCs and drives already in use)," emphasizes comprehensive security by protecting all existing data, even recoverable deleted files.

Each option is accompanied by a brief description, helping users understand the implications of their choice. Below the options, there are navigation buttons: "Next" to proceed with the encryption process and "Cancel" to exit. The background is a clean white, contributing to a user-friendly design that prioritizes clarity in decision-making about drive security. Overall, the interface is functional and intuitive, enabling users to effectively manage encryption settings for their portable hard drive.
Leave the default of Compatible mode to better ensure the files on the encrypted drive will be readable from other devices (which may be running earlier versions of Windows) if need be.
The image showcases the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" interface specific to drive F:. Prominently at the top, there's a header titled "Choose which encryption mode to use," indicating essential options for encrypting the drive. Beneath, a brief explanation mentions that Windows 10 introduces a new encryption mode (XTS-AES) that enhances integrity but may not be compatible with older Windows versions. 

Two main radio button options are provided for user selection: the first labeled "New encryption mode (best for fixed drives on this device)," indicating suitability for fixed drives, while the second states "Compatible mode (best for drives that can be moved from this device)," targeting users needing compatibility with older systems. Each option is accompanied by a succinct description to guide the user, encouraging informed decision-making. The background of the interface is designed with a light color scheme, contributing to clarity, while navigation buttons at the bottom, such as "Next" and "Cancel," facilitate user interactions. Overall, the layout exemplifies a user-friendly design aimed at smoothly guiding users through the encryption process for their drive.
Continue through the menus and finally choose to Start encrypting.
The image displays the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" interface for a portable drive labeled (F:). At the top, there is a clear header indicating that the user is being prompted to confirm encryption for the drive. The main question reads, “Are you ready to encrypt this drive?” which is accompanied by a bullet point note explaining that the drive will be unlockable using a password. It also mentions that the encryption process may take some time, depending on the size of the drive, while warning that files will remain unprotected until the encryption is complete. The interface features a clean white background, promoting readability and clarity. At the bottom right, a large blue button labeled "Start encrypting" is present, providing a straightforward call-to-action for the user to proceed. There’s also a "Cancel" button, allowing the user the option to exit this prompt. The overall layout is simple and user-friendly, suited for individuals engaging in disk encryption, emphasizing security while guiding through the procedure comprehensively.
BitLocker will begin encrypting and a separate window will pop up to show you the status. This step will either take a long time if you chose to Encrypt entire drive, or complete very quickly if you chose to Encrypt used disk space only. You do not have to wait for encryption to complete to proceed with the remaining steps, but you do need to wait for encryption to complete before disconnecting the portable hard drive from the machine.
The image displays the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" progress window, indicating the encryption status of a portable drive labeled (F:). At the top, the title reads "BitLocker Drive Encryption," with an accompanying icon of a padlock symbolizing security. Below, a progress bar shows that encryption is 99.9% completed, represented by a predominantly green fill that nearly fills the bar, implying that the process is almost finished. The percentage is displayed prominently, providing clarity on the encryption status. 

A warning message is present at the bottom, advising users to avoid removing the drive or files during the encryption process to prevent data damage. It suggests that pausing encryption is necessary before performing such actions. Additionally, a "Manage BitLocker" button is visible on the right, allowing users to access further BitLocker settings. The clean layout features a light background, enhancing readability and focus on the encryption status, making it user-friendly for individuals monitoring the encryption of their drive. Overall, this interface emphasizes the importance of drive security while providing visual feedback on the encryption progress.
Download the portable version of KeePassXC Password Manager(The prior text links to https://keepassxc.org/download/). Then extract it to your USB flash drive.
The image displays the "Extract Compressed (Zipped) Folders" dialog box on a Windows operating system. At the top, the window title reads "Extract Compressed (Zipped) Folders," indicating the file extraction process. The main section presents the path for the extracted files as "G:\KeePassXC-2.5.1-Win64-portable," suggesting that the user has chosen to extract the contents of a zipped KeePassXC folder to an external USB drive or portable storage. 

On the left panel, navigation options such as "This PC," "Desktop," and "Downloads" are visible, allowing users easy access to various locations on their computer. Below the folder path, there is a checkbox labeled "Show extracted files when complete," enabling users to automatically view the extracted files after the process is finished. The bottom of the window features two buttons: "Extract" to initiate the extraction and "Cancel" to abort the operation. The clean layout, with a light background, ensures clarity and ease of use, ideal for users managing file extraction tasks.
Launch KeePassXC.exe from the extracted folder and choose to Create new database.
The image displays the welcome interface of KeePassXC version 2.5.1, a password management application. The top section features the program title, "Welcome to KeePassXC 2.5.1," in a bold font. In the center, there is a circular green logo depicting a key symbol, emphasizing security and password management. Below this, the interface presents several options for users, prominently displaying "Create new database" as a blue button, which invites users to initiate a new password database.

Additional options include "Open existing database," "Import from KeePass 1," "Import from 1Password," and "Import from CSV," all presented in a clean, organized manner. The background is primarily white, contributing to a simple and user-friendly layout. The overall design of the interface highlights accessibility, encouraging users to securely store their passwords while easily navigating through the available functionalities. The presence of intuitive labels ensures clarity and aids in user interactions with the software, making it suitable for both novices and experienced users managing sensitive information.
Choose descriptive phrases for the Database Name and Description and click Continue.
The image displays the interface of KeePassXC password manager, specifically at the "Create a new KeePassXC database" section. The window showcases a clean, user-friendly design with a prominent green key logo on the left, symbolizing security. The title above the interface reads "General Database Information," guiding users on what information to fill out. 

Two fields are presented for user input: the first labeled "Database Name" where the user has entered "BitLocker Recovery," and the second labeled "Description," filled with "Portable Hard Drive BitLocker Recovery Key." Below these fields, there are navigation buttons: "Go Back" allows users to return to the previous step, while "Continue" advances to the next stage of database creation. The background is predominantly white, ensuring clarity and ease of readability. Overall, the layout emphasizes simplicity and accessibility, suitable for effectively managing sensitive password information while maintaining a focus on security practices.
Leave all the options on the next menu at default unless you know what you are doing and have good reason to change them and click Continue.
The image displays the "Encryption Settings" interface within KeePassXC password manager, specifically during the setup of a new database. The design includes a prominent green circular logo featuring a key symbol, representing security. The title at the top reads "Encryption Settings," offering guidance on adjusting encryption preferences. 

On the left side, the "Decryption Time" slider allows users to set a decryption duration ranging from 1.0 seconds to 5 seconds, accompanied by an explanatory note indicating that longer decryption times provide more security but may slow down database access. Below this, the database format dropdown shows "KDBX 4.0 (recommended)," implying the preferred format for compatibility with KeePassXC. 

The user interface is clean and functional, featuring a light background that enhances visibility and readability. Navigation buttons at the bottom include options to "Go Back," "Continue," and "Cancel," streamlining the user experience. Overall, the layout is intuitive, ensuring ease of use while helping users implement effective security measures for their password databases.
Choose a memorable password and click Done.
The image displays the "Database Master Key" creation interface in KeePassXC, a password management application. The top section of the window prominently features the title "Database Master Key," indicating the purpose is to establish a secure password for the database. The design is clean, with a light background that enhances readability. 

On the left side, a descriptive note informs the user that a master key, known only to them, will protect the database. The right panel presents two input fields labeled "Enter password" and "Confirm password," where users can type their desired password, represented by black dots for security. Below these fields, there's an option to "Add additional protection..." for enhanced security measures. 

At the bottom, navigation options include "Go Back," allowing users to return to the previous step, and a prominent blue "Done" button, suggesting the finalization of the process. The overall layout prioritizes usability and clarity, making it accessible for both novice and advanced users to establish secure password protection for their sensitive information.
Choose to save the file on your USB flash drive.
The image displays the "Save database as" dialog box in a Windows environment. The top of the window indicates the title "Save database as," emphasizing the process of saving a new file. The active directory path shows that the file is being saved to a USB drive labeled "USB Drive (G:)," suggesting it's an external storage device. 

In the "File name" field, the text "BitLockerRecovery.kdbx" is visible, indicating the user intends to name their KeePassXC database for storing secure information related to BitLocker recovery. The "Save as type" dropdown menu indicates the file format as "KeePass 2 Database (*.kdbx)," ensuring compatibility with the KeePassXC password manager. 

The layout of the interface is structured and user-friendly, featuring navigation options on the left side for accessing different folders. Below the file name and type fields, there are two essential buttons: "Save," which is highlighted and located on the right to confirm the action, and "Cancel," which allows the user to abort the save process. The overall design is clean, focused, and intuitive, facilitating straightforward user interactions during the file-saving operation.
In your newly created database, choose to Add a new entry from the top pane.
The image displays the KeePassXC password manager interface for creating a new database entry, titled "BitLocker Recovery." The upper section contains a toolbar with icons for managing entries and groups. A highlighted button labeled "Add a new entry" is prominently featured in red, inviting user interaction. To the left, a panel shows the current database structure, identified as "Root." Adjacent to this, the main section has columns designated for "Title," "Username," "Password," "URL," "Notes," and "Expires," which are currently empty as the user has not yet input any data.

The overall design of the interface is clean and intuitive, facilitating easy navigation and input. The background is predominantly light, enhancing readability and user-friendliness. Clear demarcation of fields indicates where users should enter relevant information for secure password storage, making it suitable for individuals focusing on effective management of sensitive data tied to BitLocker recovery.
Make the Title something memorable. Open the recovery key text file saved earlier, copy the Identifier into the Username field and the Recovery Key into the Password/Repeat fields. Leave some descriptive text in the Notes section to help clarify which fields are which of the BitLocker attributes. Click OK and then exit out of the database back on the main menu.
The image displays a Notepad interface showing the content of a BitLocker recovery key text file. The top section indicates the file name, "BitLocker Drive Encryption recovery key," in a standard font. The identifier is highlighted in red, showcasing the specific value "BF899A44-4DB2-435B-AE89-562C66115306," emphasizing its importance for unlocking the drive. Below that, a note instructs users to compare this identifier with the one displayed on their PC for verification. 

The recovery key is presented in a green box, labeled with the text "Recovery Key" and providing the key value "236885-095579-293854-269665-162437-382635-141757-516890." An additional note emphasizes the need for the identifier to match for successful drive unlocking, and it provides a link for further assistance if the key does not match. The interface is clean and organized, with a white background enhancing readability. The overall structure emphasizes crucial information for users needing to recover access to a BitLocker-encrypted drive, promoting secure data management practices.The image shows the KeePassXC password manager interface designed for adding an entry. At the top, the title reads "Root > Add entry," indicating the section for creating a new password entry. The left panel highlights a pencil icon, signaling the action of editing or adding information. 

The main section features fields filled with specific data: "Title" displays the text "Portable Hard Drive BitLocker Recovery Key," providing context for the entry. Below, the "Username" field contains an identifier, emphasized in red, reading "BF899A44-4DB2-435B-AE89-562C66115306." The adjacent "Password" and "Repeat" fields show black dots, representing the hidden format for security reasons.

In the lower part, a "Notes" section includes helpful descriptions: "Username is BitLocker Identifier" and "Password is BitLocker Recovery Key," clarifying the purpose of each field. The overall layout is clean and intuitive, with a light background ensuring readability. Navigation buttons for confirming ("OK") or canceling the input process are present at the bottom right, emphasizing user-friendly interaction with the software.
Delete the recovery key text file permanently (NOT the database file you just created). If you leave the recovery key text file on the USB drive, your encrypted portable hard drive is only as secure as that USB flash drive is, rather than needing both the USB flash drive and the password for the database to access the recovery key.
The image displays a Windows dialog box titled "Delete File," confirming the user's intention to permanently delete a BitLocker recovery key text file. At the top, the question "Are you sure you want to permanently delete this file?" is posed, suggesting a critical action that requires confirmation. 

The file in question is identified as "BitLocker Recovery Key BF899444-4DB2-435B-AE89-562C6115306," indicating its significance for unlocking a BitLocker-encrypted drive. The file type is noted as a "Text Document," and the size is shown as "0 bytes," which may signal that the document is empty or that the important data has already been processed or removed. 

The dialog box contains two prominent buttons at the bottom: "Yes," which confirms the deletion, allowing the process to proceed, and "No," permitting the user to cancel the deletion if they change their mind. The overall design of the box is user-friendly, emphasizing caution as it ensures users are aware of the irreversible action they are about to take. The background is typical for Windows, enhancing readability, and highlighting the importance of data management practices.
(Optional) Copy the contents of the first USB flash drive onto one or more additional USB flash drives to safeguard against loss of both the YubiKey and any single USB flash drive.
Clearly label the USB flash drive(s) and store them somewhere secure, such as a safe deposit box. If you have multiple USB flash drives, store them separately.
Your portable hard drive is now securely BitLocker-encrypted, with one or more USB drives serving as access to the recovery key.
︗Unlocking the drive
︗Unlocking the drive with the YubiKey
To later unlock the drive from the same or a different computer:

Physically plug the drive and YubiKey in. Click on the notification you get in the notification area, which will open the unlock menu.
The image displays a notification message on a Windows operating system, indicating that drive F: is BitLocker-protected. The message is presented in a simple, clean format, with a dark background that highlights the white text for clarity. The title "Unlock drive F:" appears prominently at the top, signaling the action required from the user. Below, the message states "This drive is BitLocker-protected," reinforcing the need for authentication to access the drive’s contents. The overall design is minimalistic, focusing on user actions related to drive security, and suggests that the user needs to unlock the drive using the appropriate credentials or security token, such as a password or a YubiKey. The interface conveys a sense of urgency regarding the need to unlock the encrypted drive before access can be granted, while maintaining a user-friendly layout.The image showcases the "BitLocker" unlock interface on a Windows operating system for the drive labeled (F:). Prominently displayed are the elements necessary for accessing the encrypted drive. At the top, the title "BitLocker (F:)" indicates the drive's identification. Below it, a text field invites users to "Enter password to unlock this drive," where users will input the required password, represented by black dots for security. A small eye icon to the right allows users to toggle the visibility of the typed password for verification. 

Additionally, there’s a "More options" link beneath the password field, which suggests alternative methods for unlocking, potentially including recovery keys or smart cards. At the bottom right, a large blue button labeled "Unlock" encourages the user to proceed with entering the password. The overall interface design is clean and minimalistic, with a white background that enhances readability, emphasizing a straightforward user experience for unlocking BitLocker-encrypted drives.
Physically touch the YubiKey's sensor for 3 seconds to get it to emit the password. It will automatically unlock afterwards.
The image showcases the "BitLocker" unlock interface on a Windows operating system for the drive labeled (F:). At the top, the title "BitLocker (F:)" is clearly displayed, indicating the specific drive for which unlocking is required. Below this, there is an input field prompting users to "Enter password to unlock this drive," where users type their password, which is obscured by black dots for security. Adjacent to the password field is a small eye icon that allows users to reveal the typed password for verification. 

Beneath the password entry, a link labeled "More options" provides additional unlocking methods, potentially including recovery keys or smart cards for users who may not have their password. At the bottom right, a prominent blue button labeled "Unlock" invites the user to proceed with their entry. The overall layout is clean and minimalistic, characterized by a white background enhancing visibility and readability, ensuring a user-friendly experience while emphasizing the importance of secure access to the encrypted drive.
The drive is now unlocked until it is unplugged again.
︗Unlocking the drive with the recovery password
To later unlock the drive from the same or a different computer if you are not in possession of your YubiKey:

Physically plug one of your USB flash drives containing a database with the recovery key in.
Open the recovery database using the password you set for it and then copy the password for the entry inside of it. This is the recovery key.
The image shows the KeePassXC password management interface, which is set to display a specific entry titled "Portable Hard Drive BitLocker Recovery Key." The upper panel includes standard menu options with icons for managing entries, groups, and other settings. The highlighted entry, identifiable by the blue color, lists pertinent information in organized columns: the "Username" contains a unique identifier (BF899A44-4DB2-435B-AE89-562C66115306), while the "Password" field, marked by hidden dots, is secured from unauthorized viewing. 

A notes section provides explanations, indicating that the "Username" is the BitLocker Identifier and the "Password" pertains to the BitLocker Recovery Key, ensuring the user understands the significance of each field. The overall layout is clear, with a light background promoting readability. Users can navigate their database easily, and various actions can be performed using icons, with "Copy username" and "Copy password" options prominently displayed in the context menu. This interface emphasizes usability, making it accessible for securely managing sensitive password information related to BitLocker recovery.
Physically plug the drive in. Click on the notification you get in the notification area, which will open the unlock menu.
The image displays a notification on a Windows operating system, indicating that drive F: is protected by BitLocker encryption. The notification appears in a simple design with a dark background that enhances the visibility of the white text. The title "Unlock drive F:" is prominently featured at the top, clearly indicating the action required from the user. Below, the message succinctly states, "This drive is BitLocker-protected," emphasizing that authentication is necessary to access the drive's contents. The overall layout is minimalistic, prioritizing clarity and directing the user's attention to the need for unlocking the drive using the appropriate credentials, which may include a password or a security token. This interface conveys a sense of urgency regarding drive security while maintaining an intuitive user experience.The image displays the "BitLocker" unlock interface for a drive labeled (F:). At the top of the interface, the header "BitLocker (F:)" indicates that this is the encryption process for the specified drive. Below the header, a single text field prompts users to "Enter password to unlock this drive," where the password is represented by black dots for security reasons. To the right of the input field, there is a small eye icon that allows users to toggle the visibility of the typed password. 

Below the password input area, the interface includes a link titled "More options," which suggests additional methods for unlocking the drive, potentially utilizing a recovery key or a smart card. At the bottom of the screen, a prominent blue button labeled "Unlock" encourages the user to submit their password to access the drive’s contents. 

Overall, the design features a clean, minimalistic white background that enhances readability and emphasizes user-friendliness, making it straightforward for users to unlock their BitLocker-protected drive securely.
Click on More options and then Enter recovery key.
The image displays the "BitLocker" unlock interface for a drive labeled (F:), clearly indicating the actions needed to access the encrypted contents. At the top, the title "BitLocker (F:)" is prominent, denoting the specific drive in question. Below the title, there is a text input box prompted with "Enter password to unlock this drive," where users can securely input their password, represented by hidden black dots. 

To the left of the password field, a link labeled "Fewer options" expands further actions, specifically highlighting "Enter recovery key," which is enclosed in a red box to draw user attention. Below this, a checkbox labeled "Automatically unlock on this PC" allows users to opt for convenience if they prefer automatic unlocking in the future. 

The lower right corner features a large blue button labeled "Unlock," inviting users to initiate the unlocking process. The overall interface is designed with a clean, light background, enhancing readability and usability, making it straightforward for users to securely unlock their BitLocker-protected drive.
Enter the copied recovery key from your database file and click Unlock.
The image showcases the "BitLocker" unlock interface for a drive identified as (F:). Prominently displayed at the top is the drive title "BitLocker (F:)," which indicates the specific drive being accessed. Below, there is a text prompt instructing the user to enter the "48-digit recovery key to unlock this drive," along with the Key ID (BF899A44) to assist with identification. This key serves as a crucial recovery element for users who have misplaced their usual unlocking credentials.

Centered on the interface is a single input box, where the recovery key is to be entered. The input is represented with black dots for security, enhancing confidentiality. Adjacent to the text box, a red "X" button allows users to clear the input if necessary. To the right, a prominent blue button labeled "Unlock" invites interaction, enabling the user to proceed once the key has been correctly entered.

The overall design features a clean, minimalistic layout with a light background that enhances readability and usability, ensuring a straightforward experience for users seeking access to their encrypted BitLocker drive.
The drive is now unlocked until it is unplugged again. If you have lost your YubiKey, we strongly recommend buying a new YubiKey, decrypting BitLocker on the drive, and then repeating the initial procedure to re-encrypt it with the new YubiKey.
︗Extra configuration
︗Set up Auto-unlock
BitLocker has the ability to auto-unlock an encrypted drive for a specific user(s) when plugged into a specific computer(s) if so desired. This creates an entry in the Windows registry on each computer's local data storage for each user you turn it on for. The entry stores a copy of the volume master key for the encrypted drive that is itself encrypted with a combination of the user's username and either the user's password, if there is one, or computer credentials.
We do not recommend turning this on as it undermines the concept of separation of the unlock methods for the drive from any specific computer. If you do want to turn this on, please ensure the user account(s) that you turn it on for are secure (i.e. have sufficiently complex passwords) and the computer(s) that you turn it on for are in secure locations.
To enable auto-unlock for a drive (per user per computer):

Insert your already-encrypted portable hard drive into any USB slot, unlock it, and search BitLocker in the start menu to open the Manage BitLocker control panel item.
The image shows the Windows 10 start menu interface, where the search function is actively searching for "bitlocker." At the top left of the screen, the search bar is filled with the term "bitlocker," and the search results are displayed below. The primary result, "Manage BitLocker," is highlighted in blue, indicating it’s the best match for the search. This entry is accompanied by an icon featuring a padlock and a key over a disk, symbolizing security. On the right side, the control panel description denotes that selecting this option leads to the BitLocker management interface, allowing users to manage encryption settings for their drives. The clean layout, with a light grey background, presents an organized view, illustrating a user-friendly environment that emphasizes accessibility and efficiency in accessing system utilities. Overall, the design focuses on guiding users through the process of managing BitLocker encryption on their Windows devices.
Expand Removable data drives - BitLocker To Go by clicking the arrow on the right and then click Turn on auto-unlock on the portable hard drive.
The image displays the "BitLocker Drive Encryption" settings interface on a Windows operating system, specifically focusing on the management of BitLocker for removable data drives. At the top of the interface, the title "BitLocker Drive Encryption" is clearly indicated, along with the guidance on protecting files from unauthorized access. Below, sections categorize different drives: the operating system drive, fixed data drives, and the removable data drives section titled "Removable data drives - BitLocker To Go."

The lower part of the screen highlights a portable hard drive labeled (F:), which is currently secured with BitLocker encryption. The detail "Turn on auto-unlock" appears prominently in a red box, signaling a crucial user action to enhance convenience. Options such as “Back up your recovery key,” “Change password,” and “Remove password” are also listed under the drive's label, directing users toward additional BitLocker management features. 

The layout is organized and user-friendly, with a light background enhancing readability. Clear labeling of each function allows users to navigate the BitLocker settings easily, thus ensuring a smooth administrative experience regarding drive security.
The drive will now auto-unlock when plugged into the computer you are currently on for your user account only. You can turn it off again by clicking on the Turn off auto-unlock option that appears in the same location after clicking the turn on button.
︗Use an encrypted drive as a backup drive
One of the more useful things you may want to do with a BitLocker-encrypted portable hard drive is set up automatic backup to it. This can be done by following the procedure on  this page, though please note you will need to unlock the drive each time when plugging it into a computer, or have configured auto-unlock for that computer, before it is accessible by backup software.

Revised by Sussan Dehghan-Kavoosi   This article was updated •  8mo agoabout a year ago   This article has 92 views. •  92 Views   This article has average rating: 0 out of 5 stars • ( )( )( )( )( )  iOS mobile devices can be configured to access UMD Google Apps and data from these apps through native iOS applications, such as Mail, Contacts and Calendars.Tap Settings.Tap Mail, Contacts, Calendars Tap Add Account.Tap Google.At the Google Sign In box, enter your current email address (DirectoryID@umd.edu). Leave the password field blank and click Sign In.You will be redirected to the CAS Login screen. Enter your Directory ID (without @umd.edu) and password. Click Login. Authenticate your identity with multi-factor authentication when prompted.Click Allow to grant access to the UMD Google Apps system.The Settings page will reopen with the Mail, Contacts, and Calendars sliders set to green. Revised by Robert Hopkins   This article was updated •  3mo agoabout a year ago   This article has 729 views. •  729 Views   This article has average rating: 0 out of 5 stars • ( )( )( )( )( )  ︗Table of ContentsPurpose(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mcq)Definitions(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mcr)Requirements(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mcs)Implementation(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mct)Applies To(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mcu)Procedures(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mcv)Waiver(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mc10)Violation(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mc11)Review(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mc12)Responsibilities(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mc13)Resources(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mc14)Contacts(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#mcetoc_1ffg4h6mc15)︗PurposeThe University of Maryland ("UMD" or the "University") provides an institutional email system to promote secure communication and collaboration, allow for business continuity, and maintain effective handling of institutional data. The use of email systems to conduct University Business is subject to federal, state, and local legal, regulatory, and statutory requirements, including but not limited to the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act ("FERPA") and the State of Maryland's public records laws, as well as University and University System of Maryland policies and procedures. Noncompliance with these laws and regulations could result in a loss of federal funding, as well as civil and criminal penalties; noncompliance with these laws, regulations, and policies/procedures could have a severe adverse impact on UMD's mission, safety, finances, or reputation. This Email Standard (the "Standard") sets forth fundamental requirements for the appropriate use of email systems to conduct University Business. Compliance with this Standard is necessary for the University to meet all the requirements of the USM IT Security Standards(The prior text links to http://www.usmd.edu/usm/adminfinance/itcc/USMITSecurityStandards.pdf) and the UMD Policy on Acceptable Use of Information Technology Resources(The prior text links to https://www.president.umd.edu/administration/policies/section-x-miscellaneous-policies/x-100a).Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗DefinitionsTerms used in this article and their definitions.TermDefinitionUniversity BusinessThe work performed on behalf of the University by its personnel (including faculty, staff, student employees, and other persons whose conduct falls under University operations), whether or not such persons receive compensation for performing this work.Institutional EmailThe UMD email system/platform provided and maintained by the Division of Information Technology (username@umd.edu) enabled by Google Workspace for Education, also known as UMD Gmail or UMD Email.Approved Email SystemUMD Institutional Email (aka UMD Gmail), plus any administrative, academic, or programmatic unit's email system granted a waiver by the Division of IT.Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗RequirementsThe University requires its personnel to use an Approved Email System to conduct University Business. Specifically, all email sent by University personnel regarding University Business must be sent from an Approved Email System.Email is an inherently insecure medium for transmitting private or confidential information. Email must not be used to transmit data with a risk level of High (Level 3) or Restricted (Level 4) as defined by the IT-2 University of Maryland Data Classification Standard(The prior text links to https://itsupport.umd.edu/itsupport?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0012438).As State of Maryland employees, UMD personnel should not use an Approved Email System for private gains or personal matters, or matters that create or appear to create either a conflict of interest or an endorsement by the University. While incidental personal use of UMD Email is acceptable, employees are strongly encouraged to use a separate, non-UMD email system for personal matters.There are significant differences in the agreement language and the data collected between a typical consumer Gmail account and UMD's Gmail (G Suite for Education) accounts. Therefore, automatically forwarding emails and documents from an Approved Email System to another email account/platform (e.g., @gmail.com, @yahoo.com, etc.) is prohibited. This practice greatly elevates the risks of sharing information that is protected as confidential by federal and/or state law or the University's contractual obligations. If University personnel are required by the terms of a University contract or other legal agreement to use a United States federal agency email account, the University may permit University email to be forwarded to a federal agency email account or otherwise defer to any federal agency requirements incorporated into the University's applicable collaboration or sponsored research agreement.University personnel may enable a UMD Gmail account on multiple devices including mobile phones. To prevent accidental use of a personal email address when conducting University Business, it is strongly recommended that an Approved Email System is used as the default outbound setting on devices.Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗ImplementationEach University administrative, academic, and programmatic unit must establish priorities and timetables to decommission their legacy email systems and transition their users to the UMD email system before June 30, 2020. Units were to communicate their plans to the Division of Information Technology at emailconsolidation@umd.edu before November 30, 2019.Subject to approval by the respective relevant unit heads and deans, the use of legacy email addresses of the form @[unit].umd.edu may continue for both inbound and outbound email as long as this email is sent and delivered by an Approved Email System.Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗Applies ToAll members of the University Community who conduct University Business via email. Excludes TERPmail, which is the University of Maryland's institutional student platform for communicating academic information and providing cloud storage and productivity and collaboration tools. All students and accepted applicants may be granted a TERPmail address.Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗Procedures︗WaiverA unit that has unique business requirements that cannot be met by the Institutional Email must submit a waiver form(The prior text links to https://itsupport.umd.edu/itsupport?id=sc_cat_item&sys_id=bdd496badb448c903fb0d92b5e961907) explaining, in detail, how conformance with this Standard would be noncompliant with federal or state laws. For example, University personnel conducting classified work are required to use an email system that meets federal government statutory or contractual requirements in specific situations. Waivers must be requested by a unit head responsible for overseeing the administrative, academic, or programmatic unit and approved by the respective Dean or Vice President and the Division of Information Technology. The Division of Information Technology VP/CIO may grant waivers to this security Standards for a period of up to 3 years (with the option for renewal). Consistent with the UMD Policy on Acceptable Use of Information Technology Resources(The prior text links to https://www.president.umd.edu/administration/policies/section-x-miscellaneous-policies/x-100a), a waiver may be revoked at any time by the VP/CIO.Waivers to forward Intuitional Email to U.S. federal agencies when required by contract, may be granted by the CIO in consultation with the Office of General Council. Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗ViolationFailure to comply with this standard constitutes a violation of the UMD Policy on Acceptable Use of Information Technology Resources(The prior text links to https://www.president.umd.edu/administration/policies/section-x-miscellaneous-policies/x-100a).Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗ReviewThe VP/CIO or a designee will initiate a review and necessary revisions of this standard as needed, with appropriate input from the Division of Information Technology staff and the IT Council.Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗ResponsibilitiesThe related responsibilities of the positions and offices mentioned in this document.Position/OfficeResponsibilitiesVice president/chief information officerConsults with the President, the Senior Vice President and Provost, and the Office of General Counsel about this standard and its implementation.Decides and communicates whether waiver requests are approved.Division of Information TechnologyProvides oversight and management access to the Institutional email platform.Provides support and training as required and requested.Takes and resolves complaints about this security standard.Periodically initiates a review and approves the necessary revisions of this security standard.Manages integration with the University Directory, which contains information about users, calendars, and conference/meeting rooms.Provides daily backups to prevent loss of data due to unintentional deletion or system failure.Provides and supports spam and virus protection.IT CouncilReviews and makes decisions related to this standard.University administrative, academic, and programmatic unitsComply with the requirements of this security standard.Establish priorities and timetables for decommissioning their own legacy email systems and transitioning their email users to the Institutional email system.Request waiver to this security standard.Faculty, staff, and student workers conducting business on behalf of the UniversityUnderstand and comply with this security standard.Inquire about and report concerns to the Division of Information Technology at itsupport@umd.edu(The prior text links to mailto:itsupport@umd.edu).Top(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport#top)︗ResourcesDIT Email Standard FAQs(The prior text links to https://itsupport.umd.edu/itsupport?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0015075)State of Maryland Updated on 05-23-2024 by Robert Hopkins4.0 - Updated on 04-27-2023 by Sussan Dehghan-Kavoosi(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport?id=kb_article_view&sys_kb_id=e1701d1f4716a9182d65a709536d4390)  3.0 - Updated on 04-21-2022 by Sussan Dehghan-Kavoosi(The prior text links to https://umd.service-now.com/itsupport?id=kb_article_view&sys_kb_id=39d8a760db941744f7ccfff31d96195a)            ︗Log in to Your Adobe Creative Cloud AccountArticle metadata.    Revised by Robert Hopkins   This article was updated •  4mo agoabout a year ago   This article has 2678 views. •  2678 Views   This article has average rating: 5 out of 5 stars • (*)(*)(*)(*)(*)  Adobe Creative Cloud is a web-based service that allows customers to download many of Adobe's most popular Creative Suite applications and cloud services via a cloud server. NOTE: You must be an active student, staff, or faculty member at UMD to use Adobe Creative Cloud.Open the Adobe Creative Cloud application from your computer, or visit the Adobe Account Login(The prior text links to https://adobeid-na1.services.adobe.com/renga-idprovider/pages/login?idp_flow_type=login_t2&client_id=adobedotcom2&callback=https%3A//ims-na1.adobelogin.com/ims/adobeid/adobedotcom2/AdobeID/token%3Fredirect_uri%3Dhttps%253A%252F%252Fwww.adobe.com%252F%2523from_ims%253Dtrue%2526old_hash%253D%2526api%253Dauthorize%26scope%3Dcreative_cloud%252CAdobeID%252Copenid%252Cgnav%252Cread_organizations%252Cadditional_info.projectedProductContext%252Csao.ACOM_CLOUD_STORAGE%252Csao.stock%252Csao.cce_private%252Cadditional_info.roles&denied_callback=https%3A//ims-na1.adobelogin.com/ims/denied/adobedotcom2%3Fredirect_uri%3Dhttps%253A%252F%252Fwww.adobe.com%252F%2523from_ims%253Dtrue%2526old_hash%253D%2526api%253Dauthorize%26response_type%3Dtoken&display=web_v2&locale=en_US&relay=53aa0466-e2d5-49e2-99a4-a812165b996f&flow=true&flow_type=token&idp_flow_type=login&s_account=adbadobenonacdcprod%2Cadbims) page using a web browser.Sign out of your Adobe ID in your browser and desktop application.Enter your @umd.edu (Enterprise ID), not your TERPmail, in the username field in the following format: DirectoryID@umd.edu. The Adobe Enterprise Login page may open. If the Adobe Enterprise Login page does not open, click Sign in with an Enterprise ID.If prompted to Choose an Account for Page, select Enterprise Account.The Central Authentication Service will open. Enter your Directory ID and Passphrase. Click Login.NOTE: If these steps do not direct you to log in to your Enterprise ID account, we recommend clearing your browser cache(The prior text links to https://itsupport.umd.edu/itsupport?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0013745).Copy Permalink︗Related ArticlesGeneral information about Adobe Creative Cloud (The prior text links to Learn more.(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/help/user/project/codeowners/index.md)                    Development        (The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker/-/blob/master/README.md?ref_type=heads#user-content-development)          Running        (The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker/-/blob/master/README.md?ref_type=heads#user-content-running)    README.md    3.67 KiB          Blame           Edit           Open in Web IDE . (The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker/-/edit/master/README.md?ref_type=heads)         (The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker/-/raw/master/README.md?ref_type=heads)   (The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker/-/raw/master/README.md?ref_type=heads&inline=false)   ︗NoneYou can fork this repo(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/derek/gpudocker/-/forks/new) and extend the Dockerfile with a machine that you have access to.  The machine does not need to have GPU resources locally to build and push the Docker image.If you are using the UMIACS Gitlab registry, then you can do something like the following (replace username with your UMIACS username).  Please note you will need to create a Gitlab personal access token(The prior text links to https://gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu/help/user/profile/personal_access_tokens.md) with the api scope and use this access token for the password when you run the login command.(fork the repo)git clone git@gitlab.umiacs.umd.edu:username/gpudocker.gitcd gpudockerdocker login -u username registry.umiacs.umd.edudocker build -t registry.umiacs.umd.edu/username/gpudocker .docker push registry.umiacs.umd.edu/username/gpudockerIf you are using a UMIACS supported system, Docker will not be installed. Please use Podman instead.  You can simply substitute podman in place of docker in the above commands, however you may also need to set up your storage.conf file.︗NoneYou can then download the image and run it on any cluster that we support Apptainer (formerly Singularity) on.First, choose a location with enough space for both the cache / tmp and the resulting image.  For this example, the image baseline requires 9.1GB of space for these two things, which makes your home directory not a good candidate.  We suggest using either a local or network scratch directory.export WORKDIR=/fs/nexus-scratch/usernameexport APPTAINER_CACHEDIR=${WORKDIR}/.cacheexport APPTAINER_TMPDIR=${WORKDIR}/.tmpmkdir -p $APPTAINER_CACHEDIRmkdir -p $APPTAINER_TMPDIRThen from this work directory (cd $WORKDIR), you can pull the image from your repository.  This will take a bit of time to pull the initial image the first time.apptainer pull gpudocker.sif docker://registry.umiacs.umd.edu/username/gpudockerNow you can run commands using this image.  Please note that you need to pass the --nv flag to apptainer to map the GPUs you have access to outside of the container.$ apptainer exec --nv gpudocker.sif nvidia-smiThu Apr  9 11:45:16 2020+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+| NVIDIA-SMI 440.44       Driver Version: 440.44       CUDA Version: 10.2     ||-------------------------------+----------------------+----------------------+| GPU  Name        Persistence-M| Bus-Id        Disp.A | Volatile Uncorr. ECC || Fan  Temp  Perf  Pwr:Usage/Cap|         Memory-Usage | GPU-Util  Compute M. ||===============================+======================+======================||   0  Quadro P6000        Off  | 00000000:04:00.0 Off |                  Off || 26%   24C    P8     7W / 250W |      0MiB / 24449MiB |      0%      Default |+-------------------------------+----------------------+----------------------++-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+| Processes:                                                       GPU Memory ||  GPU       PID   Type   Process name                             Usage      ||=============================================================================||  No running processes found                                                 |+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+$ apptainer exec --nv gpudocker.sif python3 -c 'import torch; print(torch.cuda.device_count())'1  〙
